webTitle: Lamb critical of CBI as Stewart is cleared

fields.headline: Lamb critical of CBI as Stewart is cleared
fields.trailText: Tim Lamb, in Lahore representing the ECB, has said that he thinks the Indian investigation into match-fixing conducted by the CBI should never have mentioned Alec Stewart and that such a thing would never have happened in this country.
fields.body:
Tim Lamb, in Lahore representing the ECB, has said that he thinks the Indian investigation into match-fixing conducted by the CBI should never have mentioned Alec Stewart and that such a thing would never have happened in this country.

Malcolm Gray, the President of the ICC, made an unusually blunt admission: 'Administrators had been slow, naive and wrong - whatever adjective you want to use - in not realising the problem earlier. So had the press,' he added. 'Any allegations cannot be taken lightly.' This did not quite tally with reports that Lord MacLaurin had declared that Stewart was 'absolutely clear'.

Not for the first time Lamb was required to clarify the position of the ECB. 'At the moment' - and he stressed those three words - 'the Stewart affair is closed. From what we have heard there is no basis for suspending him on unsubstantiated evidence. We feel we must accept his word.'

Explaining why the ECB had not set up their own investigation into the recent match-fixing allegations, like most other cricketing nations, he said that 'it was right and proper to put the matter in the hands of the Anti-Corruption Unit.' This is headed by Sir Paul Condon, who, according to Lamb supported the decision not to suspend Stewart. Lamb then said that it was 'wholly unjustified that the CBI should name Stewart. It would not have happened in the UK.'

Gray believed that the mood of the ICC over the match-fixing issue had moved from 'despondency' to 'quiet opti mism.' He acknowledged that the explosion of one-day matches had added to the problem but whether the ICC has the authority to check their proliferation is another matter. He also signalled that a World Championship of cricket might be established after the ICC's meeting in February, when a 10-year programme of Test cricket would be announced. There would also be discussion about a possible one-day championship.

On the home front Lamb was confident that sponsors would be found by the start of the new season. No less than three are required: for the Test series, the old NatWest Trophy and the Championship.

'We are not in panic mode,' he said. However any formal partnership with an online bookmaker was on hold since it was 'untimely' in the wake of the match-fixing scandals. He did not rule out such a partnership in the future.

Alistair Campbell and Stuart Carlisle hit half-centuries as Zimbabwe scored 232 for five on the opening day of the first Test at the Feroz Shah Kotla in New Delhi.

Campbell and Carlisle shared a 120-run stand for the third wicket after Zimbabwe, who won the toss, were reduced to 15 for two within the first hour.

Andy Flower then chipped in with 55 not out, sharing an unbroken sixth-wicket partnership of 77 with captain Heath Streak (25 not out). Javagal Srinath claimed three wickets but the Indians missed a fifth specialist bowler after opting to play an extra batsman in Venkatsai Laxman on the slow pitch.

Grant Flower went for a duck, bowled by a big inswinger from Srinath, who then forced Rennie to edge a catch to debutant wicket-keeper Vijay Dahiya. Carlisle and Campbell rebuilt the innings by staying together until just before the tea interval. Part-timer bowler Sachin Tendulkar broke the partnership, inducing Carlisle, who had made 58, to drive uppishly into the covers where Sunil Joshi took the catch. India struck two quick blows soon after tea to reduce Zimbabwe from a healthy 154 for three to 155 for five.

Srinath forced Campbell (70) to edge a catch to Laxman at second slip, while Joshi had Guy Whittall caught at gully by Rahul Dravid for no score.

New Zealand eneded the second day of the First Test against South Africa still 417 runs in arrears and with two wickets down. The tourists were 54 for two when bad light forced the close 8.4 overs early, with Craig Spearman on 14 and captain Stephen Fleming 10 not out.

Shaun Pollock declared South Africa's first innings closed on 471 for nine, leaving New Zealand to face 29 overs.

They suffered their first casualty in the seventh over when Mark Richardson was bowled by an inswinger from Allan Donald having hit three fours in the 19 balls he faced for his aggressive 23.

Donald needs only two more wickets to reach 300 test wickets.

Three overs later Matthew Sinclair, on one, edged a delivery from Pollock to Daryll Cullinan at first slip. South Africa resumed on 270 for three after overnight rain caused a delay of 90 minutes in the start of play.

Twenty-five minutes into the day's play Jacques Kallis, who was 153 not out overnight, was given out caught behind by wicketkeeper Adam Parore off left-arm seamer Shayne O'Connor for his career best score of 160. Television replays suggested that Kallis did not make contact with the ball as he lunged forward defensively.

fields.headline: Beckett goes to Hollywood
fields.standfirst: For the first time ever, the plays of Samuel Beckett are being filmed. All 19 of them. By the world's best directors - and Damien Hirst. Only one thing is certain - Godot won't turn up
fields.trailText: For the first time ever, the plays of Samuel Beckett are being filmed. All 19 of them. By the world's best directors - and Damien Hirst. Only one thing is certain - Godot won't turn up
fields.body:
In 1964, in New York, Samuel Beckett, the great poet of silence, met Buster Keaton, the great comic actor of the silent era. The playwright greatly admired Keaton's work and had reputedly watched his classic film, The General, more than half a dozen times. Keaton, on the other hand, was baffled by Beckett's plays and had previously turned down the role of Lucky in the first American stage production of Waiting for Godot. Perhaps because he had not worked in over 30 years and needed the money, the ageing actor agreed, without much enthusiasm, to play the principal role in a short film written by Beckett called, simply, Film.

Though, as Anthony Cronin puts it in his Beckett biography, The Last Modernist, there was an 'obvious affinity between the expressionless, enigmatic actor and the expressionless, enigmatic writer', their initial meeting was an unmitigated disaster. Beckett arrived at Keaton's hotel, to find him watching a baseball game and drinking beer. Cronin takes up the story: 'Beckett, finding himself in the unusual position of having to make the running, ventured a few general words about his admiration for Keaton's work. When these petered out, everybody sat in silence while Keaton, seemingly unperturbed - though because of his famous mask, nobody could be sure - continued to drink his beer and watch the game. Every now and then Beckett, almost like somebody meeting Samuel Beckett for the first time, would venture a few words, to which Keaton would respond at best in monosyllables.' In a sentence that could easily pass for a stage direction from a Beckett play, Cronin concludes: 'The minutes passed, the situation seemed to get more harrowing and hopeless and the silences to become more interminable.'

And yet, despite the author's misgivings and the actor's bewilderment, the almost silent Film - Keaton's character, O, utters only one word, a whispered 'Sssh!' - was shot over three weeks in the sweltering heat of a New York summer. Its typically Beckettian theme concerns a man who attempts to achieve a state of non-being by fleeing from the perception of others. Keaton's stone face, which had formerly been his cinematic signature, is glimpsed only once in the final scene when he awakes from a short sleep to find himself surprised by the camera. Film, because of its brevity and its obtuse subject matter, proved almost impossible to market though, ironically, it did play as part of a Keaton season in the following year's New York Film Festival where it was greeted with what Cronin calls 'a resentful silence' that was broken by the chorus of loud booing that accompanied the credits. It has seldom been shown since and predictably has attained cult status among both Beckett and Keaton aficionados. Until now, too, Beckett's more famous dramatic works, including the epochal Waiting for Godot, have resisted the often uneasy journey from the stage to the screen, not least because of the legendary protectiveness of the Beckett estate - in effect his nephew, Edward.

A few years back, a startling stage production of Footfalls, directed by Deborah Warner and starring Fiona Shaw, was pulled after only two performances because it contravened the letter of Beckett's always precise stage directions. It seems surprising, then, that the estate has agreed to allow the filming of all 19 Beckett plays, a project that is currently nearing completion under the guiding hand of Michael Colgan, artistic director of Dublin's Gate Theatre and long-time Beckett devotee. The results, funded by the Irish state broadcasting company, RTE, to the tune of £4.5million, will be screened at a special gala event in Dublin next spring, and broadcast later on Channel 4.

Thus far, Colgan and his co-producer, Alan Maloney, have attracted cinema directors of the calibre of Neil Jordan, who has employed Julianne Moore's mouth to fill the screen for the duration of Not I, and Anthony Minghella, who has filmed Play. More intriguing still is the teaming of director David Mamet with Harold Pinter in an acting role, alongside the late Sir John Gielgud, in Catastrophe. 'That's an exciting prospect,' enthuses Colgan, 'because you could argue that without Beckett, Pinter would not have written what he did in the way that he did, and likewise, without Pinter, Mamet's work as we know it would not have existed. There's a definite and definable lineage there.'

Other directors include Conor McPherson, writer of The Weir, who has chosen Endgame, Michael Lindsay-Hogg who is currently filming Waiting for Godot on location in the Irish border town of Castleblaney, and Atom Egoyan, who has finished Krapp's Last Tape, featuring John Hurt in a reprise of the role that brought in packed houses in a recent West End run.

In a brave move that may cause further trepidation to Beckett purists, Colgan has also employed younger directors with neither a theatre nor writing background, including Dubliner, Damien O'Donnell, who made his name with East Is East, and 26-year-old guerrilla filmmaker Enda Hughes, best known for his low-budget, high-concept first feature, The Eliminator. 'The Beckett estate has been incredibly supportive throughout,' says Colgan. 'Samuel Beckett's nephew, Edward, saw Damien's film of What Where and thought it had more of an impact than it ever had on stage.'

Damien Hirst, whose previous excursions into film have included a Blur video, has been chosen to direct Breath, a 45-second piece featuring no visible characters, a rubbish-strewn landscape, amplified breathing and a single cry, which will no doubt be read by many of his detractors as an unconscious comment on the current state of Young British Art.

'It is important to understand from the outset that we are making films and not versions of the plays,' stresses Colgan, the only director in the world to have staged all 19 plays together, first in Dublin in 1991, and last year at the Barbican's Beckett Festival. 'That said, though, there are strict rules governing the project: the stage instructions remain sacrosanct, and there can be no gender bending of characters or cutting of lines. We have to be true to the spirit of Beckett who, of course, was the most careful writer in the world. He was also, though, a very imagistic writer. Even if they don't remember the name of the plays, people tend to remember the images - those guys in the sacks, the people buried up to their necks, the characters in the dustbins. He created simple, sparse, strong images that stick in the mind. I think we need people of the calibre of Neil Jordan or David Mamet to interpret those images for a wider audience because Beckett is unique among modern writers in that he is both monumental but also incredibly neglected.'

Anthony Minghella was also drawn to the idea of Beckett's work reaching a wider, newer audience through the medium of film. Like Atom Egoyan, he cites the playwright as his biggest formative influence. 'I jumped at the chance to do Breath because it was the first piece I ever directed back when I was a member of Hull University's drama department in 1976. I was obsessed by the great man for five or six years in my early twenties. I'm sure there are students of mine who can recall being tormented by my Beckett quizzes. I was a total Beckett anorak back then. A lot of what I learnt about dramatic writing came from that period of entrancement.' Play features the heads of three figures, played by Kristin Scott Thomas, Juliet Stevenson and Alan Rickman, protruding from three identical grey urns, their 'faces so lost to age', Beckett wrote in his directions, 'as to seem almost part of the urns'. Minghella has taken the liberty of setting the three principals amid a host of other mute, urn-imprisoned characters in a semi-hallucinatory landscape that could be either post-apocalyptic or purgatorial. They each recite the banal details of various past encounters and indiscretions in rapid-fire, but toneless, salvoes of speech, which, in places, Minghella has created from the splicing together of several different takes.

'I wanted to create a cubist film,' he says, 'where the size and shape is constantly changing, where the audience's attention is constantly drawn to the mechanisms of film. You can hear every camera movement, every focus pull. You are forced to feel the presence of the camera, like you would feel the stage light that shines on them when they speak in a theatrical production.'

It is this kind of poetic fidelity that also illuminates Enda Hughes's remarkable reading of Act Without Words II. Here, the 'frieze effect' stipulated by Beckett to frame the 'low narrow platform at back of stage, violently lit in its entire length' has become the borders of a Cinemascope film strip, grainy and brightly flickering. Against this created background, the two actors have been filmed movement by movement, one frame at a time, to produce a cinematic effect akin to human animation.

'Beckett was so concerned with form that I think he would have employed the mechanics of film in the same inventive way that he employed lighting and the stage itself, as presences, even characters in the drama. That's what I wanted to try and do myself.'

Given that Hughes is from the post-Spielberg rather than post-Beckett school of directors, I wondered if he had been initially awed by the great man's reputation. 'Not really. I had never studied the plays but I'd seen a few performed when I was growing up and instinctively connected with his view of the world which is pessimistic and strangely humorous. He's certainly a presence, though. It's as if he's looking over your shoulder while you work. All the time, I kept thinking, would he have liked this? That was really the only guiding principle, alongside trying to be true to the essence of the work.'

In Hughes's film, the spirits of Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin loom large also, as the two characters emerge from their sacks to mime the mundane rituals of daily life, one stoically and sadly, the other jauntily and with exaggerated vigour. In playing with the conventions of both Beckett and silent film, Hughes has created a truly contemporary take on both. I think Sam - and Buster - would have approved.

webTitle: No beer, no birds, no beaches

fields.headline: No beer, no birds, no beaches
fields.trailText: On Tour James Davis on the harsh realities of following England around Pakistan.
fields.body:
Over the centuries any number of armies have visited Pakistan but few have come for the same reasons or in such depleted numbers as the Barmy Army.

It is in fact more of a regiment than an army, numbering only about 50. They have come out for the First Test at the rather intimidatingly named Colonel Gadaffi Stadium in Lahore. The Pakistan campaign is, unsurprisingly, not as popular as sorties to Australia, South Africa or the West Indies. It perhaps lacks some of the traditional prerequisites for a truly enjoyable Barmy Army touring experience - no booze, birds or beaches.

The Islamic Republic of Pakistan is officially a dry country, although non-Muslims can obtain a special 'liquor permit' that allows the holder to drink a prescribed amount of alcohol (nine litres a month is all you are allowed). As the Barmy Army have quickly found out this is not essential and booze is fairly readily available in luxury hotels and an 'International Club' that is located conveniently close to the ground in Lahore. It has even been known for a few of the contingent to pop down there for 'just the one' during the lunch interval. Alcohol can also be found in parts of other cities, usually the small Christian Quarters. There it is a case of dark alleys, long waits and black bags to hide the offending hooch - all quite an effort for a beer.

Pakistan is a very male-dominated society where the sexes are segregated and women are usually covered from head to toe. This is the case particularly in the rural areas where women rarely venture outside the house, unless accompanied by a male relative. Even in Lahore, a fairly liberal city, buses have separate sections for men and for women. Barmy Army troops who jump on to the women's section are likely to receive very strange looks from the ladies and angry stares from their husbands who occupy the back seats.

The beach has been an integral part of all previous Barmy Army tours - a place to relax between matches. There are a couple of problems with Pakistan and its beaches; they are about 1,500km away, which means a 20-hour train journey from Lahore, and a group of semi-naked Westerners would probably cause a riot.

However, Pakistan has other attractions that more than make up for the lack of beaches. It has some of the most spectacular scenery you could wish to see, including K2, the world's second highest mountain, vast empty deserts and one of the most impressive rivers in the world, the Indus. There are numerous historical sites and buildings throughout Pakistan and the bazaars in Lahore, Rawalpindi and Peshawar are wonderful and chaotic.

Religion will play a more prominent role than on any other of the Barmy Army's jaunts. The intervals in the matches are sometimes geared towards the time of prayers and it is common to see sections of the crowd laying down mats and facing Mecca. As an English spectator you also receive your fair share of advice from well-meaning Pakistanis worried about your after-life prospects in eternal damnation.

Religion will become even more significant in the final two Tests as Ramadan begins on 27 November. This means it will suddenly become very difficult to find any food or water between sunrise and sunset. A whole 12 hours without any sustenance in a sweltering Karachi is not the most appealing prospect.

Most of the Barmy Army are heading home after the first Test. The prospect of no food or water for long periods of time and a 10-day wait until the second Test has proved too much. As one supporter succinctly put it, 'I'd rather stick pins in my eyes for two weeks - lots more fun than 10 nights waiting for Faisalabad'. Sri Lanka also beckons in February and the lure of beer and beaches appeals more to England's foot soldiers.

fields.headline: Even the umpires have excelled
fields.trailText: England's captain on their last Pakistan tour gives his verdict on the first Test so far
fields.body:
What a great start. Short of winning in Lahore, England have achieved just about everything they could have hoped for in the first Test with yesterday's performance building on the good work of the opening three days.

It's been hard to fault Nasser Hussain's tactics and I was impressed with the way his team stuck to their game plan with the bat, and then again in the field when Pakistan looked like getting on top.

At 199 for two, it would have been easy for England to ease off yesterday and accept that the game was over as a contest, but the patience and persistence that earned them that big total also pushed Pakistan to the brink of following on.

Nasser kept at the home batsmen all day, never allowing the game to drift. He switched his attack around, giving the quick men short bursts and was backed up with some fine bowling, particularly from Craig White.

In my day, having Ian Botham in the team was like playing with 12 men and it's beginning to look as though England have finally found another all-rounder who is worthy of the name at this level.

White's ability to reverse swing the ball is invaluable in Pakistan - even more so on this slow wicket - and he gets it through at a good pace. It was interesting to see Abdur Razzaq facing Darren Gough without a helmet and then calling for one when White came on - poor old Goughie will take a while to live that one down in the dressing room.

The only disappointment for England so far has been the bowling of Ian Salisbury but let's not forget Mushtaq Ahmed also failed to take a wicket and both leg-spinners will benefit from a quicker surface. With White in such good form, I'll be surprised if England don't persist with two spinners in the next Test.

On a pitch where survival as a batsman was not too difficult after the first half- hour or so it was always going to be hard work to force a result and my only criticism is that we might have batted on too long on the third morning.

I'd have liked to have seen the Pakistan openers in for half an hour before lunch. After more than two days in the field, having to bat after a 10-minute break between innings - instead of the extended lunch break - would not have been welcomed, and as a batsman it's very hard to focus on anything other than survival in such a short session.

But it's understandable that Nasser strayed on the side of caution and wanted to make absolutely sure there was no way back into the game for Pakistan. A touring side are always at their most vulnerable in the first Test, and to go one-down in a three-match series gives you very little room for manoeuvre.

Finally, as for some reason everyone seems very interested in what I think about umpiring in Pakistan, I have to say so far it's been excellent.

Andy Caddick might disagree after having a close one turned down yesterday morning, and I might be biased, but I think it is always better for the officials to err on the side of the batsmen and it's good to see umpire Riazuddin has not been swayed or intimidated by the appeals of either side.

Of course, now we have one neutral umpire in Tests, it helps the local official to have someone of the stature of Darrell Hair at the other end.

fields.headline: White captures the mood
fields.standfirst: England fail to force the follow-on but after four days of the First Test there is much cause for optimism
fields.trailText: England fail to force the follow-on but after four days of the First Test there is much cause for optimism, writes Vic Marks.
fields.body:
The England camp was disappointed last night. But when you consider that their disappointment stemmed from their inability to force Pakistan to follow on, it revealed how far the aspirations of the touring party have risen over the last four days. As soon as Yousuf Youhana flicked Andy Caddick down to long leg to take the score to 281 for eight the chances of England winning this Test plummeted.

Since Youhana and his stubborn partner Saqlain Mushtaq then proceeded to bat out the last hour those chances have receded further. A draw seems inevitable.

Even so this has been a sterling effort by the England side. They had one significant slice of luck when they won the toss but since that first morning they have dominated a game that has confounded pundits and players alike.

Beforehand the general assumption was that this match would be over in four days. Well, so far 18 wickets have fallen.

The ball has turned but not venomously. The pitch generates plenty of dust yet refuses to misbehave for seamers who might have anticipated uneven bounce by now. Instead the ball doubles declutches on landing before waiting conveniently for the bat to be laid upon it. The fin ger-spinners have toiled and eventually been rewarded. The two main wrist spinners have so far propelled 64 overs without taking a wicket. The pitch is too slow for them to prosper. In any case neither Mushtaq Ahmed nor Ian Salisbury have bowled well.

England were valiant if not flawless in the field as the home side moved from 119-2 to 333-8. The greatest excitement came when Pakistan lost their eighth wicket with eight runs still required to save the follow-on but Saqlain stood firm.

Craig White was again outstanding - easily the most penetrative and the most used of the pace-bowlers. Now there are no worries about his temperament, only his body. At different times he felt a twinge in his dodgy hamstring and a burning sensation between his shoulderblades but he soldiered on and was able to reverse-swing the ball to far greater effect than his colleagues. Ashley Giles's stamina and control were admirable in his second Test match. For Pakistan Youhana, the fifth non-Muslim to represent them, calmly shepherded his side past 280, batting four hours for his unbeaten 77.

For most of the morning session the prospect of being able to enforce the follow-on seemed remote. Nasser Hussain has used five bowlers within the first hour and none of them caused any alarm for Inzamam and Salim Elahi. Inzamam's judgment of length reminded us why he's a batsman close to genius despite his lumbering brain. Maybe that's why he's allowed to spend most of Pakistan's training sessions in a comfy wicker chair. He soon seized upon two fractionally short deliveries from Giles and despatched them to the mid-wicket boundary. Elahi was less certain but soon surpassed his highest Test score, a modest 17.

They had two moments of concern. Caddick's first ball delivered after Giles and Salisbury had shared seven overs from the pavilion end thudded into Inzamam's front pad. This prompted a very good shout but umpire Riazzudin kept his finger down as he had done throughout the English innings. Caddick refrained from sharing his obvious frustration.

Soon after Elahi, facing Giles, popped a catch towards silly point off the face of his bat. But Hussain was so close and so intent on unnerving the batsman by his proximity that he could not hold on to the ball. Hussain as ever was prominent, taking time to set the field meticulously and to feel his back which is obviously misbehaving. He was having treatment when the first of a flurry of wickets fell just before lunch (interestingly Graham Thorpe took charge in his absence). First Elahi dragged an attempted drive against White onto his stumps; then the prized wicket of Inzamam was taken by Giles. The flighted delivery outside leg stump turned sharply, brushed Inzamam's back pad before hitting the wicket. White then snapped up the 18-year-old debutant Qaiser Abbas who drove away from his body to give a simple catch to Graeme Hick in the gully and Pakistan were rocking.

After the break Moin Khan scurried around for 17 runs until he was surprised - like the rest of us - when umpire Riazzudin raised his finger in response to an lbw shout from Caddick. Abdur Razzaq also looked aggrieved to be given lbw padding up by umpire Hair 15 overs later but if he studies the replay of White's in-swinging delivery he will discover that he and not Hair made the misjudgment. When Wasim Akram clipped an innocuous delivery from Giles straight into the hands of White at short mid-wicket in the next over saving the follow-on was no longer a formality.

Four runs were still needed at the tea interval but Saqlain, Pakistan's hero in this match was resolute while Youhana remained utterly secure. Indeed England rarely threatened to take a wicket in the final session of 90 minutes. The advent of the new ball did nothing to enhance the penetration of their attack.

Yet this had been a spir ited performance by England; they never lost their zest in the field and the pace-bowlers kept running in alongside Giles, refusing to be cowed by such an unresponsive surface. One of them, Darren Gough, may be miffed that he was given only 10 overs in the day but of greater concern was the bowling of Salisbury.

He was allowed only 11 overs yesterday on a pitch where the ball was turning, albeit very slowly, and five of those were after the follow-on was saved and the day was creeping to a close. Hussain felt compelled to position fielders at deep point and deep mid-wicket whenever Salisbury was bowling to guard against the bad ball. This restricted his attacking option and prevented him from building up any pressure since so many easy singles were available. With Salisbury untrustworthy England's tour party looks unbalanced. Another spinning alternative would be handy (goodness knows who? One from the old triumvirate of Croft, Such or Tufnell, I suppose). Otherwise the first four days of Test cricket in Pakistan have been unusually heartening.

fields.headline: Former college head flays 'mediocre' Oxford
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Oxford University is set to lose its reputation as one of the world's finest academic institutions because of mediocre standards, outdated traditions and byzantine bureaucracy, according to one of Britain's leading economists and business experts.
fields.body:
Oxford University is set to lose its reputation as one of the world's finest academic institutions because of mediocre standards, outdated traditions and byzantine bureaucracy, according to one of Britain's leading economists and business experts.

John Kay, who resigned last year as the head of Oxford's Said Business School, warned that, if the decline continued, it would soon be unable to compete in the international arena with major American colleges such as Harvard and Stanford. In an article for next month's Prospect magazine, Kay claims Oxford is 'sliding gradually into mediocrity'.

Although he admits league tables can be unreliable, he goes on to say: 'There is no doubt that Oxford is losing its pre-eminence among British academic institutions and that these in turn are falling behind the top US schools.'

Oxford slipped to third place behind Cambridge and Imperial College, London, in this year's performance table.

The latest row to rock Oxford follows the 'Laura Spence Affair' earlier this year, when a schoolgirl from a North-East comprehensive won a place at Harvard after being turned down by Oxford to study medicine. Chancellor Gordon Brown accused the university of discriminating against pupils from state schools. The university is currently part of a parliamentary inquiry into access and elitism in higher education.

Kay attributes Oxford's decline to its 'morass of committees' run by academics untrained in management or business which have responsibility for all decision-making. He also says its egalitarian salary structure makes it impossible to attract top-international academics.

Barry Sheerman, chair of the Education Select Committee, which has just returned from visiting six leading universities in the United States, said: 'I have the deepest respect for John Kay. If he has flagged up these problems, we should take them very seriously indeed.'

Kay became director of Oxford's prestigious business school in 1996, which was founded after a gift of £20m from Syrian-born businessman Wafic Said. Kay has not commented on his resignation from the school last June. But it was known at the time that he believed salary restrictions meant he was unable to attract top-class talent to rival Oxford's international competitors.

A university spokesman said: 'There is no doubt that Oxford remains a pre-eminent world-class university.' He added that reforms to the Oxford system since Kay resigned made his comments inaccurate and out of date.

Professor Alan Ryan, Warden of New College, Oxford, said: 'He must be furious about not being able to bring his vision to fruition and in his position I would be pretty fed up. But I still believe that if you want a good university education, especially in the liberal arts, then Oxford can do it better than anyone in the world.'

fields.bodyText: Oxford University is set to lose its reputation as one of the world's finest academic institutions because of mediocre standards, outdated traditions and byzantine bureaucracy, according to one of Britain's leading economists and business experts. John Kay, who resigned last year as the head of Oxford's Said Business School, warned that, if the decline continued, it would soon be unable to compete in the international arena with major American colleges such as Harvard and Stanford. In an article for next month's Prospect magazine, Kay claims Oxford is 'sliding gradually into mediocrity'. Although he admits league tables can be unreliable, he goes on to say: 'There is no doubt that Oxford is losing its pre-eminence among British academic institutions and that these in turn are falling behind the top US schools.' Oxford slipped to third place behind Cambridge and Imperial College, London, in this year's performance table. The latest row to rock Oxford follows the 'Laura Spence Affair' earlier this year, when a schoolgirl from a North-East comprehensive won a place at Harvard after being turned down by Oxford to study medicine. Chancellor Gordon Brown accused the university of discriminating against pupils from state schools. The university is currently part of a parliamentary inquiry into access and elitism in higher education. Kay attributes Oxford's decline to its 'morass of committees' run by academics untrained in management or business which have responsibility for all decision-making. He also says its egalitarian salary structure makes it impossible to attract top-international academics. Barry Sheerman, chair of the Education Select Committee, which has just returned from visiting six leading universities in the United States, said: 'I have the deepest respect for John Kay. If he has flagged up these problems, we should take them very seriously indeed.' Kay became director of Oxford's prestigious business school in 1996, which was founded after a gift of £20m from Syrian-born businessman Wafic Said. Kay has not commented on his resignation from the school last June. But it was known at the time that he believed salary restrictions meant he was unable to attract top-class talent to rival Oxford's international competitors. A university spokesman said: 'There is no doubt that Oxford remains a pre-eminent world-class university.' He added that reforms to the Oxford system since Kay resigned made his comments inaccurate and out of date. Professor Alan Ryan, Warden of New College, Oxford, said: 'He must be furious about not being able to bring his vision to fruition and in his position I would be pretty fed up. But I still believe that if you want a good university education, especially in the liberal arts, then Oxford can do it better than anyone in the world.' martin.bright@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Vegas welcomes the geeks
fields.standfirst: It's a gamblers' paradise - that's why the US computer trade fair feels at home here, reports  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: It's a gamblers' paradise - that's why the US computer trade fair feels at home here, reports Faisal Islam
fields.body:
Taxi drivers in Las Vegas loathe Comdex. The high-earning geek set who converge upon the gambling oasis for their annual industry shindig are not the strongest of tippers. The drivers have a joke about the conference attendees.

'Comdex people come here with $20 and one white shirt and don't change either all week,' said John Di Lamo, a taxi driver. He reels off examples of stingy techies, usually at the show on expenses. One young exec negotiated a $6 million deal in the back of the cab but tipped him just 80 cents.

Volatility in the value of their share options may partly explain such thriftiness - at one point during the show, the Nasdaq index slipped below 3,000 points.

But the vicissitudes of stock markets have done little to quell enthusiasm among delegates. Last year dotcoms held centre stage as the starting guns fired on an astonishing five-month rally. Subsequent experience suggests that some investors would have had a better return from the slot machines at Caesar's Palace.

The racy bets this year were on wireless and networking technologies, and preferably combinations of the two.

Perhaps the recent addition of a half-size Eiffel Tower to Las Vegas's casino district helped focus US companies on wireless technologies traditionally dominated by Europe. The busiest booths sported an array of such mobile gadgetry. Those promoting Palm Pilots, the similar Handspring Visor, and Ericsson mobile phones, were packed.

Delegates, all employed in the technology sector, were easily worked into a lather over the prospect of winning T-shirts, baseball caps and pens. Surely their share options haven't fallen that far?

At times it felt more like a university freshers' fair than the foremost convention of America's most important industry.

But there is one major difference - money, and stacks of it. Las Vegas is the perfect location for the meeting of an industry which, despite recent turbulence, is awash with cash. Limousines seemed more numerous than taxis. The Pyramids, the Arc de Triomphe, the Rialto Bridge, volcanos, sharks, tigers and lions were all there. EDS, the software services company, spent $6 million on its Comdex presence. 'The digital economy rocks!' shouted its booth. EDS tried to prove this by hiring out pop diva Macy Gray. She sang to assorted minions of the new economy in a converted hangar at Las Vegas airport.

A performance which can only be described as 'National Semiconductor - the musical' in the Comdex north hall took up this theme. One song featured lyrics such as 'Our market is growing so fast/The future is here to last, at Nat-ion-aal' and 'from personal devices to TV news/National is making it to use/we're freeing people from the PC'.

This 'tyranny' of the personal computer was a recurring theme during the conference. In part this reflects the Microsoft factor - it is the Manchester United of the tech world: disliked by hardcore geeks but nonetheless extremely successful.

Historically, some conflicts have been about land and others about ideology but for these guys it boils down to the thorny issue of where you store your 'apps' - either locally on a PC, or on a central device accessed by more nimble network computers.

The clearest manifestation of this was Microsoft's escalation of the war of words with Oracle and its charismatic chief executive, Larry Ellison.

'Larry's been talking about ideas that have gone nowhere for years. How long has he been talking about the [network computer]? Six years, seven years? Where did it go? Nowhere,' said Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive.

'You're considered a dead company if you write applications for the PC,' said Ellison, before referring to Microsoft's new Tablet PC concept as irrelevant 'pen computing'. He also hinted that he may take on Bill Clinton after his presidential term finishes in January.

But Microsoft spin-meisters had the best of it. They handed out mugs to people attending Ellison's speech, which claimed that Oracle salesman offer a $1m discount when trying to secure business from Microsoft customers.

'When Oracle salesman pitches $5m of overpriced software, simply glance at the mug,' it reads. 'Oracle salesman spots mug, offers 20 per cent discount.'

If that upset Ellison, then he was delighted to hear that he may be the model for a character in the forthcoming Charlie's Angels movie. Tim Curry plays a wealthy tech-exec with a penchant for fast cars and Japanese-style houses. Ellison only expressed disappointment that action star Steven Seagal wasn't playing 'him'.

Back at the exhibition, film imagery was being used extensively to inject an air of excitement into attempts to sell graphics cards, DVD drives and even earphones.

Canadian graphics company ATI used a dialogue between mocked-up characters from The Matrix to promote a graphics chip for laptops.

'It's incredible, it's as if there's no limit to ATI innovation,' said the Keanu Reeves lookalike. 'This is my reality now. Mobius gives me mobility.'

But he can't go - oh, no - on the orders of the leather-clad female character. 'You can't leave yet,' she intercedes, because 'it's time for you to experience TV Wonder USB'.

Hitachi's attempts at entertainment were especially awful, drowning out any possibility of conversation in neighbouring stands. Someone called Bob Kolyer, a dead ringer for magician David Copperfield, became unfeasibly excited about promoting DVD-Ram technology from his 'catwalk' stage. 'Don't go away, we will be showing nothing but the sexiest most beautiful technology you can ever use,' he said.

Scantily clad, pouting models then strode around the catwalk showing off their diskettes, hard-drives, and digicams.

They weren't the only ones. Sybersay, a Californian purveyor of 'state-of-the-ear' technology, crammed in four Barbarella lookalikes, resplendent in metallic blue jumpsuits, to show off earphones at their booth.

'In the south hall - that's the billion dollar boy's club where they have the beautiful, almost naked ladies,' said Michael McLean of Advanced Scientific Corporation, one of the smaller exhibitors whose booth was in the north hall.

Perhaps unsurprising then, given such marketing methods, that Adultdex 2000 should spring up in parallel to Comdex. Taking place on the 'same days as Comdex, [but] later hours!' that event promised 'the latest in multimedia, video, DVD, internet, and video conferencing'. The fliers were perhaps intended to confuse jet-lagged, sleep-deprived techies. They certainly were a reminder of the pivotal role of pornography in the commercialisation of new media, from VHS cassettes to satellite TV and the internet.

The sprawling mass of over-promotion and hyperbole that is Comdex is contradictory in itself. Given the vision of driving purchasing and marketing on to the net, surely mass meetings such as Comdex will be unnecessary? There are clearly other compelling reasons for its 200,000 delegates to visit. 'It's the biggest adult toy store you have ever been in,' said McLean. 'I'll be back next year and it will be even wilder.'

John Di Lamo, the taxi driver, offered a contrary view: 'It's quite scary that our entire economy is in these guys' hands.' He may have a point.

For five days, no one sleeps

It is the biggest roadshow on earth. A giant movable feast dedicated to the biggest, sexiest, technologies around. At this time every year more than 2,300 of the world's largest companies, including the likes of Compaq, Cisco, Dell, Eastman Kodak, Microsoft and Nokia, descend on Las Vegas to unveil their latest products and strut their stuff. A company's share price can soar on a slick presentation, often made to a live audience of 10,000 and simultaneously webcast around the world.

More than 200,000 movers and shakers of the IT world pour into the gambling mecca and for five days no one sleeps. It is not unusual for conferences to start at seven in the evening while the partying goes on until dawn. The clamour to attend the 'keynote' address which starts the event - this year given by Bill Gates - has people queuing down the strip. Much of the after-hours action takes place in three of Vegas's biggest hotels - the Venetian, the MGM Grand and the Hilton, which are booked up years in advance. Similarly, during Comdex week only the IT posse can get into the most upmarket restaurants such as Tsunami, renowned for its sushi.

During the day, companies get to sell themselves at the Las Vegas Convention Centre and the Sands Expo and Convention Centre. Booths at the conference can be up to 10,000 square feet. For this year's event, Comdex's organiser, Key3Media, sold more than one million square feet of space.

And Comdex has its eyes on world dominance. There are now 17 Comdex-branded events in 12 countries, including Brazil and Germany. The Comdex events accounted for nearly 40 per cent of the $251 million of revenue generated by Key3Media last year.

The event organiser is so flushed with its own success that this year it decided to hold its own exclusive party. Numerous politicians, and New York Stock Exchange boss Richard Grasso, turned up to help the company celebrate its good fortune. How long before Comdex comes over here?

webTitle: Row over passport for Labour's Dome donor

fields.headline: Day of destiny for the brothers who courted Blair
fields.standfirst: Billionaire Hinduja brothers who helped bail out the Dome face crucial decision on allegations that could lead to extradition to India
fields.trailText: An Indian billionaire at the centre of a corruption scandal was courted by Tony Blair's Government and given citizenship here after his family donated £1m to help bail out the Millennium Dome, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
An Indian billionaire at the centre of a corruption scandal was courted by Tony Blair's Government and given citizenship here after his family donated £1m to help bail out the Millennium Dome, The Observer can reveal.

Srichand Hinduja, who will learn tomorrow whether he and two of his brothers will face trial in India over claims that they took £7m in kickbacks from an Indian arms deal, was turned down for British citizenship by the Conservatives in 1990. The brothers are currently trying to buy Express newspapers.

Home Secretary Jack Straw approved Srichand Hinduja's application for a British passport last September, despite the fact that he and his family were at the centre of investigations by Indian police into one of the country's biggest corruption scandals. A year earlier the Hindujas had agreed to pump funds into the Dome's Faith Zone.

Senior sources at India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), the Indian equivalent of the FBI, believe it is 'very likely' that an Indian court will charge the Hinduja brothers with taking illegal commission as part of a controversial arms deal in 1986.

If that happens, Indian prosecutors have confirmed they will move swiftly to extradite the Hindujas, the leading members of Britain's wealthiest Asian family, igniting a political scandal for Blair's government.

Such a turn of events would be embarrassing for Blair as the Hindujas have built up close links with New Labour.

The Hindujas have insisted they volunteered to help fund the Dome and that no Minister 'solicited' them for money. But the brothers visited Peter Mandelson in October 1998 when he was Trade Secretary and in charge of the Dome.

Mandelson claimed the meeting was about 'Indo-British relations', although he has admitted the Dome was referred to at the end.

Mandelson is also known to have met the Hindujas several times when he was Minister without portfolio and one source recalls a dinner Blair and Mandelson had at Hinduja's central London home before the election.

Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat spokesman on the Dome, said: 'It certainly seems eyebrow-raising that somebody who the Tories had turned down for a British passport should be given one so quickly by Labour. Questions have to be asked if it was given as a thank you for trying to bail out the Dome.'

Four days after Srichand Hinduja became a British citizen, the Hindujas funded a reception at their London offices in honour of the Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine. Also praised at the event was Leicester MP Keith Vaz, who had become Britain's first Asian Minister. Mandelson and trade secretary Stephen Byers were also present.

Vaz, a minister in the Foreign Office, is one of the Hindujas' closest political associates. As a backbencher he regularly visited their London HQ and attends many of their functions. When shadow trade and industry spokesman Christopher Chopeasked a parliamentary question on the Hindujas last year, he received a call from Vaz asking what he was up to. But despite close relations with Labour, recent events suggest Downing Street is trying to distance the Blairs from the Hindujas.

The Prime Minister was invited to the Hindujas' Diwali party last month, but declined. A year earlier, the Prime Minister and his wife were star guests at the Hindujas' extravagant Diwali party in North London. Photos of Cherie dressed in a traditional Indian outfit were published around the world.

At the time the Hindujas and Downing Street were happy for the press to think the £1,000 silk embroidered kameez which Cherie wore was a gift from the Hindujas.

However, last week Cherie Blair's press secretary denied the Prime Minister's wife had taken a gift from the Hindujas. 'They got it wrong,' said Fiona Millar. 'They offered her an outfit. But she didn't want it and it went to charity.'

Moves to distance the Government from the Hindujas follow an investigation into a controversial £211m arms contract between the Indian government and Swedish defence company Bofors in 1986. Last month, India's CBI filed a charge-sheet setting out claims against the Hindujas and accusing them of a part in a 'criminal conspiracy'.

The main allegation is that the three brothers - Gopichand, Srichand and Swiss-based Prakash - used their influence with the late Indian prime minister Rajiv Ghandi to secure a contract for howitzers with the Swedish firm and illegally took more than £7m in commission.

After a long battle with the Hindujas, the CBI finally got access to details of their Swiss bank accounts, which showed that Bofors paid more than £7m into secret accounts owned by McIntyre Corporation - a Hinduja front company based in Panama.

The Hindujas denied any wrongdoing, claiming the £7m was not related to any arms deal and saying they are the victims of a vendetta. A spokesman said: 'The brothers have consistently co-operated in all respects with the authorities in both Switzerland and India and will continue to do so in the future.'

webTitle: Livingstone: my Tube war with Labour

fields.headline: Livingstone: my Tube war with Labour
fields.standfirst: In an echo of his battles with Thatcher, London's mayor is taking on the Government over privatisation
fields.trailText: I will be just like old times. Ken Livingstone has threatened to take the Government to court this week unless it hands over confidential papers about privatisation of the London Underground.
fields.body:
I will be just like old times. Ken Livingstone has threatened to take the Government to court this week unless it hands over confidential papers about privatisation of the London Underground.

The showdown will revive memories of Livingstone's legendary legal tussles with Margaret Thatcher's administration when he led the Greater London Council - only this time pitting him against a Labour Government.

The London Mayor has warned Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott that he expects the commercially sensitive documents, detailing the bids from private companies for aspects of the Tube, to be handed to his new transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, when they are received by the Government tomorrow.

'If Bob Kiley isn't given copies of the best and final bids next week, and the public sector comparator, we will go to court,' he told The Observer .

'It is completely unreasonable to expect the man who is about to become responsible for running the system not to have sight of and be able to give advice based on this information. If it remains confidential, it doesn't come to me.

'Why don't they want to give this out? Is it because the comparator [with the public sector] is full of holes and it's not a valid comparison?'

Minister for London Keith Hill told the Commons last week that Kiley had already received substantial information, but giving him commercially sensitive details about the bids 'could risk damaging the public sector position and prevent us from achieving best value'.

Livingstone still hopes Ministers will reconsider, but has taken legal advice. He insisted any court action would not become as poisonous as the infamous Fares Fair court battle between himself and Thatcher, since he got on well with Prescott.

But relations between the two men, already strained, would collapse if Livingstone went ahead, pitching the Mayor and the Government into the bitter confrontation Labour always feared.

It will also revive memories of Livingstone's battles with Thatcher, when he set himself up as a left-wing opponent to her policies, prompting months of demonstrations and legal battles over his attempts to improve transport in the capital.

But, perhaps mindful of those ultimately doomed struggles, Livingstone is well aware that the one thing for which he will not be forgiven by Londoners is failing to rescue their crumbling buses and trains.

He hired Kiley, who turned around the New York subway in the late Eighties, to mastermind a bond issue raising the necessary finance, but has been frustrated by the Government's insistence on pressing ahead with its planned part-privatisation, which Ministers say will raise guaranteed cash without compromising safety.

The row has erupted just as Livingstone, who still yearns to be readmitted to the Labour Party, had earned Downing Street's blessing for a speech on Europe tomorrow.

He will launch the London regional group of the pressure group Britain in Europe, condemning 'the small group of nutters' who want to break from Europe and arguing that London's financial viability depends on EU membership. webTitle: US plays dirty as planet chokes

fields.headline: US plays dirty as planet chokes
fields.standfirst:
Squabbles as America fights to avoid reducing emissions
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: It took a surprisingly short time to sandbag the Hague yesterday. In only two hours, environmentalists managed to surround the city's great conference centre with a 5ft wall made up of 50,000 sacks filled with soil and grit.
fields.body:
It took a surprisingly short time to sandbag the Hague yesterday. In only two hours, environmentalists managed to surround the city's great conference centre with a 5ft wall made up of 50,000 sacks filled with soil and grit.

The activists - some from Latvia and Estonia, a few from Japan, several coach-loads from Britain and hundreds from other nations - had gathered to lay siege to the building in which diplomats and civil servants were trying to thrash out ground rules for limiting global warming. It was a manoeuvre replete with irony.

Rising industrial emissions of carbon dioxide are now heating the world alarmingly, say scientists, and are accelerating natural climatic warming, threatening to melt ice caps and flood low-lying areas. Hence the sandbag, a particularly potent symbol in climate-vulnerable Holland.

However, the real eyebrow-raiser was the speed of the Friends of the Earth stunt which contrasted starkly with the lumbering negotiations that have been taking place within the convention centre. For the past week, delegates have been trying to hammer out a framework for a climate-saving deal that their ministerial bosses can then knock into shape when they arrive tomorrow.

There have been few signs they are going to succeed. Despite evidence that the greenhouse effect is now at its strongest for 20 million years, that Europe's growing season has lengthened by 11 days in the past century and that scientists are predicting all Arctic ice will have disappeared by 2080, delegates remain obsessed with the minutiae of conference protocol. As one leading UK negotiator put it: 'This could turn out to be the most important conference in human history, yet all we get is haggling over trivia.'

These squabbles threaten to erupt into full-scale war, particularly between the United States and Europe, which began an alarming exchange of insults late last week. One European Union statement even accused the Americans of 'threatening the integrity' of the entire climate change convention.

At heart, the problem is simple: how can the world halt the global warming that is increasing global temperatures, sea levels and climatic instability? At the Kyoto environment summit three years ago, the industrialised nations agreed, in principle, to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to a figure 7 per cent below their 1990 output. Unfortunately, no one has been able to agree how to achieve this, or even to ratify the Kyoto summit. That is the purpose of the Hague summit.

The prime problem is America, the world's greatest emitter of carbon dioxide, which presses, with increasing insistence, that it should be spared from reducing its output and should instead be allowed to create new forests, both in the US and the Third World. These trees and plants, known collectively as carbon sinks, will soak up all that nasty carbon dioxide, say US delegates, and will obviate the need for Americans to abandon their profligacy.

The US also believes that by planting crops specially designed to soak up carbon dioxide, it could extend its 'sink' philosophy from the wild to the farmyard, thus strengthening its case for unabated industrial emissions. It was this idea, introduced at the Hague last week, that provoked that outburst of fury by Europe's delegates.

Other US agricultural innovations circulating last week included the wonderful idea of feeding sheep, pigs and cows special anti-flatulence diets to reduce levels of methane, another greenhouse gas. This notion merely induced derisive laughter.

Europe and most developing nations, as well as most non-governmental agencies, scorn the idea of carbon sinks. Only the real thing - cuts in emissions - will definitely work, they say.

In the words of the Environment Minister Michael Meacher, who will lead Britain's negotiations this week: 'There is no substitute for taking domestic action to reduce the emissions by burning less fossil fuels.'

Yet America remains obsessed with the idea it can use the dollar to buy itself out of trouble and has proposed other ploys including the concept of buying 'carbon credits' from countries such as Russia and Ukraine whose industrial collapse over the past decade means they have already reached their Kyoto reduction targets. The US wants to buy these non-existent 'saved' emissions to put towards its own target.

In short, the nation with the greatest output of carbon dioxide, the cheapest petrol in the West and the most inefficient energy industry is struggling to avoid any domestic action that might help the planet. Its delegates claim its stance is scientifically valid, though there is little evidence at the Hague to support the claim. For example, planting trees that gobble up carbon dioxide is a dangerous game, as researchers at Britain's Hadley climate centre revealed. 'Yes, trees do soak up gases produced by factories but they also contribute to global warming,' said a meteorologist, Richard Betts.

'Trees have dark leaves and bark and stand out against light backgrounds, particularly in higher, snowy latitudes. As a result, they stop sunlight being reflected back into space. Our calculation show that in places like Canada and Siberia, planting new trees would actually increase global warming.'

So is it simply a matter of Americans trying to keep their styles of life while the rest of the world struggle just to keep their lives?

Many at the Hague privately think so, although the US delegation, emollient and polished to a man, insisted theirs was the only way forward.'We have just as much to lose as the rest of the world,' said David Sandalow, the US assistant secretary of state for international environmental affairs.

At the end of the conference its organiser, the United Nations, hopes that a group of developed nations that represent a total output of 55 per cent of all carbon dioxide emissions will be able to ratify the Kyoto protocol. If that magic number is reached, the deal becomes an international treaty. However, without the co-operation of the US, which accounts for 24 per cent of the world's total output of carbon dioxide, there is little likelihood of success.

And so the world's nations will square up to their climatic 'High Noon' at the Hague tomorrow. On one side, Europe - led by Britain and Germany and supported by the developing nations and green groups - is pressing for real emission cuts. On the other, the US is backed by Canada, Australia and Japan, nations which are desperate to avoid taking any action that might risk the wrath of voters.

These, then, are the hate figures of the environment movement, a motley crew that also includes any representative of an oil company, China which wants to build more nuclear power stations and the environmentalists' special bogeyman, Saudi Arabia, which is trying to scupper the entire Kyoto protocol because it fears a downturn in petrol use.

The Saudis claim they should be compensated by the rest of the world for any loss of revenue. 'Nothing is too outrageous for them,' said Kerr Davies, of Greenpeace.

It is against this background that more than 2,000 official delegates have struggled over the fine print of the Kyoto protocol in a bid to make it acceptable to their political masters. Most negotiations have been conducted behind closed doors, though those held in open session may as well have been held in secret so inscrutable is their terminology, with phrases like 'biome-specific threshold values' and 'verified sink credits' causing nothing but general bafflement.

Added to these hard-pressed bureaucrats are 3,500 official observers from 180 nations and more than 700 journalists, as well as a phalanx of interested parties, including green groups, wind generator suppliers and climate researchers. 'We have about 80 different meetings going on, as well as press conferences,' said the conference organiser, Michael Williams. 'This is bigger than any UN arms conference. I don't think there has been a bigger, more complex conference.'

It may be the biggest conference show on Earth. But will it save the planet? The conference president, Jan Pronk, warned delegates on Friday that if they could not agree on a deal that was 'environmentally credible' then the 'whole thing will fall apart'. Given America's hardening stance and Europe's mounting irritation, such an agreement looks unlikely.

The best the world can hope for is continued negotiations in coming months. The worst is an American victory, won through its vast industrial muscle.

As Lars Georg Jensen, of the World Wildlife Fund, said: 'If America gets its way, it won't cut emissions until its people can actually smell the carbon in the air. It will be too late for the rest of us by then, of course.'

fields.headline: 'Too late' to halt global warming
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: John Prescott has warned that international efforts to curb greenhouse gases may only have a marginal effect on global warming.
fields.body:
John Prescott has warned that international efforts to curb greenhouse gases may only have a marginal effect on global warming.

The Deputy Prime Minister begins negotiations today in The Hague on a new international agreement to combat climate change, with scientists saying that after decades of damage to the planet the situation is likely to get worse before it gets better.

Asked whether it was not time to accept that climate change is inevitable, whatever actions are taken now on gas emissions, he said: 'When you look at what is happening, on the scale of things it's not going to change it substantially - but it's a change in direction.'

Prescott also called on insurance companies not to duck their obligations over flood damage, adding that the Government would do more to prevent floods and to lead a change in public attitudes. 'My wake-up call is to say to people, these are going to be more frequent, we should do more about it,' he said.

His comments, in an interview for BBC1's Panorama programme to be screened tonight, come as the Government is to pour £7m into a high-tech bid to predict weather patterns and identify the environmental impact of climate change.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers and the Science Minister, Lord Sainsbury, will announce this week that most of the cash will be spent on a project to analyse data from around the world to build up an accurate picture of what is happening to the global environment.

Ministers are also funding a programme to send scientists out into the Atlantic to measure sea levels, which are expected to rise gradually as a side-effect of global warming, eventually threatening low-lying coastal areas.

Professor Martin Parry of East Anglia University, a member of the International Panel on Climate Change, told Panorama that changes now were being caused by events up to a century ago.

'There is, unfortunately a time lag built into the global climate system of about 50 to 100 years that would take this warming forward before it evened out again. If we don't adapt we will start to pay an increasingly high price.'

webTitle: It's true. Money won't change us

fields.headline: It's true. Money won't change us
fields.standfirst:
New research shows many of us actually like to work, and wouldn't quit our jobs - even if we struck it rich

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: New research shows many of us actually like to work, and wouldn't quit our jobs - even if we struck it rich.
fields.body:
It may be hard to believe, but more than half of all Britons would carry on working, even if they made a fortune or won the Lottery.

Research will this week reveal that most of us no longer consider ourselves 'wage slaves', forced to work for cash. Many of us work because we like it.

'The old argument over "work-life" balance has always assumed that home is good and office bad,' said Judith Doyle, a leading cultural trends analyst who carried out the study for the Industrial Society. 'But home can be a dreary place and the office can be enjoyable.

'Work for many people is fun. People listen to you, they laugh at your jokes, they appreciate your skills. Even with families there, home can be empty and cold in comparison.'

Just over half the respondents to a nationwide survey agreed with the statement: 'If I had enough money to live as comfortably as I would like, I would still work.' The desire to keep on working increases to 70 per cent among those with salaries over £70,000.

Elaine Thompson from Lyme Regis won £2.7 million on the National Lottery in December 1995. Yet she and her husband returned to work after six months, opening the Champernhayes holiday complex. 'We do all the cleaning and gardening and painting ourselves,' she says, 'and we're busy 52 weeks a year. I haven't had a weekend off since March, although we hope to go away for a week over next February's half-term.

'I couldn't sit back and do nothing but golfing and drinking. You can enjoy life and work hard too. If I didn't work I'd be bored silly.'

A spokeswoman for Lottery operator Camelot said: 'The research matches our own survey - 51% of all Lottery winners who won £50,000 or more have returned to work in spite of their win.'

Britain's most celebrated return-to-work Lottery winners were the staff of the homeless persons unit at Camden Council in London. In January 1996 a 30-person syndicate all returned to their jobs the Monday morning after winning £10m. They insisted that their clients needed them and that their work was rewarding. A year later the unit won a government Charter Mark certificate of excellence.

Tom Piper received a 'comfortable amount' after he and his sisters sold their mother's large London home. The 35-year-old stage designer says: 'I had a choice - whether to go away and live off the money or to continue as before. But by working I have a chance to be paid to be creative and to deal with other people and to be part of the world.

'It's just not viable for me to do nothing. There's such a lot of pleasure to be had out of working hard and making something happen.'

Five years ago 46-year old Norfolk decorator Tim Logan also inherited a 'reasonably large' sum when his aunt died. 'It was enough for me not to have to work again, particularly as I never had very high outgoings. However, when I'd taken a fortnight's holiday and thought things through, I realised quite simply that I needed to work.

'It's the social interaction and the satisfaction and the stimulus. I couldn't go and play golf all week. I'd be bored out of my mind. The only thing that's changed slightly is that I can be a bit fussier about work that I take. I will usually say I'm too busy to do bog-standard stuff, I prefer challenging things. But I work five days a week quite happily.'

Jayne Buxton, co-founder of Flametree, the work-life balance website, said: 'It's clear that although half of workers take pleasure from their work, the other half still see it as a chore. Money is certainly the main motivating factor for women going to work either full- or part-time. There's a long way to go before all employees - not just women - are empowered to get the most out of their work and home lives.'

But Doyle insisted: 'As employment becomes much more knowledge- and service-based, people appear to be getting more satisfaction from it. For increasing numbers, work is no longer just fixing widgets in a factory. People may stay with employers for a shorter time than they used to, however there's no reason why they shouldn't continue to be loyal if they are treated well.'

As Britain's economy moves towards the lowest levels of structural unemployment for a generation, employers are becoming keener than ever to improve workplace satisfaction. The latest American innovation being introduced by some UK employers desperate to keep good staff is 'duvet days', two or three days a year on which every employee can decide on the spur of the moment that they want to stay in bed.

Other good practice which encourages employee loyalty includes fairer bonus sys tems, better communication with staff and provision of canteen or rest spaces where employees can gossip, said Doyle. Her study will be published this week by the Futures division of the Industrial Society.

What would you do with a fortune?

Flush

 Go to your local building society and ask about rates for long-term savers.

 Invest in FTSE 100 'bricks and mortar' companies.

 Buy a place in the country. Property is as safe as houses.

 Establish your own environmental charity and build a hospital.

 Phone your financial adviser.

Flash

 Get a new car, yacht, helicopter and jet.

 Take your summer holidays in space.

 Fill your house with Damien Hirst.

 Buy Hello! magazine and put yourself on the cover every week.

 Copy your DNA so you can clone yourself before you die.

 Phone Elton John.

However, when I'd taken a fortnight's holiday and thought things through, I realised quite simply that I needed to work. 'It's the social interaction and the satisfaction and the stimulus. I couldn't go and play golf all week. I'd be bored out of my mind. The only thing that's changed slightly is that I can be a bit fussier about work that I take. I will usually say I'm too busy to do bog-standard stuff, I prefer challenging things. But I work five days a week quite happily.' Jayne Buxton, co-founder of Flametree, the work-life balance website, said: 'It's clear that although half of workers take pleasure from their work, the other half still see it as a chore. Money is certainly the main motivating factor for women going to work either full- or part-time. There's a long way to go before all employees - not just women - are empowered to get the most out of their work and home lives.' But Doyle insisted: 'As employment becomes much more knowledge- and service-based, people appear to be getting more satisfaction from it. For increasing numbers, work is no longer just fixing widgets in a factory. People may stay with employers for a shorter time than they used to, however there's no reason why they shouldn't continue to be loyal if they are treated well.' As Britain's economy moves towards the lowest levels of structural unemployment for a generation, employers are becoming keener than ever to improve workplace satisfaction. The latest American innovation being introduced by some UK employers desperate to keep good staff is 'duvet days', two or three days a year on which every employee can decide on the spur of the moment that they want to stay in bed. Other good practice which encourages employee loyalty includes fairer bonus sys tems, better communication with staff and provision of canteen or rest spaces where employees can gossip, said Doyle. Her study will be published this week by the Futures division of the Industrial Society. What would you do with a fortune? Flush  Go to your local building society and ask about rates for long-term savers.  Invest in FTSE 100 'bricks and mortar' companies.  Buy a place in the country. Property is as safe as houses.  Establish your own environmental charity and build a hospital.  Phone your financial adviser. Flash  Get a new car, yacht, helicopter and jet.  Take your summer holidays in space.  Fill your house with Damien Hirst.  Buy Hello! magazine and put yourself on the cover every week.  Copy your DNA so you can clone yourself before you die.  Phone Elton John. ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Safety changes could relaunch Concordes
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Concorde will fly again if a radical new safety plan involving state-of-the-art Kevlar armour for its fuel tanks and special non-shredding tyres is accepted by British regulators.
fields.body:
Concorde will fly again if a radical new safety plan involving state-of-the-art Kevlar armour for its fuel tanks and special non-shredding tyres is accepted by British regulators.

Engineers and specialists from British Airways (BA) will this week mount a last-ditch bid to convince the Civil Aviation Authority that proposed modifications to Concorde will make the plane safe to fly. If BA fails, it is likely to mean the supersonic jet will never fly again.

Investigators believe that the Air France Concorde which crashed last summer developed problems after a tyre hit a 16in strip of metal that had fallen off an American plane.

The impact shredded the tyre, sending a shower of hard rubber into the air. Several pieces smashed into the fuel tanks under the plane's wings, causing a massive leak which, when ignited by the heat of the engines, created a 'giant cigarette lighter effect'.

The plane crashed less than two minutes after take-off, killing all 109 people on board and four on the ground.

All those involved in the crash - including investigators, manufacturers, senior safety and airline personnel - have been meeting regularly in Paris to discuss the future of the 25-year-old plane and the tragedy. Industry sources told The Observer that, at a meeting last week, it was decided to recommend fitting special tyres to the plane which crumble into small parts, rather than shred, if damaged.

To protect the vulnerable fuel, specialists want to fit the huge 120,000-litre tanks with an armoured liner made of Kevlar - the ultralight material used in flak jackets - which should prevent any puncture. The armour would, it is hoped, 'self-seal' in the unlikely event of something smashing a hole in it. Kevlar is used in all UK military combat aircraft and had been adopted by Formula One manufacturers to protect the fuel tanks of racing cars.

Fitting Concorde's tanks with a Kevlar lining will cost up to £1.5 million per aircraft, though the cost of modifying the tyres is negligible, it is estimated.

This is well within what BA, and probably Air France, are prepared to pay to get their supersonic flagships back in the air. 'It's pennies compared with the sort of contribution Concorde makes to BA,' said one pilot.

If the British Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is happy with the changes, it would give BA's fleet a certificate of airworthiness. BA's service between Heathrow and New York could, theoretically, start by the middle of next year after the engineering of the planes has been completed.

BA says it does not think the crash will have a significant impact on passenger confidence in the aircraft on trans-Atlantic flights.

Concorde pilots are delighted at the prospect of returning to supersonic passenger travel. One said that the fuel tank lining and new tyres could be fitted in weeks, although he admitted the modifications would then need extensive testing. That could include simulated re-runs of the Paris crash, with pieces of metal like the one left on the runway and tyre shreds being fired at the modified tanks.

However, time is running out for the plane. 'There is a clear economic issue here. BA cannot afford to go on losing money hand over fist [on Concorde]. They can only sustain such losses for a finite period,' said Chris Yates, Aviation Safety editor for Jane's Transport . 'If Concorde doesn't fly again relatively soon, then it may not get back in the air at all.'

BA has continued to maintain its seven planes and pay and train its 200-strong crew.

Air France's planes are likely to remain grounded while the investigation into the crash continues.

French investigators say that metallurgical experts have found microscopic traces of Concorde tyre on the metal strip that they believe fell off a DC-10 run by American carrier Continental Airlines.

It had been, it appears, incorrectly fitted by Israeli sub-contractors. French lawyers have speculated that Continental could thus be legally responsible for the crash.
