fields.headline: Britain buys 'terror' bullets from Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: British police forces are buying millions of a controversial type of bullet made by the Israeli Army and similar to those used in recent weeks in the Middle East to shoot Palestinian protesters.
fields.body:
British police forces are buying millions of a controversial type of bullet made by the Israeli Army and similar to those used in recent weeks in the Middle East to shoot Palestinian protesters.

Weapons experts say using the bullets in a war would be against the Geneva Convention. In total, the deals are thought to have been worth more than £1m.

The bullets, known as soft-point rounds, are distributed by a British company on behalf of Israeli Military Industries (IMI) - the partly privatised commercial wing of the Israeli Defence Force (IDF). They are favoured by IDF snipers deployed in the Gaza Strip, Jerusalem and the West Bank and are thought to have been used in a number of assassinations by Israeli secret services.

Soft-point rounds are similar to the infamous 'dumdum' bullets which spread on impact to inflict appalling wounds. In America, soft-point type ammunition is advertised for its 'reliable expansion' within the body after impact and its 'deeper penetration'. Police in New York were severely criticised over its use several years ago.

Jacketed soft-point bullets in use by British police are designed for stopping power and accuracy. Senior officers last week said that they are a 'useful compromise'.

'They are less likely to travel through a target and hit an innocent victim and so are safer, but they will also stop someone without causing horrific damage. Or at least as much damage as a fully soft-tipped round,' one former firearms officer told The Observer .

However, their use and their purchase from the Israelis will be controversial. The IDF has been criticised by Amnesty International for reacting, in some instances, with disproportionate force to Palestinian protests. The human rights organisation has called for a war crimes investigation.

Soft-point rounds have also been used by Mexican security forces against the Zapatista rebels in the Chiapas region of the country.

Documents obtained by The Observer show that South Wales police concluded a deal to buy thousands of 9mm 'semi-jacketed soft-point' rounds from Samson Distraco UK, which are made in Israel, in October last year. Contract documents lodged with the European Union in Luxembourg show that the Metropolitan Police has also been buying a range of ammunition, including soft-point bullets, from the company for several years. A spokesperson for the Met refused to discuss individual contracts last week beyond saying that the force 'has to comply with the Police Scientific Development Branch national guidelines for the use of ammunition'.

The Geneva Convention only covers the actions of a state that has declared war on another state. If soft-point rounds are used against a nation's own citizens, as in Israel, it does not apply.

fields.headline: No IT, no comment
fields.standfirst:
The next boom in information technology will not benefit little dotcoms but the already great and greedy multinationals

Net news
fields.trailText: The next boom in information technology will not benefit little dotcoms but the already great and greedy multinationals.
fields.body:
So that's that then. The internet boom is over. Last week brought the now usual wave of casualties and lost hopes. TheStreet.com closed its British operation with more than 60 job losses, Ready2shop puts its website into 'hibernation', the Government's auction of the fixed wireless spectrum is collapsing, and the take-up of third-generation Wap mobiles is bitterly disappointing.

Infopunditry is at sixes and sevens. No more confident predictions that everything from the newspaper to the nation state is set to die before the advance of the new economy. No more talk of a new business model which frees dotcoms from the tedious preoccupation of making a profit. Instead, the dotcoms are watching their numbers being decimated. Their hope is to get to the 'other side' of the current evaporation of investor confidence when the old order will re-establish itself and everyone can become a millionaire again.

In this hope, they are wrong. The boom in hi-tech shares that cascaded out of the United States to infect the globe really was like seventeenth-century tulip-mania. It will never return in the same way; indeed, the greater risk is that the puncturing of the bubble will precipitate a recession as banks and institutional investors draw in their horns to cover their losses, thus triggering as vicious a circle of retraction as dizzying as its upward impulse during the boom.

The danger in this atmosphere is that we get as pessimistic about the impact of the new economy as we once got over-optimistic. The arrival of information technology is transformatory, at least for those parts of the economy and society where it goes with the grain of social possibility. IT is making every organisation more porous, with communication enabling new alliances and partnerships; the future organisational form will not be the traditional inwardly focused, hierarchically structured factory or office, but the externally focused network. But the trick to understanding what the network economy and society will bring is not to get swept away by the discontinuities between then and now - it is to understand what must endure.

This has been the Achilles' heel of infopunditry. The fact, for example, that an almost infinite amount of information is instantly available and communicable on the web is only a precondition for change, not its guarantor. Information has to serve an economic and social purpose. The reason why mobile-phone usage has taken off is that it has been socially driven. The mobile, and especially personalised text and voice-mail messages, permits a deepening of social interaction and our capacity to interact with other human beings - witness its role in teenagers' social lives. The mobile phone is not a tool to enable us to migrate to cyberspace; it is a tool that grounds us in human interaction.

This is why predictions that the net will see the end, for example, of the newspaper are so silly. Users of news websites use them in addition to, rather than instead of, their newspaper reading; it is something they have read that will typically trigger a search for more information on the net.

The newspaper remains a portable and accessible source of news, but just as importantly is a key link to membership of whatever cultural subgroup to which we belong; rather than plough through the hits that search engines provide or log on to receive our customised news service, we read the paper that we trust to have sorted out what is important for us - and whose selections we need to know because they configure who we are in interaction with others.

Indeed, newspapers are likely to become more rather than less important; they are trusted brands, landmarks that can guide us through a sea of information. The same rule applies to get any kind of fix on the future. Your projections have to pass the social interaction/social purpose test - and even then your chances of getting it right are pretty hit and miss. As Keynes observed, the point about the future is that it is unknowable.

But take the supposition about social interaction and think it through. IT should work best either where it builds on pre-existing social patterns or creates new ones, or where the relationship is already nothing more than contractual and so does not depend on social interaction. Thus, IT usage would grow explosively and dynamically in two main areas: those professional and cultural domains, such as consultancy and the media, where it reinforces necessarily dense patterns of social interaction, or in those areas where all firms, especially manufacturers, have simply contractual relationships, notably with their supply chain. And those are the areas where its impact is already huge. If my hunch is right, one overriding result will be to entrench and widen the already alarming inequalities in the structure of work, patterns of income and lifestyles.

So it is that there is a new, rich, individualistic but interdependent middle class emerging, centring on what John Knell, my colleague at the Industrial Society, has dubbed the free worker. These are the mobile, skilled individuals who can win business from the porous networked organisations as self-employed independents - everything from TV producers to business consultants.

Their entry card is their reputation and contacts book, and to stop their talented workers from joining their ranks employers pay premium salaries, encourage home-working and relax their dress codes. These are the members of 'hot' networks enjoying the boom in house prices in the privileged, drawbridge ghettos in which they live, educating their children privately and who tend to be dismayingly politically disengaged.

The losers are the anonymous workers for subcontractors in big supply chains, forced to bid for contracts in auctions mounted on the new procurement websites - and where relationships can be managed largely in cyberspace. The five great multinational car companies have just launched Covisint, the trade exchange that will post huge potential contracts on its procurement websites - but which will be auctioned by progressive lowering of the contract price.

This is an instrument for ensuring contract compliance at the keenest prices, and whose impact will be to bid down wage rates along with terms and conditions of employment. But the contract relationship was nothing more than contractual in the first place; IT simply reinforces the capitalist logic to its brutal conclusion.

What IT is doing, in short, is intensifying pre-existing trends, so that old arguments reappear in a wholly different guise. For example, the dotcoms that will survive and prosper will be those going with the grain - the auction sites and the specialist information providers. In public policy terms, though, the arrival of hot and cold networks, and the accompanying new inequalities, has the paradoxical consequence of remaking the case for redistributive tax policies, powerful social insurance and collective provision of schools and hospitals.

They help society to cope with and exploit the new economy and its consequences rather than being 'burdens' to be reduced, so that the much derided European social model becomes an advantage rather than a hindrance.

Information technology, notwithstanding its current travails, really is transformatory, but in ways few currently comprehend.

webTitle: Comment: The hell that is the suburb

fields.headline: The hell that is the suburb
fields.standfirst: Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: There is a great arrogance about the countryside in Britain. It thinks it is the soul of the nation.
fields.body:
There is a great arrogance about the countryside in Britain. It thinks it is the soul of the nation. The peasants and the pheasant shooters were shoulder to shoulder in feudal proximity on Brighton seafront during the Labour Party conference and there in their midst was John Bull, his Union Jack waistcoat at full stretch across a stomach the size of The Bulge.

You never saw that when the miners fought a Tory government. And with him as their mascot they railed against what the BNP fuel protest website calls 'this over-paid urban Labour Government'. The rural lobby is not the BNP, but they clearly see themselves as the true guardians of what is really British, a last defence against that Tory-invented poltergeist, the 'metropolitan élitism' of a Labour Government that doesn't understand the People and prefers focaccia to Hovis and, far worse, town to country.

This rural myth is buried deep in the identity of Britain, and particularly of England. Who actually likes Constable's 'The Haywain'? But consistently the British dream of the country: 84 per cent of people in the UK want to live in a small village; only 4 per cent actually do.

Even when the British live in a town they try to create the pastoral. In a trice the middle classes knock though the two ground-floor rooms of terraced houses and make a meadow. They fill it with natural wood, Laura Ashley or the rural pastels of catalogue furnishings, and imagine they are not in a town at all. If they can get a fenced garden, all the more Beatrix Potter their lives become.

From the time when Watneys invented that erzatz bit of the countryside, the Ploughman's Lunch, to Jane's Pantry at motorway service stations or that catering incarnation of a fake horse brass, the Harvester restaurant, the marketeers have known how to touch the faux rural pulse that is at the core of the average Brit.

So although, as ever, the Government can't quite bring itself to go all the way, Thursday's White Paper on cities and towns at least started the long overdue campaign against this rural myth and began to celebrate urban living.

Living in the country is fine for the 4 per cent, even though it seems odd that they associate the countryside with healthy living. After BSE it's hardly surprising that the Countryside Alliance would rather march through the lead fumes in London than risk eating anything from a farm. But if they want to preserve what they feel is a great quality of life, they need to stop cash-crop farming and start diversifying.

The suburbs are different altogether. They are killing the towns. And the countryside too. They are fuel-dependent monocultures, pushing at the boundaries of the green belts. They pretend to have a quality of life that outstrips the city. But they are theme parks of selfish individualism.

In the States they were created by the combination of cheap housing and racial prejudice and gave birth to the Mall and the drive-in lifestyle. In Britain, the natural habitat of Margot and Jerry from The Good Life, they have demonised real urban living. And they have sought to give themselves legitimacy through an aesthetic appeal to an imagined past. I call it Mrs Bridge's architecture. It is like her chutney. Developers create security compounds of mock-Queen-Anne-sub-Georgian brick houses that, like the cook in Upstairs Downstairs, never existed in historical reality.

This attempt to live in the semi-country creates bypasses, out-of-town shopping, unviable bus routes, communities held together by the invented bonds of Am Dram, Bring-and-Buy and School ties. It spills over into business parks, spacious corroders of the lungs on the edge of cities where those with cars have shrubbed parking yet employees further down the chain have nowhere enjoyable to eat. Suburbs create a hierarchy in which cities are the lowest of the low.

Except they're not. Cities are the drivers of prosperity, pioneering a quality of life where we share transport and reduce pollution, where we press through the throng and feel the closeness of other human beings that reminds us we are a society. The real rural fuel protesters have real rural worries. They must be answered. But for the rest, well they are mere defenders of the suburbs and the Government is right to be replacing their rural myths with urban celebrations.

The Britain of the future is an ordered jumble of creative humanity living hugga mugga in places where people matter more than cars. The White Paper may not have gone far enough either for me or, rather more importantly, for Richard Rogers, but this Government should be proud to be 'urban'. The city is the true soul of Britain. It was in the Industrial Age and is again in the post-Industrial one.

The peasants and the pheasant shooters were shoulder to shoulder in feudal proximity on Brighton seafront during the Labour Party conference and there in their midst was John Bull, his Union Jack waistcoat at full stretch across a stomach the size of The Bulge. You never saw that when the miners fought a Tory government. And with him as their mascot they railed against what the BNP fuel protest website calls 'this over-paid urban Labour Government'. The rural lobby is not the BNP, but they clearly see themselves as the true guardians of what is really British, a last defence against that Tory-invented poltergeist, the 'metropolitan élitism' of a Labour Government that doesn't understand the People and prefers focaccia to Hovis and, far worse, town to country. This rural myth is buried deep in the identity of Britain, and particularly of England. Who actually likes Constable's 'The Haywain'? But consistently the British dream of the country: 84 per cent of people in the UK want to live in a small village; only 4 per cent actually do. Even when the British live in a town they try to create the pastoral. In a trice the middle classes knock though the two ground-floor rooms of terraced houses and make a meadow. They fill it with natural wood, Laura Ashley or the rural pastels of catalogue furnishings, and imagine they are not in a town at all. If they can get a fenced garden, all the more Beatrix Potter their lives become. From the time when Watneys invented that erzatz bit of the countryside, the Ploughman's Lunch, to Jane's Pantry at motorway service stations or that catering incarnation of a fake horse brass, the Harvester restaurant, the marketeers have known how to touch the faux rural pulse that is at the core of the average Brit. So although, as ever, the Government can't quite bring itself to go all the way, Thursday's White Paper on cities and towns at least started the long overdue campaign against this rural myth and began to celebrate urban living. Living in the country is fine for the 4 per cent, even though it seems odd that they associate the countryside with healthy living. After BSE it's hardly surprising that the Countryside Alliance would rather march through the lead fumes in London than risk eating anything from a farm. But if they want to preserve what they feel is a great quality of life, they need to stop cash-crop farming and start diversifying. The suburbs are different altogether. They are killing the towns. And the countryside too. They are fuel-dependent monocultures, pushing at the boundaries of the green belts. They pretend to have a quality of life that outstrips the city. But they are theme parks of selfish individualism. In the States they were created by the combination of cheap housing and racial prejudice and gave birth to the Mall and the drive-in lifestyle. In Britain, the natural habitat of Margot and Jerry from The Good Life, they have demonised real urban living. And they have sought to give themselves legitimacy through an aesthetic appeal to an imagined past. I call it Mrs Bridge's architecture. It is like her chutney. Developers create security compounds of mock-Queen-Anne-sub-Georgian brick houses that, like the cook in Upstairs Downstairs, never existed in historical reality. This attempt to live in the semi-country creates bypasses, out-of-town shopping, unviable bus routes, communities held together by the invented bonds of Am Dram, Bring-and-Buy and School ties. It spills over into business parks, spacious corroders of the lungs on the edge of cities where those with cars have shrubbed parking yet employees further down the chain have nowhere enjoyable to eat. Suburbs create a hierarchy in which cities are the lowest of the low. Except they're not. Cities are the drivers of prosperity, pioneering a quality of life where we share transport and reduce pollution, where we press through the throng and feel the closeness of other human beings that reminds us we are a society. The real rural fuel protesters have real rural worries. They must be answered. But for the rest, well they are mere defenders of the suburbs and the Government is right to be replacing their rural myths with urban celebrations. The Britain of the future is an ordered jumble of creative humanity living hugga mugga in places where people matter more than cars. The White Paper may not have gone far enough either for me or, rather more importantly, for Richard Rogers, but this Government should be proud to be 'urban'. The city is the true soul of Britain. It was in the Industrial Age and is again in the post-Industrial one.

webTitle: More than 100 new trains are stuck in the sidings

fields.headline: Adding irony to insult
fields.standfirst: More than 100 new trains are stuck in the sidings.  Joanna Walters reports
fields.trailText: More than 100 new trains are stuck in the sidings. Joanna Walters reports
fields.body:
Sitting on a train that is crawling along at 20mph on broken-rail alert is bad enough. But the final insult for passengers caught up in the great post-Hatfield rail paralysis is if that train is 40 years old, dirty, overcrowded and uncomfortable.

The irony is that there are at least 100 brand-new trains that should be ready to roll out on to the network and provide a crumb of comfort for delayed passengers. But these are stuck in sidings and sheds waiting for teething problems to be fixed or held up by paperwork.

Of £3 billion worth of new rolling stock ordered since privatisation, only a fifth has gone into service - much of it in the freight industry.

Around £1.7bn worth is in the pipeline and on schedule for delivery, including huge orders such as Virgin Trains' £1bn contract for 140mph tilting trains for the West Coast main line. But around £700 million worth of orders, or 23 per cent, are held up because of technical or bureaucratic hitches.

Industry observers are concerned that this figure could rise if problems now affecting new trains in the process of being tested spread to vehicles further down the production line, as their delivery dates loom.

The problems are three-fold. First, UK manufacturers have been struggling to produce the sheer volume of orders that came in following a long period of pre-privatisation famine in train-buying. Second, problems have emerged during testing. Third, manufacturers and train operators have been berating Rail track for being slow to award the safety certificates new trains need before they are allowed on the network.

The main train-builders in Britain are Alstom, the Anglo-French consortium that took over the old Metro-Cammell works in Birmingham, and Adtranz, the rail arm of Germany's DaimlerChrysler, which owns the old British Rail works at Derby and has just been sold to Canadian engineering group Bombardier.

One industry observer said: 'The level of collaboration between Railtrack and the manufacturers is not as good as it should be. It is difficult to perfect trains in the factory that are going to run on a network that was built 175 years ago and has had bits bolted on to it ever since. And there is a problem with poor components and inferior assembly work.'

New electric trains on order from Adtranz for south-east England, for example, have been delayed partly because of fears that their software could interfere with the track or overhead power systems and trip signals from red to green.

There are 44 Adtranz Electrostar trains on order, worth £220m, for the c2c passenger franchise, formerly the London-Tilbury-Southend line. The fleet was meant to be in service last November but is 18 months behind schedule after late delivery and problems with testing. Adtranz gave the operator two free trains as compensation. In the meantime passengers use 'slam-door' trains built more than 30 years ago.

Travellers on the infamous Connex South East and Connex South Central routes into London 'will continue to suffer elderly Mark 1 stock on many routes for a long time', according to Rail Magazine, despite the takeover of South Central routes by Govia.

Connex is waiting for Adtranz to perfect a batch of Electrostars it has on order before it can start phasing out old stock. But more will have to be ordered before Mark 1 trains disappear from the network. The Government has demanded that this 30- to 40-year-old rolling stock should be removed by the end of 2002 or, if it has had safety modifications, by the end of 2004. South West Trains is waiting for electric trains from Alstom that should have been in operation in the spring but are still being tested.

Other operators have had problems with both electric and diesel trains built by Alstom, including Gatwick Express and ScotRail. Pip Dunn of Rail Magazine said some of the trains had been found to 'rock violently going over points' during testing. He queried whether the manufacturers were making designs too complex, not doing enough testing or failing to adapt proven designs.

Gerald Corbett, ousted last week as Railtrack chief executive, caused further anger earlier this month when he blamed the state of the tracks partly on lack of consultation over rolling stock design and over-heavy freight trains.

Dunn said operators supported Railtrack's priority about safety but questioned the length of time it was taking to grant certificates. 'It is not rocket science,' he said.

webTitle: Corbett forced to quit by snub from Prescott

fields.headline: Corbett forced to quit by snub from Prescott
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Railtrack boss Gerald Corbett resigned last week because he was furious about a ruthless campaign to undermine him conducted by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and the powerful rail regulator Tom Winsor, The Observer has established.
fields.body:
Railtrack boss Gerald Corbett resigned last week because he was furious about a ruthless campaign to undermine him conducted by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and the powerful rail regulator Tom Winsor, The Observer has established.

He finally quit on Friday when it became clear that senior train-operating company bosses were appalled at the way he virtually shut down the network after last month's Hatfield crash and could not guarantee a normal service would be restored until next Easter.

Passengers face a winter of delays - while safety fears over broken rails remain and fresh concern arose this weekend about drivers suffering fatigue as they adapt to disrupted timetables and operating speeds.

Corbett and his 'steward ship' of Railtrack had repeatedly been under attack from Winsor before the Hatfield derailment of a GNER train that killed four last month. But both Winsor and Prescott blatantly refused to express support for the chief executive after the incident.

Although they could not interfere with his position in a private company, as two of the men with the most influence over rail policy their refusal to bolster Corbett left him mortally wounded.

When Corbett offered to quit the day after the accident but was begged to stay by his board of directors, The Observer revealed that he did not have the support of Prescott and it would be a matter of weeks before he would be forced to go.

Railtrack sources said: 'Following Hatfield, the industry pulled together. But it didn't take long for the briefing against him to start.'

On Friday Corbett claimed he had been under no pressure to resign. The previous day he had met with the Prime Minister, Tony Blair, to outline new ways of accelerating his rail recovery plan and had given no indication that he was about to quit.

But a source said: 'After the meeting with the PM, he thought he'd given the solution, lanced the boil and it was time to go. Number 10, Gus [Lord Macdonald, the Transport Minister] and Sir Alastair [Morton, chairman of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority] have been supportive. Prescott and Winsor haven't. They were furious that Corbett saw a conflict between safety and improved services.'

A Railtrack insider said: 'In the media circus, Gerald was Railtrack. Everything was taken down and used in evidence against him.

As the number of speed restrictions on the rail network doubled from 250 shortly after the Hatfield crash to more than 500 now, Railtrack was accused by GNER, the East Coast mainline train operator, of creating 'chaos'. As the problems mounted, severe flooding throughout the UK meant many tracks had to be closed.

Accusations of who was to blame flew between Railtrack and the train operators. Corbett accused the operators of being partially responsible for the state of the railways.

Corbett, 49, floated the idea of resigning a second time last Sunday, a fortnight after The Observer revealed that he was to go 'within weeks'. He declared his position was no longer tenable due to Prescott and Winsor's lack of support.

Railtrack announced that the chaos was going to cost around £250m to put right, but it was still going to increase the dividend to shareholders, angering rail safety groups.

On Friday, Corbett walked into the office of Railtrack chairman Sir Philip Beck and announced that he was going to quit and that this time it was for definite. Beck did not try to change his mind.

Corbett, who last year was paid nearly £400,000 and pension contribution of £189,000, has a 12-month notice period on his contract. Last night there were suggestions that he would receive only a six-month pay-off, a claim denied by those close to Corbett.

webTitle: Blair 'has ruined' chance of arms deal

fields.headline: Blair 'has ruined' chance of arms deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The British Government has destroyed the conditions enabling the IRA to open new talks with the international body dealing with arms decommissioning, Sinn Fein warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The British Government has destroyed the conditions enabling the IRA to open new talks with the international body dealing with arms decommissioning, Sinn Fein warned yesterday.

The warning came as the republican movement is poised to reject the Government's Bill on the Patten reforms of the RUC and to advise young nationalists not to join the new police force.

Pat Doherty, the Sinn Fein vice-president, told The Observer that Tony Blair's handling of the Patten Bill had 'ruined the context' for his party to go to the IRA and ask that it re-engage with General John de Chastelain's International Commission on Decommissioning.

In an article for today's issue, Doherty called on the Prime Minister and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, to return the Patten Bill to its original, undiluted form to avert a new crisis in the peace process.

'The Mandelson Bill, as it currently stands, will not receive the support of Sinn Fein, and we would actively discourage our people from joining. Nor would we nominate or recommend that any republican or nationalist accept positions on the proposed policing boards.'

Doherty said it was the British Government, not David Trimble's Ulster Unionists, which had diluted the recommendations of the Patten Report.

'The British Government can and must, even at this latest stage, rectify this situation if it genuinely seeks what is required by the Agreement. That is a policing service capable of attracting and sustaining support from the community as a whole.'

Asked if Sinn Fein was prepared to ask the IRA to re-open talks with General de Chastelain, Doherty said: 'The IRA said they would carry out a second confidence -building measure and then re-engage with de Chastelain, but only in the context of political change. That context has been destroyed.

'The last IRA initiative, opening up arms dumps to international inspectors for a second time, was a miracle. I just can't see the IRA re-engaging with de Chastelain's commission in this current situation, especially since Patten has been gutted.'

The Sinn Fein vice-president called on Blair to use the 'reserve powers' that Mandelson employed as Northern Ireland Secretary to overturn Trimble's ban on his party colleagues attending the North-South meetings.

Doherty described the present impasse as 'very, very serious', but refused to compare it with the situation in the winter of 1995, which led to the IRA breaking its first ceasefire with the Canary Wharf bomb.

 John Hume urged Trimble to lift his sanctions against Sinn Fein, and called on the IRA to re-open its dialogue with the de Chastelain body to try to save the province's power-sharing government.

Hume told his party conference in Newcastle, Co Down, that the First Minister's ban was 'counterproductive'.

Trimble imposed the ban during last month's Ulster Unionist Council meeting because the IRA had failed to live up to its promises to re-engage with the commission.

'One thing we should all have learnt from the peace process is that ultimata and unilateral demands simply do not work. Indeed, while they may provide some short-term relief from political pressure, they are counter-productive in the longer term,' Hume told delegates.

webTitle: Christmas cancelled by war in Holy Land

fields.headline: Christmas cancelled by war in Holy Land
fields.standfirst:
Bethlehem streets will be dark and silent as choirs and tourists stay away

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Bethlehem streets will be dark and silent as choirs and tourists stay away.
fields.body:
Two thousand years after the birth of Jesus Christ, Bethlehem has cancelled Christmas.

The grand finale of 12 months of millennium celebrations, a Christmas spectacular in Manger Square featuring choirs from around the world, has been called off because of the violence surrounding the intifada.

Confirmation that the Bethlehem 2000 Project, which co-ordinated this year's globally televised millennium celebrations in a packed town, will not be happening as planned follows cancellations by choirs and other groups which had agreed to perform.

It also follows the complete collapse of tourist bookings to a city which had been enjoying massive urban regeneration on the back of its programme of millennium events.

In the last seven weeks, however, the ancient town and the neighbouring suburb of Beit Jala have been at the centre of some of the worst violence of the intifada.

Beit Jala, where a German doctor, Harry Fischer, was killed last week by Israeli helicopter fire as he tried to give medical attention to wounded neighbours, has been the scene of almost nightly gun battles and shelling. Bethlehem, too, has been the scene of fierce fighting and fatalities, centred on the flashpoint at Rachel's Tomb, a few hundred yards from Bethlehem's most impressive new luxury hotel.

Jack Persekian, events co-ordinator for the Bethlehem 2000 Project, told The Observer last week: 'We were going to wait and see what the situation was like next month. But the truth is that most of the groups who had agreed to come and perform have already cancelled.

'We had been hoping that the centrepiece would be a performance by children's choirs from around the world performing in Manger Square. Now we have had to put everything on hold. We have to wait now and see how serious the hostilities are before we can know whether we can have any kind of event at all. If the situation allows it, we will try to have a small religious event even if it is without the tourists.

'It is a great shame. We had put so much effort into trying to persuade people that Bethlehem was a nice place for tourists to come to and now all that is in ruins. Everyone was saying this was really a year in which everything was picking up.

'We had already started the programme of events for Christmas with Norwegian, Italian and Cologne cultural weeks planned. Hotels had been reporting booking rates for the next few months in the realm of 90-plus %. Now that has all fallen through.'.

Disclosure of the cancellation of Bethlehem's Christmas spectacular came as violence continued yesterday in the Palestinian territories. In the most serious incident, a Palestinian policeman killed an Israeli soldier and wounded two others before being shot dead himself in Gaza.

An Israeli army statement said Baruch Plum, a 21-year-old staff sergeant from Tel Aviv, had been killed in the early morning attack on an army post near the Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom. In a separate incident, a Palestinian security official said three missiles had struck a Palestinian police post in Khan Younis.

fields.headline: We must build on Patten
fields.standfirst:
Much that the commission recommended is good, but it is still only a starting point, not a conclusion
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Much that the commission recommended is good, but it is still only a starting point, not a conclusion.
fields.body:
Nationalists do not regard Chris Patten's plan for the reform of the police in Northern Ireland as some radical panacea. Rather they are prepared to give it the benefit of the doubt or to ascribe a positive potential to what Patten is prescribing. But many of the 175 recommendations made by Patten and his colleagues lack teeth and pace where positive, urgent and substantive effect is concerned. And a number of important issues are not addressed by the report.

Nationalists are angry at the retention of the use of plastic bullets and that repressive legislation remains an integral part of the apparatus of the state. Their desire for an unarmed police service, in the immediate term, was thwarted and many were outraged that serving members of the existing RUC could be retained without a human rights screening process in a new policing service.

These are very bitter pills to swallow. To republicans and nationalists, policing in this state is synonymous with persecution and repression. Nationalists have been on the receiving end of this for the last 80 years - sectarianism, pogroms, torture, shoot-to-kill and human rights abuses of all kinds have been synonymous with the RUC. And no wonder, for the primary function of this unionist militia was to secure and sustain an undemocratic sectarian statelet.

Republican/nationalist leaders will not acquiesce in the continuation of this type of policing by recommending that our communities join or support the police force that will result from the implementation of the Mandelson Bill.

Peter Mandelson and the British Government should be under no illusions as to the importance of policing to the republican/nationalist community. This is a touchstone issue and unless it is addressed properly and in a manner that will allow those with influence on our community - the Church, political leaders and the Irish government - to recommend it, then it will have been a wasted exercise.

Now, although the Patten report did not go as far as republicans wanted it to go, we acknowledged that it could have given us a basis from which to build the new beginning to policing that the Good Friday Agreement promised.

If we are to have any chance of achieving this then the initial step has to be the bridging of the gap between what is currently contained in the Policing Bill and the benchmark of Patten. It is up to the British Government.

We will make our decisions on all matters related to the issue of policing when we have all of the information - that is at the conclusion of the legislative process and when other matters not requiring legislation are published. For instance, a new implementation plan or codes of practice.

Time is short, and it is imperative that the British Government act now. The 'Mandelson Bill' as it currently stands will not receive the support of Sinn Fein and we would actively discourage young people from giving it their support. Nor would we nominate for or recommend that any republican/nationalist accept positions on the proposed Police Boards.

It should be pointed out that there exists a major and false perception - particularly in Britain - that the dilution of the Patten recommendations by the British Government is entirely at the behest of the Ulster Unionist Party. This is true only of issues such as name, badge, flag and symbols. But the refusal to implement Patten's recommendations in respect of the substantive issues is entirely down to the domination of the securocrats in the British system. In the final analysis it is the British Government which must shoulder the responsibility for this issue.

We acknowledge that in the course of the legislative process a number of important changes were made to the original Bill introduced in May. However, the gap between the benchmark Patten recommendations and the mea sures being proposed by the British Government remains substantial.

A whole range of crucial issues in the Patten Commission's report is not being implemented. These include recommendations in respect of:

 The oath;

 The name;

 Badge, flag and symbols;

 The powers of the Policing Board;

 The scope to investigate past abuses by the RUC;

 The Special Branch and the Full Time Reserve;

 Community policing;

 The remit of the Ombudsman;

 The remit of the Oversight Commissioner.

The fact remains that the RUC is 92 per cent Protestant and 100 per cent unionist. It is young nationalists, republicans and Catholics who need to be persuaded to join and support a new policing service. This Bill will not achieve that objective.

The British Government can and must, even at this late stage, rectify this situation if it genuinely seeks what is required by the Agreement. That is, a policing service capable of attracting and sustaining support from the community as a whole and which is representative in terms of the make up of the community as a whole.

The gap must be closed. Patten must be implemented in full. To do otherwise will be to reject wilfully the opportunity to deal with this issue which is critical to society, to commitments made by the British Government and to the Agreement itself.

 Pat Doherty is Vice-President of Sinn Fein.

webTitle: Adair starts court bid for freedom

fields.headline: Adair starts court bid for freedom
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Johnny 'mad dog' Adair - one of Northern Ireland's most dangerous terrorists - is bidding for freedom in the first high-profile test case of the new Human Rights Act.
fields.body:
Johnny 'mad dog' Adair - one of Northern Ireland's most dangerous terrorists - is bidding for freedom in the first high-profile test case of the new Human Rights Act.

Lawyers for the notorious leader of the Ulster Defence Association on Belfast's Shankill Road will argue that his arrest during loyalist feuding in August this year breaches Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights. The Royal Ulster Constabulary says papers on Adair's behalf were lodged with the authorities last week.

Adair is being held in Maghaberry jail outside Belfast after Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, ruled that he had broken the terms of his early release from prison. The UDA commander had been freed last year under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement but on 22 August Adair was arrested near his home in the Lower Shankill estate.

Adair had been instrumental in fomenting a feud with the rival Ulster Volunteer Force and stirring up sectarian tensions in north and west Belfast. Seven people have died since inter-loyalist violence broke out on the Shankill on 20 August.

A senior RUC officer told The Observer that the police would be 'resisting robustly any attempt by Adair to get out of prison'. He said that legal moves by Adair to secure freedom indicated that the UDA boss believed the loyalist feud on the Shankill was petering out and that it was now safe to go home.

A spokesman for Mandelson's office said the Government would oppose any move by Adair to overturn the Secretary of State's decision to re-imprison the loyalist leader.

Adair's use of the Human Rights Act also provoked fury among mainstream unionist politicians. Robert McCartney QC, the leader of the UK Unionists and MP for North Down, said: 'Nothing surprises me but I think... the Human Rights Act does not provide a shield for the innocent, the disadvantaged or the weak. Instead it puts a sword into the hand of every envious malcontent and terrorist.'

The RUC and the Northern Ireland office fear that Adair's presence back on the streets would inflame tensions between the UDA and UVF, and heighten sectarianism in Belfast. Representatives of the terror groups held talks on Friday to try to bring the feud on the Shankill and north Belfast to an end.

However, Adair has recently told prison staff in Maghaberry that he intends to lead the quiet life if released this time.

The shaven-headed UDA boss is an icon for young loyalists and a hate-figure, not only to Catholics but also his rivals in the UVF. In the early to mid-1990s he ran the UDA's terror campaign against Catholics and republicans in the Greater Belfast area. The 36-year-old former skinhead used security files leaked by British Army soldiers from the Royal Marines to target IRA members in the city.

Adair is also appealing to the Sentence Review Body, which oversees the early release of prisoners, to reverse Mandelson's decision. But even if he wins his judicial review, Adair faces further scrutiny by the RUC's Financial Investigation Unit. It is already engaged in an 'assets tracing probe' over his income and wealth.

henry.mcdonald@observer.co.uk

webTitle: How West Bank fighters had planned 'war' a year before

fields.headline: How West Bank fighters had planned 'war' a year before
fields.standfirst:
As Israel and the Palestinians were talking peace, both were cynically preparing for violence, believing an intifada could serve their political interests.

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel and the Palestinians were both actively preparing for an armed uprising in the occupied territories up to a year before the outbreak of the current violence.
fields.body:
Israel and the Palestinians were both actively preparing for an armed uprising in the occupied territories up to a year before the outbreak of the current violence.

Both were convinced the other was planning to start a conflict to benefit their negotiating positions in the peace process, it has been established by The Observer after a month-long investigation.

The startling new version of the immediate causes of the seven weeks of bloodshed that has left more than 230 dead and 8,000 injured has emerged from interviews with Western diplomats and senior military, intelligence and political figures on both sides of the violence.

It is a version that rejects the notion of the intifada (uprising) being a reaction to the Israeli killings of Palestinian protesters at the Temple Mount, demonstrating against a visit to Islam's third holiest site on 28 September by the veteran Israeli hawk, Ariel Sharon.

It is a version that - while accepting the genuine disillusion of ordinary Palestinians with the peace process and their widespread support for the intifada - suggests their anger is being cynically manipulated for political ends.

It is a version, too, that gets tacit support from those closest to the struggle.

Sitting in his office on the West Bank discussing the Palestinian conduct of the intifada, a Hamas leader asks if we are off the record, then grins. 'This is all a play. The intifada is a game,' he says, when asked about the excessive loss of life on the Palestinian side.

'The violence and deaths are part of the negotiations for the peace process. But no one is going to tell that to the parents of the children and young men who have died.'

He confirms what many observers of the violence of the last few weeks have long suspected. As UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan prepares to send a fact-finding mission to investigate the conflict, it has become clear that there is a curious ebb and flow to the clashes on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip.

Stand at the junction at the City Inn in Ramallah or one of the other main flashpoints. The boys come and throw stones, get shot, get bored and drift away. It is then that an older man comes and encourages them back to the barricades.

On the Israeli side, too, there is a sense of inevitability about the violence. It does not matter whether the rocks land close enough to harm the soldiers, they fire back in any case. The truth is that neither side wants to be seen as willing to back down.

'I guess it was last November that we started getting wind of a plan for an uprising,' says the senior Israeli military intelligence officer.

As we speak he flips between Israeli and Palestinian TV and fields calls from a bank of telephones that report exchanges of fire, as darkness falls across the West Bank.

It is as revealing about what the Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) were thinking as about what the Palestinian Authority was alleged to be planning.

'We assessed that Yasser Arafat and the Palestinian Authority were calculating that they were not going to get what they wanted from [Israeli Prime Minister] Ehud Barak. What they were asking themselves was this: do we need - or might we need - to go through an armed struggle phase before we reach the goal of a settlement with Israel.

'It was no secret. It was being said in the Palestinian press. But at that stage it was evident that they were just throwing balls in the air. They were saying to us: "Look, something terrible will happen - a disaster, a regional war - there will be a lot of violence, unless you give us what we want." Our assessment was that they would not want to disrupt the millennium celebrations or do anything until after the Pope's visit, so we calculated that nothing would happen until at least March.'

According to this Israeli version, the key moment came not on 28 September with the visit of Likud leader Sharon to the Temple Mount. It came four months before on 15 May, on Nakba (Catastrophe) Day, the national holiday that marks the success of the Jewish armed struggle in creating an Israeli state in 1948.

Nakba Day has always been a day of Palestinian protests; this year, however, the Israelis say, they noticed a different tenor to the violence. 'The previous year had been pretty quiet. This year there was a lot of live fire. It was a message - "Look we mean business". We were already looking at what had gone on before and we saw explicit signs of preparations.

'There had been a gradual building of consciousness in the Arafat-controlled media for an armed struggle. We were also seeing explicit preparations for an uprising in the autumn. We were seeing dozens of training camps for the stone-throwers in the summer. We were also aware of exercises by Palestinian Authority security forces. We had seen a battalion-size exercise down in Gaza, and elsewhere low levels of military preparation. We also had evidence that weapons were being smuggled in Palestinian diplomatic vehicles.'

According to this version, the crisis began in earnest at the end of July with the collapse of the Camp David talks.

'When Arafat came back, everyone was on their toes waiting for the order to be given for an uprising. Instead we know Arafat gave the order not to activate the planned uprising.' Instead, say the Israelis, preparations continued throughout August with a series of statements by Arafat's leading lieutenants in the Palestinian press.

'Both sides were preparing for war,' a European official working in the occupied territories says wearily, 'not just the Palestinians. No one had any doubt about it.' It was a view that was shared as early as last summer by the UN body responsible for refugees in the Palestinian areas: UNRWA.

'Looking back,' says a senior European diplomat, 'UNRWA acted with due responsibility. They sat down and said: "Do we need to have a contingency plan for an outbreak of fighting and the possibility of large-scale and long-term full closure of the Palestinian Territories in the autumn." Their view was "Yes".

'There was a real feeling around Nakba Day in May that something was going to blow. Ordinary Palestinians were very fed up. They were dissatisfied with the Israelis, the peace process, even the Palestinian Authority itself. But Arafat and Barak were still talking.' He adds, however, that Western diplomats had evidence that Arafat had accumulated a war chest estimated at up to $1 billion - though not all of it instantly realisable.

Indeed, the view of international diplomats is that even if Arafat was considering (or preparing) an uprising, the Israeli shootings at the Temple Mount on 29 September - the day after Sharon's visit - caught him unawares. 'I saw Arafat in late September,' says one diplomat. 'It was a few days before the intifada started and he was very relaxed. Violence seemed the furthest thing from his mind.'

The Israeli military intelligence officer agrees. 'We don't believe Arafat planned an uprising for September. Our suspicion was that it was supposed to have started last week on 15 November. Arafat simply responded to events.'

But if there is evidence that the Palestinian Authority was considering using an uprising to pursue a negotiated settlement, there is also clear evidence that the Israeli armed forces were also preparing for violence as early as 12 months ago when - by their own account - they regarded the threat of a new intifada as nothing more than rhetoric.

Crucially, the Israeli Army had trained four battalions for a 'low-intensity conflict', including the Nahshon Battalion, established just over a year ago, as specialists in house-to-house fighting. Its troops were being trained in mock Palestinian villages constructed on two IDF bases, and taught how to break up demonstrations and target snipers. Palestinian security sources also allege that during the summer the IDF began giving settlers arms and weapons training.

Israeli senior officers also admit that, after the Nakba Day shootings, they began to put their contingency plan, prepared in the autumn, into force. 'We increased the defence of our forces. By the time September came we were prepared mentally and physically. We did not realise that it was going to start on 29 September, but we were ready for considerable violence. We weren't taken by surprise.' Both sides had their fingers on the trigger. On 29 September, faced with rioting Palestinians on Temple Mount, the Israeli security forces pulled the trigger.

But if the violence was being anticipated by both sides, then why? 'We underestimated how difficult the final status negotiations were going to be,' says a Western intelligence source. 'We had left and lumped the most difficult things together. The status of Jerusalem and the holy sites, refugee returns, settlements and final status borders. No one had done their homework before Camp David. The gaps were just too great. But we pushed on and insisted Arafat should attend the negotiations when he did not want to come.

'What we got was a dangerous hardening of positions. The Palestinians were increasingly angry about being bullied by the Americans and calculated that an uprising at the time of the US presidential elections could internationalise the crisis and dilute American influence. The Israelis, anticipating this, seemed happy for there to be a crisis. They calculated that as long as they could keep the casualties low they could get through it, and it would strengthen their position with the Americans. This is cynicism on both sides of the highest order.'

Hussein al-Sheikh is a marked man these days. As a commander of Arafat's Fatah movement in Ramallah, and held responsible for attacks on Jewish targets, he is one of those the Israelis would like taken out of the picture. We meet in an anonymous building with gunmen at the door.

'The decision to go to war was an Israeli decision,' he says. 'The Israelis had decided they no longer considered Arafat a partner in peace. They were looking for an excuse to annex territory rather than negotiate its return. Prime Minister Barak was talking peace while preparing for war. We were pushed into this conflict.'

Later I am in Tel Aviv talking to David Chacham, a former colonel in the IDF who became an Israeli negotiator in the peace process. Now he is an adviser to the Israeli Ministry of Defence and Barak's office on Arab affairs.

'Maybe Barak is right,' he says. 'Maybe Arafat is not a partner for peace. I am convinced he could stop the violence now. Arafat is playing a strategic game.

'Arafat has always made it clear that he regards the decision to talk peace as a strategic one. When he is not getting what he wants, as we have seen often in Palestinian politics, there is a recourse to violence in a time of crisis. There is an expression for it in Arabic. It means all the options are open, including violence.'

I ask Chacham why his side too has not done more to reduce the violence, especially the fatal shootings of young stone throwers.

He seems surprised and a little irritated by the question. 'You cannot ask our soldiers to fight with their hands tied,' he says.

Israeli senior officers also admit that, after the Nakba Day shootings, they began to put their contingency plan, prepared in the autumn, into force. 'We increased the defence of our forces. By the time September came we were prepared mentally and physically. We did not realise that it was going to start on 29 September, but we were ready for considerable violence. We weren't taken by surprise.' Both sides had their fingers on the trigger. On 29 September, faced with rioting Palestinians on Temple Mount, the Israeli security forces pulled the trigger. But if the violence was being anticipated by both sides, then why? 'We underestimated how difficult the final status negotiations were going to be,' says a Western intelligence source. 'We had left and lumped the most difficult things together. The status of Jerusalem and the holy sites, refugee returns, settlements and final status borders. No one had done their homework before Camp David. The gaps were just too great. But we pushed on and insisted Arafat should attend the negotiations when he did not want to come. 'What we got was a dangerous hardening of positions. The Palestinians were increasingly angry about being bullied by the Americans and calculated that an uprising at the time of the US presidential elections could internationalise the crisis and dilute American influence. The Israelis, anticipating this, seemed happy for there to be a crisis. They calculated that as long as they could keep the casualties low they could get through it, and it would strengthen their position with the Americans. This is cynicism on both sides of the highest order.' Hussein al-Sheikh is a marked man these days. As a commander of Arafat's Fatah movement in Ramallah, and held responsible for attacks on Jewish targets, he is one of those the Israelis would like taken out of the picture. We meet in an anonymous building with gunmen at the door. 'The decision to go to war was an Israeli decision,' he says. 'The Israelis had decided they no longer considered Arafat a partner in peace. They were looking for an excuse to annex territory rather than negotiate its return. Prime Minister Barak was talking peace while preparing for war. We were pushed into this conflict.' Later I am in Tel Aviv talking to David Chacham, a former colonel in the IDF who became an Israeli negotiator in the peace process. Now he is an adviser to the Israeli Ministry of Defence and Barak's office on Arab affairs. 'Maybe Barak is right,' he says. 'Maybe Arafat is not a partner for peace. I am convinced he could stop the violence now. Arafat is playing a strategic game. 'Arafat has always made it clear that he regards the decision to talk peace as a strategic one. When he is not getting what he wants, as we have seen often in Palestinian politics, there is a recourse to violence in a time of crisis. There is an expression for it in Arabic. It means all the options are open, including violence.' I ask Chacham why his side too has not done more to reduce the violence, especially the fatal shootings of young stone throwers. He seems surprised and a little irritated by the question. 'You cannot ask our soldiers to fight with their hands tied,' he says. fields.headline: Saddam indulges in execution orgy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A top-level defector from Baghdad has told British intelligence that scores of senior army officers have been killed by Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, in purges over the past two years.
fields.body:
A top-level defector from Baghdad has told British intelligence that scores of senior army officers have been killed by Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, in purges over the past two years.

In February 1999, intelligence sources believe, Saddam ordered the killing of 38 officers, including General Kamil Saachit Al Dulaimi, suspected of plotting a coup.

Saddam has long been known to use execution as a routine disciplinary tool. But the defector has revealed a detailed picture of the state violence the Iraqi dictator uses to enforce his authority and of the personal interest he and his family take in their brutal measures.

The orders for the execution of opponents to the regime are always signed by an immediate member of Saddam's family or a close adviser. The signatory can record whether or not the victim should be tortured before execution, the defector said. Saddam's two sons, Udai and Qusai, have signed execution orders, as have three of Saddam's half-brothers.

The defector has also revealed a massive new prison construction programme. One, the Sijn Al Tarbout jail in Baghdad, is known as 'The Casket' and is located underground. Prisoners are kept on a liquid only diet.

Another jail has been built on the site of an old factory at Rashdia on the outskirts of the capital. The bunkers and workshops hold hundreds of prisoners. Other cells were recently opened by Udai Hussein in the Olympic Stadium garage.

The regime is becoming increasingly paranoid about opposition. Recent laws make it illegal to 'slander' Saddam or his family. Those found guilty can have limbs amputated. In September a man had his tongue cut out for breaking these laws, before being driven through the streets as an example to others.

Britain and the United States are finding it difficult to maintain diplomatic support for the United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq. Following the successful resolution of a Saudi airliner hijacking in October, Iraq's international image has been given a boost and there have been renewed calls for sanctions to be revoked. There is concern over the humanitarian situation within Iraq.

Britain and the US believe Iraq is using the absence of UN inspectors to hide weapons of mass destruction, including chemical and biological weapons stored in schools and hospitals.

webTitle: Comment: Lift the sanctions against Iraq now

fields.headline: Lift the sanctions against Iraq now
fields.standfirst:
Saddam's regime is evil and oppressive, but ordinary Iraqis should no longer suffer for his iniquities

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Saddam's regime is evil and oppressive, but ordinary Iraqis should no longer suffer for his iniquities.
fields.body:
My hands were visibly trembling when I handed my passport to the border guard. Standing close by was an armed Iraqi soldier. The last time I had seen Iraqi guns they were pointed directly at me; some of them had even been fired.

When I told my friends I was returning to Baghdad after 10 years they all said I was mad. Why would I want to return to the place where I was abused, humiliated and nearly died? As I waited at the Iraqi border, I asked myself the same questions. My journey had begun a few months before with an idea to make a film for the BBC as the tenth anniversary of the Gulf War approached. It had been an exciting proposition.

I knew from colleagues in the RAF patrolling the no-fly zone that Britain and America were still bombing Iraq on a regular basis. This undeclared war goes largely unreported by the media, something which I find truly disturbing. More importantly, I wanted to meet real Iraqis and see how the war and subsequent years of sanctions had affected the 'man in the street'.

Sanctions meant that I could not fly into Baghdad; the only way in is via Jordan and a 15-hour car journey. Sanctions also control the sale of Iraqi oil, a fact which seems to have escaped the Iraqis themselves as the only other vehicles on the road were oil tankers. Completely ignoring the restrictions, thousands of them plied the route between the Iraqi oilfields and ports in Syria and Jordan.

Sanctions were imposed on Iraq after the Gulf War in an effort to force the regime into surrendering its weapons of mass destruction (WMD). United Nations inspectors were also put in place with a brief to find and destroy any undeclared weapons. As I entered Baghdad, I drove past the UN compound - it was deserted. The inspectors were evicted from Iraq during Operation Desert Fox, the three-day bombing campaign in December 1998. At the end of that operation, we were told that 'Saddam had been put back in his cage'. That may have been so, but he was in his cage with his people and his weapons and we had drawn curtains tightly around the bars. Despite our overwhelming technological superiority, without UN weapons inspectors on the ground, we have no real idea what is going on in the darkest corners of Iraq.

In many ways, Britain and America have painted themselves into a corner, which really is the nub of the Iraqi problem. Sanctions, weapons inspectors and the no-fly zones are all inexorably linked. Until the UN is allowed to return and verify that all WMD have been destroyed, sanctions must stay in place, argue Britain and America. Iraq denies that it has any WMD and refuses to accept inspectors. But sanctions are having little effect on the regime; the only people suffering are the poorest. In a truly ludicrous state of affairs, even pencils come under the items banned by the sanctions.

And the no-fly zones are in disarray. They were set up to protect from Iraqi repression the marsh Arabs in southern Iraq and the Kurds in the north. But, in an obscene piece of hypocrisy, we allow one of our Nato allies to bomb the very group we claim to protect.

Aircraft patrolling the northern no-fly zone are based in Turkey and our pilots put their lives in danger on a daily basis to fly into Iraq and ensure that the Iraqi military is prevented from attacking the Kurds. However, Turkey itself is also fighting a war with the Kurds, who want an independent homeland. On a regular basis, the Turkish authorities ground our aircraft so that their own air force can attack the very Kurds that the RAF was protecting a few hours before. After the Turkish jets land, our own pilots get airborne to resume their mission over the still smoking craters.

British and American policy is a shambles. And it is only Britain and America that maintain the current position. Over the last few months, an increasing number of countries have flouted the ban on air travel and have made symbolic flights to Baghdad. At the recent Baghdad trade fair, European nations were falling over themselves to ensure they would profit if sanctions are lifted. None of our old allies takes part in the regular attacks launched into the no-fly zone. Indeed, even Iraq has decided to ignore the restrictions and has recently begun internal domestic flights around the country.

After 10 years, the time has come to admit that the current state of affairs is not working and to review the situation. The great problem is that there appears to be no means of ending the dispute.

What conditions must be met for the no-fly zones to be removed? No one seems to know any more. How long can sanctions remain in place? Again, no answer.

No one can deny that parts of the Iraqi regime are repressive and evil. But we manage to deal with other similar regimes on a daily basis. After 10 years, sanctions have failed to produce the required result. It is time they were lifted. Perhaps the removal of sanctions can be linked to a return of some sort of independent weapons inspection team. Whatever the options are, they have to be better than the current stalemate.

As I travelled around Iraq, I was struck by how friendly and personable the people were. At an Iraqi airbase, I was given lunch by an Iraqi air force colonel who might have tried to shoot me out of the sky 10 years ago. It seemed strange to sit with my former enemy and to talk about the realities of war. But we both agreed on one thing - there was little that the military could do to solve the current situation. Only our respective leaders could do that. It must be an unpalatable thought for our politicians, but perhaps the time has come for them to talk to their former adversaries.

 John Nichol and John Peters were captured when their RAF Tornado was hit by a missile over Iraq during the Gulf war early in 1991. Both men were tortured and forced to appear on Iraqi TV to denounce the war. John Nichol's latest book, Decisive Measures , is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £16.99.

webTitle: Comment: US elections: It's free but is it fair?

fields.headline: It's free but is it fair?
fields.standfirst:
America's electoral system may be faulty, flawed, corrupt and prejudiced, but it's the people who make the mistakes, says Peter Preston

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: America's electoral system may be faulty, flawed, corrupt and prejudiced, but it's the people who make the mistakes, says Peter Preston.
fields.body:
Well, was it fair? Will the 'process' - ceaselessly invoked - finally install the President that America wanted on election day? Here are just a few of the things that, according to taste, can seem grotesquely unfair.

There is the mismatch of voting methods across the United States, and often within states like Florida. Sometimes you use rusty chunks of metal a century old, sometimes the punch cards that Palm Beach made famous, sometimes optical character readers scan writing on paper, sometimes you press a screen as though you were taking money from a bank cash till. No system is perfect; each, in a desperately close election, has a margin of error or confusion that matters.

As long ago as 1984, an independent report found a 'significant lack of confidence' in the punched results from Palm Beach. Nothing was done. Twelve days ago, 19,120 voters went to the polls there and recorded an invalid ballot: 10,000 - unbelievably - failed to make any choice of President, while 1,000 more punched two holes or the wrong hole on a ballot form, which was certainly confusing and possibly illegal. A shambles.

But there are so many other matters which, to British nostrils, reek of unfairness. Take those who can vote. Not convicted felons: that wipes some 444,000 Florida citizens, mostly blacks, from the democratic reckoning forever. One puff of pot and you're out.

Take where you vote. The counties foot the bill, so rich counties have many, well-staffed booths - while poor (usually black) counties make voting a long ordeal of queues and non-information. It's easier to vote if you're white and rich.

Take simple cock-ups, the eternal tale of humanity: the tens of thousands - from Illinois to Maryland - who'd registered to vote, but found they weren't on the rolls; the black bear which invaded a Michigan polling station and had to be shot; the 22,000 votes ruled out of order in Jacksonville because Democrat canvassers gave their voters duff advice about form-filling.

Take postal ballots trailing in 10 days late with no standard procedure for telling what was, and what wasn't, decided in good faith on or before polling day. Take the partisanship built into the system. Local election boards are politically appointed by politicians for politicians. When they decide to count or re-count, they are pawns to party advantage.

Take the lawyers and the majesty of their law. Who appointed this or that judge, because - golly! - that's important? Who will promote Judge A or Judge B to higher things once this tricky decision is over? Politicians. No wonder, time after time, that the bench is full of recuseniks. Integrity today can be unemployment tomorrow.

Take lofty legal officers like Florida's Secretary of State. She's not just a politician, but co-chair of the Elect George W committee. Her conflict of interest, like her attempt at decision-making, is final.

Take the $3 billion spent on this election, the ads, the deluded exit polls revealed before one end of Florida, let alone any state in the Pacific time zone, has finished voting. Take the antique foolishness of an electoral college weighted to whites in small southern states at the expense of America. Take the simple popular vote which makes senators, governors and school board chairmen - but not presidents.

Can any of this be fair? It is all, every last jot of it, what we normally mean by unfairness. Justice, in any precise sense, has not been done.

But that is not quite the end of the story and, as the Florida Supreme Court hugs its dignity, the last chapter has yet to be written. Consider what the Bush teamsters, had they not been quite so busy going to court last week, could have said. That the political partisanship, otherwise complained about so vociferously, in fact represents the constant impact of balloting in this most democratic of countries. Katherine Harris is Secretary of State because she won on a Republican ticket. The Palm Beach County election board is Democrat-dominated because Palm Beach is a Democrat county. The key woman on that board, Theresa LePore, the designer of the butterfly ballots, has been a Democrat all her life.

The people of her county - after 1984 - could have campaigned for the lousy punch card machines to be replaced. They didn't. They could have raised instant protests over the butterfly sheets. They didn't. Each and every one of them, entering the polling booths, was permitted three goes at filling in a ballot correctly. They had plenty of helpers on hand. They could check that the card hadn't been punched twice, or not punched at all, before they put it in the counting box. They didn't.

The system, full of inefficiencies and coagulations, may stink, but it is also a system which belongs to the voters who now complain so shrilly about it. It is - in a way we don't fully comprehend in Britain - their system run by their officials under the superintendence of their courts. All of which can be democratically changed. In short, they own this shambles.

This Observer observer, who is neither a Democrat nor a Republican, can't help feeling that fairness and responsibility go together here. The Gore camp has had the best of the political argument. Something was wrong in Palm Beach County. It would have been better to sort it out by a hand recount or a re-vote, if necessary state-wide. This 'felt fair' solution is what Florida voters (and probably their Supreme Court) want.

The Bush camp, constantly moaning about hand counts of the kind George W has signed into Texas law and closing its ears to the cries of public opinion, has managed to look shifty and ruthless and arrogant. None of that will help the Republicans if they eventually come to to govern a divided nation and (more testingly) a bitterly divided Congress; but real fairness, alas, is a rather more elusive concept.

The rules of this game were set by the people, underwritten by the people, financed or not financed by the people. The hanging chads were left by the people. The failure to check ballot forms was people error. Can any Supreme Court - Democrat appointees every one - exorcise such responsibilities? The brutal truth, as we pant into the last lap, is that there is no clear fairness or unfairness here. There is only what happens.

fields.headline: Losing our perception
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Being on the receiving end of Israeli military doctrine is a nerve-shattering experience. When a 155mm shell falls close to where you are cowering, the groundshock runs through your body, sending currents into your teeth, bones, muscles and stomach, forcing you to crumple in two until you wretch.
fields.body:
Being on the receiving end of Israeli military doctrine is a nerve-shattering experience. When a 155mm shell falls close to where you are cowering, the groundshock runs through your body, sending currents into your teeth, bones, muscles and stomach, forcing you to crumple in two until you wretch.

Several trips to South Lebanon on visits to the Irish battalion of UNIFIL over the last decade have been punctuated by desperate dashes from open ground to underground shelters or fortified T-walls when the Israelis and their allies, the now defunct SLA, started shelling and shooting. Travelling around the south you become overwhelmed at the devastation the Israeli occupiers and their proxies have wreaked.

For 20 years villages like Hanin, a Shia Muslim settlement wedged between two Lebanese Christian redoubts, lay empty, their people expelled at gunpoint by Israeli trained and armed militias. The Hanin Muslims' co-religionists in Bosnia would recognise this practice - it's called ethnic cleansing.

On one hazardous journey through Israel's former security zone I came across a group of Israeli conscripts having lunch under a pylon close to an Irish UN observation post known as 'The Black Hole'. As they scooped their food from tin cans, this miserable group of Tel Aviv beach boys and dope-smoking Kibbutzniks moaned about being in Lebanon while listening to a ghetto blaster, a reminder of their European lifestyle back home. The song on their tape recorder was REM's 'Losing My Religion'. The sight of those armed REM fans huddled underneath a pole, complaining about the commanders and politicians that sent them there, in earshot of Irish peacekeepers and, no doubt, the Islamic Resistance, compounded an overriding impression that Lebanon was Israel's Vietnam.
