fields.headline: The Bank's new brake dance
fields.trailText: William Keegan: One of the consistent themes of Gordon Brown's Chancellorship is that this is a Government that meets its economic targets and does not move the goal posts
fields.body:
One of the consistent themes of Gordon Brown's Chancellorship is that this is a Government that meets its economic targets and does not move the goal posts. Thus, in the face of suggestions that current measures of inflation exaggerate the underlying trend, and that, if we measured things the way the Europeans do, inflation might be less than 1 per cent, the Chancellor sticks to his guns. Intensely political as he is, Gordon Brown does not wish to be accused of doing anything that might lay him open to the charge that he was bending his self-imposed fiscal and inflation target rules.

This does not apply right across the board. Indeed, the present Treasury has been criticised for the imaginative way in which it dresses up old spending announcements as new ones. But on the macro-economic rules that impress the financial markets it has been unbending.

It was therefore somewhat unfortunate that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee (MPC) should have altered the base of its inflation forecast this month, on the grounds that recent movements in the exchange rate gave a false picture. The net result was to make the forecast for inflation over the next two years 2.5 per cent (bang on target) rather than somewhat less.

The MPC is an honourable body, and did not mean any harm. But the result was to mar the pristine reputation of the Treasury and Bank in these matters. MPC members can justify themselves till the cows come home, but the fact is they aroused suspicion in the City that they were seeking an excuse not to reduce interest rates when they could have done. If they had phoned a friend they might not have made such a silly mistake.

The MPC is generally thought to have done well on inflation. But officials at both ends of town are at pains to stress there has been an element of luck in this, and the next few years might not be so easy. Moreover, even an inflation rate of 2.5 per cent means the value of an annuity taken out by a person of 60 is reduced by 60 per cent by the time they reach 80. So let us hope the true inflation performance is much better than the official figures suggest.

This said, the MPC has produced a most interesting November Inflation Report. Introducing it, Bank deputy governor Mervyn King gave the impression interest rates had probably peaked when he noted that, according to the MPC's forecast, 'consumption growth will slow to around, or even below, trend', adding 'that is necessary in order to create room for the growth in public spending which itself is starting to pick up'.

Another way of putting this would have been to say that, since the private sector engine of growth is slowing down, the Chancellor's vast increases in public spending are coming just in time, Keynesian-style, to avert a slowdown or even recession. But that would be a simplification. The slowdown in private spending has been deliberately engineered by earlier rises in interest rates; and the MPC is taking nothing for granted. As King says: 'Although output growth has been slowing towards trend, the labour market has continued to tighten. Unemployment is lower than for a generation ... but if steady growth with low inflation is to continue, private domestic demand growth must slow further and wage pressures remain muted.'

The subject of fiscal and monetary policy coordination (or lack of it) fascinates the House of Lords Peston Committee which looks at the MPC. The way it works, we were told the other day, is that the MPC's achievement of 2.5 per cent inflation helps the Chancellor in planning his public spending, and once his plans are announced the MPC can react accordingly. Ed Balls, the Treasury's chief economic adviser, observed: 'You don't need to be in the same room to have coordination.'

The easiest way for the public to approach the macro-economic picture is to note that the Chancellor has become Mr Two and a Half Per Cent. The growth and inflation forecasts for next year are both 2.5 per cent. It sounds as if we are on automatic pilot and the MPC might as well go to sleep. But it is not as simple as that.

The big question facing the MPC is : are we on the verge of an improvement in the UK's underlying growth rate? The answer to this question affects interest rate decisions - indeed it affects the whole of fiscal and monetary policy, however many rooms this is conducted in.

If the economy can grow at only a traditional 2.5 per cent or so a year (2 per cent from increases in output per person thanks to new technology and better working methods, and 0.5 per cent from increases in the labour force), the balance between public and private spending is very delicate. The Inflation Report notes that between 1995 and 1999 the growth of labour productivity was 'weak by historical standards' but this year the rise in productivity has been the best for 20 years.

As the Inflation Report explains, 'in the short-to-medium term, faster productivity growth dampens pressures on unit labour costs from rising earnings ... Over the long run, however, higher productivity growth will tend to sustain faster growth in real earnings and living standards.'

There are well known divisions of opinion on the MPC, but the good news is that this debate means the MPC is watching developments as closely as Alan Greenspan did in the US to see whether we are indeed in the process of achieving lasting gains. The compromise at present is that the MPC as a whole is not taking too much for granted, but has agreed 'that a small further adjustment should be made to the relationship between real earnings growth and unemployment, implying that real wage pressures would be lower for any given unemployment path.'

In other words, so far the pressure of demand in the economy has not stoked inflation the way it did in the past, and it may be possible in future to achieve higher growth without automatically applying the brakes. If the underlying growth rate has improved there is also room for a combination of higher public and private spending than would otherwise be the case. I said 'if'.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Why the past is another country

fields.headline: Why the past is another country
fields.trailText: Most investors base their investment decision on a fund's past performance, despite overwhelming evidence that this has no bearing on the future.
fields.body:
Almost every advert for an investment product boasts about its past performance. Some will gloat about growth over the past 10 years; others point to their elevated position in the league tables. Some even claim to take the top slot.

Such adverts do carry the obligatory caveat that the past is not necessarily a guide to future performance. But even those prospective investors who notice the 'health warning' in the small print seem to ignore it. Most base their investment decision on the fund's past performance, despite overwhelming evidence that this has no bearing on the future.

Studies have shown that history does not repeat itself. If a fund stays among the top performers, it is due to luck rather than a fund manager's judgment. Very few are consistently lucky. Indeed, the only time when there does seem to be some predictability is in the investment doghouse. Funds which perform very badly often continue to do so. In short, as a recent paper from the Financial Services Authority put it: 'Information on past performance would not... be useful to retail investors'.

So the FSA has decided to review the use of past performance statistics in advertising. Purists among us would have hoped it would ban their use altogether, but that is not on the agenda. Instead, the FSA's task force will confine itself to the wording, position and size of the health warnings and will consider whether companies should be forced to display their past performance data in a standardised way.

That is a good start: there are many ways to be creative with statistics. A 10 per cent annual return is impressive if alternative funds have managed only 5 per cent. It is less so if the average has been 15 per cent. A top-performing Japanese fund could still have lost investors' money.

How should investors choose where to put their money? Should savers resort to sticking a pin in a long list of unit trusts? Most certainly not. There are many factors that should influence your decision. Most important is the amount you pay your investment manager. Fitzrovia, a company that specialises in analysing fund data, says that a £5,000 investment growing by 7 per cent a year would reach £19,348 after 20 years with no charges. Add a 3 per cent annual charge, and that falls to just £10,956.

But you should also look at the flexibility of the investment - how much it will cost to get out, and can you change or even stop your level of payments?

And you should be aware of the risks of the investment. There is no point going into a volatile technology fund if you want money for retirement next year; equally a cash fund is probably too low-risk for a 25-year-old who is building up a nest egg.

Such information will also be included in the comparative tables proposed by the FSA. These will be as useful as any tinkering with the rules on adverts.

webTitle: Laugh? We nearly chose a President

fields.headline: Laugh? We nearly chose a President
fields.standfirst:
TV satirists are turning the crisis into a hilarious comedy show, and millions don't want it to end
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Americans know that the rest of the world is laughing at them, but they do not much care: America is laughing at itself. This is a great story - better than O.J. Simpson or the death of Diana, say media professionals - with a healthy civic dimension. Following it, apparently, is good for your democratic health: cholesterol-free chaos.
fields.body:
Americans know that the rest of the world is laughing at them, but they do not much care: America is laughing at itself. This is a great story - better than O.J. Simpson or the death of Diana, say media professionals - with a healthy civic dimension. Following it, apparently, is good for your democratic health: cholesterol-free chaos.

The polls are benign. Bush and Gore have handled themselves pretty well, according to the Pew Research Centre: the Florida recount - or re-re-recount - should probably, but not certainly, decide. Absolute accuracy, while desirable, may not be possible. Meanwhile, there is no great rush. The nation is relishing the show.

Why isn't everyone as incandescent with anger or filled with foreboding, as the commentators deem necessary? Steal away for a moment from the legions of lawyers giving press conferences and come to the third floor of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, where with sweet timing an exhibition called 'The American Presidency' has just opened.

It's packed with citizens educating themselves and thus, in part, appropriately sonorous. George Washington's portrait looks sternly down on you: the balances of the Constitution are duly explained. 'Relative power is determined by the individuals in various offices by their ability to affect public opinion.'

But what's this? Warren Harding's original green silk pyjamas from Chavet et Fils, President Clinton's saxophone, Grover Cleveland's fly-fishing kit and Ronald Reagan's jelly-bean bowl. Old campaign posters and buttons, old rip-off remedies - to move the bowels, take Lincoln's pills - and the doll's house Amy Carter played with.

The presidency isn't all pomp and circumstance. It is a bizarre blend of tatty royalty - here's Mrs Coolidge's sexy inauguration dress - and folksy humour and melodrama and tragedy. The impeachment room stands next to the assassination room. From one wall in the video hall, Jimmy Carter talks about his triumphs; from another, movie clips run Hollywood's celluloid Presidents - Polly Bergen, Harrison Ford, Michael Douglas. It would be no surprise at all to find Monica Lewinsky's stained dress lying in a cabinet somewhere.

Presidents aren't expected to be quasi-regal or pompous. Clinton stars in TV sketches sending himself up; George W. Bush is at his most effective joshing about the one book he read at Yale. They are surrogate comedians who trade gags with the late-night comics of Leno, Letterman and Saturday Night Live .

As such, it's impossible to take them seriously as role models, stiff-necked saints. Why didn't ordinary opinion turn against Clinton at the depths of the Lewinsky debacle? Why did George W.Bush's concealed drink-driving pass with a public shrug? The American presidency - the 'glorious burden', the Smithsonian calls it - is a heady brew of contradictions, hopes, fears, sneers, jeers. And here is why there's been so little impatience or disillusion in the past 11 days.

The race for the White House was already a familiar brand of television soap opera. Florida has given that a vital makeover. 'Hey judge, how does it feel to be a media star?' some heckler shouts at the chairman of the Palm Beach canvassing board. Katherine Harris, the Cruella DeVille Secretary of State, used to do chicken dances on stage when she was young, and her old co-stars reconstruct it for the cameras.

Terry Lewis, the magnificently moustached judge in Leon County, is a novelist: last book, Conflict of Interest . Good lawyers wear good suits; bad lawyers sweat in jackets that strain across their bellies.The heavies of rival camps - frozen-faced Democrat, Warren Christopher, and the superbly insincere Republican, James Baker - are anchormen, but this is a drama anyone can join in. Indeed, the humble counters of the chads queue to be interviewed. 'It's my chance to be a part of history,' one says.

And the static camera angles - in court or looking down on the Palm Beach count- make the connection. This is Big Brother in its latest manifestation, or perhaps its more successful clone, Survivor . We can all watch non-stop and decide who should be President of the United States. We can all decide who we'd throw off this concrete island.

Call a free number to ditch Bush or Gore? It would probably be as good a way to decide as any. Meanwhile, the watching millions aren't fretting: they are enjoying the show too much. They don't want it to end.

webTitle: The critical job that's too big for just one of us

fields.headline: The critical job that's too big for just one of us
fields.trailText: Does having a combined chairman and chief executive make a difference to a company's performance?
fields.body:
Does having a combined chairman and chief executive make a difference to a company's performance? The Association of British Insurers clearly thinks there is a case to answer. It is writing to about two dozen of the top 350 British companies which, more than five years after it was outlawed by the Cadbury corporate governance report, still have one person doing both jobs. The association is asking non-executives why they are not complying with the corporate governance rules, and when they intend to review the situation.

The list of offenders seems to give plenty of cause for concern. British Land, Alliance & Leicester, Marks & Spencer: all have seen their shares head spectacularly south in recent years. For years, Greg Hutchings did the two jobs at Tomkins. Not only has its share price fallen dramatically, its corporate governance standards were so lax that Hutchings and his fellow directors were apparently allowed to enjoy perks such as corporate flats and jets and have some of their domestic expenses charged to the company.

With others on the list, however, the case is less obvious. Shares in Amvescap, Misys - even after the recent sharp reversal - and Billiton have outperformed the market despite a concentration of power at the top. And some of the worst corporate disasters in recent years - the row over Cedric Brown's salary at British Gas and the fiasco at United Utilities for example - happened despite the presence of an independent chairman on the board. At P&O, by contrast, Lord Sterling has managed to preside over an orderly break-up of the group, despite the absence of a chief executive as foil to his hands-on chairmanship.

The ABI has no empirical evidence to link performance with corporate governance. Indeed, such evidence is thin on the ground. The closest we can get is a recent report by McKinsey, the management consultants, which concluded that investors themselves believe it makes a difference. McKinsey put the good governance premium at around 18 per cent in the UK.

So should investors who lack the ABI's power to insist on changes avoid companies that do not comply with governance codes? There are certainly worse ways to screen your investments - particularly when the going starts to get rough.

Combined chairman and chief executives may look like excellent stewards when everything is going smoothly. But that can change rapidly. An autocratic boss - particularly one who has, in effect, created the company - is more likely to ignore danger signals than someone whose role is more like an employee.

At Tomkins, for example, Hutchings resisted a break-up of the group long after it was clear that the conglomerate structure was not working. At M&S, the then chairman Sir Richard Greenbury - who effectively created the modern group - not only refused to listen to criticism, he also tried to control the appointment of his successor.

That does not mean that you should rule out buying a company with a combined chairman and chief executive. However, it does mean you should be extra cautious. Look for strong non-executives to counter his power. And be prepared to bail out quickly when the going gets rough.

Still on the line

Energis, the telecoms company that was once part of National Grid, is one of the more established of the new breed of ex-utility operators. Others, like Scottish Power offshoot Thus, have a much shorter pedigree.

The headstart does seem to be producing some advantages. Not in profits, of course - after paying its interest and tax bills and writing down the huge amount it is investing in the network, Energis' operating loss doubled to £10.5 million in the six months to September. But, on the same basis, it is making money in Britain - a £20.3m profit for the period, up from £2.7m last time.

At this stage, however, the key is revenue and Energis seems to be making progress. Overall, turnover rose 81 per cent to £368m, including a 54 per cent rise in the UK. It has signed up an impressive client list, including Friends Provident, EDS and web-hosting clients include Boots and Chrysalis. And it is rapidly rolling out its international network, adding Germany and Ireland in the period.

That should put it in a good position to be among the finishers in the telecoms race. The trouble is, it is too early to say for certain. Energis's shares have fallen from a high of 812p in March to last week's close of 503p and are likely to remain volatile. The 37 per cent stake still owned by National Grid can be sold from next spring so takeover speculation could buoy the shares. Even so, only those who are willing to take a punt on the outcome of the tele coms handicap should consider buying.

Dull but solid

How long will it take investors in chemicals company BOC to forget that they almost had 1,460p a share in their hands, through the aborted bid from rival Air Liquide? It will be at least until BOC's shares get there under their own steam - and, judging by the results for the year to 30 September, that could take some time.

Not that there was anything wrong with the figures in themselves. An 11 per cent rise in pre-tax profits before exceptionals, on turnover 15 per cent ahead, is a solid performance. But it was hardly spectacular and, for all chief executive Tony Isaac's promises, solid is exactly where it is likely to stay.

BOC is already on target to make the promised £120m cost cuts. The pledge to increase annual sales to £5 billion, compared with last year's £3.9bn, will be a harder target to meet. Its industrial gases business depends heavily on the highly cyclical steel business, and although its vacuum technology division sparkled last year on the back of a buoyant semi-conductor market that industry remains extremely volatile. In distribution, its main customer - Marks & Spencer - is facing growing questions about the very viability, never mind the profitability, of its food business.

BOC's price/earnings multiple of 13, based on forecasts of £497m for the current year, reflects its solid but unspectacular status. The yield is, however, an attractive 4 per cent and those who value solidity may find that a reason to buy.

fields.headline: You've got male
fields.trailText: I was dumped the other day. By email. To be fair, it wasn't a brutal dumping, like so often occurs at the end of a relationship. It wasn't even a relationship.
fields.body:
I was dumped the other day. By email. To be fair, it wasn't a brutal dumping, like so often occurs at the end of a relationship. It wasn't even a relationship. Nor was it an affair, a fling, or anything licentious at all.

It was just an email thing. One of those potent dotcom couplings, where you snag on to a new, or rediscovered friend, and hurl messages back and forth intensely for a designated period. Exchanging bon mots. Bonding in cyber-space. Going steady in surftime.

Just as with new love, the initial flurry of emails is you at your best. You keep them toned and friendly. You make the other person feel special by responding straightaway, but you're careful not to rush things, or to scare them off. This is the honeymoon period. You might still put yourself about a bit ('I think we should email other people'), but they don't really mean anything. It's only text.

Then, horribly, inevitably, it all goes wrong. As with romance, you get sloppy, over-familiar. You let yourself go. Messages become slapdash, misspelt, peppered with bad jokes and swearing - the equivalent of being caught by your lover with unbrushed hair, watching TV in your pyjamas at 3.30 in the afternoon. Before you know it, the game's up. Missives from your significant online other start petering away, then vanish altogether. A clump of tumbleweed bounces in slow motion through your in-box, and out into the abyss. Sometimes, it takes a while to get the message that you're not going to get 'the message' but, ultimately, you've got to face facts: in the most thoroughly modern of ways, utilising the best communications technology available, you've been chucked.

This is one of my main beefs about email. Like all forms of communication technology, it gives men the opportunity to ignore you. For years, the non-ringing phone was the chosen mode of emotional torture for the type of guy who prefers to let his silence speak volumes. Then we got the fax, and all those gruesome tales of relationships being terminated with a piece of warm, shiny paper. Now, with email, men (and women, I suppose) have yet another chance to pull the wings off your fly. The flip-side of people choosing to communicate is people choosing not to communicate. It's as painful being blanked by email as it is being ignored on the street, or at a party. Being rejected hurts terribly, however it's done.

Saying that, I got off lightly. My email amour was strictly cerebral: affectionate, if a bit spiky. 'These are my thoughts.' 'You're an idiot.' 'So are you.' Since our fall-out, he's come round a bit, but I'm not so sure - he hurt me once and he could do it again. The trust is gone. Still, it is nice finding that special someone you can judge and insult from the safety of your own home. Even lovelier to state your case at your leisure, without fear of interruption, or contradiction. With email, a singular variety of insecure control freakery reigns supreme, and that 'I wish I'd said that' feeling becomes a dim, terrible memory. Something that happened to you in your old life, before spellcheck and wordcount kissed everything better.

Admittedly, this kind of attitude was probably what led to my ignominious dumping, but at least I never fell into the trap of making lewd suggestions. It never ceases to amaze me how people who'd run a mile from videotaping their sexual escapades, or having phone sex with a new lover, think nothing of writhing about sleazily online. On occasion, my friends send me examples of their steamy e-flirtations, but I really wish they wouldn't. It's like peeking through suburban curtains and witnessing your neighbours cavorting about together, wearing thongs and feathered masks. Others might vehemently disagree, but where this sort of thing is concerned, my position is clear. The information highway is all very well, but there may possibly be such a thing as too much information.

The problem with e-filth is not that it's sad, but that it's pointless.While it is true that all good sex starts in the mind, it serves us well to remember that physical chemistry - seeing, hearing, touching - is the bottom line. That's why flirting by email with a person you've never met face-to-face is as ludicrous as waving at someone from the window of an airplane. As any online veteran could tell you, the trick, the illusion, of email is that it combines the intimacy of a telephone call with the distance of a letter. Ergo, however much you might feel you are being 'yourself', you are actually projecting a hologram, a bit like the Bat logo over Gotham City. Which explains why people invariably come a cropper when they arrange to meet up with e-flirtees. It would appear that somewhere between exchanging intimate, even rampant, messages, and clapping eyes on each other, you become shy strangers once more. Then it's all over, bar the deleting.

fields.headline: It's a one-goal slaughter
fields.trailText:
Man City 0 - 1 Man Utd
Beckham secures the points within 90 seconds.
fields.body:
Manchester City not beaten Manchester United for 11 years and have waited four years just for the chance. This remains one of the great derbies, though sadly the Blues were too long out of practice to make it much of a match.

'You could feel the relief of our supporters at the end,' Joe Royle confessed after City's fourth consecutive defeat. 'Probably one or two of them were thinking it might be a rout.'

It should have been. In their heart of hearts City fans always knew they might have too much catching up to do, though they could not have imagined they would be playing catch up from the second minute.

After all the months of anticipation a mere 96 seconds was all it took for United to establish their supremacy and take the sting out of the game, and in the best Maine Road traditions City only had themselves to blame. Traditional rivalries were preserved right up to the kick off, with City fans greeting visitors from Old Trafford with a 'Welcome to Manchester' banner and Roy Keane preferring to shake the mascot's hand rather than that of rival captain Alf Inge Haaland, who had seized the morning headlines with the view that it was hypocritical of £50,000-a-week players to criticise the supporters who paid their wages.

Practically the first thing City did once the game got under way was to put themselves under a huge handicap. Haaland clumsily and unnecessarily felled Paul Scholes to give David Beckham exactly the sort of shooting chance Royle must have warned his players about conceding. Admittedly the free kick was marginally closer to the half way line than the goal line, which may explain why City decided a wall was unnecessary, but Beckham is deadly from any distance and proved it with a glorious strike which went past Nicky Weaver's outstretched hand at almost 70 miles per hour. 'I don't think you need a wall from that distance,' Royle doggedly maintained. 'We had two half-walls, but we might have been better off with no wall at all - letting the goalkeeper see the ball. A goalkeeper who is considered one of the best in the country should not be beaten from 35 yards out.'

The pattern of the afternoon was therefore established early on, with City obliged to come forward for an equaliser and United able to utilise their collective pace and Beckham's passing ability to strike on the break. So it proved, though with chances at both ends in either half of a remarkably open game it was astonishing that the score remained unchanged.

City were unlucky on a few occasions in the second half, notably when Wes Brown cleared a Haaland header off the line then pulled over Paul Dickov for what looked like a clear penalty, but the main reason the home side were in with a chance until the final whistle was some truly atrocious United finishing.

Dwight Yorke in particular will be glad Sir Alex Ferguson missed this game, and will be hoping the only video he watches on his return from South Africa will be the one from his son's wedding. With Andy Cole and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer injured, Yorke will be leading the United attack when the second phase of the Champions League begins on Tuesday, and he will need to be a lot sharper than this against Panathinaikos.

Yorke could have put United two up after 23 minutes, when a sumptuous ball out of defence by Beckham and a precision pass from Scholes gave him a clear sight of goal, but Weaver stood up to make an important save. Credit to the goalkeeper on that occasion, though in the first half Yorke was also denied by a block from Spencer Prior after Beckham had threaded a pass through to Phil Neville, and by an agile clearance from Steve Howey when Weaver was stranded off his line.

There were not always City players between Yorke and goal, however, and when Phil Neville, again, and then the outstanding Keane sent over inviting crosses from the byline on the right, the striker was unable to make contact.

That was just the first half. Royle sent on Shaun Goater and Ian Bishop after the interval to improve City's strike rate, though not Paulo Wanchope, whom the manager explained had been dropped and not rested. In the first half the highly promising Shaun Wright-Phillips had been City's liveliest attacker, but City went forward to good effect in the second - with Fabien Barthez saving from Goater and Paul Dickov and watching the latter miss a far post sitter. It led to Steve McClaren speaking of United having to grind out the result.

This was ridiculous, for although United could not have complained had City managed an equaliser, they continued to create and squander chances throughout the second half. Scholes, Butt and Yorke missed the target in quick succession, and when Ryan Giggs came on late in the game he proceeded to do the same, tamely stroking the ball straight at Weaver when put clean through by Yorke.

Keane's ceaseless running created any number of overlaps, but United passed up every one. 'How we didn't score a second goal I'll never know,' McClaren said. 'We had enough chances and numerous one-on-ones. We didn't expect to score so early, I guess. I phoned Sir Alex to tell him the result, and he said he wasn't surprised, the players always seem to make life as hard as possible for the manager.'

McClaren praised referee Steve Dunn's performance in handling a full-blooded derby without dishing out too many cards, Royle diplomatically kept his thoughts to himself. Dunn kept control well for over an hour, but almost lost it just before the end. He incensed City fans by denying the penalty against Brown, though arguably Dickov was also guilty of holding and leaning into his man, but should certainly have dismissed the already cautioned Danny Tiatto for a reckless challenge on Phil Neville six minutes from time.

That provoked a melee on the touchline, with the unlikeable Haaland getting involved after the event and coaching staff having to separate fighting players, but the actual game ended in more predictable fashion with Keane and Yorke somehow failing to find each other in an otherwise empty City penalty area.

As Royle said, City supporters can just about hold their heads up after this, even if the need for points against Ipswich next week is now becoming desperate. The Maine Road faithful backed their team magnificently too, even in adversity, though there was no need to emphasise the point by deriding the quieter United supporters. In addition to making a lot of noise, City fans were responsible for pelting Beckham with coins and several moronic references to Munich.

Best fans in the world? Don't think so.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

Keane's ceaseless running created any number of overlaps, but United passed up every one. 'How we didn't score a second goal I'll never know,' McClaren said. 'We had enough chances and numerous one-on-ones. We didn't expect to score so early, I guess. I phoned Sir Alex to tell him the result, and he said he wasn't surprised, the players always seem to make life as hard as possible for the manager.' McClaren praised referee Steve Dunn's performance in handling a full-blooded derby without dishing out too many cards, Royle diplomatically kept his thoughts to himself. Dunn kept control well for over an hour, but almost lost it just before the end. He incensed City fans by denying the penalty against Brown, though arguably Dickov was also guilty of holding and leaning into his man, but should certainly have dismissed the already cautioned Danny Tiatto for a reckless challenge on Phil Neville six minutes from time. That provoked a melee on the touchline, with the unlikeable Haaland getting involved after the event and coaching staff having to separate fighting players, but the actual game ended in more predictable fashion with Keane and Yorke somehow failing to find each other in an otherwise empty City penalty area. As Royle said, City supporters can just about hold their heads up after this, even if the need for points against Ipswich next week is now becoming desperate. The Maine Road faithful backed their team magnificently too, even in adversity, though there was no need to emphasise the point by deriding the quieter United supporters. In addition to making a lot of noise, City fans were responsible for pelting Beckham with coins and several moronic references to Munich. Best fans in the world? Don't think so.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Tales of Hoffman
fields.standfirst: Flash Freddie in The Talented Mr Ripley, the male nurse in Magnolia, and now a transvestite in Flawless... the chameleonic Philip Seymour Hoffman has become cinema's greatest scene stealer. But that's all about to change - he's in danger of becoming almost too famous

fields.body:
You may not know the name Philip Seymour Hoffman, but, if you're a regular filmgoer, the chances are that he's already made an unforgettable impression. Over the past few years, he's loomed out of the mid-cast-list mist to become the most visible of invisible character actors.

In The Talented Mr Ripley, he stole the film with his portrayal of Freddie, the creepily louche expat who comes to a sticky end. In Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, he was outstanding as the compassionate male nurse who looks after the dying Jason Robards (the role was written specifically for Seymour Hoffman). Whatever the merits or defects of the films he's graced - from Boogie Nights to Twister to Happiness - Hoffman has effortlessly stood out, specialising in spooky man-child marginals that you'd ordinarily cross the street to avoid, and building up what he wryly calls 'my quirky redheaded-guy rep company'.

Hoffman hasn't just stolen scenes from the name-above-the-title likes of Matt Damon, Gwyneth Paltrow and Tom Cruise; he's slipped whole movies into bags marked 'SWAG' and disappeared into the night with them. Next up is the tortured drag queen he doesn't so much play as inhabit in Joel Schumacher's Flawless; even Robert De Niro, mangling his vowels as a stroke victim getting singing lessons from Hoffman's Rusty, has to play second fiddle in this one. 'When I told people I had Philip in Flawless, they looked blank,' says Schumacher. 'But when you say, "He played so-and-so in Twister", they always go, "Oh my God! I loved that guy!"'

Flawless marks something of a watershed for Hoffman. It's his first leading role: 'I've had to make the transition from sweeping in for 15 minutes, doing my stuff and clearing out, to carrying a movie for the duration - in a dress.' And the plaudits he's receiving are such that his can't-quite-place-him days are numbered. 'He's probably one of our greatest character actors, if not the greatest,' declares Schumacher. 'We bandy the term "chameleonic" around all the time about actors, but he really has that quality. In spades.' 'He has no vanity about his work. He's constantly pushing things and taking them to new levels,' raves Anderson down the phone from LA. 'He's an actor's actor, really fearless,' notes John C Reilly, Hoffman's co-star in Boogie Nights, Magnolia and the recent New York stage run of Sam Shephard's True West (a two-hander in which the actors intermittently swapped roles). 'He's not afraid to explore all sides of the character, including the ugly, creepy things that go on inside of all our heads.'

Thankfully, the real-life Hoffman, who, despite his redoubtable track record, is still only 33, isn't in the least bit ugly or creepy when we meet in New York ('People used to be funny about approaching me, but now they seem to think I'm as sane as anyone who's done what I've done in movies can be'). Off-duty, his demeanour is a world away from the intense physicality he displays onscreen. Hunkered down in a chair, baseball cap pulled tight on his head with whorls of dirty straw-coloured hair gushing out of the sides, he's clad in the standard 'resting' gear of shapeless shirt and baggy cargo shorts revealing formidable tree-trunk legs. He appears to be making an effort to contain himself, or disappear altogether, but his expansive way with a cigarette - arcing it around his head and down to the ashtray in extravagant swoops - and the occasional emphatic outburst - 'Right right right right right!' he booms in his throaty, lightly camp East Coast drawl, rocking back and forth, a Cheshire-cat grin cracking his non-designer-stubbled and more-handsome-than-you'd-imagine face - remind you that this is indeed the man who vied with the eponymous star of Twister in sound and fury terms.

Since Flawless, Hoffman has completed two more movies, both also watersheds. In Cameron Crowe's rock memoir Almost Famous (which opened the London Film Festival this month) he plays 70s gonzoid rock journalist and speedfreak Lester Bangs - a sort of headbanging Hunter S Thompson - who takes teenage Rolling Stone scribe and Crowe manqué William Miller (Patrick Fugit) in hand. It's Hoffman's first mentor role, 'albeit a dysfunctional one,' he chortles. But his most unlikely transformation takes place in David Mamet's State And Main, a screwball comedy opening in February in which he gets to play the romantic lead, wooing Mamet's wife and muse Rebecca Pidgeon. 'I'm the straight man in the middle,' he beams, 'the most normal, quiet-spoken guy I've ever played. It's great, really different from anything I've done before. For once, everything's happening to me, instead of me happening to it.'

While longtime Hoffman-watchers might be alarmed by this lurch into benignity, recent reports suggest that it might be less of a career move and more of an insanity limitation exercise; in an Entertainment Weekly interview, Hoffman was quoted as saying that he sometimes thinks about quitting, because his trademark edgy roles take so much out of him: 'I think a lot about giving up, because you want to leave stuff alone sometimes. And when you don't act for a while, you feel better.'

So it's calm down or quits? Nonsense, says Hoffman. 'It was a total misquote. My soul is in good shape. I was just saying I could picture a time where I won't act as much, because you get so involved and just need a break. But I couldn't give up acting,' he shrugs. 'I'd just get depressed and go down the drain. Though life's a hell of a lot more complicated these days. It gets to the point where you don't know what city you were just in. It's like, Monday? Toronto? Shouldn't I have called my mom? Isn't she in the hospital?' Nonetheless, he concedes, 'part of me feels like the showier kind of edgy stuff is going away anyway; I'm moving into other kinds of edgy. I don't want to repeat myself. I'm not going to play a guy like Allen in Happiness again any time soon because I did that and I don't want to tarnish or dilute that film by doing it again, maybe less well. At the same time, I don't intend to bland out. Life isn't safe or smooth, it's odd, quirky, strange and difficult, along with all the good stuff. If you leave out any of those things, you're not getting what's interesting to begin with.'

This is the nearest he comes to a mission statement, but there's no denying that Hoffman goes the full nine yards for each role; in fact, in best Spinal Tap tradition, his yards go up to 11. As Scotty in Boogie Nights, watching his beloved Dirk attacking a usurping rival, he was all outsized pre-pubescence, rigid in horror at the rear of the frame, clasping his arm to his side like a child about to burst into tears; in Happiness, he finally got to go to bed with a woman, only to contort himself on top of her pink coverlet into a foetal frenzy. No wonder he's become known as the screen poet of emotional retardation. These characters are bona-fide losers, not in the classic Hollywood lovable-sap kind of way, but as in Beck's ' I'm a loser baby, so why don't you kill me? ' 'He flipped me out when we did Boogie Nights,' says Anderson. 'He kept doing these weird twitches, movements, accidents, stutters. Not in a flashy, pyrotechnic sense; he'll just throw anything into the pot he thinks is right.'

So what emotional depths is Hoffman plumbing to create this parade of credible misfits? Pop psychologists - and journalists - would zero in on the parallels between art and life, but Hoffman likes to play a straight bat when it comes to the latter. 'I want people to respond to the characters, not to me,' he protests. Nevertheless, the facts are these: he was born in Fairport, a suburb of Rochester, New York. His parents divorced when he was nine, and he was raised, along with his younger brother and older and younger sisters, by his civil-rights-activist mother, who's running for family court judge in the state. 'I don't think it was any odder than anyone else's upbringing,' he maintains, though it's obviously left him with a taste for politics; he'll 'host' Last Party 2000, a documentary on the US election campaign, due for release next year.

A theatre buff from an early age, he got into acting at high school when he developed a crush on a girl who was appearing in a class production of The Crucible: 'Sadly, she had the hots for my brother.' He seems particularly keen to correct a persistent misapprehension, fostered by his penchant for characters of at best ambiguous sexuality, that he's gay - not, perhaps, aiding his case by revealing that his favourite film is The Rose, with Bette Midler - by alluding to various affairs, including the first time he fell in love: 'I was at college at 19, lying in bed with a woman I adored, reading The Bell Jar, listening to Patsy Cline, and feeling alienated. It was perfect.' However, he says he's currently 'very single'.

Perhaps the biggest clue to his corporeal screen presence is the fact that the portly Hoffman was once a top jock. 'I was a good baseball player and wrestler in high school, but I got a neck injury, and that was the end of that,' he says. 'I think there's still a frustrated athlete inside.' (In fact, as well as all the classic slumming-actor jobs like waiting tables, Hoffman had a brief spell as a lifeguard.) Would this account for the physicality he brings to his roles? 'Oh, I'm sure of it,' he says, nodding vigorously. 'Using my body in an expressive way is my favourite thing to do. Body language informs so much about who you are.'

Hoffman studied theatre at New York University. 'I spent six years going through all the classics,' he says. 'I think it's essential to be grounded in theatre for any actor who really wants to up their game.' He describes last year's 140-show run of True West as 'awesome' (there are tentative plans to bring it to the West End in the new year, but Hoffman describes his and Reilly's schedules as 'pretty stacked right now') and, for good measure, runs his own off-Broadway theatre company, LAByrinth, from his West Village apartment.

He waxes lyrical about the rehearsal process and 'the freedom to play around with characters'. His perfectionism is legendary. In Flawless he spent weeks getting Rusty's walk and intonation right: 'My back hurt, my throat was sore from talking high. It was like I had a constant cold.' Rusty, he says, is 'just a person who wants to be loved, wants to feel safe'. And while Schumacher, who also wrote the screenplay, auditioned dozens of real drag queens, he says Hoffman was the only person who absolutely understood the role. 'He realised that he was playing a transgendered person, someone who truly feels they've been born in the wrong body. Drag queens create this über female persona, whereas Philip was prepared to show all sides of the character.' One of Schumacher's favourite scenes is when Rusty returns from his mother's funeral in 'man drag' of a suit and tie; cowering in his flat, his face a picture of self-loathing, he looks diminished: 'Phil got the balance of vulnerability and fierceness exactly right.'

He might demur, but is Hoffman really saying that none of this emotionally onerous stuff has ever freaked him out a bit? 'No, I don't tend to be afraid,' he confirms, with another sweep of his cigarette. 'Not if I'm supported by great art, whether in the writing or directing. I don't want to do fucking weird shit for its own sake. That's really disturbing. If I see a movie full of vicious violence or sex with no context for it, I think that's deeply irresponsible.' Has he scared himself sometimes? 'Oh sure sure sure sure sure,' he exclaims. 'Some of the things I've done, I've thought: Well, I sure won't be going back there for a while. But it's a containable kind of craziness. I know when I get home that I'm not Rusty or Scotty. But things do affect your life,' he continues, looking a little pained. 'It's not like mumbo-jumbo Methody stuff, but it can get a little bothersome. If you spend the day jerking off in front of a camera, you go home and you're, well, spent. It's painful.'

His role in Almost Famous involved a different challenge - that of playing a 'real' person. 'I didn't know his work at all,' says Hoffman. 'Cameron brought a lot of his stuff over and I thought I'd have to humour him, you know, go, "Ooh Cameron, it's really good", but it's actually fantastic, passionate stuff.' The way he 'found' Bangs illustrates the way he 'builds up' his characters. 'I need to get an understanding of someone and start from there. Cameron gave me guidance and showed me videos, but when I listened to his interviews and heard his Midwestern accent come out strongly, then fade back till it wasn't there at all, I knew if I could get a sense of that confidence mixed with gaucheness, I'd be fine. I didn't just want to do an impression of him.' Crowe was floored: 'What Philip did was be Lester, and yet also be Phil being Lester. It was uncanny.' Once he's 'recognised' something in a character, says Hoffman, then 'I start asking myself questions about them, like how they'd react in a certain situation, and ideas start to come from your imagination, and you try them, and if they don't work you try something else.'

Hoffman, while 'trying to do as much work as I can before I show up on set', likes to keep experimenting once the cameras start rolling. 'And sometimes directors are, like, "Oh, what are you doing?" And I say, "Well, I'm just trying something out", so maybe they trust me or maybe I freak them out.' Schumacher is of the former school. 'He's incredibly demanding of himself. He'd do 5,000 takes if you let him; a few times I thought things were perfect and he'd go, "No, I don't think my pinkie was feminine enough in that last one." I think he thinks he's a pain the ass. He was always going, "Could we try..." and then apologising profusely.' Cameron Crowe was another: 'Watching Phil at work, burrowing away at a character is an education in itself.'

David Mamet seems to belong firmly in the what-are-you-doing camp. When I ask Hoffman about State And Main, in which, as a flustered screenwriter on a typically venal Hollywood set, he turns in a beautifully nuanced performance without bouncing off any walls - for once, you might even empathise with him - he hesitates. 'Mmm, it was good,' he says carefully. 'Me and Mamet think differently about acting. He's very "don't worry about all that other stuff - just do it". Which is fine, I respect that, but he probably thought I'd be holding up the action while I agonised over how to stress a syllable in my trailer or something. So we felt each other out a lot.'

Hoffman and Mamet do have one thing in common; in Hoffman's words, they're 'really not West Coast kinds of guys'. However, the West Coast is keen to coopt Hoffman, as the daily avalanche of scripts thunking on to his doormat attests. Which presents him with something of a dilemma: with the adjective 'Hoffmanesque' already in tentative circulation, has he become almost too famous? 'I'd like to do some leads,' he says, 'then dive back down. I don't want to move much beyond where I am now, but then I think people realise that action-hero movie-star stuff isn't really my thing. It's good to keep the invisibility factor strong. I'm not as anonymous now, but hopefully I can create something interesting and compelling enough that you forget it's me, rather than go, "Oh, another barnstorming Hoffman performance."'

Unfortunately or not, for us seasoned Hoffman-heads, those days will never return, but it's hard not to agree with Schumacher's admittedly partial tribute: 'I think he's a master. And it's amazing to remember that, in career terms, he's only just begun. I can't wait to see what he'll give us next.'

 Flawless opens on 24 November; Almost Famous on 26 January

'Mmm, it was good,' he says carefully. 'Me and Mamet think differently about acting. He's very "don't worry about all that other stuff - just do it". Which is fine, I respect that, but he probably thought I'd be holding up the action while I agonised over how to stress a syllable in my trailer or something. So we felt each other out a lot.' Hoffman and Mamet do have one thing in common; in Hoffman's words, they're 'really not West Coast kinds of guys'. However, the West Coast is keen to coopt Hoffman, as the daily avalanche of scripts thunking on to his doormat attests. Which presents him with something of a dilemma: with the adjective 'Hoffmanesque' already in tentative circulation, has he become almost too famous? 'I'd like to do some leads,' he says, 'then dive back down. I don't want to move much beyond where I am now, but then I think people realise that action-hero movie-star stuff isn't really my thing. It's good to keep the invisibility factor strong. I'm not as anonymous now, but hopefully I can create something interesting and compelling enough that you forget it's me, rather than go, "Oh, another barnstorming Hoffman performance."' Unfortunately or not, for us seasoned Hoffman-heads, those days will never return, but it's hard not to agree with Schumacher's admittedly partial tribute: 'I think he's a master. And it's amazing to remember that, in career terms, he's only just begun. I can't wait to see what he'll give us next.'  Flawless opens on 24 November; Almost Famous on 26 January

webTitle: Bruce Paltrow: Gwyneth is good for you

fields.headline: Gwyneth is good for you
fields.standfirst: He started out with Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese, but for film director Bruce Paltrow, his debut film with his daughter Gwyneth has given him the greatest pleasure yet
fields.trailText: He started out with Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese, but for film director Bruce Paltrow, his debut film with his daughter Gwyneth has given him the greatest pleasure yet
fields.body:
Gwyneth Paltrow, who last year became arguably better known for her tearful Oscar acceptance speech than for the role that earned her the award, has never been loath to bring her family into the limelight. On that mysteriously overwrought occasion, she mentioned, among others, her mother and father, her brother, her grandfather, and a deceased cousin, thanking them for allowing her to 'understand love with a tremendous magnitude'.

But most of these figures were not foreigners to fame - and they had already been publicly associated with Gwyneth for some time. Early in her career, much was made of her thespian pedigree. She was photographed with her arms around her mother, the actress Blythe Danner, and she often spoke with girlish fondness about her father, the director, writer and producer Bruce Paltrow.

It had long been known that Gwyneth spent her early years in Hollywood, and that she was later offered a small role crucial to her future by Steven Spielberg, a family friend. Now Gwyneth has become so famous, however, that pedigree seems to be turning round almost to the point of total inversion. Blythe Danner, a talented actress, has been much more visible in films recently, and cynics inevitably argue that the Gwyneth connection has added to her appeal. And now, for the first time, Gwyneth has made a movie with her dad, who I met in London last week.

Bruce Paltrow's film, Duets, has several plot strands, each of which concerns a character trying to escape from his or her life and finding a way out through karaoke. Gradually, these people form three pairs, who drive for miles and end up meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, for a karaoke grand finale that will earn the winner $5,000. Because of the multiple storylines, there is no true leading role, but your attention is effortlessly drawn to Gwyneth, the only star actress in the film. She plays a young Las Vegas showgirl, whose long-lost father turns out to be a karaoke hustler in the guise of the Eighties pop singer Huey Lewis.

So what might be called the central couple is a father-daughter duo, rather than a romantic pairing, and it's noticeable that Gwyneth's character, the teenage Liv, is supposed to be a sexual innocent. At one point in the movie, the two have a row, in which Liv assures her father that she never had sex with Tom Jones, even though she slept in his bedroom. Meanwhile, she is wise to the hustle he performs in every bar; she's clean when it comes to sex and smart when it comes to money - a girl designed to please a father. Something Gwyneth once said about her father springs to mind - 'He told me, "Do you know why we went to Paris, just you and me, and why Mommy and Jake stayed in London? I wanted you to see Paris for the first time with a man who will love you for ever, no matter what".' Although Paltrow did not write the script for Duets , it almost looks like an overprotective, Oedipal fit of pique to eliminate romance from the film entirely.

However, the film's casting had its origins in a more triangular arrangement. Five years ago, when the project started out, Brad Pitt was due to star - not in the Huey Lewis part, of course, but in a role eventually played by Scott Speedman, a nice-looking boy, the pinnacle of whose romantic achievements in the film is a flirtatious smile exchanged with Gwyneth. It's not hard to imagine that the dynamic of Duets would have been rather different had Pitt stayed on. But, Paltrow explains: 'When the kids broke up, I didn't want to hold him to it - he had agreed to do it out of affection for me.'

This was, as he puts it, 'before Gwyneth's star had really risen'. Paltrow senior had worked mainly in television (he is best known for the hit series St Elsewhere, a hospital drama which was a precursor to shows like ER and Chicago Hope), and the studio was unwilling to finance the film when Pitt pulled out. But, as if by magic, Duets gained a star without having to cast a new one. Within a few years, Paltrow's daughter had become the source of the film's bankability and the project went ahead.

The story, told like this, is tough on Paltrow, since it raises two difficult questions about his relationship with his child: one is whether he now has to depend on a ride on her coat-tails, and the other is about their connection to the father and daughter within the film. Just before they started shooting, Paltrow underwent radical surgery for throat cancer, and Gwyneth has said that her fear, 'just the thought of being without him, informed how I played the part'. The lost and found father in the film was linked up with the devoted father directing it.

Armed with these facts, I arrive at the Dorchester hotel preparing to tread on some complicated territory. But as soon as Paltrow enters the room, all of those doubts begin to look like overelaborate and offensive suspicions. He is a warm, affable man, a classic New Yorker full of anecdotes and reminiscences, with a tendency to self-effacement. He has a leathery face, masked by glasses approaching the classic Michael Caine design, and a trim physique. He seems healthy; I don't know what he sounded like before his surgery, but he now has a quiet, gruff, lively voice - a sort of Fifth Avenue Mel Brooks.

He talks straight and speaks easily about his family, the way any proud husband and father would. 'I can't take a good picture,' he says when the photographer arrives, 'unlike my daughter, who can't take a bad one. It's true. I have pictures of her since she was this high, and there's not a single bad one.' They seem to have an enviably happy life - Gwyneth's Oscar speech appears less like gush and more like an expression of good fortune - and although one can never know the ways in which happy families are or are not all like, on meeting Paltrow, my willingness to pry into this one all but crumbles.

We talk about the film and the casting of Lewis. Paltrow says he thinks Lewis and Gwyneth are perfect together: 'I think he's so believable in that part.' I agree, although you wonder, I suggest, since the father hasn't seen his daughter all her life, if they're going to get together at the end. Paltrow looks shocked. I suppose you couldn't do that, I say, retreating. 'No,' he answers, 'you'd get put in prison.'

Paltrow's next project is a script he has written about a widower who has two daughters. One daughter goes to college, the other lives in Paris. When he returns home, he finds he has nothing - no wife, no children, no job. So he goes to be with his daughter in Paris, and the film, Paltrow says, 'is about what happens to him there'. I ask him what interests him about the father-daughter relationship. 'In life,' he asks, 'or in film?' Both, I say, and he sighs, not knowing where to start. 'Oh, I think parents and their children... it's ongoing, always changing... you must have that with your own father...' Did the fact that they've always been so close make it difficult for Gwyneth to rebel? 'Oh, Gwyneth had no problem with that,' he laughs. 'I think she was a very happy adolescent - she did everything the other adolescents did - went to parties, ducked out of school.'

Paltrow considers this the first time he has worked with his daughter, although he did cast her in a small TV role when she was five. Working with her was, he tells me, 'wonderful. Wonderful. When you work with your family you develop a shorthand. I'd know immediately if Gwyneth was uncom fortable with something she was doing, or happy or unhappy'. But mostly, he says, what was nice about the shoot was that 'the whole family was together for four weeks - my son came, my wife was there. We'll probably never have that again. It was fabulous'.

Would he direct her again? 'I would do it not so fast again. I think because of the media, and being asked questions that have nothing to do with the movie.' Apologising in advance, I ask a question that has nothing to do with the movie. How did he feel when his daughter starred opposite Michael Douglas in A Perfect Murder, given that Douglas is a friend of Bruce Paltrow's, and Gwyneth was cast as his wife? 'Oh,' Paltrow replies, almost laughing at himself, 'that was the only time I sort of went, whoa...you're working with Michael? What are you talking about? What's going on here, this is disgusting! But Gwyneth said, "Dad" [he leans forward], she'd say, " Dehhhhd "... it's a shame you can't get the inflection of that in print. Then I thought, you know, they're actors.'

People must ask him all the time how he feels about having a daughter more successful than him, I venture. 'Constantly. I hate that so much. I always say the same thing - I say I'm as proud and as happy as any father of any child who's successful. I was proud of her before she was famous and I'm proud of her now - she's my child.' But there's a saying, isn't there, that you should never beat your father at chess. 'Not where I come from,' Paltrow replies. 'In America, you always hope your children are more successful than you. My father did, and so did his father.'

Paltrow's family originally came to New York from Russia. His great-grandfather was a rabbi. Though it's hard to imagine how you might outshine a rabbi, the family lore is that each generation exceeded the achievements of the last. His father, who worked in the steel business, was the first in his family to go to college, but he had only completed one year before the Depression prevented him from continuing. So, in fact, Bruce was the first. He studied art and thought, since he loved the movies and didn't really want to become a painter, that he would do something in an allied field, like scenic art. He met Blythe Danner when he was doing a play off Broadway ('She walked out on stage, and I was dazzled. That was in January, and we got married in December') and the couple moved to Hollywood, to try their luck - 'We'll see how it turns out,' Paltrow jokes.

They arrived at a legendary moment, the brink of the period immortalised in Peter Biskind's book, Easy Riders, Raging Bulls. I ask Paltrow what Hollywood in the Seventies was like. 'Oh, gosh,' he sighs, 'you know, when you're in the middle of something you don't realise you're at a point of some significance. It's like Kierkegaard said, "The curious thing about despair is when you're in it you don't know it". When you're in the middle of something you have no idea how good it is either. We were just kids, you know. We were living on the beach. Blythe was pregnant with Gwyneth. We didn't have a television set, we had very little money. Everybody was going out with everybody else - we were like the married couple, so we were the quietest of the lot. We had charades - a lot of charades, a lot of basketball. We were just... kids. Everybody was kind of beginning.'

He goes on, happy at the memory: 'The big star was Steven Spielberg. He already had a sports car. He had a directing deal with Universal, so we already knew that Steven was a big deal. He was doing The Name of the Game, a television series. I met Martin Scorsese then. He was cutting [Paltrow tries to remember] ... and he was cutting Boxcar Bertha, and Brian [De Palma] was preparing a shock movie called Sisters. Oh, gosh - it was just our generation. It was a wonderful time. I don't know what to tell ya, it was just a wonderful time.'

The year here must be 1971, since the films Paltrow is talking about - not to mention the baby Blythe was pregnant with - came out in 1972. Paltrow tried his hand at writing scripts and then became a director and producer of TV shows. He found himself fascinated, then and now, by the same sort of subjects: 'Good people who struggle to succeed.' The theme was apparent in his cult series, The White Shadow , in which a white man teaches basketball, against the odds, in a black school, and in St Elsewhere, in which the best doctors fight to save lives in the hospital with the worst equipment. 'The world's a tough place,' Paltrow explains. 'I mean, there are only so many parking spaces and there's an awful lot of cars. Some people just have to work harder.' I ask if he considers himself to be one of those people and he thinks not: 'I can't say I was an underdog.'

Paltrow prefers directing features (he directed one before Duets, a film called A Little Sex , which was released in 1982 and starred Spielberg's present wife, Kate Capshaw), but 'happenstance' has meant that he has earned his stripes in television. He speaks very articulately about the difference between the two, about how TV shows are designed for audiences who will be doing other things at the same time, about what TV directors can bring to the movies. 'John Frankenheimer, Michael Mann, Norman Jewison, Sydney Pollack - they all came from television. I would say anyone with enough help can direct a movie. In television, you have to know what you're doing. I set up all the shots - it's second nature to me - but I like spending more time on a picture, and not just churning things out.'

Clearly, Paltrow knows how to make a film - he is a craftsman, of the kind that often gets lost in an era of auteurs. Though his TV shows always managed to plug into the Zeitgeist, he has yet to achieve such popularity in the movies. Whatever his future successes, he seems doomed to be known as 'Gwyneth's dad' - but then her upbringing is clearly also a project of which he's extremely proud.

webTitle: Feature: The Screen Actors Guild strike

fields.headline: Lights, cameras...  no action
fields.standfirst: The prospect of a strike next year by actors and writers has put Hollywood into a frenzy. The studios are desperate to get movies made before the industry is paralysed, and the stars are working frantically, while they can, and for inflated fees.  Joe Neumaier reports from an industry in crisis
fields.trailText: The prospect of a strike next year by actors and writers has put Hollywood into a frenzy. The studios are desperate to get movies made before the industry is paralysed, and the stars are working frantically, while they can, and for inflated fees. Joe Neumaier reports from an industry in crisis.
fields.body:
Audiences often complain that there just aren't enough good movies. But by next autumn, there may not be enough movies at all. The threat of strikes next year by the Screen Actors Guild (SAG), beginning on June 30, and the Writers Guild of America (WGA), on May 2 which could paralyse Hollywood, have left a palpable sense of fear in Entertainment Town.

The ill-tempered dispute primarily concerns residual payments in the expanding new media outlets. It also highlights the massive gulf between the conglomerates and high earning élite who control Hollywood and the majority working within the industry. If the strikes do happen, and the estimated length of inactivity could last from four to 16 months, moviegoers around the world should be prepared for a dearth of new films after autumn 2001. In the meantime, studios are stockpiling movies like emergency rations, and the mood of many screenwriters and journeymen actors is grim.

In contrast, the stars have found their pre-strike services are at a premium and many of them are working frantically while they still can. Several high-profile films have already been affected as actors' schedules become congested. The rat pack caper Ocean's Eleven, starring George Clooney and to be directed by Steven Soderbergh, is a good example. Soderbergh saw his ensemble cast change almost weekly as actors including Mark Wahlberg and Bruce Willis abandoned the oft-delayed film (now starting production in January) to do other projects before the strikes. Sam Raimi's Spider Man, which begins shooting in January and stars Tobey Maguire, was pushed back from a winter 2001 release date to summer 2002, for special effects work and a natural blockbuster berth, producers claim, though insiders say it allowed extra time in the event of a strike. A fifth Batman film has been put on indefinite hold by Warner Bros, while Men in Black 2 was moved out of a possible pre-strike start when Will Smith and Insider director Michael Mann's Mohammad Ali bio-pic punched its way into a January start.

Films on the fast track to be finished by SAG's deadline of June 30 include Basic Instinct 2, with David Cronenberg directing Sharon Stone, Timeline, an adaptation of Michael Crichton's time-travel novel, and Terminator 3. Additionally, many small-budget comedies have been shuffled into production, as they're inexpensive and easy to make.

The strike threat has forced Hollywood's leading actors and actresses to reassess their forthcoming projects, often concluding that they can't waste time on smaller films or projects stuck in development. After finishing her role in Ocean's Eleven , Julia Roberts will quickly get to Project 3, set to begin on 1 April, the last possible pre-strike start date. In contrast Leonardo DiCaprio is facing a lengthy screen hiatus. He is reportedly hesitant to start the conman thriller Catch Me If You Can in March so soon after finishing Martin Scorsese's epic Gangs of New York, currently shooting in Italy. And rising star Jet Li, who will have major roles in the two Matrix sequels, has just departed the long-gestating action flick The Green Hornet.

On the small screen, fans of Friends may have to alter their viewing habits. In fact, virtually any show with a writing staff would be affected, including sitcoms, late-night talk shows, daytime soap operas and TV movies. The one saving grace the US TV networks have is that a strike would begin just as the summer re-run season is starting; a work stoppage may simply mean extending that indefinitely. It sounds apocalyptic, and while some involved with negotiations between the 11,000 writers and the movie studios say it's premature to imagine the worst, that's exactly what some insiders are doing.

'I'm terrified, actually, as are many people I know,' says a 32-year-old film writer who has been in the business six years. 'We are working-class screenwriters - people who write three to four scripts a year, make a living at it, but aren't A-list writers. We don't make a million a script.'

The two main issues facing the WGA is re-negotiating residuals for TV writers in this age of cable, video, foreign rights, and the internet, and so-called 'vanity credits' or possessory credits - above-the-title banners such as 'Francis Ford Coppola's The Rainmaker ' or 'Wes Craven Presents Dracula 2000', banners which the guild argues diminishes the writer's contribution. Their solution is halting the placement of these vanity credits. One screenwriter feels that while vanity credits 'are abhorrent, none of us feels it's worth striking over. It affects a very small portion of writers'.

But Vito Turso, a Writers' Guild spokesman, argues the vanity credit issue is as important as residual payments. 'That's an area writers really are struck by,' he says. 'Producers simply bring a couple of folks together. Because someone facilitates something, that doesn't mean they created it. How about we give them "Facilitated by", how's that for a credit?'

Lori Lakin, 31, a former vice-president of feature production at Twentieth Century Fox and now a sitcom staff writer for NBC, says she can see the studio's side as well as the creative side. 'I'm aware that there's a bottom line, and it's the colour green. But until studios can create content internally somehow, the writer is still essential, like it or not. These issues are more viable now than ever. Our current WGA chief [John Wells, executive producer of ER] is a TV writer, and the studios know that the writer is in charge when it comes to TV.'

As for a possible SAG strike, that also deals primarily with residuals from video and cable. Many feel that the recently completed six-month strike by 135,000 commercial actors, which saw celebrities such as Kevin Spacey, Helen Hunt, and Nicolas Cage donating money to support actors on the picket line, demonstrated that the union could mobilise and unify behind a cause.

SAG spokesman Greg Krizman says that this new wave of negotiations 'is just the latest one. It happens every three years, and it's far too early to tell what might happen'. But SAG president William Dan-iels said recently: 'If there's enough talks about strikes then, by God, there will be strikes. But we're anxious to sit down and make a deal.'

That last sentiment seems to be shared by Mona Mangan, executive director of the Writers' Guild. Though adamant that the guild's pattern of demands be met, Mangan recently alerted guild members that panic was never a good plot development where strikes were concerned. 'Hard work and communication are what labour negotiation is about, not speculating about doomsday scenarios,' she said. 'Let's keep our eye on the ball and the drama on the screen.'

The winners and losers in the strike fallout

Winners

The biggest stars: The $20 million club - including Julia Roberts - is in great demand since star movies could soon be in short supply.

Non-US films: Especially if moviegoers tire of re-runs and hastily made B-movies.

West End theatres: Expect to see even unemployed Hollywood stars following Nicole Kidman, Kevin Spacey and Daryl Hannah on to London stages.

Losers

Hollywood and New York: The movie capitals of the world will be strangely subdued when the strike halts filmmaking.

Los Angeles restaurateurs: The eating holes famous for facilitating meals and deals will see a decline in custom and rise in job applications.

Film and TV crews: Non-union work is largely restricted to Los Angeles' booming adult movie sector.

The ill-tempered dispute primarily concerns residual payments in the expanding new media outlets. It also highlights the massive gulf between the conglomerates and high earning élite who control Hollywood and the majority working within the industry. If the strikes do happen, and the estimated length of inactivity could last from four to 16 months, moviegoers around the world should be prepared for a dearth of new films after autumn 2001. In contrast, the stars have found their pre-strike services are at a premium and many of them are working frantically while they still can.
