webTitle: Observer review: In the Shadow of a Saint by Ken Wiwa

fields.headline: The loyal hunt of the son
fields.standfirst: Ken Wiwa spent 26 years running away from his father's struggle. In the Shadow of a Saint tells how he learnt to accept his inheritance
fields.trailText: Ken Wiwa spent 26 years running away from his father's struggle. In the Shadow of a Saint tells how he learnt to accept his inheritance
fields.body:
In the Shadow of a Saint: a Son's Journey to Understand his Father's Legacy
Ken Wiwa
Doubleday £16.99, pp261
Buy it at BOL

In the autumn of 1994, Ken Saro-Wiwa wrote to his son from his cell in Nigeria: 'Dear Junior, I have not heard from you in months. Your father.'

Ken Wiwa was in London trying to ignore his father. Ignoring his father had become Junior's life's work. He had even legally changed his name from Ken Saro-Wiwa to Ken Wiwa, an attempt to shunt off a destiny he felt was his rightful, but unwanted, inheritance: 'Every time I stood before him, I saw the man I was supposed to become.'

In 1994, Saro-Wiwa was accused of the murders of four Ogoni chiefs, among them his own wife's brother. Saro-Wiwa had no hand in the killings but the dictator Sani Abacha wasn't going to be inconvenienced by mere facts, not when Saro-Wiwa's Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People was encouraging the minority group to demand their rights. Worse, Saro-Wiwa, an environmentalist, was upsetting the mighty Shell oil company. He had to be silenced.

The logical progression was for Ken Wiwa to continue his father's struggle. Which is why, in the autumn of 1994, Ken Wiwa was ignoring his father. It was the moment the 26-year-old had spent his life trying to avoid. A series of passionate letters travelled between father and son until a turning point was reached. Ken Wiwa quit his job and over the next year dedicated himself to saving his father, lobbying politicians and heads of state to intervene, writing articles, giving interviews. General Abacha was unmoved. On 10 November 1995, Ken Saro-Wiwa was hanged and his body destroyed by acid.

It had all the ingredients of a Shakespearean drama: Ken Saro-Wiwa was dead and his son was primed to avenge his death. 'But like Hamlet, I hesitated and left the stage altogether pleading political naivety and the need for time and space to deal with losing my father.' Hence this book, an attempt 'to set the record straight and about Ken Saro-Wiwa, to expose his critics and accuse his killers'.

Wiwa junior's earliest memories are of a colonial mansion in Nigeria 'surrounded by a sea of gardens' full of magnolia, orange, mango and palm trees. It was a home with music, servants, lavish parties, a beautiful mother and a fun father. Until Saro-Wiwa was fired from his government job. Then everything changed. Junior and his siblings were catapulted into the post-lapsarian world of an English boarding school. The only Africans in their school, the 'Wee-Wee' brothers had to fit in, at a cost to their Nigerian identity.

Their father 'expected we would all return to Nigeria and apply the expensive education to solving Nigeria's problems'. But relations between father and son frayed. Ken Wiwa felt increasingly isolated from Africa, which had become one with his distant, activist father. He preferred, in Saro-Wiwa's words, to loiter 'around the fringes of British society'.

Ken Wiwa does not spare himself in this story. He reveals self-truths he is not proud of. You feel for him. You feel for his father. His elegantly written book is a weave of Nigerian and family history, both turbulent, both tragic, neither without hope. The book is also a song of the Ogoni people, a tribute to their struggle, their endurance. It is, moreover, a story of being trapped in history; the children of heroes find their lives shaped by their parents, as Wiwa discovers when he meets Nkosinathi Biko, son of Steve Biko, Zindzi Mandela, and Aung San Suu Kyi.

Suu Kyi's parting words are: 'Best of luck in everything you do, Ken, because you know, we are one family in all of this.'

By the end of this poignant book, Ken Wiwa has returned to Nigeria for his father's funeral. It was a symbolic ceremony because Saro-Wiwa's remains have still not been returned to the family. Ken Wiwa's return was greeted by crowds of ecstatic Ogoni 'who had come to witness the reincarnation of Ken-Saro Wiwa'. Writing this book has led Ken Wiwa to accept his place in Africa's history - it is in his blood, in his face, in his name. There is still so much to do. 'So where does Ken Saro-Wiwa end and Ken Wiwa begin? I don't know. I have no idea where he ends, but I'm learning to accept and realise that I am my father's son.'

fields.headline: At last, something good emerges from Rwanda
fields.standfirst: Against an unlikely background, Elmore Leonard has produced a truly remarkable book
fields.trailText: Against an unlikely background, Elmore Leonard has produced a truly remarkable book
fields.body:
Pagan Babies
Elmore Leonard
Viking £16.99, pp263
Buy it at BOL

Hit List
Lawrence Block
Orion £16.99, pp296
Buy it at BOL

Sea Change
Robert Goddard
Bantam £16.99, pp405
Buy it at BOL

Breaking and Entering
HRF Keating
Macmillan £16.99, pp266
Buy it at BOL

Pagan Babies marks a triumphant return to form for America's finest crime writer. Year on year for three decades, Elmore Leonard has produced crime novels that, with few exceptions, have set the bench mark for other US writers. But while in the second half of the Nineties the triple whammy of the movie versions of Get Shorty, Jackie Brown and Out of Sight established his wider popularity - and his credentials as the hippest writer around - he seemed to be losing his way.

Cuba Libre (1998) was a not entirely successful quasi-return to the decidedly un-hip western stories that first established his reputation in the Fifties. A collection of those very stories came out the following year alongside his first sequel, Be Cool, the further adventures of Get Shorty's Chili Palmer. The novel had his trademark tight plotting, colourful characters and tough-funny dialogue but the elderly Leonard set it, unwisely, in the youth music business. There were, in consequence, some embarrassing passages.

Pagan Babies is, in some ways, his most ambitious novel yet. I can't think of (m)any authors who would have the confidence to set a crime story involving a clever but heartless con against the background of the Rwandan genocide - and then make it succeed both as a comedy and a love story of sorts. The central character, Father Terry Dunn, is an unlikely priest. With a background in cigarette smuggling and tax evasion, he starts the novel in the Rwandan war zone with a church converted to a tomb for 47 unburied, mutilated victims of a Hutu massacre. His idea of penance for some of the murderers necessitates a swift return to Detroit where he sets out to raise money for orphaned children (his pagan babies).

A meeting with wannabe stand-up comic Debbie Dewey gets him involved in her attempts to get back at a low-life who cheated her out of $67,000. The resulting scam involves hustling the mob, encounters with an exceedingly stupid hitman and a mordant story of con and counter-con, double-cross and triple-cross.

There are few superlatives left unused to describe Leonard's writing but Pagan Babies warrants superlatives for the way the fast-paced narrative is both moving and highly amusing. Remarkable.

Lawrence Block is another of American crime writing's multi-award winning old pros, with almost 50 novels and six collections of short stories to his credit. He already has three series characters - PI Matthew Scudder, bookshop owner-cum-burglar Bernie Rhodenbarr and spy Evan Tanner - but now there's a fourth, hitman John Keller. Keller had an engaging outing in last year's Hit Man, which was both an episodic novel and a collection of short stories. He returns in Hit List, a more traditional mystery novel in which he is appalled to discover that he is somebody else's target.

Keller is a likeable creation. Although you might think that Pulp Fiction and Grosse Point Blank had taken the notion of quirkily attractive hitmen as far as it can go, Block takes a different line with his character. There's nothing cool about Keller, even though in this novel he has an affair with a SoHo artist. He looks like a corporate man, always wears suits and ties and does his work to pay for the cost of his hobby - stamp collecting. He even does jury service.

Block's casual, meandering approach to telling his story may jar or entertain, according to taste. There's a lot of off-the-narrative-point chat between Keller and his 'broker', Dot. Sometimes their chat and Keller's ruminations about the big and small things in life are hilarious; sometimes they are wearisome - Keller is no Socrates Fortlow, Walter Mosley's philosophising ex-con. An enjoyable read, nevertheless.

British writer Robert Goddard's novels are not easy to categorise. His 12 contemporary and historical bestsellers - which include Past Caring, Caught in the Light, Set in Stone and Into the Blue, which made a disappointing TV film several years ago - have been variously described as mysteries, crime novels, thrillers and even historical romances. What they have in common is a strong narrative thrust and ingenious plotting, elements which are robustly evident in Sea Change.

This picaresque tale of high adventure and low intrigue takes place in 1721-22, just after the South Sea Bubble has burst. Goddard's novels almost always feature an ineffectual protagonist and William Spandrel, the impoverished mapmaker who is the central character here, is, by dint of circumstances, extremely ineffectual.

Entrusted with the secret delivery to Amsterdam of a great MacGuffin - an account book whose contents implicate the highest in the land in the corruption surrounding the South Sea Company - he swaps debtors prison in London for the threat of the hangman's noose in Holland. Thereafter, in an effort to clear himself, he embarks on a long, hazardous journey to the Jacobite court in Rome, where he gets embroiled in further intrigue. He is duped at every turn in every country he passes through by a wonderful cast of crooks, charlatans and real historical characters such as Robert Walpole, the future Chancellor of the Exchequer.

In Sea Change, the historical period is vividly conjured up and the narrative flows effortlessly. There is more adventure and less mystery in this than in some of Goddard's other books, but the result is engrossing, storytelling of a very high order.

Another week, another much loved fictional police detective bites the dust. H.R.F. Keating's latest Inspector Ghote novel, Breaking and Entering, will be the last. The Bombay police inspector first made his appearance a startling 36 years ago in the Gold Dagger-winning The Perfect Murder, published in 1964. And to bring the series happily full circle, the new novel reunites Ghote with Axel Svensson, the Swedish friend who helped him solve that perfect murder so many years ago.

This time, the duo are trying to solve the murder of a wealthy businessman in a tightly secure mansion at the same time as they are tracking down an ingenious cat-burglar who has been stealing jewellery from high-rise apartment blocks. Although it's the last in the series - Keating has already embarked on a new non-Indian series - there's nothing elegiac about the novel. Indeed, it's as fresh, lively and entertaining as the first - a delight.

webTitle: Observer review: The Journals of Woodrow Wyatt

fields.headline: Lechery and treachery
fields.standfirst: Woodrow Wyatt serves up another helping of betrayed confidences and vitriol in the third volume of his journals, but is it entertaining?
fields.trailText: Woodrow Wyatt serves up another helping of betrayed confidences and vitriol in the third volume of his journals, but is it entertaining?
fields.body:
The Journals of Woodrow Wyatt. Volume III: From Major to Blair
edited by Sarah Curtis
Macmillan £25, pp750
Buy it at BOL

It is unkind to focus on a simple slip-up, especially one that has been apologised for in advance. And it would be unfair to suggest that all Woodrow Wyatt's reminiscences in this third volume of posthumous journals are subject to similar vagaries. But when the aged Voice of Reason enthuses about a reunion with Bianca Jagger in such excitable terms, it is bound to attract attention.

'She is an amazing girl,' he writes on 18 June 1992. 'Full of sexual vitality which pours out at you. At one point she grasped my wrist and arm and got her sexuality on me. She was looking at me hard with her eyes. She must be like an octopus to go to bed with, wrapping her legs all around you.'

Disconcerting to learn, then, that the late Lord Wyatt of Weeford was actually talking to someone else that night. A note ruefully inserted by the publishers reads: 'WW refers to a meeting with Bianca Jagger which we now learn did not in fact take place. He mistook someone else for her. We apologise to Ms Jagger for any embarrassment caused.'

Whoever it was that captivated Wyatt she is not the only younger woman to win his approval in this volume. The boss's daughter, Liz Murdoch, gets the same treatment. She 'is highly sexed', we learn gratuitously after one encounter.

Unfortunately, it is a bit too obvious what Wyatt is trying to do. He must be a lecher, he thinks, if his personality is ever to leap off the page. In fact, the only bit of lasciviousness that really works in this journal is a silly passing reference to the bottom of the tennis star, Martina Hingis. It is an Alan Clark-like, inappropriate sort of lusting which is amusingly underlined by the inclusion of a completely irrelevant photograph of Hingis and her cherished cheeks, along with all the snaps of the Wyatt family, for whom the book's profits are intended.

Wyatt is deliberately trying to paint himself as a rogue, probably because he suspects it is the only way to commercial success. He clearly doesn't mind the idea that his daughter, the journalist Petronella, might one day put pen to paper about him. 'I said I didn't mind her making a fortune out of turning me into a comic figure,' he recalls, when he first uncovered plans for her recent memoir, Father, Dear Father.

The author knows that he must also mix in a high quotient of vitriol. He is really teed off, for instance, when Robin Day turns up on a holiday and begins to hold court. There is particular pleasure taken too, in exposing the less generous sides of those public figures who have otherwise specialised in appearing sweet-natured. Wyatt has John Major slagging off John Prescott as a 'hypocrite', who is 'ignored by the rest of the Cabinet'. The Queen Mum, in turn, is quoted as judging John Major to be 'weak'.

Such betrayals of confidence are, of course, the stock-in-trade of the diarist, but in Wyatt's case the technique doesn't sit well with his much-trumpeted belief in the need for privacy laws. Several times he went against his editorial masters at the News of the World on this issue.

All private diarists are entitled to be inconsistent egotists, but when you decide to go into print you have a duty at least to entertain and there are three problems with Wyatt's attempts to do this. First, because he was a journalist, unlike Alan Clark, all his best stories were delivered up to the public at the time. Second, Wyatt is not prepared to be revealing enough about the areas of his life which were truly odd. Third, his writing lacks Clark's imaginative phrasing.

There are tantalising hints, however, of the faux-aristo domestic set-up with Lady Verushka (who fellow Hungarians still remember as 'Vera from Golders Green') and the winsome Petronella, known to her father as 'the St John's Wood nightingale'.

webTitle: Observer review: On Histories and Stories by AS Byatt

fields.headline: A one-woman intelligence network
fields.standfirst: AS Byatt reveals herself as a writer of broad sympathies and keen insight in her collection of essays, On Histories and Stories
fields.trailText: AS Byatt reveals herself as a writer of broad sympathies and keen insight in her collection of essays, On Histories and Stories
fields.body:
On Histories and Stories
AS Byatt
Chatto & Windus £16.99, pp352
Buy it at BOL

I can't remember ever being so angry on someone else's behalf as when I read, in Martin Amis's autobiography, the comment that AS Byatt was 'justly famous for her novels, her short stories, and her inability to get off the telephone'.

Well, as far as I'm concerned, AS Byatt can stay on the telephone as long as she likes. She is a rare and perhaps unique figure; a critic whose insights are full of a sympathetic, creative and re-creative imagination, a novelist whose fictions are wise with the knowledge of what has been done, as well as what can be. Hers is a roaming, trustworthy intelligence; she is interested, it sometimes seems, in absolutely everything, and she has the magical gift of persuading the reader that he is as intelligent as she is.

Her novels have long been filled with a critical sensibility. Many of her best books are arguments with texts, real and imagined; her remarkable The Biographer's Tale, for instance, is filled with the romance of scholarship. The long sequence which began with The Virgin in the Garden is a strange, rich history of England after the war, conducted not through public events but through a history of its imaginative events, from the Spenserian fantasy which was dredged up in the wake of a new Elizabeth to, in Babel Tower, the excuses for personal conduct which the 1960s chose to find in Sade and Blake.

Most splendid is Possession, which taught a generation how to write, that luxurious exploration of text upon text, an erotic hymn both to the palimpsest and the moments when literature fails and there is only one body upon another.

The mind that produced these splendid, strange fictions is also a first-rate critical intelligence. As she says in this collection of essays and lectures: 'Teaching good reading [is] the best way of encouraging, and making possible, good writing.' Good writers are always good readers, and there is no better reader than AS Byatt. Her criticism rises above the intrinsically ephemeral nature of all criticism, not just because it is the work of a major novelist, but because it is infused with a particular, unorthodox sensibility; a puritan seriousness, allied to a keen appreciation of physical pleasures, a reader who is fiercely protective of the autonomy of texts, whose best readings, nevertheless, are wonderful reimaginings of the literary process.

That reimagining is at full stretch in a splendid essay here about images of ice and glass in fictions about women, which brilliantly connects The Winter's Tale and The Lady of Shalott with literary and naive folk-tales, Snow White and The Snow Queen of Hans Christian Andersen. Here, one has the sense not just of a reader making connections, but of a writer delving into fruitful ground, of finding what may be of use. webTitle: Observer review: Bettany's Book by Thomas Keneally

fields.headline: Inside the outsiders
fields.standfirst: Thomas Keneally welds two enormous stories together in Bettany's Book
fields.trailText: Thomas Keneally welds two enormous stories together in Bettany's Book
fields.body:
Bettany's Book
Thomas Keneally
Sceptre £16.99, pp400
Buy it at BOL

'Do you think there is something wrong with our family? Is it in the heart, in the blood, in the brain?' So asks one member of the Bettany family to another. If there is anything wrong with the Bettanys it is perhaps that they suffer from a touching naivety. Jonathan Bettany, a nineteenth-century sheep farmer, and Primrose Bettany, a twentieth-century aid worker, battle in desperate situations in different parts of the world, and at different times, against their family's past and in a desperate hope for their own futures, to reach a kind of self-knowledge.

Jonathan struggles with himself and the terrain in New South Wales in what was known as 'The Limits of Location', Primrose's landscape and horrors are played out in Sudan, where on a mission she 'discovers' a famine which threatens 300,000 people, whilst above her disinterested satellites peer over the earth. Both Bettanys are outsiders and this is principally what they have in common, struggling in lands in which they fear they may not belong, both are innocent, well-meaning, stoical and, at times, foolish; both feel tremendous guilt for the suffering around them.

The Bettanys are not the only outsiders; there are many ticket-of-leave convicts, some from Ireland, some England, one half-Cherokee Indian, one half-Australian-half-Serbian ex-wife, an Italian POW, and while Jonathan's second wife is a part-Jewish convict from England, Primrose's lover is a Sudanese doctor who confesses: 'I'm disapproved of by some of my relatives. They think me something of a Westerner in disguise.'

The most interesting of these outsiders, though, is Felix Bettany, Jonathan's ward, a mulatto, whose aboriginal mother was impregnated and murdered by a white. Felix, an infant prodigy, learns to read Horace and become adept at geometry. There is something heartbreaking about this intelligent and earnest man, who, when discovered by Jonathan near to his mother's corpse, was unable to stop an exasperating grin distorting his face and who in his turn will commit murder. The tale of Felix, scholar and herdsman, neither white nor aboriginal, ends triumphantly in modern-day Singapore, where his descendant Sir Malik Bettany is the owner of a large bank.

Both narratives are dense and complicated, and sitting together the weight of information in Keneally's 600-page novel threatens to drown out the stories. At times it feels as if there are two novels uncomfortably welded together, the narratives so frequently interrupting each other. At other times they mirror each other wonderfully.

In the last 150 pages Keneally achieves an extraordinary feat by pulling this enormous work together, driven by the sudden urgency of their narratives. This is a difficult, sprawling, brave and ultimately rewarding novel.

webTitle: Observer review: Hooking Up by Tom Wolfe

fields.headline: Tom, Tom, turn around
fields.standfirst: Can Tom Wolfe ever live up to his legend? Hooking Up suggests not
fields.trailText: Can Tom Wolfe ever live up to his legend? Hooking Up suggests not
fields.body:
Hooking Up
Tom Wolfe
Jonathan Cape £16.99, pp293
Buy it at BOL

It was O-level time in Liverpool. The Summer of Love, as I recall. Reading Tom Wolfe's The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby (1965) on my knees under a desk while I was failing to pay attention to what the Northern Universities Joint Matriculation thought was good for me, I discovered a slick and sassy world which seemed to offer opportunities unknowable at home. It was truly a means of escape.

I didn't then know that it was called The New Journalism, but I was utterly jazzed by the neologisms, street smarts, sharp suits, seductive, high-octane, volatile Americana, sesquipedalian sentences and irreverent ideas. I was in awe of Wolfe's ability to combine microscopically acute visual observation together with a fine ear and an unknowable alchemy of getting the right words in the right cadences and proportions within a sentence to express something that has often been thought, but never said anything like as well.

This New Journalism was also the province of Gay Talese and Hunter S. Thompson. Talese was a Manhattan boulevardier of whom you hear little nowadays, perhaps on account of his name. Thompson was and remains a freak in thrall to intoxicants, hypnotics, stimulants, narcotics and a dangerously schismatic perspective on the American Dream.

His own description of New Journalism remains the best: 'Holy shit, if I can write like this and get away with it, why should I keep trying to write like the New York Times ? It was like falling down an elevator shaft and landing in a pool of mermaids.'

Wolfe was the same, but different. He was always a man apart. Sure, he had become a suave New York partygoer, but was in essence an old-fashioned Southern gent: a conservative moralist in a white suit. There's no reason to doubt Wolfe's own explanation. A PhD from Yale had not fully prepared him for his first journalistic assignment, reporting on drag racing from a strip in California. He made his notes, but could not finish the story. In despair as the deadline loomed, he typed up his scribbles and connected the jottings with what sub-editors call leader dots. Nathalie Sarraute more beautifully called them points de suspension. Whatever - a new and intoxicating style of writing was born.

Wolfe's journalism reached its peak in 1979 with his spell-binding account of the US space programme: The Right Stuff was a classic blend of meticulous observation, frontier heroics and brilliantly assimulated techno-jargon. It was probably his best book, although The Bonfire of the Vanities in 1987 is the one that made him an international celebrity.

Now the journalist had turned novelist, although both critics and admirers accept that Bonfire's strengths were more in reportage than in imagination. Its success riled the US literary establishment and for this hubris he received a drubbing. Maureen Dowd said in the Sunday New York Times that in Bonfire Wolfe 'had a hard time getting in front of his satire. He couldn't mock the masters of the universe as fast as they could make mockeries of themselves'.

I'm not so sure: Bonfire is one of the great books of the second half of the twentieth century, but maybe she had a point. Hooking Up is Wolfe's latest collection of journalism, which includes 'My Three Stooges' - his revisionist attack on Norman Mailer, John Updike and John Irving and, indeed, American literature as a whole. Other material, originally published in the American Spectator, Forbes and Harper's, and the story 'Ambush at Fort Bragg', a sort of warm-up loop for his ultimately disappointing 1998 social realist shelf-buster, A Man in Full, also appears here. The title essay is an account of millennial America with too many references to oral sex.

There is no living writer I admire more than Wolfe, so it makes me sad that this collection has a feeling of staleness. Wolfe once gave us unforgettable expressions which defined whole periods and sensibilities. Not just 'the Right Stuff', but also 'Radical Chic' and 'The Me Decade'. Here 'Rococo Marxists' is not so good. It won't catch on. The energy and invention are missing.

Wolfe's passion is the United States during what he memorably called its Bourbon Louis Romp and its 'lurid carnival'. He writes best about what he loves and understands. Historically, while always sharp and entertaining, his least satisfactory books have been his art criticism, The Painted Word (1975) and From Bauhaus to Our House (1981).

In these he allowed the cross curmudgeon to get the upper hand over the brilliantly dandified social observer. Hooking Up has the same feel. Wolfe should, for instance, have been the truest chronicler of Silicon Valley, the new frontier that dominates contemporary life and business in the United States. Instead, it has been left to far, far less talented writers including Michael Wolff (Burn Rate), Kurt Andersen (The Turn of the Century) and Michael Lewis (The New New Thing) to describe the electronic landgrab. Wolfe writes about it here, in 'Two Young Men Who Went West', his account of Intel. It is a good read, but way below his best in terms of style, humour and energy.

America, Maureen Dowd said, is now so wacko that 'satire... [is]... simply redundant'. If true, bad news for America's greatest satirist.

fields.headline: Poker - it's the new snooker
fields.standfirst: John Sweeney catches up with poker pros vying for a £1m jackpot in the Isle of Man, as promoters in Britain latch on to the game
fields.trailText: A thunderhead of cigarette smoke hanging above like a Hiroshima cloud in the cathedral of poker, an intense concentration on the cards as they flopped and the faces - oh! - the faces. The fat man greedy, lascivious; the Professor, learning and intellect and, yes, passion, too, all gone to hell; the youngster hard bitten, a hint of cruelty in his hooded eyes; and the loser, his face fallen as he runs out of matches.
fields.body:
A thunderhead of cigarette smoke hanging above like a Hiroshima cloud in the cathedral of poker, an intense concentration on the cards as they flopped and the faces - oh! - the faces. The fat man greedy, lascivious; the Professor, learning and intellect and, yes, passion, too, all gone to hell; the youngster hard bitten, a hint of cruelty in his hooded eyes; and the loser, his face fallen as he runs out of matches.

And this was just the press room. Cleaning The Daily Telegraph out of Swan Vestas is all very well, but next door the real action was less dramatic, more workaway, which was odd, really, because the world's greatest professional players were competing for a prize of £1m.

Hustlers like Chris 'Jesus' Ferguson, Dave 'Devilfish' Ulliot and Stetson-hatted Amarillo Slim, a drawl in cowboy boots, were all there.

Today the tournament, for which players paid £6,000 each to take part, concludes when the opening field of 160 will be narrowed down to six. The winner takes it all.

Philanthropy is not a principal feature of the tournament. PR, lobbying and TV rights are. Ladbroke Casinos and sports promoter Barry Hearn are out to make poker the new snooker. Sky TV is showing the final, cashing in on Channel 4's success with Late Night Poker. Watching the poker on telly is much more fun than in real life because, thanks to a glass table and a camera underneath, you can see the hands. Best of all, you can see the bluffs.

The advantage of seeing it in the flesh is that you can breathe the essence of professional gambling. It is difficult to conjure up a collective noun for poker players. A 'hand' is too obvious. Maybe a 'smoke'. Or, so long as The Observer can convey the irony, 'an honesty'. It is wrong to characterise people on the basis of how they appear, so the collection of humanity in the long room of the Douglas Hilton in the tax haven of the Isle of Man for the past week should not be described as the most amazingly dodgy seedy-looking types imaginable.

It's the body language, stupid. Ordinary people in a gathering like to open out and be inclusive. They will smile and defer to each other. Professional gamblers make an art form out of closing down their non-verbal communication. So a gathering of them makes you feel uneasy.

So, too, does the hidden agenda. The big money behind gambling is out to ridicule the 'archaic' rules of the Gaming Act and convince the Government to open gambling up: the more fun poker is made out to be, the bigger the profits.

The press get free icecreams, free sandwiches and, reportedly, free hotel rooms. But most importantly of all, the press gets free access to the players. Amarillo Slim gives great copy. He made so much money on one bet, he said, 'there were enough $100 bills there to burn 20 wet mules. It takes a lot of dollar bills to burn a wet mule'.

Hearn was somehow less photogenic, less quotable. And the suits from Ladbroke Casinos were almost, but not quite, invisible. They weren't the TV stars. But it is their show. The players themselves look like extras from Minder, or The Sweeney, the blokes who get bumped off in the first five minutes. Correction, they are the extras.

Take Simon 'Aces' Trumper, who sports dark sunglasses at 1.30 in the morning, gold bangles and a steely glare. He was a film extra, until the lure of poker overcame his wish to be the new Robert De Niro. Take Ross Boatman, a friendly Jack-The-Lad who used to star in London's Burning.

As the hours rolled by, the sudden death knock-out took its toll. Out went 'Jesus' Ferguson, the current World Series Champion, a gentle-spoken American. Out went Liam Flood, a clever, subtle Irish bookie.

But still in was Barney Boatman - Ross's brother. While all the other poker players have the body language of a long-dead armadillo, Barney, a one-time computer programmer, twitches, looks around, jokes and starts up and down. He sends out so many signals, he's unreadable. Brilliant.

But there is something curiously passionless about the main event. Nearly all the players are pros, hoping to win a million. If they get knocked out, they only lose their £6,000 starting stake, which is small change.

On the side tables you see the real game. Multi-millionaire George 'The Greek' Paravoliasakis was playing six or seven pros, and losing tens of thousands of pounds every hour. He's so wealthy it does not matter to him. Devilfish was one of the players. It probably helped that, as he played, he was being a given a vigorous massage by a Korean masseuse.

George the Greek likes to be the centre of attention. His chair was turned round the wrong way. He had a side bet of £10,000 with an Austrian. George showed a pair of kings, the Austrian a pair of aces. George threw his cards down like a three-year-old as the Austrian counted his chips. He challenged the other players: 'No guts, no nuts.' And still they took money off him.

webTitle: William Peakin on sex in space

fields.headline: Did the Earth move for you, darling?
fields.standfirst: Sex in space has been a taboo subject - until now. William Peakin on Nasa's bid to cross the final frontier
fields.trailText: Sex in space has been a taboo subject - until now. William Peakin on Nasa's bid to cross the final frontier.
fields.body:
They are calling it the 200-mile-high club - after decades of avoiding the subject, space travel experts are preparing for the first orbital docking between man and woman.

The arrival of an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts at the International Space Station earlier this month heralded a new era in which people will learn to live and work in space for long periods. The next crew, due to arrive in February, will include an American woman.

Nasa has always avoided the topic of sex in space, and Russia's explorations in this area have been cloaked in Cold War secrecy. But the agencies involved in the ISS have been forced to confront the issue after the publication in a specialist journal last week of an exhaustive study on the effects of isolation on astronauts.

Professor Stephen Johnson, editor of Quest, a quarterly journal on the history of space flight, said one passage of the study dealt with how astronauts coped with sexual stress in space. 'We don't know in long duration space flight whether cosmonauts or astronauts masturbate and relieve their sexual tension that way,' Dr Victor Schneider, chief physician for the Nasa/Mir mission, told the study's author. 'As long as they do it in private, it's a potential relief of sexual problems that may have occurred.'

Johnson, who is also assistant professor of space studies at the University of North Dakota, said that while some aspects of the study may grab people's attention for the wrong reasons, they were relevant to the subject. 'The article breaks new ground.' The 15,000-word, peer-reviewed study, The Psychological and Social Effects of Isolation on Earth and in Space , was written by science journalist Peter Pesavento, who investigated allegations of adultery in space by two Russian cosmonauts, the watching of pornographic videos on board spacecraft, and plans to film a couple having sex on Mir.

Pesavento said: 'There are issues that both the Russian and American space medicine communities have not yet definitively resolved, including depression during orbit, less-than-encouraging social interactions with mixed-gender and mixed-foreign national groups, sensory deprivation, as well as the emotional and sexual effects of close confinement on crew members.'

American comment on the ultimate contact has been limited to unofficial testimony. Harry Stine, a former Nasa technician, recalls in his book Life in Space how weightless sex was simulated - after hours - in a buoyancy tank used for astronaut training. 'It was possible but difficult,' he said, 'and was made easier when a third person assisted by holding one of the others in place.'

Pesavento said the Russians were now more forthcoming about the problems of isolation, revealing in diaries from the time their depressions and anxieties. 'No need to say what we're longing for,' wrote Dr Valery Polyakov, who holds the space endurance record for his 14-month stay on board Mir in 1992. 'Men think about those things. One can't turn away from them. But these thoughts somehow fade with time. Perhaps there is some tension building up, but "pollution" helps to unload it for a while. Then all these feelings become suppressed once again. When preparing for return to Earth, we try to regain them. Psychological Support Service sent us some nice, "colourful" movies which help to recover our will, to act like a normal adult male. There is nothing to be ashamed of. We all have wives...'

Polyakov is rumoured to have been the first member of the 200-mile-high club, along with his fellow - and married - cosmonaut, Yelena Kondakova. But allegations that the two had sex during a mission have been brushed off by them and denied by officials.

Polyakov was once asked if any 'experiments' in human reproduction had taken place. He replied: 'Only in animals. And only by the Americans. Any information that such experiments were made in the Russian program is not true.'

The cosmonaut did, however, reflect on human sexuality in space: 'It would be desirable to have a normal sex life in long-term space flights. Some people have asked me about ways of compensating for sexual abstention in space, particularly about using a doll one can buy in a sex shop.

'I strongly opposed such a solution. A person who is using such things may develop so-called "doll syndrome" or, in other words, start preferring the doll to their own spouse or loved one, even after they return to Earth.

But tensions do arise. Last January a Canadian scientist taking part in a 136-day visit to a Mir simulation module was sexually assaulted by a cosmonaut while two of his colleagues, who had been drinking vodka during New Year celebrations, had a fist fight.

webTitle: It's official:gays do NOT harm forces

fields.headline: It's official:gays do NOT harm forces
fields.standfirst: Six months on, confidential MoD report reveals no adverse effects on morale or recruitment
fields.trailText: It was supposed to lead to the collapse of Britain's military might. Faced with the prospect of gays in the armed forces, traditionalists warned that discipline would be compromised and heterosexual heroes would be outraged.
fields.body:
It was supposed to lead to the collapse of Britain's military might. Faced with the prospect of gays in the armed forces, traditionalists warned that discipline would be compromised and heterosexual heroes would be outraged.

But 10 months after the ban on gay servicemen was lifted, the first assessment of the consequences has found that the effect on morale has been non-existent.

A confidential Ministry of Defence Review, obtained by The Observer, states that the introduction of gays has had no adverse effects on the operational effectiveness of the forces. The startling conclusion will cause serious embarrassment to service chiefs, who fought to retain the ban, and to the Conservative Party, which has pledged to consider its reintroduction.

MoD staff canvassed the Army, Navy and RAF in August, six months after the ban was lifted. 'The services reported that the revised policy on homosexuality had no discernible impact, either positive or negative, on recruitment,' says the report.

'There is widespread acceptance of the new policy. It has not been an issue of great debate. In fact, there has been a marked lack of reaction. Generally there has been a mature, pragmatic approach which allowed the policy to succeed. The change in policy has been hailed as a solid achievement.'

The ban, which led to up to 200 sackings a year, was lifted in January after the European Court of Human Rights ruled it unlawful.

The court awarded £400,000 compensation to four military personnel who claimed that their dismissal was a breach of rights to privacy and family life. One, former navy Commander Duncan Lustig-Prean, was awarded £144,000. Hundreds of other cases await settlement.

The MoD report has not been published in Britain, but a summary was sent inadvertently three weeks ago to a military policy researcher at the University of California. Aaron Belkin, assistant professor of politics at the university, said: 'Looking at the situation from overseas, it appears there was a full-scale rhetorical assault on gays in the military, prior to this ban being lifted. This report from the MoD appears to admit that the arguments put forward were absolutely and profoundly untrue.'

An MoD spokesman insis-ted: 'We are pleased. Generally people have taken a pragmatic view of the change. We had one policy that was right until earlier this year. Now we have another.'

Angela Mason, director of the campaign group Stonewall, which backed the European Court cases, said: 'This report shows that the worst fears of some politicians have come to nothing.

'Opposition to gay law reform, whether over section 28, the age of consent or military service, is repeatedly rooted in unrealistic fears of the consequences.'

At Rank Outsiders, the gay service organisation, chairman Steve Johnston said: 'Most of those who objected strongly to this are old soldiers who were just unenlightened. It's society that is changing quite rapidly.

'We've had to deal with one or two minor complaints from gay personnel about their treatment this year, but they have been resolved swiftly. The MoD has asked us to go straight to them with any cases of bullying and have assured us that they will be dealt with at the highest levels.'

Johnston, a former Military Police sergeant, said: 'Of the hundreds of people we are in touch with, some have chosen to say nothing. They still see the way in which former colleagues were traumatised by their treatment.

'The services are not just a job, they are a way of life, and some people had all that taken away from them for no reason.'

The most senior officer re-admitted to active service since the ban was overturned is Michael Griffiths, a naval lieutenant-commander dismissed in 1994. One Wiltshire-based army brigadier re-signed last January, insisting that he was protesting at the removal of the ban. However, he agreed to continue serving until the end of 2001.

Prior to its removal, the ban on gay service personnel was last discussed in Parliament in 1995. Defending it, Conservative Armed Services Minister Nicholas Soames said that the services should not be 'bludgeoned out of the esprit de corps that has won every war since 1812'.

An officer in The Parachute Regiment said yesterday: 'I've known of one case since the lifting of the ban where the lads have assumed someone to be gay. He has been left alone and is doing well. Our key priority is recruiting tough, fit, team players. We need as many as possible. This sex thing has nothing whatsoever to do with their ability as soldiers. It appears to be an obsession of armchair warriors.'

Turkey is the only Nato country to retain a blanket ban on gays in the military.

webTitle: Terror plot against religious targets foiled

fields.headline: Terror plot against religious targets foiled
fields.trailText: Police in the West Midlands are believed to have smashed a ring plotting a series of terrorist attacks on religious targets.
fields.body:
Police in the West Midlands are believed to have smashed a ring plotting a series of terrorist attacks on religious targets.

More than 30 officers searched a number of properties in the Sparkbrook area of Birmingham in a dawn raid, and a small quantitiy of explosives and a number of detonators were removed. They were destroyed in two controlled explosions at a local park.

Sources in the Army's bomb disposal unit said that while the quantities involved were small, the material was highly dangerous and capable of causing death or significant structural damage.

A police spokesman told The Observer : 'These inquiries are connected to international terrorism and are not related to Irish affairs.'

A Vauxhall car, connected to the inquiry, was wrapped in plastic and carried away for detailed forensic examination. The spokesman refused to speculate about possible targets or go into detail about other material recovered from the properties.

According to neighbours, the arrested man is of Bengali origin, around 25 and living with his wife, mother, brother and two young sons. The family are believed to have lived in the area for more than 15 years and are said to be 'extremely religious'.

Six months ago, West Midlands police and officers from MI5 raided an Islamic bookshop in the same area following concerns about material being sold. Sparkhill is home to a number of extreme movements and several mosques are said to be home to secret military training camps.

webTitle: More men than women are asking to work from home

fields.headline: More men than women are asking to work from home
fields.trailText: Fathers are leading the workplace revolt against long office hours, according to a new government study which explodes the myth that only mothers want to fit their jobs around their families.
fields.body:
Fathers are leading the workplace revolt against long office hours, according to a new government study which explodes the myth that only mothers want to fit their jobs around their families.

The first official survey of trends in 'work-life balance' shows more men than women are now demanding to be able to work from home at least part of the week. It comes as Ministers are putting the final touches to the Green Paper on parental leave, which is expected to give new prominence to men's rights as parents when it is published at the end of the month.

The wide-ranging study of thousands of staff and bosses, to be unveiled tomorrow by the Employment Minister, Margaret Hodge, covers every aspect of juggling work and family. It will be used to encourage new ways of working that let staff have a life outside the office.

Its most surprising conclusion is that New Man is keener to get out of the rat-race than his partner, suggesting either that working women have struggled so hard to get into the boardroom they are reluctant to let go, or that they worry that, if they work from home, both job and family will suffer from domestic distractions. About 38 per cent of men compared to only 29 per cent of women want to work from home, and while nearly a quarter of the men interviewed by researchers from the University of Warwick already managed to do so at least occasionally, only one in six of the women did.

'It is a really interesting gender difference, but perhaps what work-life balance is about is people wanting control of their own time and that's as true of men as it is of women,' said a senior source. 'For them it is not necessarily about how long you work but where and how you work, and if you have autonomy over that. It is surprising, but when you start thinking about it perhaps women don't want necessarily to worry about the children and the washing machine while they are working.'

More than a third of those who wanted to work from home said it was because they would be more efficient at their jobs that way. Only 5 per cent said it was purely to look after their children, suggesting the other benefits of getting out of the office - such as cutting out commuting - are key motivations.

While more than a fifth of the 2,500 companies questioned said they would consider requests to work from home, only 8 per cent of workers believed their boss would let them - suggesting either that staff are being too timid in asking, or businesses are pretending to be much more generous than they really are.

Working from home was most common among professionals and least common among manual workers.

The Department for Education and Employment will repeat the survey in three years' time.

webTitle: Bank statements that reveal your true personality

fields.headline: Bank statements that reveal your true personality
fields.trailText: Bank statements cannot only tell you how rich you are, they can uncover the innermost secrets of your psyche and place you directly into one of three distinct personality types, according to research by a leading psychologist.
fields.body:
Bank statements cannot only tell you how rich you are, they can uncover the innermost secrets of your psyche and place you directly into one of three distinct personality types, according to research by a leading psychologist.

Dr Richard Wiseman, of the University of Hertfordshire, examined bank statements from dozens of customers at the Woolwich and used them as a tool of psycho-analysis. He divided the statements into one of three categories: Hedonistic Grazers, Material Martyrs and Steady Builders.

'It started out as a bit of fun but I quickly realised that you can actually analyse someone quite accurately from just looking at their bank statement. On close examination, it contains a lot of information,' Wiseman said.

Hedonistic Grazers were identified by frequent trips to the cash machine, taking out small amounts on almost a daily basis. They rarely plan ahead and make endless trips to supermarkets, buying provisions as they go. By the end of the month they are usually overdrawn.

Wiseman saw them as people who needed instant gratification and sought pleasure at every opportunity with no sense of planning for the future. In Freudian terms, they would be called 'highly oral'.

On the other side of the equation are Material Martyrs. These are people who make only a few trips a month to the bank, withdrawing enough cash to last for weeks.

They only go to the supermarket once or twice a month and they pay most of their bills by direct debit and rarely go into the red.

The Martyrs would feel guilty about carrying out acts of pleasure, restricting themselves to occasional treats. Any sign of extravagance would be frowned upon. They would also be masters of time-management, very frugal and highly organised.

'Freud would have called this lot quite anal,' Wiseman said. 'It is amazing how easily this technique fitted in with this aspect of Freudian theory.'

The final type, the Steady Builder, has no equivalent in Freudian analysis. These are people whose statement is dominated by a mortgage payment, who make few trips to restaurants and have a high number of debit card payments, often for things like the internet, and occasional enormous bills from the supermarket.

These people, Wiseman concluded, were older home-owners and both the Hedonistic Grazers and Material Martyrs were likely to one day turn into them.

Wiseman followed up the analysis with personality tests of 50 volunteers and found that he had accurately identified 75 per cent of the bank statements correctly. 'That's a high correlation, a long way beyond what chance would have predicted,' he said.

The research could also help banks and building societies target their products better. By analysing monthly bank statements in psychological terms, bankers can build up a personality profile and then send information about suitable products.

webTitle: Today's teens need labels not love

fields.headline: They said they wanted a revolution. You want the money
fields.standfirst: John Arlidge and Vanessa Thorpe visit Pop2000 and discover all today's teens need is labels, not love
fields.trailText: John Arlidge and Vanessa Thorpe visit Pop2000 and discover all today's teens need is labels, not love
fields.body:
Meet Ade, Danielle, Ryan and Lisa. They look like any other streetwise teenagers. It is 10am and they are heading off to meet their friends for a Saturday in town. But this is no ordinary weekend - they are heading for Britain's first teen lifestyle 'exhibition'.

Pop2000, which takes place in Birmingham this weekend, is Britain's biggest ever gathering of teenagers. It is big, hot and colourful, and provides an instant picture of twenty-first century youngsters. Thirty years ago, the festival would have been a mini-Woodstock of tie-dye fashion, fertility rights and naked dancing. The musicians would have sung of rebellion, alienation and changing the world.

What do today's teenagers want? Hippy fashions have been replaced by logo-heavy T-shirts and the latest £100 'must have' Adidas shell trainers. Love is still in the air, but it is love of manicures, hair styling and Tommy Girl fragrances; shopping is the new snogging. The only drugs anyone wants are the ones that keep you slim, firm your bust, or build up your Robbie Williams-style pecs. And what about music - the outpouring of disaffected youth? S-Club 7 are on stage telling the assembled teens to 'reach for the top'.

As their parents sit in the 'adults' crèche' trying to remember the rebellious Sixties, their children are out there spending their money to prop up the system. Forget Generation X and Generation Y. Generation £ is selling itself and letting itself be bought.

Big business has taken over Pop2000, turning Birmingham's NEC into more of a mall than a teenage fan club. 'It is the name that does it, definitely the name,' says Danielle, as she walks past the 'Diesel - for successful living' fashion stand. 'I love labels. If it doesn't have the label, I won't buy it. Labels are everything. It's about looking right, being part of something, of a group,' adds Ade.

And a new label is on the way. One of the chief sponsors of Pop2000 is Popworld, a global music brand launched this autumn, which aims to rival the Disney empire. Popworld, created by ex-Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller and marketing executive Robert Dodds, is already so successful the company has raised £10m to set up a theme park.

Around 50,000 teenagers log on to the patented Popworld website everyday for their fix of pop gossip. Dodds and Fuller, who now manages S-Club 7, are aiming directly at the untutored appetites of the young. fields.headline: Youth jails 'must be closed'
fields.standfirst: Prisons inspector urges Home Secretary to shut down 'barbaric warehouses'
fields.trailText: Youth prisons have become barbaric warehouses that should be closed immediately, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.
fields.body:
Youth prisons have become barbaric warehouses that should be closed immediately, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.

His comments were made against a background of increasing reports of violence, brutality and death in Britain's young offender institutions. Up to 90 percent of young people leaving prison reoffend within two years.

Ramsbotham, who has become increasingly outspoken in his demands for penal reform, said: 'If I had the power to do it, I would close these places and do it bloody quickly'. He said he was frustrated he did not have the same powers to intervene as other regulatory bodies, such as the Office of the Rail Regulator or the schools inspectorate Ofsted.

He said he had become increasingly irritated by the refusal of the Home Office and the Prison Service to act on his recommendations. Last year he described Feltham, Europe's largest youth jail in west London, as 'rotten to the core' and 'unacceptable in a civilised country'. He told The Observer that, although conditions in the juvenile wing of the prison had improved, they were still appalling for over-18s.

The only problem with closing young offender institutions, he said, was that there was nowhere else for the offenders to go. The number of children and young people in prison custody increased by 11 percent this year, to around 3,000.

He also confirmed reports in last week's Observer that he had been appalled by conditions at young offender institutions at Brinsford in Wolverhampton and Stoke Heath in Shropshire. 'What more can I do than say again and again that conditions in these prisons are unacceptable,' he said.

Ramsbotham said the responsibility for the 'completely inexcusable' treatment of young people in the prison system lay with the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, and the director of the Prison Service, Martin Narey. The Chief Inspector is especially critical of the number of 15 and 16-year-olds being held on remand while awaiting trial.

According to figures released to Parliament this week, in Feltham alone the figure has risen by more than 50 percent this year, from 91 at the end of March to 166 at the beginning of last month.

'You don't leave a 15-year-old locked up for 23 hours with nothing to do. There is literally no excuse for that,' Ramsbotham said. Problems at Feltham that had led to the murder of 19-year-old Zahid Mubarak by a mentally unstable cellmate known for his racist views were replicated throughout the system.

'This has to go right to the top. From the Home Secretary and the head of the Prison Service to the prison officer on the landing: the problem is that no one is taking responsibility and no one is accountable,' Ramsbotham said. 'Someone should be appointed to take full responsibility for prisoners under the age of 18 and another person for 18 to 20-year-olds.'

Ramsbotham has backed a report by the Church of England's Children's Society, to be published later this week, which will call for an end to the practice of imprisoning 15 and 16-year-olds on remand, which it believes is in breach of the new Human Rights Act. The long-term aim of the Children's Society is the ending of all custodial sentences for under-18s.

Britain locks up more young people than almost any other West European country and a child becomes responsible for a crime at the age of 10. This compares with 12 in Turkey and 18 in Belgium and Luxembourg. The Children's Society report will highlight horrifying new evidence that shows that half of all young people in prison have diagnosable mental illnesses. Last year there were more than 900 incidents of self-harm by young people in prison, including slashed wrists and eating glass.

Dorset police are now investigating 35 cases of alleged assault at the Portland young offender institutions where prison officers were said to run a military-style regime.

Frances Crook of the Howard League for Penal Reform, which provided evidence for the Portland inquiry, said: 'We all know that locking up young people in long-term institutions is damaging to them and damaging to us all. Because of the high rates of reoffending, we are probably creating more victims of crime this way. If there were 1,000 furry animals being held in these conditions, there would be demonstrations every day.'

The Liberal Democrat MP Dr Vincent Cable, chairman of the all-party police group, said last night: 'We have to question whether they should be closed altogether because they are doing more harm than good. Despite repeated warnings, nothing has been done to change the situation at all.'

webTitle: Homeopath's killer may have psychic grudge

fields.headline: Homeopath's killer may have psychic grudge
fields.trailText: A homeopathic doctor gunned down in a supermarket car park may have been executed because he predicted one of his clients would have an unhappy future, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
A homeopathic doctor gunned down in a supermarket car park may have been executed because he predicted one of his clients would have an unhappy future, it was revealed last night.

Father of two Baldev Khrisan Yadev practised complementary medicine from his Wolverhampton office but also read palms and tarot cards. He left his office last Friday night and was walking to his car with his brother when a man approached out of the shadows and shot him in the head before running off.

At the scene of the crime, Detective Chief Inspector Dave Unwin, of West Midlands Police, said Yadev, a widower, was killed in an assassination-style killing. 'As he approached the steps, he was approached by a male who fired one shot at him and hit him in the head. There is some debate about how many shots were fired, but ... the man bent over him and another shot was discharged. There may have been three shots discharged in total.

'The manner of the death suggests an assassination, rather than a robbery motive. It will be a very difficult inquiry. We have an unknown assailant and an unknown reason.'

Police declined to speculate about potential motives but said that their inquiries would involve a thorough examination of all areas of the dead man's professional and private life.

A friend of the victim, Harmanjit Bains, last night paid tribute. 'He was a very nice bloke. He kept himself to himself and was very friendly. I can't think of any reason why anyone would want to kill him. He did a lot for the community.'

Shopkeeper Rash Vinder Sandhu, whose supermarket is next door to Yadev's rented offices, said he was shocked at the shooting.

'It's very bad. We are devastated that such a thing could happen right on our doorstep. I can't believe it could happen at 7.45pm in a well-lit busy area.'

Sandhu, 47, of Wolverhampton, added that Yadev was known as a pleasant, quiet man, who treated patients at his clinic on an appointments basis.

He had a regular routine and normally parked his red Volkswagen in the Aldi supermarket car park.

Sandhu said: 'I didn't hear the shot fired but as soon as I saw people gathering around him, I went out to have a look at what was going on.

'I didn't recognise him. The ambulance came to take him away. His face was covered in blood and you could see on the right side of his head by the temple where the bullet went through. He looked like he was going to climb the steps and then fell back on to the pavement.'

A sign above Yadev's practice stated that it offered 'complementary medicine without ill effects' for conditions such as eczema, gout, heart conditions, hair loss, diabetes and sterility.

Another, smaller, sign promises: 'I will read your entire life.'

fields.headline: Child labour scandal hits Adidas
fields.standfirst: Brutality, poor wages and 15-hour days in the Asian sweatshops
fields.trailText: They are the ultimate status symbols for sports stars and street-conscious young people. With their trademark three stripes, Adidas clothes cost a small fortune to buy and are promoted by world-famous names such as England skipper David Beckham, Olympic heptathlete Denise Lewis and Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova.
fields.body:
They are the ultimate status symbols for sports stars and street-conscious young people. With their trademark three stripes, Adidas clothes cost a small fortune to buy and are promoted by world-famous names such as England skipper David Beckham, Olympic heptathlete Denise Lewis and Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova.

But the company will this week become embroiled in controversy when the European Parliament hears of the barbaric treatment of employees in Indonesian sweatshop factories supplying the German conglomerate.

The Parliament will be told that clothes for Adidas were made in two factories using child labour, forced overtime and sexual harassment. Representatives of workers in two Indonesian factories supplying the German company,will tell Euro MPs that in the Nikomax Gemilang and Tuntex factories, in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta, children as young as 15 were:

 made to work 15-hour days;

 expected to do at least 70 hours a week and punished for refusing to do overtime;

 paid less than $60 a month, rates below the International Labour Organisation's demand for a living wage;

 penalised for taking leave during medical difficulties and had illegal deductions taken from wages as punishments for minor misdemeanours.

Sports goods companies have been criticised for exploiting workers in the developing world before. There was a storm just before the 1998 World Cup, after footballs bearing the Manchester United club crest were being made by child labourers in India, working for as little as 6p an hour. Cricket ball manufacturers were also criticised.

A report by Christian Aid revealed that children, some as young as seven, were regularly used in the production of a wide range of sports goods in India. Most of the £13m worth of goods went to Britain.

Last year a worker from a Bangkok factory for Adidas claimed that for less than £1 per day she worked 12-hour shifts seven days a week, producing sportswear, shoes and replica kits for the company.

She claimed conditions were poor in the Thai factory and the management acted brutally to meet large orders within a limited time, often denying workers statutory rights such as holidays and sick pay. The accusations are similar to those made by the Indonesian workers.

The woman was eventually sacked in 1998 along with 23 others after they formed a union in an attempt to win more rights. The factory management claimed she was a disruptive influence.

Most Adidas goods are produced in Third World countries, particularly Asia, with orders awarded to locally run factories. Many orders are sub-contracted at local level, leading to claims that the companies have little idea of where and how their goods are produced.

Adidas denies ignoring workers' rights for the sake of profit, claiming they have strict labour codes and constantly monitoring wage levels and conditions to ensure a good working environment.

Adidas spokesman Peter Csanadi countered the allegations earlier this year: 'We have factories where the conditions are very good and we take this whole issue very seriously,' he said. 'We know we have had problems, and we had to terminate some contracts because we saw that the management were not interested in good working conditions.

'We work closely with factory management and demand that they ensure good conditions for workers. We also have a team of our own people who go to factories to sort out problems.'

Adidas, whose football shirts sell in a British high street store for more than £50, have admitted problems at the two Indonesian factories and have recently increased pay and taken steps to ease overtime demands. Copies of the labourers' identity cards are now held at the Nikomas factory to ensure that no under-18s work there.

The company admitted that at the Tuntex plant quotas were set too high. Workers complained of being fined for coming to work five minutes late. Adidas confirmed that women who took leave when menstruating, as legally entitled, lost an attendance bonus of 6,000 Rupiah (50p) and that a manager had been sacked for sexual harassment.

Pay at the Nikomas plant was increased to more than 9,000 Rs (75p per day) following the campaigners complaints, Adidas said.

The campaigners hope that the publicity surrounding the hearings next week will force states to become involved in the regulatory process.

Ingborg Wick, who oversaw much of the research, said yesterday that government involvement was crucial.

'There has to be some overview of voluntary codes that companies sign with campaigners. There also needs to be an institutional framework and legal monitoring to ensure social standards in Third World production,' she said.

The hearings - by the European Parliament's Development Committee - have been organised by Richard Howitt, the British MEP.

webTitle: Angry unions stop playing wages game

fields.headline: Angry unions stop playing wages game
fields.trailText: 'Rugby cancelled at Blackrock College'. The headline in the Irish Times did not seem like a declaration of industrial war. But last week's strike by secondary school teachers which, among other things, halted play at one of Dublin's most prestigious schools, is an ominous warning that Ireland may be heading into a winter of serious discontent.
fields.body:
'Rugby cancelled at Blackrock College'. The headline in the Irish Times did not seem like a declaration of industrial war. But last week's strike by secondary school teachers which, among other things, halted play at one of Dublin's most prestigious schools, is an ominous warning that Ireland may be heading into a winter of serious discontent.

On Tuesday the one-day strike by members of the Association of Secondary Teachers of Ireland (ASTI) closed 600 schools and affected 350,000 pupils. This was followed by selective action, including the withdrawal of supervision, which meant that most parents were forced to keep their children at home. One hundred and twenty thousand of these pupils are studying for the Leaving Certificate, which will determine whether they get sufficiently good grades to go on to university or other higher education.

The teachers are looking for a 30% pay increase and they want it now. The government is adamant that this breaches all established guidelines. The teachers' leaders have responded by threatening to escalate their action next month. ASTI is the largest union representing secondary school teachers, but members of the Teachers Union of Ireland are also threatening to strike and they are not expected to cross their colleagues' picket lines.

This is only one element in a growing wave of discontent, particularly in the public sector, which now threatens to derail Ireland's highly successfully policy of negotiated agreements on wages between government, unions and employers' organisations.

Bertie Ahern is fond of saying that the most recent of these agreements, the Partnership for Prosperity and Fairness, has served Ireland well. By reaching consensus on a whole range of social issues, the agreement has kept wage rates under control. This in turn has played a major part in keeping inflation down and attracting foreign investment.

But this year inflation is running at close to 7%, already outstripping the 5.5% wage increases provided for in the partnership agreement.

The unions point out that large sections of the workforce feel that they have not received a fair share of the profits generated by a booming economy. Added to that, the dramatic drop in unemployment rates means that workers in the private sector, particularly in such areas as information technology, are able to negotiate much better pay deals.

The government's fear is that if one large group of workers, like the teachers, is seen to drive a coach and horses through the existing wages agreements, there will be a queue of other unions waiting to follow suit. Already this autumn there have been disruptive strikes on the railways. Flights by Aer Lingus, the national airline have been grounded. There are now threats of strike action by health workers, the main civil service union, and airline pilots, to name but a few.

There is particular anger in the public sector, where wages have failed to keep pace with the success of the economy. Teachers point out that a university graduate with a diploma in education can expect to earn a starting salary of around £20,000 and that it will take 25 years service before this rises to £38,000. This compares very badly with graduates going into other professions.

There is a widespread feeling, as with nurses last year, that traditional professions have fallen behind not only in terms of pay but in loss of status.

It is against this background that Charlie McCreevy, the Minister for Finance, is due to introduce his budget on 6 December. He has an unprecedented surplus to play with and the book of estimates, published last week, indicates that there will be an increase of 13%, or more than £2bn, in public spending. A high proportion of this will go on services like health and welfare, but tax cuts are also expected.

The minister has been severely warned of the risks of fuelling inflation, which would lead to further demands for pay rises. But Bertie Ahern is expected to call an election in the spring of next year and this is McCreevy's last chance to introduce a giveaway budget.

The danger is that an inflationary budget could lead to the very thing which the Irish government most needs to avoid, a spiral of wage demands backed by strike action, which would seriously damage the credibility of the Celtic Tiger economy at home and abroad.

But last week's strike by secondary school teachers which, among other things, halted play at one of Dublin's most prestigious schools, is an ominous warning that Ireland may be heading into a winter of serious discontent. On Tuesday the one-day strike by members of the Association of Secondary Teachers of Ireland (ASTI) closed 600 schools and affected 350,000 pupils. This was followed by selective action, including the withdrawal of supervision, which meant that most parents were forced to keep their children at home. One hundred and twenty thousand of these pupils are studying for the Leaving Certificate, which will determine whether they get sufficiently good grades to go on to university or other higher education. The teachers are looking for a 30% pay increase and they want it now. The government is adamant that this breaches all established guidelines. The teachers' leaders have responded by threatening to escalate their action next month. ASTI is the largest union representing secondary school teachers, but members of the Teachers Union of Ireland are also threatening to strike and they are not expected to cross their colleagues' picket lines. This is only one element in a growing wave of discontent, particularly in the public sector, which now threatens to derail Ireland's highly successfully policy of negotiated agreements on wages between government, unions and employers' organisations. Bertie Ahern is fond of saying that the most recent of these agreements, the Partnership for Prosperity and Fairness, has served Ireland well. By reaching consensus on a whole range of social issues, the agreement has kept wage rates under control. This in turn has played a major part in keeping inflation down and attracting foreign investment. The unions point out that large sections of the workforce feel that they have not received a fair share of the profits generated by a booming economy. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A new trade association hopes to raise standards in Britain's sex-toy industry. It hopes to introduce a recognised seal of approval, to exclude shabby goods.
fields.body:
Standards for sex toys

A new trade association hopes to raise standards in Britain's sex-toy industry. It hopes to introduce a recognised seal of approval, to exclude shabby goods.

He wants to be a millionaire

An internet auction failed to raise funds for the north-east Scottish estate of Christopher Monckton, who needs £1 million to pay the winner of his Eternity puzzle.

Marie Claire

The publisher of Marie Claire has asked us to point out that, contrary to last week's news item, it has no plans to drop its award-winning foreign reportage section.

Britons die in Belgium crash

Four Britons - three men and a woman in their twenties, thought to be from London - have died in a road accident on the E17 motorway at Temse, Belgium.

Knifeman attacks pensioner

Police in Devon said that a woman aged 74 was 'absolutely traumatised' after a man armed with a knife broke into her home in Kingsbridge and tried to assault her. The attacker ran off after she managed to trigger an automatic alarm.

Baby for Liam and Nicole

Liam Gallagher of Oasis and Nicole Appleton of All Saints have spoken of their delight to be expecting a baby.

Gallagher, 28, said: 'It's absolutely great. Nicole is going to be the best mum in the world.'

Appleton, 25, less than two months pregnant, said: 'I'm cool. I've only known about it for a short time.' Beaming, she added: 'I'm looking forward to being a mother. I'm not taking any time off. I'm not sick.'

Bridge lifted into the Tyne

The largest floating crane in the world, the Singapore-based Asian Hercules II, yesterday began lifting the £20 million Gateshead millennium bridge. After being carried five miles by barge, the bridge will be put in place beside Tyne Bridge.The bridge is due to be completed by Easter and and opened next summer.
