webTitle: Infertile men turn to fathers for sperm

fields.headline: Infertile men turn to fathers for sperm
fields.trailText: By Jason Burke and Paul Harris
fields.body:
By Jason Burke and Paul Harris

BRITISH women are being impregnated with sperm donated by the father of their infertile partner, The Observer can reveal.

The controversial practice is being carried out in an attempt to continue the genetic family line if the man in the relationship is infertile.

Senior medical figures confirmed that the practice, though unusual, was now regularly performed in British clinics. One described it as 'logical, appropriate and ethical'. But the procedure - which makes a father's son his biological half-brother and a child's biological father his or her grandfather - has fuelled the increasingly acrimonious debate over artificial insemination.

Two recent studies by psychologists claimed that children born through anonymous sperm donation faced life-long emotional problems with personal identity, confusion and family mistrust.

As a result of the disquiet, as The Observer revealed last year, sperm donors could be named under new proposals being considered by the government. Children fathered by donor insemination (DI) may be given the same right to trace their genetic fathers as adopted children are.

Professor Robert Winston, Britain's leading specialist in the field who pioneered IVF practices at the Hammersmith Hospital in London, said that the practice was 'not common but not unknown. We get a handful of requests for it a year. On the whole we would be concerned about it'.

Psychiatrists warned this weekend of the impact such treatment might have on a child and its family. 'It may change every single relationship within the family,' said Dr Samantha Gothard, at London's St Anne's Hospital.

Patricia Hardcastle, of the Catholic Media Office, said the practice should not be carried out in Britain before the ethical issues were properly addressed. 'It raises very serious ethical questions about procreation. It raises questions for the child about how he or she fits in with the family. Who is the child's father? Who is its grandfather? It will be very difficult for any child born like this.'

Ann Widdecombe, the Shadow Home Secretary, warned: 'The tangled webs that we are weaving for future generations are just horrifying. This is not something that I would ever endorse.'

Ruth Deech, chairwoman of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority, which licenses and monitors all human embryo research, said that though such a procedure would not be against the law, the authority 'would have to be reassured this would not harm the welfare [of a child]. It would depend on the individual circumstances,' she said.

A spokesman for the authority confirmed they had received inquiries from couples seeking the treatment. 'We have told patients to go to their local clinic and seek the appropriate counselling and information,' he said.

But many medics are still supportive. Dr Jack Cohen, a reproductive biologist, said that during 15 years running sperm banks in western England he estimated that around 12 in every 1,000 artificial inseminations involved a father's sperm. 'It is a controversial area and you make sure you counsel the people well, but it is not an unusual practice and is one that deserves support.'

The practice is increasingly common overseas, particularly in Japan where the maintenance of blood lines is very important, and in America. In both countries it has sparked a fierce debate.

The main proponent of the technique in Japan was recently called before a special ethics committee for violating the rules ensuring the anonymity of any donor. In America, lawyers have expressed concern about 'an emotional risk' if a known donor is in the family.

fields.headline: Divorce and be damned
fields.standfirst: The pro-marriage movement is gaining strength on both sides of the Atlantic. Now its leaders say they can prove that divorce damages kids for ever. But as  Maureen Freely reveals, real life often tells a different story
fields.trailText: The pro-marriage movement is gaining strength on both sides of the Atlantic. Now its leaders say they can prove that divorce damages kids for ever. But as  Maureen Freely reveals, real life often tells a different story
fields.body:
It's far too measured, and far too refined, to qualify as a backlash. It's been going from strength to quiet strength for about 10 years now. It's still largely an American-dominated, élitist thing. Its leading campaigners have not yet reached household name status, but that won't be long now. The steady stream of deadly-serious-but-accessible exposés against the Divorce Culture is beginning to yield results both here and in the US.

The story as they tell it goes something like this. Over the past 35 years we have gone from thinking about divorce as a shame, a stigma and a minority option, to seeing it as an everyday event and every married person's right. We have convinced ourselves that it is at worst a minor disruption, even for the children, and that, even if they're upset and distressed for a while, they generally bounce back as fast as their newly liberated parents.

Not so, say the concerned communitarians at the increasingly influential Institute for American Values. Set up in New York a decade ago by a group of intellectuals and academics, the institute has a manifesto called the Marriage Movement. Its stated aim is to put an end to the 'divorce revolution'. The doubling of the divorce rate and the five-fold increase in the number of babies born out of wedlock have, to quote founder member David Popenoe, 'created tragic hardships for children, created poverty within families, and burdened us with insupportable social costs'. And for what? he asks. It is abundantly clear that 'no one seems to be happier'.

The way forward, he says, is to draw the divorcing nations of the West into an ongoing public debate about divorce. His theory is that a society aware of the 'truth' about divorce might turn against it in the same way that America has turned, so slowly but so surely, against smoking. Many feel it's best to accentuate the positive, as Linda J. Waite and Maggie Gallagher do in their new book, just out in the US: The Case for Marriage: Why Married People are Happier, Healthier, and Better Off Financially. Others think that advertising marriage is not enough: it also needs to be modernised. Popenoe suggested recently that we might 'rewrite the cultural script' for marriage by persuading new mothers to become child-centred stay-at-home dependants - but only for 20 years or so. Before and after this tiny blip, it was fine by him if they wanted to be fully-fledged members of the workforce.

Popenoe's rhetoric has not made much of a dent in the divorce statistics. But it's made quite an impression in the upper echelons of New Labour. Look at the pro-marriage manual the Government plans to launch in the New Year. It is not likely to be the last word. Inside and outside the public sector, there is growing anger about the Government's apparent desire to privilege marriage and stigmatise divorce, and a growing chorus demanding that post-divorce families get the support they deserve.

A powerful and persuasive new book just out in the US called The Unexpected Legacy of Divorce will not help their case. Its primary author, Judith Wallerstein, could be said to be the founding mother of the Marriage Movement: many members cite her earlier bestseller, Second Chances: Men, Women and Children a Decade after Divorce, as the book that converted them to the cause. Decades later, she still puts most of the rest of them to shame. In her new book, based on a longitudinal study she began in Marin County, California in 1971, she says she can now prove beyond doubtthat even conscientious divorcing parents harm their children, not just during the transitional stage, but for life.

To illustrate her point, she pairs divorce survivors from the original study with contemporaries who grew up in the same communities, in families that remained 'intact' despite similar levels of conflict. The differences, she says, are stark. The children from broken families have a much harder time trusting the people they fall in love with. Unlike their almost-like peers who grew up in 'intact' marriages, they say they haven't the faintest idea what marriage really means: it is, as one subject puts it, like being asked to do a dance without ever having seen anyone else dance it.

When parents and their children are living together under one roof, she says, the bond between the parents strengthens the bonds between parents and children. Even parents who argue incessantly can usually cooperate in the running of the household. All this changes when the family stretches itself to two households. The income that was sufficient for one unit cannot cover two. Spouses who were dependants are suddenly forced into full-time jobs. At the same time, they are entering into new relationships that do not always go so well. So they are less available, less able to keep the old routines going, and more likely to lean on their children for emotional support. This radically alters everyday experience for their children, as does the travelling back and forth between two homes.

Things are made worse, Wallerstein says, by the fact that courts impose rigid care orders that fail to take into account the ways children's needs change as they grow older, and that treat children like so many packages to be shunted between depots. Children suffer most if the depots are more like war camps. Even if relations between their divorced parents are civil, children will experience all their family bonds as tenuous, simply because post-divorce households are less stable and are in constant flux, with an ever-changing cast of step-parents, stepchildren, and half-siblings.

Here and there, she offers up helpful hints for parents trying to make the best of a bad deal. If only, if only, she were not so relentlessly negative. The idea that it might, under some circumstances, be possible to parent well after divorce is an idea she and the rest of the Marriage Movement can only entertain in the abstract. The divorced mothers and fathers in her own case studies are, almost without exception, emotional cripples who have no idea what their children want or need or think.

Is this fair or representative? If I run through the roster of all the divorced people I've ever known, I can think of a few who drifted into divorce almost on a whim, were blind to their children's needs, and used their children as pawns in their war with the other parent. But I can think of many more who have managed, very much against the odds, to work together with exes to keep their children's lives as 'normal' as they can. If anything, these struggling-to-be good-enough parents spend more time thinking about how to raise a child well than they did pre-divorce. They have no choice but to think more: they are grappling with dilemmas for which they have no context and no preparation. It is another case of dancing a dance without ever having seen it. But at least they try.

Here are just a few stories I've heard from divorced or divorcing friends and colleagues over the past week:

1 A man whose decree absolute isn't a month old yet, who still looks after his children in the matrimonial home every other weekend. But he's beginning to feel like an intruder there, and his ex seems to feel the same, because she's been leaving him the sorts of notes you'd leave for your new cleaner. Should he complain or just get on with finding a new house?

2 A woman who has been vacating her house every other weekend for a year now, so that her ex can have time with the children. But lately it's been getting on her nerves, because he sleeps in her bed and goes through all her things. She thinks she should draw the line, but she doesn't want to rock the boat, because she's broke, and doing a course, and desperate for free childcare.

3 A woman who, after barring her sometimes violent ex from seeing her son for years, has decided the boy needs a male parental influence now that he's entering his teens. So she has invited the ex over. The ex seems overjoyed to have a second chance. But how to make sure he never resorts to the fist?

4 A man who is almost in mourning because his ex suddenly backed out of her promise to let their son live with him once he was of school age. He feels she's betrayed him, but he doesn't want to risk losing the boy altogether by taking his case to court.

5 A woman who finally got around to introducing the man she has been seeing for over a year now to her daughters, only to see the two girls go into a tailspin. Should she give up on a love life for their sake, or tell the girls they're just going to have to get used to it?

6 A woman who, after initiating a divorce two years ago, got cold feet when she found out that her ex now has a new girlfriend. She thinks it's too late to get him back. For the same reason she's reluctant for her children to spend time with the new woman. But would it be wrong for her to ask him to see the children less while she gets used to the new situation?

7 A man who has not been allowed to see his daughter for five years, in tears because she just answered a letter, and she took the trouble to draw a flower next to her name. Does this mean he'll be able to see her again one day? He does not dare ask. He has to be patient, wait for her to come to him.

Their children have different, even more wrenching dilemmas. One young child cries every time her father leaves the house to go to his new flat, not because she misses him, but because she is afraid he might trip on his way out and fall into their pond and drown.

Another older child is put out because she has to share her bedroom with a new stepsister who, in spite of being the same age, wants to go to bed two hours earlier. This, she thinks, could ruin her life. But she doesn't want to mention it to her father, 'who worried enough already'.

A boy in his late teens who has been commuting between houses for 12 years talks about how tense he feels when he first arrives at his mum's. He feels obliged to sit in the kitchen and talk to her, when really he just wants to go upstairs and flop on his bed and listen to loud music.

Another used to be upset that his parents didn't speak to one another. But then when he wanted a scooter the other week, he told each parent that the other was refusing to pay for it, and they both took pity on him and gave him the full amount. Which was great, he said, until the guilt kicked in. How to give the money back without having to tell them he lied?

None of these stories is an advertisement for the 'post-divorce lifestyle'. But there is one thing they all have in common: they are about people who are trying to 'do the right thing'. If Wallerstein's diligent research fails to highlight this slightly brighter story, it is because it is asking the wrong questions. Instead of staying neutral - asking how life is different in post-divorce families - it asks how children in post-divorce families are damaged. So there is always a moral agenda there. The desire to promote marriage and discourage divorce is stronger than the desire to look at all the facts.

So what are the facts? If you look at other new research on divorce, it soon becomes clear that not all post-divorce families are doomed. There are things that make life easier for children and there are things that make life worse. For example, a recent study of co-parented children carried out by Carol Smart, Amanda Wade and Bren Neale of the University of Leeds found that children had a hard time when they were travelling between parents who were hostile to each other.

They also said that they missed their friends when staying with a parent who did not live close to them. They said there were some benefits to having 'two of everything' (for example at birthdays and Christmas) and that this sometimes made up for the lack of a settled home. While they hated any situation that forced them to choose one parent over another, they spoke about the importance of 'being fair' to both parents by making sure they gave each enough time.

The children who were happiest with their lives were the ones who felt that their parents consulted them before making big decisions. The ones who were least happy were the ones who did not feel they could talk to their parents and believed they had no say about how their time was organised.

One of the aims of this study was to shed the dark, damage-fearing frame of reference used by Wallerstein and the Marriage Movement, and to try and understand family life post-divorce as children themselves understood it. In addition to publishing its results in the usual way, the authors also published a moving book called Parent Problems! in conjunction with Young Voice. Except in the short introduction, there are no adult voices here, just direct quotes from the 52 children who took part in the study. These children have important things to say, not just to other children and divorced parents but to all of us.

Much of it runs counter to received ideas about what children want, and what matters most to them. And what mattered most to these children was not the shape of the household per se but the quality of the relationships they had - not just with their parents, but with their step-parents, their siblings, their grandparents, their friends, and even their pets. They did not see themselves as passive partners in any of these relationships. Rather, they saw themselves as helping to make them what they were. They tried hard to be fair, and to respect other people's feelings, to do the right thing.

A similar if somewhat darker picture emerges in another new book, Connecting Children, by Julia Brannen, Helen Heptinstall, and Kalwant Bhopal of the Thomas Coram Research Centre at the University of London. The book arises out of a small but wide-ranging study of care and family life as seen and constructed by children aged between 10 and 12 in different types of families. Echoing the Leeds study, it found that most children in single-parent or post-divorce families thought it was better when both parents could give their children time and attention. They also believed that they should have a say in major family decisions like divorce. But there was, Brannen notes, a troubling silence in a number of the children that indicated a large gap between their ideals and their everyday experience. Family remained a powerful symbol for all of them. The children who clung to it most passionately were the ones in foster care. It is possible, says Brannen, that what they are really talking about here are 'the basic conditions of love'. However, they express their desire in terms of family structure.

As do we all. Is it possible to maintain strong ties between parents and children outside traditional marriage? What will happen if the answer is no? If we have always depended on families to look after their young and their old and their weak, what can we expect in a world where there is no lasting sense of family obligation? Those are the questions at the root of the anti-divorce campaign. They are not so very different from the questions that parents and children ask themselves as they struggle to keep things going in the wake of a divorce. The difference is in the way each group asks the questions. Instead of being couched in the anxious, negative abstract-plural, the questions of post-divorce parents and children are rooted in the present and the specific. How am I going to tell my ex to stop treating me like a servant without dragging the children into it? How can I be civil to my ex's new wife when to tell the truth I hate her guts? How can I let my daughter know my door is always open to her, without making her feel guilty about staying out of touch so long? How can I tell my father I miss him without hurting my mother? How am I ever going to feel at home in both my homes?

All of these questions are about the same things: how to keep family ties and obligations alive, even when they are no longer sanctified by marriage. How to bring up children together in an atmosphere of mutual respect, even when you're no longer sharing the same bed. How to be kind to an ex-spouse you hate, because you both love the same children. How to be fair to both parents, without telling lies or splitting yourself into two. They are questions people have always had to agonise over. If they have added urgency today, it's with good reason. For the past 30 years, we have, as Judith Wallerstein points out, been engaged on a vast social experiment. Never before have so many children grown up outside traditional two-parent families.

It is possible that 50 years from now, we'll all look back and shake our heads and wonder why it was ever allowed. But it is equally possible that we'll have decided by then that, in certain circumstances, divorce really is the only option, and that it is possible to bring up children well after divorce, at least if you bear in mind certain all-important principles.

It's beyond doubt that divorce does affect children, and adults, and not just for a little while, but forever. For anyone who knows this, divorce can never be an easy choice. But for better or for worse, it is a choice many of us have made or have had made for us and cannot unmake. And, to the extent that we do try to do the best we can, surely we, too, deserve respect. As do our children. We do not get it from the anti-divorce campaign, who treat us like waxworks in a horror museum. It's time they stopped.

Children of the divorce revolution

My family just IS. It's different from other people's families, but I don't mind because who says what a family should be like?
Hope, 14

Having two homes is like putting your life in a couple of carrier bags every week.
Selina, 16

Sometimes you feel fed up that you've got to have separate mums and separate dads, and you don't want to do it any more. But you can cope with it really, you get used to itYou get on with your life.
Quentin, 13 and Pele, 10

You should live with whoever is nearest to school, probably, but if your dad's, I don't know, a bit of a drunk or something or one of them cares for you more than the other, then it's obvious who you should choose - which isn't true in my case because they both care for me.
James, 12

About a year ago I would come home from a weekend with Dad, and find it very hard to readjust - sometimes it's just too much. Mum was always very understanding and I used to have a lot of Mondays off school and then by the Tuesday I'd be fine.
Bob, 12

When I go on holiday with each parent it's funny because I always miss the other one and you can't really tell your mum and dad because they think: 'Oh well, she just wants to be with her dad, and stuff, or mum.' fields.bodyText: It's far too measured, and far too refined, to qualify as a backlash. It's been going from strength to quiet strength for about 10 years now. It's still largely an American-dominated, élitist thing. Its leading campaigners have not yet reached household name status, but that won't be long now. The steady stream of deadly-serious-but-accessible exposés against the Divorce Culture is beginning to yield results both here and in the US. The story as they tell it goes something like this. Over the past 35 years we have gone from thinking about divorce as a shame, a stigma and a minority option, to seeing it as an everyday event and every married person's right. We have convinced ourselves that it is at worst a minor disruption, even for the children, and that, even if they're upset and distressed for a while, they generally bounce back as fast as their newly liberated parents. Not so, say the concerned communitarians at the increasingly influential Institute for American Values. Set up in New York a decade ago by a group of intellectuals and academics, the institute has a manifesto called the Marriage Movement. Its stated aim is to put an end to the 'divorce revolution'. The doubling of the divorce rate and the five-fold increase in the number of babies born out of wedlock have, to quote founder member David Popenoe, 'created tragic hardships for children, created poverty within families, and burdened us with insupportable social costs'. And for what? he asks. It is abundantly clear that 'no one seems to be happier'. The way forward, he says, is to draw the divorcing nations of the West into an ongoing public debate about divorce. His theory is that a society aware of the 'truth' about divorce might turn against it in the same way that America has turned, so slowly but so surely, against smoking. Many feel it's best to accentuate the positive, as Linda J. Waite and Maggie Gallagher do in their new book, just out in the US: The Case for Marriage: Why Married People are Happier, Healthier, and Better Off Financially. Others think that advertising marriage is not enough: it also needs to be modernised. Popenoe suggested recently that we might 'rewrite the cultural script' for marriage by persuading new mothers to become child-centred stay-at-home dependants - but only for 20 years or so. Before and after this tiny blip, it was fine by him if they wanted to be fully-fledged members of the workforce. Popenoe's rhetoric has not made much of a dent in the divorce statistics. But it's made quite an impression in the upper echelons of New Labour. Look at the pro-marriage manual the Government plans to launch in the New Year. It is not likely to be the last word. Inside and outside the public sector, there is growing anger about the Government's apparent desire to privilege marriage and stigmatise divorce, and a growing chorus demanding that post-divorce families get the support they deserve. A powerful and persuasive new book just out in the US called The Unexpected Legacy of Divorce will not help their case. Its primary author, Judith Wallerstein, could be said to be the founding mother of the Marriage Movement: many members cite her earlier bestseller, Second Chances: Men, Women and Children a Decade after Divorce, as the book that converted them to the cause. Decades later, she still puts most of the rest of them to shame. In her new book, based on a longitudinal study she began in Marin County, California in 1971, she says she can now prove beyond doubtthat even conscientious divorcing parents harm their children, not just during the transitional stage, but for life. To illustrate her point, she pairs divorce survivors from the original study with contemporaries who grew up in the same communities, in families that remained 'intact' despite similar levels of conflict. The differences, she says, are stark. The children from broken families have a much harder time trusting the people they fall in love with. Unlike their almost-like peers who grew up in 'intact' marriages, they say they haven't the faintest idea what marriage really means: it is, as one subject puts it, like being asked to do a dance without ever having seen anyone else dance it. When parents and their children are living together under one roof, she says, the bond between the parents strengthens the bonds between parents and children. Even parents who argue incessantly can usually cooperate in the running of the household. All this changes when the family stretches itself to two households. The income that was sufficient for one unit cannot cover two. Spouses who were dependants are suddenly forced into full-time jobs. At the same time, they are entering into new relationships that do not always go so well. So they are less available, less able to keep the old routines going, and more likely to lean on their children for emotional support. This radically alters everyday experience for their children, as does the travelling back and forth between two homes. Things are made worse, Wallerstein says, by the fact that courts impose rigid care orders that fail to take into account the ways children's needs change as they grow older, and that treat children like so many packages to be shunted between depots. Children suffer most if the depots are more like war camps. Even if relations between their divorced parents are civil, children will experience all their family bonds as tenuous, simply because post-divorce households are less stable and are in constant flux, with an ever-changing cast of step-parents, stepchildren, and half-siblings. Here and there, she offers up helpful hints for parents trying to make the best of a bad deal. If only, if only, she were not so relentlessly negative. The idea that it might, under some circumstances, be possible to parent well after divorce is an idea she and the rest of the Marriage Movement can only entertain in the abstract. The divorced mothers and fathers in her own case studies are, almost without exception, emotional cripples who have no idea what their children want or need or think. Is this fair or representative? If I run through the roster of all the divorced people I've ever known, I can think of a few who drifted into divorce almost on a whim, were blind to their children's needs, and used their children as pawns in their war with the other parent. But I can think of many more who have managed, very much against the odds, to work together with exes to keep their children's lives as 'normal' as they can. If anything, these struggling-to-be good-enough parents spend more time thinking about how to raise a child well than they did pre-divorce. They have no choice but to think more: they are grappling with dilemmas for which they have no context and no preparation. It is another case of dancing a dance without ever having seen it. But at least they try. Here are just a few stories I've heard from divorced or divorcing friends and colleagues over the past week: 1 A man whose decree absolute isn't a month old yet, who still looks after his children in the matrimonial home every other weekend. But he's beginning to feel like an intruder there, and his ex seems to feel the same, because she's been leaving him the sorts of notes you'd leave for your new cleaner. Should he complain or just get on with finding a new house? 2 A woman who has been vacating her house every other weekend for a year now, so that her ex can have time with the children. But lately it's been getting on her nerves, because he sleeps in her bed and goes through all her things. She thinks she should draw the line, but she doesn't want to rock the boat, because she's broke, and doing a course, and desperate for free childcare. 3 A woman who, after barring her sometimes violent ex from seeing her son for years, has decided the boy needs a male parental influence now that he's entering his teens. So she has invited the ex over. The ex seems overjoyed to have a second chance. But how to make sure he never resorts to the fist? 4 A man who is almost in mourning because his ex suddenly backed out of her promise to let their son live with him once he was of school age. He feels she's betrayed him, but he doesn't want to risk losing the boy altogether by taking his case to court. 5 A woman who finally got around to introducing the man she has been seeing for over a year now to her daughters, only to see the two girls go into a tailspin. Should she give up on a love life for their sake, or tell the girls they're just going to have to get used to it? 6 A woman who, after initiating a divorce two years ago, got cold feet when she found out that her ex now has a new girlfriend. She thinks it's too late to get him back. For the same reason she's reluctant for her children to spend time with the new woman. But would it be wrong for her to ask him to see the children less while she gets used to the new situation? 7 A man who has not been allowed to see his daughter for five years, in tears because she just answered a letter, and she took the trouble to draw a flower next to her name. Does this mean he'll be able to see her again one day? He does not dare ask. He has to be patient, wait for her to come to him. Their children have different, even more wrenching dilemmas. One young child cries every time her father leaves the house to go to his new flat, not because she misses him, but because she is afraid he might trip on his way out and fall into their pond and drown. Another older child is put out because she has to share her bedroom with a new stepsister who, in spite of being the same age, wants to go to bed two hours earlier. This, she thinks, could ruin her life. But she doesn't want to mention it to her father, 'who worried enough already'. A boy in his late teens who has been commuting between houses for 12 years talks about how tense he feels when he first arrives at his mum's. He feels obliged to sit in the kitchen and talk to her, when really he just wants to go upstairs and flop on his bed and listen to loud music. Another used to be upset that his parents didn't speak to one another. But then when he wanted a scooter the other week, he told each parent that the other was refusing to pay for it, and they both took pity on him and gave him the full amount. Which was great, he said, until the guilt kicked in. How to give the money back without having to tell them he lied? None of these stories is an advertisement for the 'post-divorce lifestyle'. But there is one thing they all have in common: they are about people who are trying to 'do the right thing'. If Wallerstein's diligent research fails to highlight this slightly brighter story, it is because it is asking the wrong questions. Instead of staying neutral - asking how life is different in post-divorce families - it asks how children in post-divorce families are damaged. So there is always a moral agenda there. The desire to promote marriage and discourage divorce is stronger than the desire to look at all the facts. So what are the facts? If you look at other new research on divorce, it soon becomes clear that not all post-divorce families are doomed. There are things that make life easier for children and there are things that make life worse. For example, a recent study of co-parented children carried out by Carol Smart, Amanda Wade and Bren Neale of the University of Leeds found that children had a hard time when they were travelling between parents who were hostile to each other. They also said that they missed their friends when staying with a parent who did not live close to them. They said there were some benefits to having 'two of everything' (for example at birthdays and Christmas) and that this sometimes made up for the lack of a settled home. While they hated any situation that forced them to choose one parent over another, they spoke about the importance of 'being fair' to both parents by making sure they gave each enough time. The children who were happiest with their lives were the ones who felt that their parents consulted them before making big decisions. The ones who were least happy were the ones who did not feel they could talk to their parents and believed they had no say about how their time was organised. One of the aims of this study was to shed the dark, damage-fearing frame of reference used by Wallerstein and the Marriage Movement, and to try and understand family life post-divorce as children themselves understood it. In addition to publishing its results in the usual way, the authors also published a moving book called Parent Problems! in conjunction with Young Voice. Except in the short introduction, there are no adult voices here, just direct quotes from the 52 children who took part in the study. These children have important things to say, not just to other children and divorced parents but to all of us. Much of it runs counter to received ideas about what children want, and what matters most to them. And what mattered most to these children was not the shape of the household per se but the quality of the relationships they had - not just with their parents, but with their step-parents, their siblings, their grandparents, their friends, and even their pets. They did not see themselves as passive partners in any of these relationships. Rather, they saw themselves as helping to make them what they were. They tried hard to be fair, and to respect other people's feelings, to do the right thing. A similar if somewhat darker picture emerges in another new book, Connecting Children, by Julia Brannen, Helen Heptinstall, and Kalwant Bhopal of the Thomas Coram Research Centre at the University of London. The book arises out of a small but wide-ranging study of care and family life as seen and constructed by children aged between 10 and 12 in different types of families. Echoing the Leeds study, it found that most children in single-parent or post-divorce families thought it was better when both parents could give their children time and attention. They also believed that they should have a say in major family decisions like divorce. But there was, Brannen notes, a troubling silence in a number of the children that indicated a large gap between their ideals and their everyday experience. Family remained a powerful symbol for all of them. The children who clung to it most passionately were the ones in foster care. It is possible, says Brannen, that what they are really talking about here are 'the basic conditions of love'. However, they express their desire in terms of family structure. As do we all. Is it possible to maintain strong ties between parents and children outside traditional marriage? What will happen if the answer is no? If we have always depended on families to look after their young and their old and their weak, what can we expect in a world where there is no lasting sense of family obligation? Those are the questions at the root of the anti-divorce campaign. They are not so very different from the questions that parents and children ask themselves as they struggle to keep things going in the wake of a divorce. The difference is in the way each group asks the questions. Instead of being couched in the anxious, negative abstract-plural, the questions of post-divorce parents and children are rooted in the present and the specific. How am I going to tell my ex to stop treating me like a servant without dragging the children into it? How can I be civil to my ex's new wife when to tell the truth I hate her guts? How can I let my daughter know my door is always open to her, without making her feel guilty about staying out of touch so long? How can I tell my father I miss him without hurting my mother? How am I ever going to feel at home in both my homes? All of these questions are about the same things: how to keep family ties and obligations alive, even when they are no longer sanctified by marriage. How to bring up children together in an atmosphere of mutual respect, even when you're no longer sharing the same bed. How to be kind to an ex-spouse you hate, because you both love the same children. How to be fair to both parents, without telling lies or splitting yourself into two. They are questions people have always had to agonise over. If they have added urgency today, it's with good reason. For the past 30 years, we have, as Judith Wallerstein points out, been engaged on a vast social experiment. Never before have so many children grown up outside traditional two-parent families. It is possible that 50 years from now, we'll all look back and shake our heads and wonder why it was ever allowed. But it is equally possible that we'll have decided by then that, in certain circumstances, divorce really is the only option, and that it is possible to bring up children well after divorce, at least if you bear in mind certain all-important principles. It's beyond doubt that divorce does affect children, and adults, and not just for a little while, but forever. For anyone who knows this, divorce can never be an easy choice. But for better or for worse, it is a choice many of us have made or have had made for us and cannot unmake. And, to the extent that we do try to do the best we can, surely we, too, deserve respect. As do our children. We do not get it from the anti-divorce campaign, who treat us like waxworks in a horror museum. It's time they stopped. Children of the divorce revolution My family just IS. It's different from other people's families, but I don't mind because who says what a family should be like? Hope, 14 Having two homes is like putting your life in a couple of carrier bags every week. Selina, 16 Sometimes you feel fed up that you've got to have separate mums and separate dads, and you don't want to do it any more. But you can cope with it really, you get used to itYou get on with your life. Quentin, 13 and Pele, 10 You should live with whoever is nearest to school, probably, but if your dad's, I don't know, a bit of a drunk or something or one of them cares for you more than the other, then it's obvious who you should choose - which isn't true in my case because they both care for me. James, 12 About a year ago I would come home from a weekend with Dad, and find it very hard to readjust - sometimes it's just too much. Mum was always very understanding and I used to have a lot of Mondays off school and then by the Tuesday I'd be fine. Bob, 12 When I go on holiday with each parent it's funny because I always miss the other one and you can't really tell your mum and dad because they think: 'Oh well, she just wants to be with her dad, and stuff, or mum.' So I keep it to myself. But I send them postcards and I normally take a picture of one of them when it's a long time. Chelsea, 8 I'd like it if mum and dad could get back together again. We swap over houses every day, but it would be nice to go somewhere with both your mum and dad. I ask Mum sometimes, but she doesn't want to. Harold, 11 I'm just so used to it I can't imagine it any other way. I mean, there's a good side and a bad side to it as there is with everything. I'm just used to it. And I get on with my life. webTitle: I can't stop my lover snoring

fields.headline: I can't stop my lover snoring
fields.trailText: Moral muse: Margaret Cook
fields.body:
My fiancé has always had a problem snoring but recently it has become worse. It is making my life a misery. He is not overweight but he does smoke and refuses to give up or go to the doctor to seek help. Consequently I often sleep in the spare room. We are due to be married next year and I don't feel it is a good way to start married life.

C.S. of Lewisham

It is one of life's little ironies that the success of momentous events often hinges on such apparently trivial matters, which can be undignified and even ridiculous. The civilised, modern human still has need of some very basic essentials to function, such as sleep. Why a sound sleep is so vital is not known, but mental health depends on it and maybe memory too. Atavistic instincts will teach you to resent anyone who interferes with that. Meanwhile your sleeping partner is oblivious of the in-your-face disturbance to you of which he is the cause, and no doubt resents you for making so much fuss about it. I'll bet he doesn't even believe he snores.

Therefore you should prove to him just how noisy he can be in the silent hours. You could install a sympathetic friend in the next bedroom as witness, but it might be easier to use a tape recorder. He has to believe in his responsibility so that he is prepared to help you find a solution. At the same time, I don't think you should adopt such an apologetic stance. Why is it you and not he who is relegated to the spare room? Unfortunately, although snoring can be worsened by certain medical conditions, it can prove resistant to any kind of treatment. But it can disturb his own rest as much as yours, if he has the condition 'obstructive sleep apnoea' which disturbs the normal alternating pattern of deep and dreaming sleep. Therefore he should have a nasal examination, and would certainly do well to give up smoking. He should also be discouraged from taking alcohol and other sedatives particularly within a few hours of bedtime.

There are some simple things worth trying. If he only snores when lying on his back, you can roll him over without waking him. Sometimes, even a whispered 'Stop snoring,' will work. There are a variety of devices on the market for applying to the nostrils, which are expensive and useless, since they just get lost in the bedclothes.

The ultimate advice one always faces with a life-partner is - learn to accommodate and accept him as he is. Your capacity to change a person, even a lover, is very limited. You should see that he takes his share of the responsibility over this particular problem. Be assured that the degree of co-operation you get is likely to be an accurate forecast of what the future holds.

Reader's replies

I used not to be able to sleep well in company but having separate rooms worked well for us. You can still choose to sleep together when you want. But as I've got older I've also learned that (a) the real problem was my own stress level, and (b) nothing makes me sleep better than passionate love-making.

A.P. of Glasgow

Go to your dentist. It may be possible to wear an 'anti-snoring appliance' at night. Easy to get used to and cheaper than a divorce! I am a retired dental lecturer. Two years ago I read an article by some academics from Glasgow Dental Hospital. I was intrigued, did some detective work myself and have worn the appliance for nearly two years. Essentially the appliance keeps the mandible in a protruded position and this alters the shape of the posterior airway and reduces the constriction, and stops the soft palate vibrating. Complete success from night one - my wife couldn't believe it.

J.B. via email

Next week's problem

I had some counselling earlier this year for a problem that has dogged me for years. The counselling made a huge difference to me, and allowed me to deal with my situation. The problem I have now is that I can't get the counsellor out of my head. I think because of the work we did together and the total trust I placed in her, I find it difficult to accept that our sessions have ceased. I know I need to deal with this to allow me to move on, but how? Do I see her again to work this out? Do I try to speak to someone else (ie another counsellor) about it?

C.F. of Sussex

webTitle: Is the Turner good for art?

fields.headline: Is the Turner good for art?
fields.standfirst: To its detractors, the Turner Prize honours charlatans; to its champions, it honours artists on the cutting edge. As this year's winner is about to be announced, two critics evaluate its true worth
fields.trailText: To its detractors, the Turner Prize honours charlatans; to its champions, it honours artists on the cutting edge. As this year's winner is about to be announced, two critics evaluate its true worth
fields.body:
Matthew Collings says yes

I think the Turner Prize is an indisputably good and valuable cultural event. It gets people talking about creativity and ideas. Anyone can go and you can say what you like. You can turn on the tap marked furious: 'Grr, Duchamp, Huff puff, videos!' Or you can be a bit more factual and observant. Actually the second is better. But no one has to be craven about it. Be ruthless if you like. Inside the Turner Prize last Sunday, I was amazed how crowded it was. The crowds looked at everything in a serious and concentrated way. I saw the architect Charles Jencks in the Wolfgang Tillmans exhibit - 'hey,' I thought, 'the man who invented the term postmodernism looking at some postmodernist stuff'. In the space where the video portraits of the exhibiting artists are shown, I heard my voiceover on the Tomoko Takahashi film. Word Perhect, with its deliberate wrong spelling, is Takahashi's internet project. But this was the first time I'd seen the film, directed by Chris Rodley for Illuminations, the independent film company, in its smoothed-out, edited and glossed version. Takahashi seemed nice, I thought, sympathetic. Actually, I can't stand her work. But now, with the audience so numerous and attentive and thoughtful and the film so enjoyable, I had to strain to remember why not.

Howard Jacobson says no

Show me the judges before you ask me to value the prize. Then show me who picked the judges.

It's a well-rehearsed argument against the Turner Prize that there are shadowy influences on it; that there are never dissident critics on the jury; that the principle of public involvement in the nomination process is a sham; and that the chairman of the jury is forever Sir Nicholas Serota, director of what was the old Tate and the reason we have a new one.

Myself, I think the invariable presence of Serota gives the prize a transparency, not to say a professionalism, the Booker lacks. Know what Serota is about and you understand the Turner Prize. Burning with a hard, gem-like flame, Serota has used the prize to turn up the temperature of artistic awareness in this country, to the point where we are deserving of Tate Modern, our own palace of contemporary aesthetics. No small achievement, but have the means justified the ends?

Measureless caverns of conceptualism and the best hamburgers in London, but a generation of artists who have lost their way, who are neither educated nor gifted, and cohorts of cowed critics and curators, each one willing to talk more drivel than the last.

It was probably never a good idea, intellectually, for a public gallery to run a major art prize. A public gallery, by its very nature, is prisoner to happenstance.

Conceptualism occurred, conceptualism must be shown. You and I know that conceptualism has not thrown up a single work worth looking at, but a gallery can't afford to know that.

In its association with the Tate, the Turner confused its function. It wanted to be up to the minute, it wanted to be a record of now, but sometimes now is not all that interesting.

Marcel Duchamp usually cops the blame for now, but the famous pissoir only pissed on art, it did not kill it. It introduced the found object, questioned the aura of the gallery, and taught artists who were otherwise at a loose end to be pranksters. For most of the century, it served as subplot to the main event - Picasso, Matisse, Bacon, you name them - those who were still willing to risk everything in the name of being serious.

In the early years of the Turner, before Channel 4 stepped in and made it a televisable event, before it had an upper age limit of 50, ie before it became sexy, artists of substance contended for the prize. It's only in the last 10 years that the children of Duchamp have run away with it.

The connection is blindingly obvious. If you want it young, you don't want it serious; if you want it sexy, you don't want it earnest; if you want it fashionable, you want it throwaway. And exactly the right art happened to be at hand, still fulfilling its function as light relief from weightier concerns.

Enter the jokers. The rude girls, the self-promoters, the empty-wallers, the body-parters, the failed filmmakers, the failed window-dressers, the pseudo-painters for whom irony at the expense of paint is paint's only point. If there's an artistic equivalent of genocide, then the Turner Prize is guilty of it. Over the course of 10 years, it has tried to wipe out the idea of the disinterestedly serious artist. If you want to be in the money, it has effectively told young artists, don't do it that way, do it this. Else perish.

Hence the new phenomenon in art schools of a sort of avant-garde Thatcherism. In a famously uncultured Turner Prize address, Charles Saatchi wondered what the YBAs were putting in their cornflakes, to be doing so well. Success being the measure, hunting for what went into the cornflakes became the art school's first concern.

Now, if a student isn't tied up by a gallery and selling nicely before his degree show, he might as well smash up his neon tubing. Since refinement of technique is no more the valued currency than maturity of feeling, why hang around for either? As for your bona fides as a member of the avant garde, those come to you automatically with the tidbits of nursery nihilism you've snacked on in your theory classes.

Which is also how - and this is the true mark of a Turner likely - you can be delinquent and holier-than-thou, all at once. Get rich quick and turn your nose up at the bourgeoisie.

In order for us to have Xanadu on Bankside, did the Turner Prize have to be footling, fearful, exclusivist, predictable, ignorant and a slave to some of the worst theoretical writing in the history of human thought? Couldn't it have been just one of those things?

 Howard Jacobson Takes on the Turner: C4, 22 November, 11.30pm

webTitle: How I fell for the usher on my wedding day

fields.headline: How I fell for the usher on my wedding day
fields.trailText: True confessions: scenes from real life
fields.body:
It was a traditional wedding: sun streaming through the windows of the country church, six angelic bridesmaids, bells pealing and me in a cloud of white satin and huge bridal veil. I was surprisingly calm as I was driven to the church; my brother was giving me away as my father had died. My lovely mum had organised everything from the huge vases of flowers to the striped marquee waiting back home on the lawn. She'd bought me towels, sheets, tea towels and a cookery book for my bottom drawer, and marshalled caterers and cars and hundreds of relatives and all sorts of things I never really appreciated until much, much later.

There were lots of people leaning over the low churchyard walls waving as I went up the path. My brother ushered me into the porch, the bridesmaids shimmied into position (albeit one had a large lump of dope down the front of her dress) and while all this was going on one of the ushers sidled into the porch and I realised I'd made the most awful mistake. The usher was my husband's best friend. I had seen him around countless times and my heart had often lurched, but never tried to leave my ribcage as it was doing now. He just looked... perfect: rumpled, wicked, rather drunk, vulnerable and very handsome.

All this was registering as I was manoeuvred into the church, facing down the aisle and the back view of my betrothed. He was looking pretty handsome too, but it just was not right - it was as if the sun had gone in. Much as I wanted to behave like Katharine Ross in The Graduate and just leg it, I wasn't brave enough. I couldn't let my poor, recently widowed mother down; what was I supposed to do about the dinner service and the canteen of cutlery, and anyway... the usher had a very glamorous girlfriend and didn't have a clue how I yearned.

And it was a yearning, too. Five years in all. I took the hair-shirt approach and decided I had (literally) made my bed and so must lie in it. Nobody had forced me into this marriage (although the husband had been very, flatteringly, keen), so I should make a go of it. I nested and cooked and entertained and worked and even supported him when he decided to take some time off to write a play. Whenever the usher came round I'd furtively gawp at the gorgeous blonde girlfriend with the long, thick hair and the perfect nails, and I got very tired and very sad.

Maybe I forced fate's hand - you can manipulate it, you know. I was sent to New York for work... and so was the usher. I was familiar with the place so offered to show him the town. I did too, and it was a pretty great backdrop to the beginning of our romance. I returned to London first and cried all the way home. When he came back, we met and began to disentangle ourselves from our partners which was tough. Extraordinarily, the blonde and my ex got married and lived in our old house; a few years later they got divorced. The usher and I are an old married couple with two children. I love him to bits.

 The author's name has been changed

fields.headline: Saturday night is for saddoes
fields.standfirst: If today you're recovering from last night's excesses, consider yourself outside the social loop
fields.trailText: If today you're recovering from last night's excesses, consider yourself outside the social loop
fields.body:
Saturday night isn't what is used to be. Where once it was the climax of the week, the consummation of Sunday-to-Friday's social, sexual and sartorial fantasies, these days it's an empty space, waiting to be filled with activity and meaning. You might choose to spend the dying hours of the week reading, gardening or having a particularly elaborate bath. You could decide to go round to a friend's to watch a video or you might simply start painting your spare room. One thing you won't be doing, not if you're the least bit cool anyway, is getting ready for a Big Night Out.

Admitting that you spent last Saturday night at a club, pub, party, restaurant or even cinema is the new social solecism. There are ways round it, of course. You can pretend that an old college friend was visiting from out of town and 'dragged you out' (make a little face of amused disgust at this point). Or you could say that your partner had just arrived back from the States that morning so shaken up by jetlag, poor darling, that he lost track of the days. But don't, whatever you do, say that you went out on Saturday because you were after a good time.

Whether you live in London, Manchester or some outsized village, Saturday is the worst night of the week to head into town. It's difficult to get a reservation at your favourite restaurant and, if you do, then you'll almost certainly find yourself sitting next to a group of 16 people singing 'Happy Birthday' over and over again. The buses are packed with people being sick and it's impossible to find a cab home. With good reason, New Yorkers call it 'Amateur Night'.

At its worst, Saturday has the capacity to spoil everything it touches. Neighbourhoods which exude stylish cool from Sunday to Monday, turn into sixth-form discos on Saturday night. Even Hoxton seems horrible when there's a crocodile of carefully dressed visitors queuing patiently around every second building.

Nor is it just what Saturday brings that makes it naff, but what you bring to Saturday. Carol Harris, 40, a film executive living in Manchester, believes that it's the 'special occasion' connotations that make the slot so unappetising. She remembers her parents taking her every year to a restaurant on the Saturday nearest her birthday. 'We'd all get dressed up, with my dad wearing a blazer and my mum a long skirt, and there'd always be a row on the way home because expectations had been so high.' These days, Caroline eats out three times a week rather than once a year and, unsurprisingly, always avoids Saturday.

None of this comes as any surprise to researchers at the Henley Centre, who are just about to publish a report with creative consultancy Pearlfisher called 'The Night-Mode of the Future'. The 30- and 40-year-olds who opened up their evenings to scrutiny reported that, while they still liked to visit clubs and restaurants, they weren't interested in the accompanying hassle.

It's a confidence thing, says Rachel Clare of the Henley Centre: 'When you're 25, you're much more worried about whether you're dressed right and whether you'll get past the doorman. By the time you're 35, you're only interested in the quality of the experience. If it takes too long to get served, then you assume there's something wrong with the bar, rather than there's anything lacking in you.'

This concentration on the content of the moment, rather than its cumbersome cultural connotations, means that in some cities the coolest time to go clubbing is now Sunday afternoon. 'Thirtysomething parents don't find Saturday a particularly convenient time to go out, so increasingly they're leaving their children with the grandparents after Sunday lunch and heading out to their favourite clubs,' explains Clare. Once deep inside the building, you'd be hard-pressed to know that anything was amiss: the music, drinks and vibe all suggest 'Saturday' even if outside people are getting ready to go to church.

Younger people, too, are avoiding the cliché of Saturday, preferring to concentrate their efforts on Friday. For that reason it's never been easier to get a teenage babysitter, even if you have to suffer amused contempt in the process. 'Two Saturdays ago, I booked a neighbour's daughter to look after the children so that my husband and I could have a rare evening out together,' recalls London mother Louise Carpenter, 38. 'As we went into the sitting-room to say goodbye, I could see Sarah looking at us with a kind of pity. There we were, all dressed up and heading off at 7pm on a Saturday, and I suddenly saw just how sad, old and naff we must look.'

The irony of Saturday is that we don't need it any more. Historically, it developed as a night of pleasure and expenditure at a time when factories, offices and schools worked right through until 4pm on a Saturday. As recently as the 1970s, manual workers, bank clerks and schoolboys all looked forward to Saturday night as their first free time of the week. A full pay packet and six days' worth of frustrations and desires produced a pressure-cooker atmosphere in pubs and clubs around the country. These days, flexible working patterns and Sunday trading mean that there's no need or reason to focus all your hopes on those few hours. You might just as well go to a party on Tuesday, shop at midnight on Thursday and spend Saturday evening catching up on your paperwork.

All the same, old patterns die hard and it's still easy to feel that you ought to be doing something 'special' on a Saturday night. After all, it takes a certain confidence to admit to your friends that while they were out having dinner, you were busy tidying a cupboard. 'I lie about it, actually,' confesses Susan Martin, a 35-year-old copywriter. 'When people ask me on a Monday morning what I did at the weekend, I always make up something for Saturday night. It just sounds too sad, otherwise.'

Even saying that you stayed home with your partner can seem suspect. It's all right at the beginning of a relationship because everyone assumes you're too busy having great sex to go out. But after the first six months it starts to look as though you're stuck in some strange folie à deux which stops you interacting healthily with others.

If you suffer from this kind of Saturday complex, then you're about to feel very uncomfortable indeed. With the dawning of December, the Saturday effect starts to spread to other days of the week. Suddenly, it starts to seem odd if you don't have a really exciting time lined up for Thursday. By the time it gets to the 18th, even Monday will need to be filled with something sparkly-sounding. The only day you don't have to do anything, of course, is Saturday itself. Because that just wouldn't be cool.

'Two Saturdays ago, I booked a neighbour's daughter to look after the children so that my husband and I could have a rare evening out together,' recalls London mother Louise Carpenter, 38. 'As we went into the sitting-room to say goodbye, I could see Sarah looking at us with a kind of pity. There we were, all dressed up and heading off at 7pm on a Saturday, and I suddenly saw just how sad, old and naff we must look.' The irony of Saturday is that we don't need it any more. Historically, it developed as a night of pleasure and expenditure at a time when factories, offices and schools worked right through until 4pm on a Saturday. As recently as the 1970s, manual workers, bank clerks and schoolboys all looked forward to Saturday night as their first free time of the week. A full pay packet and six days' worth of frustrations and desires produced a pressure-cooker atmosphere in pubs and clubs around the country. These days, flexible working patterns and Sunday trading mean that there's no need or reason to focus all your hopes on those few hours. You might just as well go to a party on Tuesday, shop at midnight on Thursday and spend Saturday evening catching up on your paperwork. All the same, old patterns die hard and it's still easy to feel that you ought to be doing something 'special' on a Saturday night. After all, it takes a certain confidence to admit to your friends that while they were out having dinner, you were busy tidying a cupboard. 'I lie about it, actually,' confesses Susan Martin, a 35-year-old copywriter. 'When people ask me on a Monday morning what I did at the weekend, I always make up something for Saturday night. It just sounds too sad, otherwise.' Even saying that you stayed home with your partner can seem suspect. It's all right at the beginning of a relationship because everyone assumes you're too busy having great sex to go out. But after the first six months it starts to look as though you're stuck in some strange folie à deux which stops you interacting healthily with others. If you suffer from this kind of Saturday complex, then you're about to feel very uncomfortable indeed. With the dawning of December, the Saturday effect starts to spread to other days of the week. Suddenly, it starts to seem odd if you don't have a really exciting time lined up for Thursday. By the time it gets to the 18th, even Monday will need to be filled with something sparkly-sounding. The only day you don't have to do anything, of course, is Saturday itself. Because that just wouldn't be cool.

webTitle: Don't come to me with your storeys

fields.headline: Don't come to me with your storeys
fields.trailText: Deyan Sudjic: Sounding off
fields.body:
Maybe it is the sheer implausibility of Irvine Sellars, a one-time boutique owner who kept Swinging London in bell-bottoms, trying to build Europe's tallest skyscraper that has made the response to London's single most gargantuan project since Canary Wharf so muted.

Building a 90-storey colossus, smack in the middle of the Arthur Daley world of London Bridge's back streets that would tower over its neighbours like Godzilla is so bizarre a notion that it has engendered more disbelief than outrage. Why get all worked up when it is all going to vanish again in the blink of an eye, toppled by its own inherent unlikeliness? But the idea of setting out to create a brand new financial centre for London on the site of an old banana warehouse at Canary Wharf looked equally improbable 15 years ago. And it seems that Sellars has managed to get his foot in enough doors to start to build a certain momentum for the project. Not least at the court of Mayor Ken. Rather than shower unflattering adjectives in all directions as is his normal practice with out-of-the-ordinary architecture, Livingstone has so far maintained a surprising silence on the tower. Much of the credit for this must go to Sellar's shrewd decision to sideline his original architects for the project, and talk Renzo Piano, one-time partner of Richard Rogers and co-designer of the Pompidou Centre, into taking on the project.

Renzo Piano is a brilliant, innovative and sensitive architect. Unfortunately, to judge by the sketches that have so far emerged, the Sellars tower is none of these things. The jagged pyramid with which Piano now proposes to skewer the London skyline would transform the look of the city permanently; and not for the better. If a 90-storey tower really does rise on this spot, like a rocket out of nowhere, the whole of the rest of London is going to be turned into an arc of cowed, unwilling spectators unable to escape the sight of this rampant upstart.

Piano is both critically well regarded, and very successful. Even though his recent victory in the competition to design a new skyscraper HQ for the New York Times was compromised by the withdrawal of Frank Gehry, who had been seen as the Times's favourite until he decided that it would be impossible to work with the developer that the paper had in mind, this commission has made Piano the most high-profile European architect in America. The London Bridge project, more than half as tall again as Canary Wharf would make him even more visible in Britain. In Rotterdam and Sydney he is currently completing two more towers that are just as prominent.

Though the tower for Sellars is much bigger than his New York scheme, it bears a striking conceptual resemblance to it. The conventional rectangular form of the tower is in both cases camouflaged as much as possible by a skin of glass that appears to float free of the main structure. In New York, the whole composition is contained in a rectangle. But in London, no doubt under pressure to create a self-conscious landmark, Piano has tapered the structure to create a vertiginous pyramid with a top that bears more than a passing resemblance to Frank Lloyd Wright's unbuilt and unlamented design for a mile-high skyscraper. As a landmark it looks forced and unconvincing. The question that really needs to be asked is what drives an architect of Piano's calibre and achievements to take on such an unpromising commission in partnership with Broadway and Malyan, a team of architects who have given central London one of its most dubious new landmarks - a block of flats at Vauxhall Bridge that makes its nearest neighbour, Terry Farrell's M16 building, look shy and retiring by comparison.

The charitable view would be to conclude that Piano has a genuine belief that the world's big cities are inevitably going to be transformed by a wave of ever taller new buildings, and that unless architects actively get involved with the design of ultra high-rise skyscrapers, they will be left looking irrelevant to the future of the city. To judge by the crop of high-rise towers now sprouting all over London, he may well be right. And yet if this project really is built, the high-rise game in London is going to be propelled into a new and overheated territory.

So far London's tallest towers are being clustered, which makes them far less aggressive. Sellars wants to go out on a limb on his own. And that is what makes his scheme so damaging.

webTitle: Film of the week: Suzhou River

fields.headline: If you knew Suzhou...
fields.standfirst: Homages to Hitchcock are coming thick and fast. This week's offering is from China
fields.trailText:
Homages to Hitchcock are coming thick and fast. This week's offering is from China Suzhou River
(83 mins, 12)
fields.body:
Suzhou River
(83 mins, 12)
Directed by Lou Ye; starring Zhou Xun, Jia Hongsheng

The best films of the week are all rereleases - David Cronenberg's 1982 Videodrome, William Friedkin's 1973 The Exorcist (being shown in the director's cut) and Martin Scorsese's 1980 Raging Bull, which I have written about over the years in an ascending order of enthusiasm. All three have been subjected to censorship and, ironically, the reason I was unable to see these newly struck copies last week is because the day they were shown I was taking part in a conference on censorship organised by FilmFour and the ICA.

A variety of TV executives, cops, customs men, academics, lawyers, sociologists, psychologists and critics chatted in groups and plenary sessions from nine to five and reached the brilliant conclusion that there was too much censorship in Britain (the representatives of the Viewers and Listeners Association dissenting), that the situation was improving a little and that certain forms of classification were desirable in an imperfect society. I think I could have guessed all that while watching Videodrome, The Exorcist and Raging Bull.

Anyway, the week's one truly interesting new movie, Suzhou River, apparently escaped the full rigours of Chinese censorship as a result of being a low-budget production largely financed from Dutch, German and Swedish sources. The 35-year-old Lou Ye's film, a beguiling affair reminiscent of Wong Kar-Wai's Hong Kong pictures, is largely viewed through the eyes or lens of an anonymous, unseen videographer living in a flat overlooking the River Suzhou, the waterway that separates downtown Shanghai from the industrial suburb of Hong-ku.

The Suzhou is a metaphor for the merging of the old and the new China, its now polluted waters flowing relentlessly, throwing up waste and dead bodies, its banks lined with derelict, pre-war warehouses that are being pulled down and replaced by anonymous tower blocks. The young videographer watches passively and waits for the occasional responses to the advertisements he stencils on the city's wall.

One day, his pager rings and he's engaged to make a promotional video for a sleazy bar called the Happy Tavern, featuring its chief attraction, the display in a glass tank of Meimei, a go-go dancer (Zhou Xun) got up as a blonde mermaid. He falls for this flighty number, films her obsessively, and they become lovers. The mermaid, Lou Ye has pointed out, is 'a Western import like Coca-Cola and McDonald's', with no roots in traditional Chinese culture.

But Meimei has another, equally obsessive admirer, the motorcycle courier Mar dar (Jia Hongsheng), a handsome dropout recently released from jail, and the jealous videographer reconstructs Mardar's story from the man's own testimony and other sources. It transpires that Mardar had been hired to look after Moudan (also played by Zhou Xun), the wilful schoolgirl daughter of a crook specialising in contraband Russian vodka. She develops a crush on him, and when he becomes involved in kidnapping her she feels betrayed and throws herself into the Suzhou, clutching a mermaid doll. Does she now haunt its murky waters like some creature from a Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale, or has she reappeared, or perhaps been reincarnated as Meimei, the night-club mermaid? Could Meimei perhaps be exploiting, playing up to, Mardar's necrophilic guilt?

The dreamlike quality of this swooningly romantic story is enhanced by the hand-held camerawork that presents it as the videographer's subjective impressions. But it takes place in the neon-lit, glamorously garish world of film noir, and the picture recalls the mood of a 1930s French film in the Marcel Carné poetic-realist mode and also, of course, Alfred Hitchcock.

One of Hitchcock's few excursions outside the thriller was the romantically surreal Rich and Strange , which took its title from Ariel's song in The Tempest about suffering 'a sea change into something rich and strange', and was released in the States as East of Shanghai . Suzhou River is a homage to Vertigo, and the heroine's name 'Moudan' is a Chinese whisper of Madeleine, the captivating woman played by Kim Novak whom James Stewart seeks to re-create. Lou Ye's film doesn't have the power of Hitchcock's masterwork, nor does it manage to gain depth by association, but it's a charming, elegiac film in search of a popular audience.
