fields.headline: The meaning of life - or just a load of rubbish?
fields.trailText: She Was Black | Ondine, Shadowplay
fields.body:
She Was Black
Rambert Dance Co, Sadler's Wells, London EC1

Ondine, Shadowplay
Royal Ballet, ROH, London WC2

A thing haunts the surreal ballet by Mats Ek that opened Rambert's two-week London season. The title, She Was Black, is the answer to a question about the nature of God. The shapeless, wriggling Thing lurks like a bad conscience. Ignored until the final moments of the ballet, she - for the creature that emerges from its chrysalis-shroud is female - could be the human soul. Or a black joke.

This is the first time that Ek's choreography has been danced by a British company. Until the Cullberg Ballet from Sweden brought his ballets to the 1999 Edinburgh Festival, Ek's work had only been seen here on television. (Sadler's Wells hopes to present his disturbing version of Swan Lake next year, money permitting). Because Ek's take on the world is so unfamiliar, it is all the more refreshing. In Christopher Bruce's Sergeant Early's Dream (from 1984) on the same programme, the hopes and fears of its cast of Irish immigrants are common currency. Ek's Scandinavian family members are bizarrely unpredictable.

She Was Black appears to be set in a cavernous kitchen. A married couple spar, driven by a dual need to torment each other. His hat serves as her pudding bowl, her skirt as his snot-rag. He treats her like a dog; she tries to hump him in sexual frustration. Enter a horde of black and red onlookers, who sit in judgment on them, a jury of children, servants or neighbours, perched on a staircase. These characters then have their own dances, as blunt and vehement as cut-out cartoons.

Henryk Gorecki's Second String Quartet veers between ominously sliding harmonies and urgent throbbing. Its nightmare quality is reflected in the appearance of a man gliding on pointe, briefly naked except for his hat and toe-shoes. Maybe he's a fantasy of harmony between the sexes, who are otherwise at each other's throats and groins. Perhaps the Thing is his dream, an enigmatic shape enveloped in a black rubbish bag.

It visits itself upon the hapless household, witness ing the guilty secrets that are locked into closets. In the end, the monster has to be acknowledged. No longer despised as garbage, she sloughs off her sack and dances. She has a human form and voice (a recorded throat-music song), though she is still pretty strange. That's fine by Ek - his compassion extends to the low-liest outcast.

The Rambert dancers embody his vision with complete conviction. Since they have been coached by the choreographer himself, we are free to make our own interpretations - they know what theirs is. The Royal Ballet has not had that advantage with its recent revivals of works by Antony Tudor and Frederick Ashton, who are both dead. Neither Tudor's Shadowplay nor Ashton's Ondine coheres as a ballet. Yet there are such marvellous moments in both that one longs for the productions to be pulled into shape, reorganised to be seen with new eyes.

Shadowplay was coming to life by its last performance on Monday, with Edward Watson as the Boy With Matted Hair (or floppy red locks, in his case). He teetered between gaucheness and elegance. Determined to understand every step of his journey, he took us with him. In an ideal cast, he should be confronted by more formidable seducers than Jane Burn and David Pickering, but at least some alert intelligences were at play.

Ondine, last revived on the Sadler's Wells stage when the Royal Ballet was homeless, is better framed in the Opera House. It is a strange mixture of painterly and papier mché, both in Lila di Nobili's designs and the dancers' interpretations. Jonathan Cope as the hero, Palemon, reverted to the cardboard cypher he used to be before Sylvie Guillem took him on. Sarah Wildor as the wilful water nymph of the title aroused little response from him, even though she was enchanting.

Ondine is supposed to have no soul, which should make her even more alien than Ek's black Thing. But Wildor can't help being a warm-hearted mermaid, full of remorse at the devastation she brings about so unthinkingly. She cradles her drowned lover with genuine emotion, while her fellow sprites sway in the currents around them, looking like ghostly Blake watercolours.

Ashton's imagination conjures up images that modern technology ought to be able to realise more effectively than the clapped-out stage machinery he was using in 1958. True, the shipboard scene in Act II is initially a triumph of painted gauzes, but nobody on deck believes in the storm or the invasion of nymphs and tritons, flapping bits of cloth. Your heart sinks with theirs.

Hans Werner Henze describes a seascape in his score that is not reflected in the old-fashioned staging. His Ondine surely floats on the waves without the need of all-too-human hands to keep her aloft. Almost half a century on, cannot a way be found to unify music and action?

Thanks to Andrea Quinn's conducting, dancers and musicians were more in touch than usual on the opening night, even during the difficult last act. The Neapolitan dancers in the wedding divertissement stopped counting the beats and let themselves follow Henze's rhythms. Led by Johan Kobborg and Belinda Hatley, they showed how Ashton's trickiest steps can sparkle afresh.

Ditch the designs, chuck the non-dancing extras into the sea and concentrate on the choreography; that way the magic might work.

fields.headline: Lurve unlimited
fields.standfirst: Jill Scott may be more feminist than femme fatale, but her explosions of soul music's clichés are not just for the girls
fields.trailText: Jill Scott Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12
fields.body:
Jill Scott
Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12

Midway through Jill Scott's spine-tingling performance at London's Shepherds Bush Empire, the bloke standing next to me drops his drink. Jill is imitating a lecherous man in her spoken lament 'The Thickness'. In her blood-rich voice, her round face shining, Jill easy-breathes: 'I'd like to rub my lips on your precious clit, why don't you drop that big thick ass on my stiffness?' And whoops! my neighbour's glass goes AWOL. Brandy and coke all sticky on his shoes.

It's premature affirmation that Jill Scott's lovesexy take on relationships works its spicy magic upon men as well as women. When 'The Thickness' reaches its climax - 'She's been degraded, exploited, not celebrated, sssssaturated with self-hatred' - my juggle-tipple colleague cheers as heartily as everyone else.

Before I saw her perform, I'd assumed that 28-year-old Jill Scott's 500,000-selling album Who Is Jill Scott? was, essentially, a girl thing. Its 18 delicious nu-soul tracks of love found, love made, love protected, love loved seemed too romantic for contemporary masculine musical taste, divided as it is between angst-rockers and gangsta-wannabes. But tonight's audience is 50-50 male-to-female, and the men are giving it up as loudly as the women.

Rightly so: from the out set, Jill and her band play each song as though it's an encore, bursting with the energy that comes only from real talent. It's a pleasure to witness. Especially as, in these image-driven days, each member has clearly been hired on the basis of musicianship, as opposed to style: the trombonist has come out in his gardening trousers; the keyboard-player looks like Louis Theroux, but without the dress sense.

Scott herself, as she explains, is not a ghetto fabulous devotee. She wears a black shirt, check skirt, opaque tights, little boots. She looks like a human being, a long way from the photo-me slimcea chic of her soul-sisters Lauryn Hill, Erykah Badu, Macy Gray. She does this, as she does most of her communicating, with humour, her eyebrows roller-coastering, warm irony wrapping her beautiful, beautiful voice.

And it is her voice that we are here for. Whether speaking, crooning, scatting, or letting rip like a strange opera singer, Jill Scott's voice is a heavenly wonder. Even those who find her songwriting too syrupy cannot deny Jill Scott's stunning vocal gift. Actually, if the album's love talk does get your cynical goat, then I'd advise just letting it wash over you for a while. A few listens later and certain tracks will lift themselves out of the mix: the single 'Gettin' in the Way'; the funky 'It's Love'; the haunting 'He Loves Me'; the spoken tale of cheeky check-out girls, 'Exclusively'.

Tonight, we're treated to four belters in quick succession - 'A Long Walk', 'Love Rains', 'Slowly Surely', 'Gettin' in the Way' - each merging into the next, none sounding exactly as on the album, but funkier, jazzier, more freestyle and immediate. More fun.

The bassist is doing the Ali shuffle. The backing singers are grinning from ear to ear. Jill and her mates seem to be enjoying themselves. As is the crowd. A chorus of 'Bo's and cheers follows every new lick, each variation. On the seats-only balcony, people leap to their feet, throw both hands towards the stage, clap, groove... sit down again. In contrast to the players, this is a well-dressed audience. They're loving it, but they won't be losing it.

In the end, Jill et al only give us three more songs - 'It's Love', 'The Way', plus encore 'He Loves Me' - along with 'The Thickness' poem and traditional let's-meet-the-band solos. A seemingly miserly total of eight numbers. But frankly, I'd rather have eight Jill Scott tunes than 28 of Coldplay's (luckily, they've only written one). And with her charm and character, not tomention her ability to spontaneously twist a melody into something else more wonderful, it's not as though you're not getting value for money.

What Jill Scott is good at is finding the cracks in pop and soul music's fixed-grin portrait of lurve. She trickles her lyrics through forgiveness, desire, happiness, possessiveness, curves her voice around the hottest sex, the deepest hope, rejection, affir mation, the sweetest taboos. This is a woman who first went into a studio just three years ago; she can't read music or play an instrument. 'Music is such a great orgasm,' she grins towards the end. Luckily for us, her joyful skill ensures that such feelings are mutual, and simultaneous.

fields.headline: Songs from the supermarket
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's Choir of the Year |  Takacs Quartet
fields.body:
Sainsbury's Choir of the Year Buxton Opera House, Buxton, Derbyshire

Takacs Quartet Queen Elizabeth Hall, South Bank, London SE1

Rarely do the sequinned boleros and luscious close harmonies of barbershop singing find their way on to the pages of broadsheet newspapers - or of tabloids, come to that. This undervalued art form may not be to everyone's taste, but one could say the same for trio sonatas or organ voluntaries. Asked to define the term, most of us are at best vague, at worse disdainful. A French dictionary dismisses this cordial vocal habit as once the music of the street, now 'une musique d'ascenseur ou de supermarché'. You can quite see that Gallic chic might not easily find affinity with people in matching suits singing 'Sweet Adeline'.

In fact the musical style is technically precise and vocally demanding, with its own jargon of snipes, snakes and tags. Borrowing from madrigals and doo-wop, jazz and hymn singing, barbershop is always unaccompanied, with a lead voice singing the melody, and three other parts harmonising in thirds, fourths or fifths, often in an augmented or diminished form (you can see where the Beach Boys got the idea). Anyone familiar with a dominant seventh - that chord which begs for resolution, like the first half of a sung 'Amen' - will recognise its essential role in barbershop. The real excitement, for singers and listeners alike, is when the sung harmonies seem to expand and produce an overtone or undertone known as 'cracking a chord'. In the words of a spokesman for the memorably named Society for the Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America (worldwide membership 70,000), this effect 'brings you out in goosebumps the size of golf balls'.

There was a chance to experience this unfamiliar sensation at Buxton last weekend when 32 choirs gathered for the semi-finals of Sainsbury's Choir of the Year (I was an adjudicator). Barbershop only featured in the single-voice (ie, all-male or all-female) category, when red chiffoned ladies from Croydon and dapper, blazered men from the East Midlands and elsewhere - numbering a consultant neurosurgeon, a gamekeeper and a female detective among them - crooned winningly as if their lives depended on it.

In other categories children (some as young as six), mixed-voices and youth choirs sang a dazzling array of music from every culture and tradition. They tackled songs in Finnish, Lapp, Zulu, Gaelic, Welsh and a few other languages. Britain may have much to learn from the open-throated, warmly emotional singing traditions of the Nordic countries and Eastern Europe but, on the evidence here, we're becoming a country that sings. The English choral tradition, through collegiate choirs and the massed choruses of our industrial cities, has long flourished. But this competition, single-handedly supported by Sainsbury's since its inception in 1984, extends that tradition with lively open-mindedness.

Everyone can sing. Most of us do not, or think we cannot. It would take a book to enumerate its musical, physical, social and intellectual rewards. Pioneering organisations such as the Voices Foundation are fostering singing for all, especially children of primary school age. The fruits were evident here. The highlight was a riotous and entertaining performance given by the London Gay Men's Chorus, making their first appearance in the competition. Their inventive rendition of 'Teddy Bears' Picnic' brought the house down. See for yourself and find out the results when the final rounds are shown on BBCTV over Christmas. You might even join in.

After the excesses of Buxton, a plainer diet was in order. The Takacs Quartet, celebrating 25 years since the group formed in Budapest, amply provided it to a full and attentive QEH. Their concert of Mozart, Janacek and Beethoven was inspirational. Mozart's K575, written for the Prussian King Friedrich Wilhelm II, a cellist, is one of his most equable, in spirit and in the distribution of instruments. Trying to articulate the particular characteristics of one top-class string quartet (players rather than music) is not easy. Commentators tend to speak in terms of a European sound compared with an American one, as useful to a layman as reading a map in the dark. In practical terms, the transatlantic style is more driven and rugged whereas European players favour a more rounded, poetic and subtly shaded delivery.

The Takacs epitomises that sound. Every group has its eccentricity (as well as its own variation on concert dress, here designed by Vestimenta, Milan). The Takacs line-up puts the viola rather than the cello at the end position. That this is untraditional was coincidentally pointed out in passades where both Mozart and Beethoven played the visual game of pass the musical parcel with a single phrase: in both cases the phrase had to skip a player and return, inserting a hiccup into the joke. The general sound, however, seemed to gain a special bloom from the nearness of the viola's haunting sonority.

Their account of Janacek's Quartet No 1 (The Kreuzer Sonata) was impassioned and explosive, reflecting the mood of Tolstoy's intense novella from which it takes its name. With its Beethovenian echoes, the Janacek made an ideal partner to Opus 131 in C sharp minor , arguably Beethoven's greatest achievement and one of the group of quartets written at the end of his life. Beethoven had neither precedent nor model for this seven-movement work, though Bach's spirit hovers in the fugal opening Adagio. What we now revere as a touchstone of Western art was regarded by many in its day as the sad meanderings of a great mind gone adrift, deluded by deafness. Of all the deathbed words attributed to Beethoven, the most touching are: 'I shall hear in heaven.'

fields.headline: A tramp round Harold's manor
fields.standfirst: It's Pinter all right - but the pauses are for laughter
fields.trailText:
The Caretaker Comedy Theatre, London SW1

Convictions Crumlin Road Courthouse, Belfast

Peer Gynt Olivier Theatre, London SE1
fields.body:
The Caretaker
Comedy Theatre, London SW1

Convictions
Crumlin Road Courthouse, Belfast

Peer Gynt
Olivier Theatre, London SE1

The Caretaker has a strong claim to be the best British play of the last 40 years. Now it has been directed by one of our most gifted contemporary playwrights. It's an occasion to savour. At first, Patrick Marber's treatment of Pinter doesn't look radical. There are no traces of the elevated interpretations proposed for the play - in which two brothers shelter, and eventually turf out a tramp. Terence Rattigan thought the trio represented the Father, Son and Holy Ghost; Kenneth Tynan saw them as id, ego and superego. But Marber's production is revolutionary in an unexpected way. It's down to earth. It triumphantly presents what's been considered a spooky drama as a piece of comic realism.

Traditional Pinter menace is almost entirely absent. In Rob Howell's evocative design - which looks like the contents of a Hoover bag - it's not stealth, but anxiety and hilarity that are in the air. Rupert Graves is impressively restrained and ferrety as the owner of the ramshackle joint. As the brother who's been subjected to mental-hospital terrors, Douglas Hodge is superb: an obsessive who organises himself by hobbies; frighteningly trim, with a rigid body and a ticking, blanched face.

And at the centre is Michael Gambon, who does what might be thought impossible - putting the words 'Pinter' and 'florid' into the same sentence. A stooped, quivering mound of dewlaps, jowls and stomachs, all of them grimy, he has the barking racism and rages of Alf Garnett. His eating habits and fluency belong to Dr Johnson. His elaborate, daft gentility might have been scripted by Dickens. If you think that sounds unrealistic, look at the gatherings on any park bench in London.

Noël Coward - who admired the play - regretted its concentration on the 'lowest possible social stratum'. Nowadays, that stratum looks rather more inclusive than the cocktail circuit. You could see The Caretaker as a picture of how regions of the world work: one damaged and one homeless man, with a spiv in charge.

'Why don't we have a Pinter?' raged the man in the van. 'Our playwrights have the imagination of newts: all sod, soil, soldiers and sectarianism.' He was denouncing that most revered body of dramatists: the Irish. He was doing so during the Belfast Festival, as he drove me to an event at the Crumlin Road Courthouse. In citing him, I'm breaking the law which says a critic shouldn't quote a taxi driver. But his eloquence was compelling. And his fury made a strong case for theatre. I assumed he was himself a playwright. 'No,' he protested, 'I am an Angry Taxi Driver.'

He was right about the subject matter, and wrong about the quality of the Crumlin Road experience. Convictions, produced by Tinderbox, is a tremendous example of the most dynamic area of current theatre: site-specific performance. The disused nineteenth-century courthouse hosts seven plays, each by a different writer, with a different director, each set in a different part of the building. All are rooted in post-Troubles Belfast; together, they make an argument about history and heritage.

You wait in the entrance hall, near a wooden signpost (this place is another country) which points to coroner's and Crown court; you hear doors clanging and footsteps; with warder-like brusqueness, a guide tells you to move. You walk over black and white diagrams - they're police maps. You halt beside a holding cell to watch Gary Mitchell's play.

A man, waiting to be taken to jail, howls as he hangs from the vibrating bars. You overhear a high-voltage exchange with his escort - the prisoner full of bravado, the officer haggard with memories - and follow them, past the cells of silent inmates, with gates shutting behind you, until the prisoner is left alone, and breaks down.

In a lofty courtroom, seated behind the glass of the public gallery, you listen to Owen McCaffery's dialogue: a ghostly voice pleads to know who killed him. In Nicola McCartney's Jury Room you see two jurors practising on each other the feats of observation they'll use to convict. You're always passing doors marked 'Toilet', and eventually you're shepherded into the gents: a grimy roller-towel; 'Red is a tout' scrawled on the wall; a bank of cigarette stubs under the basins. In Daragh Carville's drama two men discuss the site's future use, as a tourist information centre. One suggests that the Peace Process poses a difficulty: the Troubles were the city's 'brand'.

Convictions knocks you with its immediacy, but also asks what you're doing touristing around. It's an urgent question in Belfast, where there are taxi tours to the Shankill, with its red-white-and-blue kerbstones, its murals of Princess Diana and of fighters in black balaclavas. Horror is turning into heritage - as Convictions makes you see.

It's always hard to stage Peer Gynt. Ibsen's hero has - it's his point - several selves: playful, guilt-laden, tale-spinning, truth-seeking, sexually adventurous and mother-fixated. His contradictions are projected in a plot marked by leaps and fissures. Freighted with exotic improbabilities - with trolls and fantastic adventures - the play can look like a priapic version of The Hobbit .

The production at the Olivier has also had to contend with the National's epidemic of difficulties. The original director, Conall Morrison, withdrew; Trevor Nunn stepped in. Half-developed ideas stick out all over the place.

The title role is - sensibly - distributed between three actors, but though Joseph Marcell is imposing, both the radiant Chiwetel Ejiofor and the febrile Patrick O'Kane play on a single note. Francis O'Connor's design - a mountainous heap of suitcases - is ingenious but too jaunty. The action has been transplanted - with no obvious gain - to a folksy Ireland. Frank McGuinness's new version is brisk; nothing else is.

fields.headline: Commons as muck
fields.trailText: Yesterday in Parliament | Crossing Continents | The Wire
fields.body:
Yesterday in Parliament R4 (LW)

Crossing Continents R4

The Wire R3

Duty more than desire forces me occasionally to switch to Radio 4 long wave at 8.30am to listen to the unexpurgated version of Yesterday in Parliament. Thursday's Today had already run snippets of the debate about privatising air-traffic control, but for listeners like me with a paranoid fear of flying the longer version, packed with gloom and doom about the disasters that will inevitably follow privatisation, was obligatory.

So I switched channels and now appreciate why Parliament has been banished to the backwaters of long wave. It's boring. Choice snippets of honourable members' more articulate contributions interspersed with put-downs from the BBC's Westminster hacks are quite enough. Last week's Crossing Continents was as good as documentaries get, with a report about the booming Jewish population in Berlin. fields.headline: The Brice is right
fields.standfirst: After a 20-year gap, Brice Marden's abstracts go on display in London. About time
fields.trailText: Brice Marden | Martin Creed | Simon Starling
fields.body:
Brice Marden Serpentine Gallery, London W2 until 7 January

Martin Creed Camden Arts Centre, London NW3, 14 January

Simon Starling Camden Arts Centre, 14 January

Brice Marden paints beautiful, entrancing abstract pictures that sell for millions in America but haven't been shown here for almost 20 years. This may not seem so odd when you consider that his forefather, Jackson Pollock, only had his belated due at the Tate last year. On the other hand, our museums have been working slowly through Marden's contemporaries: Carl Andre, Frank Stella, Ed Ruscha, Chuck Close. He seems to be the mysterious exception: a quiet American who has never had the limelight in Britain that he deserves.

The Serpentine show should change all that. Eighteen big paintings, some of them mural-sized, others scaled to the dimensions of a human figure, are backed up by more than two dozen drawings. Each canvas is a loose tracery of lines unfurling across a painted surface, sometimes rich, sometimes transparent, often scraped back so far that the fabric appears, its grain as soft as time-worn denim. The webs are a bit like Pollock - refined and in slo-mo; the colours often as luminous as Rothko. But there is no Ab-Ex angst, no ego in Marden. Steep yourself in his paintings and you may even discover radiant figures.

Ten years ago, at the age of 50, Marden began painting his renowned Cold Mountain series, one of which marks the start of this show. Cold Mountain was not a place but a person, an eighth-century Chinese poet who went to live among Buddhist monks as a retort to the imperial court and its 'world of dust'. Marden liked the words. More than that, he liked the way they were written: dynamic columns of vertical characters. Until this point, he had built his paintings from abutted blocks of monochrome canvas. Crudely put, he now leapt into the free flow of calligraphy, via his inheritance from the previous generation of US painters.

If you're thinking of incense and wind-chimes, put aside such notions. Cold Mountain 2 is abidingly restrained and austere. Those old monochromes are still present in the silver-grey light that seems to glimmer behind the tangle of blue and black lines. Marden had already found the tool he has used ever since - a long-handled brush that gave him less control over his line, but more distance to witness the overall effect. As it travels over the surface, criss-crossing in snags and curves, the inky line gestures at craggy mountains in cold air. This is the place - inspired by the poet's brushwork.

Since then, a great deal has happened to Marden. He spends half the year in Greece - look at The Muses, a spectacularly energetic canvas, and you may see nine figures in the lithe, Bacchanalian loops. There's something Mediterranean in the drawings, with their dazzling white against terracotta ground. There's even something romantic in these intensely disciplined paintings: the undulating, twining lines of Sisters that abstract a portrait of Marden's daughters; the pale filigree of Virgin , that sends delicate veins of indigo across a new green pasture.

It's often said that Marden, like Klee, lets the line take a walk. A slow dance would be much nearer the mark. His brush - and thus your eye - glides round the canvas with voluptuous ease, never running away with itself, never out of hand. All sorts of pleasures occur as one line fuses, caresses or dissolves into another. The ghost of previous layers is there beneath the surface, too, sending out a glow like the red beneath the gold leaf in an icon. How it's made is the essential story of each picture.

You get the image gradually, as the lines draw you slow and deep into the web. Only when you've followed all the brilliant blues and reds that ribbon across one canvas does the title - Chinese Dancing - make full sense. In his latest series, The Attendants, Marden's lines have become simpler, broader, stronger in colour. The look is elegant, curvaceous, profoundly abstract, until you notice the bent figures that look a little like Greek caryatids - by which time you will have been relaxed, seduced by the experience of looking. This is Marden, the practised lover of paint: somewhat classical, yet always ultra-modern.

There are 18 works in Martin Creed's show, too - though it would be surprising if you noticed them all at first glance. Creed likes to make little of nothing very much: a sheet of A4 crumpled into a sphere, a table partially obstructing a door, half the air in a room captured in white balloons, the other half free for all. Some works are entirely described by their titles - 'A door opening and closing'. Others are titles alone, such as the words 'Something in the middle of a wall' printed on A4 and tacked to the middle of a wall. Not quite art, not quite nothing, these are modest proposals reduced to the absurd.

Slight, quizzical, discreet, Creed's work makes few claims or demands. A metronome has 39 speeds; wishing to know how they'd sound together he sets one for each speed and creates a rhythmic serial music. A trained painter, he wants to stick something on the wall; not wishing to add more objects to the world, he makes do with Blu-Tack. It's a constant swither between imagined possibilities and self-drawn limitations.

I used to think Creed's work was anxious and equivocal - 'Don't Worry' read the flickering neon sign he showed at the Tate. Now I'm not so certain. Once you've noticed other people succeeding where you didn't even try, his obstructed door becomes a cheerful running gag; and the best work here - Love Duet - is unequivocally romantic. It shows a single bar of music in which middle C is scored for both bass and treble clef: perfect accord in a one-note harmony.

Simon Starling's propositions are more lavishly visual. He's showing what looks like a miniature neo-classical palace - but turns out to be a chicken coop - along with some egg coddlers and a primitive oven. There are photographs of a bike ride between two Le Corbusier buildings in France and a slide installation of a car trip from Scotland to Spain to return some rhododendrons to their ancient habitat.

To join the dots, to make the smallest sense of this work, I would have to reproduce the gallery's laborious captions verbatim. Starling is very big on the continent, where they have a liking for such textual props. Without them, this art cannot speak for itself: it's just documentary evidence that doesn't add up.

fields.headline: They shoot Morses, don't they?
fields.standfirst: The 'enigmatic' Oxford detective offered up a disappointingly mundane demise
fields.trailText: Inspector Morse ITV | State of the Planet BBC1 | Cold Feet ITV | Human Remains BBC2 | Christie's Story ITV
fields.body:
Inspector Morse ITV

State of the Planet BBC1

Cold Feet ITV

Human Remains BBC2

Christie's Story ITV

Having been shot during the most dismal British summer in living memory, every external scene of the final episode of 'Inspector Morose' was infected by white-out skies, thin, sickly light and recently rained-upon ground, the colours and textures of a series in its death throes. In happier times, Morose's Oxford quads and riverside pubs shimmered under a dreamy, sepia-dapple Brides-headish sun, thus persuading potential tourists that the city boasted it's own gilded microclimate. But now the truth is out: it rains in Oxford, too, so, mark my words, bookings may plummet. Or maybe I just suffer from recovered Morse-memory syndrome, part of the same wonky internal nostalgia that rewrites one's childhood Christmases as perennially snowy winter wonderlands and summers as a three-month heat-haze spent living as Swallows and Amazons.

The Remorseful Day was not vintage Morse but it was faithful to the text inasmuch as the book left me feeling that the hero's demise was a blessed release from a desolate retirement with too much Wagner, too many snifters and unsuitable divorcées taken before lunch. Faithful, too, in that the central crime was oddly unengaging and the suspects much of a don't-much-care muchness.

There are always a few jarring moments in a Morse and this was no exception: the teenage boy Roy, for example (is anybody under 40 called Roy?), and the desperately glamorous Diana Rigg-via-Honor Blackmanish upper-middle-class murder victim who lived in a mansion but, wholly unconvincingly - even if she did have a hands-on bedside manner and a bit of a thing for fetishism - also worked as an NHS nurse, all the better to sleep with paunchy, possibly even pervy, detective inspectors. But at the end of the remorseless day it was only the sadly banal death of Morse we were primed to care about, and the unnerving possibility that his passing leaves Lewis alone in charge of stemming Oxfordshire's bloody tide of a body count. Personally, I think Morse would have been much better off murdered by a schizoid Lewis, recently converted to Wagner and then swiftly promoted before being been given the case to solve. Oh dear, I think I'm going to miss them.

Perhaps it is down to the shared physical likeness between the two National Treasures - silvery hair, voices of authority - but I thought I detected a Morse-ishly plaintive swan-song note to Sir David Attenborough's State of the Planet. All the more poignant because he has no obvious successor, either, and thus the prospect of television wildlife continuing to flourish in its natural habitat, the BBC, without Attenborough seems quite remote.

The feeling that he has owned his subject for the best part of 50 years was rammed home by the fact that, had it been presented by anyone else, State of the Planet would probably have aired at teatime on a Sunday on BBC2. After all, only Sir David can be entrusted with the awesome responsibility of attempting to enthuse viewers about bacteria and nematode worms (and he didn't), or be allowed to get away with saying 'there are moths, small ones, big ones, beetles, more moths...' without anybody at the BBC imagining that, as a result, a million itchy trigger-fingers might zap elsewhere.

On the evidence of its first episode, Attenborough's State of the Planet will prove as unmemorable as the final Morse, but will also be watched respectfully, even devoutly, by those who pine for his Golden Age.

And I shouldn't be surprised if State of the Planet is resoundingly beaten in the ratings by ITV's Cold Feet. Now in its third series, popularly described as 'the British answer to Friends' (copyright: every newspaper), this everyday story of variously uncommitted early-thirtysomething professional folk, humorously juggling marriage, divorce, infidelity, babies, work (though not much of that, to be honest) and other predictable life crises inside a selection of top-of-the-range Magnet kitchens is, unfortunately, loathed by me for reasons that are far too petty and personal to count as criticism, but which I will share with you anyway simply because I can.

Basically, James Nesbitt, as a lightly comedic, housewife's-choice of a TV Oirishman, just isn't Dylan Moran. Or, to put it bluntly, how are we meant to accept that such a profoundly unattractive physical specimen could ever pull the lovely Helen Baxendale, much less persuade her to stick around and have his babies?

But aside from finding Nesbitt unsavoury, more worrying is the fact that the writers pride themselves on tackling issues like infertility and infidelity, only to douse the plots with the cheapest 'scentimentality'. For example, the show's best actress (and most engaging character) is Fay Ripley as Jenny, now being wooed by a dotcomic millionaire. In a scene of toe-curling ghastliness, this thinly veiled cipher of a character bombarded Jenny with flowers (Cold Feet loves flowers: easy visual shorthand to make men look sensitive and women girlishly vulnerable) before turning up on her doorstep, in the rain, to deliver the following: 'I'm a pretty good catch. I'm reliable. I'm affectionate. I am, I'm told, more than averagely good in bed: passionate, courteous, imaginative but not weird or kinky. And I'm clean, which might not sound like much but shouldn't be taken for granted... Whatever happens, Jenny, if you phone me or not, I think you're absolutely spectacular.' This was meant to be cute, of course, but though real men do sometimes resort to tactics like this, (though rarely so archly scripted) they often end up with restraining orders as a result, and quite right too.

But Jenny bought it and before long the tragic eunuch returned with a pair of British Airways tickets to New York. Bet Cold Feet's sponsors, United Airlines, loved that.

No sentimentality but not quite enough laughs either, in Human Remains, in which Rob Brydon reprised his mild-mannered man-at-the-end-of-his-emotional-tether routine from Marion and Geoff, but with a different class, accent and wardrobe. Brydon's chinless Peter was stuck in a loveless marriage to Julia Davis's terrifying Flick ('at Roedean a little bullying went on, but I don't regret it'), stricken with terminal vaginismus, an eye patch and an undimmed love for her deceased fiance, Geoffrey (no relation to Marion, but buried erect - 'as I like to remember him' - in Flick and Peter's garden).

'If a life of turmoil, anguish, doubt, fear, regret and longing is a bad hand, then, yes, I've been dealt a bad hand. But is it?' pondered Peter. Maybe it was down to the presence of Julia Davis, but Human Remains looked a bit like an extended sketch from Chris Morris's Jam, and you wouldn't want to watch half an hour of that, would you?

For several minutes I thought I knew where the ITV documentary, Christie's Story, was headed: it was about a life of turmoil, anguish, doubt, fear, regret and longing. Given a year to live, the twice-divorced 24-year-old American mother of little Olivia decided to undergo dramatic surgery in order to reduce her 36-stone bulk to something she would no longer be afraid to reveal in public, and would turn out to be a predictable tale of triumph over gross adversity. But then we heard Christie's mother, Lynne, at her daughter's hospital bedside, admonishing herself for her own tears:

'Uh-oh, I got that nasty cold in my eyes again!' 'Tears?' asked Olivia. 'Sinuses!' snapped Granny.

At which point we knew that something dark and potentially Grand Guignol must have occurred within this family. Subsequently, Christie lost two-thirds of her bodyweight, her mother rejected her, she moved to the projects in a sad Arkansas town and embarked on a self-destructive spiral of drink, drugs and rampant promiscuity. Meanwhile, her formerly slim five- year-old daughter ballooned into an obese seven-year-old and a small American tragedy was turned into a gripping spectacle by Christie's intelligent articulacy but desperate lack of insight. Chillingly, there was also the sense that only regular, confrontational wake-up calls from the TV documentary crew might save her, which made Christie's Story a bit like watching an episode of Jerry Springer directed, in slurred slow-motion, by Chris Morris. Still, you'd be hard-pressed to find anything on TV more compulsive than that.

Meanwhile, her formerly slim five- year-old daughter ballooned into an obese seven-year-old and a small American tragedy was turned into a gripping spectacle by Christie's intelligent articulacy but desperate lack of insight. Chillingly, there was also the sense that only regular, confrontational wake-up calls from the TV documentary crew might save her, which made Christie's Story a bit like watching an episode of Jerry Springer directed, in slurred slow-motion, by Chris Morris. Still, you'd be hard-pressed to find anything on TV more compulsive than that.

fields.headline: The loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Diva
fields.trailText: Diva.
fields.body:
Big hair, big voice and spangly frock à la Diana Ross?
No, we're talking Diva , the phenomenally successful magazine launched in 1994, and soon to become an empire. Europe's only lesbian newsstand magazine, the 76-page monthly has a circulation of 22,000 and a core readership of 25-44 years. It focuses on every aspect of lesbian life, from Brookside storylines to all the usual shopping and health pages associated with women's magazines.

Not just a label, but a lifestyle?
Well, as lesbians earn £3,000 more per year than their straight counterparts, Diva 's publisher Millivres Prowler has decided to cash in. Look out for The Diva Book of Short Stories, edited by Helen Sandler, a slew of books, a roadshow, a T-shirt - everything except a spangly frock.

Any controversy?
Sandler's last novel Erotic Deal was described by one broadsheet as being 'one of the most explicit works of sexual fiction ever published, and unworthy of shelf space at Smiths'.

So are the stories a bit risqué?
No, not really - though shoe shopping does take on a new meaning for the well-heeled...

Is anyone else coming out of the closet?
Lesbian fiction is on the increase. Take The Best Lesbian Erotica 2000 by Joan Nestle, plus the recent launch of Queercompany, an online portal for gays and lesbians with 3,600 pages of listings, culture, style, travel, finance and chat.

It's not just a fad, is it?
Let's hope not; it's about time lesbian fiction got more upbeat.

There's a need for an image change?
Gay women are seen as unlikely to fuss on clothes, and until advertisers accept that the pink pound can belong in a purse too, lesbian publishing will be on shaky ground. Even the world's biggest lesbian magazine, Curve, struggles with advertising.

So, Big Brother 's Anna at next year's Stonewall?
Let's hope so.

To order The Diva Book of Short Stories (£8.95, Millivres Prowler Group), contact Central Books (020 8986 4854; email: orders@centralbooks.com).

webTitle: Go see... Godspeed You Black Emperor!

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ... Godspeed You Black Emperor!
fields.trailText: ... Godspeed You Black Emperor!
fields.body:
Obscure Canadian instrumentalists Godspeed You Black Emperor! unveil their apocalyptic vision in four concerts at the Scala in London this week. The collective of drummers, bassists, woodwind and string players formed in Montreal four years ago, take their name from a Japanese motorbike gang. They perform a widely praised brand of instrumental music that, to their fans, provides an even more extreme version of Kid A, Radiohead's current best-selling album of tuneless pessimism.

The band strives to remain anonymous, refusing all interview and photo requests and producing abstract cover art for their records. It is this anonymity which makes their four-night residency at the Scala all the more compelling. More of a sensory 'happening' than a straightforward rock gig, Godspeed live are like watching an unsettling but poignant movie, as the nine-piece band eke out a haunting end-of-the-world soundtrack to the accompaniment of sampled field recordings and disembodied evangelical rants. They'll be dwarfed by an innovative melange of instruments, and back-projected films.

Godspeed initially wondered whether making records would cause them to be tainted with what they consider to be the satanic brush of commercialism and radio-friendly marketing. They relented, releasing three albums with titles as impenetrable as the anti-corporate declarations that they send to the music press as promotional material.

Their first album, 'all lights fucked on the hairy amp drooling' (1995), was self-released and 'f#a#*' in 1997, was followed this year by the knowing Franglais of 'Levez Vos Skinny Fists Comme Antennas To Heaven'.

The latter two contain lengthy, gasp-inducing pieces of classical- and sample-inflected rock. They are hailed as the musical vanguard of the Seattle/Prague anti-capitalist movement due to their support for sustained protest against branding and a work culture in which the profitability of human labour is exploited at the expense of creativity and freedom. It's likely, however, that they'd rather not be hailed at all.

 Godspeed You Black Emperor! is playing at the Scala, 275-277 Pentonville Road, London N1 (020 7833 2022), from tonight. 'Levez Vos Skinny Fists Comme Antennas To Heaven' is available on Kranky Records.

fields.headline: The perfect chart hit
fields.standfirst: Pete Waterman
fields.trailText: Pete Waterman
fields.body:
There's no such thing as a perfect number one, and that's what makes them number one. They're perfect to the people who buy them. People believe there' a formula, but formulae don't work. Our hits at Stock, Aitken and Waterman weren't premeditated - we'd just write something, then think, 'That works.'

The most crucial thing is a great song. It's impossible to define, but I know it when I hear it. Writing hits is not an exact science - that's why it's the most exciting job in the world. You can't write a thesis on why you get goosebumps.

The perfect hit for me would be a Gerry Goffin and Carole King song, co-written by the Beatles and produced by Phil Spector with George Martin. That would roll all my heroes into one. Most of the best hits are about teen angst and the feelings they expressed were perfect - 'Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow', 'It Might as Well Rain Until September', 'I Want to Hold Your Hand'.

George Martin added a Britishness I found satisfying and Phil Spector was larger than life. Why put one piano on when you can have 10? Why have one drummer when you can have five?

You cannot have a great chart hit without a great performer. The performance has to seem sincere, and if there is no personality and charisma in the record, it will not become a hit. Everyone from Madonna to the Spice Girls makes you feel like they're singing just to you.

These fundamental things haven't changed for 50 years. But what the public considers to be a great song changes every week. Every song you write has to be tempered by the knowledge that it will be redundant by Monday.

 Pete Waterman's biography I Wish I Was Me (£16.99, Virgin) is out now

webTitle: The cost of... buying a ranch

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... buying a ranch
fields.trailText: ... buying a ranch
fields.body:
It is not only Hollywood players such as Michael Douglas and Oliver Stone who are buying up vast ranches - CEOs and financiers are now at it, too. (Francis Ford Coppola was smarter and bought a Napa Valley vineyard: less work and a more enjoyable end product.)

Although all ranches are big - Wyoming alone, where Harrison Ford has an 800-acre ranch, is substantially larger than Britain - they can range from several hundred acres (resort or estate ranches) to several thousand (working and dude ranches). Prices vary but, for example, 10,000 acres of Montana will set you back $20m. New Mexico is cheaper, with ranches going for around $500 per acre, while prime mountain land attracts prices of up to $5,000 per acre.

Some say that all the best ranches have gone in the States and advise looking abroad: George Soros and Luciano Benetton own millions of acres in the Argentinian Andes. Land there sells for $200 to $600 per acre.

Be imaginative when stocking your ranch: bison not only look more interesting than herds of cattle, but their meat is very low in fat and cholesterol. About four acres will support one bison, and they can be bought for as little as $500. Llamas and alpacas can also be farmed and cost up to $12,000 each, depending on pedigree.

Unsurprisingly, you will have to spend quite a lot of money on preventing your livestock wandering off into the sunset, or the neighbouring state. Electric fencing is about $300 per mile and the perimeter fence should be at least 7ft high.

Other essential equipment should include a pick-up truck and a lasso, as well as the obligatory Stetson and denims. You shouldn't worry too much about venturing into a line-dancing, rodeo-riding cultural wasteland; just try using Cormac McCarthy, Georgia O'Keefe and Hank Williams as your reference points.

Much of the hard work is seasonal, so you'll have to pay cowboys to help you out at $400 per week. Or you could try persuading holidaymakers to pay for the privilege of playing cowboy for a week.

Ranch $200 to $2,000 per acre
Bison calves $500 (bulls) to $1,200 (females)
Llamas from $1,500 each
Cowboys up to $400 per week
Electric fencing $300 per mile
Lasso rope $15 per 100ft
Pickup $25,000
Ranching holiday $975 per week

fields.headline: Faking it
fields.standfirst: From the street trader to the fashion stylist, 10 per cent of the clothing we wear is fake. But where do these copies come from? Tamsin Blanchard reports from Leicester, the counterfeit capital of Europe
fields.trailText: From the street trader to the fashion stylist, 10 per cent of the clothing we wear is fake. But where do these copies come from? Tamsin Blanchard reports from Leicester, the counterfeit capital of Europe.
fields.body:
When a magazine fashion editor took a trip to Hong Kong last year, she had to buy an extra suitcase to pack her shopping in. It was a carry-on case, with a padlock bearing the initials LV. A Louis Vuitton case is a bit self-indulgent, you might think. But it cost her just HK$40 - including the padlock. She packed it full of presents and souvenirs she had bought for friends back home. Instead of chopsticks, rice bowls and jade bracelets, however, she overloaded on brand-name, luxury designer goods - fakes, each and every one of them.

'I went to the market and it was just full of Louis Vuitton,' she says. 'It's the capital of forgery. There were Vuitton logos everywhere - and they looked so convincing.' When she wasn't sure about the carry-on case, even if it was only HK$40, the stall holder presented a catalogue. If she'd had two weeks to wait, she could have ordered whatever she wanted and had it made specially. She told her friends that the bags - miniature shoulder bags in pearlised baby blue and pink which cost her just HK$30 each, after she'd haggled - were fakes. 'But you would never know!' she boasts. 'It's fun carrying a fake bag. More fool the person who thinks it's a real label. I think there's a smugness about people who only want the real thing. Who cares?' she says.

Louis Vuitton for starters. It cares very much that its Monogram canvas, created in 1896 by Georges Vuitton, son of Louis, is common currency on market stalls across the world. It cares so much that when a newspaper journalist was spotted carrying a fake Vuitton bag into one of its shows, she was pounced on by a Vuitton employee. 'Either the bag stays outside, or you go out with it,' he told her. It was the ultimate humiliation. But it could have happened to a handful of other press and buyers taking their seats ready for the show to begin. Our Hong Kong shopaholic says she would have been 'mortified' if it had happened to her, but adds: 'They are fashion fascists. You should be able to go to a fashion show with whatever bag you choose - a Safeway bag if you want.'

But while the style police might have a few disapproving comments about a supermarket carrier, Louis Vuitton's trademark protection would take a harder view. Nathalie Moulle-Berteaux, head of Louis Vuitton's trademarks and designs department, says, 'We cannot do anything. It's private property. What we can do is try to talk about the genuine products to let the fashion journalist know if she thinks it's a joke, it's not a very good joke.'

The world has gone logo crazy. We think the 80s were a decade of conspicuous consumption, but 20 years on, brand names have become a religion, with devotees who will not waiver from the path of their chosen famous name, be it Sony, Nike or Fendi. The brand name has become more important than the product itself. Fashion houses from Burberry to Dior have sprinkled their logos so liberally that the clothes themselves cease to matter. And while those who can afford it will only buy the genuine article, most of us are happy to buy into the club via the back door. By marketing logo before product, companies have created a a phenomenal demand for branded goods. If you can get away with wearing a fake, why not?

Six-hundred miles away from the luxury fashion and leather houses of Milan, 300 miles away from the designer shops of Paris, Europe has its very own counterfeit capital. It's not in Poland, or even Turkey or Portugal, where many fakes originate. The counterfeit capital of Europe is Leicester. Our textiles industry is excelling at something after all. John Fox, principle trading standards officer for Leicester city council, carries out about 15 factory raids a year. 'To say that Leicester is the clothing counterfeiting capital of Europe is not an overstatement,' he says. 'The labels we seized last year were found in different factories on different days, but when we do our raids, we're only getting a week's product in a 48-week year. It's just the tip of the iceberg. Some just start up again the next day. We can't raid everybody every day of the week.' The maximum penalty for a factory owner is a fine, and a prison sentence of up to 10 years for the company director. The longest sentence a director has had to serve is 12 months.

Less than two months ago, the ACG carried out a raid on a factory in Leicester. 'We've raided factories where legitimate product is being manufactured next to illegitimate,' says Glyn Roberts, chairman of the Anti-Counterfeiting Group for Clothing and Footwear and a UK expert on faked clothing. 'We could take you to four or five places in Leicester where they are producing counterfeit goods.' They could also show me the counterfeiter with a personal fortune of £50m, or the 'chap in the Midlands who has not worked legitimately since 1995, but who owns four houses and a couple of Porsches.' But, of course, the men at the top make sure they are untouchable.

According to John Anderson, executive secretary of the Anti-Counterfeiting Group, up to 11 per cent of clothing and footwear in circulation are fakes, and 52 per cent of shoppers admit they would buy fake goods. 'Shoppers need to be wary. Counterfeits are becoming more and more convincing and not only does the money go on to fund more dubious activities, items purchased are not made to the same safety specifications as the real thing and there is no compensation if anything goes wrong.'

It is the quality as much as the quantity that is worrying the brand owners. 'Over the past two to three years, there has been an explosion of high-quality product on to the market,' says Roberts. 'The quality of the product is superb.'

Counterfeiters are entrepreneurs in their own right. Forgery is a warped form of flattery. If a counterfeiter goes to the effort of faking a particular brand's product, it is a sure sign that the brand itself is pressing the right buttons. Tommy Hilfiger's loyal customers spent almost $2bn on the authentic product last year. Not surprisingly, that spells dollars for the counterfeiters, too. They will find out which brands are selling well, and which particular products, and spread their production lines accordingly. They do not restrict themselves to one label either. Jim Bucock, ex-fraud squad, who now works for a major high-street brand which is a member of the ACG, was on the most recent Leicester raid. 'We found several thousand garments which would have been just one week's work,' he says. 'There were half a dozen well-known international brands.'

This is an international business, but the Trading Standards officers who work with the ACG can only operate within their own particular patch. Last year alone, 500,000 fake brand labels - from Tommy Hilfiger to Kickers - were seized from Leicester factories. Some of them have been loaned to the Victoria & Albert Museum for their Brand.New exhibition on condition that they are destroyed straight after. The disposal of the labels - which are themselves currency on the black market - is something of a headache for the city council itself.

They can't be incinerated because the council has an anti-incineration policy. Instead, they have a controlled burial. The 62,000 garments confiscated in the same year were sent to charities to be debranded ('you can take Versace studs and leather patches off jeans and put plain ones back on,' explains John Fox) or, with the brand-owner's permission, useful garments, such as fleeces and sweatshirts, are sent to countries in need, like Romania and Kosovo. Otherwise, the garments are shredded and recycled as green waste, to be used as filling for continental quilts. 'It would be disastrous to throw away pieces of clothing that are otherwise serviceable items,' says Fox.

Leicester city council has been taking action with factory raids over the past two-and-a-half years. The forgery business is a relatively new phenomenon. 'It's grown up in the 90s,' says Fox. 'Consumers have become far more brand aware - it's brands and logos that people want. It's the demand that feeds the production. Any logo is a doddle to fake because nearly everything can be copied or scanned electronically.' Often it's as simple as copying a floppy disc with an embroidery programme or a screen print on it. 'There is nothing that can't be copied,' says Fox. 'Computer technology and the demand for brands have grown up side by side.'

When he first started out in trading standards at the beginning of the 90s, Fox recalls that the fakes were crude. But 21st-century fakes are such good quality that even experienced officers like himself can't tell the difference. 'The quality of embroidery in particular is so good that we have to bring clothing experts along on raids to see if goods are real,' he says. If the Bank of England has to reissue a new design, anti-counterfeit £10 note, as it did two weeks ago, it is a measure of just how sophisticated the forgery business has become.

The fashion brands themselves try to do all they can to make their goods - and their labels and swing tickets - counterfeit-proof. Fila shoes have an anti-counterfeit label hidden under the tongue of the shoe. Three years ago, Dolce e Gabbana introduced a hologram system to its collections. 'The security hologram comes with an authenticity certificate and with a label attached to the outfit,' says a spokesperson for the company. 'It has considerably reduced the production of counterfeited goods since it is quite difficult to reproduce.'

But it has not stopped the counterfeiters altogether. For Dolce e Gabbana, the problem is mainly with its more mass-production, younger line, D&G, with fake goods originating in the Far East - everywhere from Taiwan, South Korea, China, Indonesia, and Malaysia to the Philippines. Production has also spread closer to home in Italy, with counterfeit goods, most often T-shirts, caps, jeans, and sunglasses, being made in Tuscany and Campania. Like the UK experts, they too are finding that the fake goods are becoming increasingly convincing. The company employs one member of staff full-time, as well as a team of legal consultants to deal with counterfeit goods and trademark infringement. And although the hologram label has been a success, it is finding that it too can be reproduced - especially in China.

You no longer have to travel to exotic Far Eastern destinations to stock up on fake handbags and watches. You don't even have to go as far as your local street market. Simply log on to your favourite search engine and type in the designer or brand name of your choice. New technology is not just making the act of copying easier and quicker, it is also giving counterfeiters the perfect shop window to sell their goods; the internet is the counterfeiter's dream. Online sales of beauty products alone have huge growth potential, with sales projected at around $525m by 2004. Any counterfeiter worth his gold Rolex will want a slice of that.

For a wide choice of brand names, the American website, fashionbrokers.com is an entire virtual department store. 'We are a team of experienced and passionate professionals who believe that trends in fashion are too expensive and transitory to warrant paying an excessive amount of money for them,' reads the company's manifesto. It's also created AnyKnockOff.com 'to allow you to ride the trends, whatever your budget, because you get more value for your money. We are committed to quickly identifying and producing quality knockoffs for the most current lifestyle.' And sure enough, there are Louis Vuitton look-a-like bags galore - a baby blue pearlised shopper on sale for $47 (compared with $900) or a Gucci bamboo-handle fake bag for $44 as opposed to the real thing for $800. There is look-a-like Fendi, Prada, and Christian Dior. It's like a parallel universe Bond Street bargain basement. They don't even pretend to be the real thing, but know that shoppers will revel in the idea of buying into the brand-name culture they would never normally be able to afford.

At the other end of the spectrum, there's the Danita's Boutique. Chanel does not sell any product on the internet. But Danita claims to have a small range of 'genuine' bags and accessories from the luxury fashion house - and all at prices not dissimilar to the real thing. 'All of our handbags, clothing and accessories are authentic - and come with a money-back guarantee on authenticity,' claims Danita. Scroll down the site and you will be offered 'a once-in-a-lifetime find - at such a fabulous saving - your new Chanel beauty still boasts your Chanel tag - reflecting a retail of $1,160. Your handbag will arrive in your Chanel box (upon request) along with your Chanel card of authenticity (which matches your serial number inside) and your Chanel care instructions. Absolutely breathtaking!' Danita's price? A not so breathtaking $929.99, begging the question, why not just spend the extra $200 and buy one full price at a Chanel boutique or department store?

The irony is that designer logos are also being misappropriated and customised by other designers. Burberry was forced to issue a statement this year, warning of the dangers of using its trademark print after a spate of appearances on the catwalks from London to New York. Super-cred streetwear label Stussy uses its own version of Louis Vuittons monogram as a print in its own range. The limited edition Stussy hat, which uses the monogram, customised with its own logo (which in turn is a bastardisation of the Chanel crossed Cs) and tiny repeats of a graphic of a record deck, has become a cult item. You would be forgiven for thinking it was Louis Vuitton.

According to Michael Kopelman who has been instrumental in bringing Stussy to the UK at his London store, Hideout, the Louis Vuitton logo first appeared on Stussy wear around 1988. 'It comes from the Hip Hop community's appropriation of the ghetto fabulous/superstar look,' he says. Louis Vuitton's collection for spring/summer 2001 has stolen back from the Stussy street culture with graffiti splashed across its classic luggage. Vuitton's designer, Marc Jacobs, knows his stuff. But Kopelman is cynical.

'Marc Jacobs does see street things living in NYC, but Louis Vuitton is still gear for middle-aged to old ladies and over-accessorised businessmen. It's ironic if Louis Vuitton is using graffiti - they are a very square company with no real connections to this culture.'

So, a cool logo is not necessarily the key to credibility. In fashion circles branding and logos have become such common currency, they have become positively naff. For the past two or three seasons, fashion houses, including Gucci, Dior, Chanel, Celine and Fendi have made clothes and accessories so laden with logos that they have become parodies of themselves. For spring/summer 2000, the young American designer in Paris, Jeremy Scott, went so far as to appropriate cheap souvenir logos - the sort of thing you see on T-shirts in tourist shops on the Rue de Rivoli - and make them into an ironic statement about the high-fashion obsession with the logo. He even used them badly, as a counterfeiter might - misspelling Paris, or printing it back to front. To some extent, the fashion houses only have themselves to blame for the massive public demand for logos. fields.bodyText: When a magazine fashion editor took a trip to Hong Kong last year, she had to buy an extra suitcase to pack her shopping in. It was a carry-on case, with a padlock bearing the initials LV. A Louis Vuitton case is a bit self-indulgent, you might think. But it cost her just HK$40 - including the padlock. She packed it full of presents and souvenirs she had bought for friends back home. Instead of chopsticks, rice bowls and jade bracelets, however, she overloaded on brand-name, luxury designer goods - fakes, each and every one of them. 'I went to the market and it was just full of Louis Vuitton,' she says. 'It's the capital of forgery. There were Vuitton logos everywhere - and they looked so convincing.' When she wasn't sure about the carry-on case, even if it was only HK$40, the stall holder presented a catalogue. If she'd had two weeks to wait, she could have ordered whatever she wanted and had it made specially. She told her friends that the bags - miniature shoulder bags in pearlised baby blue and pink which cost her just HK$30 each, after she'd haggled - were fakes. 'But you would never know!' she boasts. 'It's fun carrying a fake bag. More fool the person who thinks it's a real label. I think there's a smugness about people who only want the real thing. Who cares?' she says. Louis Vuitton for starters. It cares very much that its Monogram canvas, created in 1896 by Georges Vuitton, son of Louis, is common currency on market stalls across the world. It cares so much that when a newspaper journalist was spotted carrying a fake Vuitton bag into one of its shows, she was pounced on by a Vuitton employee. 'Either the bag stays outside, or you go out with it,' he told her. It was the ultimate humiliation. But it could have happened to a handful of other press and buyers taking their seats ready for the show to begin. Our Hong Kong shopaholic says she would have been 'mortified' if it had happened to her, but adds: 'They are fashion fascists. You should be able to go to a fashion show with whatever bag you choose - a Safeway bag if you want.' But while the style police might have a few disapproving comments about a supermarket carrier, Louis Vuitton's trademark protection would take a harder view. Nathalie Moulle-Berteaux, head of Louis Vuitton's trademarks and designs department, says, 'We cannot do anything. It's private property. What we can do is try to talk about the genuine products to let the fashion journalist know if she thinks it's a joke, it's not a very good joke.' The world has gone logo crazy. We think the 80s were a decade of conspicuous consumption, but 20 years on, brand names have become a religion, with devotees who will not waiver from the path of their chosen famous name, be it Sony, Nike or Fendi. The brand name has become more important than the product itself. Fashion houses from Burberry to Dior have sprinkled their logos so liberally that the clothes themselves cease to matter. And while those who can afford it will only buy the genuine article, most of us are happy to buy into the club via the back door. By marketing logo before product, companies have created a a phenomenal demand for branded goods. If you can get away with wearing a fake, why not? Six-hundred miles away from the luxury fashion and leather houses of Milan, 300 miles away from the designer shops of Paris, Europe has its very own counterfeit capital. It's not in Poland, or even Turkey or Portugal, where many fakes originate. The counterfeit capital of Europe is Leicester. Our textiles industry is excelling at something after all. John Fox, principle trading standards officer for Leicester city council, carries out about 15 factory raids a year. 'To say that Leicester is the clothing counterfeiting capital of Europe is not an overstatement,' he says. 'The labels we seized last year were found in different factories on different days, but when we do our raids, we're only getting a week's product in a 48-week year. It's just the tip of the iceberg. Some just start up again the next day. We can't raid everybody every day of the week.' The maximum penalty for a factory owner is a fine, and a prison sentence of up to 10 years for the company director. The longest sentence a director has had to serve is 12 months. Less than two months ago, the ACG carried out a raid on a factory in Leicester. 'We've raided factories where legitimate product is being manufactured next to illegitimate,' says Glyn Roberts, chairman of the Anti-Counterfeiting Group for Clothing and Footwear and a UK expert on faked clothing. 'We could take you to four or five places in Leicester where they are producing counterfeit goods.' They could also show me the counterfeiter with a personal fortune of £50m, or the 'chap in the Midlands who has not worked legitimately since 1995, but who owns four houses and a couple of Porsches.' But, of course, the men at the top make sure they are untouchable. According to John Anderson, executive secretary of the Anti-Counterfeiting Group, up to 11 per cent of clothing and footwear in circulation are fakes, and 52 per cent of shoppers admit they would buy fake goods. 'Shoppers need to be wary. Counterfeits are becoming more and more convincing and not only does the money go on to fund more dubious activities, items purchased are not made to the same safety specifications as the real thing and there is no compensation if anything goes wrong.' It is the quality as much as the quantity that is worrying the brand owners. 'Over the past two to three years, there has been an explosion of high-quality product on to the market,' says Roberts. 'The quality of the product is superb.' Counterfeiters are entrepreneurs in their own right. Forgery is a warped form of flattery. If a counterfeiter goes to the effort of faking a particular brand's product, it is a sure sign that the brand itself is pressing the right buttons. Tommy Hilfiger's loyal customers spent almost $2bn on the authentic product last year. Not surprisingly, that spells dollars for the counterfeiters, too. They will find out which brands are selling well, and which particular products, and spread their production lines accordingly. They do not restrict themselves to one label either. Jim Bucock, ex-fraud squad, who now works for a major high-street brand which is a member of the ACG, was on the most recent Leicester raid. 'We found several thousand garments which would have been just one week's work,' he says. 'There were half a dozen well-known international brands.' This is an international business, but the Trading Standards officers who work with the ACG can only operate within their own particular patch. Last year alone, 500,000 fake brand labels - from Tommy Hilfiger to Kickers - were seized from Leicester factories. Some of them have been loaned to the Victoria & Albert Museum for their Brand.New exhibition on condition that they are destroyed straight after. The disposal of the labels - which are themselves currency on the black market - is something of a headache for the city council itself. They can't be incinerated because the council has an anti-incineration policy. Instead, they have a controlled burial. The 62,000 garments confiscated in the same year were sent to charities to be debranded ('you can take Versace studs and leather patches off jeans and put plain ones back on,' explains John Fox) or, with the brand-owner's permission, useful garments, such as fleeces and sweatshirts, are sent to countries in need, like Romania and Kosovo. Otherwise, the garments are shredded and recycled as green waste, to be used as filling for continental quilts. 'It would be disastrous to throw away pieces of clothing that are otherwise serviceable items,' says Fox. Leicester city council has been taking action with factory raids over the past two-and-a-half years. The forgery business is a relatively new phenomenon. 'It's grown up in the 90s,' says Fox. 'Consumers have become far more brand aware - it's brands and logos that people want. It's the demand that feeds the production. Any logo is a doddle to fake because nearly everything can be copied or scanned electronically.' Often it's as simple as copying a floppy disc with an embroidery programme or a screen print on it. 'There is nothing that can't be copied,' says Fox. 'Computer technology and the demand for brands have grown up side by side.' When he first started out in trading standards at the beginning of the 90s, Fox recalls that the fakes were crude. But 21st-century fakes are such good quality that even experienced officers like himself can't tell the difference. 'The quality of embroidery in particular is so good that we have to bring clothing experts along on raids to see if goods are real,' he says. If the Bank of England has to reissue a new design, anti-counterfeit £10 note, as it did two weeks ago, it is a measure of just how sophisticated the forgery business has become. The fashion brands themselves try to do all they can to make their goods - and their labels and swing tickets - counterfeit-proof. Fila shoes have an anti-counterfeit label hidden under the tongue of the shoe. Three years ago, Dolce e Gabbana introduced a hologram system to its collections. 'The security hologram comes with an authenticity certificate and with a label attached to the outfit,' says a spokesperson for the company. 'It has considerably reduced the production of counterfeited goods since it is quite difficult to reproduce.' But it has not stopped the counterfeiters altogether. For Dolce e Gabbana, the problem is mainly with its more mass-production, younger line, D&G, with fake goods originating in the Far East - everywhere from Taiwan, South Korea, China, Indonesia, and Malaysia to the Philippines. Production has also spread closer to home in Italy, with counterfeit goods, most often T-shirts, caps, jeans, and sunglasses, being made in Tuscany and Campania. Like the UK experts, they too are finding that the fake goods are becoming increasingly convincing. The company employs one member of staff full-time, as well as a team of legal consultants to deal with counterfeit goods and trademark infringement. And although the hologram label has been a success, it is finding that it too can be reproduced - especially in China. You no longer have to travel to exotic Far Eastern destinations to stock up on fake handbags and watches. You don't even have to go as far as your local street market. Simply log on to your favourite search engine and type in the designer or brand name of your choice. New technology is not just making the act of copying easier and quicker, it is also giving counterfeiters the perfect shop window to sell their goods; the internet is the counterfeiter's dream. Online sales of beauty products alone have huge growth potential, with sales projected at around $525m by 2004. Any counterfeiter worth his gold Rolex will want a slice of that. For a wide choice of brand names, the American website, fashionbrokers.com is an entire virtual department store. 'We are a team of experienced and passionate professionals who believe that trends in fashion are too expensive and transitory to warrant paying an excessive amount of money for them,' reads the company's manifesto. It's also created AnyKnockOff.com 'to allow you to ride the trends, whatever your budget, because you get more value for your money. We are committed to quickly identifying and producing quality knockoffs for the most current lifestyle.' And sure enough, there are Louis Vuitton look-a-like bags galore - a baby blue pearlised shopper on sale for $47 (compared with $900) or a Gucci bamboo-handle fake bag for $44 as opposed to the real thing for $800. There is look-a-like Fendi, Prada, and Christian Dior. It's like a parallel universe Bond Street bargain basement. They don't even pretend to be the real thing, but know that shoppers will revel in the idea of buying into the brand-name culture they would never normally be able to afford. At the other end of the spectrum, there's the Danita's Boutique. Chanel does not sell any product on the internet. But Danita claims to have a small range of 'genuine' bags and accessories from the luxury fashion house - and all at prices not dissimilar to the real thing. 'All of our handbags, clothing and accessories are authentic - and come with a money-back guarantee on authenticity,' claims Danita. Scroll down the site and you will be offered 'a once-in-a-lifetime find - at such a fabulous saving - your new Chanel beauty still boasts your Chanel tag - reflecting a retail of $1,160. Your handbag will arrive in your Chanel box (upon request) along with your Chanel card of authenticity (which matches your serial number inside) and your Chanel care instructions. Absolutely breathtaking!' Danita's price? A not so breathtaking $929.99, begging the question, why not just spend the extra $200 and buy one full price at a Chanel boutique or department store? The irony is that designer logos are also being misappropriated and customised by other designers. Burberry was forced to issue a statement this year, warning of the dangers of using its trademark print after a spate of appearances on the catwalks from London to New York. Super-cred streetwear label Stussy uses its own version of Louis Vuittons monogram as a print in its own range. The limited edition Stussy hat, which uses the monogram, customised with its own logo (which in turn is a bastardisation of the Chanel crossed Cs) and tiny repeats of a graphic of a record deck, has become a cult item. You would be forgiven for thinking it was Louis Vuitton. According to Michael Kopelman who has been instrumental in bringing Stussy to the UK at his London store, Hideout, the Louis Vuitton logo first appeared on Stussy wear around 1988. 'It comes from the Hip Hop community's appropriation of the ghetto fabulous/superstar look,' he says. Louis Vuitton's collection for spring/summer 2001 has stolen back from the Stussy street culture with graffiti splashed across its classic luggage. Vuitton's designer, Marc Jacobs, knows his stuff. For the past two or three seasons, fashion houses, including Gucci, Dior, Chanel, Celine and Fendi have made clothes and accessories so laden with logos that they have become parodies of themselves.
