webTitle: The way we live now: Catwalk kids

fields.headline: Catwalk kids
fields.standfirst: Clothes maketh the baby
fields.trailText: Catwalk kids
fields.body:
'I'm just popping out to get some PVC trousers,' I told my other half. There was a pause. 'Haven't you already got a pair?' my partner asked cautiously, just in case he'd got his fabrics mixed. He was right, however. I do have a pair of PVC jeans. The trousers I was going shopping for weren't for me. 'They're for the baby!' I announced.

Now, anyone who wasn't aware that you can now get PVC trousers (black, of course) for babies has clearly never paid a visit to Baby Gap. In this case, they won't have seen the tiny black leather jacket either. Yes, I've got that too, although the zip sticks a bit, especially when I've got the oatmeal cashmere hooded top underneath. Also, the collar rides up. If I don't keep tugging it down, he looks less like a miniature James Dean than Uncle Fester. I tell everyone that the PVC and leather are not fashion statements. 'They're terribly practical, wipe clean,' I say. But I'm lying. My child is a fashion victim, and it's all my fault.

I have become a casualty, or rather my son has, of the Mini Me syndrome. This is where new parents are gripped by the desire to tog their kids up in ludicrously expensive versions of adult clothing. There's the Hennes kids department and any number of designer-label kids' ranges, notably Ralph Lauren and Tommy Hilfiger. Then there's the Mini Boden and Little Badger catalogues. You see, you don't even have to leave home to make your offspring look totally ridiculous.

I am not proud of what I am doing to my child. Every time I put my jean-jacketed baby into my three-wheeled pram and push him down the street, I see other parents pushing their denim-wearing offspring in similar vehicles and I want to throw up. We are raising a generation of overdressed clones. I have to admit that I bonded with another mother at my Baby Massage class on the strength of her Gap changing bag, the same as mine. When I go to my postnatal appointments I know there will always be at least one other baby in dungarees.

I didn't start out wanting to make a spectacle of my child. 'You're not going to dress the baby in little adult clothes are you?' I remember someone asking me before the birth. 'Oh no,' I replied in an appalled tone. And at first I did quite well. I put Griffin in plain white babygrows, just like Meg Mathews said she was going to do with her baby Anais. By the way, did you see the most recent snap of the soon-to-be-ex Mrs Gallagher and child? Out have gone the babygrows. In have come pink marabou deely boppers. Not very minimalist.

The ultimate Mini Me Baby is Posh and Becks' little human accessory, Brooklyn. If there is a miniature version of an adult-sized designer label, he will have it. There is now also a TV version, Baby David on The Royle Family . I took one look at his suede fringed jacket and cringed. There, but for a different sort of cow hide, go I.

So why do I and so many other mothers do it? Well, for a start, this isn't all women's work. Some of the most enthusiastic consumers of Mini Me clothing are men. The days when it was only girls who were born to shop are now gone. Many chaps now actually enjoy looking at clothes, except they feel a bit silly buying frilly things for a baby. Still, give them a sheepskin gilet and a pair of tweeny weeny Timberlands and there's no holding them back.

When women do the buying, there are darker motives at work. If the baby is a girl, there is a lot of wish-fulfillment going on. For all those women brought up in the 70s when feminist mothers didn't exactly rush out to buy Snow White costumes, having a baby of your own is chance to indulge. If the baby is a boy, it's revenge. After 20 years spent surreptitiously struggling with successive boyfriends' clothing, this is my chance to dress a man exactly as I want, with no argument, sulking or having to offer sexual favours.

There are other factors. Dual-income couples having children later have more money to spend. If you're accustomed to spending three grand on a Conran sofa, 20 quid for a Baby Gap denim jacket doesn't seem so bad. Add in sleep deprivation and hormones doing the hokey cokey, and it's a wonder more babies aren't dressed in the silver padded spacesuit my sister just brought back for Griffin from Washington. (If you really want to play the label game, US Baby Gap trumps UK Baby Gap every time.)

It is no accident that I brought Griffin's first Mini Me outfit on a shopping trip two weeks after the birth when I was supposed to be buying clothes for myself. I couldn't get one leg in a Kookaï size 14 and was so depressed I was almost forced to jog to Hennes kids' department. Until you've shifted the pregnancy flab, the only decent shopping therapy available is babywear.

The result of all this is that getting Griffin dressed is a nightmare of fiddling with tiny buttons and zips. Then I have to decide whether to do a bib or not. Mothercare terry towelling hardly sits well with PVC, but if I decide to chance it, you can bet he will throw up all over his carefully coordinated outfit. When I leave him with Mercedes, our cleaner, she puts him into a T-shirt and jersey leggings that don't match. I think this is a hint. As my mother, who can't get her head round the PVC at all, says: 'He'd be so much happier in a babygrow.' Yes, but would I?

webTitle: Will Buckley: Village of the damned

fields.headline: Village of the damned
fields.trailText: Moving to The Priory changes your perspective. And over the past month or so I have found myself saying things to my wife and family that I never thought I would have the courage to say.
fields.body:
Moving to The Priory changes your perspective. And over the past month or so I have found myself saying things to my wife and family that I never thought I would have the courage to say. Only last week, for instance, I said all of the following:

1) 'That's an incredible cloud formation.'

2) 'Look at that tree.'

3) 'What would everyone like for breakfast?'

Extraordinary. Perhaps it's The Shock of the Yew which is bound to affect anyone who has spent 36 nature-free years in London and now finds themselves in Norfolk. Perhaps Gronnie and I are pulling the wool over our eyes. It is possible that as we sit in front of the log fire - and what on earth did people do for entertainment in the days before log fires? - mutually congratulating ourselves, in between bottles of wine, on the wisdom of our decision and how happy the kids are, that we are deluding ourselves. Such a build-up can only presage a fall. There is nothing like praise for bringing on an attack of the doubts. And...

Well, there was that moment a couple of weeks ago. Late on a Wednesday afternoon, paddock flooded, cooking apples floating up the drive, stuck high up in the west wing, alone, hadn't left the premises for a week, sitting at typewriter, tip tap tapping away, when, for a frankly queasy moment, I thought I was on the verge of transmogrifying into Jack Nicholson in The Shining . A change that would be no fun for Gron and the kids and, without being selfish, not great for me either. Nothing upsets the rural idyll quicker than a crazy running down the corridor with a chainsaw screaming, 'Here's Willy.' People talk.

Discussing it later with Gron in front of the log fire - are you getting the picture? Can we assume that unless I mention otherwise that's what we're doing? - she reckoned that I needed to get out more.

Easier said than done. The problem is both logistical and personal. It is a question of How? and Who? - the saving grace being that it hasn't yet become one of Why?.

Essentially, until I pass my driving test I am reliant on Gron for ferrying around and, no argument, she's got her hands full looking after the three kids. Clearly, I could try branching out on my own, but come the time when I have my dander up and my wellies on, I am hamstrung by another interrogatory: Where? The local pub? Twenty minutes there, 20 back to sit in the corner downing a couple of pints of Adnams while reading the Diss Express from cover to cover. Not yet, I think. The Young Farmers' Club? Bit of a culture clash. The bus shelter? What bus shelter?

I exaggerate. I am not totally without a social life. Obviously I took advantage of Halloween to do some trick and treating, and great fun it was too, albeit rather hazardous without street lighting. Then there was a PTA meeting at Swanson's Bungay. Not at first sight very promising, but I rapidly developed a colossal interest in school affairs when I discovered Swanson's was a pub.

A fine time was had by all, although it was somewhat different from my normal pub sessions. For a start, I was the only one buying rounds. Round one: a pint of bitter, two Cokes with ice and lemon, a water, and an orange juice and lemonade. Round two: a pint of bitter, a St Moritz, and a water - in my experience people very rarely ask for a second Coke.

Happily, I may have been the only one buying, but I wasn't the only one drinking alcohol. The publican, who provided some spectacular eats, made sure his white-wine glass was regularly topped up by his employee. And if the party didn't quite swing, it certainly moved. The conversation being dominated by discussion of whether some of the elderly parishioners could cope with a bring and buy sale in the afternoon and a wine-tasting event in the evening. Conclusion: probably not. Quite right, too - I'm not entirely certain that, on present form, I could adapt to such a pace. All in all, a cracking night out. Roll on the next PTA meeting.

Roll on, too, the next Book Club meeting. Call me kinky, but when I was first appraised of this shindig I assumed Book Club was a far from convincing euphemism for a different type of meeting altogether. Not a bit of it. Exactly as it said on the invite, we sat down and discussed John Banville's The Untouchable. And then we went home. Next month, The Great Gatsby.

fields.headline: Hard day's night
fields.standfirst: Insomnia doesn't just ruin your nights, it plays havoc with your days. Leah Jewett reveals the dark side of sleeplessness
fields.trailText: Insomnia doesn't just ruin your nights, it plays havoc with your days. Leah Jewett reveals the dark side of sleeplessness.
fields.body:
Insomnia hit me overnight and fast became an inadvertent hobby. Getting the better of it is not an exact science, and even now, a year down the line, I haven't shaken the habit completely. It is cold comfort that, as I've variously read, 50 per cent of the population is currently in 'sleep deficit', that 90 per cent will have insomnia at some point, that one in three is likely to experience chronic insomnia. Along with the numbers, prevailing wisdom varies wildly: one school of thought has it that adults need anywhere from three to 11 hours of sleep, depending on the individual, another maintains that seven to eight is optimal. There are always sliding scales; there are no hard and fast rules.

In the initial throes of sleep disruption, before my insomnia became chronic, I read with some foreboding the testimonials on the internet: it's been three months; six months; years. Mine is a singular case, I told myself - I'll combat this in no time. And so I went about testing the waters of different approaches.

A year ago. A crisis at work. I go home late, have dinner at 10pm, am fast asleep by 11.30pm. Suddenly the clock reads 2am, and I'm bolt-upright awake, riveted, lucid, heart surging into overdrive. Aiming to relax, trying not to think, I end up racing through a back catalogue of scenarios. After an hour or so, I slide into light sleep, only skimming the surface, then blast awake again at 4.30am, my blood pressure vertiginous. I wrestle with runaway thoughts, then around 6.45am I fall into deep, restorative rest for all of 45 minutes. Am I out of my mind? It's a question of beating myself at my own game, trying to get away with racking up as many consecutive hours of sleep as possible.

This becomes a pattern. By day, I coast through the pressure at work on less than five hours' sleep. I am on efficient automatic pilot, wired. But the anxiety doubles back on me like a boomerang in the early hours, coupled with the fear of staying awake - which becomes, of course, a self-fulfilling prophecy. The boundaries are blurred, each part of my life vampirising the next: sleeplessness taking its toll on health, health affecting work, work impinging on home. And this goes on, week in, week out.

They say that nothing ages you like sleep deprivation. So I canvas opinion from friends and acquaintances. Everyone speaks from experience; everyone has known some form of insomnia: Don't look at the clock. Get up. Get up and read. Read in bed. Listen to music. Take a hot bath before retiring. Take a hot bath in the middle of the night. Sleep on your back. On your left side. On your right side. Drink camomile tea. Hot milk. Hot milk with a banana. Have a little tipple. Avoid alcohol. Avoid carbohydrates. Eat wholemeal bread. Eat lots of protein at lunch. Eat lots of protein at night. Don't eat protein at night. Don't eat too much. Don't eat too late. Exercise.

I start by stepping up the physical exertion: I cycle to and from work, toy with weight-bearing exercises, take up yoga during my lunch hour. The calm and discipline of yoga pay dividends over the long haul. Sometimes, after several nights of erratic sleep, I am astounded to find myself drifting off during the five minutes of relaxation at the end of the session. But it isn't enough to put a dent in the insomnia.

A friend hands me a bottle of Origins' Sensory Therapy Pillow Mist. My sister gives me flash American gadgetry - a pen with a miniature lightbulb on the tip for writing in the dark. Somehow I acquire the CD Sleep Yoga by Paul Bancroft (£12.99, Ziegel), which generates an hour's worth of white noise. All to no avail.

Insomnia is held to be a symptom, a wake-up call that signals an underlying cause. And the causes are as difficult to isolate as the 'cures' are subjective and hard to nail down. It's daunting to differentiate among all the possible factors - logistical, psychological, culinary, behavioural - then to systematically cut back, reintroduce, experiment.

The process of elimination begins - and my immediate environment seems an easy target. We replace the new bed frame that makes a loud sound like a ship creaking in a storm every time we so much as turn over, buy a lighter-weight duvet, a black-out blind. This sensory deprivation notwithstanding, on some nights I still reach for the eye mask and earplugs - only to find that soundproof-booth oblivion doesn't make a blind bit of difference.

Turning towards herbal remedies, I amass an arsenal of potions, tablets, stopper-dispensing liquids. Valerian, kava kava and Herbal Nytol sometimes do the trick for a few hours at a stretch; at other times it is Russian roulette - I down a few capsules by the light of the opened fridge, and still can't surmount the restlessness.

I even flee to a retreat in the Malvern Hills which offers massage, reflexology and a flotation tank. Away from home, the insomnia subsides. Because I've altered my habits, escaped my quotidian environment, left my worries behind? Perhaps I've broken the cycle, I think, perhaps it was just a phase. But the minute I bed down in my own flat again, the staccato sleep pattern kicks in once more.

Several months have elapsed since the crisis that catalysed my sporadic insomnia - now I combat sleeplessness for no apparent reason; I translate any unease into this ongoing routine. And I begin to sound like a broken record. The Chinese herbalist I go to see turns out to be a Caucasian American specialising in Japanese herbalism. She speaks to me of yin and yang, declares that the energies of daytime spilling into the night are causing me unrest. Over the months, she metes out various powders: dragon bone, peony, ginseng, lotus seed. For a while I feel less wound up, but soon, regular as clockwork, I'm back to my usual trick of intermittent sleep.

In another last-ditch effort, I trawl through a few homeopathic chemists. 'You're over-aware,' one pharmacist observes. 'You need to be earthed.' She can recommend a concoction of specific remedies - Arsenica album is ideal for those who wake up at 2am and erratically thereafter - but because homeopathy is holistic, treating not the symptoms but the cause, she reckons it's best to see a homeopath. Sure enough, the little pillules she's given me are no soporific.

In desperation, I call on my GP, demand sleeping pills. He prescribes me five Temazepam - only five! - which prove to be a stop-gap palliative that lays me low for five hours, but leaves me shaken the next day, dulled. He also signs me up for the Stress Management Clinic he and a therapist are running. Ironically, it is stressful to down tools and dash out of work early every Monday for six weeks. When it comes time to tally up the stress-inducing events in our lives, everyone in the group scores between 16 and 63 - I'm off the scales at 231. I'd charted such upheavals in the past year as landing a new job; trouble at work; buying a flat; putting the finishing touches on the flat days before throwing a big party; getting married; my husband's heart scare. I win! I have, on paper, quantifiable reasons to be stressed.

Each week our earnest, nerve-wracked group tackles stress from a new vantage - what and how we eat; our knee-jerk reactions to tension - and through visualisation, deep breathing and other techniques we learn how to be relaxed yet alert. The process is helpful, makes me question my lifestyle. It is brought home to me that stress can be addictive - you end up craving the stimulus, upping the ante until you fall - and that relaxation is an art, a skill. The key is practice.

And it is hard work. I flirt with self-help, keeping Barefoot Doctor's Handbook for the Urban Warrior by Stephen Russell (£8.99, Piatkus) on my bedside table, dip into Ultimate Relaxation: A Seven-Step Programme for Stress-Free Living by Eddie and Debbie Shapiro (£10.99, Quadrille) and peruse the recently published Freedom From Insomnia by Alexander Stalmatski (£7.99, Kyle Cathie), a highly regimented, controversial method which purports to work miracles in five days through shallow breathing. I venture on to the net, finding the questionnaires on www.iris-publishing.com an invaluable way to sift through the morass of causes and effects.

It's impossible to ascertain what it took to gradually reacquaint myself with sleep. The crisis at work a year ago brought to the fore a delayed reaction to a backlog of stressful events, and interrupted sleep became a pattern I lapsed into when under duress. It's been a question of trouble-shooting - reading up about insomnia, trying herbal supplements and taking a stress-management course have all helped keep the restlessness at bay, and remarkably, a few late-night sessions at the newly opened nearby gym consistently induce a less fractured night's sleep. But the ultimate panacea seems to be time, and things changing slowly over time. Now I go through less extreme variations on the theme: it is rare that I snap out of sleep into panic. Sometimes, with the radio on low, I rediscover warm, dark, escapist drowsiness. Far from being entirely shot of insomnia, I am, however, losing less sleep over losing sleep these days.

Eyes wide open

 Famous insomniacs include Charles Dickens, Winston Churchill, Margaret Thatcher, Napoleon, Dorothy Parker, Van Gogh, Marilyn Monroe

 Insomnia is not just a preoccupation linked to our high-octane modern lifestyle - Aristotle wrote Sleep and Sleeplessness in 350BC

 Women tend to be more wakeful than men and are 1.3 times more likely to report insomnia

 Odd cures for insomnia abound: wearing mittens in bed, eating peanut butter before bedtime, and sucking a spoon-shaped radio transmitter while trying to nod off. The electromagnetic field is thought to influence the brain's electrical rhythms and encourage relaxation

 Lack of sleep is bad for your brain. The British Sleep Foundation warns that sleeping one hour less than the recommended eight can lower your IQ by one point the next day

 Malaysian radio DJ Halim Othman stayed awake for 42 hours to break the world record for uninterrupted radio broadcast. He was allowed only a 10-minute break every hour to eat, bathe and pray

 The longest period anyone has managed to stay awake is 264 hours. American schoolboy Randy Gardner imposed the trial on himself in 1963 and still holds the world record

webTitle: Rafael Garcia-Navarro relives the birth of his daughter Anastasia

fields.headline: An estimated 2,000 women will give birth in the UK today
fields.standfirst: Some of their labours will go smoothly. Some won't. Rafael Garcia-Navarro relives one that didn't - the birth of his daughter Anastasia
fields.trailText: Some of their labours will go smoothly. Some won't. Rafael Garcia-Navarro relives one that didn't - the birth of his daughter Anastasia
fields.body:
My wife Rachael and I had been married a little over one year, when we found out we were having a baby. It was a happy surprise. There were many others, such as the one at roughly nine weeks when we went for an ultrasound dating scan. Looking at the indistinct grey image on the monitor, we noticed a tiny blip, a flickering light racing headlong within the enveloping darkness: it was our baby's heartbeat.

Rachael's estimated date of delivery was 3 December 1996. Men don't experience physical sensations to match rushing oestrogen, but when I placed my hand on Rachael's stomach my own feelings were intense. I was full of love for her and the baby and the prospect of being a father. In contrast to many women, Rachael delighted in her changing body. Never more womanly and radiant, she seemed to coast on an emotional high.

There was a great deal to learn. Together we read books on everything from breach births to babies' names. There were classes. Rachael found one explaining every medical contingency, and another that emphasised yoga and breathing techniques. These were for women only - partners came on selected occasions for an informal get-together - a peculiarity of this country's approach to fathers that guarantees a feeling of exclusion. We met two of the four community midwives on our team, who made a good impression and were helpful in formulating a birth plan. Sensitivity to parents and open-mindedness are the best aspects of the NHS. The downside is that the number of labouring women on a ward at one time is unpredictable. During a rush, it's a lottery. In addition, the possibility that when the day came we'd end up being delivered by a stranger was unnerving.

Less than three weeks before the finish line, we switched horses: Rachael's confidence was shaken by two recent accounts from friends at the NHS hospital where she was scheduled to deliver. We were afraid of an inadequately supervised labour. Time was running out for other options. The Harley Street obstetrician recommended by our GP was a New Zealand smoothie - funny and charming but certainly no feminist: 'The patients that really make my heart sink are the ones who come with a "birth plan",' he whirred. 'I tell the ones who ask about a birthing pool that I don't pack swimming trunks. You might think you want aromatherapy oils massaged on your back and soft lights and music, but let me tell you what labour is really like. Once it begins, it hurts. You'll want pain relief. You'll want an epidural. Then I'll take over and you can have a nice cup of tea.'

The cavalier attitude notwithstanding, what he was offering was supervision and expertise, and after hearing about women screaming for hours unattended and later performed upon without proper anaesthesia, it was reassuring. He also promised to leave well enough alone if things were going smoothly. Rachael aspired to her mother's natural and trouble-free deliveries (two out of three performed at home), but she was ready to accept pain relief and medical intervention, as a last resort.

I wasn't sure what my place was in this ritual. As December approached, I felt a rush of excitement, but was much less certain how I'd feel if I saw Rachael in physical distress, particularly when there would be nothing I could do to help. My apprehensiveness was also cultural: my background is Cuban, not English; none of the women in my family have asked their husbands to witness their deliveries, nor have the men made a beeline toward the delivery room. In the event, I was the one who needed gas and air, Nicola would fill in and lend Rachael her support.

We began timing them at 7.45am: they were three minutes apart, each lasting 45 seconds. She complained of so little pain, it was a difficult at first to grasp how this could be labour, let alone one already fairly established. Rachael telephoned her birth instructor, who urged us, sensing it was going at lightning speed, to get to the hospital. We made our way through heavy traffic and a frosty downpour, arriving there at 10.30am.

By the time the first measurement was taken 15 minutes later, Rachael was at 5cm, a little over the halfway mark. She was offered an epidural and declined. The midwife called the obstetrician, who was lecturing at another London hospital. As we waited, the contractions became more intense, with referred pain to the sacrum, and the midwife again offered the epidural, suggesting that labour was likely to go on for another five or six hours, and Rachael would probably be too exhausted to push. Hoping to avoid that scenario, she consented.

When the anaesthetist finally arrived at noon, Rachael was in a state of trance; our words became murmurs heard at the end of a long corridor. Another measurement was taken; now it was 8cm. This is what is known as transition, the most intense - but frequently the shortest - phase of labour. The anaesthetist conferred with the obstetrician by telephone and without consulting Rachael, administered not the 'mobile' epidural she had expected, but the full dead-from-the-waist-down dose. With the last contraction, before the anaesthesia took hold, Rachael felt an urge to push - then nothing.

With hindsight, my passivity depresses me. I didn't know what her pain ceiling would be, and felt at a disadvantage making any kind of case to people who supervised deliveries every day. My lack of experience prevented me from taking a more active role in helping to avert the managed delivery Rachael did not want. When she agreed to the epidural, I confess I was relieved.

Our obstetrician arrived unfashionably late at 2pm. 'How nice of you to squeeze us in,' Rachael remarked. 'You almost missed it.' 'No worries,' he smirked. A preliminary examination confirmed that labour had ground to a halt and contractions were weak. The hormone solution to resuscitate them linked via a drip drew little initial response. The dose had to be increased steadily throughout the course of the afternoon until 4.50pm, when Rachael was asked to put down her cup and begin to push.

She watched the monitor for cues, only to feel the faintest tightening. Unable to squat or kneel (thanks to the epidural), she pushed while lying on her back, with one foot on the midwife and another on the doctor. Absent from her natural impulse, Rachael says today she felt completely detached, even self-conscious.

The full mechanised delight lay in store, beginning with the episiotomy, an incision to enlarge the vaginal opening. Eighty to 90 per cent of new mothers have them, according to recent studies in the United States that are critical of their general use and also show a comparable rate of increased blood loss during delivery and unpleasant complications (such as anal incontinence) following the procedure.

The clicking and snapping of flesh being cut makes fingernails on a blackboard sound like a string quartet. The doctor made the first incision to apply a ventouse. When the implement disengaged, he cut again, then again, deep this time, and finally brought out the forceps. The tension in the room was excruciating. Our baby girl was born at 5.30pm, weighing 7lb 5oz. 'She looks just like your mother,' beamed Rachael.

An expression of shock is etched in my mind: the baby could literally have been asking, 'What is this?' So, unfortunately, is the obstetrician's non-existent effort to shield us from the carnage spilled all over the room; we had the front-row view. Surreal is the polite word to describe the scene: Rachael propped up on her bed, slashed and gaping, sipping tea, asking the doctor about his sewing technique, while he calmly stitched the tissue back into place. The delivery suite looked like the Battle of Waterloo. Harley Street had provided the very experience we had hoped to avoid with the NHS, only here it came with a fee and a smile.

But we had our little girl. Gazing at her tiny wrinkled hands and feet and listening to her first, plaintive cries, the worst images of the birth room seemed very far away. I felt only gratitude. The next day a procession of family, friends and flowers made its way into our room. Rachael badly needed to recover, but kept the festivities going even as she nursed and we took turns holding our little bundle and discussed names. By the end, she was exhausted.

When I arrived the following morning, she mentioned that the baby had been sick. In the darkness, the vomit looked green. When I asked the midwives about this, they said it was normal. I noticed how the baby, so alert and self-possessed the day before, now seemed floppy and listless. Like a little dormouse, she slept most of the morning.

In the afternoon, while Rachael was having a bath, the baby was sick again. The vomit was dark green. We called a midwife immediately, who said she didn't know what it could mean but she'd call the paediatrician straight away. Our daughter was very still and quiet throughout his examination, after which he whispered something to the nurse about a radiology report.

He didn't tell us anything immediately; all he said was that the baby had vomited bile, which pointed to an obstruction. He needed a gastrointestinal (or upper GI) contrast study to know more. Suddenly, the toll of labour hit us; Rachael was so tired she had a hard time taking in the news. I accompanied the nurse to obtain the X-ray and held my baby, kissing her cool forehead as she slumbered on. As they held her down to obtain the image, her weak sobs pierced my heart.

I knew by the way the internist studied the X-ray that something wasn't right. Evening had settled, when we next met with the paediatrician, who spoke more openly. The upper GI showed a classic 'double bubble', indicating air in the stomach and lower in the intestine past the obstruction without being present anywhere else. He said he'd need to call a surgeon to confer, a famous friend from the Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital whose specialty, he said, intending to comfort us, was separating Siamese twins. His grave expression left little to the imagination: our baby's life was hanging in the balance. The surgeon only asked him one question: 'Are you matching blood yet?'

While the surgeon made his way to see us, we sat with our baby, still fast asleep, and began to come to terms with the certainty of surgery. We made calls to our families. The sadness of our situation was intolerable. I was reduced to a begging wreck. None of my questions or attempts to secure hopeful assurances met with success. They couldn't be certain of what they'd find. Rachael was so spent, she couldn't even weep.

The surgeon entered the room, which in the presence of so many bouquets had suddenly taken on the look of a mortuary. He examined the baby and dourly told us the situation was 'very grave'. He handed me a legal release form to sign, in which I was taking responsibility for her surgery, and our baby was wheeled away. It was nearing midnight.

I was 16 years old when my father died in front of me of cancer at 39. I thought life had no heavier weapon to wield against happiness. Now, having experienced the greatest joy in the birth of my daughter, I learned there was something more terrible than the loss of a parent, the prospect of losing a child. Waiting for the operation to begin, I experienced the insanity of grief. I found the sight of Rachael on the phone to her mother unbearable. Finally welling up with tears, all she could say was, 'poor little soul'. I felt like my life was being consumed by shadows.

A soul was all our baby was. We hadn't agreed on a name. From our list, we chose one we loved, whose significance was more potent than ever before. Often mistaken as Russian because of the Romanov grand duchess, it is actually a Greek name. It refers to Easter and the Resurrection, meaning literally, 'she will rise again'. To the extent that we could pray for her life, we named our beautiful girl Anastasia.

When the doctors returned 90 minutes later, their open smiles more than hinted at their news. The operation had been successful, but we were still not out of the woods. Anastasia had malrotation of the bowel, an anomaly of which the incidence rate and cause remain unknown. Either sex can be affected; approximately 60 per cent of cases present in the first month of life. Symptoms include the bilious vomiting she experienced plus three she did not, abdominal pain, abdominal distention and extreme dehydration. In the fourth week of fetal life, the entire bowel is a straight tube following the line of the superior mesenteric artery, or SMA. In a normal pregnancy, the bowel rotates in place to the left of the SMA between the seventh and 12th weeks of gestation. In Anastasia's case, intestinal rotation and fixation did not complete. It was a time bomb.

Peristalsis, the motion of digestion, is an immediate cause; vomiting bile provides the clue. The reason there were so few guarantees going into surgery was the possibility of necrosis with perforations. In that instance, Anastasia would have lost some - or most, or all - of her digestive tract; and more than likely, her life. There is a 28 per cent mortality rate associated with midgut volvulus, but timing is everything. Our swift diagnosis had been a stroke of luck.

Our surgeon performed the Ladd's procedure named after Dr William E Ladd of the Boston Children's Hospital, who developed it in the 1920s. He unravelled the twisted bowel and, observing an immediate change in colour back to pink, judged it to be viable. Before returning the bowel back into the abdominal cavity, he also performed an appendectomy - a routine procedure, as the misplaced appendix can impede a correct diagnosis of appendicitis in later life.

While no portion of the bowel was sectioned, it was nevertheless a major operation for a two-day-old baby. There was additional concern that the intestine, which resists handling, could form adhesions requiring more surgery. There were tears, not of joy or sadness even, but of devastation; it had been impossible in the space of a few hours to adjust emotionally to the enormity of what had just happened. I didn't want to see Anastasia in the neonatal unit that night, because I was afraid. A midwife called and urged me, saying I'd feel better. So I took the lift with my wounded wife to witness the survival of my wounded daughter. In her little plastic box, plugged full of morphine, hooked up to IVs and monitors, and wearing a nasogastric tube and a large laparotomy scar, I had to remind myself that this was the outcome we had prayed for.

Anastasia spent 10 days in intensive care. Separated from her baby, Rachael also remained at the hospital, having initially emerged from labour with anaemia (due to blood loss), a displaced pelvis and extreme post-operative pain. She struggled to establish a milk supply for a baby who might not live. I found myself wandering through London trying to find announcement cards, hopeful but insecure over their ultimate use.

No one tells you about the possibility; no one wants the discomfort of hearing about it afterwards. The social halitosis of a hard-luck story provokes in most people the urge to stampede. This deafening silence extended even to us as parents - we couldn't bring it up. The most cursory tasks - changing a nappy, getting out of the house in time - made me impatient and angry. My anxiety was rampaging, my need for distractions of every kind consuming. What Rachael needed most was peace, tranquillity, and a reliable husband. For a time, I was reckless with time, money and, ultimately, with my wife's bond of trust. I was dancing with ghosts.

When they came home, the expectations and hopes of the previous months had dissolved into an anxious vigil. Due to the slow re-introduction of milk, Anastasia had established a pattern of small and frequent feeds, which resulted in her needing to nurse almost constantly. She was also distressed and unsettled and cried from evening through to daybreak. By five weeks, Rachael was worn out. Her body seemed to revolt. She suffered mastitis, a terrible eczema, and a rare form of tendonitis that meant she couldn't lift Anastasia while her wrist was in a splint. The most devastating consequence came when Rachael's nipples began to crack, and once again she had to interrupt her nursing and pump instead. Misdiagnosed as a skin condition of Rachael's, Anastasia had in fact developed thrush in her mouth, a common complaint, but the disruption proved conclusive: Rachael lost her milk. Depleted of emotional resources, devoid of sleep and unable to communicate, we found ourselves on a relentless treadmill, both feeling as trapped and failed as if we were serving life sentences. Rachael deserved more from me, and consequently, I shall always feel partly responsible for the devastating postpartum depression she suffered later.

Our marriage almost collapsed. For me, the close proximity of birth to death neutralised my instinct for protection. For Rachael, the unexpected price of regaining a daughter was, she felt, the loss of her partner.

Since that time, the steps have been slow and occasionally painful. One by one, we've managed to put things back together. We sometimes talk of having another baby. Our choices can only serve us better the next time. The other day we asked Anastasia, who turns four in December, whether she wanted a brother or a sister. She said she'd like a dog.

fields.headline: Weathering the winter
fields.standfirst: Cold, grey and miserable... and we're not talking about the weather. Here's a five-step programme to help you beat the gloom
fields.trailText: Cold, grey and miserable... and we're not talking about the weather. Here's a five-step programme to help you beat the gloom.
fields.body:
It often takes a cold or minor illness to make us take a closer look at our grey faces in the mirror and realise that our bodies are run down. You need to nourish your body if you are to make it through the winter without feeling exhausted and succumbing to cold after cold. With this in mind, I've designed a five-step Bodyfoods protection plan that is suitable for everyone, including young children, who are as prone to feeling washed out as their parents, especially at this stage of the winter term, when schools are hotbeds of infection.

Step 1 Avoid food and drinks that seem to boost your energy levels, but actually make you feel more exhausted in the long run. Particularly avoid caffeine, which is contained in tea, coffee, colas and stimulating drinks like Red Bull. Prepare to endure 48 hours of feeling headachy, shattered and crabby, but you'll start to feel much more alive if you tough it out. (Take an analgesic such as paracetamol, and be sure to drink plenty of water and to rest during this withdrawal period.) Also eliminate rapidly absorbed, sweet foods such as cake, chocolate, biscuits and sugary drinks from your diet, as these will destabilise your energy levels, sending them sky high one minute and crashing the next. Overly sweet foods can also irritate the gut and make you feel bloated.

Step 2 Eat more vitamin C and zinc-rich foods to strengthen your immune system. Vitamin C encourages the brain to produce endorphins, the 'happy hormones' that can lift your mood and help your body to absorb essential minerals like iron. When you're feeling washed out, include plenty of iron in your diet, and if you don't like red meat, the most easily absorbed iron source, green, leafy vegetables, pulses and eggs offer a palatable alternative. Foods that contain vitamin C and zinc include all fresh fruits and vegetables, wholegrains, lean meat, crumbly cheeses and seafood. It is vital at this time of year to eat at least five portions of fresh fruit or vegetables a day, a target that can be achieved with minimal effort if you drink a glass of juice made with three fresh fruits or eat a few satsumas in the morning and have vegetables or salads with the rest of your meals. When you're run down, it's also important to have a good-sized portion of a zinc-rich protein a day, such as chicken, fish, a few eggs or cheese. If you follow these guidelines, you should satisfy your body's requirements for protein, vitamin C and zinc.

Step 3 My mum, who's a music teacher, often finds the start of the school year draining, and by the Christmas holiday she's virtually on her knees. She wouldn't mind feeling exhausted so much if only she didn't tend to break out in cold sores. Cold sores are a symptom of the herpes simplex virus, which causes blisters to develop on or around the mouth and can also manifest itself as genital herpes. The blisters are painful and disfiguring while they're at their 'angry' stage, and once the herpes virus has entered your body, it can follow a pattern of dormancy and eruption that lasts for years. If you are a herpes sufferer, being run down means that you're more likely to develop cold sores, but help is at hand. Increase your intake of the essential amino acid lysine, which suppresses levels of arginine in the body, an amino acid that promotes herpes-related viral growth. Boost your intake of lysine-packed foods, such as vegetables, fish and chicken, while reducing the amount of nuts, chocolate, carob and seeds that you eat, all of which are rich in arginine. Taking a 1,000mg capsule of lysine three or four times a day on an empty stomach can also suppress or banish a flare-up, while taking a 500mg capsule of echinacea three times a day will help to strengthen your immune system. Dabbing cold sores with tea tree oil a few times a day may further encourage them to disappear.

Step 4 Even if you don't suffer from cold sores, you may find echinacea a helpful prophylactic remedy. Medicinal herbalists recommend that you take the above-mentioned dose for six to eight weeks, then give your body a break for a few weeks, by which time you should feel stronger. If you end up reverting to your bad old habits and cutting nutritional corners, however, it won't be long before you feel lousy again, as your body needs weeks, even months, of nurturing before it can withstand the negative effects caused by the odd 'off' day. It's rather like failing to complete a course of antibiotics: if you stop taking them when you're feeling better, but haven't finished the course, their benefits will be diluted.

Step 5 A good night's sleep is an important step towards feeling re-energised. Stress can disrupt sleeping patterns, as can eating fatty or overly sweet foods before going to bed. Slow-release, nourishing starches have a soporific effect, so opt for pasta or a good-sized portion of potatoes, rice, polenta or bread for your evening meal. Since caffeine hinders sleep, turn to a herbal infusion before bed. Although infusions made with individual herbs like camomile or lemon balm are effective, the Neals Yard sleeping blend (which also contains passionflower and hops) has recently been lulling me into a revitalising, body-strengthening slumber.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: Playing god
fields.standfirst: After Britpop and Britart, we now have Britsoft - Britain's ground-breaking computer games industry. And whether you're bringing your hero back to life in Black & White or running an election campaign in Republic, the worlds these designers are creating are as serious as the fortunes they're earning. Michael Collins meets the programmers playing to win
fields.trailText: After Britpop and Britart, we now have Britsoft - Britain's ground-breaking computer games industry. And whether you're bringing your hero back to life in Black & White or running an election campaign in Republic, the worlds these designers are creating are as serious as the fortunes they're earning. Michael Collins meets the programmers playing to win.
fields.body:
Whatever control you fail to exercise in the real world, it is yours, all yours, in the virtual world of the new computer game. In Black & White you can literally be the skeletal hand of God, moving over the screen, pointing the finger of fate at any of your world's inhabitants. One click, one wave of the hand, and you can perform miracles. You might find a woman, broken, searching for her lost son. The son is hurt and dying in a forest. You can revive him, return him, and light up the lives of two lost souls. Or you can kill him, maybe set light to his mother's home, and destroy the village. Their fate is in your pixelated hand. In this world, you take control. You've got the power.

Created in Britain, Black & White is the electronic game that will take the genre into a new dimension, way beyond the likes of PlayStation 2, which launches later this month. The point of Black & White is that it is more than a game. Players begin to care about this world. It immerses them like a book or a film, because it is not about competing or winning, it's about witnessing a story that you are creating.

The British are lauded abroad as the most innovative games designers in the world. It's not a case of 'the British are coming' on this one - they've already arrived. The Japanese may have altered the image of the industry when Sony created PlayStation, the French and the Americans may have cornered the market as games publishers, but the British have the big ideas. The ideas that travel well and translate better. There are more design studios in the UK than anywhere else.

Now the industry has been recognised with a label: Britsoft. Like Britpop, Britart or Britlit, Britsoft too has its stars: companies with names like Codemasters, Rare, Rebellion, Free Radical Design, Elixir, Lionhead. With the publication later this month of The Britsoft Book (£50, ELSPA), the industry will be recognised as one of Britain's greatest exports.

Peter Molyneux of Lionhead is described as the godfather of the Britsoft movement, and widely credited as the originator of the God-game genre. But never before has the player actually been cast in the role of God. Perhaps the closest was the brilliant The Sims from the mind of the American Will Wright. Its success? Its appeal to people who had never picked up a computer game - the mainstream audience that has become the Holy Grail for the creators of electronic games. The game led women and gay men, among others, into a realm of entertainment traditionally ghettoised as a boy's-own world of computerised dungeons, dragons, dwarves and goblins.

The Sims jumpstarted the imagination of a thirtysomething breed entertained elsewhere by lifestyle spreads, home improvement, makeover shows, surveillance TV and soaps. Fundamentally, The Sims allowed you to create and control a family within a neighbourhood, send them to work, choose their wallpaper and keep them alive with regular visits to the fridge. The fact that Big Brother is to be transformed into a computer game smells like yesterday's news, coming six months after The Sims landed.

But The Sims is a chunk of a bigger story. The God game has come to consume the thoughts of major players in the games industry, in a bid to capture the mainstream audience. More than anyone else, Molyneux has set his sights on bringing non-game players to consoles and computers. At one point during the making of Black & White, Molyneux and his team (including a director and a cameraman) spent hours deciding how long it would take for a bead of sweat to roll down the cheek of a character. If computer games now call upon the skills of those in film, the detail applied to the imagery is as intricate as that which applies to painting, and the research for the content of a game almost as extensive as that for a weighty novel.

When you look at the games world, it isn't difficult to understand why Japan, the US, Europe and currently the British government are taking a long, hard, excited look at Britsoft. As an industry, its sales this year surpassed that of video in the UK. It's almost level-pegging with the music industry in terms of revenue. Last year British exports in television totalled £444m. The leisure software industry came in at £503m. It is a far more significant export than the British film industry. For instance, it is rumoured that the film GoldenEye cost in the region of £100m to make and took a reputed £240m. Meanwhile, the computer game cost £4m and notched up sales of £250m. Tomb Raider is currently being made into a film, with Angelina Jolie as Lara Croft, but the trend now is for the reversal of this process. Films are increasingly turning to electronic games designers to make the game before the film has barely been cast. The computer game for The Italian Job, for instance, has been completed before anyone has signed on the line for the planned film sequel.

It's no wonder that another example of the increasing legitimacy of the British games business, and one that sees it blossoming from being 'the Cinderella of the entertainment industry', is its very own annual BAFTA ceremony. Molyneux was a member on the council that launched the awards. 'I remember thinking that these are the people who would have the answer to the question that I had wanted to answer. These people would know how to entertain people. I was just shocked that they didn't. And they viewed computer games with such a degree of suspicion. They didn't understand. I still don't think the full force of what computer entertainment is has been felt yet. But I think the tremors have.'

It's true. The European software leisure market is currently estimated to be worth $6.27bn. Last year, the value of the UK market clocked out at close to £1bn. Possibly the best example of the seismic impact of Britsoft in the global games market was illustrated by the Japanese company that built what it considered to be an English village in which to place its workforce so as to inspire the kind of games ideas that emerge from British minds.

Actually, if Britsoft has a nerve centre, it has little in common with either a traditional, idyllic English village or the futuristic cityscapes of Blade Runner (a key influence in games designers' common culture, and as endemic as the artifacts that appear on the desks at their workstations: statuettes of Darth Vader, Austin Powers, jelly monsters, models of Bond-like cars, and slogans - 'I wish that I was where I am', 'Hit me baby one more time'). Leamington Spa seems to be the place where most of Britsoft's main companies have congregated. 'We started out working from two stables,' says David Darling. He founded Codemasters with his brother Richard. It now consumes most of a former farm somewhere near the M40, with outfits in France, Germany and the US.

Not far away are the Oliver twins, who run Blitz games (about to launch Chicken Run), and the Stamper brothers at Rare. This last duo is perhaps the Barclay Brothers of the industry: rich workaholics who shun publicity. They emerged at a recent industry awards ceremony to collect their prize, saying nothing, with their faces concealed beneath Lone Ranger scarves. Nearby Oxford houses Rebellion, with the Kingsley brothers at the helm. In another neck of the woods, the Collier twins and the Pickfords. Brothers. All brothers.

This is the common theme within Britsoft. It's odd, and perfect somehow, because even though games designers have long since ceased to be a breed apart, something to be avoided like Scientologists or drunks, you still, on meeting them, expect something strange to emerge. A tweedle-dee-tweedle-dumbness of the twins perhaps. A Disney tie.

Brothers? It seems that as surely as solitary male adolescents disappeared to their bedrooms to masturbate or sniff glue, a boy and his brother hitting puberty in the mid-80s disappeared to their room in the hope of becoming computer programmers. Or rather, one would design and the other would programme. One would be attractive, the other would programme.

And when you get beyond the fact that brothers seem to do this stuff extremely well, you wonder: why the British? 'The British have always been inventors, exploring new horizons, and computer games are part of those new horizons,' says Jason Kingsley, seated in a converted warehouse in a cobbled street in Oxford. Below, on the studio floor, there's the team that makes up Rebellion. All of whom are passionate gamesplayers, he says. Again, a stereotype is kicked into touch. Many of them look as though they could be moonlighting from club spreads in i-D and sleazenation. No sign of any arbiters of gothic chic or the Marilyn Manson disciples that emerge in the press when games are cited as the impetus for schoolyard massacres such as those in Kentucky and Colorado.

According to Chris Kingsley, there is another reason that Britain is leading the way in games design: 'We've always had our mad inventors, like Clive Sinclair. For me, one of the great things about doing this is that it allows you to invent without all the bits. You can invent a programme for flight simulation without going out to build a plane.'

All paths lead to Clive Sinclair, according to the leading lights of Britsoft. This was the ginger-haired genius who created the home computer on these shores with his little black box. Those that touched the Sinclair Spectrum can recall the experience the way lesser mortals recall losing their virginity. Molyneux remembers his first time. 'It was like a choir of angels. Programming for me was a godsend. I was very dyslexic. I couldn't draw or write, but I found I could be creative without those disciplines. I found my voice.'

It was an apparatus that enabled boffins to programme as well as play, thereby becoming a computer experience exclusive to Britain. It was a culture that didn't exist elsewhere. What transpired was the equivalent of music-mad teenagers going to their rooms with three chords and a guitar and swelling into an underground movement. At the time, those of us outside of it - our brains stretched to capacity by the Rubik's cube - expected these boys to metamorphose into the kind of men who wear novelty socks and wax lyrical about loft insulation. Had someone proffered the argument that the geeks would one day inherit the earth, the reaction would have been that which greeted Clive Sinclair when he jumped in the C5 and drove into obscurity.

But essentially, it was the computer-games industry that started the ball rolling and got millions of people bringing personal computers into their homes. Not all of those who formed the nascent network that grew into Britsoft stayed the course. Some ducked out, one jumped from a tall building, another became a sheep farmer. But those that survived and prospered made it to the next level. They now command armies of artists, programmers, designers, and conquer worlds. And many of them are not yet 30.

If the games industry were human, it would now be an adolescent male, which is why sex, girls and maturity are the things on its mind. The success of Lara Croft has sparked an abundance of Bond-like heroines with figures that are beginning to resemble a more realistic female form: Agent Archer (based on the looks of former L'Oréal model Mitzi Martin), Joanna Dark and the forthcoming Carmen Blake in Titanium Angels. The last is a product from the publishing company SCI, created by the most successful woman in the British games industry who isn't virtual, Pat Cavanagh. She believes that Tomb Raider can actually be credited with introducing more female players into the mix. 'Also, if you look at the statistics, you see that Nintendo players are 45 per cent female.' She herself seems more Moneypenny than Bond, seated in her riverside company in Battersea. 'Doom and Quake and the shoot-'em-up games for the PC were for the boys, but Mario and Sonic were products that began to appeal to women,' she says.

The few women working elsewhere in the industry tend to arrive via the artistic route rather than as programmers. The lead artist at Codemasters, Rachel Wood, says the appeal of working in games for her is the scope of what can now be produced on screen thanks to current technology. She believes more women in the workforce will begin to have an impact on the content. Certainly the timing is perfect. Black & White is one of a number of games in development that deal with more cerebral themes, and even a level of morality on the part of the player.

At Codemasters a game called The Realm attracts 49 per cent female players, according to David Darling. It's an online game, which is another direction in which the industry is headed. This marks its entry into another world of possibility, and the introduction of an offshoot industry that is expected to become massive.

'The online games are crossing the gender gap,' says Darling. 'You can have thousands of people playing at once. With The Realm, we've got 10,000 subscribers. Every evening 1,000 of them are in this world. They choose a character and a sex. The emphasis is less on combat and more on a kind of social activity.'

Along with these more cerebral themes, and the prospect of games becoming a bigger multi-player experience, the contemporary world as a setting is central to pushing them further into the mainstream. All of which moves the content further from its original territory of sci-fi, Tolkienesque fantasy, shoot ups and shoot outs. There's also an endeavour to give the player more of an all-round experience, dealing with a gamut of emotions, rather than those that accompany death and destruction. Perhaps this is why the forthcoming PlayStation 2 has incorporated something called 'an emotion engine'.

If the first incarnation of PlayStation took the video game from the kids' bedroom to the living room, its second coming will see it competing with the television for the eyeballs of the whole family, until Microsoft's next born, the X-box, joins the race.

The demographic for PlayStation proved to be that of 29-year-old males. It was the first console that was targeted at fathers and sons, neither of whom were strangers to interactive entertainment, having sampled Nintendo, Atari and Gameboy. Sony's plans for PlayStation 2 predominantly expand the demographic. The ads for the forthcoming machine will feature exclusively in lifestyle magazines, and include images of the middle-aged and the elderly. Also, in its bid to appeal to non-gamesplayers, it is being marketed as an entertainment unit on which to experience DVD, and the internet, instead of solely a games console.

But it will also be the platform for the next wave of new Britsoft games, such as Republic, a game expected to appear later next year, and as eagerly anticipated as Black & White. It is being developed at Elixir studios in Camden. Its setting is the fictional country of Novistrana, in which you get to assist one of the region's million inhabitants in their pursuit of the presidency. Once again, it is simultaneously a God game and a morality game. The path you choose, whether it be as a Gandhi figure or a Hitler figure, will reflect the kind of leader you become.

'A real-world setting is important because the man in the street doesn't care about goblins,' says Joe McDonagh of Elixir. 'It's the same with violence in games. It has an important role. But it has to be in a real-world context for adults to understand it.' Even though he sees film as a poor second to games, it is this modern backdrop that is likely to turn filmgoers into gamesplayers.

This pursuit of realism has also made the advertising industry wake up to Britsoft. Product placement is prohibited in television but remains legal in games. Consequently, Diesel have brought their brand to King Pin and the imminent Driver 2.

'Computer games have come a long way from being little stick men onscreen,' says McDonagh. 'Then, they couldn't do anything except the most basic thing you could teach them - to hit one another, beat each other up. Now we can teach them anything. It's almost like having a baby on the computer.'

'I think this is the era that the industry will come of age, because technology is doing some major things that you don't have to be a geeky techhead to appreciate,' says Demis Hassabis, founder of Elixir, and at 24, the industry's wunderkind. He looks 12. Tiny. Cute. More of a key ring than a computer games designer. 'I spend almost every waking hour thinking about games,' he says. He started playing them at four. At seven, he taught himself how to programme. He has his own theory as to why Britsoft is a world leader. 'The Americans are less original than British games designers, and the Japanese simply have the investment, the resources, and the manpower. Because we have little investment and smaller teams, we are forced to create the technology that can deliver our ideas.'

At 16, Hassabis co-created Theme Park with Peter Molyneux, as part of the company Lionhead. He says that it gave 'every player the chance to run their own Disneyland'. It became one of the biggest-selling games of all time, grossing around $60m. Consequently, he was offered a small fortune to develop another project but opted for a course in computer science at Cambridge.

The workforce at companies like Elixir and Rebellion are an example of the rapidly increasing Oxbridge intake to an industry where it is becoming impossible to gain entry without a degree in something smart, as well as a passion for games. McDonagh is applying the knowledge absorbed during his history degree to the research for the content of Republic. 'The games industry in the UK can now compete with the City, which, historically, has taken all the best programmers and paid them 80 grand. The games industry was never able to do that. Now it can.'

In Guildford, at the Surrey outpost of his empire Lionhead, where there is little for young Lionhead cubs to do lunchtimes but smoke and skateboard, Peter Molyneux is putting the finishing touches to Black & White. The process began on Valentine's Day 1998. This, he says, is an indication of what games design does for the social and romantic lives of those who sign in to this world for a career. He has had four days off since the beginning of the century, and that includes working weekends. He is talking about how emotional he can become when explaining all that his team has achieved in creating Black & White, and this pursuit of the contemporary and the real in a world of make-believe. 'There are as many programmers working on the eye of a character on a sports game as there are at Nasa,' he says.

In Republic it will be possible to zoom in on the petals on the flowers in window boxes of buildings, cracks in the pavement, the scrolls around the spearheads of railings. In race games, it's now possible to compete in the virtual streets of London. When Molyneux talks of his process for creating God's creatures in Black & White, it brings to mind the story that when da Vinci created the Mona Lisa, he began with the skull, the muscles, and then painted the face and skin. 'The other day we were working out how much a character's face should crease, how many eyelashes a character should have,' says Molyneux. 'Suddenly I realised we were making a real person.'

Britsoft websites

www.codemasters.com (All you need to know about the company's hugely successful online game The Realm).

www.muckyfoot.com (The place to download images, demos and wallpaper from the designers of Urban Chaos and the forthcoming StarTopia).

www.gamespot.co.uk (The number-one site for the latest about theBritish computer-games industry).
