Molyneux was a member on the council that launched the awards. 'I remember thinking that these are the people who would have the answer to the question that I had wanted to answer. These people would know how to entertain people. I was just shocked that they didn't. And they viewed computer games with such a degree of suspicion. They didn't understand. I still don't think the full force of what computer entertainment is has been felt yet. But I think the tremors have.' It's true. The European software leisure market is currently estimated to be worth $6.27bn. Last year, the value of the UK market clocked out at close to £1bn. Possibly the best example of the seismic impact of Britsoft in the global games market was illustrated by the Japanese company that built what it considered to be an English village in which to place its workforce so as to inspire the kind of games ideas that emerge from British minds. Actually, if Britsoft has a nerve centre, it has little in common with either a traditional, idyllic English village or the futuristic cityscapes of Blade Runner (a key influence in games designers' common culture, and as endemic as the artifacts that appear on the desks at their workstations: statuettes of Darth Vader, Austin Powers, jelly monsters, models of Bond-like cars, and slogans - 'I wish that I was where I am', 'Hit me baby one more time'). Leamington Spa seems to be the place where most of Britsoft's main companies have congregated. 'We started out working from two stables,' says David Darling. He founded Codemasters with his brother Richard. It now consumes most of a former farm somewhere near the M40, with outfits in France, Germany and the US. Not far away are the Oliver twins, who run Blitz games (about to launch Chicken Run), and the Stamper brothers at Rare. This last duo is perhaps the Barclay Brothers of the industry: rich workaholics who shun publicity. They emerged at a recent industry awards ceremony to collect their prize, saying nothing, with their faces concealed beneath Lone Ranger scarves. Nearby Oxford houses Rebellion, with the Kingsley brothers at the helm. In another neck of the woods, the Collier twins and the Pickfords. Brothers. All brothers. This is the common theme within Britsoft. It's odd, and perfect somehow, because even though games designers have long since ceased to be a breed apart, something to be avoided like Scientologists or drunks, you still, on meeting them, expect something strange to emerge. A tweedle-dee-tweedle-dumbness of the twins perhaps. A Disney tie. Brothers? It seems that as surely as solitary male adolescents disappeared to their bedrooms to masturbate or sniff glue, a boy and his brother hitting puberty in the mid-80s disappeared to their room in the hope of becoming computer programmers. Or rather, one would design and the other would programme. One would be attractive, the other would programme. And when you get beyond the fact that brothers seem to do this stuff extremely well, you wonder: why the British? 'The British have always been inventors, exploring new horizons, and computer games are part of those new horizons,' says Jason Kingsley, seated in a converted warehouse in a cobbled street in Oxford. Below, on the studio floor, there's the team that makes up Rebellion. All of whom are passionate gamesplayers, he says. Again, a stereotype is kicked into touch. Many of them look as though they could be moonlighting from club spreads in i-D and sleazenation. No sign of any arbiters of gothic chic or the Marilyn Manson disciples that emerge in the press when games are cited as the impetus for schoolyard massacres such as those in Kentucky and Colorado. According to Chris Kingsley, there is another reason that Britain is leading the way in games design: 'We've always had our mad inventors, like Clive Sinclair. For me, one of the great things about doing this is that it allows you to invent without all the bits. You can invent a programme for flight simulation without going out to build a plane.' All paths lead to Clive Sinclair, according to the leading lights of Britsoft. This was the ginger-haired genius who created the home computer on these shores with his little black box. Those that touched the Sinclair Spectrum can recall the experience the way lesser mortals recall losing their virginity. Molyneux remembers his first time. 'It was like a choir of angels. Programming for me was a godsend. I was very dyslexic. I couldn't draw or write, but I found I could be creative without those disciplines. I found my voice.' It was an apparatus that enabled boffins to programme as well as play, thereby becoming a computer experience exclusive to Britain. It was a culture that didn't exist elsewhere. What transpired was the equivalent of music-mad teenagers going to their rooms with three chords and a guitar and swelling into an underground movement. At the time, those of us outside of it - our brains stretched to capacity by the Rubik's cube - expected these boys to metamorphose into the kind of men who wear novelty socks and wax lyrical about loft insulation. Had someone proffered the argument that the geeks would one day inherit the earth, the reaction would have been that which greeted Clive Sinclair when he jumped in the C5 and drove into obscurity. But essentially, it was the computer-games industry that started the ball rolling and got millions of people bringing personal computers into their homes. Not all of those who formed the nascent network that grew into Britsoft stayed the course. Some ducked out, one jumped from a tall building, another became a sheep farmer. But those that survived and prospered made it to the next level. They now command armies of artists, programmers, designers, and conquer worlds. And many of them are not yet 30. If the games industry were human, it would now be an adolescent male, which is why sex, girls and maturity are the things on its mind. The success of Lara Croft has sparked an abundance of Bond-like heroines with figures that are beginning to resemble a more realistic female form: Agent Archer (based on the looks of former L'Oréal model Mitzi Martin), Joanna Dark and the forthcoming Carmen Blake in Titanium Angels. The last is a product from the publishing company SCI, created by the most successful woman in the British games industry who isn't virtual, Pat Cavanagh. She believes that Tomb Raider can actually be credited with introducing more female players into the mix. 'Also, if you look at the statistics, you see that Nintendo players are 45 per cent female.' She herself seems more Moneypenny than Bond, seated in her riverside company in Battersea. 'Doom and Quake and the shoot-'em-up games for the PC were for the boys, but Mario and Sonic were products that began to appeal to women,' she says. The few women working elsewhere in the industry tend to arrive via the artistic route rather than as programmers. The lead artist at Codemasters, Rachel Wood, says the appeal of working in games for her is the scope of what can now be produced on screen thanks to current technology. She believes more women in the workforce will begin to have an impact on the content. Certainly the timing is perfect. Black & White is one of a number of games in development that deal with more cerebral themes, and even a level of morality on the part of the player. At Codemasters a game called The Realm attracts 49 per cent female players, according to David Darling. It's an online game, which is another direction in which the industry is headed. This marks its entry into another world of possibility, and the introduction of an offshoot industry that is expected to become massive. 'The online games are crossing the gender gap,' says Darling. 'You can have thousands of people playing at once. With The Realm, we've got 10,000 subscribers. Every evening 1,000 of them are in this world. They choose a character and a sex. The emphasis is less on combat and more on a kind of social activity.' Along with these more cerebral themes, and the prospect of games becoming a bigger multi-player experience, the contemporary world as a setting is central to pushing them further into the mainstream. All of which moves the content further from its original territory of sci-fi, Tolkienesque fantasy, shoot ups and shoot outs. There's also an endeavour to give the player more of an all-round experience, dealing with a gamut of emotions, rather than those that accompany death and destruction. Perhaps this is why the forthcoming PlayStation 2 has incorporated something called 'an emotion engine'. If the first incarnation of PlayStation took the video game from the kids' bedroom to the living room, its second coming will see it competing with the television for the eyeballs of the whole family, until Microsoft's next born, the X-box, joins the race. The demographic for PlayStation proved to be that of 29-year-old males. It was the first console that was targeted at fathers and sons, neither of whom were strangers to interactive entertainment, having sampled Nintendo, Atari and Gameboy. Sony's plans for PlayStation 2 predominantly expand the demographic. The ads for the forthcoming machine will feature exclusively in lifestyle magazines, and include images of the middle-aged and the elderly. Also, in its bid to appeal to non-gamesplayers, it is being marketed as an entertainment unit on which to experience DVD, and the internet, instead of solely a games console. But it will also be the platform for the next wave of new Britsoft games, such as Republic, a game expected to appear later next year, and as eagerly anticipated as Black & White. It is being developed at Elixir studios in Camden. Its setting is the fictional country of Novistrana, in which you get to assist one of the region's million inhabitants in their pursuit of the presidency. Once again, it is simultaneously a God game and a morality game. The path you choose, whether it be as a Gandhi figure or a Hitler figure, will reflect the kind of leader you become. 'A real-world setting is important because the man in the street doesn't care about goblins,' says Joe McDonagh of Elixir. 'It's the same with violence in games. It has an important role. But it has to be in a real-world context for adults to understand it.' Even though he sees film as a poor second to games, it is this modern backdrop that is likely to turn filmgoers into gamesplayers. This pursuit of realism has also made the advertising industry wake up to Britsoft. Product placement is prohibited in television but remains legal in games. Consequently, Diesel have brought their brand to King Pin and the imminent Driver 2. 'Computer games have come a long way from being little stick men onscreen,' says McDonagh. 'Then, they couldn't do anything except the most basic thing you could teach them - to hit one another, beat each other up. Now we can teach them anything. It's almost like having a baby on the computer.' 'I think this is the era that the industry will come of age, because technology is doing some major things that you don't have to be a geeky techhead to appreciate,' says Demis Hassabis, founder of Elixir, and at 24, the industry's wunderkind. He looks 12. Tiny. Cute. More of a key ring than a computer games designer. 'I spend almost every waking hour thinking about games,' he says. He started playing them at four. At seven, he taught himself how to programme. He has his own theory as to why Britsoft is a world leader. 'The Americans are less original than British games designers, and the Japanese simply have the investment, the resources, and the manpower. Because we have little investment and smaller teams, we are forced to create the technology that can deliver our ideas.' At 16, Hassabis co-created Theme Park with Peter Molyneux, as part of the company Lionhead. He says that it gave 'every player the chance to run their own Disneyland'. It became one of the biggest-selling games of all time, grossing around $60m. Consequently, he was offered a small fortune to develop another project but opted for a course in computer science at Cambridge. The workforce at companies like Elixir and Rebellion are an example of the rapidly increasing Oxbridge intake to an industry where it is becoming impossible to gain entry without a degree in something smart, as well as a passion for games. McDonagh is applying the knowledge absorbed during his history degree to the research for the content of Republic. 'The games industry in the UK can now compete with the City, which, historically, has taken all the best programmers and paid them 80 grand. The games industry was never able to do that. Now it can.' In Guildford, at the Surrey outpost of his empire Lionhead, where there is little for young Lionhead cubs to do lunchtimes but smoke and skateboard, Peter Molyneux is putting the finishing touches to Black & White. The process began on Valentine's Day 1998. This, he says, is an indication of what games design does for the social and romantic lives of those who sign in to this world for a career. He has had four days off since the beginning of the century, and that includes working weekends. He is talking about how emotional he can become when explaining all that his team has achieved in creating Black & White, and this pursuit of the contemporary and the real in a world of make-believe. 'There are as many programmers working on the eye of a character on a sports game as there are at Nasa,' he says. In Republic it will be possible to zoom in on the petals on the flowers in window boxes of buildings, cracks in the pavement, the scrolls around the spearheads of railings. In race games, it's now possible to compete in the virtual streets of London. When Molyneux talks of his process for creating God's creatures in Black & White, it brings to mind the story that when da Vinci created the Mona Lisa, he began with the skull, the muscles, and then painted the face and skin. 'The other day we were working out how much a character's face should crease, how many eyelashes a character should have,' says Molyneux. 'Suddenly I realised we were making a real person.' Britsoft websites www.codemasters.com (All you need to know about the company's hugely successful online game The Realm). www.muckyfoot.com (The place to download images, demos and wallpaper from the designers of Urban Chaos and the forthcoming StarTopia). www.gamespot.co.uk (The number-one site for the latest about theBritish computer-games industry).

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to master your impatience, tight calfs and taking the sting out of red eyes
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to master your impatience, tight calfs and taking the sting out of red eyes.
fields.body:
We are coming up to that time of year when we find ourselves delayed at airports, stations and on the roads as the annual wind-up to Christmas comes rolling round again. This stretch of time, anchored in tradition, challenges your patience, tolerance and secretly - come on admit it - confidence in your own sanity. Even the Buddha may have experienced the odd niggle had he been caught in the tussle to get a flight to Thailand. All this is accentuated by that distant memory, triggered now and then by the odd strain of an old American movie wafting from the TV, that this is meant to be the season of 'goodwill to all men'.

Why then did they have to make it in the cold, dark winter when all our true natural self really wants to do is hibernate?

All this - the build-up, the presents, the arrangements, and expectations, the frantic escape plans to fling ourselves far across the face of the earth, the increasing alcohol and calorie levels, the parties, the spending - is possibly just a magnificently constructed foil to distract ourselves from the great void of winter's darkness.

If you find yourself already growing impatient for me to focus my drift, this only serves to illustrate my point. Impatience is perhaps the greatest scourge of our times. Without impatience, there would be none of that involuntary upper abdominal crunching as you huff and puff 10 back in the checkout line as the person paying suddenly can't find their chequebook, then their cheque card, then finally decides to pay by credit card, but the magnetic strip's worn down, and someone's mobile kicks in to the strains of 'William Tell' in pinky and perky tones.

That's your liver and spleen contracting. When your liver and spleen contract, it also places a strain on all your other organs, thus restricting blood flow and depleting energy throughout your entire system. And even though you're obviously built to take it, it makes you even more susceptible to impatience.

One could go on indefinitely listing the symptoms arising from the disease of impatience - hypertension, headaches, heart problems and so on, but luckily, according to those Oriental wizards of old, you can develop the treasured and health-enhancing quality of patience for yourself.

First, remind, cajole or even force yourself to see the current cause of impatience, no matter how seemingly great or small, as being a mere blip in the face of eternity.

Second, discipline yourself to consciously release the strain from your musculature, thereby enabling your frame to straighten up and allow your organs their fair share of elbow room, your blood vessels adequate expansion, your nerve pathways clear passages and your bladder and bowels sufficient room to move. This can be best achieved by starting at the back of your neck - often the first place to go rigid (literally stiff-necked) from impatience - and the pleasurable sensation of release once identified. Then allow it to spread to all parts including your belly, chest, face, shoulders and limbs.

To augment this physical release, take Bach Flower remedy 'Impatiens', which really can work wonders. It also helps to instill in yourself an unshakeable trust that whatever occurs - even if it seems to contradict all your carefully conceived plans - is exactly what is meant to happen and will always somehow promote an increase in your general wellbeing and temporal standing.

Yogananda, one of the greatest yogis of the past century, would start his day with the following pronouncement: 'I will go forth in perfect faith in the power of omnipresent good to bring me what I need at the time I need it.'

Or, when confronted by a perceived obstacle to your agenda's speedy passage, survey your surroundings, and however disagreeable, state, 'I am the king (or queen) of no-matter-what.'

On a more ongoing basis, consider taking up a body-centred activity that will provide regular opportunity for your mind to slow down. This could include cycling, running, walking, swimming, weight-training, yoga, t'ai chi or other martial arts, but can be anything that will give the wild animal within you for whom waiting for anything is anathema, a bit of space to let off steam.

Finally, remember not to hold your breath - a common reaction to impatience-triggering situations. Make sure you are breathing slowly and deeply from down in your belly, as this will help your liver and spleen to relax, and before you know it, you'll be sporting that look of unswerving serenity that made saints and Buddhas famous.

Your letters

Dear Barefoot, I would like to know if you can give me some advice on plantar fasciitis - inflammation of the tendon on the bottom of the foot. I've seen a chiropodist, I have bigger insoles in my shoes and do the exercises on my tight calf muscles, but the problem is very painful (and has been for two years). Can you help?
Miles Parsey, north-west London

Dear Miles, According to Oriental medicine, this condition arises from blocked kidney energy causing constriction in the bladder meridian which runs down the back of the legs causing tightness in the muscles which extends into the tendons in the soles of the feet. Acupuncture can help, as can connective tissue massage to alleviate the tightness and unblock the kidney chi, as can gently stretching your hamstrings every day. It's a matter of getting the heat which has been displaced from the kidneys and got stuck further down the meridian, to return to where it came from.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I suffer from red, irritated eyes. I've had them looked at by countless professionals and have concluded that it's an allergy. Is there anything I can do to soothe them other than using chemical eyebaths?
John Tremmens, Bridgeport, Dorset

Dear John, The eyes are the 'flowers' of the liver. Quite often external eye irritation is indicative of some kind of disorder of the liver energy (not necessarily liver function), so it would be worth visiting a shiatsu therapist to check your liver meridian and clear it if necessary. Additionally, make a mixture of camomile and eyebright (euphrasia) in tea form cooled in a spring water solution and bathe the eyes in it every hour or so. Also mint tea bags (used and cooled) laid over the eyes have a calming effect.

Barefoot Doctor is author of 'Handbook for the Urban Warrior' and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

fields.headline: Shock of the old
fields.standfirst: When the novelty of trendy dining wears thin, an old fashioned meal can hit the spot. Jay Rayner relaxes over Sunday lunch
fields.trailText: When the novelty of trendy dining wears thin, an old fashioned meal can hit the spot. Jay Rayner relaxes over Sunday lunch
fields.body:
As a boy, I could claim to know the fields and woods surrounding the village of Elstree in Hertfordshire surprisingly well, for a Londoner with a lung full of city soot. This was because I spent an inordinate amount of time hiding there in a generally successful attempt to escape games lessons at the nearby boys' school where I was a pupil. We passed the hours cooking bacon and eggs over fires of twigs or teaching each other to smoke. And when the cross-country squad came too close for comfort, we pushed a little deeper into the undergrowth.

In all those years, I never stumbled on to the manicured grounds of the Edgwarebury Hotel, which is curious considering just how close to the scene of my many crimes it is. And it is hardly what you would call an inconspicuous place. The Edgwarebury is a serious lump of mock Tudor.

It is also a good place for Sunday lunch, in a sweetly old-fashioned sort of way. There is a marked provincialism about the place, given that it is so close to London. That is not meant to be a sniffy statement. In this modern age, provincialism is not so much a state of place as a state of mind, and it can be a deeply comforting one.

Perhaps the defiantly unmodern feel of the place explains the age of the other diners, as it was full of well-heeled pensioners taking their parents out to lunch. We reckoned that our 14-month-old, Eddie, brought the average down to about 65. That said, no one seemed put out by Ed's initial lack of enthusiasm for being strapped into his high chair or his ability to lob a fresh strawberry 20 feet across the room. Repeatedly. (I blame the parents.)

For all that, our deeply pleasurable lunch was occasionally in spite of the food. There is a three-course lunch menu on Sundays at £18.95. My mother started with bruschetta, featuring a soft goat's cheese which was not, she said happily, too overwhelmingly goaty. The squid in my father's deep-fried squid salad was the right side of chewy, and Pat's smoked-chicken salad with a rich pesto dressing was fine. The duff note was my chilled melon with passion-fruit ice, which was not ripe enough.

Of the main courses, the star was the perfectly caramelised braised lamb shank with rosemary and garlic, which my father and I tried, the meat tumbling off the bone. My mother thought her beef, served medium-rare, was 'fine', though perhaps could have done with being hung for a little longer before being shoved in the oven. Both dishes were let down by the roast potatoes. (It is a source of constant wonder to me that restaurants should be so appallingly bad at something so simple as roasting a potato. A roast potato should be crisp on the outside rather than flaccid, and soft on the inside rather than crumbly. Why can't they do it? Chefs can bone and stuff a grouse, fillet herrings, create soufflés that defy gravity. But roast a potato adequately? Almost never.)

The poorest of all the dishes was Pat's tagliatelli with wild mushrooms, truffles and Parmesan. The pasta was overcooked, the sauce watery and the flavouring distinctly shy. As to the puddings - fruit gateaux, cheesecake, etc - they were fine, but deserve little attention because they were bought-in rather than made on site.

And yet, for all these gripes, the Rayner family had a jolly nice time. In the heat of a restaurant boom, when novelty is meant to be the thing, there can be something deeply reassuring about the unsurprising. The Edgwarebury Hotel is, I think, the restaurant equivalent of slipping into a comfortable pair of old shoes. And sometimes that's exactly what you want.

 The Edgwarebury Hotel, Barnet Lane, Elstree, Hertfordshire (020 8953 8227). Lunch for two, including wine, costs £55
Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

My mother thought her beef, served medium-rare, was 'fine', though perhaps could have done with being hung for a little longer before being shoved in the oven. Both dishes were let down by the roast potatoes. (It is a source of constant wonder to me that restaurants should be so appallingly bad at something so simple as roasting a potato. A roast potato should be crisp on the outside rather than flaccid, and soft on the inside rather than crumbly. Why can't they do it? Chefs can bone and stuff a grouse, fillet herrings, create soufflés that defy gravity. But roast a potato adequately? Almost never.) The poorest of all the dishes was Pat's tagliatelli with wild mushrooms, truffles and Parmesan. The pasta was overcooked, the sauce watery and the flavouring distinctly shy. As to the puddings - fruit gateaux, cheesecake, etc - they were fine, but deserve little attention because they were bought-in rather than made on site. And yet, for all these gripes, the Rayner family had a jolly nice time. In the heat of a restaurant boom, when novelty is meant to be the thing, there can be something deeply reassuring about the unsurprising. The Edgwarebury Hotel is, I think, the restaurant equivalent of slipping into a comfortable pair of old shoes. And sometimes that's exactly what you want.  The Edgwarebury Hotel, Barnet Lane, Elstree, Hertfordshire (020 8953 8227). webTitle: Jim Ainsworth: End of a line

fields.headline: End of a line
fields.standfirst: First-class fish is only a phone call away
fields.trailText: First-class fish is only a phone call away.
fields.body:
Despite gloomy stories about the sad state of our fishing industry, buying top-quality fresh fish and shellfish has never been easier - provided you know where to look, and provided you are prepared to pay a fair price. Inhabitants of Scotland and Cornwall are best placed to take advantage of fresh supplies directly. Try royal warrant holder Ken Watmough (29 Thistle Street, Aberdeen; 01224 640 321) for just about any species in season, or Dennis Knight (1 Fore Street, Port Isaac, Cornwall; 01208 880 498) for fat, oily herrings and Fowey mussels.

Thanks to mail order, however, there is no need to live on the coast. It may seem disconcerting at first buying fish without being able to see at first hand how fresh it is, but a couple of deliveries from a first-rate knowledgeable supplier will soon convince. Quayside Fish (The Harbourside, Porthleven, Cornwall; 01326 562 008) is a prime example. Either specify what you want, or take their advice: expect good sea bass and red mullet at around £12.50 to £13.50 per kg, and on no account miss the crab: large whole cock crabs (the best for white meat) weigh about 1.5kg and cost £7.50 per kg; alternatively, buy the meat at around £25 per kg (under half that for brown); add £8.50 carriage, or £12.50 for Saturday delivery. Autumn is the best time for fish because they are fattening up nicely for winter but have not yet begun to spawn, so it is a good moment to stock up the freezer, especially after a week of fine weather, when prices may drop a little. Quayside buys from day boats, and will freeze and despatch on the day it is landed, to be with you the following morning. Also ask about their smoked fish.

Wing of St Mawes (4 Warren Road, Indian Queens, St Columb, Cornwall; 0800 052 3717) is another clued-up supplier with an overnight delivery service. Their own boat operates out of St Mawes, and they buy at the morning auction in Newlyn, so there is no middleman. Ask for brill, Dover sole and monkfish, try John Dory for a change, or bag some large cod fillets while you still can. They also smoke and sweet-cure their own salmon, sourced from a small, chemical- and antibiotic-free farm on Loch Duart: buy a whole side (£26 unsliced, £30 sliced, including carriage). Robert Clifford-Wing is also a director of the wet fish shop and first-floor Seafood Café at 6 Green Street, Bath.

If the comparatively warm southwest is good for red mullet and John Dory, cold Scottish waters are ideal for a native mollusc, squid, which John MacCallum sells at £4.50 per kg in his shop MacCallums of Troon (944 Argyle Street, Glasgow; 0141 204 4456). If you find squid too messy to deal with, they will clean them for you, but MacCallum is not a man for pre-packaged and plastic-wrapped food. He finds it normal that customers - on the continent or in South East Asia, for example - should buy their seafood whole and live where possible, and prepare it themselves: he keeps live oysters, lobsters and crabs in tanks at Troon. A live lobster at £15 per kg sounds a good buy, and visitors to Troon can eat at MacCallums' Oyster Bar, The Harbour, Troon (01292 319 339).

For lots of other suppliers, restaurants, fish and chip shops, smokeries and much more, see Rick Stein's Seafood Lovers' Guide (£20, BBC), a chatty account of his fishy travels around the UK recently published to accompany the TV series.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Pip, pip, hooray
fields.standfirst: Ancient, mystical and exotic... Sybil Kapoor falls under the pomegranate's magical spell
fields.trailText: Ancient, mystical and exotic... Sybil Kapoor falls under the pomegranate's magical spell.
fields.body:
Forget crystals, aromatherapy and feng shui - what every soul needs is a pomegranate. Aside from being very au courant in the food world, it is among the most mystical of fruit. You merely have to touch its leathery, scarlet-flushed husk to sense its ancient pedigree.

It is said that pomegranates grew in the hanging gardens of Babylon, no doubt cultivated from the wild willowy trees that grow throughout Iran and Iraq. Later, its plump body, crowned by the prettiest of calyxes, was reputed to be that of a foolish nymph whom Bacchus seduced with the promise of a crown before turning her into a pomegranate. Even now, it symbolises temptation and fertility, while possessing the power to purge envy and hatred.

If you wish to fully appreciate its romantic aura, head out one autumnal night and find a street stall adorned with glaring light bulbs and piles of glowing pomegranates. Choose the heaviest fruit you can find, a sign of juiciness, and take it home. Pomegranates look too beautiful to eat immediately, but do not be lulled into keeping them indefinitely. They may have travelled the world with early Italian sailors, but they will dry out in a modern heated home.

It is at the point of breaking open the fruit that reality kicks in. What does one do with a pomegranate? Much depends on the type of fruit you have bought and your personal taste. According to exotic-fruit importer Kevin Jameson, managing director of Utopia UK, the majority of pomegranates sold in Britain up until Christmas are from Elche in southern Spain. 'We buy a rosy, sweet-seeded variety called Mollar, which has relatively soft pips,' he says.

But the best pomegranates are supposed to come from Iran and Azerbaijan. 'They tend to have a more pronounced sweet-sour flavour,' explains Jameson, 'but their pips are much more crunchy than the Spanish varieties.'

You can find them in some Middle Eastern shops: huge, deep-red specimens that cost around £1.60 each. However, do not despair, for Mr Jameson will be supplying Waitrose with Indian pomegranates in January: 'They taste wonderful, but unfortunately they scar easily.' As a result, he is planning a trip to Azerbaijan, just in case he can expand the market.

So, if the seeds of your pomegranate are easy to eat, mix them into a salad of diced cucumber, red onion and lemon or lemon-dressed chicory leaves. Alternatively, scatter over segmented oranges and season with orangeflower water. If you have found a flavoursome Iranian or Indian variety, prize their deep pink seeds away from their bitter yellow membrane and squeeze the juice for a refreshing drink. Best of all, eat them all on their own.

fields.body:
Mary Riddell's goal of trying to discredit the Roman Catholic Church on any point she could dream up overshadowed her perfectly valid concern of the Church not tackling child abuse (Comment, last week). John Baharie
Sunderland

fields.headline: Ingrams' folly
fields.trailText: I feel I need to comment on Mr Ingrams' back page contribution (Diary, last week). I happen to be a male homosexual and have lived with my partner in a properly monogamous relationship since I was 19 years of age and he 21. We are now 57 and 60 and nearing retirement. We have lived in our present home for 21 years but in the last months have noticed a change in attitude towards us by our younger neighbours, many of whom have young children. We know that the smaller children have been told not to approach us under any circumstances. Indeed, they will cross the road when they pass our house.

I feel I need to comment on Mr Ingrams' back page contribution (Diary, last week). I happen to be a male homosexual and have lived with my partner in a properly monogamous relationship since I was 19 years of age and he 21. We are now 57 and 60 and nearing retirement. We have lived in our present home for 21 years but in the last months have noticed a change in attitude towards us by our younger neighbours, many of whom have young children. We know that the smaller children have been told not to approach us under any circumstances. Indeed, they will cross the road when they pass our house.

Frankly we are glad of this because of the paedophilamania generated by the cheap press in the UK, such as the News of the World . It means that the likelihood of accusations are reduced while we rigorously refrain from speaking to children under any circumstances anyway.

To read Mr Ingrams' piece today with a return of his homophobic prejudices was very sad because of the prevailing attitudes I have described, which I think are making even fathers tentative with their own children. All to buck up the circulation of flagging newspapers.
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Driving us crazy
fields.trailText: Professors Begg and Oswald - on transport and balancing the revenue (Business, last week) - missed the point. They both treat road mileage as homogenous, when pollution and congestion could better be addressed in terms of what is being moved and why.
fields.body:
Professors Begg and Oswald - on transport and balancing the revenue (Business, last week) - missed the point. They both treat road mileage as homogenous, when pollution and congestion could better be addressed in terms of what is being moved and why.

Take my own industry - brewing. Closures, consolidation of pub ownership and outsourced, centralised distribution have created the ludicrous situation whereby Brewery A wishing to sell to Pub B, a mile away, will have to deliver into a regional depot, say, some 30 miles away, that then trucks beer to a central hub 100 miles away, which delivers it to Pub B, returning empty casks the same way - 260 miles when two would do.

In so many areas we could cut pollution and congestion by shifting advantage from big, lorry-based, centralised distribution towards small vehicle, local supply. This would increase consumer choice too. Sadly, like the M25 on a bad day, this idea is just a little too 'joined up' for our Government to comprehend.
Peter Haydon
The Society of Independent Brewers
London SE7

fields.headline: Signs of sanity?
fields.body:
Much as Neil Spencer might wish that 'astrology has seeped into science' (Review, last week), the reverse is in fact the case. While Newton, Galileo and Kepler might have been interested in astrology, no serious scientist now is. This is simply because there is no evidence to suggest that anything in astrology is either useful or true. None of my colleagues plan their experiments with reference to horoscopes and this does not seem to affect the out come to any degree. And if science and astronomy wish to 'win popular respect', then the best way is to tell the truth.
Dr Dylan Sweetman
Dundee

fields.headline: The real thing
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson says she would rather have a conversation with a cokehead than a drunk (Comment, last week) because alcohol makes people boring and loud.
fields.body:
Nigella Lawson says she would rather have a conversation with a cokehead than a drunk (Comment, last week) because alcohol makes people boring and loud.

Cokeheads may be marginally less loud, but many are tedious enough to make a sane person contemplate suicide. You will not get a word in edgeways as they incessantly talk about nothing but themselves.

Give me a drunk any day - at least there's a chance that they might fall asleep.
Marc Edmonds
London SE19

fields.headline: Not so crazy US
fields.body:
Andrew Rawnsley (Comment, last week) is right to emphasise the perverse workings of the US electoral college. He might, however, notice that we also choose our head of government through an electoral college composed of the victors of local winner-takes-all votes. The differences are that our House of Commons is much more likely to hand a victory to a party that loses the popular vote; and that unlike the Americans, we are crazy enough to let our electoral college hang around and double up as a legislature.
Alec Ryrie
University of Birmingham

webTitle: Letters: is the future in our remembrance?

fields.headline: Is the future in our Remembrance?
fields.trailText: I read Robert McCrum's article with interest, and was pleased that someone had at last raised a difficult subject (Comment, last week). Although I believe in the sacred memory of the fallen and attend Remembrance Sunday each year, I agree with the general points Mr McCrum made.
fields.body:
I read Robert McCrum's article with interest, and was pleased that someone had at last raised a difficult subject (Comment, last week). Although I believe in the sacred memory of the fallen and attend Remembrance Sunday each year, I agree with the general points Mr McCrum made.

In this region the local press reported many instances of children leading acts of Remembrance; it has been the theme of West Country Remembrance. My own feeling is that a highly emotional annual event should wither away naturally. I have encountered few young people who can grasp the meaning of the mass deaths of the twentieth century, and would suggest they do not need to be involved in it.

The brutal truth might well be unacceptable to them in any case, which is that the majority of the fallen of all countries were torn from their everyday lives by conscription, then sacrificed on behalf of the state by the politicians and generals. That is why I remember, but it might not be everyone's choice to remember for that reason.

Well done, Robert McCrum. Britain cannot go forward with its present xenophobic outlook. Sadly, Remembrance feeds xenophobia and the unhealthy side of patriotism. When those who need to remember have gone, our great wars of 1914-45 will disappear from national consciousness, just like Waterloo.
Richard Harris
Tiverton, Devon

 It is the nature of Remembrance Day that bothers me. We remember the victims of war through the language of war - not with bitter repudiation, as Wilfred Owen did in his poetry, but reverently, as though the fatuous military hubris on both sides which triggered the First World War was something to be venerated. This nostalgic wallow is slanted to give the impression that its uniformed participants are mourning their fallen comrades-in-arms. But surely it is human beings in a wider sense whose passing we should lament. As a nation, we are in thrall to the very thing which we claim to deplore - hence the use of a murder machine to signal the eleventh hour. I think we should break free.
Antony Roper
Stafford

 Robert McCrum missed the point just as surely as those he disparages. Far from being an excuse for blinkered xenophobia and anti-Germanism, Remembrance Day is a welcome reminder to us to take a look at the world we have made and ask ourselves whether it was for this that the lives of those who died in the last century's great wars were sacrificed.
Michael Baker
Rickmansworth, Herts

If the Remembrance rituals bring to Robert McCrum's mind militaristic, even triumphalist thoughts then he has no feeling for what they signify. If anything, they should be continued to help cement European integration by reminding us and future generations what the alternative can bring.
Tony Millett
London SW4

fields.headline: Ignorant Bragg
fields.body:
For someone who has 'followed the history of Israel for 50 years', Lord Bragg is lamentably ignorant of the plight of the Palestinians (Comment, last week). A Prime Minister whose policies include more settlement construction than his predecessor and whose 'restrained' army has killed around 200 Palestinians, many of whom have been rock-throwing children, can scarcely be called an ally in the Jewish state. Perhaps if Lord Bragg spoke to Palestinians who live in the occupied territories as well as an erstwhile Israeli soldier, his opinion might change.
Greg Stokes
Leeds

webTitle: Transport policy is stalled by dogma

fields.headline: Private obstacles to public mobility
fields.standfirst: Transport policy is stalled by dogma
fields.trailText: By Cardiff Central station we sat down and wept. And by Birmingham New Street. And London St Pancras. Hapless Gerald Corbett, chief executive of Railtrack, paid for our national misery last week with his job. But his successor, a former wine importer, will fare no better unless the Government is brave enough to address the ludicrous status of Railtrack.
fields.body:
By Cardiff Central station we sat down and wept. And by Birmingham New Street. And London St Pancras. Hapless Gerald Corbett, chief executive of Railtrack, paid for our national misery last week with his job. But his successor, a former wine importer, will fare no better unless the Government is brave enough to address the ludicrous status of Railtrack.

The privatised inheritor of Britain's rail network has spent its entire career wrestling with two incompatible demands. It cannot simultaneously serve its profit-hungry shareholders and Britain's need for low-cost, high- quality rail transport.

It is a sign of how unserious the Government remains about transport that it shows no inclination to rethink the structure of the rail industry. It is now obvious, even to many in the industry itself, that the only way to align the interests of the train operators and infrastructure provider is to merge them into one unit, either nationally or regionally. Until then the country will pay with an unacceptably poor - and dangerous - rail service.

Modern society rests on individual mobility. We live in dispersed communities, and need to travel to make our lives work in every dimension. The capacity to be mobile is a pivotal public good. But New Labour has yet to understand this.

The Government has begun to make good a generation's backlog of underinvestment. However, while it accepts the case for public ownership of schools and hospitals, it refuses point blank to extend that principle to transport. As a result its investment threatens to be compromised, enriching private owners of our rail, bus and coach networks before it ever improves the service. This ideological commitment to privatisation now obstructs the imperative for mobility and safety.

While there is a case for enlisting private capital and energy to serve the public interest, this is emphatically not what the Government will achieve with its idiotic insistence on part-privatisation of the National Air Traffic Control Services, its bone-headed public-private partnership for the London Underground or its pitiful failure to introduce a system of taxing utilities which cause chaos digging up roads.

In each of these disastrous cases - as with rail - policy needs amending or reversing, but Numbers 10 and 11 refuse to budge because they believe they are impressing British business and the right-wing press. They are living in a 1980s time warp. The Prime Minister and his Chancellor should leave their bunkers and try, like the rest of us, just to move round our country. We don't want ideology. We want to be mobile.

fields.headline: A different league
fields.standfirst: Parents deserve the whole picture
fields.trailText: Publication of the Government's school league tables is yet another enormously expensive exercise in stating the obvious. In every part of the country, well-resourced independent schools with the luxury of selecting their intake come top, closely followed by selective state grammar schools. The big news this year is that specialist language and technology schools, with extra funding from the Government, are outperforming other schools. This should come as no surprise. Such schools, able to select a proportion of students according to aptitude, are merely another divisive element in the existing hierarchy.
fields.body:
Publication of the Government's school league tables is yet another enormously expensive exercise in stating the obvious. In every part of the country, well-resourced independent schools with the luxury of selecting their intake come top, closely followed by selective state grammar schools. The big news this year is that specialist language and technology schools, with extra funding from the Government, are outperforming other schools. This should come as no surprise. Such schools, able to select a proportion of students according to aptitude, are merely another divisive element in the existing hierarchy.

The Conservatives introduced secondary league tables, along with a tougher schools inspectorate, in a genuine attempt to offer parents enough transparent information to make a better choice of school. In practice, tables have had the opposite effect. Schools shown to be performing well have the pick of the best pupils from surrounding primary schools. Parents of those left over have a choice only of schools branded 'underperforming'. This is profoundly unjust.

The Government is in a difficult position: parents would not accept less information, nor should they. Proper transparency means 'value added' ranking so parents can assess the boost to young people's chances offered by truly good teaching as opposed to the inbuilt advantages a school gains through geography and the class and wealth of its intake. Without these, we are simply intensifying the pecking order reflected in the league tables and, more worrying, recreating the secondary modern system in all but name.

fields.headline: Men's talk
fields.standfirst: The page three debate comes of age
fields.trailText: Once, there was a debate about page three girls, which could be summarised as follows:
fields.body:
Once, there was a debate about page three girls, which could be summarised as follows:

Women: It's degrading to be depicted as sex objects. Women have brains as well as bodies.

Men: What's wrong with looking at a lovely female body? Most women would love to be a page three girl.

Now, as the Sun celebrates 30 years' supremacy in the art form, nudity is a cliché; raunchy and aggressive 'girl power' bursts out of every women's magazine, probably even including the Lady, and passive, pouting page three girls seem as anachronistic as a saucy McGill postcard. Meanwhile, male pin-ups are also commonplace, and women don't pretend to worship George Clooney for his intellectual achievements. So, have we achieved a measure of equality after all, albeit only of both men and women increasingly judging each other on externalities? To the extent that there is still a page-three debate, it could be summarised as follows:

Women: If you've got it, flaunt it. If you haven't, shut up or risk being called a humourless feminist. It's no big deal.

Men: What's wrong with looking at a lovely female body? Most women would love to be a page three girl. And what about George Clooney?

webTitle: Clinton's tributes and tears charm Vietnam

fields.headline: Clinton's tributes and tears charm Vietnam
fields.trailText: Where once there was napalm, let there be charm. By the time President Clinton left Hanoi for Saigon last night to continue the first visit to Vietnam by a US President since the end of the war more than 25 years ago, he had opened a new chapter in a tragic story.
fields.body:
Where once there was napalm, let there be charm. By the time President Clinton left Hanoi for Saigon last night to continue the first visit to Vietnam by a US President since the end of the war more than 25 years ago, he had opened a new chapter in a tragic story.

He wept, he worked the crowd, he shook their hands and shook them again. He encountered an extraordinary spontaneous show of public curiosity and warmth that left the veteran Communist leadership vaguely unsettled. And although his talk was largely of reconciliation, planted in his texts and conversations was a quiet but persistent affirmation of democratic principles.

At home in the US, where the battle for the White House dragged on, commentators hailed his achievement. The New York Times said in an editorial: 'At a moment when many Americans are wondering whether the contested election is diminishing the presidency, Clinton's appearance in Hanoi seemed to demonstrate the enduring power and symbolism of the office.'

The visit had received only low-key publicity from the regime, but on Friday tens of thousands of Vietnamese lined the streets to greet the President. Whenever he stepped from his limousine, they gathered around him enthusiastically. Millions watched on television screens when Clinton addressed the students of Hanoi University.

Yesterday his eyes brimmed when he stood with the sons of Captain Lawrence Evert, shot down 33 years ago. Standing in a rice paddy beside the pit where Vietnamese and Americans were working together, digging the soil and sifting it for remains, Clinton said: 'This common endeavour we make as friends is unprecedented in all human history.'

He promised that America would not rest until it had accounted for all its lost veterans. But he also praised Vietnamese cooperation in the search which had helped to create the climate in which his visit became possible.

In another striking gesture of reconciliation, Clinton went to the Communist Party headquarters to chat with the party secretary, Le Kha Phieu, head of the 18-member Politburo which determines government policy.

In recent years Phieu has slowed efforts to open the economy and silenced party veterans who dared call for greater political freedom. This lost foreign investment and fed public disillusionment. In response to these pressures, Vietnam recently signed a new free-trade agreement with the US, but there has been no corresponding movement toward political liberalisation.

In his speech to the university, Clinton spoke respectfully about Vietnamese history, diplomatically about the sacrifices of both sides during the war and positively about the promise of globalisation. But he said that 'Americans believe the freedom to explore, to travel, to think, to speak, to shape decisions that affect our lives enrich the lives of individuals and nations'.

He also discussed human rights issues with officials, to their evident discomfort. He told Phieu it was important Vietnam continued to move towards openness, and that it would be far more successful and stable if there was greater political freedom.

The popular reaction to Clinton's visit was exemplified by Dang Dinh Hiep, 52, a postal worker who, 25 years ago, was a soldier who helped to liberate Saigon. After Clinton twice grasped his hand, Hiep said: 'I'm a happy man. He's a wonderful man.'

Clinton, who flies back to the US after today's visit to Saigon, bade a brief farewell to President Tran Duc Luong in Hanoi. 'I have to go home to see if there's a President,' he said.

webTitle: Leaking oil blamed for 155 deaths on Alps train

fields.headline: Leaking oil blamed for 155 deaths on Alps train
fields.trailText: The cable car inferno that killed 155 people in an Alpine tunnel last week was caused by leaking lubricant set ablaze by intense heat, it was claimed last night.
fields.body:
The cable car inferno that killed 155 people in an Alpine tunnel last week was caused by leaking lubricant set ablaze by intense heat, it was claimed last night.

The German news magazine Focus said it had discovered that more than 13 gallons of the flammable liquid - probably from leaking pipes - had flowed to the lower control house for the funicular train. The suspected causes of the leaks were a defective wheel or blocked brakes, the magazine said. Then, it seemed, heat or sparks on the track ignited the oil.

Officials declined to comment directly on the Focus report. 'We can't say anything at all,' said Harald Hofmann, a police spokesman in Salzburg province, where the tragedy happened. 'Everything else is speculation.'

The police have said they were analysing a lubricant found on the line leading to the tunnel to see if it might have played a role in the blaze. But they said yesterday that examination of the substance, used to lubricate cables and ball bearings in the cable car system, had yielded no special clues.

A safety expert told Focus that last weekend's fire may have spread more quickly because of small gas devices carried by skiers and snowboarders to heat wax before they head out on the slopes.

Those killed in the accident included 92 Austrians; 37 Germans; 10 Japanese; eight Americans; four Slovenes; two Dutch, one Briton and one Czech.

Austrians are still trying to come to terms with the tragedy, the country's worst involving winter holidaymakers.

In the town of Wels, thousands of people, including weeping relatives of some of the dead, gathered in a sports hall, as the province that was home to many of the victims, Upper Austria, said a final farewell to them at an ecumenical church ceremony.

Among the dead a week ago yesterday near the Alpine village of Kaprun, south of Salzburg, were 44 snowboarders and skiers from Upper Austria, the single largest number among the 92 Austrian victims. Thirty-two of them were from Wels.

Mourners in the town's sports hall lit 44 candles on a stage covered with black cloth. Many of the relatives wept, and some were so upset that they had to leave. Several federal government ministers and other dignitaries were present.

Repeating the theme of a memorial mass for all the victims, held in Salzburg a day earlier, Roman Catholic Bishop Maximilian Aichern said even the Bible could not answer the question 'why - why the tragedy had to happen.

'We pray for the relatives and friends of the victims of Kaprun, so that they have the strength to survive these hard days,' he said.

In Salzburg on Friday, mourners placed a single red rose for each of the victims at the foot of a Baroque crucifix, while the Salzburg bishop compared the pain of those grieving for the dead with Christ's agony on the cross.

'The Lord cried... "My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?" ' Bishop Georg Eder said, invoking Christ's moment of doubt before death. 'Why? Why? [It is] a piercing, gnawing question that is impending here today in the cathedral.'

Among those at Friday's mass in Salzburg were Austrian President Thomas Klestil, the Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel and the Germany Chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

webTitle: Racism row haunts probe into Hong Kong tragedy

fields.headline: Racism row haunts probe into Hong Kong tragedy
fields.standfirst: As Harinder Veriah lay dying in hospital after a fit, she told her journalist husband 'I'm at the bottom of the pile'
fields.trailText: The Chinese newspapers in Hong Kong reported last week's inquest on Harinder Veriah, wife of former editor of Marxism Today Martin Jacques, in bold characters.
fields.body:
The Chinese newspapers in Hong Kong reported last week's inquest on Harinder Veriah, wife of former editor of Marxism Today Martin Jacques, in bold characters.

'Indian lawyer suspects colour discrimination, then loses life in local hospital.' They headlined the tears shed in court by Jacques, described as a 'famous English voice', as he made the charge.

'I am at the bottom of the pile,' she had said to him in the Ruttonjee Hospital where she was under observation after suffering an epileptic fit. 'I am the only Indian here, everyone else is Chinese.'

Jacques decided to take her home the next morning. Instead, he was summoned urgently to the hospital where he found Veriah unconscious, attended by only two nurses. An hour- and-a-half later she was dead.

The week-long inquest has raised questions of diagnosis, choice of drugs and medical competence. Veriah was admitted in the early hours of the new millennium. The doctor responsible for her prescribed valium when she had a second fit, saw it administered, and walked away shortly afterwards. He had been on duty for 24 hours.

There have been critical cases recently of alleged negligence in Hong Kong's public health system. But it is the charge of racial prejudice, in a place where the majority Chinese population lived under white British rule until three years ago, that touches a really sensitive nerve.

'It's the last day of the millennium,' said Veriah on the evening of the 31st, as she lay in bed weak from diarrhoea contracted on a holiday in Vietnam. 'How can I not go out?'

Jacques told the court they were entertaining the historian Professor Eric Hobsbawm and his family, who were visiting Hong Kong. Veriah, who worked for the international London-based law firm Lovells, had the first fit soon after midnight. The party was leaving the Excelsior Hotel on the packed streets of Causeway Bay.

It was Veriah's 33rd birthday. Earlier they had travelled by boat to Lantau Island where they had taken a bus to the fishing village of Tai O. On the boat-trip back, they cut her birthday cake.

The first doctor to examine her before she entered hospital decided her 'grand mal' attack - only the second of her life - had been precipitated by 'tiredness' and 'two mouthfuls' of champagne. Though assigned to a neurologist, she never saw him because it was the New Year.

The charge of discrimination hit the headlines and then was barely mentioned again in court. But it hovered in the air during proceedings that illustrated Hong Kong's complex ethno-cultural mix.

The medical staff being questioned were Chinese: their friends sat supportively to one side of the public benches. Jacques's friends were mostly non-Chinese: they sat on the other side.

The two key witnesses gave evidence in Cantonese - their mother tongue - though they had written the case notes in English. Questions involving abstruse medical terminology put by Jacques's Indian barrister had to be filtered through a struggling interpreter. Coroner Andrew Chan, fluent in both languages, sometimes became exasperated and took over.

Jacques spoke intimately of his relationship with his wife and of their two-year-old child: 'Hari always phoned me from the office every day: we loved each other,' he told the court.

His attitude has upset some overworked public service doctors who feel they are being made scapegoats.

'I pity our profession', wrote one signing himself 'a humble doctor' to a medical website. 'Nowadays, patients cannot be dead. If dead, we become the murderer, the discriminator, the negligent doctor. Why could the patient's family [not] act more elegant[ly] and not blame us for any death? Why do we doctor[s] need to discriminate [against] anybody?'

Jacques maintains the case raises important questions, not only about the standard of care in Hong Kong hospitals, but as to whether all races enjoy parity of treatment. A senior civil servant of Indian origin phoned him during the hearing to say he was right to raise the issue.

The Hong Kong government was accused of whitewashing racism in a report it submitted last month to the UN. It was 'almost a social norm', said a Human Rights Commission spokesman, that people with darker skin suffered discrimination. The government denies the need for an anti-racial discrimination law. Former legislator Christine Loh, who has called for a law, says 'the problem is they never ask ethnic minority groups'.

Critics says Hong Kong's money-conscious society looks down on 'people from poor countries'. Domestic workers from the Philippines and Indonesia often complain of harsh treatment: a maid was branded by her Chinese employer with an iron.

Traditionally, many Indians here worked as guards and doormen or in the import trade. There are now Nepalis from ex-Gurkha families working on construction jobs. Jacques said Veriah found racial discrimination during her year in Hong Kong to be far worse than in the previous four years living in London. She came from the multicultural society of Malaysia, where her left-wing father had been the youngest MP in its first Parliament.

Veriah, said Hobsbawm at her funeral, 'linked the worlds of Asia and the West. Eastern and Western politics framed her life. But she remained non-political, straddling and combining her worlds.'

Her grieving husband is now committed to a crusade to force Hong Kong to face up to what he insists are deep flaws in its society.

The coroner will give judgment on the case this week.

A senior civil servant of Indian origin phoned him during the hearing to say he was right to raise the issue. The Hong Kong government was accused of whitewashing racism in a report it submitted last month to the UN. It was 'almost a social norm', said a Human Rights Commission spokesman, that people with darker skin suffered discrimination. The government denies the need for an anti-racial discrimination law. Former legislator Christine Loh, who has called for a law, says 'the problem is they never ask ethnic minority groups'. Critics says Hong Kong's money-conscious society looks down on 'people from poor countries'. Domestic workers from the Philippines and Indonesia often complain of harsh treatment: a maid was branded by her Chinese employer with an iron. Traditionally, many Indians here worked as guards and doormen or in the import trade. There are now Nepalis from ex-Gurkha families working on construction jobs. Jacques said Veriah found racial discrimination during her year in Hong Kong to be far worse than in the previous four years living in London. She came from the multicultural society of Malaysia, where her left-wing father had been the youngest MP in its first Parliament. Veriah, said Hobsbawm at her funeral, 'linked the worlds of Asia and the West. Eastern and Western politics framed her life. But she remained non-political, straddling and combining her worlds.' Her grieving husband is now committed to a crusade to force Hong Kong to face up to what he insists are deep flaws in its society. The coroner will give judgment on the case this week.

webTitle: Speeding skier sent to jail over death on piste

fields.headline: Speeding skier sent to jail over death on piste
fields.trailText: The world of skiing was shocked yesterday after a skier was sent to prison for his role in a fatal accident on an American piste.
fields.body:
The world of skiing was shocked yesterday after a skier was sent to prison for his role in a fatal accident on an American piste.

Nathan Hall, 21, was convicted of criminally negligent homicide in a court in Eagle, Colorado, and faces up to six years in prison.

The accident took place in 1997 when Hall, who was working as a lift operator at the leading American resort of Vail, lost control skiing down the mountain and struck Alan Cobb, inflicting severe head injuries.

Although there have been prosecutions of skiers and snowboarders and civil cases for damages, lawyers involved in the case say this is the first criminal trial of a skier for killing someone.

Witnesses said Hall, who had been a ski racer while at school in California, had been skiing far too fast. He was also convicted of possession of marijuana and possession of alcohol by a minor, although he tested negative for marijuana after the accident and was not drunk.

Prosecution lawyers said that the verdict would make 'the ski world a safer place'.

'I think it sends a message to safe skiers and potentially unsafe skiers that there is accountability. You can't just walk away because it happens on a ski slope.'

The verdict was welcomed by British skiers. Denis McShane, MP for Rotherham and an experienced high-speed and off-piste skier said: 'This is an overdue warning to all hooligan skiers that if they can't control their speed, they should stay in bed. The iron law of skiing is that the person higher up the slope is responsible for avoiding the people below. Good skiing is about controlling speed, while stupid lager-lout skiing is about terrifying and cannoning into slower skiers.'

But Nigel Hook, of the Central Council of Physical Recreation, which represents skiers and their governing bodies, said: 'This is a sad day for skiing and this case will send shock waves rippling through the sport. Skiers should make sure they have insurance that will cover them if they end up in court.'

The Colorado trial followed years of legal wrangling in which courts twice dismissed the case on the basis that no reasonable person could have expected that excessively fast skiing would cause someone else's death. But the Colorado Supreme Court reversed those decisions earlier this year.

Hall, being treated at a hospital for concussion and apparently unaware of what had happened, told a sheriff's deputy: 'I tried to slow down. I was trying to get control. I went off a knoll. I was off my feet. I'm an expert skier. I can stay in control all the time. I just hope I didn't injure another person.'

The defence said the incident was a 'tragic accident'.

The killing followed a series of highly publicised accidents. Many resorts in Colorado, including Aspen, Breckenridge and Vail, now have more safety patrols and warning sign. Speeding skiers can have their lift passes confiscated.

Attention has now been focused on the record of European resorts, with the number of injuries on increasingly crowded runs giving cause for concern. In February, a British schoolgirl suffered serious head injuries after a pile-up on a ski-lift in the Dachstein mountains in Austria. Six other children were injured. Some ski areas have by-laws to stop skiers speeding.

fields.headline: WORLD IN BRIEF
fields.trailText: Swastika men held
fields.body:
Swastika men held

Three amateur Polish filmmakers who displayed a 15ft swastika in what they said was part of a pacifist project were detained by police in Warsaw and may be charged. The public display of Nazi emblems carries a maximum two-year jail term.

Speed traps Minister

Germany's new Transport Minister, Kurt Bodewig, appointed after Reinhard Klimmt quit over an embezzlement scandal, admitted he had once been banned from driving for speeding but said he had learnt his lesson.

Factory workers burn

Ten women and a man on night shift at a Johannesburg shoe polish factory were burned to death after an explosion. Police investigated allegations that they had been locked in.

Bootleg brew kills 128

The death toll in Kenya from a lethal illegal brew of beer laced with methanol rose to 128. A man was arrested at a chemical factory in a Nairobi slum.

City put in receivership

Michigan has declared a state of emergency and appointed a civic leader to the small working-class city of Hamtramck, which is in receivership. It is known for having a bar per block, strong union influence and rats fattened by uncollected rubbish.

Third quake strikes

An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.8 shook Papua New Guinea, the third to strike in as many days. No casualties or serious damage were reported.

Backstreet fans hurt

Ten people were injured when fans armed with cameras mobbed the bus of pop group the Backstreet Boys when it arrived in Tokyo on a world tour. Thousands of screaming girls greeted them at the airport.

Bomb kills worshippers

A bomb exploded outside a mosque at Bafia in a remote corner of north-west Pakistan, killing two people and injuring five others. No one claimed responsibility.

webTitle: Women kept abreast of the latest fashion

fields.headline: Women kept abreast of the latest fashion
fields.trailText: Drivers in Rio seeking distraction from the city's chaotic traffic jams were this week able to ogle road-side billboards bearing a pair of breasts and the unambiguous phrase: 'If she used half-cups, they'd spill over.'
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Drivers in Rio seeking distraction from the city's chaotic traffic jams were this week able to ogle road-side billboards bearing a pair of breasts and the unambiguous phrase: 'If she used half-cups, they'd spill over.'

The poster campaign was not advertising lingerie but instead a particularly Brazilian journalistic scoop - the first photographs of dancer Scheila Carvalho's recently-operated cleavage. Carvalho's dark features and ample rear have made her a popular symbol of Latin beauty. For her to implant silicone in her chest is little less than a national event.

'I decided that my breasts should be bigger because my hips are full. Proportion - know what I mean?' Carvalho told Playboy, whose November issue has 18 pages of exclusive snaps. The magazine's front cover shows the dancer with a pair of scissors to her bra, as if she is about to launch a new product on the market. Which is exactly what she has done.

Plastic surgery was pioneered in Brazil and has long been flaunted by the rich and famous, yet with Carvalho's nationally-announced boob job the custom has reached disquieting new levels of ostentation.

Next month Playboy goes one step further when it presents its readers with a well-known dancer who has changed her entire physique. Carla Perez is being marketed like a new line of Barbie doll. 'New hair. New nose. New breasts. New tummy. New tush. Don't miss Carla Perez's new body,' trumpets the magazine.

Perez used to dance alongside Carvalho in the same pop group and their rivalry is now being played out on the surgeon's operating table.

'I can understand how another culture might find it grotesque, but in Brazil at the moment it's acceptable,' argues Cynthia de Almeida, Playboy's editor-in-chief. 'We are playing with the idea of reforming one's body.

'Both women have already featured in the magazine. If we put them in again we want to show that they are different than before.'

Beautiful women are regarded as a symbol of Brazil's identity and Playboy - regularly the best-selling monthly magazine in the country, with an average circulation of 500,000 - is probably the best barometer of this national pride.

But the growth in visibility of cosmetic operations has meant that specialist magazines are catching up on the traditional titles. Plastic Surgery and Beauty, the market leader, features almost identical covergirls as Playboy. This month Carvalho is on both.

Plastic Surgery and Beauty Editor Katia Neves says no celebrity has ever refused the chance to be on its front cover. 'Plastic surgery used to be elitist. Now you can have operations from just over £1,000. The scars are almost invisible. Any middle-class person can do it. It's easy and accessible,' she adds.

Brazil has more plastic surgeons per capita than any country in the world, according to its trade association, and Carvalho's billboard breasts will do nothing to stop the flow of women succumbing to the scalpel. Spring has just begun and with it the slow run-up to carnival at the end of February, making this surgeons' busiest time of year.

The industry has been helped by a fad for large breasts - inspired by a buxom television presenter called The Sorceress - which has confused all the experts. Until about a year ago the ideal of Brazilian beauty was a flat chest and large bottom - very different from, say, the curvacious figure of Brazilian supermodel Gisele Bundchen.

'We never used to have an American standard of beauty. It used to be tha case that if anyone had breasts like the Soreceress, she would have an operation to reduce them,' says Ms de Almeida.

The man who many consider to have started Brazil's craze for cosmetic surgery, Professor Ivo Pitanguy, is reluctant to say that the desire to alter one's body has gone too far. For him, the more commonplace it is the better.

Speaking from his Rio surgery, he said: 'My great fight is for these things to be done as normally as possible. We are not doing something extraordinary. The important thing is to be natural.'

He believes that plastic surgery has an important role in modern society: 'Its is not about fashion. It is deeper than the skin. We are improving people's self-esteem.'

But he adds that women should be cautious in treating themselves like dolls. 'I do not think that changing the whole body is a good advertisement for plastic surgery. Very many times when you change the whole body you are not happy.'

webTitle: Villagers lock horns over £25m Nokia windfall

fields.headline: Villagers lock horns over £25m Nokia windfall
fields.trailText: A batch of Nokia shares bequeathed to a tiny Finnish village has divided the local community, provoked an acrimonious legal battle and forced the locals to negotiate a moral maze from which they are just beginning to emerge. But a happy ending may at last be in sight.
fields.body:
A batch of Nokia shares bequeathed to a tiny Finnish village has divided the local community, provoked an acrimonious legal battle and forced the locals to negotiate a moral maze from which they are just beginning to emerge. But a happy ending may at last be in sight.

In a yarn that would have Hollywood's finest reaching for their cheque books, an elderly Finnish man in the Sixties left his native village shares in a small company that produced rubber boots.

The company was Nokia - almost 40 years later it is the world's biggest manufacturer of mobile phones. The value of the shares has rocketed and they are now worth tens of millions of pounds.

But the 2,000 inhabitants of Pukkila, 60 miles north of Helsinki, cannot agree on how the windfall should be spent and have wasted years arguing among themselves.

In 1962 Onni Nurmi died, leaving the village 760 Nokia shares in his will. The legacy was then worth £10,000 and he left instructions that the shares should never be sold.

Instead he insisted that the annual dividends be spent on 'entertaining' the 25 or so elderly people in the village's modest yellow washboard nursing home.

The sluggish pace of life in Pukkila, where many of the locals work the land, continued uninterrupted for the next 30 years. But in the mid-Nineties Nokia's diversification into mobile phones turned it into a global colossus. Suddenly the dusty Nokia shares were worth serious money.

In 1997 the local council, anxious to protect its investment and all too aware of the extreme volatility of technology stocks, prepared to sell a third of the legacy, which at its peak last spring was worth some £35 million.

But not everyone was happy. Some villagers said Nurmi's last will and testament was not being respected. There were concerns that the council would spend the money on frivolous projects, including a swimming pool, leaving the village's old folk in the lurch.

Others cannily pointed out that they would not need to pay taxes for 12 years if the windfall was poured into the council's budget.

For a small hard core of residents, enough was enough and they launched legal action to stop the sale. The legal wrangling dragged on for three years and it was only in June that the case was wound up: the council won. Today things are calmer.

Juha Myyrylainen, Pukkila's council leader, sits in a modest office overlooking the old people's home, monitoring the rise and fall of Nokia shares on his PC.

Pukkila itself looks like any other Finnish village: low-slung red and white washboard houses with well-kept lawns are hemmed in by birch and pine tree forests and muddy fields.

Myyrylainen talks cautiously about how the village will spend its windfall, and he is adamant the money will still be targeted exclusively on the elderly. 'We can invest the profits, make other investments and use the money for all kinds of care for old people. We can even build a new old people's home.'

In the existing home, pensioners are grouped around a huge widescreen TV watching a soap opera. Each morning a nurse tells those who are interested how the shares are faring.

The home has long been the envy of old people for miles around and there is a long waiting list to get in. In the dining room a portrait of Onni Nurmi takes pride of place. Little is known about him, except that he worked in America where he made his fortune before coming home to die.

A foundation is now to be set up in his name to oversee the sale of his shares, which at today's market prices are worth around £25m. It will meet for the first time tomorrow and Myyrylainen is likely to sit on its board.

Residents are frustrated, he says, that the money has not been spent sooner. 'It does test the patience. It's been dragging on for too long and people want to see concrete results.'

Profits from the shares were first spent on small items such as magazines and theatre trips, but have now been ploughed into extra staff for the nursing home as well as a minibus, special beds and other equipment.

Myyrylainen says: 'The plan now is to build each and every one of the village's pensioners their own self-contained units in a new nursing home.'
