webTitle: War of words over Graham Greene

fields.headline: Greene's heart is pierced by poison pens
fields.trailText: Even beyond the grave, Graham Greene can still inspire a vicious fight between women who knew him. A war of words fought across the pages of  The New York Review of Books and the  National Post  features bitter accusations of betrayal and duplicity as vivid as any in Greene's fiction.
fields.body:
Even beyond the grave, Graham Greene can still inspire a vicious fight between women who knew him. A war of words fought across the pages of The New York Review of Books and the National Post features bitter accusations of betrayal and duplicity as vivid as any in Greene's fiction.

The dispute between Yvonne Cloetta, Greene's mistress in his last 20 years, and Shirley Hazzard, an American writer who socialised with the couple, centres on Hazzard's recently published memoir, Greene on Capri.

In the book, Hazzard, who was among the few people Greene socialised with while visiting his island house, describes the author as a curmudgeon whose life on Capri was a way of coping with boredom and black moods.

She tells how he picked quarrels with friends with 'a playground will to hurt, humiliate and ridicule'. He developed a 'readiness to hurt even, or especially, those who were fond of him or wished him well' and 'evidence of the pain he caused gave reality to his own existence...'

Writing to the New York Review of Books following a review of the book by author David Lodge, Cloetta rails at Hazzard, saying she and Greene 'fundamentally disliked each other but never dared admit it and played a kind of parody of friendship'.

She claims Hazzard lacks any 'psychological intuition and is thus completely mistaken in her observations about Greene' in her 'cold little book'.

Cloetta, who now lives in southern France, rebuffs Hazzard's claim that Greene disliked Capri and his house there, Villa Rosaio. As evidence of his meanness, Hazzard gave an example of Greene wishing to take a bus rather than a taxi home after dinner. Not so, says Cloetta. 'It was just an excuse to escape from her constant talking which he couldn't bear any longer.'

Cloetta goes on: 'She claims he lacked tenderness, but I never found this to be true in the 32 years of closeness between us, and I feel pretty sure his friends - his real friends - would share my feelings.'

In a reply to the literary journal, Hazzard accuses Cloetta of garbling her 'explicit words' in her eagerness for indignation. Hazzard denies suggesting Greene disliked Capri, that he was mean ['from time to time he chose to flourish frugality'] or lacked tenderness. She sought only to 'revisit and pay tribute to Greene in his restless engagement with life'.

Hazzard accuses Cloetta ['Greene's self-appointed proprietress'] of duplicity - initially encouraging her to write a memoir 'by one who loved him and who he loved', then being behind a scathing review of her book under a pseudonym in Canada's National Post .

In that review writer 'Judith Evans', accuses Hazzard of failing to exhibit 'a shred of human sympathy - as though to be human, a man must be faultless. Behind the apparently warm focus of Hazzard's remembered friendship, her account is a betrayal: unconsciously, of the author's consuming rivalry with her subject, and a worse public betrayal of the affection Greene and Cloetta showed her.'

Hazzard, she writes, 'has put herself on the wrong side of history. Didn't you ever, Shirley, ask yourself why he wasn't as fond of you as you'd like him to have been?'

Since the author, whose name is familiar to none, addresses Hazzard by her first name, Hazzard suggests the 'article patently though undeclaredly derived from Yvonne herself'. The review was sent to her anonymously.

David Lodge, who described Greene on Capri as 'an affectionate but not uncritical remembrance' has wisely excused himself from the battle between the two women.

Writing to the New York Review of Books following a review of the book by author David Lodge, Cloetta rails at Hazzard, saying she and Greene 'fundamentally disliked each other but never dared admit it and played a kind of parody of friendship'. She claims Hazzard lacks any 'psychological intuition and is thus completely mistaken in her observations about Greene' in her 'cold little book'. Cloetta, who now lives in southern France, rebuffs Hazzard's claim that Greene disliked Capri and his house there, Villa Rosaio. As evidence of his meanness, Hazzard gave an example of Greene wishing to take a bus rather than a taxi home after dinner. Not so, says Cloetta. 'It was just an excuse to escape from her constant talking which he couldn't bear any longer.' Cloetta goes on: 'She claims he lacked tenderness, but I never found this to be true in the 32 years of closeness between us, and I feel pretty sure his friends - his real friends - would share my feelings.' In a reply to the literary journal, Hazzard accuses Cloetta of garbling her 'explicit words' in her eagerness for indignation. Hazzard denies suggesting Greene disliked Capri, that he was mean ['from time to time he chose to flourish frugality'] or lacked tenderness. She sought only to 'revisit and pay tribute to Greene in his restless engagement with life'. Hazzard accuses Cloetta ['Greene's self-appointed proprietress'] of duplicity - initially encouraging her to write a memoir 'by one who loved him and who he loved', then being behind a scathing review of her book under a pseudonym in Canada's National Post . In that review writer 'Judith Evans', accuses Hazzard of failing to exhibit 'a shred of human sympathy - as though to be human, a man must be faultless. Hazzard, she writes, 'has put herself on the wrong side of history. Didn't you ever, Shirley, ask yourself why he wasn't as fond of you as you'd like him to have been?' The review was sent to her anonymously. David Lodge, who described Greene on Capri as 'an affectionate but not uncritical remembrance' has wisely excused himself from the battle between the two women.

webTitle: Focus: Death of a dreamer in Kitzsteinhorn fire

fields.headline: 'My daughter wants Papa back. She doesn't think I'm as funny'
fields.standfirst: The face of Kevin Challis was flashed all over the world, but those pictures didn't tell the real story of how a restless young Englishman finally found happiness in the mountains, only to have it snatched away. By Kate Connolly and Paul Harris
fields.trailText: The face of Kevin Challis was flashed all over the world, but those pictures didn't tell the real story of how a restless young Englishman finally found happiness in the mountains, only to have it snatched away. By Kate Connolly and Paul Harris.
fields.body:
Like many young men, Kevin Challis was a dreamer. Growing up in the sedate surroundings of Bridport surrounded by a loving family, he looked beyond the rolling hills and beaches of Dorset to a life of adventure.

Unlike many of his contemporaries, however, Kevin lived out his fantasy. While others settled down into office jobs, he moved to the Alps to carve out a life amid the peaks and snowfields.

Last week, his image was flashed around the world and printed in newspapers from Manchester to Melbourne. His poignant story had resonance beyond the horrific tragedy of the Kitzsteinhorn ski train: it was also about one man's search for contentment in the world, and the fact that he had died when he had finally found it.

The irony is not lost on his widow Christl. The view from her bedroom window is dominated by the stunning 10,500ft Kitzsteinhorn glacier, where she first met Kevin in 1991. Last Saturday, the 40-year old ski instructor was on his way to the glacier, the place he loved, when he died in Europe's worst winter sports disaster. His daughter, Siobhan, later told her mother how he had given up his seat on the Alpine train to an elderly man, telling her he would come on the next one and meet her at the top.

As she waved to him, the eight-year old was unaware it was the last time she would see her father, whom she liked to call 'the funniest man on Earth'.

'That's where it all began, and that's where it all finished, I suppose,' said Christl, also a ski instructor, as she gazed at the snow-covered mountain, cloaked in grey cloud.

But, in truth, Kevin's love for the mountains and the thrills they promised had begun a lot earlier. His father Roy, 68, brought him up to cherish the outdoors, teaching him to swim in the sea when he was just a toddler. He loved sport from the moment he could walk. Though he found school lessons boring, he played football and cricket for local teams and swam at least once a week. During the summer he would plunge into the waves almost every day.

'He was a bit of a daredevil. He just loved to be active and doing something adventurous,' Roy said. He was also a determined young man and had fierce loyalties. While his brothers and father supported local football team Southampton, Kevin was enticed by Brian Clough's Derby County. Even after the club lost its winning ways - and its maverick manager - his loyalty to them never wavered.

Kevin's wild and rash streak was a trait that occasionally got him into trouble. His father remembers him constantly getting told off at his Sea Scout troop. If there was a canoeing trip, Kevin would forget to put on his helmet; if they were sailing he would be caught without a lifejacket. Keeping him in line was at times difficult, but with a smile and a joke Kevin would somehow always avoid serious punishment.

The key moment in all his high jinks occurred, however, in Yeovil. A trip to the dry-skiing slope there at the age of 12 saw him catch the skiing bug after a single lesson. From then on, skiing was to be his sporting passion and the outlet for all his adventurous desires.

He left school at 16, taking a job as an apprentice bricklayer with a friend of his father's. He began to live like a carefree man-about-town with money in his pocket and a desire to have as much fun in Dorset's pubs and clubs as possible. Four years later, aged 20, he joined his father's building firm like his two brothers John and Michael. All seemed well, but Kevin had never lost that passion for skiing. His trips to the slope at Yeovil became weekly jaunts and he picked up some qualifications as an instructor. He soon realised that it was in the Alps that his dreams lay. Aged 28, he quit his job and moved to France with the aim of becoming a professional ski instructor.

In 1991 he journeyed to Austria as an instructor for a group of teenagers on a ten-day tour. Almost immediately a chance meeting on the slopes changed his life. Christl remembers it still, though at first she was not impressed by the brash young man from the West Country. 'When I first saw him on the glacier, I didn't think too much of him,' admits the 39-year old.

But Kevin was undeterred. A few days later he asked her to go for a drink and waited patiently for her to finish her afternoon shift in the ski school office. They left together in the cable car and for the next few days rarely left each other's side. When Kevin's trip finished he promised a sceptical Christl he would return as soon as possible. 'I just thought, "Oh yeah". But he did - 14 days later. He brought all his stuff on the bus, including his ironing board and iron, and whatever he might need,' she said.

Christl was taken aback by her suitor's zeal.'I wasn't that desperate to live with somebody,' she said 'I travelled a lot, and had my own life. I couldn't imagine to live with the same person, eat with the same person every day, speak to the same person every day. But it turned out okay.' She laughs gently. 'It didn't get boring. No, with us it didn't get boring... no... never...'

Three weeks after his arrival, she discovered she was pregnant. They married six months later. That was how Kevin Challis unexpectedly swept into Christl's life. 'I'm just glad for those 10 years,' she said.

Now Christl knows she will never look upon Kevin's rugged face again. His charred remains have been recovered from the two-mile mountain tunnel leading to the glacier where an inferno snatched the lives of 155 skiers and snow-boarders in minutes. He is thought to have escaped from the burning train through a window, but was then overcome by the toxic fumes as he tried to run up the stairs.

Salvage workers have told the relatives of victims that the remains of their loved ones are a distressing sight: faces, noses, eyes and ears have melted, while other corpses have been reduced to little more than ashes. The remains are being painstakingly sifted through by pathologists in Salzburg who are DNA-testing them for identification.

Christl has handed over her husband's toothbrush to scientists so that they can make the correct match. She is not ready yet, she says, to face the details of what happened in the accident, but of one thing she is very clear: she will not see his remains. 'No, no, I don't want to see it. He was a beautiful man, and I'd rather keep him like that.' Her short laugh turns into a deep sigh.

In Kaprun everything is upside down. The tourists have left the resort, their beds taken over by the world's media, and for the past few days a strong wind has wrapped the town of 3,000 souls in a blanket of unsettlingly warm air. Flowers are starting to bloom - although it's the start of the winter ski season.

Like the daily routines of many of the children in the town who have lost fathers, brothers, teachers and ski-instructors, Siobhan's life has been turned upside down. Most of the time, according to her mother, she is putting on a brave face. 'She is sleeping with me, and during the day when she has her moments, she comes to me and cries and we talk about it. When she's in a good mood I let her be... I'm sure that Kevin will be more happy that she laughs and giggles with her friends than if she goes to church and cries, because there'll be enough times when she cries.

'This morning she said to me "without Papa I don't want to live". I comforted her and told her that Papa was here with us and that we had to get on with our lives together. 'She turned to me and said "but Mama, you're not as funny as Papa was".' Humour, in fact, had always been one of Kevin's strengths. In Austria, as in Bridport, he was always the life and soul of the party and it helped win the locals over to accepting a foreigner into their tight-knit Alpine community. The house they created together was quickly filled with totems of their love. Wedding and skiing photographs were plastered on the fridge, a red love-heart with 'Kevin' scrawled through it is still stuck on the fridge door.

But life was not all easy. Kevin had already escaped death seven months earlier when 11 of his ski-instructor friends were swallowed by an avalanche as they skied down the Kitzsteinhorn. Kevin had been due to join them until a last-minute change of plan forced him to drop out. Their deaths affected him badly.

Money was also tight and in the summer months both of them did odd-jobs to make ends meet. Christl too had her own brush with tragedy. Five years ago while visiting a local golf course with Kevin - an eight-handicap player - a golf ball struck from the tee shot straight into her left eye, which she lost as a result.

However, living the dream was still all that mattered. Yet all that ended a week ago. Christl drove her daughter and husband up to the train early in the morning and then returned home. She listened to some music and then left to visit a friend. As she walked she heard a fire alarm and saw fleets of ambulances racing past. At first she was not worried. She had taken Kevin and Siobhan to the train early and was convinced any accident must have happened long after they had reached the top.She was only right about her daughter - Kevin was already dead.

Just to check, Christl rang a friend already on the slopes on her mobile phone. She told her that Siobhan was right next to her alive and well, but that Kevin was on the train. 'Then I think I started to scream,' she said.

Siobhan was brought down at 3.30 by the gondola. By then Christl had already given up hope. 'Siobhan, Kevin is dead,' she told her her daughter. 'Siobhan had sort of expected it because when she was at the top she saw the black smoke pouring out of the Alpine centre, and her daddy never came,' she said.

Kevin's death ended his dream just as he was finally showing signs of calming his urge for adventure. It was a change that Kevin's father had noticed too. In August Kevin and his family had spent a holiday in Bridport and Roy had never seen his son more at ease. 'I had never really thought he would be happy as a family man, but he really was. He was so content with his life. I almost couldn't believe it,' he said. But some of the old Kevin was still there. Lounging on the beach near where he had learnt to swim, Kevin suddenly jumped up and put on his wife's bikini bottoms. He then ran into the sea. Roy could not help but follow him. 'It was the first time I had been swimming in the sea in years, but it was such a funny thing for him to do, very typical of his sense of fun,' he said.

In his life, Kevin won friends across the world. Christl has had calls from as far afield as South Africa. But nothing can change the fact Kevin is gone. There is now only a burial left to close the chapter on the life of an ordinary man who lived out extraordinary dreams.

Her Englishman will be buried in the cemetery on the hill, Christl says, with a grand view of the mountains he loved so much. 'Maybe in six months' time, I'll want to know every detail of what's happened,' she says, 'but for now I have to separate the life from the tragedy, because the life was beautiful and the catastrophe was ugly and horrific.'

fields.headline: A different league
fields.standfirst: Parents deserve the whole picture
fields.trailText: Publication of the Government's school league tables is yet another enormously expensive exercise in stating the obvious. In every part of the country, well-resourced independent schools with the luxury of selecting their intake come top, closely followed by selective state grammar schools. The big news this year is that specialist language and technology schools, with extra funding from the Government, are outperforming other schools. This should come as no surprise. Such schools, able to select a proportion of students according to aptitude, are merely another divisive element in the existing hierarchy.
fields.body:
Publication of the Government's school league tables is yet another enormously expensive exercise in stating the obvious. In every part of the country, well-resourced independent schools with the luxury of selecting their intake come top, closely followed by selective state grammar schools. The big news this year is that specialist language and technology schools, with extra funding from the Government, are outperforming other schools. This should come as no surprise. Such schools, able to select a proportion of students according to aptitude, are merely another divisive element in the existing hierarchy.

The Conservatives introduced secondary league tables, along with a tougher schools inspectorate, in a genuine attempt to offer parents enough transparent information to make a better choice of school. In practice, tables have had the opposite effect. Schools shown to be performing well have the pick of the best pupils from surrounding primary schools. Parents of those left over have a choice only of schools branded 'underperforming'. This is profoundly unjust.

The Government is in a difficult position: parents would not accept less information, nor should they. Proper transparency means 'value added' ranking so parents can assess the boost to young people's chances offered by truly good teaching as opposed to the inbuilt advantages a school gains through geography and the class and wealth of its intake. Without these, we are simply intensifying the pecking order reflected in the league tables and, more worrying, recreating the secondary modern system in all but name.

webTitle: Focus: The Bordeaux harvest is in

fields.headline: Vintage year? Not till the Nose says so
fields.standfirst: Bordeaux claims victory - but only this wine guru can confirm it.  Stuart Jeffries  reports
fields.trailText: Bordeaux claims victory - but only this wine guru can confirm it. Stuart Jeffries reports.
fields.body:
In Bordeaux, the world's greatest wine-growing region, the harvest is in and the signs are good. The weather in August and September was ideal, the grapes are healthy with thick skins and good tannins.

After a series of disappointing vintages, Bordelais viticulteurs have been allowing themselves little smiles and fancy predictions. Antony Perrin, director of Chteau Carbonnieux, says: 'It will be a great vintage. All the grapes are so healthy with no rot. The level of sugar is high and we think the vintage may compare with [the great years of] 1982 and 1990.'

But the man with the world's most important palate has yet to pronounce. He is the equivalent of the Man from Del Monte. If he says 'yes', sales can go through the roof; if he gives a low rating a winemaker can be ruined.

He is the maker and breaker of vintages: 1982 was seen as a great year for Bordeaux wines only after his nose and palate detected something that passed other critics by. Latterly he has led a one-man campaign against Bordeaux's sometimes over-priced, underwhelming wines. Earlier this year he accused some top chteaux of greed and mediocrity and called on them to slash prices by up to 30 per cent.

At the same time he championed small-scale, so-called garage wines, made by fanatical Bordelais winemakers. The result has been a war of words between a tough-talking American and Bordelais winemakers increasingly exasperated at his influence.

In his native United States, they call Robert M. Parker Jr the million dollar nose. In France they often call him something less complimentary - usually under their breath and mostly in the form of anonymous quotations. And no wonder: Parker is the most powerful critic in the world. There is no film or theatre critic who wields such influence. For nearly two decades, no one has changed tastes, prices or driven markets into frenzies as much as this plain-speaking man from Maryland.

'He makes the market, from Paris to New York to Moscow,' said one dealer. 'By the time his latest ratings reach Hong Kong, the price of some unheard-of wine will have shot from 100 to 800 francs. And there's no one who will risk gainsaying him. He's way too powerful.'

Parker refuses all hospitality and freebies and spends tens of thousands of dollars a year on his wine-tasting trips to Europe. It is a level of American probity that is little understood in France. 'What I've brought is a democratic view,' he told the Atlantic Monthly. 'I don't give a shit that your family goes back to pre-Revolution and you've got more wealth than I could imagine. If this wine's no good, I'm gonna say so.'

Apocryphal stories abound about Parker. In one, a man buys a case of Chardonnay, tastes a bottle, and returns the case because he doesn't like it. The next day Parker's verdict is published in his magazine, The Wine Advocate. The man returns to the shop and buys the remaining 11 bottles - at six times the price.

Eloi Durrbach, from the once unknown estate of Domaine de Trevallon in Provence, was woken at 3am by a barrage of phone calls after Parker marked him high. And Charles de Nonancourt, of the once insignificant champagne house of Delamotte, had no idea why his US orders had boomed until he saw Parker's magazine.

Parker, 53, a former banking lawyer, had his first real taste of wine when touring France as a poor student. He drank wine because it was cheaper than the beer and Coca-Cola he was used to, and he became hooked.

Back in Maryland he started organising wine tastings and reading wine journalism, but soon realised the so-called experts were not what they were cracked up to be and that most of what they wrote was intended for wine trade professionals anyway. So in 1978 he launched The Wine Advocate with a loan of £2,000 from his mother.

'I was [in 1978], and remain today, significantly influenced by the independent philosophy of consumer advocate Ralph Nader,' he wrote in the introduction to last year's edition of Parker's Wine Buyer's Guide. 'Moreover, I was marked by the indelible impression left by my law school professors, who pounded into their students' heads in the post-Watergate era a broad definition of conflict of interest.'

Parker made his name by spotting the 1982 Bordeaux vintage. When he flew home from tasting its wine 'futures' in the spring of 1983, he realised he had the scoop of a lifetime, a vintage that he was convinced would become one of the greatest in history, and that other critics seemed to have underestimated. Domaine Des Amouriers 1999
Vacqueyras Les Genestes

Rated : 90/100

Gigondas

Rated : 90/100

webTitle: The long term: The elderly - who cares?

fields.headline: The elderly - who cares?
fields.standfirst: Government has given little help, reports  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Government has given little help, reports Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
Many pensioners may thank Chancellor Gordon Brown for the £200 winter fuel allowance this month. But there could be a sinister motive for the Government's new-found generosity to-wards pensioners. It may be drawing attention away from long-term care, where the most vulnerable pensioners are doing very badly.

There has been very little discussion about the most basic levels of provision of long-term care.

A report by the Institute of Gerontology at King's College, London, paints a worrying picture. Author Fay Wright tells of the patchy provision of financial and other help for the elderly in her report 'Capital Offences: variations in local authority treatment of older homeowners entering residential care'. She highlights the inadequate measures used to assess the needs of the elderly and financial constraints which suggest that thousands of old people are not getting the care they need.

In some local authorities, people living in their own homes are told that they cannot have more than two hours of help from social services each day. Some older people 'will be pressurised into moving into care homes', because it is cheaper for councils to house them there. Many older people could be paying too much towards their residential care because the means testing is often conducted by a social worker, rather than a financial officer. Wright and her team interviewed several financial chiefs who 'commonly perceived this as problematic because they thought that social workers shied away from asking to see relevant [bank and other] statements and were often uncertain about what to do'.

Local authorities take different approaches to the financial position of a relative or carer who continues to live in the family property when the old person goes into a home. If the old person is the owner, they cannot be forced to sell their home if their partner, child over 60 or incapacitated relative continues to live there. Although they can show discretion with other people, some authorities are ruthless. In one case, a 56-year-old daughter who had looked after her mother nearly all her life was told that she would be deemed to own part of the property and that a charge would be put on the rest. The social worker involved said: 'I still don't feel very comfortable about that. The daughter had given up her job, she had taken care of mum, and her portion isn't going to buy her a flat.'

Pauline Thompson, of Age Concern, says she regularly speaks to people who find it difficult to locate a home within the price range enforced by the local authority. 'We've had relatives saying that they've tried 20 or 30 homes in an area but that none would accept anyone for that price.' There are also many problems with long waiting lists at homes.

Despite the rapprochement with healthy pensioners, the Government has made few noises about helping the infirm. It would defend itself by saying that it is creating a 'National Service Framework for Older People' - a National Health Service blueprint due by the end of the year, which is aimed at improving services for the elderly.

These will include more spending on rehabilitation for the elderly leaving hospital.

But changes proposed in the summer to the overall infrastructure of long-term care will do little to help infirm older people who want to stay in their own homes. It will pay the 'nursing' element of fees for the 600,000 people living in homes. Campaigners for the elderly fear that it will amount to just £70 a week to a typical Alzheimer's sufferer whose total weekly nursing home fees are £400.

The Government has yet to organise a parliamentary debate on the long-term care. With the new regime due to come into place next October and a general election likely in the spring, time for discussion is running out.

Scotland seems to be a step ahead, with the parliament there indicating that it might introduce a more generous system than the one proposed by Westminster.

Campaigners for the elderly realise that they need to get their message across this autumn.

The Royal Commission on Long-Term Care report in 1999 called for an overhaul in the provision of care.

Such commissions are rare and the opportunity for change should not be missed.

webTitle: The long term: Many a slip twixt home and hospital

fields.headline: Many a slip twixt home and hospital
fields.standfirst: Broken bones or failing memory needn't mean a total loss of independence, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Broken bones or failing memory needn't mean a total loss of independence, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
When you are a child, you expect to fall over and dust yourself down several times a day. But by the time you reach your seventies or eighties, falling over is probably one of the events you fear most.

About 40 per cent of people going into old people's homes do so after a fall. For many people, particularly women, bone density has decreased to such an extent by old age that a slip can easily lead to a fracture. And a broken hip or arm can frequently trigger a chain of events which end up in institutionalisation.

But it does not have to be this way. Many older people fight to stay in their own home. Crucial to the outcome is the way those people - or their relatives - handle discussions with GPs, hospitals and social services.

Hospital assessments

If you end up in hospital, you should ensure that you get a 'hospital assessment' before you leave. This is your 'route to after-care services', says Stephen Lowe of Age Concern. This is where you will discuss the provision ofhome helps, for instance, meals on wheels, future medical and nursing re quirements, rehabilitation and any equipment or adaptations you may need, including wheelchairs or handrails. Don't let the hospital discharge you without an assessment - as many try to do if they are under pressure for space.

GP consultations

If your fall was not bad enough to take you to hospital, your route to other care services comes through your GP. Ask the doctor for a social services assessment from the local authority. Getting an assessment is crucial - even if you end up paying some or all of the help and services you receive yourself. By assessing you, social services will be accepting that they have some responsibility for you.

Who foots the bill - NHS, social services or you?

This is a very confused - but critical - issue. If you continue to be the responsibility of the National Health Service after discharge, your treatment is free. So if you go back for out-patient treatment you do not have to pay. Or if you are in a rehabilitation unit under the auspices of the NHS, that is free.

Individual health authorities set their own criteria for 'continuing care'. Most of this care will be specialist in nature, rather than something a well-trained home help could provide. But as Lowe says: 'If you have a fall, you are likely to come under social services.' This means, in nearly all authorities, that you will be means-tested for the cost of home helps or other services.

Your home will be excluded from the means-test if you continue to live there, but the local authority may insist on your making a contribution. If you go into a home, your property could be taken into account - as will assets over £10,000.

Claiming benefits

You may be able to claim Attendance Allowance or other benefits if your health deteriorates to the extent that you need assistance. Attendance Allowance - a non-taxable benefit - can provide up to £53.55 a week.

Complaints - often the best way out

Since many local authorities are under huge financial pressures, they often provide a very poor service to the elderly. This means that to get treated well you often have to create a fuss. Elderly people who have articulate relatives to fight their cause will usu ally fare better than a lonely old man with Alzheimer's. Lowe warns that local authorities often 'draw out' the first informal stage of a complaints procedure, where there are no time limits within which the authority is expected to sort out the problem. 'Once you get past that stage there are time limits,' he says. 'So once you have attempted to resolve the issue, you may want to tell them that the first stage is exhausted.'

Enduring power of attorney

Set up an 'enduring power of attorney' (EPOA) even before you become unwell - but avoid arranging a 'power of attorney', warns the Alzheimer's Society. You can keep the EPOA document in a drawer and ask your relatives to enforce it only if you become temporarily or permanently unable to manage your affairs. While a POA gives away your right to control your affairs immediately, an EPOA becomes effective only if it needs to be used.

Many people who have a fall or operation have a short-term period of confusion. It will be far less stressful for their relatives if someone else can easily take charge of bills and other financial decisions. Harry Cayton of the Alzheimer's Association recommends against paying regular bills by cash or cheque: 'Pay by direct debit or standing order. If you go into hospital, nobody has to worry about your electricity being cut off.'

Free sources of help

Citizens' advice bureaux regularly advise the elderly on community care and benefits. Age Concern (0800 009 966) has a series of free factsheets. Some charities also give financial contributions. The Alzheimer's Society (020 7306 0606), for instance, runs the Caring Fund, making small grants to families caring for someone with dementia.

fields.headline: Rocker now rolling a burger van
fields.standfirst: From cocaine to catering, former pop star David Van Day talks to Jill Insley
fields.trailText: From cocaine to catering, former pop star David Van Day talks to Jill Insley.
fields.body:
The founding member of pop bands Guys and Dolls and Dollar, David Van Day, says that he has blown - or rather snorted - thousands of pounds on cocaine. 'It was like stuffing it down a manhole,' he says.

Some 20 years after Dollar (remember the diminutive duo singing 'Mirror mirror' and 'Give me back my heart') wound up, Van Day can be found in Brighton, selling hamburgers, doughnuts and ice creams. Most of the 'several million pounds' that he earned as a pop star has gone. 'I know it's not as glamorous and people probably see it as sad, but I can't do anything about that,' he says.

Van Day is currently starring in a new Virgin TV ad campaign that focuses on his financial downfall. In the advert, he is asked if he could have done with financial advice. 'You bettcha,' he replies.

But he admits that plenty of people tried to advise him at the time. 'I wasn't interested. When you are that young and famous, you don't think it's going to stop. You don't think about getting money into a pension.'

And although he has cultivated the impression of being a financial ignoramus for the sake of the advert, he is actually quite astute. Ten years ago he did a life insurance sales course. 'I now know it's one of the hardest things to sell,' he says.

Perhaps this is why he has ended up with a 'few endowments which will hopefully pay off the mortgage'.

But his properties have undoubtedly been his most successful investments. He bought a flat in Brighton five years ago for £140,000 and sold it a few years later privately through a newspaper for £225,000. His home in Hove Park, bought for £250,000, was recently valued at £500,000. Though his fans may frown on his catering businesses, their profit potential is promising. The ice cream business alone sold £1,200-£1,500 of stock a week this summer, at a 60 per cent profit. And, as he points out, he's not the first pop idol to enter the world of food - Bill Wyman has his Sticky Fingers burger restaurant in Kensington.

Van Day also makes a tidy sum from the cabaret circuit, appearing as part of Bucks Fizz with one of the band's original members, Mike Nolan. This work has spurred an interest in the stock market. 'I read the financial pages because I need to know what the main leisure groups are up to - anything that may affect people who book us.'

The duo are paid £2,000 a night, part of which they pay to two women singers who complete the line-up. He also books acts to appear at venues. The only grit in the oyster is a legal battle that Van Day and Nolan are currently fighting against Nolan's former partner, Bobby G, who is also claiming the right to use the Bucks Fizz trademark. Their legal costs have already risen to £50,000, and the case is likely to continue for another nine months.

Van Day seems quite comfortably off for someone who is meant to be on his uppers. His daughters, Olivia and Amber, are both in a local private school, and have ballet and piano lessons, while his wife Maria, a former model, is now a housewife. But the trappings of rock and roll stardom are gone. Instead of a limousine, he gets around in a four-wheel drive or a Rover diesel. 'It's boring, but it does the mileage around the country'.

He says he doesn't miss the money or the lifestyle, but adds: 'If I had the money I'd spend it even quicker. I would do it all again.'

webTitle: Property: When killing is a real seller

fields.headline: When killing is a real seller
fields.standfirst: A bloody past can blight - or boost - a property, says  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: A bloody past can blight - or boost - a property, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
A good address is part of having a good house.

It must conjure up positive images, to the residents at least. But where addresses are synonymous with murder, the feelings are very different indeed - and can be a nightmare when those properties come to be sold.

Earlier this year property developer Peter Radley paid £57,750 at auction for 25 Midland Road in Gloucester, a large Victorian property converted into three one-bedroom flats. It is best known as the house in which, some 30 years ago, Fred and Rosemary West killed at least three women before they moved to the even more gruesome address of Cromwell Street.

'It was the very competitive price that determined I should buy the property,' says Radley, a farmer. 'The flats were already tenanted when I bought it. The tenants in there would obviously be hard put not to know of the history of the building but it was a very long time ago. Now they tend to be more disturbed by the publicity itself.'.

The house at nearby Cromwell Street has been razed, as have a lot of notorious properties including the Manchester council flat where Moors Murderer Ian Brady lived, the west London house where John Christie strangled his victims, and the north London house of Dr Crippen.

Reluctance to live in a house where a murder has taken place is nonsensical according to psychologists.

'People believe that if something bad has happened to someone in a particular place, it might happen to them too. It's utterly primitive,' says Dr Terry Kellard, a psychologist at Warwick Consultants.

'It's inaccurate and irrational, and difficult to reconcile with life in contemporary Britain, but we nearly all do it. The sort of people who do the opposite and want to live in a place with that sort of history have a simple morbid curiosity.'

A difficult history that puts some prospective buyers off can cause little concern to others.

'We were recently selling a basement flat in west London when someone was murdered on the pavement outside as a result of a party getting out of hand in the flat above,' says Peter Rickenberg of agents Leslie Marsh and Co.

'This happened on the Friday night. On the Saturday morning we turned up for a viewing with a woman and her parents to find police swarming around and the whole area cordoned off. Amazingly enough, the woman was unperturbed and bought the flat.'

In nearby Fulham, two Polish emigrés in their eighties who had escaped Stalin's purges were viciously murdered in 1997 in a case that received widespread media coverage.

'Their six-bedroom property sat empty for a year afterwards and then we were instructed by solicitors to sell it. We were obliged to tell any prospective purchaser about the murders before they even went and viewed,' recalls James Bailey of agents Douglas & Gordon.

'We were asking for offers of around £450,000, which was the right market value for an unmodernised house in that area. A lot of people were put off by the history but we also had a great deal of interest and in fact it sold to a young couple with two children who lived around the corner and knew exactly what had happened there.'

Some new owners will even rely on the passing of time turning bloody murder into a gentler form of nostalgia.

Back in the late 1980s a house on Hampstead's opulent Bishop's Avenue in north London was sold with three silver bullets still in an oak panel in one of the rooms, the scene of a murder a year earlier.

In east London the nightly Jack the Ripper tourist tours of Shoreditch take visitors to the scenes of the brothels he frequented and alleyways where he committed his killings. One stopping-off point is 8 Fairclough Street, which is now a three-storey house on the market for a very up-to-date £299,950. But it used to be a brothel outside which the Ripper reputedly killed a prostitute. Far from being shy about the history, the house owner has put the history in the details given to prospective buyers.

For those who believe in the powers of feng shui, the problem with a property which has witnessed an event such as a murder is that its ominous atmosphere - 'negative chi' to the experts - can be transferred to people who move in afterwards.

'The feng shui take on this is that all buildings have predecessor chi which can affect the new residents if something isn't done, whether it has been caused in the past by arguments or illness or something as traumatic as a murder,' says Katie McKeogh of the Feng Shui Academy. The answer, she says, is to create positive chi by changing the layout of the rooms. And, of course, hope that the next buyer is a feng shui disciple.

fields.headline: Illegal sale ends with £900 win
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
As a newly qualified doctor in 1991, I joined the NHS pension scheme. In 1992, I was persuaded to take a free-standing Additional Voluntary Contribution scheme with National Mutual. Four years later, a financial adviser with Albany Life, now Canada Life, persuaded me to take out a second FSAVC but, at a follow- up visit last May, he told me I could contribute to only one at a time, although he was fully aware that I already had one when he sold it to me.

Canada Life has failed to give me an adequate explanation of how to proceed, or what my options are.
JB, Oxford

Not only has Canada Life sold you an illegal pension, it has handled your complaint badly. You complained to Canada Life on 27 May, but the company reacted only when you chased them three months later. It admitted breaking the Personal Investment Authority rule: to respond within two months.

In May, the salesman had called his mis-selling an 'oversight' and an 'anomaly', saying he realised no one could hold two FSAVCs only when he studied for an advanced qualification. In practice, this is one of the first FSAVC facts a salesman learns. In November, he said he had 'misinterpreted' the FSAVC legislation.

Canada Life then discovered that the contributions he told you to make exceeded the Inland Revenue maximum, although he knew how much you earned and contributed to other pensions when he sold the policy.

If, instead of buying the Canada Life policy, you had paid more to your National Mutual FSAVC, the most you could have put in would make it now worth an extra £7,110. Canada Life has agreed to pay you this amount and refund £692 in overpayment plus £144 interest. For these serious errors, it initially offered you just £150 compensation but, on second thoughts, increased it to £500.

Christmas post: Airmail muddle

For years I have sent lightweight Christmas presents, calendars and tea towels to Australia by surface mail. I post them on 2 October, the Post Office's last posting date, but invariably, the envelopes arrive during the third week of October.

We set up an experiment, and found that the same happens in the opposite direction. If, as seems likely, surface packages go by air, why does anyone pay for airmail?
SC, South Molton

The Post Office insists that you get what you pay for. If you pay for surface mail, your Christmas presents travel by boat, which takes three weeks. But your parcels are handled differently when they arrive in Australia, or Australian deliveries arrive here.

Surface mail is given express treatment internally, forwarded by air inside Australia and delivered within 48 hours of reaching the port.

If you posted your envelopes after October 2, they would still arrive early, but the Post Office says they could get caught in the Christmas rush, which is why it likes to get surface mail out of the way early.

Credit card slip: Egg on my face

I tried to withdraw £300 on my Egg Visa card from three cash machines, but all showed that the transaction was not available.

When I complained, Egg said I had withdrawn £300 from Yorkshire Bank but, after two months, I received a letter saying the matter had been resolved and £300 removed from my credit card bill.

But another two months later Egg wrote to tell me that Yorkshire Bank now said I did receive the £300, and they added it back to my account with interest. I know I have not received this money.

Egg gave me £20 for not returning my calls but, because I want a mortgage soon, I could not afford for my name to be black-marked so I paid off my credit card balance in full.

What can I do?
EG, Coventry

Egg says it has a docket from Yorkshire Bank showing that £300 was dispensed from that ATM on your credit card, so it does not accept liability.

This does not mean you received the money but, because of the confusion, Egg has agreed to pay you £300 compensation and delete the interest charges. It has also sent you three bottles of wine, even though you told them you did not drink. It now realises that this was inappropriate and has sent you a cheque for £75.

Pension top-ups: Moving request

I want to top up my occupational pension. Can I move previous Additional Voluntary Contributions into either a personal or a stakeholder pension?
JM, Cambridge

You can move free-standing AVCs into a personal pension but not if you are still contributing to your company scheme.

The rules will be different for stakeholder pensions, where people earning less than £30,000 a year can contribute to both company pension and stakeholder at the same time. The Inland Revenue maximum applies to all your contributions, however they are distributed.

Slow-lane bank: Unreal time

My pension is paid on the twenty-seventh of each month and my First Direct bank statement indicates that the money enters my account that day. But, if I check my balance by phone on the twenty-seventh, even at 8pm, the operator says the money is not arriving until the following day. Nor does it show up if I check the balance on the internet.

I conclude that the bank is making use of my money for 24 hours each month.
SH, Maidstone

This fiasco is caused because banks do not have real-time banking. When you check your balance on the internet, even late in the evening, you are seeing the previous day's position. If you check it by phone, the operator is also looking at the previous night's balance, but can also see payments due 'tomorrow'.

Payments made by 3.30 pm on the twenty-seventh are in your account that day, and you can draw against them, although your statement is not updated until the night of the 27th/28th.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Include a telephone number, but not SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The paper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Help: How do I give to the homeless?

fields.headline: Help!
fields.standfirst: How do I give to the homeless?
fields.trailText: How do I give to the homeless?
fields.body:
However you feel about the Government's drive to stop people giving money directly to beggars, you can increase the worth of your donation to good causes by up to 83 per cent by planning your gifts. You can get not only tax relief, but a Government top-up, too.

The issue attracted fresh controversy this month, when Cabinet Office Minister Mo Mowlam launched the Change a Life campaign, aimed at ending cash donations to beggars on the street and redirecting donations to charities.

Many people dislike the approach: if the whole of the public followed its example, many beggars would have to go into homes, giving up their dogs and giving up drinking (nearly all hostels are 'dry').

So, if you want to maintain their personal liberty, you can continue donating directly, or support a charity such as Shelter, which has declined to take part in the campaign, believing people of the street will be stigmatised. Shelter is sending out a mailshot to 800,000 people this week. Or you could ring 0207 505 2086 or visit www.shelter.org.uk.

Alternatively, if you support Change a Life, telephone 0845 60 61 623 or visit www.changealife.org.uk.

You can offer your time to a homeless charity that supports the campaign (your details will be fed into a database and matched up with a local organisation) or offer gifts such as an old TV set or some cast-off clothes. The final option through Change a Life is to give money. This cash will be split between four charities: Centrepoint, Crisis, the National Homeless Alliance and the Salvation Army.

You will be asked if you want to give through Gift Aid, a tax-efficient donations scheme through which the charity can get basic-rate tax relief of 22 per cent on top of your contribution. The Government will add another 10 per cent.

A good way to give at any time is through Give As You Earn. You donate a set amount each month from your salary to one of the country's 180,000 charities. The charity gets the basic-rate tax relief and the 10 per cent Government top-up. If you are a higher-rate taxpayer, you can claim back 18 per cent - the difference between the 40 and 22 per cent tax rates.

webTitle: Comment: Innovation make the little banks bigger

fields.headline: Innovation make the little banks bigger
fields.trailText: Building societies have long been told that if they want to survive as mutuals, they have to provide something that the shareholder-owned banks lack.
fields.body:
Building societies have long been told that if they want to survive as mutuals, they have to provide something that the shareholder-owned banks lack.

Some, including the Nationwide, have argued that the competitive rates they pay on savings accounts and charge on mortgages speak for themselves. Obviously this was not enough to convince the members of the Bradford & Bingley, who will receive their windfall shares resulting from its demutualisation early next month

But now the Britannia and Yorkshire building societies are developing an idea which really would demonstrate what mutuality should be all about - providing a service for everyone. The two societies have already announced a branch-sharing agreement, which will enable their customers to make basic transactions through any of the Britannia's and Yorkshire's branches across the country.

They are now hoping to extend the idea of branch-sharing to other societies. About half of the UK's remaining 67 societies have expressed interest in joining the scheme once it is up and running.

The Britannia and Yorkshire's ultimate aim is that if you are a building society member, you should be able to walk into a branch of any society anywhere in the country to deposit or withdraw money at no extra cost.

The scheme could help to ensure the survival of some of the smaller societies which provide a good branch service to communities in their own regions but not nationwide. So while many 'big' bank customers are facing life without a local branch in their town or village, customers of even the smallest society could have access to more than 2,200 branches throughout the country.

Go green early

Some, including the Nationwide, have argued that the competitive rates they pay on savings accounts and charge on mortgages speak for themselves. webTitle: Wealthcheck: A new future begins at 40

fields.headline: A new future begins at 40
fields.standfirst: A 'lazy' teacher tells  Helen Pridham  he'll try harder
fields.trailText: A 'lazy' teacher tells Helen Pridham he'll try harder.
fields.body:
Lawrence Young

Age 40

Lives in Leeds

Occupation Teacher

Earns £10,000-plus

Mortgage None

Debts Student loan

Investments £15,000 in bank, £500 Premium Bonds, 1,000 Abbey National shares

Pension None now, but has belonged to schemes in the past

Aims To plan a comfortable retirement and buy a bigger house

Life begins at 40, they say. For Lawrence Young, it has brought a realisation that he should get his finances better organised.

Not that he has any major money worries. 'I consider myself to be in a very fortunate position because my father left me enough money when he died a few years ago so that I could buy a house outright and not have a mortgage to worry about,' he says.

But he admits this has been a mixed blessing.'Not having a mortgage to pay has tended to make me a bit lazy,' he says. 'It has meant I can choose whether I work or not, and therefore I have tended to do so in "fits and starts", typically three or four days a week.'

At present, however, he is working full time, teaching English at a special school. As a result he expects to earn more this year (pro rata around £28,000 ). When he was younger he went from job to job, mostly in the pub lic sector, working for a variety of local authorities, the Department of Social Security and the penal reform group, Nacro.

But when he was 30 he decided to take a degree in English and theatre studies. This was followed by teacher training.

Since then he has been supply teaching. 'I am now thinking of taking a permanent job working with children with behavioural and learning difficulties.'

He is not a member of a pension scheme. He decided against joining the teachers' plan when he started supply teaching, thinking he could do better with the money himself. He has some bits and pieces of pensions from his previous employment in the public sector, but is not sure how to track them down.

However, he has not neglected his savings and has built up £15,000 in an Abbey National Supersaver account. He had originally earmarked this money for round-the-world travel, but now thinks this trip is unlikely to happen, so he does not need the money to be so accessible after all. As a result, he is in the process of moving £3,000 into an Isa with Smile, the online bank. He also feels he would like to dabble in shares.

His finances are helped by the fact that he has a lodger, another teacher, who pays rent of £30 a week. Lawrence has no debts apart from a student loan, which he is repaying at £25 a month, though he is not sure how long it will take to clear. He thinks he would like to move to a larger property in two or three years' time. If he is in a full-time job, he will probably take out a mortgage to fund the extra cost.

His only extravagance is travelling around the country supporting his old home football team, Aldershot.

Adviser 1: Amanda Davidson

At the age of 40, retirement planning becomes critical. If Lawrence thinks he has some old pensions with previous employers, he needs to write to them and ask for information.

Lawrence should join an occupational pension scheme. He is wrong to think that he could do better with the money himself. An employer contribution in most cases will at least match the employee's payment and sometimes exceed it. Any investments outside this would need to do spectacularly well just to equal the returns. He should also seek financial advice on whether it is better to transfer his previous benefits to his new scheme.

Lawrence should catch up on past pension provision by transferring a lump sum into a pension. He can go back over previous years, but he needs to hurry, as rules change in April 2001 and will be markedly less generous. His £15,000 savings need to be better invested. In order to buy a house, he needs to keep some of it in cash.

For the longer term, say five years plus, he could invest his money in unit trusts, rather than individual shares, which are more risky. He can, for instance, put £3,000 into unit trusts via a mini-equity Isa.

If Lawrence does get a full-time job, he may also be able to take out a regular savings Isa to help towards his future security. Once he takes out a mortgage, he should look carefully at critical illness cover to ensure mortgage protection in case he falls sick.

Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan.

Adviser 2: Steven Price

Lawrence should move sooner rather than later in order to repay any mortgage before retirement. Based on an earnings multiple of 3.25 and £30,000 in earnings, he could borrow up to £97,500.

With some £46,000 from the sale of his present home (which he estimates to be worth £250,00) he could buy a property for up to £144,000. For a 20-year loan, I would recommend a repayment-only mortgage.

Lawrence needs to act on his pension quickly, for a standard of living after retirement comparable to the one he enjoys now.

He should join the Teacher's Pension Scheme. This is likely to be better than anything he finds himself. It is a good, final salary occupational scheme. Based on 20 years of service from now and a final salary of £30,000 in today's terms, he would get a pension of £7,500 a year and a cash sum of £22,500. Additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) or other savings could top up these benefits.

As for his savings, I suggest Lawrence moves £1,000 of his Abbey National shares and £2,000 from his bank account to a mini equity Isa using, for example, Save & Prosper's Premier Equity Growth fund.

He could continue adding to this holding in future via a regular savings Isa. He is moving £3,000 to a cash mini Isa. This leaves £10,000 of liquid savings. He should keep some £5,000 for moving costs, and £5,000 as an emergency reserve fund.

Steven Price works for financial adviser Towry Law. Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Video turns Granada nasty
fields.standfirst: Martin Bright  tells how the firm hounded him over a stolen VCR
fields.trailText: Martin Bright tells how the firm hounded him over a stolen VCR.
fields.body:
My flat was burgled almost two years ago. It was quite a neat job: no personal insults daubed on the wall; the cats left untortured.

This was Hackney, in east London, where it was not unusual to meet a police cordon on the way home from work as a result of yet another an armed siege, so although the burglary was upsetting, I thought I was lucky it hadn't been worse.

The thieves took my laptop containing five years of freelance work; someone, somewhere is making good use of my old passport and I still haven't replaced my natty little Sony shortwave radio.

I called the police and two officers from nearby Shoreditch station took fingerprints and a statement. I was not optimistic that they would retrieve anything, and so it has turned out. But I knew I would need a crime number for insurance purposes.

The last thing I was concerned about was my rented video recorder. I'd signed an insurance agreement with the Granada showroom when I hired it and that, I thought, would be enough. I reported the loss to the local branch and left it at that.

Then, last May, I received a letter from Granada Home Technology saying it had come to their attention that I was no longer paying for my video by direct debit so I faced an extra charge for paying by cash. I phoned to explain that the equipment had been stolen 18 months previously, and was told it would be sorted out.

A month later I received my first letter from Granada's credit control department with the photocopied signature of Georgina Richards at the bottom. Over the months that followed I would get to know the squeezed-up, mean-looking lines of that signature very well.

After July's missive, with my outstanding bill standing at a modest £22.36, I confirmed the date of the theft and the crime number with the police, and passed them to the credit control department. Again, I was told that it would be sorted out and that I could apply for a repayment of any extra direct debits I had paid after the machine was stolen.

Yet on 29 August, Georgina started playing hardball. Unless she heard from me within 48 hours she would 'apply for a Default Notice to be served under Section 87 (1) of the Consumer Credit Act 1974'. A week later, the notice arrived with a warning that if I didn't pay the outstanding balance, which had then risen to £61.08, 'we shall take all the necessary steps to recover ALL [sic] monies due from you together with ALL legal costs.'

This was beginning to get scary so I phoned again. I asked: 'Don't you think it seems a little unfair to expect me to continue to pay for a video that was stolen from me two years ago.'

The call centre operator said: 'Our records say you owe us the money.'

Me: 'Are you seriously saying you will take me to court for payments on a piece of equipment that the police know has been stolen?'

'It's not my decision,' he said.

I was told to report the theft to a Granada show- room - something I had done two years earlier. I said I didn't see why I had to go through the process again. This, I later discovered, was registered on my Granada file as an outright refusal to report the theft.

In October things started to get really heavy. Granada had passed the account to the TSR Debt Recovery Service, which demanded £272.47 to cover the outstanding payments and the cost of the stolen machine. At the end of the month, a firm of solicitors, JM O'Connor, warned me by letter that it was applying for a county court summons. My goods could be seized to recover the money owed, my pay taken from my employer or cash grabbed direct from my bank account.

Last week, I decided to ring the Granada press office to see if this was usual procedure. The company has recently merged with Radio Rentals to become Box Clever, with a turnover of £4 billion. I asked if the company had a policy of persecuting people who had made the mistake of having their video recorders stolen.

I had spotted that the solicitors O'Connor and TSR Debt Recovery were both based at 239 Ampthill Road, Bedford, which just happens to be the headquarters of Granada Home Technology. The headed notepaper was just another of its scare tactics.

Until this point I had proceeded as an ordinary citizen. But as soon as I revealed that I was a journalist, I was phoned within an hour from the managing director's office at Granada/Box Clever. I was told the 'debt' had been written off and was asked to accept an apology.

I will do so if they can assure me that ordinary citizens are treated with such courtesy. Somehow, I doubt whether they honestly can.

Playing it safe

Simply telling the local branch of a chain from which you rent an electrical item about its theft is not enough. Malcolm Hurlston of the Consumer Credit Counselling Service says: 'There is a real problem with communication between the point of sale and the people who deal with the collection of payments. Attention to detail is not a strong point when we are being sold products.'

So what should you do? First, report the theft to the police. At the very least they will provide you with a crime reference number. Then report the theft to the local branch, providing them with written details (of which you should retain a copy) which include the crime reference number.

Insist on confirmation that the crime number has been passed on to the company's head office. In most cases, insurance is invalid if they don't receive the report within 30 days of the theft.

Cancel the direct debit for rental payments if this is how you are paying. Keep copies of all written correspondence to support your case if the company later challenges you for further payment.

For further help contact:

Consumer Credit Counselling Service on 0800 138 1111

Your local Citizens Advice Bureau (look in Yellow Pages or call 020 7833 2181 to find the nearest).

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: £1m cover offered to rugby players | Capital ideas | Gym'll fix it
fields.body:
£1m cover offered to rugby players

Rugby union players of all ages are being offered enhanced insurance protection through a scheme by insurance brokers Marsh.

Four players are left paralysed each year in England alone. For £99 a year, any player left paralysed will receive a payout of up to £1m from Marsh's top-up scheme rather than the £375,000 under the compulsory cover for players.

Contact 0845 601 2703.

Capital ideas

Capital One is offering 0 per cent APR for six months on three themed credit cards, aimed at cat lovers, the Welsh and Irish.

All cards have a choice of three designs. Applicants for the cat lovers card will receive a free copy of the book Cats - the World's Best Breeds by Dr Bruce Fogle. Welsh and Irish card applicants will receive a free Kodak camera. After six months the cards revert to an APR of 12.9 per cent. If you are transferring a bal ance in the first six months, there is a lifetime rate of 7.9 per cent. You can apply on 0800 9525252.

Gym'll fix it

If you cannot use your health club or gym because of injury, illness or unemployment, a new protection plan will reimburse your fees.

You can also make a claim for the annual joining fee under the CSL membership protection plan.

The cost of cover starts from 2.1 per cent of the annual membership fee. Benefit begins after 28 days and is payable for up to 12 months.

Those who have paid membership in full will receive a refund of their fees in proportion to the amount of time they cannot use the club.

Call 0161 247 8480.

Fat piggy banks

If you despair at having to make room for all the presents your children will receive this Christmas, per haps it's time to suggest cash donations into a savings account instead.

Children's accounts offer generous rates compared with adult versions, acording to a survey by MoneyFacts magazine.

The Nationwide Smart 2 Save account offers the best rate in the high street at 6.95 per cent from as little as £1. Even the lowest high street rate is 5.5 per cent, offered by the Bristol & West on its Money Monsters account.

If your child is unlikely to need his or her money immediately, Dunfermline building society is offering 7.15 per cent on £500 or more on its three-year variable-rate children's bond.

Abbey National offers a four-year bond fixed at 6.5 per cent, again for £500 plus.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Sarasin Self Invested Pension Plan
fields.trailText: Sarasin Self Invested Pension Plan
fields.body:
Contact Andrew Hall on 0207 236 3366

Aim To provide all the benefits of a normal pension plan but with extra flexibility and greater control over investments held in your pension fund.

Bells & whistles You can choose from a number of different withdrawal patterns for your pension, including an income drawdown plan that invests in the stock market while you draw an annual income. Buying an annuity can be deferred until you are 75: if you die, your family inherits the fund rather than the insurance company.

How it works Sipps give you control over your pension by allowing you to invest in a wide variety of investment funds from the complete range of providers, including two Sarasin funds: GlobalSar and EquiSar. Sarasin acts as the investment manager on your portfolio, while third-party firm PPM carries out the administration. You can also invest in fixed interest holdings such as corporate bonds, or invest directly in equities.

Minimum £250,000 to build up a pension pot, or £500,000 if you want to use the Sipp to house your pension on retirement.

Charges An initial charge of 1 per cent on the two Sarasin funds, plus an annual management charge of 1.2 per cent. Investors may have to pay the standard initial and annual charges on other funds. It costs £500 to set up the Sipp with PPM, which charges an annual administration fee of £500.

Risk Variable depending on the investments used.

Should you invest? Thomas McPhail of Wolverhampton independent financial adviserTorquil Clark says: 'It is a pointless product with second-rate charges using a third-rate Sipp administration company. You would get more competitive products and more choice elsewhere.' But Ben Yearsley of Bristol firm Hargreaves Landsdown says: 'Sarasin's investment style is very good. They are a thematic investment house, meaning they look at themes such as globalisation and e-commerce and find the companies to fit. They have a very good track record.'

Points out of 10 McPhail - 0, Yearsley - 8.5.
