webTitle: Cultivating a taste for art for  satire's sake

fields.headline: Cultivating a taste for art for  satire's sake
fields.standfirst: The excoriating work of UK cartoonists is appreciated in America far more than here.  John Windsor  reports
fields.trailText: The excoriating work of UK cartoonists is appreciated in America far more than here. John Windsor reports.
fields.body:
Among pictures by Alfred Munnings, Stanley Spencer and L S Lowry in Sotheby's sale of Modern British paintings and drawings next month are five cartoons by Gerald Scarfe. One caricatures the Prince of Wales with elephant ears, another shows Baroness Thatcher as Winston Churchill, giving a V salute.

It is only the third time in 12 years that Scarfe's work has been included in Sotheby's sale of Modern British fine art. Cartoons are usually sold in sales of 'books and original book illustrations'. Are cartoon ists now to be valued as fine artists? What is going on?

It was Susannah Pollen, Sotheby's Modern Brit specialist, who, at a bibulous boardroom lunch, first persuaded Scarfe to consign his work to auction. She says: 'I call them cartoons and make no apology for that. Scarfe's combination of draughtsmanship and satire make his cartoons by far and away the best of their genre.'

But Scarfe is not the vendor of the five up for sale. Although Sotheby's has chosen not to reveal their provenance, they are, in fact, owned by John Cleese, of Fawlty Towers fame, and the way they came to auction gives some clues about what is happening at the top end of the cartoons market.

Cleese bought them some 12 years ago from Chris Beetles, Britain's leading dealer in original illustrations. Beetles has a reputation for getting the best prices, so recently, when Cleese set up house in New York and wanted to shed some of his belongings, he instructed Beetles to sell his Scarfes.

Ironically, the main market for Scarfe's work, and for the comparable excesses of the British cartoonist Ralph Steadman, popularly known for his Oddbins adverts, has shifted to the United States. So much so, that Beetles, fed up with chasing after the two cartoonists on the telephone on behalf of well-heeled clients, has stopped dealing in their work. He therefore consigned Cleese's Scarfes to Sotheby's.

It will be interesting to see how they fare at the forthcoming auction without bids from Beetles the market-maker. Sotheby's pre-sale estimates are not much different from their prices at Beetles' London gallery 12 years ago. The black ink and watercolour of the Prince of Wales, for example, which had a £4,500 tag at Beetles', is estimated £4,000-£6,000. The black ink of Lady Thatcher, also originally £4,500, is estimated £3,000-£5,000.

Meanwhile, Beetles is firming up his gallery's prices for cartoons by Ronald Searle, another British cartoonist lured to America who is now aged 80 and living in France. Searle's vivacious line and taste for the macabre influenced the work of the youngsters Scarfe and Steadman. And all three of them - the outrageous three Ss - owe a debt to James Gillray, the late eighteenth-century caricaturist who audaciously depicted members of the royal family, notably George III and the Prince Regent, defecating, vomiting and fornicating.

In a few years' time, this spiritual link with eighteenth-century rumbunctuousness is bound to reveal the cartoons of the three Ss as belonging in a class of their own. No other cartoonist of the twentieth-century - neither Giles nor Low, even Cummings, but with the possible exception of Steve Bell - has matched the way they spatter venom. And their cartoons are as yet underpriced. They are worth considering as an investment. Searle's cartoons for the St Trinian's and Molesworth books of the Fifties are now so well-loved that it may be difficult to understand why the collected works of Gillray was Searle's book choice on Desert Island Discs.

But his biographer, Russell Davies, juxtaposes the black humour of his cartoon of a gang of St Trinian's girls under the lash of a school mistress as they pull the sports ground roller with a strikingly similar drawing Searle made as a prisoner of war in Changi jail, Singapore, in 1944, of a gang of prisoners pulling tree trunks. In jail, he drew the dead and dying. In 1963, in New York's Bianchini Gallery, he launched a series of 73 ink, wash and watercolour 'Anatomies and Decapitations', anguished anatomical deconstructions never seen in Britain and still languishing in store.

Until recently, his original cartoons fetched half the price of Scarfe or Steadman's, which are in notoriously short supply. But Beetles is pushing up his prices. In his current selling exhibition, Searle's 1992 ink and watercolour for Forbes FYI Magazine , 'The Glorious 12th', showing carnage on the grouse moors, has a tag of £7,500. Molesworth in Elizabethan costume, an original illustration for Willans and Searle's 'Whizz for Atomms' (1956) is £3,500 at Beetles, having cost £1,180 (estimate £600-£800) at South Kensington in June.

If those prices sound steep, consider that Beetles is offering EH Shepard's original pen and ink illustration of Christopher Robin and Piglet watching Pooh eat honey, from A.A. Milne's The House at Pooh Corner (1928), for £85,000. It was bought at South Kensington in June for £49,350.

Beetles says: 'I admire Searle probably more than any other cartoonist. And his work is plentiful; he's not arrogant like some other cartoonists. The response to the Searles in my show has been fantastic. People seem to be rediscovering him.'

Gerald Scarfe has branched out since making a name for himself in Private Eye and Punch. He created the characters for Disney's animated film Hercules, has designed sets and costumes for the Los Angeles Opera and designed and directed animation for the film Pink Floyd: The Wall . Last year the National Portrait Gallery, which paid £4,510 for his iconic cartoon 'Nanny Thatcher' at his first outing in a Sotheby's Modern Brit auction in 1988, gave him a one-man show.

He told me: 'I do regard my cartoons as art, but don't mind if people regard cartoons as a lowly form of it. A lot of artists have been cartoonists - Daumier and Lautrec, for example.

'When I started working for Private Eye, people said I drew like Gillray, but I didn't know who Gillray was. I do now. But at the age of 14-16, Searle was my great hero. I absolutely adored his work. He lived in Newton Road, Bayswater, and I lived in Hampstead and used to cycle over to his home, intending to ring the bell on his gate. But I never had the courage. I think he is someone that England has overlooked; I think he should receive an honour.'

Scarfe's work is not exactly being fought over at auction, certainly not by Beetles. Two Scarfe ink and watercolours showing wine tasters each fetched a modest £822 at South Kensington in June, having been estimated £800-£1,200 each. A third wine-tasting cartoon of his failed to sell.

Ralph Steadman seems to have the eighteenth century in his gut. His wild drawings are spattered with coloured ink that could be blood, wine, or plain filth.

His illustrated books include lives of Freud and Leonardo; Hunter S Thompson's Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, now a Terry Gilliam film; and he wrote the libretto for an oratorio, Plague and the Moonflower, which was made into a BBC2 film. Interviewing Steadman is like taking the lid off a jar of vitriol. 'I don't sell a lot of stuff in England. I sell in America. Over here, forget it. I'm a stranger in my own land. Nobody here wants my work because I almost go out of my way to make it difficult to use. In the times of Hogarth and Goya the cartoonist's job was to be so offensive that nobody of note wanted to be around him. "Watch out, or the little bastard will nail you." That's what cartooning should be like.

'Cartooning in this country is pathetic. They're playing a game - eminent politician buys cartoon of himself by eminent cartoonist. I refuse to play that game. I loathe these politicians. I wouldn't invite them to dinner, so why should I draw them? I'll only draw their legs - it's more insulting.'

Steadman has been paid $24,000 by a collector in Indiana for a drawing of a wine label, and his silkscreen prints, on his sophisticated website, are priced at up to $3,000. But at Christie's South Kensington's most recent sale in June two of his original cartoons, one titled 'Let me out!', (estimate £200-£400), the other of a gormless socialist couple (estimate £400-£600), failed to sell.

Much of Steadman's passion is now directed towards an art gallery/community project in a disused lunatic asylum in Haverfordwest, Dyfed, which will train youngsters who are 'underprivileged or institutionalised' in art and music. He insists on calling it The Asylum.

In Christie's South Kensington's next sale of printed books and original book illustrations, 8 December (11am), there are 21 Searle lots, including three Molesworths estimated around £600-£800 and a classic St Trinian's of wicked girls with a cannon, originally a greetings card illustration, estimated £500-£700. A rare portfolio of Searle's Changi jail sketches is estimated £1,500-£2,000. Expect to pay more.

 Sotheby's Modern British sale is 6 December (10.30am), inquiries (020-7293 5000). Christie's South Kensington (020-7581 7611). Chris Beetles selling exhibition 'The Illustrators: The British Art of Illustration 1850-2000' until 5 January (020 7839 7551).

fields.headline: Invensys plans £4bn spin-off
fields.trailText: Troubled engineering giant Invensys is expected to announce the £4 billion spin-off of its fast-growing power systems division this week
fields.body:
Troubled engineering giant Invensys is expected to announce the £4 billion spin-off of its fast-growing power systems division this week.

The shake-up follows pressure from big City institutions after the firm's shares slipped following a shock profits warning two months ago.

Invensys, formed from the £8bn merger of BTR and Siebe in 1998, has since been dogged by persistent speculation about a foreign bid.

Last week, however, one leading suitor, US conglomerate Tyco International, turned its attention closer to home, buying Lucent Technologies' power systems operations for £1.7bn.

Other rivals understood to have run the slide rule over Invensys are United Technologies and Emerson Electric of the US, and German electrical giant Siemens.

Invensys' power arm made profits of £198 million on sales of £1.4bn last year. It is the world's leading supplier of industrial energy storage systems and number two in power switching, monitoring and protection equipment.

The division is set to be floated off separately and, barring last-minute hitches, the news is anticipated with the group's half-year results on Wednesday, City sources said this weekend.

'People have been very disappointed with Invensys' management since the September trading statement,' one source said. 'A flotation is the best way to demonstrate shareholder value.'

The City has also been unimpressed by the £700m purchase of troubled Dutch software group Baan during the summer.

City anger has been mainly directed at autocratic chief executive Allen Yurko but, as The Observer revealed last month, investors' patience with chairman Lord Marshall, who also chairs British Airways, has been wearing thin. Invensys' senior non-executive director, Sir Philip Beck, has also failed to impress the City in his role as chairman of Railtrack.

Invensys made profits of £516m in the first half of last year and declared an interim dividend of 2.5p. Analysts, however, are bracing themselves for bad news this week.

fields.headline: Taxpayer to foot BNFL bill
fields.standfirst: Government plans single authority for nuclear clean-up
fields.trailText: Government plans single authority for nuclear clean-up
fields.body:
The Government is considering a new nuclear authority to take responsibility for cleaning up all Britain's atomic sites.

If, as senior Whitehall officials wish, the new body's remit were to include British Nuclear Fuels, this would salvage the controversial sale of 49 per cent of the state-owned company, but only by leaving the taxpayer with its liabilities, totalling up to £34 billion.

The body, provisionally called the Liabilities Management Authority, would provide a clear view of the total costs of decommissioning, which are now obscure.

On top of BNFL's £34bn, the UK Atomic Energy Authority has a stated total liability of £7.9bn. The Ministry of Defence has an undisclosed amount. These could add up to £50bn.

However, it is unclear whether certain costs are duplicated, or what additional bills there may be. Any alteration to the differing 'discount rates', which allow decommissioning costs to be accounted for over varying time spans, would affect future bills dramatically.

The LMA plans, which are in their early stages, are part of a five-yearly review of the Atomic Energy Authority, which now concentrates on decommissioning civil sites.

A source close to the review said: 'What is proposed is that ownership of the liabilities remains with the Government, and control of them goes to the authority.'

The inclusion of BNFL would meet the concern of officials and Government advisers about the company's liabilities undermining the confidence of private investors and scuppering its part-privatisation. These liabilities include decommissioning reprocessing plants and the first generation of Magnox atomic power stations, as well as managing radioactive waste.

Official fears about the BNFL sale were raised in Sep tember, when it announced the results of an internal review which increased the cost of decommissioning by £7bn to £34bn.

Creation of the LMA would mean that BNFL could be sold to investors as a nuclear services company, carrying out operations ranging from clean-ups to fuel reprocessing and reactor construction, but without any liabilities.

A source close to the review, which is scheduled to report next March, said: 'The private sector is never going to take on board these liabilities because they are too big, and there are risks which they cannot account for.'

This is ironic because the public-private partnership was originally designed not only to expose BNFL to private-sector management, but also to transfer liabilities to the private sector. However, officials now appear to have conceded that the transfer of these risks may no longer be possible.

One senior Whitehall source said that those for the Magnox stations, for example, could be transferred to the LMA as the individual plants come to a standstill, between now and 2020.

But concerns remain. One is the potential problem of recruiting people to run what would effectively be a nuclear janitor. Perhaps more immediate is the political difficulty of saddling taxpayers with a huge bill, while removing from them much of any gains from the future activities of BNFL.

webTitle: Nomura loses taste for Welsh Water

fields.headline: Nomura loses taste for Welsh Water
fields.trailText: The prospect of Japanese Bank Nomura bidding for Welsh Water is diminishing, according to sources close to the bank
fields.body:
The prospect of Japanese Bank Nomura bidding for Welsh Water is diminishing, according to sources close to the bank.

Nomura's Principle Finance Group, headed by Guy Hands, is said to be unlikely to table an offer for the group unless a rival offer by Glas Cymru, a consortium of Welsh investors, is dropped or ruled out by the water regulator Philip Fletcher.

Earlier this month Fletcher signalled that he saw no fundamental problems with the Glas bid, headed by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns, although there were details that needed to be addressed.

These include whether an organisation that is effectively a non-profit making mutual made up of members rather than conventional shareholders is capable of taking on the risks of managing water assets.

Nomura originally bid for Welsh Water's parent, the beleaguered multi-utility Hyder, but was beaten in an extraordinary contest by US based WPD after a sealed bid process saw the company sold for £2.4 billion.

Hands' interest was renewed several weeks ago after Glas Cymru put in an offer to buy Welsh Water's assets from WPD for £1.8bn, financed entirely by debt.

An offer from Nomura would include raising equity of 25 per cent, which would mean the Japanese bank bearing extra financing costs to cover increased risk - a bill of £5m-£10m a year.

A source close to Nomura said: 'They have looked closely at the numbers and they do not seem to make sense because Welsh Water is a tight proposition and they are facing additional costs just to table a similar offer to Glas.

'Unless Glas withdraws it is unlikely Nomura will bid.'

A source close to Nomura said: 'They have looked closely at the numbers and they do not seem to make sense because Welsh Water is a tight proposition and they are facing additional costs just to table a similar offer to Glas. 'Unless Glas withdraws it is unlikely Nomura will bid.'

webTitle: The number of black cabs on London's roads is set to rocket

fields.headline: Cab? There'll be lots more along soon
fields.trailText: Cyclists beware! The number of black cabs on London's roads is set to rocket
fields.body:
Cyclists beware! The number of black cabs on London's roads is set to rocket.

Manganese Bronze, the quoted manufacturer of most of the world-famous taxis, plans to double the number it produces by building a new factory in the West Midlands. Its decision is driven by a shortage of cabs in the capital and increased overseas demand.

Manganese's subsidiary, London Taxis International, which now makes 3,000 of its TX1 models each year, wants planning permission to turn its existing Coventry factory into a B&Q Warehouse, a hotel and business units. If it wins council consent, it will sell the site and use the proceeds to build the new plant.

Margins from selling TX1 taxis are under pressure from, of all things, the strengthening yen, because the company uses Nissan 2.7 litre engines.

The prospect of increased car production, even by a relatively small manufacturer, will be welcome in the West Midlands, where in the last 12 months both Rover and Rolls-Royce have shed thousands of jobs.

webTitle: How the future of western democracy hangs on a fish

fields.headline: How the future of western democracy hangs on a fish
fields.trailText: One of the truly satisfying spectacles of the year has been the sight of the most technologically advanced society on Earth getting itself into a tangle over the tallying of votes
fields.body:
As Tom Stoppard famously observed, it's not the voting that matters - it's the counting. One of the truly satisfying spectacles of the year has been the sight of the most technologically advanced society on Earth getting itself into a tangle over the tallying of votes.

The solicitous offers of assistance from Messrs Putin, Castro and Mugabe show that high political office does not always mean the surgical removal of a sense of humour. If Idi Amin were around he would doubtless have offered to provide Ugandan advisers.

Many foreign observers - this columnist included - have been puzzled by how controversial the issue of a manual recount seemed to be, especially to the Bush camp. One could understand why such a recount might be questionable in somewhere like Zimbabwe, say, but surely it would be okay in a mature western democracy?

Baffled by this, I eventually went looking on the net and discovered that it's all to do with technology, and in par ticular with hanging chads. Eh? A chad, as every schoolboy knows, is a fish. But in American electoral parlance it is something quite different - the perforated square (or circle) on the ballot paper that the voter depresses with a pin to indicate his or her choice.

The chad hangs from the ballot if the voter doesn't fully depress the pin - which apparently often happens with older voters. And this is important because it turns out that the primitive voting machines used in places like Florida are unable to tabulate cards with hanging chads. But surely this means that manual recounts are the only reliable way to check disputed electoral returns?

Not necessarily, for one reckons without the relentless ingenuity of members of the American Bar Association. According to a fascinating article by Arnold Steinberg in the online edition of the National Review, manual recounts in the presence of lawyers can be just as dodgy as anything involving obsolete technology.

He reports his own experience of a recount when he was working for Bobbi Fielder, a Republican candidate in the 1980 Congressional elections who ran against a long-term Democratic incumbent, James Corman. Fielder won by a small majority and the Democrats demanded a manual recount.

'What my lawyers soon discovered,' writes Steinberg, 'was that the opposition would eyeball a disputed ballot before picking it up to officially inspect it. If the hanging chad indicated a vote for Fielder, the lawyer for the other side picked up the ballot ever so carefully, so he could argue that the voter really never intended to vote for Fielder. If the hanging chad was a Corman vote, the lawyer picked up the ballot quite vigorously, so that the chad soon was no longer hanging. "You see," their guy would declare, "that voter obviously intended to vote for Corman".'

There was some embarrassed discussion in geeky circles last week about the absurdity of an advanced technological society electing its leaders by punching holes in processed wood pulp. Some companies were touting all-electronic gizmos. Unilect Corporation's product is called, with no apparent irony, the Patriot Voting Machine and has no fewer than 35 unique selling propositions - including, naturally, 'no hanging chads'.

Some people have been arguing that the time has come to move over to online voting. But for every critic who argues that it would disenfranchise the great unwired, there is a proponent claiming that it might be a way to reverse the low turnout in US presidential elections.

And of course an online electoral system would be easy meat for the Russian hackers who broke in to Microsoft. I wonder if that is why President Putin is reputed to be keen on it? For the US, you understand, not Russia.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Leon the gas guzzler
fields.standfirst: Paul Farrelly says Amerada Hess's £2.4bn Lasmo takeover sees the son take on the mantle of his audacious father
fields.trailText: Paul Farrelly says Amerada Hess's £2.4bn Lasmo takeover sees the son take on the mantle of his audacious father
fields.body:
The men from Amerada Hess have come knocking again. Fresh from squeezing British Gas out of hundreds of thousands of homes around the country, the aggressive US energy group is now taking its biggest British gamble since it helped open up the North Sea in the 1960s.

Amerada Hess's £2.4 billion takeover of Lasmo means that yet another stalwart of Britain's once-vibrant independent oil and gas exploration sector will have been snapped up by an overseas predator.

Yet this is not just another faceless US mega-corporation gobbling up every minnow in its path. The story of Amerada Hess reads like a Hollywood rendition of the great American dream. It is a rags-to-riches script of grit and determination dating from the Great Depression.

The burial of Leon Hess, the company's 85-year-old founder, last year, marked more than just the passing of yet another fabulously rich tycoon (his wealth was put at $720 million). It was a farewell to the last in a long line of great US oilmen, whose ranks included John D Rockefeller, John Paul Getty and the now disgraced Armand Hammer.

The son of Jewish Lithuanian immigrants, Hess started out in the oil business in 1933, taking over the struggling New Jersey door-to-door delivery round begun by his father, a kosher butcher by trade. At 18, selling fuel oil at four cents a gallon seemed to have brighter prospects than digging up clams or any of the sharp-witted youngster's other schemes to turn a buck.

Today the trademark toy tankers issued by the firm every Christmas hark back to the 615-gallon second-hand Chevrolet truck with which Hess started out. Old mint-condition models fetch up to $5,000 apiece, a far cry from the $24.60 Hess first had to scrabble together. 'Everyone was broke then,' he once said. 'I had to pay for the truck before I delivered the oil.'

By 1938, Hess Oil was running a fleet of 12 trucks and its self-effacing but highly motivated owner had also built his first oil storage depot in New Jersey. During the Second World War he supplied petrol to General George Patton before returning to build Hess Oil's chain of green-and-white liveried petrol stations into one of the most familiar features of America's East Coast. Last year, by the time he died, the firm was running 630 retail stations, in New York, New Jersey and Florida, and clocking up $7bn in sales and $440m in profits.

Hess, a shrewd negotiator and political cultivator (he was a major donor to the Democrats), also relished a corporate scrap. The Amerada oil and gas exploration side came into the business after a hostile bid battle with rival Phillips Petroleum in 1969. The firm was set up in 1919 by an Englishman, Sir Wheetman Dickson Pearson, who later became Lord Cowdray. An amalgamation of 'America' and 'Canada', Amerada first drilled for oil in Oklahoma in the 1920s. The venture also bore the unusual distinction of being nationalised by Tory Winston Churchill in the 1940s and privatised by Labour's Harold Wilson in the 1960s.

Hess had already arrived in Britain before snapping up Labour's first state sell-off, however. In 1964, a year after buying the New York Jets football team, the publicity-shy tycoon joined a consortium with Amoco, British Gas and Texas Eastern to take part in the first UK licensing round in the North Sea.

Now, even before the Lasmo deal, Amerada Hess is the third-largest oil and gas producer in the UK behind BP Amoco and Shell, with interests in 35 fields and sales of $1.7bn last year. Since 1996, when the domestic gas market was opened up to competition, Amerada has become a growing rival to its erstwhile ally British Gas, and has now moved into electricity, too.

'The UK is already crucially important to us and, with Lasmo, will continue to be,' an Amerada Hess spokesman said. 'We are pioneering floating production systems, like the new Triton field in the North Sea, and prospecting in the deep waters around the Faroes.'

John Hess, now the firm's 45-year-old chief executive, could not have had a more different upbringing from his father. Educated at Harvard, he is a product of the Ivy League, with the obligatory MBA, who also speaks Arabic, Farsi, Spanish and French. He joined Amerada Hess in 1976 as a graduate trainee and, the only son among three children, took over the helm in 1995.

That was the second time the firm's autocratic patriarch had retired. His first comeback, at the tender age of 72, took place in 1986, when Amerada Hess cut a fifth of its workforce, skipped its dividend and took a $430m write-down against its shipping fleet in a depressed oil sector. During the latest roller-coaster ride of the oil price (Amerada lost $460m in 1998), the founder remained chairman of the executive committee right up to his death.

So why Lasmo and why now for Amerada Hess's biggest deal since the 1969 merger? 'We're always looking, but Lasmo only became available in the last few months,' a spokesman said. 'And it fits very well. They have assets where Amerada wants to be.' It also pushes the group into the oil world's top 10 for the first time.

Lasmo, the old London & Scottish Marine Oil, has had a lousy time since it narrowly escaped a hostile bid from UK rival Enterprise in 1994. Fresh talks foundered again last year as the two could not agree a vision for the future. Lasmo had tottered after overpaying in splashing out £1bn on Ultramar in 1991. Of late, it has made the same mistakes again, paying a pricey £550m for Monument Oil & Gas last year and a high £300m entry fee to get into Venezuela two years before.

It is Lasmo's South American assets, plus its exposure to the North Sea, the Caspian, Asia, Algeria and Libya, which most interests Amerada. The deal pushes the boundaries without paying over the odds - just $5.49 for every barrel of Lasmo's reserves and this would certainly have pleased Hess Senior. He once emerged from talks in Libya, at which one of Muammar Gadaffy's aides pulled a gun, saying he wasn't the slightest bit fazed.

The younger Hess, however, doesn't get to enjoy all his father's fringe benefits. The old man won the Superbowl just once - in 1969 - with the Jets and saw his life's pas sion come within one game of making the final again just four months before he died.

In his will, however, he stipulated that on pain of having their inheritance cut by 25 per cent none of his family should get involved in the Jets. Instead, the team was to be sold. So, the burden of healing the team's wounded pride rests, rather appropriately, with the new owner: Robert Wood Johnson IV, heir to the Johnson & Johnson healthcare fortune.

webTitle: The Government cannot bury the problem of nuclear waste storage

fields.headline: Timebomb under our feet
fields.standfirst: The Government cannot bury the problem of nuclear waste storage.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: The Government cannot bury the problem of nuclear waste storage. Oliver Morgan reports
fields.body:
An intriguing parliamentary question will be answered tomorrow in the House of Lords. Tabled by the Labour peer Lord Winston, it reads: 'To ask Her Majesty's Government what is their policy on the management of nuclear waste.'

Winston, chairman of the Lords Science and Technology select committee, is hoping for a comprehensive answer. Nearly two years ago, the committee published a report detailing some of the intractable problems raised by the storage of materials that remain radioactive for thousands, even millions of years.

The report did not suggest a specific site, but the creation of institutions to oversee the process. It tackled such issues as whether waste placed in a repository should be retrievable or buried for ever - arguing for the former. The Government has not produced a detailed response.

The timing of Winston's question is what lends it intrigue. Since March 1997, when the Conservative Environment Secretary John Gummer blocked plans from radioactive waste handler Nirex to construct a test lab for a deep underground store at Sellafield in Cumbria, the Government has not had a policy on long-term management of waste. A Green Paper on the issue was scheduled for summer last year; there is still no sign of it.

Winston hopes - though says he does not know - that his question will trigger the publication of the paper. He said: 'It is always frustrating to the chairman of a select committee if serious recommendations are thoughtfully made and there is not much evidence of them being implemented or examined fully. It does seem as though we are in that situation.'

Too right. Throughout the summer DETR officials drafted and redrafted and agonised over publishing. After the Nirex fiasco - blamed on a fatal pre-judgment of the method of disposal and the potential geographical sites of a repository - the issue has become so sensitive that part of the purpose of a Labour Green Paper would be to consult on methods of reaching a decision rather than on the decision itself.

The party conference season focused minds on eliminating political risks in advance of a possible spring election and by the autumn officials were indicating that radioactive waste was judged too politically sensitive. This view has resonance among some Labour backbenchers. One MP who follows nuclear issues closely said last week: 'It would be sensible to shelve it until after the election. Opposition candidates will whip up fears about government plans for waste dumps in any constituency with the remotest link to the nuclear industry.'

But recent unofficial hints from DETR suggest that there may be greater political problems from delaying publication of the paper than from disclosure.

What has prompted such a reassessment of the risks? Nuclear industry insiders point to a surprising change in Conservative policy last month - possibly the result of lobbying by BNFL - which broke a decade-long political taboo over discussing new nuclear power stations by stating they may offer a solution to global warming and reduce over-dependence on gas.

Then in a Commons debate on 8 November, senior Labour figures including former 'Cabinet enforcer' Jack Cunningham and Trade and Industry Select Committee chairman Martin O'Neill argued for future nuclear plants. Cunningham, whose constituency contains Sellafield, said: 'I would love to see it happen.'

This places the onus on Ministers to explain how to combat the long-term rise of carbon dioxide without building new nuclear stations. DETR figures predict that UK carbon dioxide emissions will fall from 1990 levels (168 million tonnes of carbon) to 152.2 million in 2000, but will rise again after 2010.

Last month Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers said power companies must increase their renewable energy use to 10 per cent by 2010.

But there are credibility problems. As O'Neill said in the Commons debate: 'The attractions of alternative forms of generation have probably been exaggerated. I therefore think we ignore the nuclear element at our peril.'

The difficulty for the Government is that it cannot address one link in the nuclear chain without preparing cast-iron positions on the others - including the reprocessing of the spent fuel by British Nuclear Fuels, and final disposal.

It does not have fully developed policies on either. Government plans for BNFL - involving sale of a 49 per cent stake in a public-private partnership - have been delayed by questions over the future of reprocessing and the extent of long-term liabilities for decommissioning.

The BNFL situation is complicated by waste disposal issues that would be examined in the Green Paper. At the centre of the question is plutonium, the hazardous by-product of nuclear fission.

The House of Lords report noted that Britain, which reprocesses fuel from other countries including Japan and Germany, will hold about 100 tonnes, or two thirds of global plutonium stocks, by 2010. Proliferation and security concerns, along with scepticism over the military and commercial need for plutonium, led the committee to urge that all but a strategic reserve be declared waste, and soon, so that storage implications could be calculated.

Another problem is caused by spent fuel delivered by BNFL's overseas customers, which is separated into three waste streams by reprocessing - low-level (LLW), intermediate (ILW) and high level (HLW) - before being returned.

BNFL argues that the UK should keep some extra ILW and LLW as a substitute for small amounts of extra HLW being sent back. It believes this has environmental benefits through reduced shipments, and is a commercial opportunity. Environmental campaigners, however, believe allowing substitution would turn Britain into a 'global nuclear dustbin'.

Current policy is that ILW and HLW should be returned in the absence of a UK repository. The House of Lords report said this should be changed to allow substitution. It also urged the Government to produce a Green Paper addressing these issues. But the commercial implications of decisions on plutonium, substitution and the consequent impact on reprocessing have caused bitter arguments between DETR and DTI - whose PPP plans depend on a 'bankable' commercial future for BNFL.

These sensitivities are reflected in drafts of what is a very Green Paper. The document makes clear that the treatment of plutonium is a crucial and commercial issue, and that a decision should be taken now.

The paper does not make the decision itself and asks for views. It reproduces arguments by BNFL that it will lose out on about'£300 million in lost premiums and future contracts' if substitution is not allowed. It forecasts a reduction in waste shipments and a decrease in the amount of HLW to be managed - although there would be an increase in ILW.

It also sets out arguments from nuclear generator British Energy that attack the economics of reprocessing spent fuel, saying it is more expensive than long-term storage. BE demands the right to decide on the most economic option for disposal of its spent fuel in future - which would both undermine reprocessing and create alarm that a private company was effectively running nuclear policy.

Inter-departmental tensions are matched by wider electoral concerns. For this reason the Green Paper is expected to treat the issues of retrievability and site selection with ultra-sensitivity. It will be interesting to see if these views are made public soon. But even if they are, the tone of the paper may not satisfy those who believe waste disposal solutions get more difficult the longer they are delayed.

As O'Neill said in the Commons debate: 'The attractions of alternative forms of generation have probably been exaggerated. I therefore think we ignore the nuclear element at our peril.' The difficulty for the Government is that it cannot address one link in the nuclear chain without preparing cast-iron positions on the others - including the reprocessing of the spent fuel by British Nuclear Fuels, and final disposal. It does not have fully developed policies on either. Government plans for BNFL - involving sale of a 49 per cent stake in a public-private partnership - have been delayed by questions over the future of reprocessing and the extent of long-term liabilities for decommissioning. The BNFL situation is complicated by waste disposal issues that would be examined in the Green Paper. At the centre of the question is plutonium, the hazardous by-product of nuclear fission. The House of Lords report noted that Britain, which reprocesses fuel from other countries including Japan and Germany, will hold about 100 tonnes, or two thirds of global plutonium stocks, by 2010. Proliferation and security concerns, along with scepticism over the military and commercial need for plutonium, led the committee to urge that all but a strategic reserve be declared waste, and soon, so that storage implications could be calculated. Another problem is caused by spent fuel delivered by BNFL's overseas customers, which is separated into three waste streams by reprocessing - low-level (LLW), intermediate (ILW) and high level (HLW) - before being returned. BNFL argues that the UK should keep some extra ILW and LLW as a substitute for small amounts of extra HLW being sent back. It believes this has environmental benefits through reduced shipments, and is a commercial opportunity. Environmental campaigners, however, believe allowing substitution would turn Britain into a 'global nuclear dustbin'. Current policy is that ILW and HLW should be returned in the absence of a UK repository. The House of Lords report said this should be changed to allow substitution. It also urged the Government to produce a Green Paper addressing these issues. But the commercial implications of decisions on plutonium, substitution and the consequent impact on reprocessing have caused bitter arguments between DETR and DTI - whose PPP plans depend on a 'bankable' commercial future for BNFL. These sensitivities are reflected in drafts of what is a very Green Paper. The document makes clear that the treatment of plutonium is a crucial and commercial issue, and that a decision should be taken now. The paper does not make the decision itself and asks for views. It reproduces arguments by BNFL that it will lose out on about'£300 million in lost premiums and future contracts' if substitution is not allowed. It forecasts a reduction in waste shipments and a decrease in the amount of HLW to be managed - although there would be an increase in ILW. It also sets out arguments from nuclear generator British Energy that attack the economics of reprocessing spent fuel, saying it is more expensive than long-term storage. BE demands the right to decide on the most economic option for disposal of its spent fuel in future - which would both undermine reprocessing and create alarm that a private company was effectively running nuclear policy. Inter-departmental tensions are matched by wider electoral concerns. For this reason the Green Paper is expected to treat the issues of retrievability and site selection with ultra-sensitivity. It will be interesting to see if these views are made public soon. But even if they are, the tone of the paper may not satisfy those who believe waste disposal solutions get more difficult the longer they are delayed. oliver.morgan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Plasma screens at the pub are pulling in the punters and the profits

fields.headline: Drinking to the future
fields.standfirst: Plasma screens at the pub are pulling in the punters and the profits, says  Nic King
fields.trailText: Plasma screens at the pub are pulling in the punters and the profits, says Nic King
fields.body:
Pull up a stool at the bar of The Lamprey in Gloucester and you can tell you've stepped into the pub of the future. It's a place where the drinks are cool, the crowd is frisky and return on investment is, literally, on tap.

It's a young, lunchtime crowd of mainly business customers. Three-and-a-half foot wide plasma screens hang on the walls, showing a continuous mix of adverts and videos of extreme sports such as hang-gliding. The regulars are surfing the web, clustered around the free internet stations. And there's a new buzz above the steady sound of chatter over lunch and a pint.

The world of e-business is coming to a pub near you. The Lamprey and a dozen other pubs around the country are taking part in a pilot project that threatens to change a visit to the local forever. Especially those locals with an 18-30 crowd - because all of this, if you hadn't guessed, is in the name of winning a larger share of the twentysomethings' spending power.

Advertisers know that 18- to 30-year-olds are notoriously difficult to reach. They're too busy working hard or playing hard to watch TV or read magazines. They go to the cinema, but only once a month, on average. You're more likely to catch them with a glass in their hand - they visit a bar or a pub twice a week on average. Once there, they are fickle in their drinking tastes, as likely to switch allegiance from Bacardi Breezer to Smirnoff Ice, from Bud to Becks, if that's what's hot with their friends. But they have high - and highly sought after - discretionary income.

This venture aims to solve the advertisers' quandary by targeting eyeballs of the twentysomethings while they're having fun. The package includes point-of-sale monitoring at the tills, so there's an almost instant measure of the effect on sales of advertised brands.

Translucis, the company behind the venture, is backed to the tune of more than £5 million by Diageo, the company formed from Guinness and Grand Metropolitan. Their top people come mainly from Diageo and are drinks industry veterans. This is one of the new breed of 'clicks and mortar' e-business projects backed by a combination of industry know-how and the deep pockets of a market leader.

The plan, says Liz Paxton, Translucis's commercial director, is to install systems in pubs that attract crowds of 800 or more on a busy night. The package consists of plasma screens, internet connections and point-of-sale software. Translucis sells airtime to advertisers and broadcasts the ads and entertainment content over satellite links to the pubs. Participating publicans can choose what they want to show and take a share of the advertising revenue. They will see a swift return according to Paxton, quoting the example of a three-screen package costing around £18,000 with a payback period of between a year and 18 months. Internet access also provides the publican with services like previewing videos of bands and booking them for live gigs, a kind of intranet for the licensed trade.

But the key feature is the link between the screens and the tills. What really interests the advertisers, of course, is the impact their ads are having on drink sales. The main benefit of the system is that it tells them precisely how much their brand's exposure on screen is doing for sales - at which till in which pub. It's the kind of test marketing that they could only achieve in the past by comparing the results of different ads in different TV regions.

A ready reckoner supplied as part of the package helps publicans work out how quick a payback they'll receive from their share of the advertising revenue. So far, the licensees say the system is looking like a promising investment.

'It's a powerful tool,' claims Jamie Anderson, proprietor of Café Latino in London's Soho. As soon as the screens started showing ads for Red Bull, says Anderson, 'you could tell the next day - sales were up'. He says his customers like the buzz of rapidly changing content on the screens.

'Its right there, in their faces. There are people jumping off mountains on bikes and people canoeing down waterfalls,' he explains. Anderson says it's unlikely his customers would want to watch sports such as soccer but they enjoy the mixture of adverts and entertainment the system offers. The bottom line is that he's had a better month since it was installed and he's planning to keep it.

As with many e-business projects, it is difficult to pin down the overall impact on takings, but the signs are that adding entertainment and interactivity to the retail experience does persuade us to part with more cash.

Back at The Lamprey, the regulars are voting with their pay packets. Ross Andrews, assistant manager, says the screens are leading to changing drinking habits. Hardly any of his regulars used to drink Sol. Now that they've started seeing the ads on the plasma screens, he says, they're drinking their way through seven crates a week.

High street traders take on the e-tailers at their own game

With many of the online e-tailers falling down badly on fulfilment of orders, the traditional 'bricks and mortar' businesses are taking the fight to the e-tailers' own battleground, adding interactivity to the retail experience. It is difficult to put figures on the impact of this, but top retailers claim there is a significant pay-off.

Debenhams claims its internet-based wedding gift service, available on in-store screens as well as at home, now has 25 per cent of the wedding gift market and is used by more than 25,000 couples a year. The list is updated as soon as a guest buys a gift, to avoid duplication.

Waitrose says Quick Check, its service giving shoppers a running total of what they are spending and allowing them to skip checkout queues, is an important factor in the company's climb up the food chain.

And Waterstone's says screens at the entrance to its stores achieve outstanding success in promoting the latest titles. Clare Minett, duty manager at Waterstone's in Piccadilly, says 'hand on heart' that sales of The Birth of a Legend , the recent biography of Muhammad Ali, took off when it was promoted with on-screen videos of his fights.

We haven't gone quite as far as the Americans - yet. At the Forum shopping mall in Las Vegas, shoppers are greeted by animatronic Roman gods while the lost city of Atlantis rises and falls on the hour, every hour. Tellingly, the mall achieves sales per square foot four times the US national average.

But can it be long before a visit to the supermarket is accompanied by a soundbite from Jamie or Nigella to whet your appetite at the fish counter?

webTitle: Dome slapstick kicks off the panto season

fields.headline: Dome slapstick kicks off the panto season
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward: The pantomime season seems to have started early this year. And the biggest show in town - the one under the tent in Greenwich - has come under fire from numerous critics
fields.body:
The pantomime season seems to have started early this year. And the biggest show in town - the one under the tent in Greenwich - has come under fire from numerous critics.

Last week, the panto resorted to desperate tactics when it tried turning itself into a French farce. Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the impresario once ostensibly in charge of the Dome, declared his interest in buying the tent if no one else wanted to.

This injection of surrealism was followed by news that the Government was to postpone until next week at the earliest a decision on whether the Legacy consortium will get the chance to run the show. In the middle of all this, Robin Young, permanent secretary at the Department of Culture, apologised to MPs for not telling Parliament that the directors of the New Millennium Experience Company were given special indemnities that meant they were not liable for up to £200 million in debts.

So the 'sorry' list now reads: Young, Bob Ayling, the ex-NMEC chairman, and a half-muttered apology from the Prime Minister's official spokesman. But one person who doesn't seem to be too keen on saying sorry is NMEC's sole shareholder, Lord Falconer. Despite numerous calls for one of the PM's closest allies to go, Falconer displays few signs of contrition. Like all good panto characters, he has a catchphrase: 'I was only the shareholder, I wasn't responsible for the mess.'

But this argument won't wash. Falconer actually had a very hands-on executive role, making crucial decisions in running the Dome. He attended the majority of NMEC board meetings, including that of 11 November, when the threat of a mounting financial crisis first emerged. At this meeting it was decided that the best response to this threat was to establish a budget sub-committee chaired by Ayling.

Shockingly, the committee never formally met, and at the very least Falconer as, presumably, a concerned shareholder, should have asked why. It was Falconer, too, who took responsibility for the look of some of the zones in the Dome - hardly hands-off.

Falconer must have breathed a sigh of relief earlier this month when what could have been the panto's biggest critic, the National Audit Office, delivered its verdict on the Dome. But the report, while damning about the lack of procedures established to oversee the Dome's finances, did not say much about how they came to be so poor in the first place.

Interestingly, the report audits the Dome's performance only for the past 12 months - despite the fact that it rightly says it needs to refer to the past to set everything in context. The important point is that the report only 'refers' to the past - it doesn't audit it. Semantics? No, this crucial decision defining the remit of the report meant that the Government's role before the Dome was opened to the public was not examined. The catalogue of errors throughout 1998 and 1999 that resulted in the Government's failure to create a suitable structure to oversee such a complex, ambitious project will never come under scrutiny.

So, instead, perhaps after this week's surreal events there is a need for a surreal suggestion. Lord Falconer must resist all further calls for his resignation. He must remain to become what the Government is scrambling to prevent the Dome from being: a testimony to what happens when hubris goes unchecked. He's behind you, Tony.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: While attention is on Abbey National as the next focus for consolidation in banking, it would be unwise to ignore its great rival, Halifax.
fields.body:
While attention is on Abbey National as the next focus for consolidation in banking, it would be unwise to ignore its great rival, Halifax.

Halifax is now worth less than Abbey, yet it has a higher share of the mortgage market and little in the way of Abbey's huge diversification away from personal finance.

For a prospective partner, therefore, Halifax is arguably a far cleaner deal than Abbey. Certainly it would make as much, if not more, sense as an alternative option for Bank of Scotland. Lloyds TSB would not face the extensive 'rape and pillage' scenario as it does with shedding Abbey's non-mortgage activities.

Remember, too, that Halifax once spurned a merger of equals with Barclays.

Under chief executive James Crosby, Halifax has so far shown no outward signs of wanting to give up its independence. Crosby has a strong following in the City but, after Abbey, expect it to be next to come under scrutiny. Already there are murmurs, for example, about the sense of Halifax going after current accounts in a big way when it could have merged with a clearer that had them in abundance.At 587p, the shares are a buy.

Creaky Croda

Last week's management buyout of Peter Black Holdings, the private label cosmet ics supplier, is another reminder that low valuations in unfashionable sectors mean a steady string of bids and that public-to-private deals are on the way.

One related firm that really could do with such a boost is Croda International, the skincare, cosmetics and speciality chemicals outfit.

At 226p, Croda shares have had a miserable time lately, and, trading at 12 times forecast earnings, are not especially cheap without bid action. But many of the likely buyers, Laporte or ICI for instance, have either shifted focus or are hamstrung by problems of their own.

Croda chairman Keith Hopkins has just delivered his other outfit, Ellis & Everard, up to a Dutch bid but Croda's top brass are thought not to be too keen to sell out. Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has just downgraded its earnings forecasts for 2001 and 2002.

Avoid for the moment.

Hidden power

Take a look at Renold, the power transmission and machine tools group. At 85p, the shares are at rock-bottom, despite interim results last week well above analysts' expectations.

The present price means that Renold shares are trading at just 6.4 times current year earnings and are well below net asset value.

Broker UB Warburg, for one, believes the low valuation to be unwarranted and has just upgraded its investment stance to 'buy' from 'hold'. Orders, the broker points out, are buoyant and the management is confident of further growth in the second half of the year.

UBS Warburg is sticking with its 115p price target for the shares, which means it sees 35 per cent upside potential. Buy.

End of the line?

THE FIRM may well be running into the buffers, but don't give up on GB Railways just yet. Last week, the Aim-quoted minnow of the UK rail industry warned that slower, less frequent services following the Hatfield rail crash may well cause it cashflow problems in the new year.

It said it was in talks with the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority over the future of its East Anglian rail franchise, which runs until 2004.

Our industry moles tell us the firm is talking to potential bidders about an outright rescue or surrendering its UK franchise. The latter course would leave it with freight management expertise and a stake in Australia's Great Southern Railway.

At 49p, the shares are a speculative hold.

fields.headline: Journey's end for the king of the costas?
fields.standfirst: After years at the top, David Crossland, the pioneering Airtours boss, should now get away from it all - or so say his City critics
fields.trailText: After years at the top, David Crossland, the pioneering Airtours boss, should now get away from it all - or so say his City critics
fields.body:
Life is no beach for holiday boss David Crossland. While the 13 million customers of his Airtours group are reclining on the sand, his share price has halved in the last year and the City wants answers.

The Lancashire lad who built what until recently was the world's biggest holiday business from scratch has tumbled from stock market darling to scapegoat.

With an estimated £400 million family fortune, houses in Jersey and Aspen, a private jet and world-record levels of workaholism, Crossland should be basking at the pinnacle of his career, or planning early retirement. Instead he is working sweatshop hours in Germany, trying to shore up a loss-making acquisition. And this week, after two warnings, he will have to explain to shareholders why underlying group profitability for 1999-2000 has slumped to around £90m, compared with £156m in the previous year. Staff share options are under water.

If that was not grim enough, the legendary predator has been turned into prey, and observers are urging him to do his last deal - not buying this time, but selling out.

People close to Crossland describe him as unique, and explain how some of the principal entrepreneurial qualities that transformed him from zero to hero are now working against him and his firm. Several senior executives out of a swathe that have abandoned Airtours in the last two years have told The Observer they became disillusioned with the company but certainly not with Crossland (who has made them all millionaires). One said: 'He is absolutely unbelievable. I have never known someone in such a senior position stay so close to the minutiae of the business.

'When I first introduced myself to him he instantly regaled me with more facts about my previous companies than I knew myself. And he will spot almost instinctively the one figure that is wrong on a balance sheet.'

Crossland is famous for getting up at 4am and working like a Trojan, even on 'holiday' - something he rarely took until recently, despite being in the travel business. Colleagues say he is ruthless in meetings, swiftly rooting out waffle or ignorance with a sharp cry of 'bullshit!' in the direction of any hapless executive who has dared sound a millimetre off the ball.

But he does not lose his temper and is described as showing a humbleness rare in big business, an asset it is said his more bumptious lieutenants have lacked over the years. The ex-Airtours executive said: 'When I was going to leave it was David who fought hardest to persuade me to stay, when others below him let their egos get in the way. David knows the business is bigger than him and complacency is a killer.

'Whereas others have come along who share his hard edge, many lack his incredible passion for every last detail of the business - he can be really intimidating but is also the best motivator I have ever worked for.'

Crossland has described his best day in management as the day he floated Airtours in 1987. Close associates say his unfulfilled ambition is to see Airtours in the FTSE 100 index of leading shares. It was pretty close at about 110 18 months ago, and would have pushed in if he had succeeded in forming a £3 billion group with the hostile takeover - blocked by the European Commission - of rival First Choice last year.

But with Airtours' current market capitalisation at £1.1bn that is now a fantasy and the group could well end up in foreign hands some time in the next year.

Management issues aside, Crossland has described the best day of his life as 13 August 1963, the day when, having left Burnley Grammar School at 16 with three O-levels, he was given his first job making tea in a travel agency.

He got his big break in 1972 when an elderly couple sold him their two travel agency shops. His brother-in-law lent him half the money and he borrowed the rest from the bank - selling a holiday to the bank manager as he clinched the loan.

He did the same with his wife Anne, and loves telling how they met. She came into one of his agencies more than 20 years ago and he asked her out to dinner. 'But not before I'd sold her a holiday and taken the money,' he boasts.

In the decade after 1972 Crossland scooped up almost 20 agencies and began putting together travel packages. He was carrying almost 250,000 people a year in the early Eighties and formed Airtours International as a charter airline as business grew.

The first was lingering question marks over the quality of the product - the price was always tempting, but compared to solid market leader Thomson Holidays or smaller players such as Cosmos, the complaint rate from unhappy Airtours customers was a dodgy 8 per cent.

The second was the question of whether Airtours would survive or implode under the pressure of 'pile it high, sell it cheap' tactics as it expanded in great leaps in the early Nineties on the back of other failures in this notoriously volatile industry.

When Harry Goodman's International Leisure Group (ILG) collapsed spectacularly in 1991, Crossland swooped. An insider recalls: 'Before anyone could blink David hired a Lear jet and, overnight, dropped contractors in all the major holiday resorts in Europe to buy up ILG's hotel beds.' In only a year, Airtours' capacity tripled to around 600,000 packages a year.

In the early years, Crossland used to travel overseas with at least one suitcase full of hard cash 'just in case he needed to do a deal'. Then he bought the agency chains Pickfords and Hogg Robinson and transformed them into the 800-strong Going Places chain. By the mid-Nineties, when the business was still growing so fast the City wondered if it would follow ILG, Crossland made an emphatic move. The insider said: 'He had the sense to realise price was not everything. We ditched a lot of the worst-sell ing hotels and made a culture change to improve quality.'

Airtours began its next wave of expansion, both of product and geography. Crossland bought the leading travel business in Scandinavia, then left Thomson standing with acquisitions in Belgium, Holland, the US, Canada and a partnership with US cruise giant Carnival.

He expanded into long-haul holidays and bought cruise ships. But he has been outflanked since Thomson was bought by German leader Preussag earlier this year for £1.8bn.. A potential partner, German number two C&N, shunned Crossland's asking price of £5 a share and now seems keener on buying Thomas Cook than Airtours. Now commentators fear Crossland will be left behind in the European size game. They worry about losses in his businesses in North America, an expected £100m deficit at the Frosch Touristic subsidiary in Germany, and a sense of drift at Airtours since it failed to buy First Choice last year, despite a solid summer performance in the UK.

Critics say Airtours has missed Crossland's sure touch as he took half a step back in the last year and handed over to his new protege Tim Byrne. But fans say Crossland is an 'industry icon' and his mix of graft and magic will find a solution yet.

Born: 18 December 1946

Job: Chairman, Airtours

Other directorships: Carnival Corporation

Hobbies: Skiing in Aspen, Colorado, with wife Anne, their children and grandchildren

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Short Piers
fields.body:
Short Piers

The first rule of email is never, ever send anything that can come back to haunt you. And the first rule of business is never take your personal life into work.

On both counts it seems beleaguered Mirror editor Piers Morgan has failed. Morgan is fidgety about an imminent DTI hearing into the share-tipping Mirrorgate scandal thanks to jobsworth DTI officials seizing emails showing just what a keen interest he took in equities.

But Piers also contributed to the sad demise of his virtual friend, Sun gossip hackette Marina Hyde, who last month was frogmarched out of Wapping for emailing the enthusiastic share trader.

Which brings us to the bringing your personal life into work. Last Friday's Mirror editorial took a somewhat personal line. 'Email has created a whole new breed of ghastly snoopers,' intoned the Voice of the Mirror. And just who are these ghastly people? None other than people 'who sneekily read private memos sent by their employees to friends or family when there is no commercial sensitivity involved'.

The only thing Diary can't work out is who the devil this venom is aimed at - the DTI or Mekon of the Sun? Read between the lines of the solemn editorial and it becomes clear, however: 'The bald truth is that private emails should stay just that.'

Something for the weekend?

Now a DTI investigation is obviously something that would make many people anxious. It is a stressful event and some people could be forgiven for feeling concerned about the outcome. It could even be assumed that in certain cases there might arise a concern for one's own personal safety. But Diary is somewhat alarmed to learn just how concerned for his safety Morgan has now become.

A couple of weeks ago Morgan visited himself on Prague with top hack mate Andy Coulson, the deputy ed of the News of the Screws, to celebrate Coulson's impending marriage. There are many things thrusting roister-doisterers take on stag weekends: handcuffs, wigs, celebrity masks, cameras and, um, protection. But the Coulson party took this latter requisite somewhat literally. Throughout the entire duration of the stag weekend Morgan and co enjoyed the protection of two bodyguards wherever they went in the notoriously rough capital.

Cook the book

Lindsay Cook, managing editor of the Express and a woman described in this month's Spectator as 'bossy, judgmental and humourless' (there were other adjectives but Diary is running out of space) had the bright idea a couple of years ago of introducing a revolutionary pay-off for any editorial staff made redundant. If they found alternative employment within the allotted redundancy period they had to return the cash to their former employer. Given that the Hinduja Brothers and the Daily Mail & General Trust, the two leading bidders for the Express , have said they will replace the paper's executive staff, the paper's management must now be hoping Cook secures a somewhat better deal for them.

fields.headline: Commuting a life sentence
fields.standfirst: People spend hours getting to the office. Neasa MacErlean on ways of easing the burden
fields.trailText: People spend hours getting to the office. Neasa MacErlean on ways of easing the burden
fields.body:
In the days of the communist bloc, we used to watch television pictures of housewives queueing for bread and feel sorry for anyone who had to waste two hours a day on something so fruitless. Those same women could surely look at us now and wonder why so many people spend two hours a day just getting to and from work.

The average worker in central London spends 110 minutes a day commuting, according to the Government's Transport Statistics. Although the average national commute is 50 minutes a day, there are many people who are spending three or four hours daily in this way. And many people are finding that short distances are becoming more difficult: travelling seven miles in London can easily take 90 minutes.

Recent train delays and flooding have made the problems of antiquated infrastructures far worse.'The situation is going to continue to be quite difficult,' says Andrew Smith, national director of the Rail Passengers Council. 'We're looking five years ahead before people will notice a difference.' In fact, with a 6 per cent annual increase in passenger journeys - reaching about 2 million journeys a day - overcrowding on trains could deteriorate.

Lack of investment in the London Underground would see major disruption continuing on the Tube. 'The situation is going to get worse before it gets better,' says Irving Yass of London First, a group representing London employers. Problems that sound as if they should be relatively small - such as the poor functioning of escalators - are bringing months of frustration to passengers at King's Cross, Moorgate and other important stops. Different problems that have been kept out of the spotlight could also come to the fore. The rising water table in London means that pumps have to be continuously employed to ensure that large parts of the Tube network are not flooded.

On the road, the country's 17 million car commuters are also facing greater congestion, weather and parking problems. Plans to restrict parking in some city centres could push those workers back on to rail - if they can get to stations. And many commuters who used to drive part-way and then take a train are now being thwarted by local parking restrictions banning all drivers apart from local residents. 'The number of places you can park free is diminishing by the day,' says Mike Johnson of the AA. 'Paid parking schemes are a good means for councils to make up their revenue.'

Long working hours are made worse by long commuting periods. And these are made worse still by the potential health hazards of overcrowded or stressful travelling. Being pushed up against people with germinating flu viruses makes you more likely to get the flu. 'This is an unresearched area,' says Anthony Smith. 'We've got very little idea of the effects of overcrowding [on trains on the spread of viruses].'

So what are the options for the future? Will commuting ever become a pleasure again? Many schemes and ideas are forthcoming - even if John Prescott has not yet managed to add much impetus. An increase in capacity would improve many pressing rail problems, according to the Rail Passengers Council.

It is calling for greater investment in signalling; more passing loops to develop alternative routes to busy tracks; the expansion of the lines at London Bridge, Victoria, Waterloo and other 'choke points'; more frequent services (so frequent that the timetable could be abandoned in a few years' time and replaced with trains at, perhaps, 15 minute intervals in some areas); longer trains; new lines (such as the Channel Tunnel link, which will massively increase capacity in the area); and better information (telling rail passengers about any problems with the London Underground or other connecting services before they get there).

Local communities are also contributing. A new community bus service in the Yorkshire Coalfields near Barnsley is allowing workers in an area of 35 per cent unemployment to take up jobs in call centres that were 70 per cent understaffed. Until the service started last week, the journey was uneconomic.

With the help of the Community Transport Association, about 30 Wheels to Work schemes have been developed across the country. These provide free bikes or mopeds to young people in their first six months of work or training. Linda Cox of South Shropshire council hopes to expand the local Wheels to Work initiative. 'Lack of transport shapes the whole of people's lives,' she says. 'A young person might decide against doing a course at college because they cannot get there. Or they will take a job in building because that is the only thing they can get locally.' Many other community transport schemes would also be possible if rules regulating small bus services were loosened to help the schemes employ professional drivers.

Transport 2000, the lobbying group, wants to see employers take more responsibility for encouraging 'green commuting'. Increased bicycle parking spaces and shower facilities would encourage many more workers to cycle, says spokeswoman Carey Newson. Asda, the supermarket chain, which employs 100,000, looks set to become a model company. Worried by October's fuel crisis, it decided to offer all employees cost-price bicycles from the new year and other green travel plans including ways of encouraging car-sharing.

Another option is for more people to work from home on top of the 2.5 million who already do so. Enlightened employers are increasingly trusting some staff to work some of their week there. Such arrangements could also help if the infrastructure has to deal with major health and safety checks, floods and other problems of the sort we now face.

Of course, traffic chaos and overloading can be a direct function of successful capitalism - an unwelcome side effect of an otherwise welcome phenomenon. 'When the economy is doing well, it does traditionally drive more people on to the railway,' says Smith. If job opportunities are burgeoning, many people will think it worth their while to travel to them. But the Government must help. After all, it's clearly in its interest too.

Hospital finds remedy for its transport problems

One of the largest non-teaching hospitals in Europe, Derriford Hospital in Plymouth, faced a crisis in getting staff to work when it built additional wards in 1996.

When the council refused its request for 630 new parking spaces, managers at the acute and specialist hospital set up their own transport plans.

They began encouraging car-sharing among the 5,000 staff. Nowadays, nearly 700 people participate in this scheme. They get priority parking closest to the hospital and are allowed to park free - while all non-sharers have to pay.

Bikers and motorcyclists can get interest-free loans for up to three years - £500 to buy a bike, £1,000 to get a motorbike.

A 10 per cent discount has been negotiated with a local motorcycle training company. There are special parking bays for these employees - and showers are available if they want to have a wash before starting work. But perhaps the most ambitious scheme concerns buses. Up to 44 buses an hour now stop at the hospital, the result of negotiations with the council and two local bus companies - double the number stopping in 1996.

About 450 staff have subsidised bus passes; this, again, was negotiated with the council and bus companies. The hospital has also arranged for a 'green travel pass' to be accepted on various other bus routes within a 30-mile radius and has agreed 27 per cent discounts with the operators which staff can use for leisure travel as well as commuting.

'It has worked very successfully,' says spokesman Andrew Davies. 'Staff realise why we had to introduce the scheme. We don't get many people who complain. And the benefits for staff are quite outstanding.'
