fields.headline: Faster pussycat
fields.standfirst: The Jaguar XKR eats tarmac for breakfast, but don't expect sympathy from the traffic cops
fields.trailText: The Jaguar XKR eats tarmac for breakfast, but don't expect sympathy from the traffic cops
fields.body:
Jaguar XKR

Price £67,000

MPG 22.2

Engine size 4 litres

Max speed 155mph

0-60mph 5.3 seconds

Driven wheels 2

I suppose it had to happen. I had driven up from the Costa del Sol to the City via the Channel Tunnel and M20, stopping overnight at Aracena, San Sebastian and the depths of Perigord. On the move, the Jag was only rarely travelling at less than 100mph. The fast, new roads that scythe through Spain and France are so beautifully aligned and the supercharged XKR so supremely sure and relaxed that travelling at anything less than Valkyrian speed seemed an insult to both the mechanical big cat from Coventry and the engineers who built these pan-European expressways.

What had to happen? Did I prang the Jag/finally deplete the world of its fossil-fuel reserve/decide to give up motoring for fear of floods/global warming/general guilt/speeding offences? No, I got nicked, bang-to-rights, for making a right turn on a no-right-turn sign outside King's Cross station, driving at walking pace in the teeming rain and about a mile from home. The police officer was nice enough, once we got down to a bit of a Jag talk. I think he thought I was fair game, not just because I was breaking the law but because I was slinking around in a £67,000 Jag and, in his eyes, taking a Toad-like view of the rules of the road. Anyway, it was only a 20-quid fine, so no bad feelings either way, Officer.

It did strike me, though, that the XKR is not all that suited to British roads. In its element purring along the Costa del Sol, flying straight as an arrow along European roads that make England's seem positively pre-Telford, this is a true grand tourer. And little, anti-Europe Britain is no place for grand touring; the XKR had to be held on a tight mechanical rein from journey's beginning to its end within the confines of these traffic-coned isles.

So what's a chap to do with a 370bhp, 155mph sports car but chase the sun across rainless plains, drift through high sierras and schmooze along coasts in the kind of style the Spanish love, the French most probably respect behind the supercilious sneers and even English traffic cops sneakily admire? This is one of those cars I didn't want to give back. It is a terrific performer and made friends for Jaguar wherever it went. The Mayor of Aracena enjoyed a lift back to his office. Children in the villages above Algeciras took turns to raise and lower the hood. El Jaguar (pronounce the J as H) was a much-loved beast.

When the XK8 (the XKR is the extremely powerful supercharged version) first appeared a few years back, I was critical of its shape. Too American, too bulbous, a Corvette crossed with some bloated Nissan coupé. In XKR form, with a number of small styling changes, the car looks pretty good. Low-slung, high-wheeled, a complex of Spitfire-like compound curves, fiercely feline but subtle. Just the one small, badge featuring a roaring Jaguar and the legend '4-litre Supercharged' on the prognathous bonnet and a sleek XKR below the rounded boot. The XKR is definitely a Jaguar.

I do have reservations. Please, Jaguar, get rid of the plank of mirror-finish wood veneer that looks more like a mantel shelf from a Las Vegas whorehouse than the dashboard of one of the most civilised cars on the road. Give me a set of decent gauges rather than a gimmicky navigation system. Reduce the number of gadgets in the centre console. These are so complicated that I never discovered what most of the buttons did.

As for the how fast'll-she-go-mister/signor/monsieur factor, the answer is plus vites, muy rapido. With near-imperceptible changes, the five-speed automatic gearbox transfers the iron-fist-in-velvet-glove punch of the mesmeric V8 engine into one smooth stream of blissful speed. The brakes are beyond reproach. It can be steered through curves at speeds that no machismo Spanish driver should try to emulate in a lesser machine. I drove this car along every conceivable kind of European road. It never even twitched. Don't try any of this super-fast stuff in the rain, reader, as greasy roads and oodles of power go together like New Labour ministers and the taking of responsibility for the Greenwich Dome.

Gosh, I'm sorry. Is this all getting a bit Jeremy Clarksonish? I almost expect Jonathan Porritt to lean over and say, as he did once when visiting a motor museum, 'Looking at the size of the car bonnets here, I wonder about the adequacy of the people who drive them.' I promise to back off the high-speed, gas-guzzling, Clarkson stuff, but those comments about cars with long bonnets and inadequate men are as corny as certain breakfast cereals and, in the case of Jaguars, plain wrong. The cars look like this because they are developed from Malcolm Sayer's D-Type Jag of 1954. Its supremely slippery shape enabled it to reach speeds of up to 180mph along the Mulsanne Straight on little more than 250bhp. That's a clear case of sound aerodynamics.

In fact, the XKR is as delightful a car to cruise along Mediterranean promenades - a true automotive flanneur - as it is to catapult priapically, if that's the way you think, towards the toll booths of European motorways. It is so civilised, those few design cavils aside, that it could be used as an everyday car, as long as you have a spare 67 grand and no children, or believe they should be sent on ahead by train. Essentially, though, this great British car is a magnificent toy to be savoured on high days and holidays and preferably overseas. Just remember to mind how you go on homespun roads, especially around King's Cross with a traffic cop on your tail.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Separated as toddlers, twins Stuart and Alex Lawson had very different upbringings - one lived in poverty, while the other went to boarding school. But their shared love of kick boxing has brought them together again
fields.trailText: Separated as toddlers, twins Stuart and Alex Lawson had very different upbringings - one lived in poverty, while the other went to boarding school. But their shared love of kick boxing has brought them together again.
fields.body:
Stuart Lawson: My parents divorced when we were still babies and our mother took us to Spain to live with her family. After eight months in Spain, Alex developed a hernia, so he went to England to stay with our father for treatment. I was two when he left. It was only meant to be temporary, but father ended up keeping him.

I remember standing in a desolate cold hallway in our flat in Spain looking for my twin to play with. I can't really blame my parents - maybe my Mum thought she couldn't handle any more kids and Dad felt he could only look after one.

Alex grew up with all the privileges of an only child, he got a good education and he made the best of it. But I got to grow up with an elder brother, John, who always looked out for me.

After three years in Spain, we moved to a north London council estate. We found it incredibly hard to adjust. My mother suffered terrible abuse and we were known as the little Paki boys. Urban life without money in England can be cruel. Everyday, we literally had to fight to survive.

We got into kick boxing after a streetfight. John was stabbed - it was awful - blood spurted out of his chest like a fountain. We decided we had to learn to protect ourselves.

Growing up, I always missed my twin. In our teens we started to see each other more, as we could travel independently. Alex's sport was rugby until I convinced him to join us. It was a great feeling seeing my twin enter the dojo [training area], I knew then that the sport would bring us closer together. Watching boxing matches together or comparing moves would strengthen our bond.

When John decided to set up his own kick-boxing gym, blood, sweat and tears from all of us went into making it a success. Alex and John are far more motivated than I am, they want to build an industry and be financially secure, for me security is to have a family and settle down. We don't argue much but, sometimes if we have a score to settle, the only way to do it is in the ring. We'd never fight each other in a proper competition, though, the bond is too close. It has to be genetic that all three of us fight the way we do. Alex and I never really lived together, so it must be in our blood.

Alex Lawson: I did feel isolated growing up away from my brothers, especially my twin. I'd yearn for the holidays so I could see them again. After we'd spent time together, I would always be the one who had to leave, I never understood why and I would always pine for a few days after.

From the age of 13, I attended a boarding school in Surrey. It was difficult knowing my brothers were having a tough time on that estate. There was a stage when I started to blame myself. I used to feel guilty for having had a private education, nice holidays and a big bedroom to myself, but I had no control over my youth.

Once I'd left boarding school, I saw my brothers much more. When I started training, our relationship grew much stronger. It was a difficult time because it was then that I realised what I'd missed out on for so many years. Now I can tell Stuart anything. There's a good balance in our relationship, we're comfortable with each other - I relax as soon as I see him.

Our personalities are reflected in the ring: Stuart has a real ruthlessness, he can be a beast. He'll knock opponents down and laugh at them, while I'll run to the corner and feel concerned. All of us are well respected on the kick-boxing circuit and, I suppose, sometimes feared. Opponents will opt to fight a Lawson brother if they've got something to prove.

I do want to emulate my brothers' success in the ring, both have been world champions. Sometimes I worry that coming from a different background to my brothers, I don't have the same hunger, drive and commitment that they had to push them to the top. I'd never fight my brothers professionally, though, because one of us is going to lose.

Setting up my own gym was something that I felt I needed to do. I was itching for the challenge of a varied workload; managing a team and taking on my own responsibility. Our childhood was difficult, but we've got through it, now I'm just grateful that we all work in the same industry and get on as well as we do.

fields.headline: Things can only get pettier
fields.trailText:
press
Will Buckley on the seedier side of the press-club relationship.
fields.body:
Chairman takes exception to something hack has written, hack gets ideas above station and isn't properly contrite. Chairman, in high dudgeon, orders hack never to darken doors of his ground again. It's a story as old as the hills but in the news again as Sir Alex Ferguson takes on Match of the Day magazine, and, realising that might be seen as a bit petty, escalates the feud to incorporate the BBC. Elsewhere, a spate of spats involving chairmen and journalists simmer on.

Most amusing is the one that emanated from a disputed restaurant bill following a lunch in Marseille. Ken Bates reckoned the hacks should pick it up, the football writers were under the impression that Mr Chelsea was footing the bill.

The story wormed its way into the Peterborough column in The Daily Telegraph , Bates took umbrage and promptly banned one of that paper's football writers, Christopher Davies, from the Stamford Bridge press box in perpetuity. Not perhaps the gravest of punishments given that the view offered from that bit of the Bridge is marginally worse than that afforded from the back of The Shed.

Davies was blameless although he might have been forewarned had he read Chelsea... My Year by Ken Bates (first published in Britain in 1984 by Chelsea Football Club, priced £8.00 in paperback). In particular, he should have heeded the following entry:

Friday, 21 October: 'We had a boisterous time at the Isolabella although I had us moved to a better table after the first course, which Fred said was typical of me. (Pam and I once had a five-course meal on five different tables in Durban!) Towards the end of lunch we were both a little merry.

'Fred paid the bill with his Visa card, which I carefully inspected when it had been returned with receipt [sic] by the waiter and exclaimed to him in front of Fred, "You know this is a forgery don't you" and promptly tore it in half and slung the bits back on the plate.

The manager got worried just in case he had been paid with a forged card and came over to examine the remains. Fred was most put out and I had to quieten him with a lecture on the evils of paying on credit.'

Wonderful stuff (wouldn't you have loved to have been in Durban?), which proves, if proof were needed, that Bates resembles nothing so much as Michael Winner without a restaurant column. 'Another Table for Mr Bates' might paper up this oversight.

Similarly bizarre is the tale of Charlie Allan from the Aberdeen Evening Express, who was just one of many to fall foul of the McLean brothers at Dundee United. 'I'd written a story about Mark Perry moving from Dundee United to Aberdeen,' says Allan. 'And Tommy McLean and his brother agreed that if I didn't reveal my sources I'd be banned from Tannadice' - actually, Perry did move shortly after. 'And the newspaper in its wisdom made up a series of masks of me for the fans to wear, which they did.

'There were guys at the door checking that I was not trying to sneak in so I wore one of the bloody masks and got in no problem. And I'm a bit rotund, shall we say, and the fans who wore the masks were getting free pies. It was quite amusing but a bit embarrassing.'

Soon after the McLean brothers, conscious they were losing the publicity war, recanted and lifted the ban.

Less fortunate was Tim Taylor of the Newcastle Journal , who was banned from St James' Park when Kevin Keegan was manager and 'as far as I know I'm still banned'. His offence, after some confusion involving a couple of Terrys, Venables and McDermott, over the state of Andy Cole's shin splints, was to write that either someone was being economical with the truth or McDermott needed to be properly briefed.

'It was shown to the lawyer and okayed,' says Taylor. 'And the next week the paper and I were banned. I wasn't even being particularly aggressive, just straight forward.'

Taylor moved over to cover Sunderland, and later, when his son was diagnosed as having schizophrenia, moved up to a management job so he might help care for him. At no time did Newcastle rescind the ban so blithely imposed. A journalist who was never afraid to rattle a few cages, Taylor is less than sanguine as to the prospects of newspapers standing up to intemperate chairmen and managers, particularly at local level.

'In the old days, before the advent of Sky, the local paper and the club needed to rub along. The newspapers would hope to build a circulation and the clubs would hope to build a gate. Now do the clubs need local paper coverage? Do they fuck. By the time I get to my old age we will be talking about the days when Mark Lawrenson, Patrick Collins, Hughie Mcllvanney and Kevin Mitchell were telling it like it was rather than some big blob telling us how it should be.'

By such a time, Tony Hudd might yet be allowed to watch Gillingham again. Since March 1998, Hudd and his paper Medway Today , formerly Kent Today , and all who work for it have been banned from Priestfield by chairman Paul Scally.

Hudd believes that it is the longest blanket ban to be imposed on a newspaper and there is little prospect of it end ing. 'I wrote to him in the summer,' says Hudd, 'and surprise, surprise I'm still waiting for a reply. I've covered the club for more than 25 years and I'm resigned to the fact that I'll never be able to walk through the gates again as a bona fide working journalist.'

It only takes a phone call for a dictatorial chairman to quell a dissenting voice. Not that there are many. The TV companies are dependent on chairman for their precious TV rights; the journalists dependent on the clubs for their precious exclusives. Thus it is that the majority of what you see and read is just so much public relations.

Not long ago, Tony Hudd orchestrated the campaign for Peter Taylor to become Gillingham manager following Tony Pulis's departure after a bust-up with Scally. When Taylor moved on he spoke to Hudd and said he'd told Scally that one of the conditions of his staying would be the lifting of the ban. Taylor went and the ban remained.

So it is that the man arguably responsible for the appointment of the acting England manager is still prevented from watching Gillingham at home. It's that petty, and things can only get pettier.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: FA Cup review
fields.trailText: FA Cup review
fields.body:
Kingstonian, second from bottom in the Nationwide Conference, gave themselves the perfect tonic yesterday when they clinched a place in the FA Cup second round with a 3-1 win at Brentford.

Geoff Pitcher gave Kingstonian the psychological fillip of putting them ahead on the stroke of halt-time; and Sammy Winston inflicted more agony on Brentford by scoring the visitors' other goals.

When it came to embarrassing Cup slip-ups, Brentford were in good company. Of the 19 non-league teams facing league opposition, the other winners were Yeovil, who had an even more resounding victory - 5-1 over Colchester - and Gateshead, who overcame Halifax 2-0.

Yeovil, of course, are masters of the art of embarrassing league teams. The Conference leaders, having already gained the record as the non-league club who have produced the highest number of giant-killing acts in the competition, made Colchester their 13th victims.

Warren Patmore scored twice, and their other goals came from Barrington Belgrave, Terry Skiverton and Darren Way.

The next best performances from so-called "minnows" were the draws that Northwich, Nuneaton and Kettering gained against Bury, Stoke and Hull.

Then there was the shock that Hampton and Richmond gave to Barnet. The Rymans Premier League club, whose president is the TV and radio comedy scriptwriter, Alan Simpson, seized control with a 21st minute goal from their former Southampton, Huddersfield and Swindon striker Craig Maskell.

fields.headline: United in the gaffer's absence
fields.trailText: Ian Whittell offers a Maine Road verdict.
fields.body:
For the Blue corner, the biggest fixture in five seasons, for the Reds not even the most important game of the week, even if the three points and the maturity displayed by David Beckham will have handed the absent Sir Alex Ferguson the excuse to open an extra bottle of bubbly as he toasted his son Mark's wedding in South Africa.

But for City players ad supporters, five years of pent-up and choking inferiority complex was painfully evident and nowhere more apparent than in the treatment meted out to Beckham. Initially spat at by home fans when taking corners, the vitriol demonstrated towards the England midfielder threatened to become far more sinister when coins were thrown at him.

'The good thing is they were all pound coins, I was picking them up and keeping them,' said Beckham, admirably restrained if somewhat tactless in his response. 'You expect a little bit of stick when you come here. It was only my second derby and I enjoyed it.'

Beckham also received the close attention of some City tackling that could be most kindly described as 'wholehearted,' Danny Tiatto and Paul Dickov were both cautioned for fouls on him although City players and manager Joe Royle both clearly felt the United man was guilty of diving.

The United No2 Steve McClaren, in charge in the absence of Ferguson, pointed out, not unreasonably, that Beckham was merely taking evasive action as he predicted challenges and was full of praise for Beckham's composure in trying circumstances. 'He has shown his maturity just recently,' said McClaren. 'Look at Wednesday night when he captained England in Italy. He knows he is in the spotlight and is handling it very well.'

There is still a slowly simmering fuse to Beckham, it threatened to ignite as he lunged at Alfie Haaland after the City captain had kicked the ball, perhaps deliberately, perhaps not, at Phil Neville who was lying on the ground injured. But there was none of the sneering aggression that once seemed to be his permanent game-day visage. Nor is his play any the poorer for its absence, as his 30-yard match-winning free-kick amply illustrated after 96 seconds, a goal that should have been the first of many.

Profligacy in front of goal aside, Ferguson will have been heartened by the report telephoned in to him from the United dressing room after the match.

'I spoke to him straight after the game,' said McClaren. 'He just said that as usual the players have made it harder for us with the misses. But he passed on his congratulations and I left him just as he was opening the first bottle of champagne.'

fields.headline: Taylor's boys bury Barrow
fields.trailText:
FACupBarrow 0 - 2 Leyton Orient
Taylor's boys bury Barrow.
fields.body:
Barrow's biggest match of the season pitted them against Third Division highfliers Leyton Orient in the first round of the FA Cup. They promised much, but despite putting the Londoners under a good deal of early pressure, the league side rode the storm and eased their way into the second round.

The Cumbrians' Holker Street ground was packed and the sense of anticipation grew when the kick-off was delayed 15 minutes because of travelling problems encountered by the visiting fans.

Barrow, led by manager Kenny Lowe and whose Unibond League Premier Division team bristled with football league experience, dominated the first half in wet and breezy conditions.

They began in lively fashion and looked to have taken the lead in the second minute when Lee Ellison finished off strike partner Nicky Peverell's cross from the left but it was ruled offside.

The O's keeper Ashley Bayes was called into action again in the 20th minute to foil Mark Hume from six yards when he latched onto a loose ball in the area follow ing Wayne Bullimore's 30-yard free-kick. The fans were also treated to some unexpected entertainment when a streaker ran onto the field.

Before today Orient had faced Barrow in the Football League, but they finished as losers on three occasions when they travelled north for Third Division encounters in the late 1960s.

O's manager Tommy Taylor played in one of those matches, as a 15-year-old back in 1968, and although he scored early on he finished on the losing side. Yesterday it was a different story.

After absorbing all the pressure in the first half Orient took the lead in the 53rd minute when Carl Griffiths sneaked in at the near post to slip the ball home after good work by Nicky Shorey.

The O's sealed victory in the 73rd minute when substitute Steve Watts, who made a tremendous impact during the second half, drove into the roof of the net from 10 yards after connecting with Andy Harris's pass.

Barrow, though, were not downhearted: Hume headed just over and Graham Anthony shot high from 35 yards but Orient finished the stronger.

Halfway through the second half an announcement was made notifying Orient fans that their connection from the ground was leaving before the final whistle, but most appeared happy to hang around to celebrate.

fields.headline: Stiffs threat to Irish glory
fields.standfirst: Ian Whittell on how World Cup stars are struggling for a game
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland may be earning respect for a convincing start to their World Cup qualifying campaign, but many of Mick McCarthy's players are not considered adequate for the domestic stage.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland's surprisingly convincing start to their World Cup qualifying campaign has won friends and influenced many on the European stage. Not so, closer to home.

Mick McCarthy, handily placed in Group Two following draws in Holland and Portugal and a home victory over Estonia, faces an ironic situation as he enjoys the more relaxed atmosphere of friendlies against Finland, handily dispatched 3-0 in Dublin this week and Denmark, visitors in February.

For a number of his players, who have earned their spurs in emphatic fashion at Amsterdam Arena and the Stadium of Light, are not considered adequate for leading the domestic - even First Division - stage.

Of McCarthy's established first-choice line-up, the one he selected unchanged for all three World Cup games, no fewer than five are struggling for regular first-team football - Blackburn pair Alan Kelly and Jason McAteer, centre-halfs Gary Breen of Coventry and Manchester City's Richard Dunne and, the most high-profile of the set, Inter Milan striker Robbie Keane.

It is an issue that is becoming increasingly important to McCarthy, especially as a number of potential back-up players such as Manchester City winger Mark Kennedy, Lee Carsley of Blackburn and Watford striker Dominic Foley are also currently subsisting on a diet of predominantly reserve team football.

'You can't keep switching it off and switching it on,' said the Irish manager when quizzed about the untypically lackadaisical displays of Breen and Dunne in midweek. 'Richard needs to play regularly. You can't perform the way he did in our first three World Cup games every single time when you're not playing. At some stage that will catch up on him.

'Gary's the same. He's been in and out of the side, a side that's been conceding goals, as I say, you can't keep switching it off, switching it on.'

Blackburn goalkeeper Kelly appears the most likely candidate to lose his place for these reasons. Impressive in all three World Cup contests, he has inexplicably found himself relegated to third choice at Blackburn behind John Filan and the erratic Brad Friedel.

Shay Given, no stranger himself to reserve-team football, is currently established at Newcastle and probably did enough against the Finns to oust Kelly when Ireland recommence their World Cup campaign in Cyprus in March.

Yet when McCarthy embarked on the World Cup trail he presumably did not expect Keane to fall into the category of players struggling for competitive football. His future at Inter, who paid Coventry £13 million for his services last summer, has been placed under a cloud by the team's inept start to the season and the appointment of Marco Tardelli as manager in place of Marcello Lippi.

Reggina, looking ahead to Italy's next transfer window in January, attempted to secure the loan signing of 20-year-old striker Keane last week, a move that was rejected by Inter - for the time being. Privately, Tardelli has been impressed by Keane's attitude and skill level, still considering him a sound long-term investment, but is less than enamoured with his positional sense and tactical awareness, the result, he believes, of sub-standard coaching in Britain.

So the likelihood is that Keane will spend the second half of this season out on loan, a policy Inter adopted with some success in the cases of Uruguayan striker Alvero Racoba and French goalkeeper Sebastian Frey.

webTitle: PFA's Taylor accused of transferring his interests

fields.headline: PFA's Taylor accused of transferring his interests
fields.trailText: Player's boss Gordon Taylor stands accused by senior figures within football of endangering the future of the game by backing radical changes to the transfer system.
fields.body:
Player's boss Gordon Taylor stands accused by senior figures within football of endangering the future of the game by backing radical changes to the transfer system.

The chief executive of the Professional Footballers Association is under fire for endorsing moves to let players rip up their contracts and switch clubs whenever they wish. A formidable coalition of influential voices in the game - including Premier League chairmen, the Football League and Uefa - believe the plans would lead to top players earning huge wages and smaller clubs going bust.

Taylor's critics say he has done a spectacular U-turn in his views on reforming the transfer system and is now out of step with the opinion of the professional players he represents. The PFA boss has become the target of criticism because he is also the chairman of Fifpro, the international confederation of players' unions, whose policy is at odds with the one which Taylor, as the PFA's chief executive, spelled out in The Observer on 3 September, just after the row first broke over the EC's desire to scrap transfer fees.

In that article, Taylor argued strongly that players, clubs and fans benefited from the existing stability of players' contracts and warned that change would be disastrous for the game.

However, Fifpro's policy is very different. They want the EC to introduce a new transfer system whereby players have the freedom to have a unilateral breach of contract. That is at odds with Uefa and Fifa's policy, which has the backing of the FA, Premier League and Football League.

The League last night criticised Fifpro's proposals as likely to undermine the viability of clubs and to threaten the nurturing of young players.

'Football teams and football clubs are about developing players and developing relationships between play ers and crowds. What wouldn't be best would be to have a huge merry-go-round of players, because supporters love to identify with crowd heroes. Players perform at their best when they are settled at a club,' said spokesman John Nagle.

'We don't want to comment on Fifpro's position directly but we assume that their motivation must be the financial interest of players. That, however, would not be in the best interests of the game.'

Taylor warned in these pages that the EC's interference in the transfer system would lead to top players such as Luis Figo earning £250,000-a-week, was not wanted by any of his 3,000 members and 'could destroy many of the smaller clubs in England, Scotland and across Europe'.

'People may wonder why the chief executive of the players' union is arguing against a move that will make many of my members significantly richer,' Taylor continued. The answer, he said, was that 'there's no point in creating greater freedom for professional footballers if as a result of that freedom there are fewer clubs left to employ them'.

Taylor could not be contacted yesterday to explain the discrepancies between his original views and Fifpro's stance. But in a report to PFA members, he admits that there is a serious split between Fifpro and Uefa and Fifa involving 'the fundamental principle of whether players should be allowed, as the Commission are requesting, to break their contracts. Fifpro believe a unilateral termination of contract is required under European Union employment law'.

Football agent Richard Cody, whose clients include Charlton's Finnish striker Jonatan Johansson, said Taylor's original views were correct: 'Fifpro's proposals take away both a club's ability to plan a long-term future and a player's security.

'If a player can terminate his contract, clubs can do it to a player - maybe one who has lost form or suffered a bad injury. Only a minority of players would benefit. Gordon Taylor has done a good job for players and for football but he should think again. Players don't want to be able to rip up their contracts.'

Darlington chairman George Reynolds said that if Fifpro's proposals were accepted by the EC - which Taylor believes they will be - the result would be turmoil. 'A financially strong club such as Manchester United could afford to have 100 players on their books while weak clubs would go under. Gordon Taylor will have changed his mind because there will be something in it for the players.'

Chris Farnell, a Manchester-based sports lawyer who represents many international players, questioned whether Taylor's new stance was really in the best interests of his members.

'Players have never asked for the ability to unilaterally breach their contracts,' he said. 'Why has Gordon Taylor changed his mind? It appears to be a political move to strengthen his position at the negotiating table. When the EC originally demanded change, he was all in favour of maintaining the status quo.

'Now he knows the old system is open to legal challenge, he has decided to adopt a more aggressive stance for reasons best known to him.'

webTitle: Graham: These fans won't beat me

fields.headline: Graham: These fans won't beat me
fields.standfirst: Old pals Darren Anderton and Nick Barmby meet again when the Reds arrive at troubled White Hart Lane
fields.trailText: Old pals Darren Anderton and Nick Barmby will meet again when the Reds arrive at troubled White Hart Lane this afternoon
fields.body:
Remember that scene in Monty Python's Life of Brian , where members of the Judean People's Front pour scorn on the People's Front of Judea ('bunch of ******s')?

It is a bit like that at Tottenham at the moment, with various 'action' groups voicing their protests against: a) Alan Sugar; b) George Graham; and c) each other, not necessarily in that order.

The latest protest group call themselves SOS - Save Our Spurs - and they plan to hand out 20,000 or so leaflets before today's game against Liverpool at White Hart Lane.

Others have included TISA, TAG, RAGTAG and BOBTAIL - the last two are fictitious of course, but there is nothing to stop any loose collection of fans giving themselves a title and issuing statements claiming to represent the club's supporters.

The true level of disenchantment is harder to gauge, with wildly opposing opinions appearing on the club's unofficial websites, and the volume of booing at White Hart Lane rising in inverse proportion to the standard of play.

But Graham says they are all wasting their time because they will not force him out. 'I am not going to walk away from this job - that's ridiculous,' he said on Friday.

'I've read the stories and heard the hysteria but it's all happened before. Wherever you go there is an action group who surface as soon as you lose a couple of games.

'Even at Arsenal I would never have won all the fans over. I remember one Janu ary we went out of the European Cup at home to Benfica, then a few weeks later lost to Wrexham in the FA Cup.

'All of a sudden the champions, who were expected to be high-flyers, were out and there was criticism. But I don't worry about it - it goes with the job and I can handle it, no problem.

'And anyway the fans have been very good over the past two weeks, even at Aston Villa last week when we were very poor. It's just that hard core who stir everything up and get a lot of publicity.'

More worrying for him is Tottenham's inconsistency, which has left them with polarised home and away form. They are unbeaten in the league at White Hart Lane, with five wins out of six, but have lost six of their seven away matches.

'There are two reasons,' he adds. 'Firstly the squad is not big enough or talented enough, and secondly we haven't been able to cope with injuries to key players.'

One of those is Darren Anderton, who is equally baffled by Tottenham's up-and-down form. 'I don't know why it is, but we seem to struggle to get back into games if we go a goal behind,' he said.

webTitle: Fans' fury at new Cup switch

fields.headline: Fans' fury at new Cup switch
fields.trailText:
Wembley woes
The semi-finals of the FA Cup will be played at Wembley once it reopens in a desperate bid to help the £660 million stadium pay its huge debts.
fields.body:
The semi-finals of the FA Cup will be played at Wembley once it reopens in a desperate bid to help the £660 million stadium pay its huge debts.

The Football Association have decided that both semi-finals will be staged at the rebuilt venue for 30 years after its scheduled unveiling in early 2004. Critics claim letting four FA Cup contenders rather than just the two finalists play at Wembley will threaten the supposedly 'special' nature of playing there.

They have accused the FA of ignoring the Cup's traditions in its determination to give the stadium - which it now owns - two guaranteed sell-out events.

Malcolm Clarke, national chair of the Football Supporters Association, said the move undermined the FA's well-publicised promises earlier this year to 'revive the magic of the Cup' after a series of blows including holders Manchester United's non-participation last year and a growing loss of interest among fans.

'Most fans will be disappointed by this news,' said Clarke. 'This won't help restore the Cup to its former glory. Part of its traditional appeal was the magic of Wembley and the idea that going there wasn't routine. It shouldn't be routine to get there. It will make going to Wembley less special.'

The FA's decision comes amid growing concern that the new stadium may not generate enough money to pay the £30m-a-year interest on the £410m loan it is currently trying to raise to fund the redevelopment.

The FA's financial director, Michael Cunnah, confirmed that both semi-finals will be held at Wembley after it reopens in 2004. However, if two teams from the North-East or North-West are drawn to meet in a semi-final, that match may be played instead at a league ground to save fans having to travel to London.

A Sunderland-Newcastle United game could thus be played at Old Trafford, for example, or a Manchester United-Liverpool match at St James' Park. Usually, though, both semi-finals will be played in north London.

This action will bring in several millions of pounds in much-needed revenue for Wembley National Stadium Limited (WNSL), the stadium's owners. WNSL is a subsidiary of the FA and believe that the semi-final switch will help ease doubts about the project's financial viability.

The Cup semi-finals are on a list of nine 'prestige events', which the FA admits hold the key to Wembley being a financial success. The list also includes the FA Cup Final, Worthington Cup Final and England internationals. Stag ing these events is crucial to selling 12,800 'premium' seats at the 90,000-seat venue to big companies and wealthy individuals for up to thousands of pounds per season. WNSL is hoping to raise a staggering £40m a year from executive seats, club seats, corporate hospitality and associated catering.

Wembley currently generates £2.8m in this way from 1,500 'fatcats'. The company says such this anticipated 14-fold increase in income is realistic as they will simply be legitimising the existing black market in unofficial hospitality packages, but FA insiders fear WNSL is being over-optimistic.

Chase Manhattan, the bank which is trying to raise the £410m, has also admitted that the total cost of Wembley will be close to £1 billion, and not the previously estimated £660m. This change in figure is due to the £300m interest that will have to be paid over a 20-year loan period. Building the new stadium will cost £326.5m of that, while buying the land cost £120m.

Meanwhile, Observer Sport can reveal that the Government has received a blunt warning that Britain will never stage an Olympic Games or sports event of similar importance unless it sorts out the growing mess surrounding the venue for the 2005 World Athletics Championships.

At the moment they are due to be held at a new, purpose-built athletics stadium at Picketts Lock in Edmonton, north London. But huge doubts surround that venue's viability because of its out-of -the-way location, lack of a permanent tenant and potential to become a 'white elephant' after the championships are over.

When Ministers recently considered not hosting 2005 at Picketts Lock, both UK Sport and the British Olympic Association warned that if they moved the venue elsewhere, Britain's credibility would be so badly damaged that they would never be awarded the Olympics or WAC again.

If London proves incapable of staging 2005, the International Amateur Athletics Federation may instead hand the event to Berlin. It could be hosted in Berlin's Olympic stadium, which will be upgraded for Germany hosting the 2006 football World Cup.

Furthermore the Government may find that Picketts Lock is its only option for hosting 2005. It has agreed that Wembley - which was due to host it until last year's bitter row over how to accommodate athletics there - can be released from its contractual obligation to make itself available for a World Athletics Championships on a non-profit making basis.

Hosting both the WAC and an Olympics was a condition of Wembley receiving £120m Lottery money.

fields.headline: Clough: Phillips must do more
fields.trailText: Brian Clough chips in with some advice for on-the-bench international Kevin Phillips.
fields.body:
Here's a thought for Kevin Phillips and the Sunderland supporters aggrieved that he did not start England's friendly against Italy despite the absence of Michael Owen, Andy Cole and Teddy Sheringham: Phillips has already won three times as many caps as Brian Clough.

A curtailed career, which featured 267 goals in 269 games for Middlesbrough and Sunderland, earned Clough just two international appearances in 1960. Clough was a player who undeniably suffered from bizarre selection decisions bracketed with the fact he spent his career in the North East and predominantly in the old Second Division.

Now Phillips and his advocates talk again of an international bias against players from the less fashionable clubs. The true reason is probably less sinister, with Clough hinting that Sunderland striker Phillips still has something to prove.

'Only in three or four years will we know how prolific young Phillips is going to be,' says Clough. 'He's got to do it every season. Time will tell, but he's obviously had a tremendous start.'

The pair met when Clough visited the Stadium of Light last March. 'I told him I don't want you flitting in one season and flitting out the next,' Clough says in a Tyne-Tees Television interview to be screened tomorrow.

Phillips's admirers still insist the 30 goals he scored last season would have earned him an appearance at Euro 2000 and a place against Italy if he played for the likes of Manchester United or Arsenal. The theory conveniently ignores Andy Cole's infrequent international outings, Teddy Sheringham's failure to make the Euro 2000 squad and the substantial favourable publicity generated by Phillips last season.

Phillips was also unfortunate to be scoring those goals at a time when Cole, Alan Shearer, Michael Owen, Robbie Fowler and Emile Heskey were his rivals.

Last Wednesday in Turin, Phillips got his sixth cap but for barely quarter of an hour after replacing Heskey, the first choice as lone striker. But Phillips's international anguish is nothing compared to that of Clough, who reflects on his two internationals and admits: 'It still rankles. There was a bloke called Sir Walter Winterbottom in charge while I was playing for England and he was definitely an amateur. He didn't have any idea about the professional game... he was well-spoken, very presentable and well liked by the FA, but never caused a ripple in his life.'

Clough was hurt when he missed the 1958 World Cup squad and recalls: 'I was a filler-in. I was always on tour, but never the No1.'

Phillips says he was not disappointed at being named on the bench again and added: 'I want this to be a fresh start.'

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Lyon lying in wait as underdogs
fields.trailText: Jaques Santini's team are clear underdogs in Group C, having qualified despite losing three times in the first phase - including twice against last season's finalists Valencia. They scraped into the last 16 after a nervy 1-0 home victory against Olympiakos in the final group game. Santini's squad consist mostly of French talent but also have quality from abroad in the Brazilian striker Sonny Anderson and abrasive Cameroonian midfielder Marc-Vivien Foe, signed from West Ham in the summer.

webTitle: Bayern revel in the return of Stefan the headstrong

fields.headline: Bayern revel in the return of Stefan the headstrong
fields.trailText: The return of Stefan Effenberg is the most compelling reason for believing Bayern can improve on their indifferent form so far.
fields.body:
When Arsenal landed in Bayern Munich's group at last week's Champions League draw, the German club's boss, Ottmar Hitzfeld, nodded knowingly as he noted the names of his opponents on his writing pad.

'Thank goodness we've been able to get Stefan back in time,' remarked Hitzfeld. The 'Stefan' in question is Stefan Effenberg, Bayern's guiding star and, at 32, as inspirational a personality as Tony Adams is for Arsenal. Effenberg has just made a successful first-team comeback after months on the sidelines. recovering from complicated surgery on an Achilles heel injury that had threatened to end his career.

His return 11 days ago against Rosenborg in Bayern's final Champions League qualifier was his first match of the season. As a precaution he was substituted after an hour, but so pleased was Effenberg with the reaction that he played the full 90 minutes three days later, in last weekend's Bundesliga clash against Schalke.

Without Effenberg's presence and ability in midfield, Bayern struggled to make an impact both in domestic competition as well as in the Champions League.

Their start this season is their poorest since 1994. During the entire championship last season only five games were lost. Already this season they have lost four - with only a third of the programme completed.

While Effenberg's absence has not been the only reason for Bayern's indifferent form, his return remains the most compelling reason for believing an improvement can follow.

'I hope I'll be back at my best by the time we face Arsenal at Highbury next month,' says Effenberg of the first-ever meeting in European competition between the two clubs. 'Arsenal are a top team and they'll be difficult to beat.'

Effenberg's commitment to Bayern, and particularly the club's success in the Champions League, is total. He has long since made that clear by his repeated refusals to play for the German national team again.

But his presence alone may not be enough to bring the success Bayern crave in the Champions League. The defeat in injury time by Manchester United in the 1999 final still hurts. But it has also hardened Bayern's resolve to win the game's most prestigious prize for the first time since the Beckenbauer era of the Seventies.

So much so that they are now eager to strengthen their defence. Bayern may top Manchester United's £12 million bid for Ivan Helguera, Real Madrid's multi-purpose defender. He is the type of defender Bayern need to improve security so as to allow Effenberg greater scope for creativity.

For the time being, Bayern must depend on the players they have for their immediate needs - the upcoming Champions League clashes with Olympic Lyon and Spartak Moscow as well as Arsenal. They have sufficient strength in depth - at least for the attacking variations Hitzfeld favours.

Mehmet Scholl has finally emerged as the touch-player of quality that his talent as a teenager promised. His match-winning contribu tions as chance-maker and chance-taker have made him an automatic choice in Voller's national side.

Add the aggressive striking power of Hassan Salihamadzic, the precocious Bosnian, Carsten Jancker's strength in the air and Alex Zickler's electrifying speed and Bayern have the potential to score often enough to qualify for the knock-out stages.

Arsène Wenger, though, can draw comfort from what has been discovered so far this season in the Bundesliga. Bayern are only half a team without Effenberg. So switch off Effenberg - and it could be lights out for Bayern.

webTitle: Wenger spells out cold facts of life to Arsenal

fields.headline: Wenger spells out cold facts of life to Arsenal
fields.standfirst: Gunners coach can't match the playing exploits of his millionaire charges but he can tell them all about football at minus 22 degrees
fields.trailText:
Focus on Arsenal
Gunners coach can't match the playing exploits of his millionaire charges but he can tell them all about football at minus 22 degrees
fields.body:
There are few shrewder punters in the transfer market than Arsène Wenger, so it is a fair bet that he would not have recommended himself to the Arsenal board as a potential signing.

The magnanimous Frenchman is the manager players love to love for his rare ability to make the most average footballer feel he might at least hit the roof if he aims for the stars.

But he is not soft and is brutally honest in the assessment of his own 'average' playing career which spanned 11 years of modest reliability with Mulhouse, Mutzig, Vauban and Strasbourg.

In the absence of a massive medal collection - he did at least win the French championship with Strasbourg, however - Wenger's humanity and track record as a manager are two of the qualities which earn him respect in the dressing room.

So no wonder he was smiling when he watched the draw unfold for the second phase of the Champions League.

Not a bad draw for starters, but it also afforded him a prized opportunity to issue a team talk based on his own experience as a player before leading his millionaire internationals into their opening game away to Spartak Moscow this week.

Arsenal will start as favourites, and Wenger's principal fear is that his players will freeze in the sub-zero temperatures of the Russian capital, mindful of how Leeds United were sent home without kicking a ball last season when their match was postponed despite the presence of undersoil heating.

Weather permitting, Wenger will be able to tell his players with authority that they can triumph in such adversity and how not to repeat his mistake of 20 years ago.

'It will be cold, perhaps minus 20, but I have played before at minus 22 for Strasbourg in the Uefa Cup against Dusseldorf in 1980,' Wenger said.

It was 8-4 on aggregate, so Wenger will no doubt be hoping that revenge is a dish best served cold this week.

'We have a tough European group,' he said. 'But we are better prepared this year in that we have gained experience of playing at this level, and I feel that the squad is stronger in both depth and ability.'

Nigerian striker Kanu agrees, point ing to the addition of players such as Robert Pires, Sylvain Wiltord and Lauren as three reasons for Arsenal to be cheerful following the summer departure of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit, whose boots seemed to be getting a bit small for them last season.

Kanu said: 'We have been well prepared in the Champions League in the past, but we lost matches we shouldn't have - and made some mistakes. This time around we have the experience, the depth and we know what it is like to lose. Nobody wants to make those silly mistakes again.

No fear there, then. After Spartak, French club Olympique Lyonnais, aka Lyon, and Germany's Bayern Munich are Arsenal's other opponents. And, as ever, Wenger's obsession with the beautiful game means he has an inbuilt knowledge of them all.

Lyon, he will relate, can call on the likes of Sonny Anderson, Tony Vairelles and former West Ham man Marc-Vivien Foe to help their cause. But an InterToto Cup triumph is their greatest European feat to date.

Wenger said: 'Lyon are probably fourth favourites in the group, but they are not to be underestimated. Their manager Jacques Santini is a very good friend of mine.

'He has been out of a job for a few years and this is his first season back in the game. He has done well. Lyon have invested a lot of money this year and they have big potential, especially offensively. They have also bought the Brazilian Edmilson, who I tried to bring to Arsenal, and they look as if they have a good balance to their team.

'Lyon have been able to buy Edmilson because their work permit rules are very different. In France, as soon as you are offered a job you automatically get a work permit. When we tried to buy him he was ineligible because he did not meet the criteria here .

'You could say that it is unfair, but it is just the facts that everywhere in Europe there are different rules concerning work permits.'

At least Wenger will be able to use his non-flying Dutchman Dennis Bergkamp for the trip to France in February. Bergkamp will not travel to Moscow, though, and Wenger will assess the importance of the tie before deciding whether he should drive to Munich next March.

Arsenal have not played Bayern, still in therapy following Manchester United's last-gasp triumph in the final last year, since a 3-0 pre-season win 12 years ago, just before the blossoming of George Graham's first championship side.

Bayern's pedigree when it matters is far more impressive. They won the Uefa Cup in 1996 and celebrated a legendary back-to-back-to-back run of victories in the European Cup from 1974 to 1976.

Wenger believes counterpart Ottmar Hitzfeld also has a good team today with players of the calibre of Bixente Lizarazu, Mehmet Scholl, Giovane Elber, Paulo Sergio and Carsten Jancker.

In short, they are Germany's most successful ever team and Wenger, hardly surprisingly, rates them as Arsenal's most dangerous, though far from invincible opponents.

He said: 'Bayern Munich are always there in the final stages and they will be a tough team to knock out. But I believe we have a very good chance to do well ourselves in the Champions League.

'We have worked hard to get into this position and we are not about to throw it away.'

fields.headline: West restores pride
fields.trailText:
Derby 2 - 0 Bradford
Taribo West restores Derby's pride.
fields.body:
According to Derby's new signing, Taribo West from AC Milan, it was Divine Will which led to him being here for his debut yesterday. 'Where ever I fall into a situation where there is darkness it means God is about to use me for something,' said the Nigerian.

West, resplendent with black-and-white ribbons in his hair, was certainly a useful reinforcement, but it was Derby's other gift from the gods who helped them shed their record of being the only side in the country without a league win to their name.

Georgi Kinkladze has been worshipped wherever he has gone, and he carried the fight to Bradford, setting up both Derby's goals.

There was no shaft of light for Bradford, though. Stan Collymore worked hard on the ground where he broke his leg playing for Leicester last season and there was industry from the likes of Dean Windass and Jamie Lawrence.

But their only real shot came in the ninth minute from Collymore - in 14 games they have scored only five times. It must have made for depressing viewing for Jim Jefferies, the former Hearts manager, who is expected to take over at Bradford tomorrow. 'We just don't look a threat at the moment,' admitted Stuart McCall, the caretaker-manager.

How he must wish Bradford could call on the talents of someone like Kinkladze. Starting a Premiership match for only the sixth time this season, it was the Georgian who, in the words of manager Jim Smith, 'came into his own and ran the show' in the second half.

It was his mazy run which spread such panic in the 55th minute and allowed Malcolm Christie the opportunity to find space, which he exploited brilliantly when he received the ball by hitting his shot beyond the Bradford keeper Matt Clarke for his sixth goal of the season.

The same combination were also involved in the second goal. Kinkladze controlled Christie's pass splendidly and waited for new England cap Seth Johnson to arrive and whip in a cross which Rory Delap buried beyond Clarke with a powerful header to consign his misses at Arsenal the previous week to the history books.

'This was a big game,' said Smith. 'We looked really good and solid at the back.' The visitors next week are Manchester United. Smith will be hoping that God can again find a few spare minutes in his diary.

fields.headline: Watford on the slide
fields.trailText: Full review of Nationwide Division One.
fields.body:
Watford, Fulham's closest championship challengers, lost more ground when they went down 3-2 at home to Preston.

However, that can hardly be viewed as a surprise because they lost their two previous matches, and Preston's other victories include one over Fulham. Watford appeared to be set for at least a point after twice coming from behind to make the score 2-2. But they were then sunk by a goal from Iain Anderson.

Watford's manager, Graham Taylor, pointed out: 'It could easily have been us in that position. A shot from Allan Nielsen was turned on to the post by the keeper, who then saved a great effort from Neil Cox. But I am not making too much of this. We had situations like that going our way when we had a 15-game unbeaten run, and we should not complain when it doesn't go our way.'

Bolton, in third place, closed the gap between Taylor's troops and themselves to three points with a 2-0 win at Norwich.

Burnley's manager, Stan Ternent, has still not given up hope of persuading the irrepressible Ian Wright to reconsider his decision to retire. In the meantime, Wright, while keeping in touch with his son Sean at Manchester City, still occasionally trains at Burnley (as he did last week) and Ternent has been given another scoring option through the successful conclusion of the drawn-out negotiations to sign Stockport's Ian Moore.

He certainly could have done with it when Burnley faced one of their biggest tests of the season, at Birmingham.

Burnley, beaten only once in their previous 11 games, produced some excellent attacking football, which often had the home defence at panic stations. They should have taken the lead in only the second minute, when an unmarked Andy Payton failed to find the net with the goal at his mercy.

Birmingham made them pay for it early in the second half when Dele Adebola and Martin O'Connor put the home side 2-0 ahead. Although Burnley's finishing improved, the deficit was too much for them to overcome and they eventually lost 3-2.

Though they were without Moore, Stockport eased their relegation fears - albeit slightly - with a 2-1 win at Crewe.

The Stockport manager Andy Kilner said: 'The lads were down before the game because of Moore's departure and I am sorry to see him go, too - he's a great lad who always did a top job for me. But life goes on and the lads have to take credit because of the way they responded on the field.'

It was a similar story for Wimbledon. They left John Hartson out of their side at Nottingham Forest because of his proposed move to Charlton, but he hardly seemed to be missed as they won 2-1 through goals by Jason Euell and Trond Andersen.

West Brom's Lee Hughes. scored all his side's goals in the 3-1 win over Gillingham to bring his total for the season to 11.

Another striker who was the centre of attraction was Huddersfield's Kevin Gallen. He scored the opening goal against his old club, QPR; and then, after QPR had equalised through Karl Connolly, had a penalty saved by Ludo Miklosko. One wonders what his father made of it - he is a QPR season-ticket holder.

The most exciting First Division game was at Crystal Palace, where the home team twice came from behind to beat Tranmere 3-2. Their last two goals - from Jamie Pollock and Clinton Morrison - came in the 83rd and 86th minutes.

According to Tranmere manager John Aldridge, though, it was easy for them. 'I have never seen us play so badly,' he said. 'If you can't pass the ball you shouldn't be on the pitch.'

The training pitch is another matter. 'I can't accept that kind of play today and the boys will be in for training tomorrow,' he said. 'If I'm feeling as bad as I am, then they're going to feel it.'

fields.headline: Seagulls prey on Pape
fields.trailText:
Aldershot 2 - 6 Brighton
Seagulls prey on apathetic Aldershot.
fields.byline: Will Buckley at The Recreation Ground
fields.body:
At about the same time that Sky created the premiership, Aldershot went bust. Sky were to herald in an age of hype and hyperbole, Aldershot 'died from apathy more than anything', says club secretary Graham Buckland. They couldn't pay debts of £92,000, which one would guess is less than the salary of Sky presenter Richard Keys, and were kicked out of the league.

A few months later they re-emerged as Aldershot Town (1992) in the Isthmian League Division Three. Three promotions later and they find themselves a promotion away from the Conference.

Enough of the league - yesterday was about the Cup. Not that you would have known it from the newspapers, which continued to plug the Premiership - this week's whine coming from Alfie Haaland. No one cared down at the Rec, where seven-and-a-half thousand turned up for the visit of Brighton. Seven- and-a-half thousand and Tony Gubba. Yup, the Match of the Day cameras were present and Gubba looked most Presidential - well, US presidential - sitting behind the mike.

The Rec is a fine throw-back of a ground: terraces behind both goals and a sign outside saying that the premises could be hired out for 'skittles nights'. You have to diversify to stay ahead in this business. And, out on the pitch, there were under-age cheerleaders - is there a legal minimum age for cheerleading? - who pom-pommed around every corner of the ground. In the distance, a rare sight indeed, a train went by. All this and a cup-tie.

However, much of the excitement of the final part seemed to evaporate when Brighton took a second-minute lead. Richard Gell was penalised for a foul 25 yards out and Richard Carpenter, signed on a Bosman from Cardiff, side-footed the ball past a bewildered Andy Pape. Another train went by. Aldershot 0, Brighton 1, South-West Trains 2.

Nervous at the start, Aldershot became even more hesitant on finding themselves behind, particularly Pape. He erringly punched away a cross from Paul Watson and faffed away a long-range shot from captain Paul Rogers.

Before yesterday he had let in only three goals here all season. Yesterday, he looked likely to double this tally by half-time. His defence were being out-run and his midfield out-passed or by-passed. It looked bad for Aldershot. The only thing that went their way was a yellow card for Brighton's Danny Cullip after he manhandled Gell in the centre circle.

But the Seagulls failed to make the most of their early supremacy and Cullip's next intervention was even more crucial. He scythed down Wayne Andrews in the corner of the box and conceded a penalty. Up stepped Gary Abbott and he pummelled it home. His fifth in the Cup this season, his seventeenth in all competition. Abbo, as he is known, is one to watch.

After that, the pendulum swung towards Aldershot with the speedy Wayne Andrews, once with Watford, twice embarrassing the Brighton defence but failing to score. Aldershot were suddenly confident, direct and threatening.

But that was reckoning without Pape. A minute before the interval he actually got a hand to something, but unfortunately it was Bobby Zamora's right ankle. Another penalty. Watson left-footed it into the right corner. Pape went the right way but didn't fall quick enough.

During half-time there was a different type of shock - a kid asked Tony Gubba for his autograph.

Shortly after half-time, it was game over as Charlie Oatway curled the ball in from the edge of the area, and 10 minutes later Pape missed the ball and grabbed Nathan Jones to concede yet another penalty. Up stepped Watson again - same place, same slow fall from Pape. 4-1.

Aldershot kept going, substitute Stafford Browne forcing the ball into the net but fouling the keeper in the process. Ten minutes from time, the impressive Zamora headed in from close range for Brighton's fifth. Two minutes later, Wicks side-footed a sixth.

At the end, Abbott headed his second - with six goals, he may turn out to be the competition's top scorer. Aldershot, out of the Cup, were left to concentrate on the Ryman League. Next week, Canvey Island.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Robson on the brink
fields.trailText:
Middlesbrough 0 - 3 Leicester
Robson on the brink after a proper stinker.
fields.byline: John Wilford at the Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Contrast the mood of managers Peter Taylor and Bryan Robson today. Taylor, having blooded England's youngsters in Italy where he was generally acknowledged to have worked minor miracles, watches Leicester extend their unbeaten run to four games and move to third in the table. Robson's side haven't won at home this season and have now lost six games on the trot. They are in the bottom three with a meagre 10 points.

There's a mantra in these parts that Robson enjoys the full support of his chairman, Steve Gibson. But for how much longer? Robson says: 'I've no intention of walking away and quitting on the job.' On Saturday, Boro entertain Bradford City. Failure there could leave both men with no option but to call it a day.

Taylor inherited from Martin O'Neill a side known for their commitment and energy. He's bolted on to that the meanest defence in the league - they've conceded a miserly eight goals - and sharpened up their teamwork to make them an outstanding passing side.

Lennon, Izzet and particularly Savage are the engine room. Their stamina and willingness to work is of Olym-pian proportions. Up front he has two sprinting strikers in Benjamin and Akinbiyi who collect balls knocked into predetermined channels and hold up play for the midfield cavalry to arrive. It's simple, straightforward and effective.

Boro, without Ince who has missed five games, offered no combative element in midfield. Stamp put in a couple of disgraceful tackles and was lucky to stay on the pitch but that was the sum of it. For most of the game they chased shadows.

Ehiogu, an £8 million buy, was captain for his home debut but looked as desperate as anyone in their ragged defence. He lacks fitness and appeared bewildered by his team-mates' incompetence.

The goals were inevitable. Gordon clattered Izzet who got up and scored from the penalty spot. Benjamin outwitted Gordon to get goalside and head in a cross from Lennon that any sensible defence would have cleared much earlier. And substitute Darren Eadie scored with his first touch of the ball, driving hard and low into the net after Akinbiyi had teed up the shot. The goal resulted from a typical Leicester move involving half-a-dozen players with the outstanding Savage the fulcrum.

Boro had their chances. Deane twice missed from excellent positions. Boksic, looking far from international class, drove impetuously over the bar when well placed and hit the post with a free kick.

But the result was never in doubt. Taylor applauded his side's interplay: 'You often hear Leicester praised for their teamwork but I'd like to see them get credit for their passing. It was outstanding.'

People talk about Liverpool, Leeds or even Chelsea finishing third at the end of the season. At Filbert Street they know they have a side equipped for a place in Europe.

And Mr Robson? No one likes to see a dedicated, courteous manager on the rack. But he has failed to produce a team who play like a team. A team like City, for instance.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ranieri suffers awayday Blues
fields.trailText:
Charlton 2 - 0 Chelsea
Ranieri suffers awayday Blues.
fields.body:
Charlton will play better than this and lose this season, that is how bad Chelsea were yesterday. Charlton were solid, well-organised and did nothing out of the ordinary to lift themselves into seventh place and send Chelsea tumbling into the bottom half of the Premiership.

It could be time for a few home truths at Chelsea because the table does not lie. The frustrating thing about Chelsea is that their star- studded line-ups look mouth-watering, but their performances are too often soulless and just dry as a bone.

On paper, they had the expensively assembled players and a formation which should have been able to pick apart a workmanlike Charlton team. But desire, spirit and commitment are always more telling qualities than lofty, individual reputations and the ability to execute a fancy backheel.

That is why Chelsea are without an away win since April last season and are 16 points adrift of a Manchester United side they had expected to challenge for the Premiership title when the season started only four months ago.

Chelsea's Italian manager, Claudio Ranieiri, agreed that it was time for some straight talking and, through an interpreter, said: 'We suddenly looked nervous after Charlton took the lead and that shouldn't happen. The team that wanted to win won the game and when the first difficulty arose, we got nervous and afraid.

'It is not good enough. I am not worried because we have so many good players, but we have a lot of talking to do.'

Ranieiri also went on to reveal that he is not a magician, and that he had no idea how long it would take to get his players on side. But it might not have helped them that their manager changed their formation at least three times during this game, leaving them looking like lost schoolboys at times.

Charlton did nothing special, but showed they had more unity when it mattered. They also displayed a sharper cutting edge when the Chelsea defence were left flat-footed as Jonatan Johansson gave them a 35th-minute lead.

Graham Stuart slid the ball in between the Chelsea central defenders and Finnish striker Johansson won a battle with Marcel Desailly to stretch and score with a right-foot shot, four yards inside the area. Desailly should have been sent off six minutes later when he hauled down Johansson when the striker had only Ed de Goey to beat.

Ranieiri made drastic changes soon after and a new- look Chelsea emerged for the second half. Midfielders Gus Poyet and Sam Dalla Bona had been axed and on came strikers Eidur Gudjohnsen and Tore Andre Flo to flank an occasional four-man attack as Dennis Wise moved into the middle of the battle.

Ranieiri mixed it up again when he withdrew Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink with just under 20 minutes remaining, but throughout the second half Chelsea recorded only one shot on target. Charlton grew increasingly defensive, although they ultimately need not have worried as substitute Martin Pringle marked his first appearance of the season after injury with a 90th-minute goal - a neat header from a Stuart corner.

Charlton manager Alan Curbishley, who is reportedly ready to move for Wimbledon's John Hartson, said: 'Chelsea have some fantastic players, but they did not really trouble us after we went ahead.'

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Parity not enough for Gers
fields.trailText:
Dunfermline 0 - 0 Rangers
Parity leaves Gers championship hopes fading fast.
fields.byline: Tom McGregor at East End Park
fields.body:
On a day when Rangers' bitter title rivals Celtic won at a canter, 6-1 against Hearts, Dick Advocaat's inconsistent side saw their hopes of adding to their tally of Scottish league championships fade further after a goalless draw at Dunfermline.

Despite good chances for Jorg Albertz and Kenny Miller the Ibrox side could not break down a stubborn Pars defence.

The home side also came close on a number of occasions and Rangers goalkeeper Stefan Klos, returning from injury, made a positive impact when he blocked late efforts from Youssef Rossi and Scott Thomson.

But travelling supporters had to wait to see the German keeper in action because a power failure in the main stand meant the kick-off was delayed by 15 minutes.

When the game eventually started the home side instantly went on the offensive, a smart one-two between Lee Bullen and Stevie Crawford epitomising Dunfermline's thoughtful attacking play.

The visitors had their moments too, though, as one would expect of a team of their undoubted potential. Barry Ferguson had a decent chance to give Rangers an early lead but a vigilant Dunfermline defence ensured cleared his header. Then the lively Ronald de Boer released compatriot Arthur Numan down the left minutes later but the Dutchman's cross failed to connect with Miller, who was lurking in the box.

Miller almost scored a few minutes later - Lorenzo Amoruso sent a long, hopeful ball up to the young striker on the edge of the box but goalkeeper Marco Ruitenbeek beat him to the ball.

The Pars keeper saved his side again with a superb stop from one of Albertz's trademark bullet-straight free-kicks from 25 yards out.

This was a frustrating time for Rangers, who enjoyed the majority of the first-half possession but found it difficult to break down Dunfermline's resolute defence.

It was the home side who looked like scoring five minutes before the break when Chris McGroarty broke clear but he was pulled down by Tony Vidmar, who was promptly booked for the foul.

The game's pattern continued into the second half, with Rangers creating a number of decent scoring chances. Albertz found Miller who exchanged a neat one-two with Michael Mols before bursting into the six-yard box but the Ibrox striker stumbled over the ball and the danger was cleared, albeit at the expense of a corner.

Even Barry Ferguson was getting in on the action. He produced a rare shot on target when he smashed a terrific effort at goal from 25 yards only for Ruitenbeek to push the ball past the post. Ten minutes later the persistent Albertz had another go from outside the 18-yard box but his shot was wayward.

De Boer should have grabbed the opener when he pounced on a long cross from Amoruso but he fired straight at the keeper. By this stage, Advocaat must have been tearing out what little hair remains on his head.

As the match entered its endgame, Rossi had the chance to put Dunfermline ahead with 15 minutes remaining, but the Moroccan's free-kick sliced through the Rangers defence only to be blocked by Klos. And with just 10 minutes to go the home team had a great chance to take the three points.

Crawford released David Moss who had only the goalkeeper to beat but sent the ball wide and, as a result, sent Rangers back to Glasgow with at least a point.

But considering the glut of chances that they had, a point was two less than they deserved and, more importantly, two less than Celtic.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Old style with new class
fields.trailText: D1Fulham 3 - 1 Portsmouth
fields.body:
This was football to remind you of the Seventies, the last time Fulham had a team this decent. Two were sent off, missiles rained down from the terraces, the referee needed a police escort and it all threatened to kick off again between rival fans in the des res sidestreets of South-West London.

The home fans, growing in number as Fulham stride ever closer to the Premiership, grew angry at Portsmouth's physical approach. Actually, it was because Pompey struggled to keep pace with the flowing movement of their French-inspired hosts, not merely wanting to deny them time and space. Linvoy Primus and Ceri Hughes duly received red cards for fouls, in quick succession, prompting missiles from a section of Portsmouth's rain-sodden support at the Putney End.

The acrimony didn't end there. Portsmouth's frustrated player-manager, Steve Claridge, on the way to his first defeat in his eighth match in charge, became involved in a slanging match with Fulham fans in the paddock and, at the final whistle, Lee Bradbury thumbed his nose at the referee Keith Hill as Mr Hill was about to shake his hand.

Claridge couldn't understand the ref's lack of sympathy for his team. 'We used to go in the same bookie's in Royston,' he said.

The game turned on the Primus dismissal, Claridge convinced the defender had made contact with the ball rather than Louis Saha. The score then was 1-1, Claridge himself having equalised Barry Hayles's opener. But it was inevitable that Fulham would ultimately prevail.

Hayles's second, to be followed by the goal that the neat, industrious Lee Clark deserved, made it three goals for the fifth successive match for the league leaders. Quaint may be the approaches to Craven Cottage, and the ground itself still, but Fulham's football was anything but Seventies.

It remains just about the most pleasant walk in football, from Putney Bridge through Bishops' Park and not much has changed once into Stevenage Road. From outside you can still hear 'Diddy' David Hamilton (What kind of Ful-ham I) working the PA system. The graffiti on the walls has defied the years. 'Mullery is God', it says, sprayed by the 'Thamesbank Travellers', Fulham's old 'firm' from the Seventies. Yet you can bet one day someone covers it with 'Fayed Out'.

And that is where everything has changed. Although the Hammersmith End is one of the last great places to lean on a crush barrier and moan, Fulham fans these days have had to break the habits of a lifetime and actually enjoy what is going on out there. When Mohamed al-Fayed walked on to the pitch, a flunkey holding an umbrella over him, he was roundly and generously applauded. Football fans care little about a man's background... only the size of his wad.

His money has bought well, French being the wise vogue. Jean Tigana was the best signing in the club's history, apart from that made by the scout who found Johnny Haynes, and his management has not only procured such a gem as Saha but also brought the best out of such domestic journeymen as Steve Finnan and Andy Melville.

Yesterday offered them a worthy challenge, with the other managerial surprise packet of the season bringing his Portsmouth side, unbeaten in his seven games in charge, and 6,000 fans to the Cottage.

It took a while for Claridge's team to cotton on. In midfield, in the absence of John Collins, Clark pulled the strings and the ball was moved with swift accuracy, notably to the French under-21 international Fabrice Fernandes, a coltish boy with a left foot to die for.

After one of Fernandes's twiddly bits, Saha took on the ball and picked out Hayles with the loveliest, most penetrative of passes through the Portsmouth defence. Hayles could hardly miss and didn't.

Pompey are dogged, though, and, after Maik Taylor saved from Bradbury, Claridge decided to do it himself. Over came Ceri Hughes's low cross from the left and the Pompey talisman diverted it home from close range.

'We would have gone on to win, 11 v 11,' Claridge later insisted. Doubtful. Against nine admittedly, Fernandes weaved some more magic and Hayles steered home the cross, to be followed by Clark's low 18-yard shot into a corner.

The Cottage duly rose to worship Craven images.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
