fields.headline: Niall cruise on Tyne
fields.standfirst: Dramatic Shearer penalty miss means Quinn emerges the derby hero after all
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 1 - 2 Sunderland
Shearer penalty miss leaves Quinn derby hero.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St. James's Park
fields.body:
The Derby which means more than any other Premiership game to Newcastle United supporters is proving to be a cruel experience for Alan Shearer.

Last season, manager Ruud Gullit famously left out Shearer against Sunderland and Newcastle lost 2-1. Yesterday, the Newcastle captain was guilty of a rare and extremely costly failure from the penalty spot and the outcome was identical.

But, as manager Bobby Robson insisted in the dressing room, there was no necessity for the apology offered by Shearer. His 82nd-minute spot-kick was not as decisive as usual, but it still required an excellent save from Thomas Sorensen to seal Sunderland's victory.

Even Sunderland manager Peter Reid feared the worst as Shearer stepped up. 'He's normally deadly,' said Reid. 'I thought we were heading for an exciting 10 minutes at the end, but Thomas pulled off a magnificent save. He showed he's a top-class keeper.'

Sorensen certainly won't need to buy any drinks on Wearside in the foreseeable future, although grateful supporters will have to get in the queue behind Niall Quinn. His reckless challenge on Robert Lee gifted the penalty, but Sorensen's save ensured the Quinn's winning goal will be remembered long after his foul is forgotten.

Quinn, frustrated for much of the match by 20-year-old Steve Caldwell, directed a 12-yard header beyond keeper Shay Given in the 75th minute. The goal capped a Sunderland revival which was started when Don Hutchison - a Newcastle fan as a youngster - cancelled out an early goal by Gary Speed. The sequence was the same as last season's meeting which led to the swift departure of Gullit, although this is an immensely superior Newcastle line-up and hence a more valid success by Peter Reid's team.

Reid said: 'My players showed tremendous character because we had to dig deep to get a foothold. I know it's still just three points, but it's a fantastic result for our fans.'

More than 19,000 of those Sunderland fans watched the game beamed back to the Stadium of Light, but it was the 3,000 inside St. James' Park who contributed much to the occasion, including an ironic chant of 'Shearer... Shearer' towards the end. St James' Park crowds have too often been of the prawn cocktail variety this season, but this was different. A stadium which is usually only half-occupied 10 minutes before the start was full yesterday.

The prelude to the kick-off was sufficient to underline the importance of a North East derby to players from outside the region - and there were plenty of those yesterday. Newcastle included just one local in Shearer, while Sunderland possessed two in Michael Gray and Hutchison. But the fevered atmosphere and the crowd's delirious reaction to the opening goal from Speed soon indicated this was no ordinary match.

Speed's goal represented the perfect start for Newcastle, yet it should have been even better because the Welsh captain sliced a shot wide from an excellent position after a mere 18 seconds. Sunderland did not learn from that. Three minutes later, Speed thumped a header against a post from Nol Solano's cross and, while grounded, hooked the rebound past keeper Thomas Sorensen for his fourth goal of the season.

Speed was pivotal in an opening half-hour when Newcastle's slicker passing and fluidity too often made Sunderland appear predictable. And Speed twice went close to further goals when his 11th-minute header was smartly saved by Sorensen and a 20-yard shot drifted wide.

Sunderland's response to their early difficulties was relayed through Quinn - notably a ninth-minute lob was turned over by Irish team-mate Shay Given.

Otherwise, it was a largely frustrating half for Reid's team and it prompted the manager to sacrifice defender Chris Makin for winger Julio Arca after 68 minutes. The effect was immediate - Phillips escaped Hughes and his cross was turned in by Hutchison at the far post.

Solano hit the post from a free-kick before Sunderland broke and Quinn met Gray's left-wing cross to beat Given with a fine header.

'You could throw 60 at Quinn from the same position and he wouldn't hit the target,' said Robson, failing to disguise his misery. 'I'm very sad, very low - I thought we would win this one. I was very confident. Alan thinks he cost us the game, but he doesn't need to apologise. This was one penalty he wouldn't want to miss. He won't be feeling too happy tonight.'

fields.bodyText: The Derby which means more than any other Premiership game to Newcastle United supporters is proving to be a cruel experience for Alan Shearer. Last season, manager Ruud Gullit famously left out Shearer against Sunderland and Newcastle lost 2-1. Yesterday, the Newcastle captain was guilty of a rare and extremely costly failure from the penalty spot and the outcome was identical. But, as manager Bobby Robson insisted in the dressing room, there was no necessity for the apology offered by Shearer. His 82nd-minute spot-kick was not as decisive as usual, but it still required an excellent save from Thomas Sorensen to seal Sunderland's victory. Even Sunderland manager Peter Reid feared the worst as Shearer stepped up. 'He's normally deadly,' said Reid. 'I thought we were heading for an exciting 10 minutes at the end, but Thomas pulled off a magnificent save. He showed he's a top-class keeper.' Sorensen certainly won't need to buy any drinks on Wearside in the foreseeable future, although grateful supporters will have to get in the queue behind Niall Quinn. His reckless challenge on Robert Lee gifted the penalty, but Sorensen's save ensured the Quinn's winning goal will be remembered long after his foul is forgotten. Quinn, frustrated for much of the match by 20-year-old Steve Caldwell, directed a 12-yard header beyond keeper Shay Given in the 75th minute. The goal capped a Sunderland revival which was started when Don Hutchison - a Newcastle fan as a youngster - cancelled out an early goal by Gary Speed. The sequence was the same as last season's meeting which led to the swift departure of Gullit, although this is an immensely superior Newcastle line-up and hence a more valid success by Peter Reid's team. Reid said: 'My players showed tremendous character because we had to dig deep to get a foothold. I know it's still just three points, but it's a fantastic result for our fans.' More than 19,000 of those Sunderland fans watched the game beamed back to the Stadium of Light, but it was the 3,000 inside St. James' Park who contributed much to the occasion, including an ironic chant of 'Shearer... Shearer' towards the end. St James' Park crowds have too often been of the prawn cocktail variety this season, but this was different. A stadium which is usually only half-occupied 10 minutes before the start was full yesterday. The prelude to the kick-off was sufficient to underline the importance of a North East derby to players from outside the region - and there were plenty of those yesterday. Newcastle included just one local in Shearer, while Sunderland possessed two in Michael Gray and Hutchison. But the fevered atmosphere and the crowd's delirious reaction to the opening goal from Speed soon indicated this was no ordinary match. Speed's goal represented the perfect start for Newcastle, yet it should have been even better because the Welsh captain sliced a shot wide from an excellent position after a mere 18 seconds. Sunderland did not learn from that. Three minutes later, Speed thumped a header against a post from Nol Solano's cross and, while grounded, hooked the rebound past keeper Thomas Sorensen for his fourth goal of the season. Speed was pivotal in an opening half-hour when Newcastle's slicker passing and fluidity too often made Sunderland appear predictable. And Speed twice went close to further goals when his 11th-minute header was smartly saved by Sorensen and a 20-yard shot drifted wide. Sunderland's response to their early difficulties was relayed through Quinn - notably a ninth-minute lob was turned over by Irish team-mate Shay Given. Otherwise, it was a largely frustrating half for Reid's team and it prompted the manager to sacrifice defender Chris Makin for winger Julio Arca after 68 minutes. The effect was immediate - Phillips escaped Hughes and his cross was turned in by Hutchison at the far post. Solano hit the post from a free-kick before Sunderland broke and Quinn met Gray's left-wing cross to beat Given with a fine header. fields.headline: Everton disarm Gunners
fields.trailText:
Everton 2 - 0 Arsenal
Evereton disarm the Gunners to leave Wenger off the pace.
fields.body:
Manchester United's early win set a challenge to Arsenal as the most likely pretenders to their championship crown. It was one that Arsene Wenger's side proved unable to handle as Everton undid them with a performance of great discipline and fierce commitment - two qualities that their much-fancied opponents were unable to match. What now of the Premiership's supposed two-horse race at the top?

Everton's success was made all the more remarkable by the circumstances that surrounded it. Yesterday their fans were asked to decide on the club's possible relocation to the King's Dock. They are expected to vote overwhelmingly in favour, and after a run of six home matches without a win such an attitude was understandable. They had failed to taste victory in this fixture since the birth of the Premiership, and with two wins in 10 games their form compared unfavourably with Arsenal's 12-match unbeaten run. On top of all that, they were missing 11 first-team players through injury or suspension.

It never showed. Forced to defend for long periods while Arsenal dominated possession, they rarely allowed their visitors a sight of goal. 'When you've got so many players out, you've got to make sure that you work really hard,' said Walter Smith. 'I couldn't ask any more of the players, and though our defence was a rather makeshift one I felt they did very well.'

Arsenal, too, had an unfamiliar look about them, with Alex Manninger starting in goal for the first time this season and six first-team players left at home ahead of Wednesday's Champions League match against Spartak Moscow. But they still fielded a team of 10 full internationals plus Ashley Cole, whose time will surely come. 'It's not an excuse, either for us or for them, if we have players out,' insisted Wenger. 'We just didn't do enough going forward. We always had the ball but never looked dangerous. It's a problem we also had against Derby. We are not so sharp at the moment.'

'Not so sharp' can more accurately be read as 'completely lacking invention'. Of all their attackers - and they often played with four - only Sylvain Wiltord looked ready to match Everton's commitment and tireless running in kind. Dennis Bergkamp was ineffective and Kanu almost invisible. Only once, in the seventh minute, did they seriously threaten to score, as Wiltord and Kanu saw shots blocked before Fredrik Ljungberg's long-range drive was headed on to the bar by Gary Naysmith. The remarkable treble miss served only to instil Everton's defence with more confidence.

And so it was that, despite the imbalance of possession, once Everton took the lead they never looked likely to relinquish it. 'It was a very difficult game for us,' said Wenger. 'Everton were happy to defend and they did that very well. In those circumstances, it was important to get the first goal.'

Given the importance of the first goal, Arsenal could have done a bit more to stop it. A long ball from Everton's left sailed over the head of Oleg Luzhny and fell at the feet of Danny Cadamarteri, a beneficiary of the home side's injury crisis. He took it past Cole with disappointing ease before calmly sidefooting past Manninger to mark his first start of the season with his first goal.

Arsenal increased the tempo of their attacks in an effort to get back in the game, but Everton's lead already appeared comfortable. It became so in the 74th minute when Cadamarteri, having scored one, turned creator. Picking up the ball on the right wing, he turned away from Cole and scampered into the area before squaring to leave Kevin Campbell with a simple fin ish for his first goal against his former club. Perhaps Goodison Park isn't so bad after all.

fields.headline: Celtic break Hearts
fields.standfirst: Martin O'Neill's men turn on the style to reign supreme in Glasgow
fields.trailText:
Celtic 6 - 1 Hearts
Celtic turn on the style and break Hearts.
fields.body:
Celtic ran the risk of ruining their reputation as a team who know how to win but not exhilarate. The idea that Martin O'Neill was in charge of a team of artisans rather than artists had always seemed as untrustworthy as a rumour, but this exceptional display would betray it as a myth.

Pulling double over Hearts virtually throughout the 'contest', the Parkhead side's only blemish was incurred early, when they conceded the opening goal to Colin Cameron. Even the Hearts supporters must have been mystified by the sight of their team taking the lead after a period of unremitting pressure by the home side, during which Antti Niemi had to prevent the ball from crossing his line three times and the visiting defence must have felt as though they had been released into a safari park.

They took a mauling before the relief of Cameron's goal, although the respite was of such short duration that its effects would soon be neutralised. When the Celtic midfield and attack resumed their foraging, they were quite merciless. They were entitled to a certain vengefulness after that opening goal, which amounted to an insult in the light of what had gone before. What followed was testimony to this present Celtic team's ruthlessness.

Cameron's strike coincided with Hearts' first forward thrust, begun with Scott Severin's hard work to win possession in the centre circle and play the ball to his fellow midfielder. Cameron gave it back and, when Severin supplied him a second time, his right-foot chip from the edge of the penalty area twisted and dipped into Robert Douglas's top right corner.

Celtic were level and already on their way to a terrible retribution within a minute. A long free-kick from the right eventually found its way to Bobby Petta on the left and the Dutch wing-back played the ball back to Joos Valgaeren.

The big Belgian defender looked more like David Beckham as he sent a beautifully-controlled right-foot drive from 20 yards curling high to the left of Niemi. The Finnish goalkeeper managed to keep Celtic from at least another two goals on top of the four they did score before the interval.

But two magnificent saves from headers by Henrik Larsson and Jan Mjallby were avenged when the two Swedes scored a little later.

Moravcik, who won the man of the match award, began the rout when he took the loose ball after a free-kick from Mjallby on the right and slotted the low, left-foot drive from 18 yards to the right of Niemi. Larsson got his own back when he ran on to Didier Agathe's forward pass and had his low shot blocked by Niemi, but followed up to bury the rebound behind the goalkeeper.

Mjallby's headed fourth was scored without a challenge, the big defender nodding the ball over the line from six yards after Moravcik had crossed from the left after combining with Petta at a short corner.

Untroubled apart from the moment Cameron scored - and when the same player brought a fine save from Douglas with Hearts' only other genuine, open chance - Celtic had some impressive performers in every department of the team. But it was in midfield, where Moravcik, Alan Thompson, Agathe, Petta and Stilian Petrov controlled the match, that the productivity began.

Thompson continues to burrow into the affections of the Parkhead support, at the heart of many of the most menacing moves and capable of a deadly finish when given the opportunity. He had Niemi diving to his right to stop a low, powerful free-kick from a couple of yards outside the left edge of the penalty box.

But Chris Sutton - who has not appeared fully fit, and certainly not as sharp, since his return from injury - allowed Niemi the save after Petrov's surge through the middle took the ball to Larsson, who flicked it to his partner. The big Englishman had time to carry the ball forward and pick a spot, but hit it early and shoulder high, the kind of shot goalkeepers enjoy.

Sutton was replaced soon after by Tommy Johnson, who played Larsson in for the fifth, the striker's low shot hitting Niemi and crawling over the line.

The sixth came from another marvellous contribution by Agathe, the Frenchman skipping past Gordan Petric on the right, carrying the ball to the six-yard line and leaving Petrov with an unmissable chance with the cut-back.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Beattie bests tame Villa
fields.trailText:
Southampton 2 - 0 Aston Villa
Beattie bests tame Villa
fields.body:
Fortunes can change dramatically in football, as opposing centre-forwards James Beattie and Dion Dublin can testify. Just two weeks ago, Beattie was wondering where his next goal was coming from, having gone 18 months without scoring.

Now he is the toast of this part of the South Coast, having scored two first-half goals to end Villa's five-match unbeaten run and take his personal tally to five in the past three games.

Dublin, on the other hand, looks a shadow of the player who hit a hat-trick here two years ago. The former England striker has scored only two goals this season and looks way off his game, missing chances he would previously have buried without a second thought.

With Julian Joachim just as shy in front of goal, Villa rely heavily on the inspiration of Paul Merson in midfield. Unfortunately for Villa, Merson also had an off day and was substituted at half-time by John Gregory, who was clearly unhappy with his side's opening 45 minutes.

'We were second best to everything in the first half and that is not like us,' he said. 'At 2-0 down we had a mountain to climb, and though we had a fair crack at it after the break, we gave ourselves far too much to do.'

Southampton started sharper and more purposefully, and were rewarded when Beattie put them ahead in the 22nd minute. Jason Dodd chipped the ball forward from the right and Beattie ghosted between Gareth Southgate and David James to head the ball over the stranded goalkeeper and into an empty net. 'That was straight off the training ground,' said a delighted Glenn Hoddle afterwards.

Southampton were 2-0 ahead just two minutes later when Marian Pahars slipped the ball past a line of Villa defenders appealing in vain for offside and Beattie hammered in a shot that James got his hand to but failed to stop.

Coming after his spectacular goals against Chelsea and Sunderland in the previous two games, the young striker's confidence is understandably high. 'He can't wait for the next game to come,' added Hoddle. 'His finishing and work rate are excellent, and I cannot fault him. Crystal Palace were interested in him but I didn't really want to sell.'

Beattie could have had a swift hat-trick if James had not charged out of his area to tackle the former England Under-21 striker in the 25th minute, as Southampton threatened to run riot.

Villa looked more like a top-five side after the break, but found Paul Jones in defiant mood. The Southampton goalkeeper did not have a save to make until the 71st minute, when he dived full-length to keep out a piledriver from George Boateng, and he topped that shortly afterwards when he tipped over a point-blank shot from Villa substitute Lee Hendrie.

'It was a fantastic save,' said Hoddle, whose side are now unbeaten in three games. 'We are on a bit of a run now and have to build on that - especially at home.'

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Winterburn by a head
fields.trailText:
Leeds 0 - 1 West Ham
Winterburn by a head for the handy Hammers.
fields.body:
West Ham's squad were about to board their bus to Yorkshire when Paolo Di Canio complained of a stomach bug, perhaps feeling nauseous at the thought of carrying team-mates he doesn't rate. Had he made the journey he would have eaten a few choice words. An accomplished performance from what Harry Redknapp described rather parsimoniously as '11 players willing to work' earned a triumph which was as impressive as it was important. That spell at the foot of the Premiership is well behind West Ham now.

So effective was the new look front line of Frederic Kanoute supported by Kaba Diawara that Di Canio - and fellow injured absentee Joe Cole - cannot be certain of waltzing back into the side. 'It's very hard to change the team, I couldn't fault any of them,' added Redknapp.

David O'Leary would love to be in a position to shuffle his pack and lamented the fact that it is nigh impossible to sustain a dual domestic and European challenge with an injury ravaged squad. 'That was a tired performance,' he said.

With Real Madrid looming on the horizon this was not the time for Leeds's bright young things to start feeling drained. Their fatigue was put into perspective by a man old enough to father Alan Smith, yet still gallivanting around like a souped-up schoolboy. A precious goal from Nigel Winterburn earned West Ham reward they fully merited at a ground where they haven't tasted victory for more than 20 years.

Half time was seconds away when Diawara and Kanoute linked up to send Trevor Sinclair galloping into the box, and the 36-year-old Winterburn ghosted in to nod home a teasing cross for his first goal in claret and blue. Leeds could muster no reply.

Defensive organisation stifled them, the perfect foundation for two of their starlets to cause all manner of problems. Michael Carrick's mature and astute promptings were a thrilling feature, while Kanoute gave Lucas Radebe a torrid afternoon. 'Freddie was almost unplayable, he was really awesome,' cooed Redknapp. 'He's 6'4", he has strength, pace and skill. He's a real threat.'

Kanoute was one of several visitors who won the admira tion of Leeds manager O'Leary. Rio Ferdinand, who O'Leary has long been interested in, was naturally one of them. The West Ham defender will have raised his considerable stock still further after he dealt comfortably with Mark Viduka as West Ham restricted Leeds to the odd crack from long range. 'I think Rio is a good player, but so is Carrick and Cole. I wouldn't mind a few of them,' quipped O'Leary.

And it wasn't just the young ones who caught the eye. 'Where do you find people like that now? They are a dying breed,' enthused Redknapp of matchwinner Winterburn. The message to Di Canio was loud and clear, and the coach trip home was no doubt a buoyant one.

webTitle: Extra training for social workers requires workplace support

fields.headline: Extra training for social workers requires workplace support
fields.standfirst: Plans to shake up the social work qualification will involve radical changes to the way employers and staff operate, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: Plans to shake up the social work qualification will involve radical changes to the way employers and staff operate, writes Linda Steele
fields.body:
A little learning is a dangerous thing, the government has concluded. Or rather, a lot more learning (perhaps three years rather than two - and that's just the start) is needed to turn out competent, newly qualified social workers.

Social work training is due for a shake-up. The catalyst is the need to raise quality across the board. Published alongside the government's quality strategy in August, were two reports by JM Consulting, commissioned for the four UK health departments. The government is consulting on their proposals for a fundamental reshaping of social work training (and separate but similar debates are happening in Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales).

Recommendations include centres of excellence running the Diploma in Social Work (DipSW) courses according to a national curriculum. This should avoid current inconsistencies in content and quality.

There's general agreement that two years - split roughly 50/50 between college and work placements - aren't enough. "For certain areas, such as child protection and mental health, a three-year course, with mandatory refresher courses, is absolutely necessary," says Havering social services director Anthony Douglas.

JM Consulting also argues that the DipSW - which has a 35% pass level - lacks intellectual depth. Only a degree-level qualification will produce the "competence and self-awareness, critical judgement and analytical and interpersonal skills for safe practice."

Social care minister John Hutton is thought to be in sympathy with this view. But the government is concerned about the effect of upping the profession's entry requirements on the already insufficient numbers of recruits.

Suffolk council training manager Paula Stott believes that traineeships could ease serious recruitment and retention problems. "We need to grow our own," she says. Suffolk, in tandem with Ruskin College, Oxford, and town hall union Unison, has developed a day release DipSW course for its staff who want to become qualified social workers.

The first year saw 150 applicants - 40 of them "ideal", according to Stott - for 18 places. "I suspect that would be the same nationally. They weren't starry eyed idealists. They were knew exactly what they were looking at."

Flexibility appears to be the way ahead, with more sandwich, modular, distance learning, part-time and day releases courses. Andrea Rowe, manager of the employer-led Training Organisation for the Personal Social Services England, is keen to encourage employers to foster links with GNVQ health and social care courses.

Other public services are recruiting in the same pool, she points out, and social care employers need to get in earlier. "Our employers have been a bit sniffy because they generally take older people," she says. "But young people could take a care assistant's job and take NVQ level 3 or 4 and do a social work qualification, as a trainee, later."

A range of routes in, with accreditation for prior, relevant learning and experience, is more likely to suit social work's traditional, older recruits. A full-time degree with student loan is unlikely to be the preferred option for someone with a job, mortgage and family.

The other two strands in creating a confident and competent graduate profession are continuing professional development and an aptitude for conducting and using research in practice. Neither of these will come about without a sea change among many employers, as well as staff. It has begun - but it needs to go further.

"The biggest problem is that staff are not given workplace support or release to do post-qualifying training," says Douglas. "It's primarily a resource rather than a cultural issue. Most staff I know are pretty motivated to do the training, especially the right sort of training. Organisations aren't necessarily geared up to pitching the training at the right level."

And updating your skills through training and research may seem slightly less attractive when you're overworked, with no cover for a heavy caseload if you're away from work.

fields.headline: Arrogant or insolvent?
fields.standfirst: Marie-Jose Kleef on the stark reality behind the Dutch drive for a new Euro League
fields.trailText: Fancy idea from fancy chairmen or a life-saving operation for the balance in European football? Marie-Jose Kleef reports on the stark reality behind the Dutch drive for a new Euro League.
fields.body:
They might have been branded arrogant by Sir Alex Ferguson, but Dutch football clubs know all too well that their part to play in the future of European football is very humble indeed. PSV Eindhoven chairman Harry van Raaij is happy to explain why his brainchild - the Euro League - is not just a fancy idea sprung from the minds of a few ambitious chairmen, but a life-saving operation for the balance in European football.

The Dutch champions waved a sad goodbye to this season's Champions League when they were beaten by Anderlecht to make way for Manchester United in group D's promotion spot. Many at PSV fear they might never again compete like they did in 1988, when they won the European Cup. The club has been presented with a gloomy scenario of continuous further decline. Their tireless, passionate chairman has been working on a plan.

The plan is called the 'Euro League' and is - despite good intentions - hugely unpopular with fans and Uefa alike because it involves some of the biggest clubs in Europe abandoning their national leagues. To underline the urgency felt by those involved in such a drastic and unpopular move, Van Raaij quotes compatriot Johan Cruyff: 'I read in an interview once that when Cruyff was asked by his surgeon if he was ready for his open-heart surgery, he answered: "I'd rather not have it, but I don't think I have a choice." That is exactly how we feel.'

In the past 10 months, seven European clubs who feel their businesses are in danger have come together to find a way to restore the balance in European football. In October representatives of Celtic, Glasgow Rangers, Anderlecht, Benfica, Ajax, Feyenoord and PSV presented their findings to Uefa. To the frustration of Van Raaij, Europe's governing body did not particularly warm to their ideas. Van Raaij states: 'If we accept the current status quo, the smaller countries in Europe will fall behind dramatically.'

Not so long ago any club in Europe capable of filling their stadium and nurturing their youth talent was in with a chance in the European competitions. But no longer. In the days when the sale of broadcasting rights is the most important source of income and when players as young as 17 move to wherever the best money is to be earned, clubs from countries with smaller markets are missing out.

Unsurprisingly, it is all about money. 'The only way to avoid that is if we all go back to amateur football,' says 64-year-old Van Raaij, who was financial director at PSV's founding electronics company, Philips, before he became the club's chairman four years ago.

'The power of the media has made it virtually impossible for clubs in smaller countries to compete with clubs from Italy, Spain, England, France and Germany. In the Netherlands, clubs receive around £1.5 million from the sale of broadcasting rights. In England a new deal could see them end up with 20 times as much. Already when one of my players has one good European game, there are masses of foreign clubs on the phone to buy him. And they won't be short of cash to tempt him. If top clubs in Holland and Portugal want to keep up with clubs - even relegation candidates - in England and Spain, things will need to change.'

The idea is to set up a new 16-team competition featuring the best clubs from the smaller countries. These clubs would still play in their domestic cup tournaments and in the European cups in midweek, but abandon their national league to play their Euro League partners on Saturdays. So far Holland, Portugal, Belgium, Scotland, Denmark and Sweden have been incorporated in the plans, but other countries are desperate to get on that list. Van Raaij: 'I have been swamped with letters from Ireland, pleading to involve Irish clubs in our plans.'

The six countries involved in the current plan would result in a potential market of £50 million. Research by Oliver & Ohlbaum, the bureau that was also responsible for the development of the Premier League and Champions League set-ups, has shown that the new league could raise PSV's income from broadcasting-rights sales to about £15 million.

Apart from the Euro League-partner hopefuls, there is little support for the 'deserters'. Last month Van Raaij spoke to representatives of the Dutch clubs who will be left behind in a competition deprived of its main attractions. 'They are very critical towards these plans. If I was in their shoes I would not like it either. But the Euro League will not be a closed shop. There will be some sort of promotion/relegation ruling.

Like any other competition, the Euro League will benefit from strong feeding competitions.' Sounds nice, but with a projected total rise in revenue in both the domestic leagues and Euro League competition calculated at maximum of 50 per cent in the first three years - and with the budget of PSV rising tenfold in that period - the smaller clubs know exactly who will pay the price.

Van Raaij had anticipated their resistance. His main frustration is the reluctance of Uefa to seriously consider the plans. 'I heard Mike Lee, Uefa's communication director, say that Uefa acknowledges our problems, but they will only negotiate with Uefa countries, not clubs. And they will only support domestic competitions. That is like going to the doctor with a belly-ache to hear him confirm that you have a serious problem without him doing anything about it,' says the disappointed Dutchman. 'They ask us to sympathise with the smaller clubs in our countries. But when did they ever ask the bigger countries in Europe to sympathise with us? The proceeds from the Champions League are not and will never be distributed equally either.

'We are confronted with the results of a united Europe in that our costs are virtually the same as for every other club in Europe. Our income, on the other hand, is limited by the size of our market. Uefa is blocking us to react to those facts accordingly.'

'I thought we were in talks with Uefa, but after hearing Mr Lee I can only conclude that they have not been listening. If things stay as they are, we will have to accept that in less than 10 years none of the smaller countries will compete for the European Cups. In the last eight years only one club from outside the five largest countries managed to win the Champions League (Ajax, '95). Before that more than half of the European cups were won by clubs from the smaller countries.'

Van Raaij plans to retire from the PSV board in two years, about the time that the first Euro League clashes are scheduled to take place. 'I sincerely hope to be able to leave behind a healthy organisation with a bright future.'

In December, Uefa will decide if there is a future for the Euro League. Half of Europe is holding its breath.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Kids are not so green
fields.standfirst: England's Turin side was hardly wet behind the ears, but Peter Taylor's selection gave us a glimpse of the future
fields.trailText: England's Turin side was hardly wet behind the ears, but Peter Taylor's selection gave us a glimpse of the future.
fields.body:
England know better than most to be wary of setting too much store by friendlies. Was not the 'encouraging' performance in Paris in September followed a month later by the debacle against Germany at Wembley?

Fortunately England do not have a game next month, or even the month after that, so why has everyone made such a fuss about Peter Taylor picking a different team and earning a few plaudits on Wednesday night in Turin?

Different is about the only adjective which can properly be used, since despite all the pre-publicity and the early bedtime jokes, the side Taylor sent out to meet the Italians was hardly wet behind the ears. Every single one of the starting line-up had played for England before, and of five substitutes used the only new cap went to Seth Johnson, who almost managed to score with his first touch.

True, Taylor gave England a new shape, but playing three at the back is only what people have been pleading for these last couple of years. Ditto Rio Ferdinand as sweeper. Full marks to Taylor for having the bravery to try it, and to Ferdinand for at least looking the part when defending, but if Rio is as good as Franco Baresi says he is then awarding him a tenth cap hardly counts as radical. Not when his teammate Frank Lampard is sitting on the bench and Joe Cole, had he been fit, would have been fogbound with the Under 21s.

In fact, given Alan Shearer's retirement, Teddy Sheringham's non-selection under Kevin Keegan, David Seaman's inconsistency and injuries to Tony Adams, Sol Campbell, Andy Cole, Graeme Le Saux and Nigel Martyn, the difference between Taylor's Turin side and what would have passed for a normal England team a few months ago amounts to not much more than Martin Keown.

Alan Smith would more than likely have got a game had he not been withdrawn, but as Taylor confirmed afterwards it had been his intention all along to play Ferdinand as sweeper, there might not even have been a place for Wes Brown, if, as seems likely, the experience of Gareth Southgate and Gary Neville was deemed necessary.

Due to prevailing circumstances, an isolated friendly presided over by a caretaker manager making a point as well as cheerfully seizing his moment, Taylor could have turned out practically any side without seriously impinging on England's ability to qualify for the next World Cup. So what on earth was Terry Venables doing, moaning about failing to see the logic of 'dumping' England's senior players? 'Especially when it's pretty much guaranteed that Sven-Göran Eriksson will bring them all back for the World Cup qualifiers in the spring.'

That's the point Tel, actually. If Eriksson brings them all back they can't really have been dumped, can they? Surely the whole point of friendly fixtures, not to mention expensively recruited foreign coaches, is so that you can look forward as well as back and break the cycle of forming your next squad almost exclusively on the basis of the last. Eriksson and Tord Grip will have to look at the situation in March and decide who is playing well and who is available, and on the whole one doubts whether they saw anything on Wednesday which would dissuade them from sending for Sheringham or Adams if they so wish. But what harm can it do to know that Nick Barmby can also play the split-striker role in which Sheringham excels, that Ferdinand can look secure in the middle of a back three or that David James can get through a game without calamity?

Like David Beckham's captaincy and Kieron Dyer's ability to find space (albeit on the flanks where he could surely have been used more effectively), these were all minor positives in England's 1-0 defeat which would have been missed had Taylor heeded Venables' advice. Experience is invaluable in big matches, but it is not the most important commodity in friendlies against half-interested Italians. 'The older players are still good players,' Taylor patiently explained. 'I just thought this was an experiment worth trying, because we had a rare opportunity.'

Taylor did the right thing, not so much by trusting youth as by trusting his players. It is only six months, after all, since Keegan was heard complaining that England couldn't pass. Yet here they were stroking the ball around with panache, retaining possession for significant periods and putting together passing moves which occasionally reached double figures. Here was Emile Heskey, unrecognisable as the figure of fun who spent most his time on the floor in the second half against Portugal in Euro 2000, controlling Beckham's passes neatly and causing problems for some of the world's best defenders.

How did Taylor do that? 'I didn't do anything, it was the players. I just asked them to pass the ball. I told them I didn't mind how much greyer I got, but I wanted them to show what they could do, to play with confidence and try to find each other. It takes a bit of bottle to do that, to look for the right ball and not the easy one, but I was very pleased with the belief they showed. They were very calm, which does them credit. This was high-quality opposition, and they handled the situation well.'

So they did, and when you consider the team Taylor could have fielded - the one with Smith, Brown, Michael Owen, Paul Scholes, Steven Gerrard, Joe Cole and Paul Robinson - there is every reason to believe England can only get better. That is not to say they would do worse by recalling what might now be termed the old guard, just that there is no point debating the matter for the next three months. There is no debate. Whoever is in charge for the next game, and the qualifiers after it, will pick whichever players he believes are up to the task. Just like Taylor did.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Fergie ups the ante in Auntie row

fields.headline: Fergie ups the ante in Auntie row
fields.trailText: The unseemly spat between Sir Alex Ferguson and the BCC took a turn for the litigious last week when the Man Utd manager's lawyers demanded an apology and damages.
fields.body:
What would Lord Reith have made of it all? The Scottish director general, whose British Broadcasting Corporation was viewed almost as reverentially as the Church of England, might have had some difficulty with the organisation's involvement in an unseemly run-in with a football club.

But the world has galloped on since the Twenties and Thirties when Lord Reith had time to concentrate on championing the moral and intellectual role of broadcasting in the community. His latest successor, Greg Dyke, would no doubt crave an opportunity for such Olympian ponderings, but the mundane keeps interrupting.

Dyke's latest concerns include the row between the BBC and Manchester United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson, which took a turn for the litigious last week when the footballing knight's lawyers announced their client wanted an apology and substantial damages for a passage that appeared in the September issue of Match of the Day magazine.

Until then, the feud had been waged unofficially with Ferguson refusing to speak to the BBC, a state of affairs communicated to the nation by various asides from Gary Lineker while introducing Match of the Day on Saturdays.

Ferguson is notoriously sensitive to criticism and a lingering frostiness between him and the Radio 5 Live commentator, Alan Green, has helped to make him wary of the BBC.

So it was hardly surprising that he was unamused when MOTD magazine, flagging up a less than obsequious critique of Ferguson's career by their editor Tim Glynne-Jones, referred unflatteringly to the manager's attitude to perceived opponents of United.

Ferguson's immediate response was to stop speaking to the BBC and to tell his minions to be similarly uncommunicative. As it was an action that infringed the spirit rather than the letter of the contract between the Premiership and MOTD, there was little anyone could do to make Ferguson call off his boycott.

Quite what led Ferguson to up the ante is hard to say, although the probability is that he recognised the problems of sustaining what was essentially a private spat. Taking legal action gives it more substance.

The BBC have preferred to take the line that least said soonest mended, which they should have known would not have been the case where Ferguson was concerned.

The fact that MOTD will stop showing Premiership action from the start of next season, when coverage will transfer to ITV, might also have persuaded them to make a more vigorous response to Ferguson's unilateral retaliation, although the return of live coverage of the FA Cup to the BBC in 2001, when United's matches are likely to be prime choices, presumably outweighed this.

In the meantime, there is resentment within the Beeb that a magazine with no link with MOTD other than its name has damaged the flagship football show.

'It's not as if Niall Sloane was writing in the magazine as the BBC's executive editor of football and was blasting off at Ferguson,' said one insider.

There is also a general feeling of frustration in dealing with Ferguson. As one source close to the BBC said: 'As everyone knows, it's not just the BBC who Ferguson is treating like this. There are a number of different elements in the media, which, for his own reasons, he won't deal with. And he never explains himself, so everyone has to work on assumptions.'

We can only assume that normal service will not be resumed for a little time yet.

fields.headline: The world's most uncivilised fans
fields.trailText: After the behaviour of their fans in Turin last week, Italy risks taking over the mantle of 'dirty old man of football' from England.
fields.body:
Italians are growing increasingly shocked at the bad behaviour of their football fans. The Italy-England friendly and other recent events suggest the problem is getting worse.

Italian newspapers deplored the racist booing of England's Emile Heskey during Wednesday's match in Turin. This followed the abuse hurled at Arsenal's Patrick Vieira last month by Lazio's player Sinisa Mihajlovic.

However, concerned Italians say the problem goes further than racism. Arrigo Sacchi, Italy's former coach, commented in the weekly Rigore this week: 'We have the least inhabitable, most uncivilised and poorly educated stadia of the world. The sporting culture is broadly deficient.'

The Italy-England game proved his point. God Save The Queen was loudly whistled, the Torino fans in the ground jeered the Juventus players Pippo Inzaghi and Alessandro del Piero, while the Juve fans at the opposing end chanted abuse at Torino and at their own manager, Carlo Ancelotti. The two ends united only to boo Heskey.

'An ugly game but the worst was in the stands,' summed up the quality daily La Repubblica in a headline. It called the booing of Heskey 'ritual', while the Corriere della Sera newspaper spoke of 'the lowest levels of pure racism'. However, the pink sports daily Gazzetta dello Sport gave priority to the partisan abuse of Del Piero.

In Italy, an almost entirely white nation with a powerful far-right movement, little attention has been paid so far to racism in football. T-shirt campaigns against it have been largely ineffectual. The 'Ultra' fans of many clubs are openly racist and are linked to far-right movements. The racism last season was among the worst on record.

The football establishment seems little concerned. When Lazio were fined about £1500 last season after their fans had abused the black Venezia player Bruno N'Gotty, the then Italian manager Dino Zoff commented: 'I don't know whether you could really call that racism. I think it could just be a question of people making fun of someone.' He explained that fans picked on tall, short or grey-haired players too.

Gianluigi Buffon, the Italian keeper in the game against England, was spotted last season wearing a T-shirt with the Fascist slogan 'Death to those who surrender.' He said he had no idea of the history of the phrase.

There was further controversy this season, when the keeper picked 88 as his Parma squad number. The number is used by neo-Nazis to represent 'Heil Hitler', because H is the eighth letter of the alphabet. Again, Buffon denied any knowledge of such associations.

Italy risks taking over the mantle of 'dirty old man of football' from England. 'The English fans, in the ground at least, behaved themselves well,' noted La Repubblica on Thursday. England fans have caused little trouble since Euro 2000, and hooliganism is fairly dormant at English grounds, while legislation against racist chanting has also been passed.

In Italy the problems only seem to be getting worse. Juventus this week wrote to the Turin police about threats made to its players after recent poor performances. The Juventus defender Ciro Ferrara has suggested closing down Serie A for a weekend as a statement to the fans.

fields.headline: Don't be too nice, David
fields.trailText: By keeping the lid too tight on his emotions, did David Beckham unwittingly to England's defeat against Italy?
fields.body:
There he was, the new mature David Beckham, captaining England for the first time with a restraint that augured well for his and their future. Did it though? By keeping the lid too tight on his emotions, did Beckham unwittingly cost England the game?

It looked a penalty - even if less of one than Alessandro Nesta bringing down Emile Heskey - when Rino Gattuso nudged Beckham and the Italian was subsequently fortunate to escape censure when admonishing his midfield opposite number with a flick of the wrist to Beckham's back. You sensed that Kim Milton Nielsen, the man who sent off Beckham against Argentina just over two years ago for a flick of a foot, would not have missed it.

Admirably, Beckham settled for a verbal volley as retaliation, scarcely needing a prescient Ray Parlour intervening between him and his irritant. Then, within a minute, Gattuso had scored with his long-range shot. The closest man, Beckham, was slow to shut him down, arriving too late after the ball had been despatched and then a yard from making any contact with the player. It looked as if Beckham was still worrying about what he might do if he got too close.

Such was Beckham's sense of image and responsibility that the assertive, aggressive figure brought up by Manchester United to win the personal battle against his opposite number had turned momentarily into a more submissive shadow, willing to concede ground rather than risk punishment, and conceding with it, albeit inadvertently, the winning goal.

Now Beckham has learned his lessons well. Since France '98, he has erased the angry legacy of St Etienne with a succession of committed and accomplished performances for the national team; a shaft of light in a dark age. His love of the game and his family has won over all but the most rabid of United-haters.

He has, in addition, cut out the excesses in his game - a foot left in here and there, a tendency to dive - and emerged as a player of world stature. His central performance in Turin showed a range of passing to lift him from merely an awesome crosser of a ball. A role model in many ways, a model professional.

There is, too, a necessary edge to being a professional. At times, United have been boorish in the heat of the contest but they have the quality of winners instilled by Sir Alex Ferguson and that entails winning the one-on-one contests, physically and tactically. For a costly moment, Beckham lost his last Wednesday night.

It was a lesson for him and us. England need David Beckham on the field, able to to walk away from a flashpoint, but they need a David Beckham with the spikiness to his game that makes him the winner that he is. Responsibility should not reduce effectiveness, fear of headlines that undermine his recent charm offensive must not mean him learning lessons too well. Let us hope that the captaincy inspires rather than inhibits.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: A game of tabloid tennis
fields.trailText: One of the reasons I get so much enjoyment from managing Coventry is that I do not have to deal with the media as much as a number of my counterparts elsewhere.
fields.body:
One of the reasons I get so much enjoyment from managing Coventry is that, as this is a comparatively low-profile club, I do not have to deal with the media as much as a number of my counterparts elsewhere.

Some managers relish being in the spotlight - display a notebook or microphone in front of them, and they come alive. I think most managers, however, while accepting it is part of their job to communicate with the media to keep the fans informed about their teams and football in general, find it something of an ordeal.

I do. I can talk about football all day, but it's a different story when I'm called upon to do so in the context of a formal media interview. I get on well with most football journalists, but if you were to ask me if I trusted them, I would have to say: 'Not totally.' While I feel I can relax with some journalists more than others, I am always on my guard to a certain extent.

The reason is that I have a reasonably clear understanding of what the majority of them are looking for from people like me and the pressure on them to get it.

I tend to look upon media interviews as matches of verbal tennis, with the person at the other end - the server - firing in questions designed to get a response that will provide him with a good story, and me hitting them back into his court.

There was a good example of how the game works the other day, when I received a 5pm call from a journalist about a newspaper report that Coventry's goalkeeper Magnus Hedman was on the point of being transferred to Arsenal.

'Can I have your comment on this?' he asked.

'The first I heard of it was when my wife drew my attention to the newspaper report 15 minutes ago.'

For me, that was the end of the matter. But the journalist persisted: 'Can I quote you as saying that Hedman is under contract and is not going anywhere?'

He was only doing his job, but I had fears about where the development of the subject might lead to. As we were talking, I had a vision of headlines such as 'Hands off our keeper, Arsène' or 'Strachan tells Gunners no-go over Hedman.'

There was no substance in the story and I saw no reason to keeping it going. Sometimes, the more you talk about something, the more you can dig a hole for yourself.

Obviously, some people in football play the 'tennis' game better than others. One who clearly does not play it at all is West Ham's Paolo Di Canio. An interview with the Italian must be tantamount to being handed a Christmas present; in addition to being one of the most talented strikers in the Premiership, he is also arguably the most outspoken. As even his own team-mates are liable to get stick from him - hardly ideal when you are trying to establish a strong dressing-room harmony - it should come as no surprise that this side of Di Canio has apparently become a major source of concern for the manager, Harry Redknapp.

No doubt, Di Canio would argue that he is only being honest, that there's nothing wrong in saying what's on one's mind. However, while I can appreciate the point, I have to say that if everyone in football did that, the game would explode.

The question of where the line should be drawn has long been one of the sticking points in the relationship between football clubs and the media. When one considers the extent to which the football media has grown, it is hardly surprising that it has become more volatile than ever.

The remarkable increase in the number of people covering the game these days, for newspapers and magazines, TV and radio stations and dotcom companies, has inevitably also meant an increase in the competition for high-impact stories. It seems to me that, in some media areas, the quest for these has become little short of desperate. Thus, the nature of a lot of those 'stories' - in terms of both the degree of exaggeration and the controversy they are designed to provoke - leaves me in no doubt that the situation has got out of hand.

A particular hobby-horse of mine concerns the often outrageous stick meted out to clubs and individuals on radio phone-ins. I don't necessarily blame the fans for going over the top, but occasionally I get the impression the presenters have wound them up and encouraged them to do so. The result is what I would describe as 'yob radio.'

I have already fallen out with the Coventry City correspondent for our local radio station. When conducting a phone-in on whether I should be sacked, he implied that I owed my survival in the job to my friendship with the chairman, Bryan Richardson, pointing out that we sometimes go away together on short breaks.

The correspondent has not been banned by the club, but I felt duty bound to take a stand on his comment. The result is that while he can attend my press conferences, he is not allowed to ask me any questions directly.

Nobody should feel he is above criticism and I certainly don't. What I object to is criticism that is not constructive, and is personal.

As far as radio phone-ins are concerned, I wish they were all like the one fronted by Tom Watt on Talksport. He clearly has a respect for professionals, an understanding of the problems we face, and the result is a programme which I find very well balanced and stimulating.

The compliment, I should add, has nothing to do with the fact that he once worked for The Observer.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today.
fields.body:
Visit London's largest antiques fair at Alexandra Palace, with 700 stalls; 11.30am-5pm. Alexandra Palace Way, N10.

Brief Encounters, one of Britain's leading short film festivals, will hold competitions for aspiring writers and filmmakers at the Watershed Media Centre in Bristol. Today, the British premiere of four Beckett short films is followed by a talk with Anthony Minghella. Screenings from 11am-5.30pm. Canon's Road, Bristol BS1 5TX; £4.50, concs £3. Box office 0117 9253845.

Tate St Ives presents Coastal Journey, a series by the key English modernist Peter Lanyon depicting towns and shores of the West Country. Porthmeor Beach, St Ives, Cornwall;. £3.95, concs £2.50 (01736 796226).

The Richmond Festival, until the end of November, features appearances from authors from Britain and abroad. Crime writer P. D. James is at the Orange Tree Theatre today. The festival also offers guided tours and walks of the area and its literary connections; 4pm Festival prices £5-8 with concs. (0208 332 0534 w/days).

The world famous Shaolin monks will perform in Cambridge, incorporating theatre and music with their incredible martial arts skills. Corn Exchange, Parsons Court, Wheeler Street; 8pm (01223 357851) and on Tuesday at Ipswich's Regent Theatre (01473 433100).

Enjoy a Traditional Finnish Christmas Fair at the 100 year-old Finnish church, 13 Albion Street, London SE1; 10am-6pm (020 7237 4668). Entrance 50p.

Visit an exhibition of sacred Indian art, from ancient times until the twentieth century, at the Sainsbury Centre of Visual Art, University of East Anglia, Norwich; 11am-5pm, £2. (01603 456060).

Go to the twelfth International Guitar Festival of Great Britain at Wirral in Merseyside, until 27 November. Events at the Floral Pavilion in New Brighton and Pacific Road start at 8pm. (0151 666 5060).

Paranormalist Uri Geller will explain the theories in his book Mind Medicine at the Southend Natural Healing Exhibition, Garon Park, Eastern Avenue, Southend, Essex; 2pm, £10. (01702 613000).

One of the finest collections of early Italian art still in private hands in Britain is being shown fat the National Gallery of Scotland, Edinburgh. Last day today 12pm-5pm. Free. (0131 624 6200).

fields.headline: Way back Sven...
fields.standfirst: Arsenal profit from an old lesson dished out by England's new man :   7 Nov, 1991
fields.trailText:
Focus on Benfica
Ian Ridley recalls November 7, 1991, when England's new man (then manager of Benfica) taught Arsenal a lesson.
fields.body:
It was one of those cracking and crackling European nights at Highbury, optimism heavy in the North London air. Amid the anti-climactic conclusion that was to follow, though, few would have thought that it would be of such import for the future of Arsenal and indeed England nearly a decade later.

Nine years ago this very month, Benfica were the visitors. It was the first season of a new Champions League format, the first year of English participation after the five-year Heysel ban. Arsenal had drawn 1-1 in Lisbon and hopes were high that they would qualify for the last eight, with its experimental format of two groups of four. After all, they had beaten FK Austria 6-1 here in the previous round.

Arsenal battered the Portuguese in true George Graham style but after taking the lead, were pegged back to 1-1. In extra time, Tony Adams hit a post - 'from about a yard; the worst miss of my career', he recalls - but canny Benfica broke out to win 3-1. They were managed by none other than Sven-Göran Eriksson. The Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, now also FA vice-chairman and recently its headhunter, took note.

It wasn't quite the footballing Road to Damascus experience that a European defeat by Red Star Belgrade proved for Bill Shankly's Liverpool in 1973, when the legend realised a change of approach was needed, but it was certainly a reference point for Dein. Graham brought Cup-Winners' Cup success to Arsenal, doggedly sticking to his guns. Dein foresaw the arrival of the Champions League expansion and knew modernisation was necessary; be there or be Tottenham Hotspur. You can bet the name of Eriksson, then settled in Italy, did more than just cross Dein's mind before he approached Arsène Wenger.

Eriksson's response to his Benfica team's victory was, in hindsight, revealing. 'I was in London that night and I've never seen him more happy with a result,' says his friend of 15 years, Bryan King, the former Millwall and Coventry goalkeeper. 'It meant so much to him to beat Arsenal at Highbury. He had been there to study them training years earlier when he was a young coach. In those days, Don Howe was coaching the Arsenal side and Sven remembered all that. It was a special result for him.'

'Physically they were stronger than us but on the ground we were the better team with the better technique,' said Eriksson himself that night, before adding. 'For 12 to 15 years I have been a great admirer of English football. I like the mentality of always attacking.'

English football has learnt much from that banner-carrying night - Arsenal in particular - such as modifying always attacking to attacking when opportune. This season, there are three teams in the last 16; the days of the mid-Nineties when every autumn seemed to provoke debates entitled 'What's wrong with English club football?' seem distant.

'I think our '91 team had the potential to win the European Cup,' says Adams, still Arsenal captain. 'It was partly that we had no experience after five years out, partly that it wasn't a league system then and partly impatience on our part. We met a very good Benfica team as well, remember, and two-leg ties are very unpredictable. Now, the top teams come through to the last eight, which was the idea of Uefa.

'We had success in the Cup-Winners' Cup and we beat some of the best. Parma were at the top of their league, so were Paris St Germain. But we've got more great English teams challenging now and we are one of them. I do believe that when Manchester United won the treble, it could have been us. I believe that year we were the two best teams in Europe at the time.'

Adams also believes that Arsenal are better equipped than ever for European competition. 'We played to our strengths in '91 and opposing teams didn't like that. There was a resilience then. Now we also have continental players with experience of Europe. There are no surprises now. Liverpool were very successful in the Seventies and Eighties with their English style and British-based players and they added a bit more. United have also done very well with that approach. I think with our players from abroad we have it as well. It's a good blend.'

Indeed with Adams and Martin Keown in central defence, allied to a clutch of penetrative attacking players - Robert Pires proving himself especially a runner always looking to hurt the opposition - Arsenal this season could well be England's best prospect for the competition. It does depend, mind, on them converting some of their many chances again, by not spurning the scruffy goal in attempting the spectacular.

Good enough to win the European Cup for the first time? 'Yes, but then I've said that for the last two years,' says Adams. 'Injuries and suspensions have worked against us. You've just got to keep buying the lottery ticket. It's no good having talent, you've got to have the opportunity as well. We're back in there with a great shout, a great squad and a great chance of winning it.'

Adams acknowledges that it needed a man like Wenger to update Arsenal. 'Yes it did but I am glad we've got the players as well. The buck stops with them. I can't see Arsène having Stevie Morrow, Paul Davis and Ian Selley in his midfield. With the financial backing of the club he has been able to bring quality players to Arsenal. He's been allowed to encourage that and take us to another level. All due respect to Arsène but without that he would have had to resort to Grampus Eight coaching, telling people where to go and how to kick it.'

According to Adams, he and Arsenal will travel to Moscow to play Spartak next Wednesday having learnt from bitter experience the huge significance of the first match in a group, draws against Lens and Fiorentina in the past two seasons being scant reward after dominating the matches and exit after the first phase resulting.

'A very important game,' says Adams. 'They are very dangerous and they are going to be very up for the game. It's been reported that they are expecting us to be the worst team in the group, so if they are to go through, Arsenal are going to be the team they are looking to beat.

'But we had a great start in the last phase this time around, winning in Prague and beating Lazio, and after that the pressure was off. If you don't get those results you are chasing your tail. The last couple of seasons, we went away and didn't get the points on the board early. Moscow will be a very important game from that point of view. I really believe that the first two games before Christmas, in Moscow and against Bayern Munich at home, will determine whether we will go through.'

Adams himself expects to make the trip, having recovered from a deep-seated bruise running the length of a thigh. Much may have been made of youth in recent weeks, what with Leeds United's vibrant progress and England's promise, and the unfettered vitality can indeed be refreshing. It can also mean impatience, though, as a young Arsenal team found out those nine long years ago.

This looks like a job for experience, just as England's World Cup games next Spring also do when it comes to Adams and company. That gleaned the hard way against Eriksson's Benfica by Graham's broadsword of a team will be needed now by Wenger's stiletto.

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Of relative interest | Stay in a volcano | Diamond geezers
fields.body:
Of relative interest
Dreading the relatives coming to stay for Christmas? Perhaps you could tactfully slip them a copy of Heritage Hotels' winter brochure (0870 400 8855). which has special rates over Christmas for friends and family who need a place to rest their head over the festive season. From 18 December to 9 January, more than 40 hotels around England will be offering room rates from £50 a night, including breakfast. And once the mistletoe and madness has passed, you could unwind with a Candlelit New Year package at one of 11 hotels. Prices start from £75 for a one-night stay at The Gifford in Worcester with champagne, four-course dinner and breakfast.

Stay in a volcano
The Pico de Fogo is an active volcano which last erupted in 1995. Explore Worldwide's (01252 760 100) new Cape Verde tour offers the chance to spend two nights in a village located in the volcanic crater and trek through the barren moonscape and deserted beaches of this remote archipelago off the coast of West Africa. The 14-day trip, which is graded as easy to moderate and costs from £1,035, is one of three volcano treks which the adventure specialist has added to its 2001/2 brochure. Lava lovers can also take their chances on a trek through Tanzania's Great Rift Valley and a three-island tour of Indonesia.

Diamond geezers
Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) is offering visitors to the diamond capital of Europe the chance to win one of the precious gems on a complimentary tour of the Stoeltie Diamond Factory in Amsterdam. Guests taking the tour on a Saturday or a Wednesday will be offered a glass of bubbly which could contain a diamond worth at least £120. The factory will also clean and polish all personal jewellery free of charge while you wait. The offer will be available from 1 December until 10 March. Hotel prices in the city start at £197 for a two-night break at the two-star Hoksbergen hotel with Eurostar tickets.

Corsican views
The rooftop terrace of the Casa Vista Mare - a four-bedroom townhouse in the centre of Calvi's fifteenth-century citadel in Corsica - has uninterrupted views to the Mediterranean and is a short walk from the marina, a sandy beach and the town's bars and restaurants. A week in the house costs from £340 per person based on eight sharing. It's one of several new properties added to the Corsican Places 2001 brochure (01903 748180) which features more than 80 villas, village houses, apartments and hotels on the island, including a selection of mountain auberges.

Free trips to Heathrow
Heathrow Express is offering free transport from central London to the airport this winter for anyone checking in skis, snowboards or golf clubs at its Paddington station check-in desks. Seventeen airlines offer a check-in facility at Paddington to relieve travellers of bulky luggage and ease airport queues. The offer is valid from now until 1 February. Rail tickets can be pre-booked at www.heathrowexpress.co.uk.

Health check

Since 12 October, 78 suspected cases of Japanese encephalitis, including14 deaths, have been reported in eight districts in Andhra Pradesh state in southern India. Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito. Many who become infected may not show any symptoms, but in severe cases of brain inflammation the fatality rate can be as high as 60 per cent. Preventative measures including disease surveillance, mosquito control and the immunisation of children have been implemented. Travellers who intend to stay for a long time in rural areas where rice paddy fields and pig farming co-exist should consider Japanese encephalitis immunisation and take steps to avoid mosquito bites.

To obtain a health brief tailored to your journey call the MASTA Travellers Health Line on 0906 8 224 100 (calls charged at 60p/min).

For general travel health advice visit the website at www.masta.org.

fields.headline: Following the trail
fields.standfirst: Cross-country skiing is an antidote to downhill - it gives you time to marvel at the scenery. Here are five resorts that have altitude and attitude
fields.trailText: Cross-country skiing is an antidote to downhill - it gives you time to marvel at the scenery. Here are five resorts that have altitude and attitude
fields.body:
Ceillac, France, is tucked into a beautiful corner of the High Alps close to the Italian border at an altitude of 1,640m. It enjoys a good snow record and is well known for its cross-country skiing, with 56 kilometres of trails, some as high as 2,000m. The hidden valleys of the Queyras National Park maintain a strong individual character and culture. The village is at the end of the road and the only way to penetrate the hinterland is on skis. Some people think that this is where Hannibal crossed the Alps.

Hotel Cascade, two-star, half-board seven nights in January from £497 sharing, by air to Marseilles then by rail and taxi. Inntravel (01653 629034).

Kanderstec, Switzerland, at 1,170m in the beautiful Bernese Oberland, is still unspoilt though it has been attracting holiday visitors for more than 100 years. It is in the upper valley of the River Kander, south west of Interlaken. It gets its name from the first footbridge - 'steg' - over the stream. Surrounded by dramatic mountain scenery it has been called a secluded Shangri-La. There are 130km of excellently prepared trails, one even floodlit for use at night. There is plenty of non-skiing activity, including sleigh rides, skating, curling and tobogganing. Après-ski is quiet.

Hotel Alpina, two-star, half-board seven nights in January from £438 sharing, Friday Swissair flights from Heathrow to Zurich and transfers included. Kuoni (01306 742500).

Sjusjoen, Norway, is a pleasant lakeside village in a spruce forest about 20km east of Lillehammer, which was the centre for the 1994 Winter Olympics. Ideal terrain for cross-country skiing, with many small villages linked by a large, well-maintained area with 300km of trails. At 900m altitude, snow conditions are usually excellent. Beginners often manage to ski around its lake, which freezes up, on their second day. Dog sledding or fishing through the ice are options if you want a change.

Fjellheimen Hoyfjellssenter, half-board with packed lunch seven nights in February from £475 sharing, flights and transfers included. Waymark Holidays (01753 516477).

Åre, Sweden, is set beside a large lake and is the country's premier downhill resort. Getting about on skis is a way of life for most Swedes so it is not surprising that cross-country skiing is a favourite activity. There are 84km of trails available, mainly on the south side of the lake which is frozen during the winter, six kilometres of which are floodlit. For expert cross-country skiers there are another 210km of marked but unprepared trails in the vicinity. Despite its modest height of 380m, Åre is far enough north to have a good snow record. The après-ski is enthusiastic.

Hotel Sunwing, four-star with indoor pool, half-board seven nights in January from £555 sharing, flights and transfers included. Crystal Holidays (0870 848 7000).

Leutasch, Austria, is a tranquil valley edged by the mountain grandeur of the Zugspitze Alps. This is farm country and the villages each have their own onion-domed churches standing just a little taller than the houses with painted frescos. There are 250km of trails to choose from. Beginners enjoy easy runs across the snow-covered meadows while the experts can wind through the wooded hillsides. You can stop for lunch or a drink in one of the many small, friendly inns that are dotted around. At just over 1,100m this is a reasonably snow-sure area.

Hotel Xander, four-star with indoor pool, half-board, seven nights in January £777 sharing, flights and transfers included. Headwater Holidays (01606 813395).

webTitle: Under the spell of pixie dust in Disneyland Paris

fields.headline: Under the spell of pixie dust
fields.standfirst: Kit Spring  finds herself as enchanted as her daughter by Christmas at Disneyland Paris
fields.trailText: Kit Spring finds herself as enchanted as her daughter by Christmas at Disneyland Paris.
fields.body:
It's not how you expect a child to react to the Disney experience. 'Mum! Get me out of here,' 10-year-old Harriet hissed urgently, pushing her face into my side. Mind you, we were in pitch darkness, maniacal laughter and screeching was coming from somewhere much too close and we were crammed into a small, shuddering room shoulder to shoulder with strangers whose faces we could picture even though we couldn't actually see them because we had had 45 minutes to study them in the queue for spooky Phantom Manor.

'It's fine,' I said firmly. 'It's fun.' A disbelieving snort came from the depths of my jacket. I just had time to wonder if this had been a good choice for our first Disneyland Paris ride when the doors were flung open and we were ushered into cars to set off through the haunted house.

And it was amazing. When we finally emerged, we were total converts to the power of Disney. Our main reason for going to the park was to experience Christmas Disney-style and we had already submitted completely to the illusion it was the festive season - despite its being only the middle of November in the outside world.

And that's what Disneyland Paris is - another world. If you took the Eurostar from Waterloo straight to the park itself - which is an option - it would be easy not to realise you were in France. (All the staff smile and smile and smile. There was one exception; a woman who served us ice cream with the sullen rudeness only ever achieved by French shop assistants. And quite honestly, it was refreshing to see that Disney has not completely broken the local spirit.) Harriet and I travelled by Eurostar to Paris and then got a coach to the Hotel New York, where we were staying for a couple of nights, just five minutes' walk from the park. The hotel, with its Art Deco bedrooms, was very comfortable and bedecked with Christmas trees. Icicles hung from the ceiling of a silvery snow tunnel which served as the entrance to a huge dining room that had been turned into a winter wonderland for our dinner and a show that evening.

Imagination, illusion and - there's no denying it - magic is everywhere at Disneyland, especially if you're with a child. We dumped our bags and raced for the park. It was late afternoon and, as dusk fell, the myriad lights across the park, down Main Street USA and round the Sleeping Beauty's castle twinkled and shimmered. We wandered into Adventureland with its Arabian Nights and tropical islands theme. Most visitors had left and we climbed high up into the Swiss Family Robinson's tree house and then delved down into the caves of Davy Jones's locker with a real sense of adventure and mystery.

Next day, with a frosty sun gleaming, we wandered back to the park, past the skaters on the rink outside the hotel. Disneyland is a wonderful experience if you suspend all disbelief. Everywhere is pretty, colourful and clean, everything is impressive or amazing or cute or spectacular. There is nothing grim or drab or grey. As we headed across the main square of the perfect fantasy small American town that makes up the principal shopping area, Harriet said: 'Do you think the music will drive us mad?' I had my doubts but was determined to approach the Disney experience with an unjaded mind. And, indeed, soon it was impossible to imagine life without merry or sweet music floating up from the drain covers. It was completely cocooning.

Harriet, in any case, was so thrilled with the Disney characters wandering around and with the rides that she had lost all critical sense within a couple of hours. But you'd have to be a complete curmudgeon to go to Disneyland at Christmas and not feel festive.

The Christmas parade is a terrific spectacle based on the Nutcracker theme with huge floats and dancers in amazing costumes making their way up Main Street. We got there early enough to get places right on the pavement and it was well worth the wait as the parade takes a good while to pass by. Frontierland has a Wild West theme and Fantasyland is full of rides for smaller children. Disneyland Paris also has Main Street USA, which is full of souvenir shops. And Disney Village is a sort of Los Angeles in France and has clubs, bars, restaurants and shops.

There are five hotels and a lake, eight car parks and a train that goes all round the park.

I ate at Times Square restaurant in Hotel New York (the food was very good) and at the Steak House in Disney Village, which also had very good food. At Times Square there was special Christmas entertainment and Disney characters.
