It would scare younger children as it scared me a lot. The queue was about 45 minutes and the ride about 15 minutes. Pirates of the Caribbean was a funny and exciting ride on water that takes you through villages and caves belonging to pirates. 1 You can beat the queues by going to the park as soon as it opens at 9am. This is really worth it. You will get straight on to the ride of your choice.

2 Stay as late as you can in the evening. The queues get shorter as the crowds thin.

3 Disney has introduced Fastpass on the most popular rides. You can choose to put your park ticket into a special turnstile to be given a return time. You can then go and do something else in the meantime before going straight on to the ride. You can do this at only one ride at a time.

4 Try not to eat between noon and 2pm. The queues are huge.

5 Get to the parades in Main Street a good half hour beforehand to be sure of a good view - especially if you have children with you.

6 Wrap up well. Be prepared for rain. Wear comfy shoes.

Getting there

During the Christmas festivities, prices start from £231 per adult and £106 per child for two nights at the Sequoia Lodge, based on two adults and two children (3-11) sharing a room, travelling Eurostar to Disneyland Paris and having unlimited access to the park. fields.headline: Have a nice day, comrade
fields.standfirst: Muscovites are being trained to smile in an effort to boost visitor numbers
fields.trailText: Muscovites are being trained to smile in an effort to boost visitor numbers.
fields.body:
Standing in Red Square with my back against the rust-coloured walls of the Russian History Museum I try to work out what is missing. It's a cold, bright Saturday morning and the sunlight reflecting off the well-worn cobbles makes it difficult to see without squinting.

To my right are the Kremlin walls, which allow only tantalising glimpses of the palaces and golden cupolas within. To my left are the elegant arcades of GUM, the first Soviet department store. Pronounced 'goom', it used to be as dreary and spartan as its name sounds, but stroll through its designer boutiques and speciality shops today and you could be in Milan. Ahead is the riotous confection of St Basil's Cathedral built by Ivan IV to celebrate his victory over the Mongols before he turned Terrible, adopting a severed dog's head as his mascot and setting about the random torture and massacre of whole villages. Beyond is the steely grey Moskva River.

A party of Russian schoolchildren queue crocodile-style to enter Lenin's Mausoleum while a shivering bride poses for pictures wearing a silver puffer jacket over her white dress. Street vendors laden with Russian Army hats stand around smoking and waiting for business. And that's when it hits me. Where are all the tourists?

This must surely be one of the most impressive squares in any city. Maybe not the most beautiful but the vast, rolling expanse of it and the resonance of recent history are enough to make the hairs on the back of your neck stand up. A day's sightseeing here can range from the sublime - notably the eye-bulging collection of jewels and Fabergé eggs in the Kremlin's Armoury - to the vaguely ridiculous (though it's meant to be solemn) experience of visiting Lenin's embalmed body, which is creepy and surreal from start to finish.

While I would rather queue for 20 minutes in the cold to see a dead Socialist leader than stand for one minute in the sunshine watching a motionless mime artist pretending to be a statue on Barcelona's Ramblas, most people would not. Which explains why there are more British tourists in Barcelona than in Moscow on this and, indeed, most weekends.

In an attempt to reverse declining numbers of foreign tourists (put off by reports of soaring street crime and the war with Chechnya) the Moscow City Government has decided to make the Russian capital - and its people - more welcoming for visitors. Within the next two years, Moscow will open its first tourist information centre and create 20 landscaped 'tourist zones' with cafes, toilets, benches, signposting and souvenir shops. It will also train a special tourist police force, which will patrol visitor hotspots, such as the Kremlin and Red Square, offering assistance and peace of mind to visitors.

There are also plans to build more three-star hotels to bridge the accommodation gap between Soviet-era monstrosities such as the 6,000 room Hotel Rossia and the luxurious five-star Hotel Baltschug Kempinski which sit facing each other on opposite banks of the Moskva River. The new tourism strategy goes far beyond the cosmetic: it will also attempt to get under the skin of the Russian people with a government-sponsored campaign to teach the citizens of Moscow to smile. Not at each other, because they do that anyway, but at tourists.

The idea goes something like this: rather than drumming their fingers impatiently on the counter, shopkeepers will help customers as they fumble to count out their roubles. Instead of blank stares, policemen will happily give directions to lost tourists and taxi drivers will resist the urge to wheel-spin off into the distance as new and bemused arrivals stutter over unpronounceable street names.

'It's a very serious issue,' says Sergei Ananov, deputy chairman of Moscow City Government's tourism committee. 'People need to change mentally. This campaign will educate Muscovites to raise their sense of hospitality and teach them that tourists are good for the economy.'

This drive to attract tourists is all part of a wider strategy by the energetic Mayor Yuri Luzhkov to revitalise the city centre, which has encompassed everything from filling in potholes to major building projects, ranging in scope from Russia's first Ikea store (causing three-hour traffic tailbacks as Russians clamoured for their first encounter with flat-pack furniture) to the imposing Church of Christ the Saviour, Moscow's largest cathedral. Originally built to commemorate Napoleon's expulsion in 1812, it was destroyed by Stalin in 1931 to make way for the Palace of the Soviets, a colossal skyscraper which was to be dominated by a 300ft statue of Lenin. The building failed to materialise and the site became an enormous outdoor swimming pool.

When the question of what to do with the site was put to the Russian people they voted to rebuild the cathedral. The blinding white walls and gilded domes of the £209 million structure now dominate the northern bank of the Moskva River - another 'must see' on the tourist map.

Moscow is changing rapidly and the pace can be bewildering for tourists and residents alike. Though Stalin's seven gothic skyscrapers still ring the city, other relics of the Communist era have been put out to grass. Statues of Brezhnev, Stalin and the feared founder of the KGB, Dzerzhinsky, sit quietly in a neglected plot of land known as the Graveyard of Fallen Monuments while in nearby Gorky Park children clamber over a Russian space shuttle which now serves as a fairground attraction.

But as is often the case, it's the subtle changes which are the most significant. As I checked in at the Lufthansa desk for my flight home, the Russian clerk handed back my tickets with a shy smile and murmured something. I could be wrong but I think she said: 'Have a nice day'.

Moscow 'must sees'

The Kremlin: political, religious and historic nucleus of the city. Within its walls are several beautiful churches, the Armoury with its collection of jewels and Fabergé eggs and the Patriarch's Palace.

Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts: Moscow's answer to St Petersburg's Hermitage, including an impressive collection of French Impressionist art.

Red Square: traditionally a place for gatherings, declarations and protests, home to St Basil's Cathedral and Lenin's Mausoleum.

Church of Christ the Saviour: work on Moscow's biggest cathedral finished this year.

Cathedral of the Assumption: beautiful icons and richly painted interior formed a backdrop to the coronation of Russia's Tsars.

 Joanne O'Connor flew to Moscow with Lufthansa (08457 737 747) via Frankfurt. The airline has 11 daily flights to Moscow from five UK airports. Accommodation at the Hotel Baltschug Kempinski, which overlooks Red Square and St Basil's Cathedral, starts at $400 a night for a standard room (00 800 426 313 55).

fields.headline: Monopoly money for Muscovites
fields.trailText: Focus on Spartak Moscow
fields.body:
Nikolai Starostin wishes he could be at the Luzhniki Stadium on Wednesday when Spartak Moscow play Arsenal. But he died four years ago aged 94, and so must spend the evening in Moscow's Vankangovskoye cemetery.

Starostin deserves better: he virtually made Spartak.

Born in 1902, son of a hunter who died in a typhoid epidemic, Starostin fed his younger brothers by playing ice hockey in the winter and football in the summer. He captained his country at both sports, and in 1935 gave Spartak Moscow its name.

In the late 1930s, the peak of the Soviet purges, a Spartak team starring the four Starostin brothers won three league titles. However, this displeased Lavrenti Beria, Stalin's terrible secret police chief, who happened to be president of the Dynamo Moscow club.

Starostin spent years waiting to be arrested. At last, one night in 1942, he was awoken by a torch shining into his eyes and two pistols pointed at his head. He was taken to the Lubyanka, the secret police headquarters, where he was interrogated for two years and told that he had plotted to murder Stalin.

The charges were eventually dropped - that there had been no attempt to kill Stalin was a problem - but Starostin and his brothers were nonetheless tried and found guilty. However, they were given just ten years in Siberia each. This was considered such a mild sentence it was practically a let-off. 'The future seemed not so gloomy after all,' he gloated in Football Through the Years, the memoir he published when he was 87. He knows why he got off lightly. 'The Starostins did not exist by themselves. In people's minds they personified Spartak. Beria had to deal with the hopes of millions of fans, ordinary Soviet people.'

For Spartak was, and is, a special Russian football club. Dynamo was the club of the KGB, CSKA of the army, and Torpedo of the Zil car plant, while to this day Lokomotiv Moscow are still funded by the railways ministry. Spartak alone were always independent. To millions of people, supporting Spartak was a small way of saying no.

IN THE GULAGS Starostin was treated as a hero. The poet Osip Mandelstam was killed, but no one was allowed to touch Starostin. 'Hardened recidivists would sit quiet as mice to listen to my football stories,' he wrote. The reason, he explained, was that 'for most people soccer was the only, and sometimes the last chance and hope of retaining in their souls a tiny island of sincere feelings and human relations'.

Starostin was eventually recalled to Moscow by Stalin's son Vassily, who made him manager of the air force football club. But Beria was still in pursuit, and so for safety's sake Starostin shared a bed with Vassily, who kept a revolver under his pillow. In 1953, when Stalin père died and Beria was executed, Starostin could at last relax. Over the next four decades he watched his club transform.

When the USSR collapsed, and other Russian clubs began running out of money, Spartak struck. Since the Russian Premier League was founded in 1992, they have won it eight times out of a possible nine. A perky Starostin shared in much of the pleasure: he was Spartak's honorary president when he died.

Spartak have, in effect, become a monopolist. Money has rolled in from the Champions League, from sponsors keen to woo their ten-million-plus fans, and from sales of players to the West. They have gone European while half their rivals, stuck in the Russian economy, don't even have shirt sponsors.

So dominant are Spartak that they have taken it upon themselves to ask President Vladimir Putin to give Russia a national anthem with words, while their coach, the gaunt Siberian Oleg Romantsev, is not only club president but also manager of the national team: a Russian Alex Ferguson, Ken Bates and Sven-Goran Eriksson rolled into one.

Spartak have even begun assembling a foreign legion. Three years ago they signed the Brazilian Luis Robson, and this summer they added two more Brazilians and Jerry-Christian Tchuisse of Cameroon. Tchuisse, who plays according to Christian principles and has yet to receive a yellow card in the Russian league, originally came to Russia as a student. He began playing amateur football, somehow made it to Spartak, and may soon become a Russian citizen so that he can play for the national team. 'I like this country very much,' he says.

However international Spartak have become, they get the occasional reminder that they still play in Russia. No one is sent to the gulag any more, but in 1997 contract killers murdered a Spartak director and a colleague in her dacha. Several players have moved West citing fear as a reason, and earlier this year the club captain Andrei Tikhonov vowed to follow when his car was stolen, though he soon changed his mind, reflecting that it was 'only a piece of steel'. Before one Champions League game last year, a bomb was found outside the Luzhniki.

And if bombs don't get you, the fans might. As early as the late 1970s, Spartak began producing fanaty - a Soviet term denoting a cross between a British hooligan and an American gangster. The fanaty went about in Spartak colours, pillaged city centres and scrawled graffiti everywhere.

These were eccentric habits in Brezhnev's USSR, but the fanaty prospered, and by the 1980s were thought to number tens of thousands. One anthropologist told me he had expected them to make the revolution against Communism.

Watching a Russian match today is much like watching one in Britain in the 1980s. Fanaty throw bottles on to the pitch, fight at metro stations and stab one another. So bad did things get that Spartak were initially ordered to play the decisive match for this year's league title behind closed doors.

In the event the ban was lifted, but the mere 20,000 fans who turned up at the Luzhniki on November 2 were guarded by 4,000 soldiers and policemen.

The question is whether the club can ever conquer Europe. The closest they have got so far was defeat to Olympique Marseille in the semi-finals of the European Cup in 1991. However, their prospects are improving. For a start, Spartak can at last retain Russian players of the calibre of Tikhonov and Igor Titov. This, it must be said, is largely because Western clubs have finally realised that Russians tend to get homesick and flop abroad.

Secondly, and crucially, Russian players are shedding their timidity. No longer are they overawed by the Bernabeu or Hilton Hotels or Western footballers with clever hairstyles. In recent years Spartak players have been all over Europe and are acquiring poise, even if Titov has been known to play in a bobble hat. They may not be multi-millionaires, but the best of them earn well over £100,000 a year and are given large houses for life.

Against Arsenal on Wednesday, they won't kick off with a psychological 1-0 deficit. It may be a decade or two before they win the Champions League, but when they do, there will be dancing in the pathways of Vankangovskoye cemetery.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

'The Starostins did not exist by themselves. In people's minds they personified Spartak. Beria had to deal with the hopes of millions of fans, ordinary Soviet people.' For Spartak was, and is, a special Russian football club. Dynamo was the club of the KGB, CSKA of the army, and Torpedo of the Zil car plant, while to this day Lokomotiv Moscow are still funded by the railways ministry. Spartak alone were always independent. To millions of people, supporting Spartak was a small way of saying no. IN THE GULAGS Starostin was treated as a hero. The poet Osip Mandelstam was killed, but no one was allowed to touch Starostin. 'Hardened recidivists would sit quiet as mice to listen to my football stories,' he wrote. The reason, he explained, was that 'for most people soccer was the only, and sometimes the last chance and hope of retaining in their souls a tiny island of sincere feelings and human relations'. Starostin was eventually recalled to Moscow by Stalin's son Vassily, who made him manager of the air force football club. But Beria was still in pursuit, and so for safety's sake Starostin shared a bed with Vassily, who kept a revolver under his pillow. In 1953, when Stalin père died and Beria was executed, Starostin could at last relax. Over the next four decades he watched his club transform. When the USSR collapsed, and other Russian clubs began running out of money, Spartak struck. Since the Russian Premier League was founded in 1992, they have won it eight times out of a possible nine. A perky Starostin shared in much of the pleasure: he was Spartak's honorary president when he died. Spartak have, in effect, become a monopolist. Money has rolled in from the Champions League, from sponsors keen to woo their ten-million-plus fans, and from sales of players to the West. They have gone European while half their rivals, stuck in the Russian economy, don't even have shirt sponsors. So dominant are Spartak that they have taken it upon themselves to ask President Vladimir Putin to give Russia a national anthem with words, while their coach, the gaunt Siberian Oleg Romantsev, is not only club president but also manager of the national team: a Russian Alex Ferguson, Ken Bates and Sven-Goran Eriksson rolled into one. Spartak have even begun assembling a foreign legion. Three years ago they signed the Brazilian Luis Robson, and this summer they added two more Brazilians and Jerry-Christian Tchuisse of Cameroon. Tchuisse, who plays according to Christian principles and has yet to receive a yellow card in the Russian league, originally came to Russia as a student. He began playing amateur football, somehow made it to Spartak, and may soon become a Russian citizen so that he can play for the national team. 'I like this country very much,' he says. However international Spartak have become, they get the occasional reminder that they still play in Russia. No one is sent to the gulag any more, but in 1997 contract killers murdered a Spartak director and a colleague in her dacha. Several players have moved West citing fear as a reason, and earlier this year the club captain Andrei Tikhonov vowed to follow when his car was stolen, though he soon changed his mind, reflecting that it was 'only a piece of steel'. Before one Champions League game last year, a bomb was found outside the Luzhniki. And if bombs don't get you, the fans might. As early as the late 1970s, Spartak began producing fanaty - a Soviet term denoting a cross between a British hooligan and an American gangster. The fanaty went about in Spartak colours, pillaged city centres and scrawled graffiti everywhere. These were eccentric habits in Brezhnev's USSR, but the fanaty prospered, and by the 1980s were thought to number tens of thousands. One anthropologist told me he had expected them to make the revolution against Communism. Watching a Russian match today is much like watching one in Britain in the 1980s. Fanaty throw bottles on to the pitch, fight at metro stations and stab one another. So bad did things get that Spartak were initially ordered to play the decisive match for this year's league title behind closed doors. In the event the ban was lifted, but the mere 20,000 fans who turned up at the Luzhniki on November 2 were guarded by 4,000 soldiers and policemen. The question is whether the club can ever conquer Europe. The closest they have got so far was defeat to Olympique Marseille in the semi-finals of the European Cup in 1991. However, their prospects are improving. For a start, Spartak can at last retain Russian players of the calibre of Tikhonov and Igor Titov. This, it must be said, is largely because Western clubs have finally realised that Russians tend to get homesick and flop abroad. Secondly, and crucially, Russian players are shedding their timidity. No longer are they overawed by the Bernabeu or Hilton Hotels or Western footballers with clever hairstyles. In recent years Spartak players have been all over Europe and are acquiring poise, even if Titov has been known to play in a bobble hat. They may not be multi-millionaires, but the best of them earn well over £100,000 a year and are given large houses for life. Against Arsenal on Wednesday, they won't kick off with a psychological 1-0 deficit. It may be a decade or two before they win the Champions League, but when they do, there will be dancing in the pathways of Vankangovskoye cemetery.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: A calendar of culture
fields.standfirst: Whether you're into poetry or Japanese No theatre, opera or contemporary music, there are plenty of events taking place next year to cater for all tastes.  Claudia Pritchard previews some of the biggest and best
fields.trailText: Whether you're into poetry or Japanese No theatre, opera or contemporary music, there are plenty of events taking place next year to cater for all tastes. Claudia Pritchard previews some of the biggest and best.
fields.body:
Brighton

Brighton International Festival
Saturday 5 May - Sunday 27 May

Sir Peter Maxwell Davies conducts the Philharmonia in the première of his own Antarctic Symphony , Pushkin's Boris Godunov is staged in Russian, and recitals are housed in the Pavilion's lavish music room. Hundreds of events ranging from the sublime to the bizarre, all set against the crackling backdrop of 'London by the sea'.

Where to stay: artists and patrons stay at the refurbished Royal Albion (01273 329202), Pelirocco (01273 327055) or the Oriental (01273 205050).

Where to eat: sensational sushi at Moshi Moshi or round-the-clock Italian at Pinocchio.

Brochure: early March, when public booking opens. Telephone the box office: 01273 709709; website: www.brighton-festival.org.uk

Salisbury

Salisbury Festival
Friday 25 May - Sunday 10 June

The first programme under new artistic director Trevor Davies is very broad-ranging with music, drama, literature, children's events, street theatre and contemporary work at venues including the cathedral, Playhouse, City Hall, Guildhall and community locations.

Where to stay: the Red Lion in Milford Street (01722 323334) is a thirteenth-century coaching inn; walk in across the meadows from Harnham's old paper mill where water runs under the beamed restaurant of the Old Mill (01722 327517). Festival-goers have special rates at the seventeenth century White Hart (0870 4008125).

Where to eat: handy eateries include The Gallery Café, Le Herisson and The Refectory in the cathedral.

Brochure and booking: early April. Telephone: 01722 323888; website: www.salisburyfestival.co.uk. Box office: 01722 320333

Aldeburgh

Aldeburgh Festival of Music and the Arts
Friday 8 June - Monday 25 June

The fifty-fourth festival will be Thomas Adès's third year as artistic director and will feature more contemporary music continuing the success of informal weekend 'jam' sessions by top artists at the new Pumphouse evening venue, launched this year. Recitals, concerts and small-scale opera at the Snape Maltings and Jubilee Hall, Aldeburgh, include appearances by Ian Bostridge and Mitsuko Uchida. There will be a Salvatore Sciarrino UK première with Leonard Slatkin and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, and a Richard Ayres world première with the CBSO conducted by Sakri Oramo. The project to stage five Britten operas over five years continues with The Rape of Lucretia, conducted by Paul Daniel; a new three-part opera by Alexander Goehr is based on Japanese No drama.

Where to stay: everyone loves The Wentworth (01728 452312) where each bedroom has a copy of Orlando the Marmalade Cat , which is set in the town and sales of which help the festival. B&Bs are very festival-minded, and rooms are available in private houses.

Where to eat: The Lighthouse and 152, both in the buzzing High Street, are favourite nosheries.

Brochure: end of January

Booking: opens Monday 19 March. Telephone: 01728 687110; website www.aldeburgh.co.uk

Ludlow

Ludlow Festival
Sunday 24 June - Monday 9 July

The picturesque ruin of Ludlow Castle dominates this Shropshire town, and the annual Shakespeare production staged amid its craggy walls dominates a programme which also includes music, art, drama and literature, with appearances by Carlo Curley and Andrew Sachs.

Where to stay and eat: the Michelin-starred Mr Underhill's (01584 874431) at nearby Dinham Weir is the Good Hotel Guide's Restaurant-With-Rooms of the Year. Number Twenty Eight (01584 876996) is an upmarket B&B in the town centre.

Brochure and booking: join the free mailing list before booking opens on 1 April. Telephone: 01584 875070; website: www.LudlowFestival.co.uk or write to Ludlow Festival Society, Castle Square, Ludlow SY8 1AY

Chichester

Chichester Festivities
Sunday 1 July - Tuesday 17 July

Classical music, jazz and light music amid the Chagall glass and Piper tapestries in the cathedral, cabaret, comedy and chamber music in the ballroom at Goodwood House, a Caribbean carnival and fireworks at Goodwood racecourse and contemporary sculpture. The festivities attract a distinguished list of speakers; celebrity talks by writers, journalists and historians are a feature.

Where to stay: popular hotels include the Ship (01243 778000) and Suffolk House (01243 778899).

Where to eat: Woodies Wine Bar and Kevin's Bistro are good value; Comme ça is expensive but special.

Brochure: published in April.

Booking: opens 19 April. Telephone 01243 785718, website: www.chifest.org.uk, email: info@chifest.org.uk

York

York Early Music Festival
Friday 6 July - Sunday 15 July

Now with a permanent base at the National Centre for Early Music, this annual celebration of early and authentic sound attracts the top exponents: artists for 2001 include the Gabrieli Consort and Players, the New London Consort with Philip Pickett, and Musica Antica of London. A satellite event at Beverley over the May Bank holiday weekend (Thursday 24 May - Monday 28 May) features the Tallis Scholars and the Academy of Ancient Music.

Where to stay: visitors to York head for the Dean Court Hotel (01904 625082) opposite the Minster, Jeremy Cassel's Regency town house The Grange (01904 644744) or the former home of the diarist Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, Middlethorpe Hall (01904 641241), a Grade II listed William and Mary mansion.

Where to eat: Betty's Tea Rooms serve cakes and savouries until mid-evening; the Blue Bicycle bistro is handy for artists at the National Centre.

Brochure: end March

Public booking: opens 10 April. Telephone: 01904 658338, email boxoffice@yorkearlymusic.org, or write to The National Centre for Early Music, St Margaret's Church, Walmgate, YO1 9TL.

Harrogate

Harrogate International Festival
Thursday 19 July - Saturday 4 August

A Michael Nyman commission will be premièred here before a nationwide tour, and the 2001 event also marks the centenary of Gerald Finzi with concerts and the unveiling of a blue plaque at his former home. Cleo Laine and Johnny Dankworth are expected to headline at the jazz weekend, and this year's Leeds International Piano Competition winner Alessio Bax will play. The Victorian Royal Hall continues to host events, despite an uncertain future, and a series of concerts by rising young professionals is given at the Old Swan Hotel, scene of Agatha Christie's disappearance, and popular billet for visitors.

Where to stay: The Crown (01423 567755) and The Majestic (01423 700300) are landmark hotels.

Where to eat: artists and audiences head for The Tannin Level for good food and drink.

Public bookings: from 12 June. Telephone: (01423) 562303; website: www.harrogate-festival.org.uk, email: info@harrogate-festival.org.uk

Edinburgh

Edinburgh International Festival
Sunday 12 August - Saturday 1 September

A three-week long party of music, drama and dance with added film, literary and fringe events. Artists provisionally include Andras Schiff, Hillevi Martinpelto, David Daniels and Ian Bostridge. Scottish Opera will perform Die Walküre , continuing the Ring Cycle begun this year.

Where to stay: favourite hotels in the Georgian New Town and West End, within walking distance of most events, include Drummond House (0131 557 9189), The Howard (0131 557 3500) and The Bonham (0131 226 6050), with a Malmaison at Leith (0131 468 5000).

Where to eat: elegant dining and excellent fish at the Café Royal. Festival-goers converge at The Hub from early morning until after midnight.

Brochure: 22 March

Public booking opens 7 April. Telephone: 0131 473 2000, fax 0131 473 2003; website: www.eif.co.uk email: boxoffice@eif.co.uk

Ross-on-Wye

Ross-on-Wye International Festival
Thursday 16 August - Monday 27 August

A purpose-built 1,500-seater pavilion on the banks of the river Wye houses an eclectic mix of British and international music, dance, theatre and comedy. Some big names, lots of low prices - recent years have seen Joan Armatrading, Bob Geldof, Steven Berkoff. Family events, concessions and a Park Your Kids service.

Where to stay: some patrons camp or B&B, others head for town hotels. The Royal (01989 565105) and The Chase (01989 763161), or the country house Pengethley Manor (01989 730211).

Where to eat: good Chinese food at China Boy Jo, Indian at Obliash, French at Le Faison Doré.

Brochures and bookings: from 1 June, telephone 01594 544446 for information; website: www.festival.org.uk

Gloucester

Three Choirs Festival
Saturday 18 August - Saturday 25 August

The oldest music festival in the world, founded in 1715, celebrates British music and the centenary of Gerald Finzi, with Raphael Wallfisch in the cello concerto, plus new commissions from Patrick Gower and John Sanders. The 200 voices drawn from the choral societies of Hereford, Worcester and Gloucester combine with the city's cathedral choirs and the Philharmonia as orchestra in residence. Programme includes Belshazzar's Feast, Delius's Mass of Life, Vaughan Williams's Sea Symphony, Messiah, Dido and Aeneas, Elgar's cello concerto.

Where to stay: favourite hotels include the New County (01452 307000) and Corse Lawn (01452 780771).

After the music : artists and patrons meet at the Festival Club in King's School.

Brochure: leaflet with dates available now. Booking brochure from mid-February.

Public booking: opens April. Telephone 01452 529819; website: www.3choirs.org email: info.Gloucester@3choirs.org.

Norwich

Norfolk and Norwich Festival
Wednesday 3 October - Sunday 14 October

Orchestral, choral and chamber concerts, jazz, comedy, theatre, dance, street entertainment, and exhibitions, plus events to coincide with National Poetry Day, Thursday 11 October. The festival has a reputation for staging world premières and for attracting artistes from outside the circuit. The cathedral, churches and civic buildings host scores of events within easy walking distance of each other.

Where to stay: The Beeches (01603 621167), 10 minutes' walk from the centre, has rooms in a row of Georgian mansions in a romantic Victorian garden; By Appointment (01603 630730), restaurant with rooms, dates from the fifteenth century and won the Good Hotel Guide's 1999 prize for 'utterly enjoyable mild eccentricity'.

Where to eat: food at all hours at The Last Wine Bar and Restaurant and Orange's Brasserie.

Brochure: 12 July

Public booking: opens 16 July. Telephone: 01603 766400; website: www.nnfest.demon.co.uk

Cheltenham

Cheltenham Festival of Literature
Friday 12 October - Sunday 21 October

Founded in 1949 and now the country's leading event for readers and writers. Live readings, discussions, book club, work shops, children's events, poetry with jazz, bookbinding, and calligraphy. Events take place in the Town Hall and Everyman Theatre; the Voices Off outreach programme uses local pubs and clubs.

Where to stay: rub shoulders with your favourite authors at the Queen's (0870 400 8107) and state-of-the-art Hotel Kandinsky (01242 527788).

Where to eat: Le Petit Blanc has Raymond Blanc at the helm, but the bustling Café Rouge may suit more pockets.

Brochure: beginning of August

Booking : opens 13 August. Brochure hotline: 01242 237377; www.cheltenhamfestivals.co.uk

Wexford

Wexford Festival Opera
Thursday 18 October - Sunday 4 November

A town of only 15,000 inhabitants welcomes artists from all over the world. The centrepiece of the 50th festival is the production of three rarely performed operas: Friedrich Flotow's romantic German three-act Alessandro Stradella , Dvorák's Jakobín sung in Czech, and Massenet's Sapho sung in French, each piece sung six times. Concerts, recitals, buffets and opera extracts keep the town en fête.

Where to stay: the opera has sold out for six years running, and rooms go quickly too: try The Ferrycarrig (00 353 53 20999), Talbot (00 353 53 22566), and Whites (00 353 53 22311).

Where to eat: La Riva, Mange 2 or Heavens Above.

Brochure: free mailing list.

Booking: opens 5 June. Telephone: 00 353 53 22144; website: www.wexfordopera.com email: info@wexfordopera.com

webTitle: Longer stays suit the city break set

fields.headline: Longer stays suit the city break set
fields.trailText: Short breaks are getting longer, according to specialist operator Travelscene.
fields.body:
Short breaks are getting longer, according to specialist operator Travelscene. Bookings for city breaks of four days or more have risen by 25 per cent in the last two years, a faster growth than those for shorter stays. And seven-night breaks, perhaps split between cities, are growing even faster.

The trend is behind the launch of a new Cities Worldwide brochure featuring long-haul cities as far afield as Buenos Aires, Cape Town, Singapore and Sydney. Travelscene marketing director Nick Bamford said these cities attracted 'cash-rich, time-poor' travellers, who did not want to tread the traditional long-haul path. These are generally well-heeled couples aged 45 or over. They like to stay in two or more cities but in a short timespan. The brochures feature a choice of four hotels from three to five stars in each of 31 cities. The breaks are flexible, dictated only by the flight days and times.

Brochures from 0870 777 4445 or see www.travelscene.co.uk.

These are generally well-heeled couples aged 45 or over. They like to stay in two or more cities but in a short timespan. The brochures feature a choice of four hotels from three to five stars in each of 31 cities. The breaks are flexible, dictated only by the flight days and times. Brochures from 0870 777 4445 or see www.travelscene.co.uk.

fields.headline: Can Cuper say 'Hola' again?
fields.trailText: Focus on Valencia
fields.body:
What a difference a year makes. This time last season, Valencia were miles off the pace in the Spanish Liga, the Champions League would have appeared to your average Valencianista like a pipe-dream, and Hector Cuper had done nothing to make them forget their former coach Claudio Ranieri and was about to receive the 'white hanky treatment'.

Now, Valencianistas can look ahead to a clash with Manchester United with considerably less trepidation than they did 12 months ago, and can expect to go through as one of the group favourites and league-leaders in Spain.

The last time Valencia had topped Spain's Primera Division in early November 1993 their lead lasted precisely one week. Then the perennial nearly-rans of Spanish football were mauled in a Uefa Cup tie 7-0 and their morale suffered a fresh battering when they went down 2-0 in the league at Sporting Gijon to be knocked off the top, and the rest is a history of under-achieving. Until now. Enter the dragon.

This time last year, the fans were squirming in their seats when one Hector Raul Cuper moved onto the bench vacated by the 'popularisimo' Claudio Ranieri. Cuper's start gave hardly any indication of the great days to come, as the team kicked off the campaign with four straight defeats.

A few weeks before the Champions League kicked off again after its winter break, the white hankies came out at Mestalla when Cuper substituted striker Claudio Lopez with the game being drawn, and then, when the team were beaten, called for his head. A few months later, when the team returned from Rome having qualified for the semi-final of the competition after knocking out Lazio, the stern Argentine took an eternity to cross the airport because of the number of fans mobbing him.

Valencia have traditionally bought 'em cheap, piled 'em high and sold 'em expensive, and the team that defied all of the odds and reached the Champions League final in Paris was to be no exception. The deal to take Claudio Lopez to Lazio had been sealed as far back as last October. Valencia fans were astounded when dynamic midfield duo of Farinos and Gerard were also sold. The spine had been ripped out of the side.

Though cash at Valencia is surprisingly scarce, they still managed to spend £30m on eight new players, as Cuper opted to improve the all-round strength of the squad. In came strikers Diego Alonso and John Carew, midfielders Didier Deschamps, Vicente Rodriguez and Ruben Baraja, attacking midfielder Zlatko Zahovic, and defender Roberto Ayala.

Inspirational captain, Gaizka Mendieta, is without doubt the most in-form Spanish player around, and the team carried on the new season where they left off the old. If the league had commenced in the year 2000, Valencia would have been champions - only two defeats this season, away at Real Madrid and Español. At Mestalla, Valencia remain unbeaten in all competitions since January. In Europe, Valencia waltzed through their Champions League group, winning the first four games to wrap up qualification. Cuper's cachet has soared and he is now touted as the potential successor of England-bound Eriksson at Lazio, as well as being linked with just about every bench at Europe's elite. Real Madrid are watching eagerly the development of contract talks, and with Cuper unlikely to go beyond 2002, at what price might Manchester United lookto 'go foreign' and repatriate the man of English ancestry (when the family was Cooper) when their bench is finally vacated, coincidentally, that very summer?

But there have been worrying signs of late for Valencia aficionados, with the team turning in below-par performances after their blistering start to the season. They might have the squad, but they lack the cutting edge of last season's team that made the final, and Cuper is clearly none the wiser about his best attacking options. An injury to veteran left-back Carboni is a blow, and it emerged this week that ageing sweeper Djukic and accident-prone goalkeeper Cañizares do not speak because the Serb made two mistakes two years ago!

When Valencia reached last season's final, a local paper produced a T-shirt for the benefit of the 'ambience' of the host city Paris, bearing the slogan: ' Hola! Je suis Valencien et mon jour de gloire est arrivé .' It was a salutary reminder that the Champions League, for some, was more about the moment than hunger for success. I hope another outsider makes it to Milan this year and does a 'Valencia': they'll always have Paris.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Nevilles buck the system
fields.standfirst: Manchester United can forget a 'Hollywood' image while they happily rely on Gary and Phil
fields.trailText: Focus on Manchester United
fields.body:
Back in the old days when Manchester United were still coming to terms with the Champions League, they used to arrive at the mid-point break desperately grateful for the chance to give the Premiership their undivided attention.

A mere four years ago a 2-0 victory over Rapid Vienna saw chairman Martin Edwards practically cracking open the champagne as he explained that United had won themselves not just a place in the quarter-finals but a whole three months breathing space. As Old Trafford had just witnessed its first European defeats in that campaign, not once but twice as first Fenerbahce then Juventus left Manchester with a single goal and all three points, one could easily understand Edwards's relief. His domestic concerns were justified too - United ended up winning the Premiership by a comfortable margin from Newcastle but could only fit all their fixtures in by playing the last four matches in nine days - though their European adventure that season was ended at the semi-final stage by Ottmar Hitzfeld's Borussia Dortmund.

How much has changed in four years? Well, in 1996 David Beckham was only just breaking into England's side and was not widely regarded as a future captain. Eric Cantona was the player entrusted with the almost total responsibility of making United tick. Paul Scholes had not yet gained his first cap, Teddy Sheringham was still at Spurs, and, with Gary Pallister, the Neville brothers were the most regular England internationals.Virtually everything has changed, in other words, including the Champions League format, the size of the United squad deemed necessary to cope with it, even the club's philosophy about whether it is a core domestic or European player seems subtly to have shifted.

The last four years have seen Beckham survive lionisation by his own supporters and vilification from everyone else to establish his name as something approaching a global brand. Roy Keane has returned from serious injury to calm down, pick up player of the year plaudits and learn to save his scorn for remote supporters rather than rulebound referees. Scholes has fulfilled his potential and more, a singular Danish goalkeeper has given way to an idiosyncratic French one and Continental defenders like Jaap Stam and Mikael Silvestre have been assimilated. United can sign whoever they want now; should they ever need to replace Ryan Giggs, Dwight Yorke or Andy Cole they can just go shopping for a new superstar, always assuming he passes the medical. But they will never turn into FC Hollywood as long as managers keep picking the Neville brothers, and there is every indication they will continue to do so for some time.

The Nevilles' claim to be the great unsung heroes of Old Trafford could perhaps be disputed by Denis Irwin, who could challenge a clockwork train set for reliability, ease of maintenance and inconspicuousness when not in use, but the Irishman's long and illustrious career is beginning to wind down. Sir Alex Ferguson has started using him sparingly, resting him whenever he can, and there have been occasions, particularly in Europe, when Irwin has been caught on the turn and exposed for pace. Irwin might be making his final bows around the same time as his manager, whereas there is little doubt the Nevilles will be going strong for the new man.

There is no danger of the next manager failing to recognise the virtues of two of the most consistent performers in the Premiership. Everyone wanted to rave about Rio Ferdinand in Turin on Wednesday, even though England's sweeper had only contributed the defensive part of his brief and been content to let Beckham come back and carry the ball out of defence, but Peter Taylor was quick to set the record straight. 'Rio is getting a lot of credit, but I think he would be the first one to thank Gary Neville and Gareth Southgate for the solid support,' Taylor said. 'It must have been a big help to be playing between such experienced international defenders.'

With 41 caps in his 25 years, that is exactly what Gary now is. His ability to switch seamlessly between full back and central defence makes him an almost priceless commodity in England and United squads. United play a rigid 4-4-2 but utilise Neville in either position. He has long been England's preferred right-back, but even if the switch to 5-3-2 becomes permanent there is little doubt the caps will continue as a member of the back three. Gary Neville may not be the most demonstrative or flamboyant England international, but good defenders rarely need to be conspicuous.

When they are, it is usually for the wrong reasons, as younger brother Phil found to his cost with England last summer. There is no need to go over the penalty drama against Romania in Charleroi again, suffice to say England's stand-in left-back paid a heavy price for a single mistake. The most unfair aspect was that Phil Neville was somehow left to bear the brunt of all England's failings, as if it were his fault Graeme le Saux was injured, that the country could not provide any left-footed alternatives, or that Kevin Keegan kept insisting on a formation which was bound to show up the side's lack of balance sooner or later.

To his credit, Phil Neville has responded in exactly the same way Beckham applied himself after a similar distraction two years ago - by keeping his head down and concentrating on what he does best. Neville does not have the sizzling free-kicks and pinpoint crosses in his repertoire to redeem himself as instantly as Beckham, though his selfless overlaps to give his teammate a passing option and take a defender with him should not be underestimated. What can be safely said is that though friends were initially worried about his possible reaction to England criticism, no excuses have had to be advanced on his behalf at any stage of the season. The subject is closed, the episode behind him.

United's main defensive worry, as Panathinaikos arrive to start the Champions League' second stage, continues to be the absence of Stam. Or rather, what to do about it. Ronny Johnsen's fitness continues to be erratic, Wes Brown is still playing himself back after cruciate surgery and Silvestre is still prone to expensive aberrations. Good thing the Nevilles are around, really. Few frills, but few question marks either.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Europe still the big draw
fields.trailText: Armchair view: Whats on live before Christmas
fields.body:
What price European club club football? Still surprisingly high considering the drop in viewing figures for the Champions League reported in this column last week.

After an extraordinary bidding battle - involving a number of broadcasters - for the first leg of Liverpool's Uefa Cup third-round tie against Olympiakos in Athens next Thursday, the BBC eventually fought off Channel 5 to win the rights with an offer of £640,000 - a record amount for this early stage of the competition.

'I can't believe they went that high,' an industry insider said. 'It's such a lot of money - a 50 per cent rise, which is a serious jump.'

Two factors helped to force up the price. First, that Liverpool are the sole surviving English side in the competition; and second, that Olympiakos drove the negotiations themselves, rather than using an agent with favoured clients, and only in the final stages combined with TWI/IMG to complete the deal.

Bidding opened at £400,000 for the complete package of rights - TV, advertising and third-party - and rose sharply, mainly because the BBC, which secured Liverpool's home Uefa Cup matches before the start of the season, were eager to frustrate Channel 5's annoying habit of picking up the away games.

The football industry will no doubt be delighted that their product can still generate such frantic media interest - despite the first phase of Champions League matches on ITV this time pulling in 1.5 million fewer viewers per match than last season. Only time will tell, though, whether the BBC's rather extravagant splurge on Liverpool's game in Athens was the result of a particular set of circumstances or broadcasters' faith in football remaining unshaken.

Whatever the answer, ITV will be hoping business picks up when the Champions League resumes this week, although they have already suffered one minor disappointment. Because the Arsenal and Leeds United matches this Wednesday have staggered starts, they reluctantly accepted that showing both games one after another would be giving over far too much peak air time to football.

Ideally, both games would have kicked off at the same time and most of the network would have taken Leeds's home match against Real Madrid, with Carlton serving up Arsenal's away fixture against Spartak Moscow for viewers in the London region. This would almost certainly have given them a bigger figure than showing Leeds right across the network.

As it is, Arsenal's match, kicking off in Moscow at 5pm, will be shown on ITV2.

ITV's dearest wish will be that Manchester United keep going all the way to the final as they did two seasons ago, which still seems to be the only real guarantee of attracting large audiences - of course, whether these viewers are genuine United fans cheering on their team or those with both feet firmly in the anti-United camp hoping for their comeuppance, does not matter a jot to the broadcasters.

For their two semi-final matches against Juventus in 1999, United delivered ITV audiences of more than 11 million. There was then a huge peak viewing figure of 18.8 million for the memorable final against Bayern Munich.

Last season, with no British interest beyond the quarter-final stage after Manchester United were defeated by eventual winners Real Madrid, the semi-final audiences were a lowly 5.5 and 5.6 million with only seven million watching Madrid conquer Valencia in the final.

United's next appearance on ITV this time will be the match against Austrian club Sturm Graz at Old Trafford on 6 December.

'Obviously you take a calculated risk when you get involved in a competition that has an elimination element to it,' says Brian Barwick, ITV's head of sport. 'But if you want to win the raffle you've got to buy a ticket.'

Will the prizes soon lose their glister, though?

Champions League 21 Nov: Manchester Utd v Panathinaikos ONsport1 (ko 7.45pm)

22 Nov: Spartak Moscow v Arsenal ITV2 (ko 5pm)

22 Nov: Leeds Utd v Real Madrid ITV (ko 7.45pm)

5 Dec: Arsenal v Bayern Munich ONsport2 (ko 7.45pm)

5 Dec: Lazio v Leeds Utd ONsport1 (ko 7.45pm)

6 Dec: Sturm Graz v Manchester Utd ITV (ko 7.45pm)

Uefa Cup 3rd round 23 Nov: Olympiakos v Liverpool BBC2/BBC1 (ko 7.05pm)

7 Dec: Liverpool v Olympiakos BBC (ko tbc)

webTitle: Austria's debt to the Tank and the Terminator

fields.headline: Austria's debt to the Tank and the Terminator
fields.trailText: 'It was in Graz that I built up my biceps from 14 inches to 19 inches', quivered a proud Arnold Schwarzenegger at the ceremony held by Sturm Graz in 1997 to honour their favourite son. 'I always dreamed of being a bodybuilder and going to Hollywood but I never dreamed I would make it this big.'
fields.body:
'It was in Graz that I built up my biceps from 14 inches to 19 inches', quivered a proud Arnold Schwarzenegger at the ceremony held by Sturm Graz in 1997 to honour their favourite son. 'I always dreamed of being a bodybuilder and going to Hollywood but I never dreamed I would make it this big.'

In this case, making it big meant having the small-town Austrian club name their stadium after him. The good people of Graz clearly forgave Arnie for leaving Austria the minute his biceps hit the 20-inch mark.

Since they began playing at the Arnold Schwarzenegger Stadium, Graz, then managed by former Bayern Munich defender Klaus Augenthaler (pictured, left), have won successive Austrian league titles and are the surprise team of this year's Champions League, having beaten Rangers, Monaco and Galatasaray at home to qualify for the second phase and another crack at Manchester United.

United defeated Graz home and away in the first phase last season. The Austrians have beefed up since then, though. Current manager Ivica Osium, Augenthaler's Yugoslav successor, has signed the unpredictable Russian Sergei Yuran (centre). The 31-year-old forward scored four of the 11 goals that helped Sturm top their group.

Yuran has been a revelation in Austria. The man nicknamed 'The Tank' bears no resemblance to the player who in 1996 made a dozen appearances for Millwall. Mick McCarthy, then manager at the New Den, signed Yuran on loan from Spartak Moscow, along with compatriot Vasili Kulkov. On signing Yuran said: 'We have played for some great clubs in Europe but this is the pinnacle of our careers'. Derision followed diplomacy - Millwall's fans soon rumbled Yuran as more 'Pie' than 'Tank'.

Jimmy Nicholl, who replaced McCarthy, described Yuran as 'definitely the worst professional I have ever seen in my life'. The Tank has defied his many critics since those dark days - now comes the chance to make Arnie proud. Hasta la Vista, Fergie.

fields.headline: Focus on Real Madrid
fields.trailText: Same fundamental problem as last year and recent seasons for the reigning European Champions , infuriatingly inconsistent. Vicente del Bosque has changed formation to 4-4-2, with defence suffering as a result. They miss midfield general Redondo but gained a Figo - not bad when going forward but they lack something through the middle.
fields.body:
Same fundamental problem as last year and recent seasons for the reigning European Champions , infuriatingly inconsistent. Vicente del Bosque has changed formation to 4-4-2, with defence suffering as a result. They miss midfield general Redondo but gained a Figo - not bad when going forward but they lack something through the middle.

The coach has experimented with several combinations of central midfield pairings without being any the wiser, new signings Makelele and Flavio have failed to convince.

The team has impressively reached this stage of season without their only striker, Morientes, and will be praying he's soon back to full fitness. Midfielder Guti has impressed in the role, however.

Using Morientes' aerial prowess and Figo's crossing, they surely can only go from strength to strength. Madrid attack from all over, and any team which carries the threat of a Raul, Roberto Carlos, Savio or Munitis is going to cause problems (McManaman is only a reserve), the only question is whether can they keep score down at the back.

Defence is suspect all over, del Bosque doesn't know his best right-back or central-pairing, so thank God for outstanding keeper Casillas (Spain's undisputed number one at 19!). Sir Alex Ferguson already knows all about him.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Aguiar Nunes, head concierge at Reid's Palace, Madeira
fields.trailText: Aguiar Nunes, head concierge at Reid's Palace, Madeira.
fields.body:
Any famous guests?

I have worked at Reid's Palace since 1965 and some of the first guests I remember, as a 13-year-old pageboy, were the King and Queen of Sweden. We have had many heads of state, such as President Botha of South Africa and the president of Cuba, Batista, before Fidel took over. Batista kept everything here - there was a whole room full of his private papers and documents. But I also remember celebrities such as Sandie Shaw and Roger Moore. Many of our guests are English - indeed the first wine business on Madeira was started by an English family.

Did they keep it in the family?

Yes, family ties are important here. The Blundy family, for example, have been here since the eighteenth century. Mr Blundy came out with the British Army, liked the weather and stayed. They used to own Reid's. But my family are the oldest family at Reid's - members have worked here continuously since 1894.

Has Madeira changed much?

I remember that before the airport was opened only seaplanes could land. There are many more hotels now, but the countryside is the same. The two constants on Madeira are the security and the weather.

Any unusual requests?

I have been here for 35 years - I spend more time inside the hotel than outside - and I have heard some strange things in that time. A Canadian couple once asked if I could get them some cocaine. I told them I can provide everything; but not that.

What about a day out?

We have levadas - small canals that bring the water down from the mountains to the villages - and it is wonderful to just walk along one. The mountains are quiet and there are lots of nice villages and big botanical gardens. Every 100 metres you can find a church - there are more than 200 on the island. Several British families have formed the Madeira Wine Association which offers tours and tastings.

And a night out?

Restaurants serve international, Portuguese and local cuisine, such as ispadas. There are lots of good bars in Funchal. My personal favourite is a small one called Queen's Bar, where I often have a pint of Guinness.

Reid's Palace: 00 351 291 71 71 71. Standard double rooms from approximately £155 per night including breakfast. www.orient-express.com.

fields.headline: Focus on Lazio
fields.trailText: Fears in Rome that Sven-Goran Eriksson's decision to accept the England job would quickly result in distraction and disunity at Lazio have so far proved unfounded.
fields.body:
Fears in Rome that Sven-Goran Eriksson's decision to accept the England job would quickly result in distraction and disunity at Lazio have so far proved unfounded.

Indeed after a shaky start to the season, Lazio won three games on the bounce following Eriksson decision, ending their run with a creditable draw at Juventus last Saturday.

Although the Swede has a large squad to select from, there were question marks over whether the back-up players offered real options, with the likes of Attilio Lombardo and Fabrizio Ravanelli well past their best.

Eriksson largely dismissed that theory when for the final Champions League game at Sparta Prague, with qualification already in the bag, he fielded a complete reserve team against a Czech side desperate for a win to get a Uefa Cup slot and came away with a 1-0 win.

Ravanelli scored the only goal of the game while little-used players like Portugal's Fernando Couto and youngster Roberto Baronio, showed that while real competition for places is limited, there is solid enough cover to cope with the demands of another phase of action on two-fronts.

Summer signing Claudio Lopez will miss most of the Champions League games after suffering a knee ligament injury, but Chilean Marcelo Salas has taken his chance to forge a promising partnership with Argentine Hernan Crespo.

fields.headline: Focus on Anderlecht
fields.trailText: When the Belgian champions were crushed 5-1 by Manchester United at Old Trafford back on 13 September few observers would have raised an eyebrow at the result. Fewer still would have given much for Anderlecht's chances of coming back in their remaining five group games to qualify for the second group stage, let alone go on to top Group G ahead of the English champions.
fields.body:
When the Belgian champions were crushed 5-1 by Manchester United at Old Trafford back on 13 September few observers would have raised an eyebrow at the result. Fewer still would have given much for Anderlecht's chances of coming back in their remaining five group games to qualify for the second group stage, let alone go on to top Group G ahead of the English champions.

But that is exactly what Aimé Anthuenis's men did, thanks mainly to a deserved 2-1 home win against Alex Ferguson's side - described by Anthuenis as 'perhaps the most flamboyant victory I've ever had' - and a stunning 3-2 away victory over PSV Eindhoven in the final round of group matches, a result which consigned their bitter Dutch rivals to the Uefa Cup and helped restore some pride to Belgian football after the debacle that was their national team's performance at Euro 2000.

Anderlecht's key performers have been their captain Lorenzo Staelens, an experienced defender with 70 caps for Belgium to his name, and striker Tomasz Radzinski, who has already netted four times in this season's Champions League - including twice in the crucial win against Manchester United. The 26-year-old Canadian, capped 22 times by his country, has scored an impressive 29 goals in 47 games over the last two seasons to help propel Anderlecht into the European spotlight.

Radzinski's striking partnership with the awkwardly tall, yet extremely effective Czech Republic international Jan Koller has done much to bring Anderlecht this far. But is it a partnership capable of bettering the defences of Lazio, Real Madrid and Leeds?

fields.headline: Viduka leaves the asylum
fields.standfirst: Leeds' laid-back striker is a goalscoring institution but he was never, ever mad - just misunderstood
fields.trailText: Leeds' laid-back striker is a goalscoring institution but he was never, ever mad - just misunderstood. Amy Lawrence Australia's man of the moment.
fields.body:
As Mark Viduka chews the fat about football, the universe and everything with the kind of self-possessed ease Australians are famed for, it doesn't seem possible that he could feel so messed up he would run away from it all. But his most infamous move so far in British football was to turn on his heels and abandon Celtic days after signing for them two seasons ago: as a result he is perceived by some as temperamental, sensitive, and unstable. What a misconception.

Leeds United striker Viduka is so easygoing you can't help but feel relaxed in his company. He makes signing autographs and posing for snaps look like he's catching up with an old friend. His mates tell you he's utterly unchanged and - with an open smile and an 'all right mate' on the tip of his tongue - he comes across as blissfully oblivious to the trappings of fame. He isn't. He has just learned the hard way that the star system is a fickle mistress best avoided. As he says, 'I have seen how it is to go from superstar to everybody hates you. People will do whatever they want around you but you have to stay level.'

The background to his disappearing act is a situation beyond the comprehension of your average British footballer. He joined Celtic from Croatia Zagreb, a period of his professional and personal life embroiled with so much complexity and anxiety it made him fall out of love with the game. He had been invited to Zagreb as a teenager when he was making waves as a young footballer of immense promise Down Under. The calling came from the president of the club - who also happened to be the president of the country. The late Franjo Tudjman was on an official visit to Australia and was told that the sensation who had been top scorer in the Australian league for two seasons running was of Croatian descent. Viduka and his parents went to meet Tudjman for lunch in Melbourne and, feeling 'honoured and flattered', he was soon on his way, making the opposite journey taken by mum and dad in the Sixties.

Croatian traditions had been a large part of his upbringing - it was the first language he spoke - but he was so ingrained in the Australian lifestyle that Zagreb's greeting amounted to a huge culture shock. 'When my parents came to Australia they came because they had no money, they were poor, at that time it was a communist system and it wasn't a free place. It's a battle: you come to a new country, you don't know the language, don't know where you're going to sleep. When I went to Croatia I was all right because I had a job and I got paid pretty well. But it was tough because I was 19 and I came to a place in transition between communism and democracy. For me, being in a place where the people had the communist mentality was difficult because I'd lived in a free country all my life. You see how people think and react differently. It was very, very stressful.'

'The situation is so bad over there people are struggling to live. They earn something like $100 a month and you can't live on that. Also people have a lot of social problems, having lost a lot of relatives and limbs in the war. Where my father was from was occupied for about four years in the early Nineties and it was taken over. They killed my grandmother's brother and her son. So...' He pauses and reflects.

Life for Viduka on the field was also alien to a boy bred in a country where sport is a positive thread in the fabric of society. Playing for the team seen as an arm of the government because of the President's patronage meant political hatred was rife. Opponents resented what was seen as favouritism and complained of corruption, and even the club's own supporters railed against them because Tudjman had changed the name from 'Dynamo' to 'Croatia' Zagreb, in an attempt to make them the national club. They felt their heritage was being betrayed and wanted vengeance.

'Marko' Viduka, who had gone there merely wanting to play football, was mystified: 'I remember leaving the ground and the home crowd were cheering for the other team the whole game. It was politically motivated. Towards the end of my time there, because of my involvement with the President, people were having a go at me. It was hard because I would go out and play, and I remember one game where, before I even started, there were 40,000 people singing "Viduka's a pooftah" or something like that. My own fans! It's not a very nice situation to be in. There was a game when I was man of the match and after I scored a really good goal they were booing me. So it's not a normal situation to be in. I wasn't motivated to play. I was confused, thinking what have I got to do to have a normal situation? It turned me off football. I was happy to go. Moving to Britain was refreshing. People are just interested in football, not politics.'

Enter Celtic, and the relief of a fresh opportunity. But when his transfer became prolonged - it kept stalling on the way the fee would be divvied up between Croatia Zagreb and Viduka's signing on fee - he'd suddenly had enough. So he fled to the sanctuary of his family in Melbourne for a two-month sabbatical to get his head together.

The Scottish media painted him as another Paolo Di Canio permanently on the brink of explosion. He feels unfairly misrepresented. 'In that respect it was a bad place to go to because the Scottish press are mental up there,' he muses. 'They made up so many things, they said I was in an asylum and went to some cuckoo place. It was ridiculous. I had three training sessions before I went and they said somebody kicked me so I got upset and went home!' He laughs at the lunacy of it all. As if.

Viduka, as Leeds have recently come to realise, is anything but a cowardly player. His critics in Scotland had to acknowledge it too, considering he finished last season there as top scorer and Players' Player of the Year.

Whilst in Glasgow he took particular interest in the fortunes of Leeds, because Harry Kewell is his mate, and his impact since joining him in Yorkshire has been dramatic. He has bought a new dimension to the team. Although last season at Elland Road was immensely promising, you couldn't help wondering how much more could have been achieved had they not lost Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Granted, the exuberant efforts of Alan Smith and Michael Bridges went a long way to filling a gaping hole, but Leeds still needed a free-scoring, line-leading spearhead; a forward with supreme self- confidence; a striker with a proven record and presence.

It took Viduka a while to find his rhythm. Just as his talents blossomed at Celtic after a false start, Leeds have also felt the benefits of his penchant for invigorating himself with a few deep breaths of Aussie air. Before returning for the Olympics he looked, as one Leeds sup porter so delicately put it, like he had been on the Tomas Brolin diet. Short of fitness, they reckoned David O'Leary had bought a hulking, workaday number nine who would hopefully nick the kind of scrappy goals so alien to the works of art favoured by Harry Kewell and Michael Bridges. Those expectations have been exceeded in spades.

'When I first arrived I wasn't scoring goals, which was basically due to lack of fitness. I had been out for three months and had done nothing. For me, I'm a big bloke and I really need to get fit. I have to do a really good pre-season just to get my lungs and my engines going. This pre-season I signed for Leeds and had to wait a week for my work permit while the boys were all training.

'Then I injured my ankle and was out for another three weeks. Even in the Olympics I didn't feel fit, I couldn't recover after runs and stuff. How did it turn around? I scored some goals, that's how it is in my game.

'For some reason when I came back I felt good. When you're confident you can be standing on the edge of the box, somebody kicks the ball, it hits your arse and goes in. But you work on confidence. It comes with training and that's where I try to give 100 per cent in training because if I do it there I'm going to do it in the game as well.'

That confidence glowed during that astounding, virtuoso four-goal show against Liverpool. Afterwards he deliberately decided to duck out of the limelight, wary of the pitfalls of being portrayed as the main man in a team game. Personally and professionally, preening is not his style. Pat Rafter, commenting on what is expected of Australian sportsmen, summed it up succinctly: 'Australians are very laid back people, very approachable people. If any athletes aren't that way they are generally perceived as dickheads.' It's a sentiment Viduka fully subscribes to.

During the Socceroos successful jaunt at Hampden Park for last week's international, the spotlight of attention focused so intensely on Viduka it virtually blacked out the rest of the squad. It would have been embarrassing were they not all so chummy about it. There is a general acceptance that 'Duks' as he is known to his team-mates, is worthy of special treatment. As fellow striker Paul Agostino pointed out, 'He gets a lot of attention but to me it's fair because he's a world-class player and he deserves everything that he gets.'

There wasn't a trace of jealousy or sarcasm in his voice, even though he has a superior goals-to-games record for his country than Viduka. Agostino admires the fact that while he made it to Europe on the back of hard work and aggression, Viduka's break was based on the kind of natural skill and flair other players can only wish for. He is one of the shining lights who give the Socceroos credibility. They are all desperate to take that further by qualifying for the next World Cup. David O'Leary might baulk at the thought of every call-up but Viduka won't fail the cause.

He is blossoming vibrantly in the Premiership. So much that Australia coach Frank Farina reckons Viduka would fetch in the region of £20 million today, five months after Leeds paid a mere £6 m. On the majestic form epitomised by that quartet against Liverpool, he could pick his world club if he wanted to.

It's easy to get carried away by one mesmerising performance but, as Farina points out, he's been on a permanent hot streak since childhood. 'He was scoring a lot of goals as a teenager in Australia and when he left a lot of people doubted he would score goals in Croatia. Sure enough he ended up top scorer there two or three years in a row. Then he went to Scotland, and then on to England, and the same doubts cropped up again. But Mark Viduka keeps scoring goals. It's a God-given talent. He's a very big man but he's very quick on his feet and he has a gift for goals, which makes him a perfect centre forward.'

Viduka was a born goalscorer. When he was nine he struck 13 times in a single match, and he has barely stopped since. His consistency is remarkable. If it can continue, the prospect of his burgeoning partnership with Alan Smith being reinforced by the attacking urges of Harry Kewell, Michael Bridges and Jason Wilcox, when they recover from injury, promises exciting times ahead.

Viduka, who 'can't wait' to play with compatriot Kewell, enthuses about his new club's prospects. 'We're really good, and when we get the players back and we have the depth in the squad and have to start competing for spots, that's when you get the best out of these players.'

Past experiences give him the perspective to realise how exhilarating his football at Elland Road can be. Although he lives for the present he doesn't forget what he saw along the way. Viduka is proud that a stand at his first club, Melbourne Knights, was built by the money trickling though from his transfers and bears his name. He also remains bonded to Croatia - he and his Zagreb-born girlfriend have Croatian television at home and he watches it every day. His extraordinary exploits around the globe stay with him, constantly inspiring his hopes for the future.
