The calling came from the president of the club - who also happened to be the president of the country. The late Franjo Tudjman was on an official visit to Australia and was told that the sensation who had been top scorer in the Australian league for two seasons running was of Croatian descent. Viduka and his parents went to meet Tudjman for lunch in Melbourne and, feeling 'honoured and flattered', he was soon on his way, making the opposite journey taken by mum and dad in the Sixties. Croatian traditions had been a large part of his upbringing - it was the first language he spoke - but he was so ingrained in the Australian lifestyle that Zagreb's greeting amounted to a huge culture shock. 'When my parents came to Australia they came because they had no money, they were poor, at that time it was a communist system and it wasn't a free place. It's a battle: you come to a new country, you don't know the language, don't know where you're going to sleep. When I went to Croatia I was all right because I had a job and I got paid pretty well. But it was tough because I was 19 and I came to a place in transition between communism and democracy. For me, being in a place where the people had the communist mentality was difficult because I'd lived in a free country all my life. You see how people think and react differently. It was very, very stressful.' 'The situation is so bad over there people are struggling to live. They earn something like $100 a month and you can't live on that. Also people have a lot of social problems, having lost a lot of relatives and limbs in the war. Where my father was from was occupied for about four years in the early Nineties and it was taken over. They killed my grandmother's brother and her son. So...' He pauses and reflects. Life for Viduka on the field was also alien to a boy bred in a country where sport is a positive thread in the fabric of society. Playing for the team seen as an arm of the government because of the President's patronage meant political hatred was rife. Opponents resented what was seen as favouritism and complained of corruption, and even the club's own supporters railed against them because Tudjman had changed the name from 'Dynamo' to 'Croatia' Zagreb, in an attempt to make them the national club. They felt their heritage was being betrayed and wanted vengeance. 'Marko' Viduka, who had gone there merely wanting to play football, was mystified: 'I remember leaving the ground and the home crowd were cheering for the other team the whole game. It was politically motivated. Towards the end of my time there, because of my involvement with the President, people were having a go at me. It was hard because I would go out and play, and I remember one game where, before I even started, there were 40,000 people singing "Viduka's a pooftah" or something like that. My own fans! It's not a very nice situation to be in. There was a game when I was man of the match and after I scored a really good goal they were booing me. So it's not a normal situation to be in. I wasn't motivated to play. I was confused, thinking what have I got to do to have a normal situation? It turned me off football. I was happy to go. Moving to Britain was refreshing. People are just interested in football, not politics.' Enter Celtic, and the relief of a fresh opportunity. But when his transfer became prolonged - it kept stalling on the way the fee would be divvied up between Croatia Zagreb and Viduka's signing on fee - he'd suddenly had enough. So he fled to the sanctuary of his family in Melbourne for a two-month sabbatical to get his head together. The Scottish media painted him as another Paolo Di Canio permanently on the brink of explosion. He feels unfairly misrepresented. 'In that respect it was a bad place to go to because the Scottish press are mental up there,' he muses. 'They made up so many things, they said I was in an asylum and went to some cuckoo place. It was ridiculous. I had three training sessions before I went and they said somebody kicked me so I got upset and went home!' He laughs at the lunacy of it all. As if. Viduka, as Leeds have recently come to realise, is anything but a cowardly player. His critics in Scotland had to acknowledge it too, considering he finished last season there as top scorer and Players' Player of the Year. Whilst in Glasgow he took particular interest in the fortunes of Leeds, because Harry Kewell is his mate, and his impact since joining him in Yorkshire has been dramatic. He has bought a new dimension to the team. Although last season at Elland Road was immensely promising, you couldn't help wondering how much more could have been achieved had they not lost Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Granted, the exuberant efforts of Alan Smith and Michael Bridges went a long way to filling a gaping hole, but Leeds still needed a free-scoring, line-leading spearhead; a forward with supreme self- confidence; a striker with a proven record and presence. It took Viduka a while to find his rhythm. Just as his talents blossomed at Celtic after a false start, Leeds have also felt the benefits of his penchant for invigorating himself with a few deep breaths of Aussie air. Before returning for the Olympics he looked, as one Leeds sup porter so delicately put it, like he had been on the Tomas Brolin diet. Short of fitness, they reckoned David O'Leary had bought a hulking, workaday number nine who would hopefully nick the kind of scrappy goals so alien to the works of art favoured by Harry Kewell and Michael Bridges. Those expectations have been exceeded in spades. 'When I first arrived I wasn't scoring goals, which was basically due to lack of fitness. I had been out for three months and had done nothing. For me, I'm a big bloke and I really need to get fit. I have to do a really good pre-season just to get my lungs and my engines going. This pre-season I signed for Leeds and had to wait a week for my work permit while the boys were all training. 'Then I injured my ankle and was out for another three weeks. Even in the Olympics I didn't feel fit, I couldn't recover after runs and stuff. How did it turn around? I scored some goals, that's how it is in my game. 'For some reason when I came back I felt good. When you're confident you can be standing on the edge of the box, somebody kicks the ball, it hits your arse and goes in. But you work on confidence. It comes with training and that's where I try to give 100 per cent in training because if I do it there I'm going to do it in the game as well.' That confidence glowed during that astounding, virtuoso four-goal show against Liverpool. Afterwards he deliberately decided to duck out of the limelight, wary of the pitfalls of being portrayed as the main man in a team game. Personally and professionally, preening is not his style. Pat Rafter, commenting on what is expected of Australian sportsmen, summed it up succinctly: 'Australians are very laid back people, very approachable people. If any athletes aren't that way they are generally perceived as dickheads.' It's a sentiment Viduka fully subscribes to. During the Socceroos successful jaunt at Hampden Park for last week's international, the spotlight of attention focused so intensely on Viduka it virtually blacked out the rest of the squad. It would have been embarrassing were they not all so chummy about it. There is a general acceptance that 'Duks' as he is known to his team-mates, is worthy of special treatment. As fellow striker Paul Agostino pointed out, 'He gets a lot of attention but to me it's fair because he's a world-class player and he deserves everything that he gets.' There wasn't a trace of jealousy or sarcasm in his voice, even though he has a superior goals-to-games record for his country than Viduka. Agostino admires the fact that while he made it to Europe on the back of hard work and aggression, Viduka's break was based on the kind of natural skill and flair other players can only wish for. He is one of the shining lights who give the Socceroos credibility. They are all desperate to take that further by qualifying for the next World Cup. David O'Leary might baulk at the thought of every call-up but Viduka won't fail the cause. He is blossoming vibrantly in the Premiership. So much that Australia coach Frank Farina reckons Viduka would fetch in the region of £20 million today, five months after Leeds paid a mere £6 m. On the majestic form epitomised by that quartet against Liverpool, he could pick his world club if he wanted to. It's easy to get carried away by one mesmerising performance but, as Farina points out, he's been on a permanent hot streak since childhood. 'He was scoring a lot of goals as a teenager in Australia and when he left a lot of people doubted he would score goals in Croatia. Sure enough he ended up top scorer there two or three years in a row. Then he went to Scotland, and then on to England, and the same doubts cropped up again. But Mark Viduka keeps scoring goals. It's a God-given talent. He's a very big man but he's very quick on his feet and he has a gift for goals, which makes him a perfect centre forward.' Viduka was a born goalscorer. When he was nine he struck 13 times in a single match, and he has barely stopped since. His consistency is remarkable. If it can continue, the prospect of his burgeoning partnership with Alan Smith being reinforced by the attacking urges of Harry Kewell, Michael Bridges and Jason Wilcox, when they recover from injury, promises exciting times ahead. Viduka, who 'can't wait' to play with compatriot Kewell, enthuses about his new club's prospects. 'We're really good, and when we get the players back and we have the depth in the squad and have to start competing for spots, that's when you get the best out of these players.' Past experiences give him the perspective to realise how exhilarating his football at Elland Road can be. Although he lives for the present he doesn't forget what he saw along the way. Viduka is proud that a stand at his first club, Melbourne Knights, was built by the money trickling though from his transfers and bears his name. He also remains bonded to Croatia - he and his Zagreb-born girlfriend have Croatian television at home and he watches it every day. His extraordinary exploits around the globe stay with him, constantly inspiring his hopes for the future.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Touch the earth
fields.standfirst: To experience Africa fully, there's nothing for it but to get on your bike, says  Stephen Pritchard
fields.trailText: To experience Africa fully, there's nothing for it but to get on your bike, says Stephen Pritchard.
fields.body:
A young South African man was talking to a woman selling fruit in the main street of a northern Tanzanian village. 'Do you think you could make one of these?', he asked in rapid Swahili, holding up a lidded box, a simple frame covered with woven banana leaves. 'I'll try,' she replied. 'Come back in a couple of days.'

Jean Du Plessis makes many similar calls in Mto wa Mbu (Mosquito River) near Lake Manyara in his quest to provide some income for the local tribeswomen. 'It's difficult to believe, but there is a litter problem in the Serengeti,' he said. 'People go on game drives and just dump their cardboard and plastic picnic boxes. I'm trying to persuade the local women to make boxes from banana leaves that are biodegradable or that the tourists will want to take home. That way everybody wins: the environment and the people.'

Two days later we returned to the fruit seller and a perfect replica of the original had been turned out. 'It took me a whole day,' she said, 'but I think I will get faster. I could probably make about three a day.' That would represent about an extra £2 a day for her family; not much, but significant in a nation where the average wage is only £35 a month.

Du Plessis, a 26-year-old former ranger, wants Tanzanians to share in the prosperity that big game tourism is bringing to the country, but to do it in a way that does not harm the environment. Going on an African safari is hugely rewarding, he says, but looking at animals from inside a Land-Rover is a bit like sitting in a goldfish bowl; your feet literally never touch the ground, and after a few days you can feel strangely detached from the real Africa and its people.

Serena Active, Du Plessis's new arm of the Serena hotels and lodges group, aims to connect the safari-goer with the landscape and culture. He leads fascinating walks through Mto wa Mbu, describing the crops and meeting and talking to the locals who greet him with undisguised pleasure. These are not Disneyesque 'cultural experiences': no one tries to sell trinkets or entice you into their rudimentary shops; this is a real opportunity to learn about an almost medieval way of life.

We were welcomed by Bibi, an 80-year-old woman who showed us her home; an earth-floored, mud-walled, banana leaf-thatched hut, which she shared with her daughters and numerous grandchildren; children who would benefit directly from the walk we were taking that morning. Some of the profits from the £28-a-head charge go directly to the village. So far Jean has spent about £250 building a kindergarten out of local timber with a £350 concrete toilet block. Eighty children are taught in three sessions every day by a dedicated teacher part-funded by the walking project.

A few days later we sped down the Rift Valley escarpment on a 10-mile mountain bike ride that took us through the village again. Children ran out to greet us and stare at these strange creatures in helmets and backpacks. It was election day and the kindergarten, just like any school in Britain, had been turned into a polling station; a patient, humbling queue forming outside. We rode out to the Masai tribesmen's land on the banks of the lake where young children drove cattle herds 300-strong on to fresh pasture and maribou storks and brilliantly-coloured bee-eaters wheeled overhead in the warm air. The day before we had hiked for three hours with Du Plessis's partner, Megan Craft, amid the stunning scenery surrounding the Ngorongoro crater, a 100-square-mile caldera, formed nearly three million years ago.

We walked away from the crater and up the slopes of Mt Oldeani, passing cattle and goats kicking up clouds of red dust on their way down to drink. We encountered Masai tribesmen, visible for miles in their bright red tunics and armed only with spear and staff. This is a national park and home to all the wild animals of Africa; lion, cheetah, leopard, elephant, buffalo, rhino. While the area we walked was deemed to be away from their normal habitats, each hike is accompanied by an armed park ranger - just in case - but the fearless Masai put their trust in their mystic red and their spears.

We had spent the previous day and that morning in a Land-Rover, touring the crater, marvelling at the huge variety of wildlife, and were ready to stretch our legs. Leading the trek was Tim Mdinka, one of the seven staff employed by Serena Active who act as guides on walks and bike rides, bringing their local knowledge to bear when describing the dramatic landscape, the animals , the plants and the trees. Tim told us about life in Tanzania; how education is compulsory from seven to 14 , but how few go on after that; how families are still having eight to 10 children each; how the Masai honour their cattle (the larger the herd, the higher the status of the herdsman). He stooped down and picked some objects off the ground. 'Here, have these,' he said, handing them to my younger son Nicholas, 'they're zebra teeth.'

A little later he stooped again and picked up something bright; a carefully worked tool, like an arrow head. 'Something from a witchdoctor, I think,' he said and added it to Nicholas's collection.

Over the final ridge we watched the sun set over Lake Eyasi, a lovely sight made even lovelier by a glass of champagne supplied from a Land-Rover waiting to drive us back through the dark to the Ngorongoro Serena lodge. Far below us on the banks of the lake live the 500 members of the Hutza tribe - hunter-gatherers who wear animal skins and eat baboons. No government has yet been able to persuade them to send their children to school.

To help elect a new government, Tim joined us the next day for a lift back to Manyara. He had to vote in his home district, so chose to give up a day and a night to go to the polls; a country that has been independent for only 40 years values democracy rather higher than we do in this country.

We joined Jean again on our final day at Manyara for a hike down a river gorge to the gates of the national park. We were going to spend the whole day in the Land-Rover in the company of our excellent, knowledgable driver, Peter Njau, so it made sense to have a good walk beforehand - and some walk it was. We began by skirting along the edge of escarpment, followed by curious baboons. Jean explained that some 60 troupes live here, each with about 80 members. He pointed out mongoose, civet and bushbuck tracks; a hyenas den - 'don't stand in front of it. They rush out when disturbed'- and a termite mound, a teeming miniature city with 20 million inhabitants. 'They are rather tasty when fried. Like peanuts.'

After showing my sons how the damsel fly traps ants for her supper, Jean led us on a 400ft descent into a river gorge where great trees shaded the sun and water rushed over massive boulders. As we picked our way through the undergrowth, Jean told us of his background; he had worked as a ranger in the Kalahari and Zululand and managed game lodges across Tanzania. It was at Klein's Camp that he met Megan, who was conducting a year's research into the lions of the Serengeti. They both noticed that safari-goers needed to get some exercise after long hours in trucks and came up with their hiking and biking plans earlier this year. Abseiling and climbing followed and next year they plan to launch game-watching from canoes on Lake Manyara.

Mto wa Mbu, in common with a lot of Africa, has its fair share of street children, some abandoned by their parents, but more often orphaned by Aids. Serena Active want to employ about 15 boys to act as canoe crew, maintaining and launching the boats and manning the picnic stops. It's another example of the desire to get the local people positively involved in the benefits of tourism.

It seems a far cry from Jean's days as a game ranger. My sons listened spellbound as he recalled being charged by rhino and buffalo - and meeting lions face-to-face.

'It's the sound of their roars that really shakes you,' he said. 'It goes right through to your bones. But mostly it's a warning; they are not going to attack you, just give you a very, very big fright. You must stand completely still and they'll back off.'

We'll take your word for that, Jean...

Getting there

Serena Hotels has safari lodges and hotels in Kenya,Tanzania and Zanzibar (00 254 2 710511 or mktg@serena.co.ke).

Somak Holidays offer a Serena Serengeti Safari departing weekly from Gatwick for a six-night itinerary which includes one night at Lake Manyara Serena Lodge and two nights at the Ngorongoro Serena Lodge. Prices start from £1,213 per person. This includes return flights on British Airways transfers, game drives, full board and free regional add ons from 11 regional airports. 0208 423 3000 or email: holidays@somak.co.uk

Serena Active charge £28 for long hikes, village walks, biking and abseiling.

fields.headline: Buy, buy, buy in Bombay
fields.standfirst: From glitzy malls to cavernous bazaars, shopaholics will love Asia's Dream Factory, writes  Jennifer Coyle
fields.trailText: From glitzy malls to cavernous bazaars, shopaholics will love Asia's Dream Factory, writes Jennifer Coyle.
fields.body:
'Mobile phone or credit card, Madam?' You won't get past the stern doormen at Crossroads Mall in Bombay without one of these status symbols. This draconian admission policy was introduced by the store owners as a despairing response to the hordes that thronged the city's glitziest mall to try out the escalators instead of the shops.

The Western-style shopping experience is still a novelty here in the city known as the Dream Factory, the home of Bollywood movies and the best shopping in India. Forget about the odd mall or department store, the real business of buying and selling takes place on every street corner or in one of the cavernous bazaars of Bhuleshwar and Kalbadevi. Leave your credit card behind, take a deep breath and plunge straight in.

The biggest of these enormous bazaars is Crawford Market, where the shopkeepers perch vertiginously atop piles of fruit and vegetables. They'll nimbly navigate these towering displays to fetch and weigh your chosen items; watch out as well for the wholesale buyers and the cryptic handshakes that confirm their deals.

The central animal market is a real Noah's Ark, and you can even escort your doomed purchase to the nearby meat market for slaughter, although less hardened carnivores should make straight for Mangaldas Market instead. This is where Mumbaikars choose from the dazzling array of fabric and material, from the finest silk saris to raw cotton. Shopping is serious business here and speedy transactions are unheard of. No money changes hands before many cups of chai are consumed and dozens of prices are ritually offered and scorned by both parties. Slip off your shoes, take a seat on the floor with the shopkeepers and expect preposterous outrage at the onset of the delicate negotiations: 'At that price Madam, my family of 13 and mother-in-law will starve in the streets!'

Much doleful sighing and sad head shaking from both parties must accompany the serious haggling before the deal is struck and everyone parts the best of friends. Get a local tailor to make an impeccable copy of a favourite garment from your new material, or go native and get fitted for some floaty shalwar kameez or kurta pyjamas. Pick up some stylish sandals from Kemp's Corner, or get a cobbler to make them to your own design.

Brave the machinegun-wielding guards at Zaveri bazaar or the glittering 'TBD' store at the old Opera House and accessorise your new outfit with some seriously glamorous jewellery.

If you've still got money to burn, take a wander through Chor Bazaar. You're sure to pick up something interesting in this warren of eclectic shops and stalls - how about an antique gramophone or kitsch film mementoes? This is a graveyard of old Raj-era memorabilia and nautical artefacts but it's also infamously dubbed the Thieves Market, so don't expect a guarantee. For the strictly law-abiding, Phillip's Antiques in Colaba has enjoyed an unblemished reputation since 1860.

When you're weary of haggling, Bombay has plenty of more sedate shopping options. Pick up some cut-price casual wear as you stroll down 'Fashion Street' near the Bombay Gymkhana. For souvenirs or traditional handicrafts, head for the vast government- run Cottage Industries Emporiums, which sell products from all over India under one roof.

Although these are fixed-price stores, you don't just hand over cash for the goods - here there's a different kind of shopping ritual to observe. An army of assistants will trail shoppers around each department, providing receipts in exchange for the chosen items. Bring the collection of receipts to the Cash till, make the payment, wait for a handwritten note to produce at the Delivery till, then wait at the Dispatch Counter where the goods will be painstakingly wrapped, labelled and stamped before finally being entrusted to the impatient customer.

For the committed consumer, Bombay is shopping heaven. Don't expect anything to open before 10am and take the time to enjoy the protracted negotiations with every purchase - at least there's no fear of impulse buying. At the end of a hard day's haggling, head for one of the fabulous Art Deco cinemas and suspend your disbelief for an hour or three as you enjoy a lavish masala movie. The fabulous costumes and ornate sets will inspire you to do bit more bargaining tomorrow.

This draconian admission policy was introduced by the store owners as a despairing response to the hordes that thronged the city's glitziest mall to try out the escalators instead of the shops. The Western-style shopping experience is still a novelty here in the city known as the Dream Factory, the home of Bollywood movies and the best shopping in India. Forget about the odd mall or department store, the real business of buying and selling takes place on every street corner or in one of the cavernous bazaars of Bhuleshwar and Kalbadevi. Leave your credit card behind, take a deep breath and plunge straight in. The biggest of these enormous bazaars is Crawford Market, where the shopkeepers perch vertiginously atop piles of fruit and vegetables. They'll nimbly navigate these towering displays to fetch and weigh your chosen items; watch out as well for the wholesale buyers and the cryptic handshakes that confirm their deals. The central animal market is a real Noah's Ark, and you can even escort your doomed purchase to the nearby meat market for slaughter, although less hardened carnivores should make straight for Mangaldas Market instead. This is where Mumbaikars choose from the dazzling array of fabric and material, from the finest silk saris to raw cotton. Shopping is serious business here and speedy transactions are unheard of. No money changes hands before many cups of chai are consumed and dozens of prices are ritually offered and scorned by both parties. Slip off your shoes, take a seat on the floor with the shopkeepers and expect preposterous outrage at the onset of the delicate negotiations: 'At that price Madam, my family of 13 and mother-in-law will starve in the streets!' Much doleful sighing and sad head shaking from both parties must accompany the serious haggling before the deal is struck and everyone parts the best of friends. Get a local tailor to make an impeccable copy of a favourite garment from your new material, or go native and get fitted for some floaty shalwar kameez or kurta pyjamas. Pick up some stylish sandals from Kemp's Corner, or get a cobbler to make them to your own design. Brave the machinegun-wielding guards at Zaveri bazaar or the glittering 'TBD' store at the old Opera House and accessorise your new outfit with some seriously glamorous jewellery. If you've still got money to burn, take a wander through Chor Bazaar. You're sure to pick up something interesting in this warren of eclectic shops and stalls - how about an antique gramophone or kitsch film mementoes? This is a graveyard of old Raj-era memorabilia and nautical artefacts but it's also infamously dubbed the Thieves Market, so don't expect a guarantee. For the strictly law-abiding, Phillip's Antiques in Colaba has enjoyed an unblemished reputation since 1860. When you're weary of haggling, Bombay has plenty of more sedate shopping options. Pick up some cut-price casual wear as you stroll down 'Fashion Street' near the Bombay Gymkhana. For souvenirs or traditional handicrafts, head for the vast government- run Cottage Industries Emporiums, which sell products from all over India under one roof. Although these are fixed-price stores, you don't just hand over cash for the goods - here there's a different kind of shopping ritual to observe. An army of assistants will trail shoppers around each department, providing receipts in exchange for the chosen items. Bring the collection of receipts to the Cash till, make the payment, wait for a handwritten note to produce at the Delivery till, then wait at the Dispatch Counter where the goods will be painstakingly wrapped, labelled and stamped before finally being entrusted to the impatient customer. For the committed consumer, Bombay is shopping heaven. Don't expect anything to open before 10am and take the time to enjoy the protracted negotiations with every purchase - at least there's no fear of impulse buying. At the end of a hard day's haggling, head for one of the fabulous Art Deco cinemas and suspend your disbelief for an hour or three as you enjoy a lavish masala movie. The fabulous costumes and ornate sets will inspire you to do bit more bargaining tomorrow.

webTitle: Here comes that media circus -  'the NHS winter crisis'

fields.headline: Here comes that media circus -  'the NHS winter crisis'
fields.standfirst: The annual winter crisis is a media event, used by NHS managers to leverage more money out of the Treasury. The NHS plan is the first step to solving it, writes Nick Samuels
fields.trailText: The annual NHS winter crisis is a media event, used by NHS managers to leverage more money out of the Treasury. The NHS plan is the first step to solving it, writes Nick Samuels
fields.body:
"Downing Street forces BBC retreat on health poll," reported the Guardian two weeks ago. This was a preview performance for the best Christmas panto of the year - the NHS winter crisis. There will be a crisis this year, because there always is. It is an annual fixture that has little to do with access to NHS services and everything to do with NHS politics and the media.

The crisis is akin to the annual flu bug. We know it's coming, but we don't know where, or when. Vaccination against it can never be comprehensive and, once identified, there is little we can do. It festers uncomfortably for a short while before quietly slipping from public notice. For NHS managers, the lull before the storm is an uncomfortable period while they try to workout which hospital will be hit first and on what issue: intensive care beds, A&E waits, nurse shortages

Then, the polls come. Everyone is doing survey after survey - almost every day - to assess the "true" state of the NHS. NHS and government surveys are designed to identify problems earlier and sort them out fast, before the media find out. Media surveys are designed to identify problems and publicise them fast, before the government can respond. For the average NHS manager, they are a complete pain. The volume and spread of data requested tie up many staff, including doctors and nurses, who could be more usefully occupied elsewhere. I'm still waiting for the poll that asks how many surveys have been completed this week.

Hospitals hate polls. Not only do they have to provide performance snapshots, but they need to anticipate where they will feature in the league table that will be created. The ideal position to be in is chugging along nicely in the top third. Not so high that others will wait to watch you fail, and not so low that ministers start suggesting rapid change.

For local NHS staff, it is like waiting for a doodlebug to hit. You can hear it coming, but just pray that it flies over and hits someone else. First, a local crisis story emerges: refrigerated vans doubling as mortuaries, local radio appeals for anyone familiar with thermometers to come and lend a hand. Second, one of the polls will strike just the right note to turn the local issue into a national one. Last, and most disastrously, a newspaper editor will turn up in A&E needing treatment, experience bedlam and seek revenge. The winter crisis has then truly started. This is the moment that many have actually been waiting for.

The media are delighted. All the tried and tested NHS crisis stories are dusted down, almost verbatim, from the previous year and acres of coverage can be filled. The columnists have a field day creating quick fixes for a 50-year-old issue. The BBC can now almost certainly guarantee high ratings for the Casualty Christmas misery special. NHS managers and health ministers are usually quietly pleased. Everyone can start sending their shopping lists to No 10. Managers and doctors want new wings, operating theatres, intensive care beds. Unions demand more staff and better pay - happily just before pay negotiations reach conclusion. Ministers push themselves to the front of the extra funding queue at the Treasury. Education, police, roads and trident submarines get pushed back again.

I am not seeking to diminish the difficulties the NHS faces during the winter, nor the unacceptable and traumatic experiences of some patients. Staff shortages, lack of intensive care beds and crowded A&Es are near year-round issues which get highlighted at Christmas. Creating the NHS plan is the first serious recognition that the system was failing, not winter. Funding the plan is the first serious attempt to put it right.

webTitle: Book of the week: Eye of a navigator

fields.headline: Eye of a navigator
fields.standfirst: 'Around the World in 80 Years' by Eric Newby, Harper Collins
fields.trailText: 'Around the World in 80 Years' by Eric Newby, Harper Collins
fields.body:
Eric Newby, the former Observer travel editor whose books inspired a generation of narrative writers, is hanging up his boots at the age of 80. Around the World in 80 Years may be his swansong but it throws a new reflective light on his work, for this is a collection of Newby's photographs, many previously unpublished, adorned only by a nostalgic introductory essay and some anecdotal captions.

There is a wonderful scrapbook set at the front with pictures of Newby, his wife Wanda - his constant travelling companion - and their family and friends. 'My life has been an exercise in erratic navigation,' writes Newby and it is the charming but direct Wanda who has kept him steady as he panics when his luggage goes out of sight or chaos looms. She is pictured sleeping blissfully on the Trans-Siberian railway in a compartment 'reduced to a shambles' by her husband.

The excitement of Newby's writing comes from his self-deprecatory humour, his intense curiosity about people as well as places and an enthusiasm for the uncharted path. It was this raw energy that fired his writing. These pictures, beautifully presented with a warm sepia-edged glow, provide another perspective. They show a gentle stylish side to Newby. He is an outstanding photographer who combines an ability to capture the significant moment with some creative composition.

Some of the landscapes are beguiling. The river Tay winds timelessly through Perthshire framed by a ruined tower on a cliffside at Kinnoull Hill; vines on the Veneto appear to be on a winter march and a silhouetted boy brings perspective to a primeval water landscape in Bali.

As in Newby's writing, the book catches a specific moment in the lives of the people he meets. A serene elderly woman looks out from her window in Rouseau, Dominica; a lorryload of Turkish guestworkers beam for the camera on their return home from Germany; and Signor Ugolotti, the Apennine farmer who hid Newby behind enemy lines during the war, puffs proudly on his pipe.

We'll miss not having New adventures to follow but this self-confessed worrier need have no fears that his loyal army of readers will be enchanted by his final collection.

fields.headline: Happy hair-raising experience
fields.trailText: Christmas shoppers struggling for inspiration could find what they are looking for in their local travel agency. Two new brochures have been launched this month offering a variety of gift 'experiences', ranging from a massage at a top health spa to a day on a Welsh pig farm.
fields.body:
Would Uncle Derek prefer the car defroster gift set or a flight in a MiG fighter jet? Tricky one. And does Mum really need another Delia Smith cookbook or would a masterclass with Jamie Oliver be more suitable? Hmmm. Christmas shoppers struggling for inspiration could find what they are looking for in their local travel agency. Two new brochures have been launched this month offering a variety of gift 'experiences', ranging from a massage at a top health spa to a day on a Welsh pig farm.

Thomas Cook travel agents will sell Red Letter Days' open-dated gift vouchers from 20 November to 20 December with prices starting from £49 for a morning's riding in Hyde Park and going up to £1,000 for a day's Formula One racing.

'This is the first time that such a wide range of experiences has been available on the high street. Customers can book these experiences in the same way as a holiday, or for a Christmas gift you can buy an open-dated Red Letter Days voucher,' said Thomas Cook commercial manager Paula Thomson.

For the first time activity holiday specialist Acorn Activities (08703 33 88 77) has produced a separate brochure presenting its range of Great Escapes gift vouchers. Most experiences are geared to get the adrenalin pumping, from bungee jumping and driving a tank to the romantic 'zorbing for two', where the lucky couple are strapped into a giant inflatable plastic ball and rolled down a hill in Dorset.

All packages include free insurance but, just to be on the safe side, Acorn's brochure adds the precautionary footnote: 'It is assumed that participants have a strong heart and a good sense of humour.'

fields.headline: Hotel du Vin, Bristol
fields.trailText:
Sounds like a place with a big cellar.
You bet. This is the third Hotel du Vin. Others are already up and running in Winchester and Tunbridge Wells, wowing visitors who require comfortable, hip and reasonably priced town-centre boltholes with great little bistros attached. Like its siblings, the Bristol establishment (built as a sugar warehouse) takes its wine list jolly seriously. Every bedroom is named after a different vintage.
fields.body:
Sounds like a place with a big cellar.
You bet. This is the third Hotel du Vin. Others are already up and running in Winchester and Tunbridge Wells, wowing visitors who require comfortable, hip and reasonably priced town-centre boltholes with great little bistros attached. Like its siblings, the Bristol establishment (built as a sugar warehouse) takes its wine list jolly seriously. Every bedroom is named after a different vintage.

Decorated to match? Who could rest easy in Veuve Cliquot orange?
No - thankfully the colour scheme in all the rooms is uniform. Cream walls, slate-coloured woodwork, chocolate linen curtains and crisp white bedlinen. But I'll wager guests spend most time in their bathrooms.

Why would they want to do that?
The baths are freestanding roll-top jobbies with clawed feet. The walk-in, walk-out powershowers are as forceful as Paxman in a strop. And the water is always piping hot.

So what's the rest of the place like?
Low-key and groovy, without falling into the trap of being trendy (which simply means a place feels dated two weeks after opening). Neither is this one of those painfully styled hotels where the staff look daggers if you dent the armchair cushions. It's busy, full of cigar smoke and cooking smells. And the pock-pock of billiard balls (there's a green baize table upstairs in a den). After lunch, loll in the deep leather sofas while snoozing your way through the papers, and you'll suddenly find it's time for supper...

Which brings us to the bistro.
Dark polished wood, candlelight, and friendly French staff. The menu - lots of fish - is fresh, unpretentious and delicious. Prices might seem a bit steep for Bristol, but the locals plainly feel it's worth every penny (the place was packed, even on a Sunday night).

So now Bristol has got a spanking new hotel to go with its spanking new Lottery-funded museums?
And it's every bit as good as Explore@Bristol, a splendid new science museum a stone's throw away on the quayside. I didn't get around to visiting Wildscreen, the new wildlife centre. Oh well, time to book a return visit...

 Hotel Du Vin & Bistro (0117 925 5577), The Sugar House, Narrow Lewins Mead, Bristol BS1 2NU. Double rooms cost from £99 to £125

webTitle: Livingstone: my Tube war with Labour

fields.headline: Livingstone: my Tube war with Labour
fields.standfirst: In an echo of his battles with Thatcher, London's mayor is taking on the Government over privatisation
fields.trailText: In an echo of his battles with Thatcher, London's mayor is taking on the Government over privatisation.
fields.body:
It will be just like old times. Ken Livingstone has threatened to take the Government to court this week unless it hands over confidential papers about privatisation of the London Underground.

The showdown will revive memories of Livingstone's legendary legal tussles with Margaret Thatcher's administration when he led the Greater London Council - only this time pitting him against a Labour Government.

The London Mayor has warned Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott that he expects the commercially sensitive documents, detailing the bids from private companies for aspects of the Tube, to be handed to his new transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, when they are received by the Government tomorrow.

'If Bob Kiley isn't given copies of the best and final bids next week, and the public sector comparator, we will go to court,' he told The Observer.

'It is completely unreasonable to expect the man who is about to become responsible for running the system not to have sight of and be able to give advice based on this infor mation. If it remains confidential, it doesn't come to me.

'Why don't they want to give this out? Is it because the comparator [with the public sector] is full of holes and it's not a valid comparison?'

Minister for London Keith Hill told the Commons last week that Kiley had already received substantial information, but giving him commercially sensitive details about the bids 'could risk damaging the public sector position and prevent us from achieving best value'.

Livingstone still hopes Ministers will reconsider, but has taken legal advice. He insisted any court action would not become as poisonous as the infamous Fares Fair court battle between himself and Thatcher, since he got on well with Prescott.

But relations between the two men, already strained, would collapse if Livingstone went ahead, pitching the Mayor and the Government into the bitter confrontation Labour always feared.

It will also revive memories of Livingstone's battles with Thatcher, when he set himself up as a left-wing opponent to her policies, prompting months of demonstrations and legal battles over his attempts to improve transport in the capital.

But, perhaps mindful of those ultimately doomed struggles, Livingstone is well aware that the one thing for which he will not be forgiven by Londoners is failing to rescue their crumbling buses and trains.

He hired Kiley, who turned around the New York subway in the late Eighties, to mastermind a bond issue raising the necessary finance, but has been frustrated by the Government's insistence on pressing ahead with its planned part-privatisation, which Ministers say will raise guaranteed cash without compromising safety.

The row has erupted just as Livingstone, who still yearns to be readmitted to the Labour Party, had earned Downing Street's blessing for a speech on Europe tomorrow.

He will launch the London regional group of the pressure group Britain in Europe, condemning 'the small group of nutters' who want to break from Europe and arguing that London's financial viability depends on EU membership. Livingstone argues that inward investors are working on the assumption that the UK will join.

'I argued strongly that we should have gone in the beginning. I think Tony Blair would have won a referen dum in 1997 but as soon as the issue becomes one of joining a weak currency it becomes more difficult,' he said.

'If it were up to me I would say I think this is so hugely important to the future of Britain, we are turning the election into a referendum. I know Gordon's view is very much that we want to totally separate the euro from the election but the Tories won't allow us to do that.'

Six months into the job, Livingstone knows there have been grumbles that he should have done more by now to change Londoners' lives. But he is unrepentant, insisting that they will not see major differences until 2003, arguing that the media have not reported what he is doing.

'It won't be until my third year that people begin to notice differences. If they don't, there will be a new mayor in 2004,' he said.

'Given that a lot of papers, particularly in the last 10 days of the campaign, said it would be a great trauma, London would disappear into a black hole, anarchists and rioters will murder our children in their beds, it is up to them to explain why everything has been quite quiet.'

webTitle: The cook, the knife, the fief and Oliver

fields.headline: The cook, the knife, the fief and Oliver
fields.standfirst: Strange tales and Cork's colourful locals make  Martin Love and his family forget the rain
fields.trailText: Strange tales and Cork's colourful locals make Martin Love and his family forget the rain.
fields.body:
'Would anyone like another scone?' asks Rosemary. 'Or maybe a spot more tea? Do have some cake. It's made with our own eggs.' There was nothing unusual about the lavish tea spread, except for one minor detail: it was well after midnight. But sitting in the huge kitchen of Burton Park, a crumbling mansion in deepest Ireland, there seemed no better antidote to the horrors of our marathon 15-hour car/ ferry/car journey from England than a mug of Earl Grey and a few fairy cakes.

We had just arrived with our friends Ros and Ben and our various children for a family holiday in Co Cork - an area described in our brochure as being 'a sub-tropical oasis of palm trees and flowers'. If indeed it was a sub-tropical paradise, then we had obviously arrived during the rainy season. 'Ireland' and 'rain' may well be two words that feel lonely if they don't appear in the same sentence, but even the locals were amazed by the five days of continuous driving rain we brought with us. But, as they say, it didn't dampen our spirits.

Burton Park, a fine Caroline-period house which was rebuilt in 1709, may sound like a very grand holiday house, but we were staying in the old servants' quarters which had been converted into a subterranean holiday flat - complete with 4ft-thick walls and concealed tunnel entrances. Rosemary, the mistress of the house, suggested we might like a tour of Burton Park in the morning and asked us to come to the front steps the following day. 'If I don't hear you,' she said imperiously, 'just sound the gong.'

Unfortunately, we had no need to sound the gong as Rosemary came to fetch us bright and early. The guided tour began at the castellated gatehouse, took us past the huge oaks planted to commemorate the birth of each of the Rev Matthew Purcell's daughters in the 1800s, through huge drawing rooms and echoing hallways, before ending up in the family chapel.

Rosemary also showed us a carving- knife - well just its box actually - which apparently belonged to John Purcell who, in his eighties, used it to kill three muggers in 1811. For this he was knighted (he was known as the Knight of the Knife) and a law was passed saying that Irish octogenarians could kill in self-defence. Legend now has it that the next person to open the carving knife's box would die within the year. Looks like the Sunday roast is off this week, then.

Burton Park dominates the tiny village of Churchtown - a one pub, one shop, one church town (there's a sur prise) of about 20 houses. The son of a local family, the appropriately named Boss Murphy, has taken it upon himself to spruce the place up and he's even created a website (www.churchtown.org) - which seems as incongruous as having grazing cows in Oxford Circus. But if anything's going to put Churchtown on the map, it's the town's most famous former resident - the late Oliver Reed.

He's buried in the old Bruhenny graveyard under a huge grey slab inscribed with the simple words 'Robert Oliver Reed, 1938-1999, He made the air move', and the overgrown walls and weather-beaten stones of the ancient churchyard seem to provide a perfect resting place. We toasted him with a pint of Guinness in O'Neill's, Ollie's local pub, which is a short stumble across the road from the grave. The barman remembered him well. 'Oh yes, he was a decent fellow,' he said. A regular propping up the bar recalled how he used to buy everyone in the pub a drink by shouting 'And get one for the peasants.'

I imagine Oliver Reed might also have been a fan of Tony O'Neill's, an extraordinary grocer's, garage and pub all rolled into one in the next village of Buttevant. There, having filled up on gasoline and Guinness, we were shown pictures by Mrs Tony O'Neill of Michael Palin's recent visit and asked to sign her visitor's book - fame at last. It struck me that the extraordinary friendliness of everyone we met was in direct contradiction to the misery of the weather. It must be a real party come the winter.

One of the secrets of having a good holiday in Ireland, however, is to make sure you travel with someone who happens to have very good friends who live in the vicinity - not the easiest of things to do I grant you. But Ros and Ben came up with the goods by arranging lunch with their old friends Simon and Caroline. They invited us all to lunch and spent the week introducing us to the many weird and wonderful people of north Cork.

There was the local doctor who bred French heavy horses in a walled garden, there were Nick and Deirdre who had just bought a 100-room castle for the price of a two-bedroom flat in Putney (the one drawback being that only six of the rooms are habitable), and there were Simon and Caroline. He's a sheep-farmer-turned-landscape painter who writes music and builds model aeroplanes and she owns a designer shop which would be more at home in Sloane Street - it just happens to be in the frontiertown of Mallow (Moda on Main Street, if you're passing). All a little eccentric to you and me, but in this corner of Ireland it was boring old us who stood out like sore thumbs. It seems you can't live in the country's multi-coloured houses without becoming a little colourful yourself. But we are learning_ when we arrived home at the end of the holiday, well after midnight, the first thing we did was knock up a fresh batch of scones.

webTitle: Ancient Greeks head for silver screen

fields.headline: Stand aside Gladiator, the real Classics are coming
fields.trailText: The classics are back - not pseudo, sword-and-sandal sagas like  Gladiator , but the real thing. Ancient Greek historians and playwrights are providing the inspiration for a new wave of violent, psychological thrillers
fields.body:
They are the new screenwriters Hollywood is desperate to use. And soon they will be at a cinema near you: Euripides, Herodotus, Homer, Aristophanes and Aeschylus.

The classics are back - not pseudo, sword-and-sandal sagas like Gladiator, but the real thing. Ancient Greek historians and playwrights are providing the inspiration for a new wave of violent, psychological thrillers.

Next year The Bacchae, a full-length screen version of Euripides's sexually explicit and brutal play, will reach British screens. Produced by a major Hollywood filmhouse - Turman-Morrissey - the script has been described by reviewers as 'very adult'.

'This is not a period piece,' one said. 'But a movie that some will find offensive and many will find controversial.'

In 90 action-packed minutes a man is torn to shreds by a group of libidinous naked women; a pregnant mother is zapped by a lightning bolt sent by the father, Zeus; and amid scenes of mass nudity Dionysus, the hero, smashes his way through walls.

Other classical projects in production include a film by Michael Mann, director of The Insider, dramatising the heroic defence by the Spartan warriors of the pass at Thermopylae against the Persian hordes in 480 BC. Scriptwriters are drawing heavily on original Greek accounts, particularly those of Herodotus, traditionally seen as the father of history.

The part of Leonidas, the leader of the Spartans, is rumoured to have been written with George Clooney in mind. Mann has commissioned a second script about Julius Caesar and Pompey, whose rivalry led to civil war. Tom Hanks's name has been linked with the role of Caesar.

Even the producers of Tantalus (pictured), a 10-hour stage epic drawn from fragments of ancient texts, have been approached by American and British producers.

Mark Cousins, the BBC2 film critic, believes the trend represents a search for a new kind of masculinity on the screen. 'As Schwarzenegger and Stallone age, there is the need for a new macho hero. It was something that started with Russell Crowe in Gladiator and I think it is a reaction to the effeminate or gay characters in some of the recent successful romantic comedies. It is a reaction to Rupert Everett, in many ways.'

Cousins also believes the sudden emphasis on classical texts is part of a familiar Hollywood pattern. 'Whenever there is a technological development, the movies turn to the classic stories. They did it with early silent movies, they did it with Cinemascope, and now they are doing it with digital,' he said.

'They are the most baroque plots to take on. It is as if they are saying, "Look at what we can do".'

There are other, political, motivations. As the calls to check the growth of screen violence grow louder, Hollywood is turning to different ways of bringing home the box-office hits. 'By going back to the classics, film-makers can say, as they always have, "What do you mean, we are too violent?" These early stories were just as bad. It is a less controversial way of dealing with censorship,' Cousins said.

Last week's British launch of Sir Peter Hall's epic production of Tantalus, written from fragments of original ancient texts describing the story of the Trojan war, has brought the classic myths centre stage in Britain too. The Royal Shakespeare Company's co-production received rave reviews in Denver, where the 10-hour play cycle was first performed.

The RSC has already been approached by film companies interested in bringing the extraordinary work to the big screen. The scene in which the Trojan horse makes its fabled entrance into Troy has been hailed as a theatrical triumph and is believed to have whetted the appetite of directors.

John Barton, the play's writer, believes that the power of the Trojan myth is more than just 'relevant' today. He claims it addresses all the big questions, while having the narrative drive of a soap opera.

Professor Valentine Cunningham, of Oxford University, said he was not surprised to see some of the oldest tragic tales being revived for the big screen. 'Classic stories, or stories that are just very ancient, gain the status of myths in their retelling,' he said. 'They are stories that can be revivified... so they earn long life.'

While other classical scholars have pointed to the presence of 'deep structures' and 'archetypes' to explain the appeal of myth, Cunningham is sceptical.

'We should admit we don't know why they are retold. It is a mystery. We do know that each time they are retold the film director or author believes he is reaching the essential truth, and each time [those truths] are different.'

webTitle: Dorothy L Sayers fell for her detective hero

fields.headline: Sayers fell for her Wimsey, letters reveal
fields.trailText: Evidence of Dorothy L Sayers's obsessive relationship with her detective hero, Lord Peter Wimsey, comes to light this week in a collection of previously unseen letters and notebooks. The writer, who was fiercely protective of her suave and well-bred sleuth, appears at times to have believed he really existed.
fields.byline: Vanessa Thorpe, arts correspondent, and Simon de Burton
fields.body:
Evidence of Dorothy L Sayers's obsessive relationship with her detective hero, Lord Peter Wimsey, comes to light this week in a collection of previously unseen letters and notebooks. The writer, who was fiercely protective of her suave and well-bred sleuth, appears at times to have believed he really existed.

She drew up a full fictional family tree for Lord Peter and violently objected to attempts to portray him on stage or screen. The documents are expected to fetch up to £360,000 at auction next month and form the largest collection in private hands. Although Sotheby's has kept the identity of the owner a secret, she is known to be Fortuna Fleming, second wife of Sayers's son, Anthony.

'She has obviously decided to sell the family letters at last,' said Barbara Reynolds, the author's biographer and friend.

Sayers was not married, and her son grew up with a favourite cousin, Ivy Shrimpton. Much to Sayers's pride, Anthony won a scholarship to Balliol College - the same Oxford college Sayers had chosen for Wimsey.

The new documents have intrigued the writer Jill Paton Walsh, who published her own solution to Sayers's unfinished Wimsey mystery, Thrones, Dominions, in 1998. The manuscript had been abandoned by Sayers in 1936 and was rediscovered 60 years later in a safe at her literary agency. 'If some of the notes refer to Sayers's own plans for the ending of Thrones,' said Paton Walsh, 'then I am keen to see them.'

The sale at Sotheby's in London on 19 December will attract worldwide interest. A representative from Wheaton College, Illinois, where most of Sayers's manuscripts have been kept since the 1970s, is coming to London for the auction, but will have to bid against private devotees of Wimsey and his faithful manservant, Bunter. Included with the sale lot of papers, books, letters and contracts are rare, signed first editions, handwritten and typed manuscripts for novels and plays, the author's files on real-life crimes and more than 2,000 volumes from her library.

Up to £35,000 is expected for almost 300 of Sayers's original publishing contracts, royalty statements and bank records, while two typescripts for the Lord Peter Wimsey play, Busman's Honeymoon, could fetch £15,000. 'This is perhaps the most interesting find of all,' said Paton Walsh, who believes Sayers fell deeply under the spell of Wimsey. 'I would say she was more than a little in love with him.'

Sayers introduced Wimsey in Whose Body? in 1928. Her newly disclosed response to a request from the actor Peter Haddon, who wanted to play Wimsey in a film, betrays the strength of her feelings. 'I do not like the films and I do not want them,' she writes. 'There could not be a worse moment than this for letting film-minded people tamper with Peter. I will see the whole bunch of fools and liars at Elstree and Ealing in hell first.'

Sayers invented a genealogy of Wimsey's family which included spoof letters and documents relating to ancestors dating back three centuries. A thick file of papers relating to 'The Wimsey Family' is estimated to fetch up to £9,000.

Also under the hammer will be hundreds of letters sent to Sayers and copies of her typed replies, mostly dating from the late 1930s until her death in 1957, a period when the writer, who liked to wear men's suits complete with tie and cufflinks, was one of Britain's most celebrated public figures. One of the earliest letters, dated 1910, was sent by the Antarctic explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton to thank Sayers for a sonnet she wrote about him.

Dorothy Leigh Sayers was born in Oxford in 1893 and educated in Salisbury and at Somerville College, Oxford. After teaching in Hull, she became an advertising copy-writer and helped create the famous Toucan Guinness adverts. After the success of the first Wimsey book he appeared in eight further stories, among them Clouds of Witness (1926), The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club (1928), The Five Red Herrings (1931) and Strong Poison (1930).

Peter Selley, a books and manuscripts specialist at the auction house, said: 'Sayers was unquestionably one of the greatest detective writers of the twentieth century and this archive contains much autograph and typescript material not preserved in any other form. It covers the author's entire literary and professional life from her earliest juvenilia to her final lectures, articles, and her work during World War Two which included broadcasting on religious subjects for BBC Radio.'

Christopher Dean, chairman of the Dorothy L Sayers Society, said: 'Our concern is that, as far as possible, the items of extreme value to scholars are kept together. The personal letters are of tremendous significance, as are the papers relating to her scholastic life in areas other than detective fiction, such as her translation of Dante's Inferno and her Christian writings. It is all of great importance.'

webTitle: Regions are back on the agenda

fields.headline: Regions are back on the agenda
fields.standfirst: A recent Whitehall report on regional government provides important clues on government thinking, writes Dennis Reed
fields.trailText: Regional government, in a second Blair term, seems very much back on the agenda - having been kicked into touch early in this parliament, writes Dennis Reed
fields.body:
Regional government, in a second Blair term, seems very much back on the agenda - having been kicked into touch early in this parliament.

The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) recently published a "preliminary review" of literature and research findings on regional government in England. This is a substantial piece of work, analysing both domestic and international research. While carefully non-judgemental, it provides important clues on current government thinking.

The report covers research which indicates that regional government can be introduced both incrementally and asymmetrically - with different powers for different areas at different times - which fits in with current Labour thinking that referenda on regional government should only take place where there is strong public support, as in the north east, and in Yorkshire and Humberside. However, the report points out that such an approach can lead to less devolution of powers from national level, and more powers being taken upwards from local government.

The research also indicates that it is not necessary for there to be a historic identity in a region, in order to create a successful modern political structure (the German states are quoted as examples). This might be used to tackle the oft-quoted argument that there is no popular identification with some proposed regions, for example the east Midlands.

The report does not duck the inevitable tensions between a regional tier of government and local authorities over their respective powers and responsibilities. It argues that there should be a clear definition of powers to prevent "malfunction and conflict" and refers to the Council of Europe's helpful suggestion that "it may be prudent for local authorities to have a judicial remedy to protect themselves from interference."

The report is weaker on arguing the case for regional government and, in particular, on the fundamental democratic argument that existing layers of regional government - such as the regional development agencies, regional arms of national quangos, health service regional offices - are almost wholly unaccountable.

The research report provides an evidence-based rationale for directly elected regional government, and the fact that the DETR has published it now, prior to the publication of election manifestos, says much for the personal support of the deputy prime minister. The views of Hilary Armstrong, minister for local government, are known to be more ambivalent, and perhaps closer to those of No 10.

For example, a group of modernisers very close to Hilary Armstrong, the New Local Government Network, has recently issued a pamphlet which says it is "not persuaded" by current models of elected regional government. Instead, it advances the case for an informal city region concept backed up by a "subregional partnership contract". This suggestion is neither evidence-based nor thought through, and would inevitably involve local government functions, such as regeneration and planning, rather than central government devolution.

fields.bodyText: Regional government, in a second Blair term, seems very much back on the agenda - having been kicked into touch early in this parliament. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) recently published a "preliminary review" of literature and research findings on regional government in England. This is a substantial piece of work, analysing both domestic and international research. While carefully non-judgemental, it provides important clues on current government thinking. The report covers research which indicates that regional government can be introduced both incrementally and asymmetrically - with different powers for different areas at different times - which fits in with current Labour thinking that referenda on regional government should only take place where there is strong public support, as in the north east, and in Yorkshire and Humberside. However, the report points out that such an approach can lead to less devolution of powers from national level, and more powers being taken upwards from local government. The research also indicates that it is not necessary for there to be a historic identity in a region, in order to create a successful modern political structure (the German states are quoted as examples). This might be used to tackle the oft-quoted argument that there is no popular identification with some proposed regions, for example the east Midlands. The report does not duck the inevitable tensions between a regional tier of government and local authorities over their respective powers and responsibilities. It argues that there should be a clear definition of powers to prevent "malfunction and conflict" and refers to the Council of Europe's helpful suggestion that "it may be prudent for local authorities to have a judicial remedy to protect themselves from interference." The report is weaker on arguing the case for regional government and, in particular, on the fundamental democratic argument that existing layers of regional government - such as the regional development agencies, regional arms of national quangos, health service regional offices - are almost wholly unaccountable. The research report provides an evidence-based rationale for directly elected regional government, and the fact that the DETR has published it now, prior to the publication of election manifestos, says much for the personal support of the deputy prime minister. The views of Hilary Armstrong, minister for local government, are known to be more ambivalent, and perhaps closer to those of No 10. For example, a group of modernisers very close to Hilary Armstrong, the New Local Government Network, has recently issued a pamphlet which says it is "not persuaded" by current models of elected regional government. Instead, it advances the case for an informal city region concept backed up by a "subregional partnership contract". This suggestion is neither evidence-based nor thought through, and would inevitably involve local government functions, such as regeneration and planning, rather than central government devolution. I welcome the report and urge the DETR to follow it up with more material about the need for elected regional government and the importance of democratic accountability at a regional level, along with measures to ensure that local democracy is not jeopardised.  Dennis Reed is director of the Local Government Information Unit

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Gladiator | After Life | Beau Travail | American Graffiti
fields.trailText: Gladiator | After Life | Beau Travail | American Graffiti
fields.body:
Gladiator
(2000, 15, Columbia Tri-Star, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)
The most ferocious 'sword and sandals' epic since Barabbas (1962), Ridley Scott's exhilarating epic covers much the same period as Anthony Mann's classic Fall of the Roman Empire (1964), from the death of Marcus Aurelius in AD 180 to the disastrous 13-year rule of his decadent son Commodus. But it's an entirely pagan affair, eschewing early Christian piety, and centres on the revenge sought by the brave, loyal Spanish-born General Maximus (the formidable Russell Crowe), against Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), who sold him into slavery. From the opening battle against the Gauls, it's a gritty affair, cruel, exciting, magnificently staged. There's a special two-disc DVD version with out-takes, a 'making of' feature and historical background documentary.

After Life
(1998, PG, ICA Projects, DVD/Retail, Rental)
Following the collapse of traditional beliefs, twentieth-century playwrights and filmmakers continued to be fascinated by depicting life after death. Kore-Eda Hirokazu's wonderful movie is set in a Japanese limbo, a sparsely furnished former sanatorium where, every Monday, 20 recently dead people are processed for eternity. They have a day to select the moment in life they most want to remember, which is then processed on film to be retained after all other memories are obliterated. This humanist work is as much about our relations one to another in life as it is about how we compose ourselves to face death. It's moving and unsentimental.

Beau Travail
(1999, 15, Fox-Pathé, VHS/Rental, Retail)
Writer-director Claire Denis was born and grew up in French Africa and all her movies reveal her wonderful eye for the beauty of the continent and a complex feeling for the relationship between Europeans and their ex-colonial subjects. This poetic film, her finest to date, evokes in its title P.C. Wren's 1924 bestselling Beau Geste, and is a transposition to a present-day French Foreign Legion post beside the Red Sea of Herman Melville's homoerotic novella Billy Budd. The pure hero becomes the victim of a sad, envious sergeant (boot-faced Grégoire Colin), and Melville's God-like Captain Vere becomes a guilty veteran of French colonial wars played by Michel Subor, star of Godard's Le Petit Soldat. A haunting, unforgettable film.

American Graffiti
(1973, 12, Col Tri-Star, DVD/Retail)
George Lucas is the richest, most influential filmmaker of the past 30 years, but he's only directed four movies. This rite-of-passage picture set in a small Californian town one late summer day in 1962 is his best, a touching, truthful meditation on America's last truly innocent generation. Richard Dreyfuss and Ron Howard are contrasted high school graduates facing an apparently hopeful future in the pre-Vietnam, pre-assassination days of the Kennedy presidency. Francis Coppola produced, Haskell Wexler was visual adviser, and the music is a treat. The disc contains various extras.

webTitle: Agony aunt: Part-time pay for full-time working

fields.headline: Part-time pay for full-time working
fields.trailText: Agony aunt: Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
My son has a part-time job where he is supposed to work 24 hours a week. In reality he always does at least 48 hours a week. His net weekly pay is £120. Although he has worked there for 10 years, the company will not make him a full-time worker. This means he gets pay for only 24 hours when he is on holiday. And his sick pay would be similarly reduced. Can he do anything about this?

 Your son is working for a company that does not appear to obey the law. He should be paid at least £3.70 an hour to comply with the National Minimum Wage laws but he seems to be well below that rate. He could point this out to the company or he could ring the Government helpline on 0845 6000 678. The officials there will investigate the company without saying who tipped them off.

There are two ways to calculate the sum he should be paid when on holiday. Under the first, he would get just his contractual hours. Under the second, which assumes he is paid a variable amount per week, the average of his last 12 weeks' pay would be payable per week. Free advice is available from Citizens Advice Bureaux or from the Low Pay Unit.

Legal advice from the Low Pay Unit (helpline 0207 713 7583)

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: How Blair courted the Dome's great benefactor

fields.headline: How Blair courted the Dome's great benefactor
fields.standfirst:
Home Secretary faces questions after Tories rejected citizenship for Indian billionaire at the centre of corruption allegations

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: An Indian billionaire facing extradition from Britain was courted by Tony Blair's government and given citizenship here after his family donated £1m to help bail out the Millennium Dome,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
An Indian billionaire facing extradition from Britain was courted by Tony Blair's government and given citizenship here after his family donated £1m to help bail out the Millennium Dome, The Observer can reveal.

Srichand Hinduja, who will learn tomorrow whether he and two of his brothers will face trial in India over claims that they took £7m in kickbacks from Indian arms deals, was turned down for British citizenship by the Conservatives in 1990.

Home secretary Jack Straw approved Srichand Hinduja's application for a British passport last September, despite the fact that he and his family were at the centre of investigations by Indian police into one of the country's biggest corruption scandals. A year earlier the Hindujas had agreed to pump funds into the Faith Zone at the Dome.

Senior sources at India's Central Bureau of Investigation, the Indian equivalent of the FBI, believe it is 'very likely' that an Indian court will charge the Hinduja brothers with taking illegal commission as part of a controversial arms deal in 1986. If that happens, Indian prosecutors have confirmed they will move swiftly to extradite the Hindujas, the leading members of Britain's wealthiest Asian family, possibly ignitting a political scandal.

Such a turn of events would be highly embarrasing for Blair as the Hindujas have built up close links with New Labour.

The Hindujas have insisted they volunteered to help fund the Dome and that no Minister 'solicited' them for money. But the brothers visited Peter Mandelson in October 1998 when he was trade secretary and in charge of the Dome.

Mandelson claimed the meeting was about 'Indo-British relations', although he has admitted the Dome was referred to at the end.

Mandelson is also known to have met the Hindujas several times when he was Minister without portfolio and one source recalls a dinner Blair and Mandelson had at Hinduja's central London home before the election.

Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat spokesman on the Dome, said: 'It certainly seems eyebrow-raising that somebody who the Tories had turned down for a British passport should be given one so quickly by Labour. Questions have to be asked if was given as a thank you for trying to bail out the Dome.'

Four days after Srichand Hinduja became a British citizen, the Hindujas funded a reception at their London offices in honour of Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine and Leicester MP Keith Vaz, who had become Britain's first Asian minister. Mandelson and trade secretary Stephen Byers were also present.

Vaz is one of the Hindujas' closest political associates. As a backbench MP, he regularly visited their headquarters in London and attends many of their functions. When shadow trade and industry spokesman Christopher Chope asked parliamentary question on the Hindujas last year, he received a call from Vaz asking what he was up to.

However, despite such close relations with New Labour, recent events suggest Downing Street is trying to distance the Blairs from the Hindujas.

The Prime Minister was invited to the Hindujas' Diwali party, celebrating Indian new year, last month, but declined. A year earlier, the Prime Minister and his wife were star guests at the Hindujas' extravagant Diwali party in North London. Photos of Cherie dressed in a traditional Indian outfit were published around the world.

At the time the Hindujas and Downing Street were happy for the press to think the £1,000 silk embroidered kamize which Cherie wore was a gift from the Hindujas.

However, last week Cherie Blair's press secretary denied the Prime Minister's wife had taken a gift from the Hindujas. 'They got it wrong,' said Fiona Millar. 'They offered her an outfit. But she didn't want it and it went to charity.'

Moves to distance the government from the Hindujas follow an investigation into a controversial £211m arms contract between the Indian government and Swedish defence company Bofors in 1986. Last month, India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) filed a charge-sheet setting out their claims against the Hindujas and accusing them of taking part in a 'criminal conspiracy'.

The main allegation is that the three brothers - Gopichand, Srichand and Swiss-based Prakash - used their influence with the late Indian prime minister Rajiv Ghandi to secure a contract for how itzers with the Swedish firm and illegally took more than £7m in commission.

After a long battle with the Hindujas, the CBI finally got access to details of their Swiss bank accounts, which showed that Bofors paid more than £7m into secret accounts owned by McIntyre Corporation - a Hinduja front company based in Panama.

The Hindujas denied any wrongdoing, claiming they are the victims of a political vendetta. A spokesman said: 'The brothers have consistently co-operated in all respects with the authorities in both Switzerland and India and will continue to do so in the future.'
