webTitle: Outsourcing problem services is no solution

fields.headline: Outsourcing problem services is no solution
fields.standfirst: Tony Elliston argues that outsourcing failing services often amounts to nothing more than exporting the problem
fields.trailText: Tony Elliston argues that outsourcing failing services often amounts to nothing more than exporting the problem
fields.body:
Decisions about whether local authority services should be outsourced or managed in-house have always been influenced more by political dogma than business considerations.

In the old days of compulsory competitive tendering, outsourcing policy ran largely along party lines. The more rabid Conservative councils believed that everything that moved, and quite a bit that didn't, should be privatised, with the council meeting once a year to award contracts. Meanwhile, old-guard Labour authorities subscribed to the "do it all" principle that services should remain in-house regardless of cost or quality.

Best value was supposed to put an end to this municipal nonsense, by positing the heretical doctrine that decisions regarding externalisation should be based on achieving the best outcome for the customer. Whereas most councils are now anxious to embrace this philosophy, at least in public, there is little evidence that outsourcing decisions are any more soundly based now than they were five years ago.

This is largely because a new set of political considerations has emerged to cloud the landscape. The traditional role of local authorities as service providers is increasingly being challenged. At a macro level, this is reflected in the debates about the demise of local education authorities and about the creation of NHS super trusts that would take over responsibility for social services. At a tactical level, it is entrenched in the policy of requiring local authorities to outsource services that are deemed to be failing.

The most obvious example of this is education, where successive councils have been forced to hand over failing support services, or, in the most extreme cases, the local education authority function in its entirety to the private sector. Three years ago, there was no recognised market for providing services to local education authorities. The government has both actively nurtured the development of a burgeoning supply chain and used Ofsted inspections as a means of creating a constant, although often reluctant, demand for these services.

It is too early to say whether this new industry will improve educational standards. However, one of the main problems with the strategy is that it only applies to those authorities that are seen to be underperforming. Outsourcing is being used as a penalty for failure, whereas the survival of the in-house service is a reward for competence.

Privatisation has become a panacea. There is a flawed assumption that disposing of a service to the private sector will magically transform it. But this type of designer solution owes far more to desperation and abrogation than a strategic approach to outsourcing.

Local authorities have also been guilty of this approach themselves. There is an irresistible temptation to outsource services that represent a problem. However, in most cases, the problem is simply exported along with the service. The company that wins the contract inherits both the staff and the prevailing culture. A change of ownership does not automatically change the organisational culture, particularly where the problems are systemic. The service may need to be re-engineered, but it doesn't necessarily need a new engineer to do it. Privatisation enables a council to relieve itself of the responsibility of managing a failing service, but there is little evidence that local authorities are any more adept at the commissioning role.

The recent crop of high-profile disasters on contracts to adminster housing benefits tells its own tale. In every case, the service was inadequate at the time it was contracted out. Unrealistic expectations of service improvement and cost reduction failed to materialise and the much heralded private-sector medicine has simply thrown the patient into terminal decline. Outsourcing a problem is, all too often, a placebo rather than a cure.

webTitle: Let them drink vin de table

fields.headline: Let them drink vin de table
fields.standfirst: Having shot themselves in the foot, France's wine bureaucrats have a revolution on their hands
fields.trailText: Having shot themselves in the foot, France's wine bureaucrats have a revolution on their hands.
fields.body:
There are no half measures when the French shoot themselves in the foot. Not for our cross-Channel neighbours a flesh wound or the loss of a toe. No sir: when the French cock up, they really do it in spades. The latest example comes from Bordeaux, where the Institut National des Appellations d'Origine (the paperclip-fondling bureaucrats who police the country's wine industry) has fired its regulatory shotgun at three local wine producers. In the process, it may have changed the face of French wine forever.

The story doesn't sound terribly dramatic at first. Three châteaux - one in St Emilion and two in lowly Fronsac - have been ordered to sell part of their 2000 crop as vin de table rather than as superior appellation contrlée. Their 'crime' was having used under-vine plastic sheeting to protect their vineyards against rain. These bches are expensive to deploy, but in wet years such as 1999 can help to prevent rainwater seeping down to the vines' roots and thus swelling the size of the crop. Despite the fact that the châteaux used the plastic sheeting to improve the quality of its wines, INAO has declared that it was illegal.

If the three châteaux in question were inconsequential producers, all this would merit a paragraph in the local newspaper. But one of them is Chteau Valandraud, a star Right Bank property. Another of the châteaux, Fontenil, is owned by globe-trotting consultant Michel Rolland, arguably the most famous French winemaker on the planet. In other words, INAO is not dealing with lightweights here.

Neither Rolland nor Jean-Luc Thunevin of Chteau Valandraud has taken the decision lying down. Thunevin has called it a 'ludicrous piece of INAO bureaucracy', while Rolland has criticised the organisation's 'total stupidity'. Both have indicated that they will comply with the ruling, but sell their vin de table, which cannot bear a vintage for legal reasons, at a higher price than the appellation wines they have produced from neighbouring, unsheeted vineyards.

If all this sounds vaguely familiar, it's because Italy went through a similar process in the 80s and 90s. In Tuscany, meddling bureaucrats prevented local winemakers from producing wines including Cabernet Sauvignon or made entirely from Sangiovese. The result was the Super Tuscan movement, where producers opted out of the official DOC(G) regime and sold their vini da tavola at higher prices. It's taken 20 years and a monumental climbdown by the authorities to end the revolt.

Could something similar be about to happen in France? Could Rolland and Thunevin puncture INAO's smug façade? At a time when sales of French wine are in free fall (exports to the UK are down 10 per cent this year, to their lowest-ever point), many French producers are beginning to question the validity of a system which is rigid, unimaginative and tradition bound. If they are to compete with the New World, where wineries are at liberty to experiment and can plant pretty much what they like, where they like, then Gallic winemakers must be allowed to operate free of pointless rules.

INAO could argue that vins de pays exist for such a reason, to allow producers to make new-style wines outside the constraints of the appellation system. There's an element of truth in this, but no more than an element. France needs to change quickly and fundamentally if it is to retain the loyalty of customers who are fed up with the inconsistency and poor quality of many appellation wines. However inadvertently, INAO's obsession with plastic sheeting may have provided the spark for such change.

Best cellars

Four vin de pays wines which won't break the bank

1999 Domaine de Ciffre Viognier, Vin de Pays d'Oc (£6.99, selected branches of Safeway). There are cheaper Viogniers, but nothing comes close in terms of value for money. A perfect introduction to the grape's apricot and white peach characters, with the right amount of acidity.

1999 Domaine de Richard, Vin de Pays de l'Aude (£2.79, Majestic). I can't remember the last time I had a drinkable bottle of wine under £3. A juicy, unoaked red with medium-weight tannins and plenty of flavour.

The Co-op's Vin de Pays d'Oc Chardonnay, Foncalieu (£3.99; £2.99 from 8 December). Another great-value French vin de pays. This is a pure, melon-like Chardonnay with good lemony acidity and attractive fruit flavours. Hard to beat for under £3.

fields.bodyText: There are no half measures when the French shoot themselves in the foot. Not for our cross-Channel neighbours a flesh wound or the loss of a toe. No sir: when the French cock up, they really do it in spades. The latest example comes from Bordeaux, where the Institut National des Appellations d'Origine (the paperclip-fondling bureaucrats who police the country's wine industry) has fired its regulatory shotgun at three local wine producers. In the process, it may have changed the face of French wine forever. The story doesn't sound terribly dramatic at first. Three châteaux - one in St Emilion and two in lowly Fronsac - have been ordered to sell part of their 2000 crop as vin de table rather than as superior appellation contrlée. Their 'crime' was having used under-vine plastic sheeting to protect their vineyards against rain. These bches are expensive to deploy, but in wet years such as 1999 can help to prevent rainwater seeping down to the vines' roots and thus swelling the size of the crop. Despite the fact that the châteaux used the plastic sheeting to improve the quality of its wines, INAO has declared that it was illegal. If the three châteaux in question were inconsequential producers, all this would merit a paragraph in the local newspaper. But one of them is Chteau Valandraud, a star Right Bank property. Another of the châteaux, Fontenil, is owned by globe-trotting consultant Michel Rolland, arguably the most famous French winemaker on the planet. In other words, INAO is not dealing with lightweights here. Neither Rolland nor Jean-Luc Thunevin of Chteau Valandraud has taken the decision lying down. Thunevin has called it a 'ludicrous piece of INAO bureaucracy', while Rolland has criticised the organisation's 'total stupidity'. Both have indicated that they will comply with the ruling, but sell their vin de table, which cannot bear a vintage for legal reasons, at a higher price than the appellation wines they have produced from neighbouring, unsheeted vineyards. If all this sounds vaguely familiar, it's because Italy went through a similar process in the 80s and 90s. In Tuscany, meddling bureaucrats prevented local winemakers from producing wines including Cabernet Sauvignon or made entirely from Sangiovese. The result was the Super Tuscan movement, where producers opted out of the official DOC(G) regime and sold their vini da tavola at higher prices. It's taken 20 years and a monumental climbdown by the authorities to end the revolt. Could something similar be about to happen in France? Could Rolland and Thunevin puncture INAO's smug façade? At a time when sales of French wine are in free fall (exports to the UK are down 10 per cent this year, to their lowest-ever point), many French producers are beginning to question the validity of a system which is rigid, unimaginative and tradition bound. If they are to compete with the New World, where wineries are at liberty to experiment and can plant pretty much what they like, where they like, then Gallic winemakers must be allowed to operate free of pointless rules. INAO could argue that vins de pays exist for such a reason, to allow producers to make new-style wines outside the constraints of the appellation system. There's an element of truth in this, but no more than an element. France needs to change quickly and fundamentally if it is to retain the loyalty of customers who are fed up with the inconsistency and poor quality of many appellation wines. However inadvertently, INAO's obsession with plastic sheeting may have provided the spark for such change. webTitle: Nigel Slater: What's in season in autumn?

fields.headline: What's in season in autumn?
fields.standfirst: With summer's skimpy salad days well and truly over, it's time to open the late-autumn store cupboard
fields.trailText: With summer's skimpy salad days well and truly over, it's time to open the late-autumn store cupboard.
fields.body:
I have never enjoyed shopping for my supper more so than in the last few weeks. The air is crisp. The market stalls are groaning with fat roots, purple cabbage and wacky mushrooms. The new apples spurt with juice and the Conference pears are still hard enough to hurt your gums. There are pomegranates, quinces and fat figs. Partridge is there, too, with plump, wet scallops and diminutive beetroots complete with their bloodshot plume of leaves. And someone, somewhere, is roasting chestnuts.

Fish, be it mackerel, mussels, lobster or crab, is now at its autumn peak. The piscatorially minded are spoilt for choice, and there seems no reason to do anything more than fling your fillet on the grill and offer it up with wedges of fat lemon or bake it with a drizzle of oil and some salt. Last week I roasted tiny cubes of aubergine, salted to stop them soaking up too much oil, then laid my mackerels, whole and unboned, on the side. Olive oil, a pinch of ground cinnamon and a couple of sprigs of thyme went in there too: a robust Mediterranean-scented supper for a wet Wednesday night.

We must cook rather than graze if we are to survive the cold and the wet. Those allergic to cooking may need to bite the bullet and get the casserole down from its shelf if they are not to short-change the family dinner table. No supermarket dinner-in-a-dish will hit the spot now. Only onions, starch and meat juices can get through to our marrow when everyone comes home soaked through to the skin. Herbivores might like to try boiling onions in their jackets then lifting them into a roasting dish with butter, salt and black pepper, letting them bake sweetly till their flesh is as soft as silk.

Game figures high on any omnivore's autumn shopping list. How you cook your partridge, pheasant or mallard will depend on what else looks good when you get to the shops, but apples could figure in there somewhere. Try throwing some peeled and chopped Worcesters or Cox into the roasting pan, then crushing them to sweeten the pan juices. A potato masher will do nicely. A tart sauce made by simmering a couple of peeled Bramleys, Grenadiers or lesser-known George Caves with a very little water can be whisked to a smooth slop, and is for me a happier accompaniment than most for a roast wild duck. Both sauce and bird will take about half an hour.

Whether it flies or waddles, duck seems right for this pre-Christmas season. The inevitable march of the turkey will soon be upon us. The Chinese way with star anise or five-spice powder is warming enough. Some days I use oyster sauce with it instead. Those who cannot face roasting a whole bird - too much fug and grease, if you ask me - might like to have a go at a leg or two instead. I cook mine this way: slowly sauté the duck legs in a covered casserole with a little oil and salt, then cut the meat from the bone and set it aside. Shred half a red cabbage, then fry in the same pan but with a clove or two of crushed garlic and over a higher heat till its colours shine like pickled cabbage. Shake in a little oyster sauce, a little dark soy, then add the shredded duck.

Late autumn, with the air on the slide from cool to cold, was the time many families used to kill their pig. The offal, which could not be cured or dried or made into a fat-covered confit for keeping, would be the après-slaughter feast. The blood that was saved was made into black pudding. How convenient then that it should go so well with apples, the fruit of the moment. I fry finger-thick slices of Bury black pud, and thinner ones of apple, in butter, then drizzle them with an impromptu sauce made from the buttery juices left in the pan thickened with cream and a spoonful of mustard.

I took my fill of home-grown tomatoes and green beans this year and, now they are gone, I have taken to the season's kale, chard and cabbage more than ever. The high spot has been the January King cabbages that have been around for the last couple of weeks. These are true winter brassicas, their leaves crisp and frilly, their flavour as deep and earthy. Steamed, shaken dry and tossed with salted butter or hot bacon fat, it is as fine as any other veg. The trick is simply not just to slightly undercook it, but to serve those heavily veined green and mauve leaves as hot as you can get them.

We shouldn't ignore the chubby white roots of celeriac. The time-honoured treatment is to grate the woody lump and stir it into a mustard mayonnaise to make celeriac remoulade, but with a bit of tweaking you can eat it hot, too. I give it much the same treatment, just changing the mayonnaise for crème frache and adding a shake from the wine vinegar bottle. The mustard is what makes it, but don't go overboard - you don't want to cancel out this root's deep mineral flavour.

We are approaching the polenta season. You can, of course, eat this substantial golden maize paste at any time of the year, but we only really need it, like porridge, when the wet sets in. Good as it is with thick gravies, I like mine with a slice of blue cheese melted into it. Try a collapsing Gorgonzola, or for a milder taste, the stripy hybrid that includes layers of that and mascarpone.

With my weekly purchase of Comice pears edging their way toward perfection on my kitchen windowsill it seems right and fitting to get the most suitable cheese to go with them. With their cold flesh as soft and clear as a fruit sorbet, you could take a salty or nutty cheese - either will work. Nuggets of old, craggy Parmigiano Reggiano fit like a dream with a ripe pear, but so too do the milder English varieties such as the floral, buttery Mrs Kirkham's Lancashire. My cheese of the month has to be the Ticklemore I have been picking up from Neal's Yard's shop in the endangered Borough Market. Its crust the beige and white of a field mushroom, this is a nutty, firm-fleshed goat's cheese whose milk-and-green-hazelnut flavour seems more pronounced than I have ever known it.

The chestnuts that are cooked over coals in the street rarely live up to the promise of their nutty, charcoal aroma. At home, they are worth taking trouble with, by which I mean soaking them in boiling water, peeling and scrupulously de-fuzzing them. It takes an age, but the vacuum packed and tinned varieties all taste muddy to me and have none of the rich nuttiness of the fresh. (The delectable and hideously expensive marron glacé are a different matter altogether.) I roast my peeled nuts in a dry frying pan, letting them colour deeply before salting them gingerly and offering them warm, with pre-dinner drinks. The wonderful thing is that everyone thinks you have gone to so much trouble. The truth is that you have.

While I shall miss those autumn raspberries, the first zest of a peeled clementine - a teasing whiff of Christmas if ever there was one - will suffice for a while. Better still is the honey-and-rose scent of a bowl of quinces. The English ones, such as pear-shaped Meech's Prolific, are worth tracking down for poaching in muscat wine and vanilla. Quince-tree owners seem blessed with the generosity gene. Make friends with one before the frosts bring the deep golden fruits off their branches.

I would be failing my duty if I omitted to remind you of the Italia grapes in the shops now. They have the sweetness and flavour of Beaumes de Venise and should, I think, be served very cold, so they burst juicily in the mouth. I have taken to eating them after supper with the new walnuts, which if you catch them young, are pale and supple. Don't eat the grapes too soon. They are worth keeping until they reach an almost transparent golden-green, when their sweetness will be at its most noticeably honeyed.

The Turkish figs - plump, purple and tender as a bruise - make up for the autumn's lack of peaches and apricots. What they miss in flavour they make up for in sheer sensuality. Unless you are going to bake them, they must be wantonly ripe. Look for a bead or two of nectar around the base. A ripe autumn fig is gagging to be eaten.

fields.headline: Frozen assets
fields.standfirst: Coloured leaves, bright barks and shining berries help keep the faith through cold dark days
fields.trailText: Coloured leaves, bright barks and shining berries help keep the faith through cold dark days.
fields.body:
Three years ago I wrote a piece on viburnums. I got a long and angry letter from an older reader berating me for using an unacknowledged quote from Hillier's Guide to Trees and Shrubs . Quite right, too - although perhaps not quite the proof positive that, as he suggested, I was a charlatan unworthy of 'this once-great paper's pages'. But ever since then I have always tried to acknowledge descriptions that were not my own and also to limit myself to writing about what I know. And I know so little. And I have so many books. And I read so much. And - this is the real issue - my own garden here in Herefordshire is deliberately and inevitably very limited to what we like and to what will grow happily in our wet climate and heavy clay loam.

I have a problem with winter-flowering shrubs. I don't mean the early-spring-flowering ones such as the daphne, witch hazel, forsythia or winter-flowering jasmine. I like them as much as for their being harbingers of spring as for their flowers. Nor do I mean the latecomers, such as the few roses that will flower on to Christmas, especially when helped along by global warming. But this no-season's land between Bonfire Night and Christmas, or not-autumn and not-quite-winter, is a season of coloured leaves, coloured barks and berries. Leaves are valued mainly in their passing. If they stayed half-alive and half-dead for more than a few weeks, we would soon be tired of them. Likewise berries, which are so shinily un-flowerlike that they are another completely new instrument playing the old tune. And bark is perfect for winter. The more coloured stems we have in this garden the more I want. It suits the season.

Each of these things is lovely on its own and well orchestrated, and they can enrich a poverty-stricken time. But no plant, at this stripped-out time of year, provides flowers in scale, form or colour that warrants space in the garden. I can look them all up, know a fair bit about them and can collate all that knowledge for you, but it does not really convince me. There is something about a lone-flowering shrub on a wet winter's day that seems rather futile. However lovely the plant, it often fails to do enough. The lesson is not to ditch them but to think carefully about their positioning. They are not at their best in a border that is geared for summer display.

Nevertheless it would be less-than-optimistically human to abandon the precious few flowers that we do get in midwinter just because they don't quite work in the garden. I realise that for most people they have a powerful magic. The few times I have seen really effective use of winter shrubs, they have been tucked into a corner or in the lee of a wall or by a door or window. They need to be used as a vignette, not a statement, because there is too much sky and, with a few exceptions, the statement is lost in the wind, rain and muddy grey of a winter's afternoon. Keep it cosy.

The viburnums are the biggest and best-known group for this. I had dinner with a garden-designer friend the other day who told me that when he started out and was asked the name of a shrub that he did not know - and one of the surest rules of life is never trust anyone who can instantly name every plant in any garden - he would reply, 'Viburnum.' It worked every time. The reason for this is that it is such a large and diverse family, ranging from the most familiar of the lot, Viburnum x bodnantense 'Dawn' with its floret bubbles of tiny flowers on bare branches that can start appearing now and last right through to March, to the evergreen V tinus 'Laurestinus' or the spring- flowering Viburnum plicatum ' Mariesii' that looks like an exceptionally lovely hydrangea. Viburnum farreri has a good fragrance and is best outside against a warm wall that will trap its scent. The species flowers are white, tinged with pink, whereas V farreri 'Candidissimum' is pure white. V tinus has no scent but the distinction of black berries, while V x bodnantense 'Dawn' smells, according to my letter writer (telling me a little more than I wanted to know) like cat's pee. It doesn't.

I have been trying to think of ways to make these shrubs work, to improve them, and it cannot be done. The truth is that I think these are dull plants and belong to dull gardening. In the summer they are hopeless and in winter, for the most part, their flowers are a token, rather like the Christmas present that you do not want. You appreciate the thought but_ They stem from a lazy view of garden-as-chore, which breeds the notion that a 'good' plant is one that covers most space with least work. Think of all the gardens with a strip of token border around the edge and lax shrubs planted too close to the fence dotted without rhyme or reason along it. Either that or think of the approach to an M4 corridor corporate headquarters. Better to fill the body of the garden with shrubs as understorey to a few standard trees - which is what most of them want to do.

I do have a soft spot for wintersweet, Chimonanthus praecox. Like many winter-flowering shrubs, it isn't much of a looker, but the little primrose-yellow blooms are fabulously fragrant and make very good cut flowers. The scent stays much longer if kept in a cold room. It can be trained to make a climber on a sheltered, sunny wall and, in many ways, is best grown like this, with a clematis using it for support in the summer.

I like mahonias, although I wouldn't go so far as to plant one in my own garden - no place that feels right for them. I like the way the evergreen leaves and bright-yellow flowers combine a faintly exotic, jungly feel with daffodil freshness. An unlikely mix, but it does seem to work. Mahonia x media is perhaps the best known, with the clones 'Charity' and 'Lionel Fortescue' very available. All mahonias smell good, but M japonica is perhaps the most fragrant of all. The Asian mahonias like shaded sites and will tolerate a wetter soil than the American mahonias. They are particularly suitable for a thin soil over chalk.

Although I have been dismissive of these scant winter-flowering shrubs, I do grow a couple of varieties of winter-flowering honeysuckle, Lonicera fragrantissima and L purpursii and the evergreen version, L standishii. I somehow acquired them years ago and, tucked away almost entirely out of sight on a north-facing wall, they provide the best-scented of all winter flowers. It is rare for them to flower this early, but there are usually a few tentative tiny flowers by Christmas, and they hit their full stride by the middle of January.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

Did I say that we got through the floods unscathed? I spoke too soon. Between writing last week's words and these, the water has lapped at our door and laps yet. To try to provide drainage, we have dug a trench right down the length of the garden and laid a perforated land drain. It was dug fast, by eye, and curves subtly.

The floods rose again as this was being done and the trench promptly filled to the brim, without making any noticeable difference to the water levels in the garden. The trench was cut down a grass path, but the rain made the sides collapse overnight, so parts of Jewel garden borders had to be evacuated so this could be repaired. While the emergency digging went on, Poppy, our Jack Russell terrier, went on a manic vole-hunt, digging dozens of holes in the borders, spraying tulip bulbs at every pass and destroying the roots of scores of plants. Sort of funny, but also sort of the last straw.

Although the canal/trench is a thing of sinuous beauty, there is a huge amount of soil thrown up from it. This is now completely saturated. An utterly sodden 70m mound of mud. The demarcation lines between grass, flood and mud are indecipherable runes ploughed into the ground.

The truth is that if we knew then what we know now, we would have laid this garden out in a completely different way to accommodate the inevitable flooding. Over the past week, I have toyed with taking a JCB to the place and doing just this, but balk a little at that. If I inspect my motives honestly I have to confess that I feel I have not displayed what we have done enough. I want more TV crews, more public sharing in this place before I rip it apart. Vanity or altruism? Neither, really. Just a natural born show-off.

Despite the waters rising, we have continued the process of cutting four new 2m brick squares into the Jewel garden. This means digging up hard paths, potting up plants, removing topsoil and putting in scalpings and sand before laying the bricks. It is worth the trouble tenfold and has dramatically improved the garden. This garden has always been very long on places to delve and hoe and short on sites to sit and consider, which means that the large beds now revolve around these small seating areas and we can go out and drink our champagne in one of five spots according to the light and state of performance of the plants. Dressed, of course, in waterproofs and waders.

Your roots: Golden rules for prudent pruning

I know that people can get into a muddle about pruning shrubs - as though there was anything to be muddled about.

The first rule of all pruning is: when in doubt, don't. The second rule is always to cut back to something, be it a leaf, bud or branch. And the third is that winter pruning promotes vigorous spring regrowth . So resist the evidence of your eyes and cut the existing weak growth back hardest.

Notice if the flowers are produced on the current year's fresh growth or on the previous year's. If the former, it is best to prune in early spring - as in the case of buddlejia - and if the latter, the time to do it is immediately after flowering - as with ribes.

When you plant shrubs, prune any weak growth hard to encourage good strong shoots from the base of the plant next spring.

If you are growing a shrub for its leaves, as I do with a cut-leaf golden elder, cut it back hard each spring and the new leaves will be both bigger and better coloured than they would be if it had been left unpruned.
fields.bodyText: Three years ago I wrote a piece on viburnums. I got a long and angry letter from an older reader berating me for using an unacknowledged quote from Hillier's Guide to Trees and Shrubs . Quite right, too - although perhaps not quite the proof positive that, as he suggested, I was a charlatan unworthy of 'this once-great paper's pages'. But ever since then I have always tried to acknowledge descriptions that were not my own and also to limit myself to writing about what I know. And I know so little. And I have so many books. And I read so much. And - this is the real issue - my own garden here in Herefordshire is deliberately and inevitably very limited to what we like and to what will grow happily in our wet climate and heavy clay loam. I have a problem with winter-flowering shrubs. I don't mean the early-spring-flowering ones such as the daphne, witch hazel, forsythia or winter-flowering jasmine. I like them as much as for their being harbingers of spring as for their flowers. Nor do I mean the latecomers, such as the few roses that will flower on to Christmas, especially when helped along by global warming. But this no-season's land between Bonfire Night and Christmas, or not-autumn and not-quite-winter, is a season of coloured leaves, coloured barks and berries. Leaves are valued mainly in their passing. If they stayed half-alive and half-dead for more than a few weeks, we would soon be tired of them. Likewise berries, which are so shinily un-flowerlike that they are another completely new instrument playing the old tune. And bark is perfect for winter. The more coloured stems we have in this garden the more I want. It suits the season. Each of these things is lovely on its own and well orchestrated, and they can enrich a poverty-stricken time. But no plant, at this stripped-out time of year, provides flowers in scale, form or colour that warrants space in the garden. I can look them all up, know a fair bit about them and can collate all that knowledge for you, but it does not really convince me. There is something about a lone-flowering shrub on a wet winter's day that seems rather futile. However lovely the plant, it often fails to do enough. The lesson is not to ditch them but to think carefully about their positioning. They are not at their best in a border that is geared for summer display. Nevertheless it would be less-than-optimistically human to abandon the precious few flowers that we do get in midwinter just because they don't quite work in the garden. I realise that for most people they have a powerful magic. The few times I have seen really effective use of winter shrubs, they have been tucked into a corner or in the lee of a wall or by a door or window. They need to be used as a vignette, not a statement, because there is too much sky and, with a few exceptions, the statement is lost in the wind, rain and muddy grey of a winter's afternoon. Keep it cosy. The viburnums are the biggest and best-known group for this. I had dinner with a garden-designer friend the other day who told me that when he started out and was asked the name of a shrub that he did not know - and one of the surest rules of life is never trust anyone who can instantly name every plant in any garden - he would reply, 'Viburnum.' It worked every time. The reason for this is that it is such a large and diverse family, ranging from the most familiar of the lot, Viburnum x bodnantense 'Dawn' with its floret bubbles of tiny flowers on bare branches that can start appearing now and last right through to March, to the evergreen V tinus 'Laurestinus' or the spring- flowering Viburnum plicatum ' Mariesii' that looks like an exceptionally lovely hydrangea. Viburnum farreri has a good fragrance and is best outside against a warm wall that will trap its scent. The species flowers are white, tinged with pink, whereas V farreri 'Candidissimum' is pure white. V tinus has no scent but the distinction of black berries, while V x bodnantense 'Dawn' smells, according to my letter writer (telling me a little more than I wanted to know) like cat's pee. It doesn't. I have been trying to think of ways to make these shrubs work, to improve them, and it cannot be done. The truth is that I think these are dull plants and belong to dull gardening. In the summer they are hopeless and in winter, for the most part, their flowers are a token, rather like the Christmas present that you do not want. You appreciate the thought but_ They stem from a lazy view of garden-as-chore, which breeds the notion that a 'good' plant is one that covers most space with least work. Think of all the gardens with a strip of token border around the edge and lax shrubs planted too close to the fence dotted without rhyme or reason along it. Either that or think of the approach to an M4 corridor corporate headquarters. Better to fill the body of the garden with shrubs as understorey to a few standard trees - which is what most of them want to do. I do have a soft spot for wintersweet, Chimonanthus praecox. Like many winter-flowering shrubs, it isn't much of a looker, but the little primrose-yellow blooms are fabulously fragrant and make very good cut flowers. The scent stays much longer if kept in a cold room. It can be trained to make a climber on a sheltered, sunny wall and, in many ways, is best grown like this, with a clematis using it for support in the summer. I like mahonias, although I wouldn't go so far as to plant one in my own garden - no place that feels right for them. I like the way the evergreen leaves and bright-yellow flowers combine a faintly exotic, jungly feel with daffodil freshness. An unlikely mix, but it does seem to work. Mahonia x media is perhaps the best known, with the clones 'Charity' and 'Lionel Fortescue' very available. All mahonias smell good, but M japonica is perhaps the most fragrant of all. The Asian mahonias like shaded sites and will tolerate a wetter soil than the American mahonias. They are particularly suitable for a thin soil over chalk. Although I have been dismissive of these scant winter-flowering shrubs, I do grow a couple of varieties of winter-flowering honeysuckle, Lonicera fragrantissima and L purpursii and the evergreen version, L standishii. I somehow acquired them years ago and, tucked away almost entirely out of sight on a north-facing wall, they provide the best-scented of all winter flowers. It is rare for them to flower this early, but there are usually a few tentative tiny flowers by Christmas, and they hit their full stride by the middle of January. My roots: A week in Monty's garden Did I say that we got through the floods unscathed? I spoke too soon. Between writing last week's words and these, the water has lapped at our door and laps yet. To try to provide drainage, we have dug a trench right down the length of the garden and laid a perforated land drain. It was dug fast, by eye, and curves subtly. The floods rose again as this was being done and the trench promptly filled to the brim, without making any noticeable difference to the water levels in the garden. The trench was cut down a grass path, but the rain made the sides collapse overnight, so parts of Jewel garden borders had to be evacuated so this could be repaired. While the emergency digging went on, Poppy, our Jack Russell terrier, went on a manic vole-hunt, digging dozens of holes in the borders, spraying tulip bulbs at every pass and destroying the roots of scores of plants. Sort of funny, but also sort of the last straw. Although the canal/trench is a thing of sinuous beauty, there is a huge amount of soil thrown up from it. This is now completely saturated. An utterly sodden 70m mound of mud. The demarcation lines between grass, flood and mud are indecipherable runes ploughed into the ground. The truth is that if we knew then what we know now, we would have laid this garden out in a completely different way to accommodate the inevitable flooding. Over the past week, I have toyed with taking a JCB to the place and doing just this, but balk a little at that. If I inspect my motives honestly I have to confess that I feel I have not displayed what we have done enough. I want more TV crews, more public sharing in this place before I rip it apart. Vanity or altruism? Neither, really. Just a natural born show-off. Despite the waters rising, we have continued the process of cutting four new 2m brick squares into the Jewel garden. This means digging up hard paths, potting up plants, removing topsoil and putting in scalpings and sand before laying the bricks. It is worth the trouble tenfold and has dramatically improved the garden. This garden has always been very long on places to delve and hoe and short on sites to sit and consider, which means that the large beds now revolve around these small seating areas and we can go out and drink our champagne in one of five spots according to the light and state of performance of the plants. Dressed, of course, in waterproofs and waders. Your roots: Golden rules for prudent pruning I know that people can get into a muddle about pruning shrubs - as though there was anything to be muddled about. The first rule of all pruning is: when in doubt, don't. The second rule is always to cut back to something, be it a leaf, bud or branch. And the third is that winter pruning promotes vigorous spring regrowth . So resist the evidence of your eyes and cut the existing weak growth back hardest. Notice if the flowers are produced on the current year's fresh growth or on the previous year's. If the former, it is best to prune in early spring - as in the case of buddlejia - and if the latter, the time to do it is immediately after flowering - as with ribes. When you plant shrubs, prune any weak growth hard to encourage good strong shoots from the base of the plant next spring. If you are growing a shrub for its leaves, as I do with a cut-leaf golden elder, cut it back hard each spring and the new leaves will be both bigger and better coloured than they would be if it had been left unpruned.

webTitle: Why adland is still lad land

fields.headline: Why adland is still lad land
fields.standfirst: Yob culture is still excluding women from creative jobs, says  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Yob culture is still excluding women from creative jobs, says Jamie Doward
fields.body:
'Good ideas don't have genitals,' says Debbie Klein, head of planning at ad agency WCRS. Klein makes this surreal statement with a weary stoicism. It is clear that, despite her belief, this is not what the advertising industry thinks. Klein has just finished writing a report on women in advertising and has come up with some shocking findings.

Despite the industry's great lurch towards gender equality over the last 10 years - the number of women in the sector now equals the men - one corner of the advertising world is still resolutely running a closed shop when it comes to bridging the gender divide. The creative arm of the advertising industry may have a reputation for radical thinking and challenging orthodoxy but it doesn't seem to be too keen on thinking out of the box on gender issues. The picture that emerges seems to have come straight from a centre spread in Loaded .

Klein's report concluded that in the creative world of adland 'the stereotypical laddish atmosphere is still very much in existence'. Entering the creative world seems to make many women shudder.

'It's like walking into a pub. It's quite daunting,' says Amanda Walsh, chief executive of Walsh, Trott, Chick, Smith. Numerous quotes in the report culled from interviews all across adland reinforce this view. 'It's a bit like walking into the lion's den,' says one female creative. Another says: 'Women find the atmosphere childish, petulant and myopic and they don't want to put up with that.'

The suggestion is that the few women who do make it into the creative sector end up having to adopt a coping strategy. 'All successful women creatives have certain characteristics: they're powerful, feisty, hard as nails and can deal with men in a male way,' one creative director concluded.

The report's findings are all the more surprising because the macho culture that seemed to stereotype the entire industry a few years ago now seems to have virtually disappeared in its other parts. The proportion of women who are directors of ad agencies has increased steadily over the past 10 years, up from 16 per cent in 1990 to 22 per cent now.

In addition, the number of female account handlers has more than doubled - up from 27 per cent in 1986 to 54 per cent in 1999. More than half of those employed in planning and research are women. Women make up nearly half of all media teams. The statistics go on and on.

But the creative side earns nil points . Only 17 per cent of copywriters are women - that's down from 20 per cent 10 years ago. Similarly, only 14 per cent of art directors are women - the lowest level ever, according to the report. Only two women in the top 20 agencies have the title 'creative director'. These statistics are not repeated elsewhere in the world. The UK creative advertising sector appears to be a supreme offender.

'The report shows that in the last decade nothing has changed on the creative side of advertising,' Walsh says.

But in reality it should have done. It's not as if the number of women wanting to break into advertising is diminishing. The pool of female talent exists. Women are in the majority on fine arts, design, media studies and communication courses - the spawning grounds for many creatives. But this doesn't translate into what is happening in the creative world of advertising. It seems to have become that most horrible, damaging, unacceptable concept in adland: the cliché. Rightly or wrongly it has earnt itself an image made up of laddish stereotypes which means that women are intimidated when applying for jobs in the creative sector.

'When we're recruiting, over half the applicants are female. It means the creative directors, who are virtually universally male, must be giving out horrible vibes,' says Christine Walker, a partner at Walker Media.

The report states: 'The laddish, yobbish end of the male creative fraternity gives it a real image problem for would-be creatives - the same way that the media used to have an image problem as full of Essex barrow boys.' Many female creatives reported what one referred to as 'rampant, laddish, sexist behaviour'.

The bias against women may help partially explain why complaints about sexist advertising are on the increase. Last year the Advertising Standards Authority received 487 complaints related to sexist ads - a 12 per cent increase on 1997.

But, argue many of the senior women in the ad industry, of more significance is what would happen to the creative product if there was greater female input. 'It would bring different ways of looking at things. After all, more than 70 per cent of expenditure is made by women. The balance between people who write the ads and those whom they should be aimed at is completely out of whack,' Klein says. Some argue this means many ads end miss the mark.

'It's no coincidence that most of the famous advertising has been done for cars and beer. You won't find much for food and cosmetics. A lot of the great ads come about because people have a natural empathy with consumers. This is very difficult if you have a young male creative team which doesn't have much empathy. It's a heresy to say it because people within an agency get hugely insulted,' Walsh says.

But considering that by 2002 more than half the working (and therefore spending) population will be female, ad agencies might start to wake up to the need for more balance in its creative divisions. 'If anybody believes DIY ads are aimed at men, they are mad. You don't need female creatives to work just on tampon ads. You need them for things like financial services, the lot,' Walker says.

But the advertising industry has so far shown few signs that it believes this argument is a winner. Few women creatives think much will change in terms of the status quo, and the industry could end up missing out as a result.

After all, the advent of new technology means that there is a raft of creative industries that weren't here five years ago. 'We are a sexy business but we are no longer the only sexy business in town,' Klein says.

Could the time be ripe for a spot of rebranding?

webTitle: WH Smith opens second front in magazine turf war

fields.headline: WH Smith opens second front in magazine turf war
fields.trailText: THE vicious turf war that earlier this year threatened to rip the magazine industry apart is poised to flare up again, writes Jamie Doward .
fields.body:
THE vicious turf war that earlier this year threatened to rip the magazine industry apart is poised to flare up again, writes Jamie Doward .

In August, Tesco rocked the publishing world when it announced a controversial plan to take delivery of magazines from only one national distributor, WH Smith News.

The move prompted fears this would mean the end of the current regional distribution network for magazines and the closure of up to 12,000 newsagents.

Tesco subsequently backed down and WH Smith postponed plans to launch its own national magazine distribution system until next year, while it tried to agree a compromise with publishers.

However, The Observer has learned that WH Smith has quietly been approaching independent publishers with a view to signing them up. Getting them on board will be crucial if WH Smith is to force through its plan.

One publisher described the tactics as 'arrogant and showing a total disregard for all the hard work and negotiations of the last five years'.

webTitle: Mail in ultimatum over Express deposit demand

fields.headline: Mail in ultimatum over Express deposit demand
fields.trailText: The Daily Mail & General Trust has raised the stakes in the war to buy Express Newspapers by threatening to pull out of the bidding process if the seller, United News & Media, doesn't drop a key demand
fields.body:
The Daily Mail & General Trust has raised the stakes in the war to buy Express Newspapers by threatening to pull out of the bidding process if the seller, United News & Media, doesn't drop a key demand.

Earlier this month, the DMGT expressed concerns that United was demanding a multi-million pound non-refundable deposit from bidders. Last night sources close to the company indicated just how concerned they were about the clause.

'If they continue to ask for this deposit, it will become a major stumbling block,' a source familiar with the company's thinking said. 'There is no appetite to pay this. They will kill the best bid off if they absolutely insist on it.'

However United argues that the deposit is the price companies need to pay in return for seeing price-sensitive information.

But another source said: 'United is still trying to play by these bizarre rules. It threatens the sale. This is just not something any company that respected its shareholders would demand.'

The DMGT's threat to quit would be good news for the Hinduja Brothers, who have tabled a £120 million offer for Express Newspapers. So far Daily Telegraph owner Hollinger, which has also expressed an interest in buying the newspaper group, has failed to table a bid. Separate bids from the Channel-Islands- based Barclay Brothers and former Mirror Group boss David Montgomery have fallen by the wayside.

However, City sources said there were rumours that several other newspaper groups were also actively considering entering the fray.

This weekend there was speculation that this could mean Tony O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers making an eleventh-hour entrance.

'I think an outcome is get ting closer,' one informed source said. 'I think a deal will be announced by the end of this month, if not earlier.'

The sale of the Express group would be the latest in what promises to be a long line of disposals initiated by United chief executive Lord Hollick.

United has also quietly put a 'for sale' sign above its stake in Line One, the internet service provider it jointly owns with BT.

webTitle: DTI's Mirror inquiry casts net wider

fields.headline: DTI's Mirror inquiry casts net wider
fields.trailText: The Department of Trade and Industry has extended its inquiry into share dealings at the Mirror to cover alleged hacking into the newspaper's City share tips pages by certain of the newspaper group's staff
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry has extended its inquiry into share dealings at the Mirror to cover alleged hacking into the newspaper's City share tips pages by certain of the newspaper group's staff.

DTI inspectors are understood to be investigating dealings by scores of outsiders who bought shares plugged by the Mirror's disgraced Slickers tipsters before the articles appeared in print.

The tips, sources say, are believed to have been passed on to friends and associates by certain staff who hacked into Slickers' articles in the paper's editorial system.

'There are more than just journalists involved,' one source close to the inquiry said. 'Those who have access to a computer system may abuse that system.'

Mirror editor Piers Morgan was severely censured by the Press Complaints Commission in May for buying shares ahead of a tip in the paper. The Slickers, journalists Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, were fired over their controversial dealings and are claiming unfair dismissal.

The initial scandal surrounded Morgan's purchase in January of shares in Viglen, the renamed Amstrad computer-maker run by Tottenham Hotspur owner and Mirror columnist Sir Alan Sugar. There is no suggestion of any wrongdoing by Sugar. The DTI's extended inquiry, however, is understood to have examined share dealings by a leading light at another London football club.

Journalists and other staff at the Mirror have recently been formally interviewed by DTI inspectors in the inquiry, which is being conducted under the insider dealing provisions of Section 117 of the 1986 Financial Services Act.

Last week, Morgan came under further pressure following the disclosure of emails that showed he had told Bhoyrul about his purchase of the Viglen shares. This appeared to contradict Morgan's story as published by the PCC in May.

This weekend, however, the newspaper's owner, Trinity Mirror, denied that the PCC's published account formed part of its submission on Morgan's behalf to the press watchdog. The PCC also retracted the disputed words that 'he [Morgan] did not tell the City Slickers journalists of his Viglen purchase'.

'Trinity Mirror is correct,' PCC secretary Guy Black said. 'But our censure against Morgan was not based on the emails.'

Trinity Mirror's own investigation cleared Morgan of any wrongdoing. The emails leaked last week were recovered by the firm from its computer servers during its review and passed to the DTI.

'We have held a thorough investigation and nothing new has come to light,' a Trinity Mirror spokesman said this weekend, declining to comment on the latest twist to the DTI enquiry. The DTI also declined to comment.

webTitle: On the press: All the news that's fast - and cheap - to print

fields.headline: All the news that's fast - and cheap - to print
fields.standfirst:
Special report: US election
Audio: Ed Vulliamy in Florida
fields.trailText: On the press: Peter Preston
fields.body:
After the agony columns, the agonising columns and agonised columnists. American journalism, in its constant pursuit of public and self esteem, is swilling in introspection over the humiliation of an election got terribly wrong. When the TV channels run out of news, they switch - almost automatically - to more hacks exuding more gloom about their standing in society.

That is not, perhaps, the British way. We tend to grimace, shrug and move on, locked in the rush of daily production. Another opening, another show. But there's a hard issue behind the US angst that ought to give us all pause.

What went wrong with the exit polls, and thus with so many of TV's result calls on the night and so many newspaper headlines hailing premature triumph for George W Bush? That's been commodiously explained. One outfit, the Voter News Service, did all the exit polling. It supplied the basic information - some of it maybe a touch tentative - to its network clients (and at one remove to watching newspaper reporters). The networks, each with four or so assessors on the control room 'decision teams', made their own choice when to call a state for Bush or Gore. Effectively, though, they decided as a pack. When Fox declared Bush the winner at 2.16am on the Wednesday, the others swiftly nipped into line - at least for 46 minutes, before the second debacle of election night eclipsed even the first one, the premature handing of Florida to Gore.

Same data: competing teams of 'experts', each looking anxiously at the others. Relentless time pressure: a driving desire to be first with the call, even by 15 seconds. That sounds like a disaster waiting to happen - and so it proved.

Why was there only one Voter News Service, gathering the material in which every projection was based? Because 10 years ago the US networks dismantled their own rival teams of exit pollsters and, in the name of economy, formed VNS. Competiti10on became not the gathering and purveying of separate information, but the interpretation of common information. As such, it is all of a part with trends in newsrooms everywhere, including perhaps a newsroom near you.

Chat to the Washington correspondents of newspapers from all over the States, and they soon start using the same jargon - the jargon of cost-efficiency and 'synergy'. What does synergy mean? Here's the editor of the Chicago Tribune talking to a writer for the American Journalism Review about his role. 'I am not the editor of a newspaper. I am the manager of a content company. That's what I do ... we gather content.'

So they do. The Tribune newsroom in Chicago has a directly abutting TV and radio service which simultaneously services WGN-TV and WGN-Radio and CLTV, the 24-hour cable news channel, plus digital subscribers and website readers. This (modelled on its original Washington operation) is total integration - one story serves all.

More, one pundit serves all. The writing reporter is also the radio reporter and the guy on TV pontificating and - now - joining in the post-mortem on what went wrong. Here is synergy and, just as important, the propagation of the company's brand (for branding, too, is a buzz word in this particular world).

Plaudits for Chicago? Certainly the Tribune was ahead of the synergetic game, but the other big multi-media groups have caught up fast - and it is instructive to try to draw a diagram of what that meant on election night: a single VNS pipeline of anything potentially significant flowing on to the same desk and then being turned into something new on paper, on the net, on TV, radio, on digital. That is a chorus of voices seeming, independently, to sing the same tune - and hide the solitary, shared hymn sheet. It lures readers and listeners into the trap of believing what everybody says must be true, because everybody's saying it.

And there are wider dimensions. One, a result of expanding newspaper chains with stock market quotations on their minds and contracting staffing levels, is the shrinkage in reporting numbers so that there are fewer people on the ground available for digging and research. Another is the mounting of multi-media demands on those reporters who remain, too busy recycling the same tale over and over again to work on the next story. Yet another, already quite visible, is the sacking or retiring of more experienced journalists whose faces don't look fresh enough on screen: a wisdom loss as well as a numerical loss.

Trends in a far-away country of which we know little? Not entirely. Britain's regional chains of papers have been following the cost-cutting road for decades, some to a precise US model. Most national newspapers here are already grappling with the problems of running net and print coverage side by side. The essence of John Birt's BBC multi-skilling revolution was using the same correspondents across different media and, although the Dyke counter-revolution is rolling some of that back, it is also rolling forward on the supposed synergies of 24-hour cable coverage and spin-off shows like the revamped TV breakfast news.

In this sense, America's inquest matters. It asks where news comes from, how many reporters and researchers are needed, what time they must have and what investments are necessary to nurture alternative sources of information. Are newspapers, in short, just businesses like any other, ruled by the disciplines of Wall Street and the FT ? An interesting question - with not an exit poll in sight.

webTitle: TV mogul to join Labour election team

fields.headline: TV mogul to join Labour election team
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The millionaire TV mogul Lord Alli is to be drafted in to work on Labour's election campaign.
fields.body:
The millionaire TV mogul Lord Alli is to be drafted in to work on Labour's election campaign.

After a boardroom shake-up edged him out of his job as managing director at Carlton TV this week, the New Labour peer is now expected to take his corporate skills to the party's Millbank headquarters.

The party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, who has come under fire for the London electoral fiasco and for low morale among staff, is a close friend of Alli and the two speak on the phone most days. She is understood to be anxious to bring him on board, probably in a consultant role.

The charming and well-connected Alli - guests at his country mansion near Kent have included Peter Mandelson and Mo Mowlam - was a donor to the Labour party at the last election after making his fortune from the TV company Planet 24 he founded with his partner, Charlie Parsons. Alli has been tipped as a future junior Minister.

The move to bring Alli to the heart of Labour's operations comes as planning for the general election shifts up a gear, with three by-elections due next week in a 'Super Thursday' that is Labour's last big chance to feel the pulse of the nation before the next election.

'Gordon's great fear is that we will not get the credit for a sound economy,' said one senior Minister. One likely strategy will be to compare where Britain is now with how it would have been had Labour never got into power, for instance with fewer hospitals or more young unemployed.

The party is braced for a poor turnout on Thursday at the Labour-held seats of Preston, vacant because of the death of MP Audrey Wise; in Glasgow Anniesland, vacant because of the death of Donald Dewar; and in West Bromwich West, Betty Boothroyd's constituency.

Although Labour should hold all three seats, majorities are likely to be badly shrunk. In West Bromwich West, the threat to jobs at Longbridge and residual resentment among pensioners despite their budget increases may cut the vote for Labour's Adrian Bailey.

In Preston, where the party controversially passed over Wise's daughter Valerie in favour of the Blairite former MEP Mark Hendrick as their candidate, the Lib Dems are hoovering up disaffected voters. In Glasgow, both Dewar's Westminster and Scottish parliament seats are up for grabs, with Labour fielding Dewar's former election agent John Robertson and local councillor Bill Butler for the respective seats. The threat here is from the SNP but it would need a massive swing to take the seat.

webTitle: Comment: Paul Boateng: our bombastic jailer

fields.headline: Our bombastic jailer
fields.standfirst:
The state of our jails and low morale among prison officers reflect the malign influence of Paul Boateng

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The state of our jails and low morale among prison officers reflect the malign influence of Paul Boateng.
fields.body:
If the colonel-in chief of the Coldstream Guards was obliged to remind his men not to shoot women and children in the back, or if Ruth Rogers had to tell her River Cafe chefs that cannibalism was a food fad too far (even for west London), you might conclude that both regiment and restaurant were staggering on the edge of barbarism.

Martin Narey is director general of a more significant institution - the Prison Service. Last week, Narey felt compelled to explain to staff controlling a disproportionately large number of black inmates that they could not actually be Nazis and expect to enjoy a career in the Home Office. Membership of the British National Party would result in dismissal, he said. 'We have to own up that racism is a big problem for the prison service. This is one of a raft of measures needed to get it right.'

A raft will be too small a vessel. Recent years have seen Alton Manning unlawfully killed in Blakenhurst jail and the Prison Service trying to stop an inquest's investigation into his murder or manslaughter. Meanwhile, a culture of 'sustained and promoted overtly racist behaviour' was revealed in Brixton prison. And, at the atrocious Feltham Young Offenders Institution, Zahid Mubarek was banged up with and murdered by Robert Stewart, a deranged bigot who had sent hundreds of letters from prison praising the killers of Stephen Lawrence and predicting the death of his luckless cell mate.

There is a quick explanation for the violence - prison officers are attacked everywhere as white, working-class dinosaurs who frustrate the good intentions of their superiors...Yet what is striking about the toleration of the murders - and the suicides and the beatings - in the Prison Service is that the rot starts, and often stops, at the top; it breeds among well-bred politicians and senior civil servants who would be appalled if they were suspected of any bigotry in their private lives.

The failed attempt to stop an inquest jury returning a true verdict of unlawful killing after it had heard how Alton Manning was dragged through a private jail by a posse of guards was planned at the highest levels of the Home Office. Mubarek's death was the result of the insouciance of its mandarins. In 1996, they gave themselves the easy target of providing racial and sexual awareness training to all employees by 2000. Result: 19 per cent of managers and 9 per cent of staff have been educated to date. In 1998, the service promised that inmates would not be forced to share a cell unless a rigorous risk-assessment had been completed. (Its incentive was the murder of Christopher Edwards. He was incarcerated with a psychopath who jumped on his face until his skull was so crushed dental records were needed to identify him.) Again, urgency descended into indolence. Paul Boateng, the Prisons Minister, admitted to the Commons this year that risk-assessments had yet to come to Feltham for all the bold commitments. If Whitehall had required officers to understand racism or judge dangers to inmates then Mubarek would not have been confined with Stewart, a man who sang the praises of the Ku Klux Klan.

Boateng is the most senior black politician in British history and might be expected to care about such matters. But just as the first Labour Ministers in 1924 displayed a laughable deference to the monarchy and the first woman Prime Minister was, well, Margaret Thatcher, so the highest-flying black Minister is something of a disappointment all round.

His career has followed a tired trajectory. He was an ultra-leftist on the Greater London Council in the Seventies who mellowed into a mainstream Kinnockite when the fashion changed. He is now a Third Way hard man, applauded by the Daily Mail for his harshness towards convicts, derision of social workers and love of the sacred vows of marriage.

The dilemma such friends bring is made manifest by the deaths in his slum prisons. You cannot keep the patronage of Lord Rothermere and run a civilised justice system. It is simply impossible and only a fool would try.

There are many reports that the strain is taking his toll. 'I must have known 35 to 40 Ministers in my time,' one union leader told me, 'and they would all be polite, whatever they thought of you - even Michael Howard. Boateng just yells.' The Prison Governors Association alleges that when it told him sickness levels among senior staff were at record levels as jails tried to cope with an ever-increasing population, Boateng replied: 'If they can't hack it, let's get rid of them.' When Boateng visited Brixton, a woman officer who was white but, along with the majority of staff, was not a racist, complained of years of underinvestment. Boateng bellowed in reply: 'That's exactly what I would expect from someone like you to say. It's people like you who are part of the problem.' She burst into tears. Her union has since complained about Boateng's boorishness.

'Whenever he runs into a problem his only answer is to threaten privatisation,' said Harry Fletcher, of the probation workers' union, Napo.

The bombastic style was displayed last week when Boateng had to deal with the Commons Home Affairs Committee report on the disastrous raid on Blantyre House. As this notebook has reported, the prison had the highest success rate for reforming criminals of all jails in the country. It had a liberal regime which prepared inmates for a straight life outside by allowing them to take jobs with charities and Kent employers. Inevitably, its triumphs produced many enemies in the zero-tolerance Home Office. The prison was trashed and governor forced out as 80 officers in full riot gear stormed in.

The committee of MPs from all parties vigorously condemned the wreckers. Narey had 'misled' them when he justified the assault by saying 'a quite frightening amount of contraband had been found'. In fact, the 'contraband' was the prisoners' legally held wages, bank cards and tools for charity work. All the prisoners were tested for drugs. Not one sample was positive.

Boateng, who had also told MPs about stashes of imaginary contraband, could have admitted his error and promised to reform his department. Instead, as Clare Checksfield from the Prison Service Secretariat revealed, the Home Office decided to bluff it out. A memo to him, passed to me by a helpful mole, suggests he should 'stand by the operational decision' to destroy the governor's career and wreck the jail and say there were no 'grounds for disciplinary action against Prison Service managers'. He did as he was told as he blustered his way round the TV studios on Thursday.

There is a price to be paid for his machismo. You may not care greatly about feeble prisoners who are bullied or murdered. But anyone who is genuinely tough on crime, rather than a poseur, should worry that Boateng would rather save his face than save the Blantyre Houses which do what he can never do: protect the public.

 This week Fraser Kemp, a loyal and sweet-tempered Blairite MP, will propose a modest reform. He will ask Parliament to abolish the British Empire gongs which pepper the biannual honours list.

Kemp has two arguments. First, it is no great honour to be acclaimed by an empire which does not exist and, second, he is fed up with his working-class constituents being patronised with the lesser prizes - Member of the British Empire - while the Commanders are always the aristocrats of the bureaucracy. You may believe that this is mere gesture politics, but symbolism matters. Australia displayed an energetic egalitarianism when it renounced MBEs, OBEs and CBEs for the one-size-fits-all Order of Australia.

I think I can predict with certainty that his proposal to create an Order of the United Kingdom will be flattened. It is a familiar complaint that the great, modernising Blair Government which promised to democratise the land lost its radicalism with the first whiff of power. Freedom of information has become a bleak joke, the House of Lords remains unelected, local democracy in England is dying... I'm sure you know the litany by now.

So comfortable with the status quo has the inner-circle become that many MPs wonder how on earth the Government will fill its days if it wins the next election.

Such cynicism is appaling. New Labour has not stood still. It has dropped the task of turning Britain into a democracy for the far more radical undertaking of transforming the country into a corporation. As I noted a few weeks back, the 2,000 punters who have asked to be 'independent' legislators in the Lords will have their applications vetted by a panel chosen by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The Government's faith in the accountancy firm too muddled to spell its own name has gone further. Its Executive Resourcing Department has now been asked to find a chairperson and board members for the Committee on Standards in Public Life. The watchdog that guards against conflicts of interest between political parties and public bodies on one hand and commercial interests on the other will be picked by big business's management consultants.

If America is a country that was once a democracy and is now run by lawyers, we are a country that was never a democracy and is now run by accountants.

webTitle: Labour gets into bed with private medicine

fields.headline: Labour gets into bed with private medicine
fields.standfirst: Soon NHS patients will have their hernia operations 'outsourced'.  Nick Mathiason asks whether this adds up
fields.trailText: Soon NHS patients will have their hernia operations 'outsourced'. Nick Mathiason asks whether this adds up
fields.body:
Two weeks ago a Labour government signed the 'unthinkable'. Smashing 50 years of ideological hostility towards private medicine, Health Minister Alan Milburn agreed a historic 'concordat' with Britain's private health industry.

Milburn reportedly acted on Prime Minister Tony Blair's direct order to cross this Rubicon in a bid to avoid a repetition of last winter's emergency bed crisis sparked by a flu epidemic. Front page news stories featuring sick patients lying on trolleys in corridors seemed to prove the NHS was on the critical list. And this under a Government 'trusted' to run it.

But the five-page concordat goes far deeper than averting a short-term public relations disaster by asking private hospitals to admit winter snivellers. The World Trade Organisation is lobbying for national governments to allow the private sector greater involvement in health provision and financing through what is known as Gats - General Agreement on Trade in Services.

'With profits in manufacturing falling, the corporate lobby is targeting the proportion of gross domestic product that governments spend on public services,' said University College of London health finance expert, Professor Allyson Pollock. 'In health and education alone, government spending is in excess of 15 per cent of GDP in many European countries, but much of that goes on voluntary and public sector provision.'

Britain is at the European cutting edge of this liberalisation. Last Monday Milburn confirmed this by inviting consortia to bid for 18 controversial new Private Finance Initiative hospitals worth £18 billion. PFI is a financing mechanism which allows private companies to build hospitals and rent them back to the NHS at considerable profit. The advantage for the Treasury is that infrastructure projects are kept off balance sheet.

Most health industry insiders acknowledge that PFI is an expensive way of building new hospitals which means less money is left to spend on patient care. But Milburn said he wants to see PFI extended 'beyond the hospital gates to include GP surgeries, community pharmacies, health centres, intermediate and long-term care facilities'.

However, the significance of the concordat is chiefly in its effect on the direct provision of health care which has so far largely escaped the private sector. The Independent Healthcare Association (IHA) says the amount of elective surgery (operations the patient can survive without) it takes on for the NHS is worth £35 million - less than 5 per cent of the sector's overall revenue, or the equivalent of six hours of the NHS's £40bn annual budget.

Currently the biggest players in private healthcare are Bupa, the provident association; BMI, owned by General Healthcare; Nuffield Hospitals, a charity; Community Hospitals Group, which is the subject of a takeover bid by Bupa; and US-owned HCA. Combined, they turn over £2bn from acute health provision. The majority of this comes from private medical insurance, with 22 per cent self-paid or from overseas patients.

These days private hospitals can treat a wide range of ailments but are known particularly for the five Hs: hips, hernias, hysterectomies, hearts and haemorrhoids. Barry Hassell, IHA's chief executive who helped frame the concordat, believes the UK's 300 private hospitals could undertake 150,000 operations for the NHS each year. This would triple private hospitals' income. Hassell says current meetings of the NHS and private healthcare providers could lead to the building of new private facilities.

But it won't be easy to make this outsourcing work. 'There's still some hostility to contracting out client services but it may well be that the Government will push the NHS and local authorities towards agreeing contracts with the independent sector,' said leading healthcare analyst William Fitzhugh.

It will be in the intermediate sector - or rehabilitation - where the private sector will gain most. Westminster Healthcare, run by Chai Patel - an influential government adviser - will within days be the first group since the concordat to reach agreement with the NHS to take on this work. Patel said the deals involve no more than 15 beds but it is the shape of things to come. 'The private sector can offer long-term care more efficiently, at lower cost and more competently.'

But Steven Weeks of health workers' union Unison disagrees. 'All the evidence suggests that private sector involvement will push up the cost of long-term care. This is the main area where the private sector operates. Staff get worse wages and conditions. Some people in government will say that's not a problem.'

Healthcare isn't always a licence to print money for the private sector. In the area of long-term care Nursing Homes Properties, which built hundreds of nursing homes in seven years, is on the verge of financial meltdown having lost £7.1m in the six months to March, because a number of its tenants went to the wall. They got burnt when local authorities scaled down their fees.

But this hasn't diminished the private sector's appetite for medicine. And so critics fear the concordat will lead to more contracted out services, charging for health care and eventually mean that what the Government - and therefore all taxpayers - can achieve with its health budget will diminish because private providers, which have to make profits, will be dearer.

Hassell disagrees: 'What's important is that contracting authorities get value for money,' he said. 'But it's an assumption to say the private sector will be more expensive. The Department of Health won't reveal cost information so nobody knows the true picture.' Perhaps a little forensic analysis should be undertaken before we proceed with this operation.
