fields.headline: Lottery ticket sales boost Camelot
fields.trailText: Camelot's attempts to run the lottery for a second term will receive a boost this Wednesday when the operator unveils a healthy set of figures showing ticket sales are on the up
fields.body:
Camelot's attempts to run the lottery for a second term will receive a boost this Wednesday when the operator unveils a healthy set of figures showing ticket sales are on the up.

National Lottery ticket sales over the last six months are expected to show a 4 per cent rise to more than £2.34 billion compared with the same period last year. There had been concerns that sales, which fell in 1999, would continue to slide.

The rise in sales means there will also be around a 4 per cent increase in the amount of money going to good causes - to more than £650 million over the last six months. However, it is believed that sales of scratchcards, which have dropped dramatically since they were first introduced, will continue to be a cause for concern.

In a bid to boost interest in scratchcards, Camelot is to introduce a new range early next year. One scratchcard game will give players the chance to win £1m. Another scratchcard game will offer punters the chance to win luxury cars.

Camelot is also trying to introduce a new sort of pan-European draw which it claims will create £1bn for good causes.

However, the operator's watchdog, the National Lottery Commission (NLC) branded the plan 'unworkable' in August. Camelot says the plan, in addition to gaining support in France and Spain, has also attracted interest from Australia and the US, something which could pave the way for a global game.

The NLC is currently studying Camelot's bid to run the lottery. Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery consortium was originally the favourite to win the new licence, which runs from September 2001, after the Camelot bid was thrown out earlier this year over concerns about the operator's link with controversial US gaming giant GTech.

But Camelot has pledged to sever its links with GTech, which supplied the technology behind its network of terminals. The operator says it will use its own team to run the network.

Following an appeal, the Commission is considering both bids and will announce the winner next month. Lord Burns, who heads the Commission, is due to give evidence about the selection process to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

webTitle: Simon Inglis - Lock's stock over a barrel: why Chris Smith should think again

fields.headline: Lock's stock over a barrel
fields.standfirst:
Stadium expert Simon Inglis says Culture Secretary Chris Smith should think again over Wembley
Wembley crisis - Observer special
fields.trailText: Stadium expert Simon Inglis says Culture Secretary Chris Smith should think again over Wembley.
fields.body:
Almost uniquely international circles, the British are not much given to naming sporting arenas after public figures, not even royalty. There may be roads named after Sir Matt and Sir Stan but on the whole we tend to shy away from the aggrandisement of individuals that is so common overseas.

Even so, I have no hesitation in suggesting that if the national athletics stadium at Picketts Lock in north-east London is eventually built, it should be named after the man most responsible for calling it into being, the Culture Secretary, Chris Smith.

Mr Smith, it may be recalled, started the whole process last December when a sudden 'gut feeling' led him to reject the new Wembley as a venue for athletics, and in particular for the 2005 World Championships. Having turned then, the gentleman has not been for turning since. He dismissed outright a Select Committee for Culture, Media and Sport, which concluded in March that the 'platform' solution being proposed by Wembley for a temporary athletics track was 'a commendable and innovative solution.' Nor was he swayed when a report critical of Wembley's plans, commissioned by UK Sport, turned out to have been based on incorrect and incomplete information.

Thus, after a hurried search of potential sites in London, it was announced that an alternative site for 2005 and a possible Olympic bid for 2012 had been found at Picketts Lock, and that Sport England would allocate £60 million of lottery funds towards the project - £20m of it culled from Wembley's £120m grant - should further consultations prove it to be viable.

To most stadia experts, many of whom were genuinely excited and intrigued by Wembley's platform proposal, this seemed odd - pick a site, then see if it will work, then determine what facilities and events might go there. Still, having approached the Millennium Dome in a similarly unconventional manner, presumably the Government knew what it was doing.

To be absolutely sure, nevertheless, Sport England has just provided a further £1.3m to complete a detailed feasibility study at Picketts Lock. If the final conclusion, due next March, proves positive then, assuming another £35m (or more, most likely) can be found to match the £60m Lottery offer, work will start on the proposed stadium in March 2002. Seating 43,000 for the 2005 World Championships, the stadium would then be cut down in size to hold 20,000 thereafter; ideal for annual Grand Prix events and, the stadium's backers hope, for use by an as yet unnamed rugby union club. Saracens fans, are you reading this?

But what if the case for Picketts Lock - call it Plan B - does not stand up to scrutiny? Having rejected Plan A (Wembley), is there a Plan C?

The trouble with even raising this issue is that to question the development of Picketts Lock is to be deemed to be anti-athletics, while to suggest the return of athletics to Wembley is to risk being allied to the football lobby.

Although London and the South-East may be crying out for the type of training facilities currently being proposed for Picketts Lock (including indoor 200 metre and 60m tracks, a high-performance centre and a National Institute for Sports Medicine), for the stadium itself to be viable, or even justifiable, it is likely that several athletics events would have to be transferred from provincial venues. UK Athletics insists it will retain sufficient events outside London, and that the existence of Picketts Lock will enable it to bid for other events or even create new ones. But in an increasingly competitive venue marketplace, it is hard to see how the addition of another medium-size stadium in London will help.

More crucially, it is now widely recognised that Picketts Lock could not accommodate an Olympic Games. The former Sports Minister Tony Banks recently described its credentials as 'a joke'. But most experts I have talked to recognised this almost as soon as Picketts Lock was proposed.

So, does the British Olympic Association and the Government admit that London can no longer bid for the games - no bad thing in many people's books - or does it try to find another site?

If one could be found, that would mean the government spreading its largesse among three separate sites in the capital; Wembley (£100m if athletics remains elsewhere), Picketts Lock (£60m at least), and a new Olympic venue, which would cost a minimum of £300m. And afterwards the stadium - a certain white elephant - would consume cash for maintenance. Again, does this add up to a sensible, cost-effective strategy, for sport, for London and, not least, for voters outside London?

Equally, if indeed a suitable site for the Olympics does exist - Stratford in east London being one of the favourites - why isn't the new athletics stadium being built there in the first place?

Behind all these unresolved issues lie two uncomfortable truths. The first is that London has to come up with a venue for the 2005 World Championships. If it fails, Berlin lies waiting in the wings. Having already lost the 2006 World Cup to Germany, national pride patently demands that Picketts Lock be made to work, regardless of whether it is right.

The second is that nowhere in the world is athletics, as a sport, able to sustain and operate its own stadiums without considerable public subsidy. Athletics fans cannot even draw comfort from the success of the Sydney Olympics. On 23 November, the track graced by Cathy Freeman and others this summer will be dug up and moved to another part of the Homebush site. Stadium Australia will become an 80,000-capacity stadium for the various football codes. For all its athletes' accomplishments, by next year Australia will not have a single athletics stadium holding more than 25,000 spectators.

Gone too are the tracks at Atlanta (1996 Olympics) and Los Angeles (1932 and 1984). Has this jeopardised America's prowess as an athletics super power? Of course not.

In short, what Britain's athletes need is more funding and superior training facilities, not more stadiums. This is why I urge the Government to resurrect one option for London that would save a great deal of public money - if not the blushes of Chris Smith - guarantee the 2005 World Championships and, at the same time, retain a London bid for the Olympics.

The new Wembley is due to open its gates in mid 2004. If a temporary platform for athletics were to be in place for the opening (at a cost of about £10m), according to the architects this would allow the 2004 and 2005 Cup Finals, and the 2005 championships, to take place before 80,000 spectators, offering excellent sightlines for athletics and football. Afterwards, the platform would be removed with the stadium configured to its 90,000 full capacity. Wembley would retain the £20m it is now trying to return to Sport England (as the price of not having to stage athletics), and, more importantly, would be able to affirm its status as a serious contender for a future Olympics.

But that is only half of the problem solved.

If Wembley is to accommodate the World Championships or an Olympics, it would have to offer a warm-up track. Finding the land for such a track presents obstacles but there is some ideally-placed land to the east of the current stadium, occupied by a run-down business centre.It could cost anything up to £20m to buy under a series of compulsory purchase orders.

Yet the advantages would be significant. For a further £20-£25m the warm-up track could be developed to accommodate up to 20,000 spectators, meaning a total bill of around £45m. This venue could then fulfil the role intended for the Picketts Lock stadium while its running costs could be met in full by Wembley National Stadium Limited. WNSL is already committed to paying one per cent of its annual turnover to a trust for community and recreational purposes. According to WNSL, this should provide between £1.5-£2m per year, more than enough to cover the costs of the adjacent stadium, whose operation and maintenance would, in any case, be carried out by the same team responsible for Wembley.

Good government is not only about leadership and resolve. It is about knowing when to listen, and when to pull out of an impending mess. Now is that time for Chris Smith.

 Simon Inglis is the author of Sightlines - A Stadium Odyssey, published by Yellow Jersey Press.

fields.headline: One currency, two faces
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Just before eight o'clock last Wednesday night, a smiling Peter Mandelson glided into the members' lobby of the House of Commons.  He paused beneath the brooding statue of Churchill, whose foot is worn to a shine where superstitious MPs touch it for luck, for a brief chat with defence secretary Geoff Hoon, before slipping off with his duty done: voting against that night's Commons revolt on air traffic privatisation.
fields.body:
'I do not think there is any point expending campaign capital on the issue of the single currency before the issue is ready to be put'

Press statement, Thursday

'Pro-Europeans are making a mistake if they fail to appreciate the need for political and constitutional arguments.'

Address to businessmen, Wednesday

Just before eight o'clock last Wednesday night, a smiling Peter Mandelson glided into the members' lobby of the House of Commons.

He paused beneath the brooding statue of Churchill, whose foot is worn to a shine where superstitious MPs touch it for luck, for a brief chat with defence secretary Geoff Hoon, before slipping off with his duty done: voting against that night's Commons revolt on air traffic privatisation.

What the MPs milling around him did not know, however, was that he was about to set off a revolt of his own.

For the presses were already rolling on a front page story in the Financial Times, which would reopen Labour's rifts over the single currency once more, wrongfoot some of Mandelson's allies and crown a week in which all of Downing Street's best-laid plans for Europe went ingloriously astray.

Mandelson had, at a supposedly private business dinner, said it was wrong to ignore the political as well as economic case for euro membership, exploding three years of Gordon Brown's polite fiction that the decision was purely about protecting jobs or investment.

This is a message with which Robin Cook, Steve Byers and Tony Blair might agree in private - but not, at least until after the election, in public. Unfortunately, Mandelson's thoughts had found their way into the FT's first editions - plus a Guardian column - even before he stood up and uttered them. Someone was determined to ensure the message got out.

The impact was instant. Brownites spat that their old foe 'lacked the intellectual capacity' even to talk about the euro; fellow diners complained angrily that they felt used; and the stage was set for another damaging Cabinet convulsion.

Or was it? As so often where Mandelson is involved, the truth was not that simple.

As he finished voting at Westminster that night, a few minutes across central London just over a dozen wealthy and well-connected businessmen were gathering around the long, polished boardroom table of a well-known international company's headquarters.

Unilever chief Niall Fitzgerald was the host and his guests were expecting a sumptuous dinner with the Northern Ireland Secretary and reassurance that the Government had not given up on the euro. Most were potential donors to a future referendum campaign, and so they had been assured of total secrecy.

Others, however, believe Mandelson was simply fine-tuning his own position after taking a harder line recently in an attempt to mend fences with Brown.

'Peter was trying to row back from his remarks a few weeks ago that the referendum wouldn't be for years,' said one long-standing ally.

'It is nothing to do with picking a fight with Gordon Brown. It is about Peter's personal positioning, nothing bigger.

'It really is the case that the Government is trying to close this debate down, and Peter agrees with that.'

And that is the crucial twist in the tale: for once, this week was not about a cabal of pro-Europeans tweaking Brown's tail with the indulgence of Downing Street. Firstly Blair was irritated this time. And secondly, this was the week that the Government stumbled through being too clever by half.

It was Neil Kinnock who most succinctly expressed the problem facing New Labour over Europe. After listening patiently to the eager delegation from Britain in Europe, outlining plans for their pro-euro campaign, he leaned forward over the desk in his spacious Brussels office and said: 'Yes, but what are you going to do about the Sun?'

The man once crucified by an eve-of-poll front page calling on the last man in Britain to turn the lights out if he got into Downing Street has personal reasons to fear the tabloid. But his point, at that meeting three years ago, was that his successor should fear it too.

Senior ministers regard the Eurosceptic rightwing press - chiefly the Sun, the Mail and the Telegraph - as the greatest stumbling block in the propaganda war over Europe, fuelling the public hostility charted weekly both in the polls and in Philip Gould's beloved focus groups, where Labour has been scoring badly on patriotism since the spring.

And they realised several months ago that tabloid blood pressure would only shoot up further in the runup to the EU summit in Nice this December, at which a difficult treaty on EU enlargement will be hammered out. They wanted to spike the press's guns.

The deal hammered out between Downing Street and Britain in Europe, with the agreement of Charles Kennedy and senior Tories, was a tactical retreat on the euro for now, focussing on the less controversial virtues of the EU instead. They would battle not over the euro, but over euroscepticism. Only after the election could the gloves come off.

'For the next six months it is important that we maintain our discipline,' says a senior source from Britain in Europe.

'The argument does need to be remade, but it will be made more powerfully after the election.'

It was a fine line to tread, but for several weeks it seemed to work, so when Robin Cook upped the ante last Monday with a broadside against the eurosceptic media he only expected a minor stir.

'The Mail, the Sun and the Telegraph we have written off. That's why we have decided to pick a fight with them,' said one source close to him. 'These papers are not contributors to the debate, they are political activists.'

Eyebrows were raised at the regular Monday morning meeting to discuss the week's agenda: Downing Street hates upsetting tabloid readers. But Cook would have got away with it, but for a line to the press slipped out from Number 10 the next day that escaped the eagle-eyed scrutiny of press secretrary Alistair Campbell.

A telephone call between Tony Blair and Jacques Chirac revealed differences over the bottom line on Nice, it said. Which was diplomatic code for 'whacking great row'. The headlines wrote themselves.

By the time Mandelson's 'private' dinner was splashed all over the papers, it was beyond repair. Campbell's 'storyline' for the week was to trumpet millions of pounds for health and education and roads: but Europe, only ever meant to be background music, had swamped it.

'This positioning for Nice caught fire and basically took us off where we wanted to be, which was on investment,' admitted one senior Whitehall source.

Although there was no carpeting for Mandelson - most ministers privately accept he was right - Blair was irritated by the coverage and told him so. The Northern Ireland Secretary issued a soothing statement agreeing he did not want to start the campaign now.

And despite initial growls from the Treasury, Brown appears to have accepted that for once this was not a Downing Street-sponsored raid on his territory. The truce brokered by John Prescott earlier this autumn, under which Mandelson, Cook, Byers and Brown agreed common ground on the euro, has been shaken but is holding. But there are testing times to come.

The white-overalled workers spilling out of the gates of Sunderland's Nissan plant last week face an anxious Christmas.

Nearly 2,000 jobs here depend on building the Micra, along with at least 10,000 jobs in the supply chain.

The car provides a lifeline to a community that had known bitterly hard times before the Japanese arrived. Early next year Nissan will reveal whether it will build the new Micra here, guaranteeing their jobs, or inside the euro-zone in France.

Any threat to the plant, barely three months before an election, will renew all the arguments over whether being outside the single currency is hurting British manufacturing.

And no matter how hard Labour tried to control the debate, thousands of car workers would not let it go away. The real problem facing the Government is that it cannot, on the euro, always make the weather.

Nor can it always allow for the regular exocets from Berlin or Paris, where the most casual remark from a foreign minister or EU commissioner is gleefully seized on to embarrass Blair. 'The problem with Brussels, basically, is Brussels and the people in it,' sighs one union source.

The Government will try hard to push reform of the EU's creakier institutions at the Nice summit. But it may well be drowned out by arguments about the carve-up of votes between member states and the abolition of the veto on several issues, not to mention Tory howls of a federal superstate created by stealth. Even if Britain can negotiate a successful deal, Labour will need to enter the next election with a manifesto commitment to ratify it in order to force the legislation through the House of Lords.

Once again the Government has tried to get its retaliation in early. Cook will give evidence on Nice to a Commons select committee this week, and the week after the Foreign Policy Centre - an impeccably Blairite thinktank - will publish a paper on The Future Shape of Europe with essays from Blair himself, his favourite 'third way' guru Anthony Giddens, and a string of EU foreign ministers.

It is meant to show Blair is far from the only European leader suspicious of a 'United States of Europe.' But the lesson of this week is that unless the narrators closest to home get their story straight, there is not much chance of a happy ending abroad.

Certainly Ken Livingstone, that other great uncontrolled force of Blairite politics who will make his own speech on the euro tomorrow, doubts that Europe really can be controlled as conviently as Labour would like.

'No one can manage an election campaign,' he says. 'The political parties have an influence in setting the agenda, so does the media. But whatever Tony Blair does and says will never be enough, whereas if you had gone into the euro back at the beginning it would not be an issue.'

It may be little comfort to his old adversary, but even Ken refuses to be drawn on Mandelson, however, insisting with a beatific smile that he has 'no informed comment' to offer. Tony Blair must hope his ministers take a leaf out of Red Ken's book.

webTitle: Investors warned over cashing in endowments

fields.headline: Investors warned over cashing in endowments
fields.trailText: Investors cold be sitting on another endowment mortgage time bomb, lenders are warning.
fields.body:
Investors cold be sitting on another endowment mortgage time bomb, lenders are warning.

They are concerned because some people cashing in mortgage endowment policies early are failing to make alternative arrangements to pay off the capital on their home loans.

Homeowners may not realise the error because they continue to make interest-only repayments to lenders. But they risk being hit with huge bills for the capital at the end of their loan periods. Mortgage Express managing director Tim Dawson says: 'This could be a big problem in the future if we do not do something about it.'

There has been a jump in the number of people cashing in mortgage endowments after the adverse publicity about the product and letters going out from providers warning of potential shortfalls. Traded endowment policy dealer Policy Portfolio has seen inquiries increase by a third for these reasons. In this year alone it expects some £1.2 billion worth of endowments to be cashed through the second-hand market or through surrender to the provider.

Council of Mortgage Lenders spokeswoman Michelle Vosper says: 'If you have not taken advice and have cashed in your endowment of your own accord, you might not be aware that certain repayment elements are missing.'

There are up to three components to a mortgage, often provided by different companies: interest, capital and life assurance.

Under the mortgage code - a set of guidelines for the industry - lenders have to write to customers each year reminding them of the need to have an adequate repayment method in place. The Council is working on standard wording for these letters so that they are crystal clear.

Other than this annual statement, the lender has no responsibility to inform you of whether the capital on your loan is being paid off. New Barnet-based Mortgage Express has written to its customers likely to be affected - about 15 per cent - but generally lenders leave it is up to you to ensure there is a vehicle in place.

David Cresswell, of the Financial Ombudsman Service, says: 'This problem shows how complicated an endowment mortgage is, so remember to think carefully if you do cash in an endowment. And if you do, think of the cheque as mortgage money, not as a windfall.'

Lenders' annual statements start going out at the end of the year. Mortgage Express advises people looking for a capital repayment vehicle to seek independent financial advice.

webTitle: Whoops, there's a chad in my lunchbucket

fields.headline: Whoops, there's a chad in my lunchbucket
fields.standfirst:
Euan Ferguson savours the gifts showered on the language by election-speak 2000

Special report: US election
Audio: Ed Vulliamy in Florida (3mins 42)
fields.trailText: EVERY election of recent years has thrown new words and phrases into the American-English lexicon. Credibility gap, wimp factor, vision thing, I am not a crook, read my lips. The past 10 days of foot-shootery are unusual in that they have presented Americans with a fiercely arcane selection to remember: tiny vote-specific pieces of esoteric knowledge which in normal times should have passed well under Joe Blow's radar.
fields.body:
EVERY election of recent years has thrown new words and phrases into the American-English lexicon. Credibility gap, wimp factor, vision thing, I am not a crook, read my lips. The past 10 days of foot-shootery are unusual in that they have presented Americans with a fiercely arcane selection to remember: tiny vote-specific pieces of esoteric knowledge which in normal times should have passed well under Joe Blow's radar.

There's Bakered , the term describing the process in which a lowly state paralegal is suddenly hit by an apparently unstoppable avalanche of vitriolic legalistic abuse from a former Secretary of State. And we've seen the rise of the Yuca , the Young Upscale Cuban American, a key group formed of those who are too young to remember exile from Fidel, and who hated the way Elián became a republican pawn, and who thus, highly unusually for Florido-Cubans, are Democrat voters. (Not to be confused with Lunchbucket Democrats - the blue-collar Gore vote which takes its lunch outside, as opposed to inside the country club). And there's been coast-to-coast fame for Broward County , previously registering only when hosting an ugly little execution.

Bloviators have made a welcome return to the language. To bloviate is, of course, to speak pompously; and there has been much bloviation of late. The term disappeared for decades last century but began to make a comeback in the Nineties and is now hardly out of the mouths of other bloviators.

But the most bizarre must surely be chad , the word for the little holes of punched paper (or, rather crucially, the non-existent little holes of un punched paper) which could swing the Florida vote. The origins are debated. Chad was, as older readers may remember, the original bald head that popped up from chalk-drawn wartime walls, bemoaning shortages with the caption 'Wot? No_' cigarettes, Spam, whatever. The OED says he may have been created by British cartoonist George Edward Chatterton. Later, he and the American legend 'Kilroy was here' met and married, and appeared on walls together. The word also appears much earlier, in the Scottish National Dictionary, defined as gravel or 'such small stones as form the bed of rivers' (1808) - and apparently the word was applied by a Scottish teletext operator during the First World War to the accumulations of paper discs from punched tapes.

Alternatively, the term came directly from America, from the 'Chadless keypunch', named after its inventor. This was a type of paper-punch which merely serrated paper in a half-moon rather than punching the whole little circle out: as these serrations were 'chadless', went the reasoning, the little circles left by alternative punches must be chads.

Whatever. All you really need to remember are the five types being examined by checkers at the moment to see if the vote counts. A dimple chad is a simple indentation. A pregnant chad or nipple chad bulges out but has not been punched through at any point. A hanging-door chad has one corner hanging off slightly; a swing-door chad has two corners hanging, and a tri-chad is one with three corners hanging off. So now you know.

The only shame is that no one has yet coined a '-gate' suffix, without which it seems no American political drama can be complete. How long, though, before we start to hear the word 'alligate' to become terminally chewed in Florida?

webTitle: See-saw farce grips  the sunshine state

fields.headline: See-saw farce grips  the sunshine state
fields.standfirst:
Six judges dragged Al Gore back from the brink and sparked the legal tug-of-war for a pivotal state. But, as Ed Vulliamy reports from West Palm Beach, lawsuits have always been America's answer when politics fail

Special report: US election
Audio: Ed Vulliamy in Florida (3mins 42)
fields.trailText: The verdict from Judge Terry P. Lewis of Leon County was passed down through the sweltering heat of Friday morning, and the hurricane of lawyers blowing through Florida swirled into a typhoon.
fields.body:
The verdict from Judge Terry P. Lewis of Leon County was passed down through the sweltering heat of Friday morning, and the hurricane of lawyers blowing through Florida swirled into a typhoon.

The colour drained fastest from the face of Dexter Douglass, the Democratic Party's lead attorney in Florida. With a shaking hand, he managed to dial a number on his cell phone, then ran to join his heavy-hitting senior partners from Washington in a frantic huddle.

The scene was a rerun of what political aides in both the Al Gore and George Bush camps were doing during the apparently never-ending election night. Only now it was the lawyers' turn. And like the second Florida 'result' on election night, Lewis's verdict seemed to spell the beginning of the end of the election, of a long week in court and of Gore's hopes.

Republican attorneys also plunged into conclave to plan the next move, barely concealing their surprised elation. The judge had spoken few words, read to the waiting world by a gasping Terry Cass, spokeswoman for Leon County Court. But with them, Lewis in effect snatched the presidency for Bush by handing the contested result of the state's pivotal vote into the hands of a woman who has been catapulted to prominence more than any other figure in this election: Florida's Secretary of State, Katherine Harris.

Lewis ruled that Harris had used 'proper discretion' in refusing to accept the result of manual counting of 1.5 million votes in three disputed counties on which Gore's hopes were pinned: Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade.

Ten long days ago, no one had had heard of Judge Lewis, who writes murder mysteries on the side. After his announcement, the highest-earning attorneys in America and the politicians themselves went into meltdown. Bush left his Texas ranch for the state capital, Austin, preparing to follow his father across the White House welcome mat.

In Washington, Gore - clinging by his fingernails to the dream for which he was groomed - called campaign manager Bill Daley, who told him: 'It's not good. But wait, wait'. It was 10.08am, and Harris duly prepared to declare the state, and in effect the presidency, for Bush.

It was to happen once the deadline for counting absentee ballots had passed at midnight last Friday, giving Bush a lead of 760 votes.

But all week, there had been a persistent irritant to Harris's plan. It lay inside a building at the junction of Military Trail Boulevard and Gun Club Road, opposite the Mermaid stripclub on the scrappy edges of West Palm Beach. It is the Emergency Operations Centre, usually concerned with hurricane evacuation; only this time, the disaster was man-made.

While Judge Lewis's verdict was read, teams of volunteers and local government employees in an auditorium continued the West Palm Beach manual count. The same was happening down the coast in Broward and it was about to restart in sprawling Miami-Dade.

The counters in Palm Beach had been counting nothing but minutes and hours since Monday, waiting for the legal skies to at least partially clear so they could begin tabulating votes instead.

The motions to recount had been lodged, thwarted and re-lodged, and had finally been given the go-ahead on Thursday by the Florida Supreme Court. There was sudden flurry and hush as elections supervisor Theresa LaPore entered, carrying two grey metal cases full of ballot papers. She read out the rules: no talking to the political party monitors; no eating at the tables - all that had hitherto happened in the windowless room under huge yellow air conditioning ducts.

But now the judge had ruled that these key counts - would almost certainly count for nothing. Democrats' hopes were further dashed by another vote-count being faxed, phoned and emailed to the state capital, Tallahassee, on Friday. Ballot papers from voters overseas were mounting slowly to crank up Bush's majority of 300 to 342 by early evening.

Then, suddenly, came a volte-face that echoed both the election itself and the endless seesaw since. Just as Florida was wrapped in a tangerine dusk, the six judges in the state Supreme Court delivered a verdict that sent the drama back into vortex where it has been entrapped for nearly two weeks.

The court handed down an order forbidding Harris's certification of the Florida result for Bush, at least for now. Gore, back in Washington and back from the brink, dispatched cookies and coffee to reporters huddled in the cold. The snacks were followed by the man himself; 'Hi,' he said, in a gravelly voice.

The judges decreed that it was awry for Harris to declare the state for Bush ahead of the manual count, which should continue. The court will reconvene tomorrow at 2pm and hear arguments from both sides, before reaching a final verdict.

And so the count goes on, with the Democrats anticipating that by the time the judges next meet, there will be 'factual evidence' - that is, enough votes for Gore - to invalidate Harris's certification while another result is possible, if not probable.

These seven justices due to sit were all appointed by former Democrat Governors Bob Graham and Lawton Chiles, except one who was jointly appointed with Jeb Bush. Six are Democrats, one an independent.

The court has a reputation for detachment from politics - Governor Chiles lost as many cases in it as he won - but this time the chips are down. There have been no 'rebellions' in Florida so far by anyone with a political affiliation - except by Judge Lewis, a Democrat who wrote a thriller in 1997 entitled Conflict of Interests. Indeed, the question hanging over the denouement to this election is whether the law is above politics, or vice-versa.

Another two hours passed during which the Federal Appeals Court in Atlanta rejected a further plea by the Bush camp for the manual recounts to be stopped.

With the Bush side now appealing through the federal system he derides, it is now conceivable that if the appointment of the forty-third President of the United States is not concluded by a handful of votes, it could go all the way to the Supreme Court in Washington.

Litigation is the American way. When the political process fails, you file a lawsuit, over anything from slavery to cigarettes. In the Sixties, civil rights litigators created a model for forcing social reform through the courts. In their wake came legal battles over abortion, tobacco and gun control, creating laws that Congress was unable or unwilling to pass.

It started with the 'Dred Scott' case of 1857, when the Supreme Court ruled it had no right to ban slavery in the South, thereby detonating the Civil War. But no one really expected the presidency itself to go the same way - tearing America apart once again in the process.

Watching Florida's week of endless litigation has been like inspecting apparently smooth skin through a microscope to reveal every pore and minuscule wart, every strength and weakness of democracy. Behind the severity of the motions, counter-motions and name-calling have been golden moments of democratic farce. There were the open-air meetings of the Palm Beach canvassing board, demanded by Florida's open government 'Sunshine Laws'. Or the Republicans in Broward County finding a bundle of ballot 'chads' - the crucial slips of paper in a ballot sheet that are supposed to have been punched out to register a vote - in a rubbish bag.

There is the debate over what kind of unpunched 'chad' (a 'hanging' or 'pregnant chad') does, or does not, constitute an intended vote. 'In Palm Beach,' said Bruce Rogaw, a lawyer for the county, 'we're not interested in pregnancy, only in penetration'. The hookers along the beach have a new lexicon to play with, offering clients a 'manual recount'.

Yet in reality, the whole affair is deadly serious. If Gore wins this election, it will be because he is a dog-fighter without equal, who will have directed the most determined, take-no-prisoners legal marathon in American political history. His generals in that victory will be have been a hit-squad of lawyers which descended on Florida armed with stardom rather than ideological zeal.

Among them are Harvard Professor Laurence Tribe, who is America's leading constitutional lawyer, Alan Dershowitz, who was counsel to such celebrities as O.J. Simpson and Claus Von Bulow, and David Boies who mauled Microsoft through the federal courts.  Every vote should count and, in Florida law, be counted to assess the voter's intention. If that happens, we think we can win in the end. When is our 'finality'? When we're ahead in the Florida vote - including hand counts?

 Say that the process can be speedy - but admit it could stretch into December. 'The American people are patient people.'

 Hire ever more expensive lawyers.

 Use the Vice-President from Washington mansion on TV to look presidential. Always remember that this is more politics than law. Be statesmanlike and concerned (and keep campaign chairman William Daley under wraps).

 Try to find the high ground - thus Gore's offer of a statewide hand recount, including Republican counties - but encourage heavily Democratic counties like Miami-Dade to recount.

Republicans:

 Get it over with (because, after two full machine counts, we're in the lead).

 Pretend that George W. Bush is the inevitable victor, the next President who should be building a Cabinet now in the national interest.

 Visualise - in public - a process stretching ahead for weeks if not months. 'When will it end? When will there be finality?' (James Baker).

 Construct deadlines - first, yesterday's delayed certification of the vote; now Thanksgiving on Thursday, when the people 'need and deserve' an answer. Americans want to eat turkey not watch politicians talk it.

 Attack Democrats as unprincipled launchers of law suits. Launch Republican law suits as necessary. Attack Florida's Democrat-appointed Supreme Court judges as partisan creatures.

 Defend Secretary of State Katherine Harris (and Bush campaign co-chair) as fine public servant. Describe hand counting as messy, chaotic, unprincipled and possibly rigged.

 Invent more ludicrous adjectives to hang on chads.

 Claim that hand-counting in Texas (signed into law by George W. Bush) is different.

 Basic calculation: if the Democrats can build up a hand count lead, to add to their electoral college and popular vote leads, we're in trouble. Every day the hand counting goes on, makes that more likely. Stop it now!

Who's winning?

The Democrats are still behind, but the Florida Supreme Court on Monday is crucial. If that court allows the hand counts and delays certification of the result to include them, then Gore has the advantage. But will it in all the recounting counties, or just Palm Beach? The hand counting numbers aren't rolling back Bush's lead yet. Gore might simply lose on the vote, however counted.

fields.body:
John Ellis is not unlike any other American journalist in wanting to be first with big news. At the helm of Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Network's election night decision team, he achieved the now dubious distinction of being the first to call Florida - and the presidential election - for George W. Bush. The numbers he was working from were not official, but the viewers did not know that. Nor did they know that Ellis was very chummy with Bush - he's his first cousin.

No one might have given Ellis much notice if the election was not still hanging by a chad almost two weeks later - or if he had not bragged to the New Yorker magazine that throughout what's come to be known as 'Indecision 2000' he was constantly on the phone with his cousins George and Florida's Governor 'Jebbie', tipping them off with the latest internal projections on the voting.

The revelation has caused disquiet within the more high-minded of media circles, not least because his decision to call it for 'Dubya' on Fox at 2:16am forced the hand of competing networks. CNN, NBC, ABC and CBS followed the Ellis lead within four minutes, only to be forced into embarrassing retractions less than two hours later. But the fateful decision has proved convenient for Republicans in the ongoing PR war, say media watchers, creating a lasting impression that Bush 'won' the White House - and all the legal wrangling down in Florida is just a case of Democratic 'snippiness'.

'The notion you'd have the cousin of one presidential candidate in a position to call a state, and the election, is unthinkable,' says Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism. 'Fox's call - wrong, unnecessary, misguided, foolish - helped create a sense that the election went to Bush, was pulled back, and it's just a matter of time before his President-elect title is restored.

'But that said, John Ellis is a good man, a good journalist whose judgment was overcome by excitement. He put himself in an impossible situation, but the mistake was not so much his as Rupert Murdoch's for putting him in that position.'

Ellis, the son of former President Bush's sister, Nancy Ellis, opted to fall on his sword. But the News Corp chairman and CEO, oddly enough a major Republican donor, told a Fox shareholders' meeting on Wednesday he was in no way concerned by the brouhaha. 'Every journalist on every channel was trying to get in touch with candidates,' Murdoch said, adding, apparently with a straight face, that there had been 'no partisanship at all' in Fox's election coverage.

But even Republicans and Democrats can agree that Fox is an ideologically motivated channel, leaning far to the right of the mainstream. It offers itself up as a balanced alternative to the so-called 'liberal' networks, but it's made no secret of its support for Bush during the pre- and post-election campaigns.

'Everybody knows it's a partisan channel, but its marketing slogan, "We report; you decide", is now totally obliterated by the fact that one candidate's first cousin is actually deciding, and then they report,' says Rosenstiel.

Fox News says it is conducting an internal inquiry into Ellis's role to see if he violated any election night rules set out in a memo to staff from John Moody, the vice-president. One of those rules prohibits producers and reporters from 'sharing proprietory information' with anyone outside the organisation. Sources suggest Ellis will be 'quietly let go' in a month or so for providing his cousins with exit poll data, pending a House of Representatives' investigation into the news networks' use of such figures.'

But on the face of it the case looks pretty plain for all to see. 'It was just the three of us guys handing the phone back and forth - me with the numbers, one of them a governor, the other President-elect. Now that was cool,' Ellis told the New Yorker . 'And everybody followed us.'

webTitle: Bush set to clinch the presidency

fields.headline: Bush set to clinch the presidency
fields.standfirst:
Gore under pressure to concede after Florida blow

Special report: US election
Audio: Ed Vulliamy in Florida (3mins 42)
fields.trailText: George W. Bush was last night inching towards the White House while his rival Al Gore was facing an agonising choice between concession or a long legal battle that would produce new depths of bitterness in US politics.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy  in West Palm Beach  and Peter Preston in Washington
fields.body:
George W. Bush was last night inching towards the White House while his rival Al Gore was facing an agonising choice between concession or a long legal battle that would produce new depths of bitterness in US politics.

Bush's lead in the decisive state of Florida grew steadily as absentee ballots from overseas were counted and Gore appeared to gather fewer votes than expected from continuing manual recounts.

Taking into account the 67 counties where the absentee voting was complete, Bush was left with an overall Florida lead of 930, more than triple his lead before the overseas votes were counted. All counties were required to report absentee totals by noon yesterday, and the two campaigns spent the morning squabbling over several hundred overseas ballots discarded because of postmark disputes.

Late last night the Bush team in Austin launched a virulent attack on the recounting process. Karen Hughes, Bush's press spokesman, denounced 'distorting, reinventing and miscounting' in Florida.

Governor Marc Racicot of Montana reported Bush votes in Gore piles and stacks of ballot forms dropped on the floor. 'What in the name of God is going on?'

The attacks marked a new escalation in the crisis, with the Bush camp seeking to discredit the whole business of hand counting as fraudulent, impotent and corrupt

The Gore campaign had been thrown a lifeline on Friday when the Florida Supreme Court prohibited Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state, from certifying the result after noon yesterday. This would almost certainly have given Bush Florida's 25 Electoral College votes and the presidency.

The court will convene at 2pm tomorrow to hear arguments as to whether manual recounts in three Florida counties are legal. Last night lawyers for both sides stayed up all night to prepare their cases, and hand counts in Broward and Palm Beach counties continued. Miami-Dade decided to begin the tally on Monday but estimated the task could take two weeks, citing staff shortages.

From what evidence was available, the maths was beginning to move against Gore. In the Democratic stronghold of Broward he picked up only 49 more votes in hand counts of 30 per cent of precincts. Officials said there was 'no significant gain' in Palm Beach. It was calculated that if this rate persisted he would add only 218 votes through the manual count, less than a quarter of what he needs to beat Bush.

The tally for Gore would be much higher if 'overvotes' - invalidated because two holes were punched - were counted, he said. These are the votes Democrats say resulted from confusion in the ballot paper and which are properly theirs.

Other projections have been more optimistic for Gore, with statisticians working for the Miami Herald calculating a gain of 1,900. The Gore camp in Florida is divided between those who counsel caution in the case of a defeat in court tomorrow, led by former Secretary of State Warren Christopher, and the hardliners, led by campaign manager Bill Daley and, surprisingly, the soft-spoken running mate Joe Lieberman. Gore is said to be leaning towards his militant wing.

If the Democrats lose the court case on Monday Gore has few options but to concede or appeal over the head of Florida's court to the Supreme Court in Washington. Meanwhile Democrats in another Florida county - Seminole - have begun legal action challenging the validity of 4,700 absentee ballots, most of them Republican. A local judge sits in Palm Beach tomorrow to decide whether to order a complete revote in the county.

If every verdict cuts the Republican way, this election could be over by the middle of next week. Gloomier observers worry about Christmas.

The US Supreme Court has never been asked to adjudi cate on a presidency. The present court, headed by the conservative Chief Justice William Rehnquist, is the most narrowly divided for decades. It has a history of being a bastion of the right, but two appointments by President Clinton made it more evenly balanced.

The Republican charge against Vice President Gore was led yesterday by a bevy of governors meeting in conference. Governors are usually more circumspect than Senators or Congressmen, but they turned their full fire on the Democrat campaign for hand counting Florida's votes - and, significantly, on the Florida Supreme Court which has allowed those counts to go on.

'My greatest fear is that with six Democrats on this court and one independent, they could pretty much make up whatever they wanted,' said Governor John Rowland of Connecticut. Governor Frank Keating of Oklahoma called the Supreme Court decision 'totally irrational'.

fields.headline: Brave knock by real all-rounder
fields.trailText: Vic Marks salutes Craig White, who took the game to Pakistan and did much to help secure such a large first-innings total.
fields.body:
We are, let's face it, flabbergasted at the size of England's first innings in Lahore on a pitch that was supposed to disintegrate and allow all and sundry a day off today. But the manner in which the key contributors to that total of 480-8 declared scored their runs has not been so surprising - except in the case of Craig White.

Graham Thorpe diligently nudged and ran for more than seven devoted hours. Mike Atherton oozed phlegm as he usually does, and it has now reached a stage where we are not so taken aback when Marcus Trescothick looks comfortable in the Test arena. This pair are bright enough to realise that Pakistan is one of the few venues in the cricket ing world where it is a definite bonus to be an opening batsman. For once runs are easier to come by against the new, hard ball, a rare consolation for having to open up against McGrath, Donald, Pollock or Walsh in other climes. But Craig White had us blinking.

His was the most assertive innings among the English batsmen, which, as Thorpe readily admitted, 'made life easier for me'. It was aggressive, yet controlled, unlike the extravagant effort of Shahid Afridi on Friday, whose enterprise gave way to wanton irresponsibility.

White's 93 displayed courage and good sense, qualities rarely seen in England's lower order in recent times. When he came to the crease at 225-5 the standard, old pro-ish advice would have been 'hang in there with Thorpey; keep an end up and try to eke out a few more runs. Don't do anything rash.' White was bright and brave enough to take an alternative route.

If he had dutifully propped and cocked, the chances are that he would have been snapped up by Saqlain. Fine technicians like Atherton and Thorpe may be able to survive by wearing down their opponents, but White, surprisingly diffident by nature given his Aussie background, would never claim their technical excellence.

Instead he opted to assert his authority. Soon he was jumping down the wicket to Saqlain and driving him over mid-off; Shahid Afridi, underbowled in that first innings, was deposited over the ropes for six - a long way at Lahore. These were high-risk strokes. A slight error of judgment, a ballooned catch to the outfield and he may have encountered a grimace from his captain (even though Hussain had tried this ploy and failed); more certainly he would have been castigated by the press corps for his 'irresponsibility'.

However, he had the nerve to strike the ball rather than just survive and his self-belief mushroomed. Thereafter, with his authority established and his score in the thirties, he was confident that he could cope against the spinners without playing any 'big' shots.

It is not only White's runs in Lahore which will affect how England approach the rest of this series. His bowling, often underestimated in the past by opposition batsmen, has also been hugely impressive. He is rarely wayward and considerably faster than his shortish run-up would have you believe.

White finished with figures of 3-48 at the end of the fourth day's play in Lahore, making him England's most effective bowler - so it seems the England tour management now have a genuine Test all-rounder at their disposal. If conditions are like this in Faisalabad and Karachi, two spinners will be essential. Now they can contemplate White coming in at seven with some confidence.

As White's Test career blossoms, a couple of England coaches will be smiling. Ray Illingworth spotted his talent back in 1994 and picked him in the hope that he would be the magical rabbit plucked out of a Pudsey hat. In fact White himself acknowledges that he was not ready for Test cricket when first selected. Fletcher has since resurrected his career, insisting on a central contract for him last April which no one expected. His hunch was correct, and in 2000 the timing was right, for White has matured. In the past his diffidence may have been a handicap; he remains endearingly self-effacing, but now he enters the harsh arena of Test cricket as if he belongs there.

webTitle: A gentler globe begins at home

fields.headline: A gentler globe begins at home
fields.standfirst: Is your tired old boiler to blame for the floods? Jill Insley on greener houses
fields.trailText: Is your tired old boiler to blame for the floods? Jill Insley on greener houses.
fields.body:
Prince Charles may have jumped the gun in attributing the floods of the past few weeks to mankind's 'arrogant disregard' for the delicate balance of nature, but scientists are generally agreed that prolific generation of greenhouse gases is causing changes to the climate.

Half of the UK's greenhouse gas emissions are caused by heat escaping from our homes; a further quarter is generated by our cars. So we really can make a difference by cutting back our personal use of the carbon fuels that generate greenhouse gases.

Saving energy saves money, too. Professor Max Fordham, one of the country's leading specialists in heating, water supply and electrical installations, has estimated that the ultimate wish-list for converting an old home into an energy efficient one - including adding insulation to walls, installing a natural light energy system, plus a range of energy efficient appliances - could cost up to £23,000. This is beyond the pockets of most homeowners, but there are still plenty of affordable things you can do. The Energy Savings Trust estimates that simple energy awareness could save a typical household £250 a year.

A good starting point is your local Energy Efficiency Advice Centre (call 0800 512012 for your nearest branch). It will provide a questionnaire about the age and size of your home. Depending on your answers, the EEAC will recommend changes, estimate how much these will cost, and how much money they will save you. The service is free. Several private companies offer a similar service, but charge anything from £50 to £150. The EEAC's recommendations may include:

Boilers

If your boiler is more than 15 years old, it is significantly less efficient than a modern one. You could save a fifth of your fuel bill if you switch to a new one - even more if you buy a condensing boiler. These convert 85 per cent of fuel into heat, compared with 65 per cent to 75 per cent for a standard boiler. However they cost more to buy (the cheapest versions at B&Q cost £554, compared with £389), and produce water vapour, so you need a drain for the condensation.

Households that use oil or liquid petroleum gas rather than gas or electricity for heating may qualify for a grant of up to £250 by replacing their old boiler with a condensing boiler and installing heating controls. The EST estimates that a small three-bedroom semi could save £100 a year with a condensing boiler.

Lagging tanks and pipes

Water stays hot longer if your tank and pipes are insulated properly. The jacket should be 3 inches thick and cover the entire tank, and your hot water pipes should be insulated along their entire length, but particularly between the boiler and the hot water tank. Expect to pay between £5 and £10 for a tank cover and £1 for three metres of pipe lagging. Annual saving: £20 for the water tank, a further £5 for the pipes.

Fridge/freezers

Manufacturers have not been allowed to use CFCs for several years, but the most commonly used refrigerant, R134a, while not quite so damaging to the ozone layer, is still a greenhouse gas. If you want to help the environment, check that the appliance you buy uses the newer refrigerant, R600a, which does not damage the ozone layer and is not a significant greenhouse gas

Also, check energy ratings: appliances are rated from A to C, with A using the least energy. Which ? magazine recently tested fridge freezers, and found that of five appliances that claimed to have an A rating, only two - the Zanussi ZA25 and the Bosch KGE32 65GB - lived up to the manufacturers' claims.

Washing machines

Modern detergents work just as well at lower temperatures unless you have very dirty washing, and you can cut electricity use by using a 40 degree rather than 60 degree cycle. Wait until you have a full load to run the machine.

Loft lagging

You can do this yourself, but use goggles, mask and gloves, as the lagging fleece is irritating to skin. The recommended depth is 8in, with 4in across joists. However you should not block ventilation openings from the eaves, and do not lag underneath your water tank, as this may cause it to freeze in winter.

Lagging costs from £4.67 for an eight-metre roll, but bear in mind that you would need a double thickness to achieve the desired 8 inches. Expect to save 20 per cent on your fuel bills, or about £35 a year for a small three-bedroom house.

Low-energy light bulbs

One of the easiest ways to save money. The initial outlay may seem expensive - the most expensive at B&Q costs £22.98 compared with £1.09 for a pack of four normal lightbulbs, but it should last for 15 years and use one fifth of the energy. They are best used in places where you have lights on most often and for longest, simply because they will save you the most money this way. Annual saving £10 per bulb.

Green - but not money-savers

For a real test of your environmental credentials, there are several products you can use that will cause less damage to the environment, but are likely to cost the same or slightly more.

Green energy

Burning coal, oil and gas in power stations to produce electricity also produces vast quantities of CO2 and other polluting greenhouse gases responsible for climate change. However, several utility companies now offer green tariffs, where you pay for green energy supplied by renewable energy projects such as hydro-electricity, wind and wave generators.

Friends of the Earth has rated companies offering green tariffs according to whether they offer customers the chance to buy green energy, their record for energy-efficiency and pollution, and their environmental policy and that of their parent company. Ecotricity and Unit[e] scored best.

For details visit the organisation's website at www.foe.co.uk.

For information about prices and how to switch providers, contact Ofgem on 0800 887777 or visit its website at www.ofgem.org.uk.

Low VOC-content paint

Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are solvents and other chemicals in paints that evaporate during use. They are released into the atmosphere and react with nitrogen oxides, contributing to atmospheric pollution. They may also be linked to certain health problems, including asthma.

You can help by using paint with low VOC content - emulsions use water rather than synthetic solvents, and typically contain less than 4 per cent VOCs. Gloss and varnishes need higher VOC levels (between 40 and 80 per cent). B&Q labels paints to show level of VOCs.

Timber products from well-managed forests

The Forest Stewardship Council is a global organisation that sets standards for and assesses the management of woodland around the world. Look for timber and products made from wood (everything from doors to toilet seats) carrying the Forest Stewardship Council label.

Look on the FSC's website - for further information about the scheme and retailers that stock approved products.

How to step off the gas

The simplest way to save money and cut emissions from your car is not to use it. Some people car-share; others switch to bikes. But if these are not options for you, how can you become a greener driver?

Petrol engines are less efficient than diesel, and emit more CO2, CO and hydrocarbons. But Friends of the Earth points out that diesel engines produce more nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, black smoke and particles associated with poor urban air quality. FoE says both petrol and diesel can be reformulated to lower emissions, and urges drivers whose cars have a catalytic converter to look for city diesel and petrol, clean diesel and petrol, low-sulphur petrol, ultra-low-sulphur diesel and low benzene petrol. These make no difference to a car's performance, and should become cheaper from next March thanks to the cuts announced in the pre-Budget report.

Other ways to cut fuel consumption include:

 Remove roof racks when not in use. They cut fuel economy by 10 per cent even empty.

 Keep tyres at the correct pressure: under-inflated tyres cut efficiency by a mile a gallon.

 Drive more slowly. Doing 80 or 85 mph increases your costs by 25p per10 miles.

 Try not to use air conditioning. It eats petrol at up to 7 per cent more than normal.

The jacket should be 3 inches thick and cover the entire tank, and your hot water pipes should be insulated along their entire length, but particularly between the boiler and the hot water tank. Expect to pay between £5 and £10 for a tank cover and £1 for three metres of pipe lagging. Annual saving: £20 for the water tank, a further £5 for the pipes. Fridge/freezers Manufacturers have not been allowed to use CFCs for several years, but the most commonly used refrigerant, R134a, while not quite so damaging to the ozone layer, is still a greenhouse gas. If you want to help the environment, check that the appliance you buy uses the newer refrigerant, R600a, which does not damage the ozone layer and is not a significant greenhouse gas Also, check energy ratings: appliances are rated from A to C, with A using the least energy. Which ? magazine recently tested fridge freezers, and found that of five appliances that claimed to have an A rating, only two - the Zanussi ZA25 and the Bosch KGE32 65GB - lived up to the manufacturers' claims. Washing machines Modern detergents work just as well at lower temperatures unless you have very dirty washing, and you can cut electricity use by using a 40 degree rather than 60 degree cycle. Wait until you have a full load to run the machine. Loft lagging You can do this yourself, but use goggles, mask and gloves, as the lagging fleece is irritating to skin. The recommended depth is 8in, with 4in across joists. However you should not block ventilation openings from the eaves, and do not lag underneath your water tank, as this may cause it to freeze in winter. Lagging costs from £4.67 for an eight-metre roll, but bear in mind that you would need a double thickness to achieve the desired 8 inches. Expect to save 20 per cent on your fuel bills, or about £35 a year for a small three-bedroom house. Low-energy light bulbs One of the easiest ways to save money. The initial outlay may seem expensive - the most expensive at B&Q costs £22.98 compared with £1.09 for a pack of four normal lightbulbs, but it should last for 15 years and use one fifth of the energy. They are best used in places where you have lights on most often and for longest, simply because they will save you the most money this way. Annual saving £10 per bulb. Green - but not money-savers For a real test of your environmental credentials, there are several products you can use that will cause less damage to the environment, but are likely to cost the same or slightly more. Green energy Burning coal, oil and gas in power stations to produce electricity also produces vast quantities of CO2 and other polluting greenhouse gases responsible for climate change. However, several utility companies now offer green tariffs, where you pay for green energy supplied by renewable energy projects such as hydro-electricity, wind and wave generators. Friends of the Earth has rated companies offering green tariffs according to whether they offer customers the chance to buy green energy, their record for energy-efficiency and pollution, and their environmental policy and that of their parent company. Ecotricity and Unit[e] scored best. For details visit the organisation's website at www.foe.co.uk. For information about prices and how to switch providers, contact Ofgem on 0800 887777 or visit its website at www.ofgem.org.uk. Low VOC-content paint Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are solvents and other chemicals in paints that evaporate during use. They are released into the atmosphere and react with nitrogen oxides, contributing to atmospheric pollution. They may also be linked to certain health problems, including asthma. You can help by using paint with low VOC content - emulsions use water rather than synthetic solvents, and typically contain less than 4 per cent VOCs. Gloss and varnishes need higher VOC levels (between 40 and 80 per cent). B&Q labels paints to show level of VOCs. Timber products from well-managed forests The Forest Stewardship Council is a global organisation that sets standards for and assesses the management of woodland around the world. Look for timber and products made from wood (everything from doors to toilet seats) carrying the Forest Stewardship Council label. Look on the FSC's website - for further information about the scheme and retailers that stock approved products. How to step off the gas The simplest way to save money and cut emissions from your car is not to use it. Some people car-share; others switch to bikes. But if these are not options for you, how can you become a greener driver? Petrol engines are less efficient than diesel, and emit more CO2, CO and hydrocarbons. But Friends of the Earth points out that diesel engines produce more nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, black smoke and particles associated with poor urban air quality. FoE says both petrol and diesel can be reformulated to lower emissions, and urges drivers whose cars have a catalytic converter to look for city diesel and petrol, clean diesel and petrol, low-sulphur petrol, ultra-low-sulphur diesel and low benzene petrol. These make no difference to a car's performance, and should become cheaper from next March thanks to the cuts announced in the pre-Budget report. Other ways to cut fuel consumption include:  Remove roof racks when not in use. They cut fuel economy by 10 per cent even empty.  Keep tyres at the correct pressure: under-inflated tyres cut efficiency by a mile a gallon.  Drive more slowly. Doing 80 or 85 mph increases your costs by 25p per10 miles.  Try not to use air conditioning. It eats petrol at up to 7 per cent more than normal.

fields.headline: MGM volunteers an equitable deal
fields.trailText: Up to 10,000 members of life office MGM Assurance are in line to receive payouts following the High Court verdict against life office Equitable Life earlier this year.
fields.body:
Up to 10,000 members of life office MGM Assurance are in line to receive payouts following the High Court verdict against life office Equitable Life earlier this year.

The court of appeal ruled that Equitable's decision to cut final or terminal bonuses payable to members with guaranteed annuities was unlawful. It said the life office should hand over the money to the 90,000 holders of the pension policies leaving Equitable to pick up a £1.5 billion tab. The life office has been forced to put itself up for sale as a result.

Now MGM Assurance has decided it will reinstate terminal bonuses on its guaranteed annuities, both in future and retrospectively. It will be reopening as many as 10,000 cases to see if they are eligible for a payout. Policies which matured in the past three years will be re-examined, as this was when the bonuses were curbed.

Worthing-based MGM has not decided how big the compensation awards will be. Some policies earn nothing in terminal bonuses - it is up to the providers how much they pay - but MGM head of marketing Richard Wood says they intend to treat those who took the annuities 'equally' to those who took the cash option when they retired.

In the past, terminal bonuses on the cash option have been as much as 40 per cent of reversionary or annual bonuses.

MGM says it has not decided on the size of the terminal bonus because it is seeking legal advice on how the situation will impact on different products.

But it is hoping to bring the matter to a speedy conclusion. The life office can generate the money it needs to compensate the annuity holders in one of two ways, according to industry analyst Ned Cazalet of Cazalet Financial Consulting. It can reduce its solvency generally, or cut future bonuses. Either way Cazalet says: 'They will be hit and hit badly. The reserves will have to be strengthened considerably.'

At the end of last year MGM, whose traditional product base has been mortgage endowments and personal pensions, had assets of £138 million. Cazalet says MGM is weak relative to other with-profits life offices, making any blow significant. Cazalet puts this into perspective: 'If everyone is awarded just £2,000, that translates into a bill of £20m.'

It may escape the fate of Equitable Life and struggle along on its own but, as Cazalet says, a merger with a stronger life office has become 'compelling' and is better for its pension holders, who could otherwise see their future bonuses slashed.

webTitle: Pensions: Look before you make a leap forward

fields.headline: Look before you make a leap forward
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean on a predicted carry-on about extra pension contributions
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean on a predicted carry-on about extra pension contributions.
fields.body:
Pensions experts are predicting a scramble among well-heeled, self-employed people to make extra pension contributions before they are stopped from doing so at the end of this financial year.

But experts are also warning people against getting carried away and making contributions they cannot afford just to get the tax relief.

The scheme, which is coming to an end, is known as 'carry forward'. Under these rules people with personal pensions and retirement annuity contracts can carry forward up to six years of unused pension contributions. So, for example, if Fred did not make all the contributions he could have done in 1997-98, he could now make a payment into a personal pension to use that allowance retrospectively.

This arrangement is open to anyone with a personal pension or retirement annuity contract - but it is particularly useful for self-employed people whose businesses are on the up and can now afford contributions that were beyond their reach previously.

Many advisers are contacting self-employed clients to explain the impending demise of the scheme. Peter Smith of adviser Hill Martin says: 'A lot depends on the client's normal expenditure on pensions and their available cash. Is it a good idea to take out a mortgage to do it? I don't think so.'

Andy Bell, managing director of Sippdeal, which offers online dealing in self-invested personal pensions, says: 'All the advisers we deal with are looking to launch a campaign in this area in the next few months. But people have to understand this. If you've got spare cash, great. But I would draw the line at borrowing to do it.'

While the ability to carry forward contributions on personal pensions stops on 5 April, holders of retirement annuity contracts can make contributions after that date through the carry- forward system. This may be one reason why someone who has such as contract may prefer to continue paying into it, rather than going for one of the new low-charging stakeholder pensions.

The Government has seized the opportunity of the launch of stakeholder pensions on 6 April to do away with the carry forward system, which it thinks too generous to wealthier people.

Ian Johnson of accountant Grant Thornton explains: 'The carry forward rules helped people who had a very high-earning year, an insurance policy that matured or perhaps a legacy. Those most helped were people such as partners in firms of accountants and solicitors. Carry forward could help them and others with their own business: the last thing you might be thinking of in the early years of a business would be paying pension contributions.'

Anyone wanting to do a carry forward before the end of the tax year needs first to calculate how much relief they have available. Leaflet IR78 - in tax offices, on www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk or through the Revenue's orderline on 0645 000 404 - explains how this is done.

The amount you can pay to a personal pension depends on your age and how much you earn. A 37-year old with net relevant earnings (income less certain deductions) of £20,000 could pay a maximum of 20 per cent of that income - £4,000 - into a personal pension. If that 37-year old had only made £1,000 of contributions, he could now pay in another £3,000 and get the tax relief.

If you decide to go ahead, contact the Inland Revenue and fill in form PP43 (or simply 43 if you have a retirement annuity contract). Although it could be argued that you do not have to send in proof that you have made the pension payment, you'll make life easier by enclosing copies of the letter you wrote to the pension provider, the cheque you sent or their receipt.

'If you don't send in the documentation, you are asking for an inquiry,' says tax specialist Richard Murphy. The Inland Revenue can launch investigations into any taxpayer's affairs: inquiries are usually expensive and stressful.

Bell warns people doing a carry forward to look at the charges on any pension policy they already have. 'A lot of policies taken out before 5 April will generate very fat commission. If you are making a large single contribu tion, make sure the charges are low.'

There is nothing to stop someone starting a new low-charging policy if they think they will be better off there than paying into a plan that takes off 5 per cent or more in initial charges. The new stakeholder plans are limited to annual charges of 1 per cent a year, and they cannot make initial charges at all.

For some people, the 5 April deadline can be postponed to 31 January 2002. Interlocking with the carry forward rules are the 'carry back' rules. These allow you to carry back a payment made before 31 January in a fiscal year to the previous tax year if you had not used up your full pension payments allowance in that year.

So some people will, during 2001-02, be able to get themselves back into the 2000-01 tax year by using 'carry back' and then lock into the previous six years by getting into the 'carry forward' rules. But this approach is more for well-placed tax relief aficionados than the person in the street.
