fields.headline: Share-outs sweeten sorrow
fields.standfirst: Middle-class wives win an instant slice of pensions, says  Neasa  MacErlean
fields.trailText: Middle-class wives win an instant slice of pensions, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Up to 10,000 unhappily married middle class couples each year are expected to take advantage of a change in the law that will allow them for the first time to share out pension funds .

The change applies where one member of a Middle- England couple - perhaps a bank manager, police officer or civil servant - is in an occupational scheme.

When this part of the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act takes effect, on 1 December, partners will be able to split the funds in the same way as they now divide shareholdings, book collections and other assets.

They can agree any proportions they like for the share-out. Many will go for a 50:50 split. A divorcing wife whose husband's fund is worth £100,000 could keep her half in his employer's scheme, or take it out and set up her own pension.

'This will be attractive to Tony Blair's England - people in their late forties or fifties who have built up a pension fund,' says David Davidson of solicitor Charles Russell and author of Pensions and Marriage Breakdown .

'It will help them make a clean-break settlement. It will also help people with very good pension schemes who are working in declining industries.'

But pension-sharing is still controversial. Women's campaigners, particularly the group Fairshares, fought hard for this breakthrough, which ensures that women are never left out of divorce settlements, as they were in the past. This used to favour higher-earning husbands at their ex-wives' expense.

But the new rules have their own snags: they could be too costly for many people; they will be misunderstood by many divorce professionals; and the outcomes will be unfair in many cases.

A similar change in the law - allowing a share of an ex-spouse's pension to be earmarked for the future - has attracted only 1,000 couples since it took effect in 1996. When the scheme member draws a pension, the ex-spouse gets one as well. But the ex-wife gets nothing if her former hus band dies early or postpones taking the pension, and she loses any right to the fund if she remarries.

Anyone considering the latest sharing option should first consider simply trying to divide the assets without carving up the pension. If, for example, a couple have £100,000 in a pension fund and own a clear £100,000 of the value of their home, the husband could keep the pension, while the wife took on the house.

If pension-sharing still seems best, a fair valuation of the fund by the scheme's trustees is crucial. The Divorce Corporation, a specialist firm of pension fund valuers, has seen cases where the wife received only half of what would be fairly due to her under the earmarking rules, because of the valuation. The trustees will assume that the husband will retire at 60 or 65, even if that won't happen.

A policeman aged 49, for example, would be assumed to start drawing his pension at 60. In reality, many officers can retire at 50 with very comfortable 'final salary' pension from that age. A wife who accepted a valuation based on retirement at 60 would lose 10 years' potential income.

Study your own and your spouse's financial statements carefully. Financial claims are dealt with in parallel to the divorce claim. You will both submit sworn statements of your means, and will be able to put questions to each other and ask for further information.

Get of a copy of the rules of your spouse's pension scheme and find out what benefits it has paid so far. If, for instance, a 'final salary' scheme has regularly given pensioners rises above the rate of inflation, you could make a higher claim, as you could reasonably assume that your spouse will get similar increases. Be aware of the difference between 'money purchase' schemes, where the member simply builds up a pot of money; and 'final salary' schemes, where members accumulate only an entitlement to an annual income.)

You are best off trying to negotiate your own settlement, but mediation services are available in case of difficulty. You will finally agree a 'pension sharing order' which sets out the percentage split between you and tells the trustees to make the arrangements.

You may be forced to move your share out of the scheme. 'Most require ex-spouses to transfer their share to their own scheme,' says Sarah Tier of pension solicitor Sacker & Partners.

If this happens, you may need to set up a new personal pension of your own. You will have a choice of many low-fee schemes from April, when the new state-backed 'stakeholder pension' is introduced. Charges will be only 1 per cent a year - considerably lower than on traditional plans.

Pension schemes are allowed to charge for the costs of setting up a pension share. Most will follow a list of suggested charges, which is being published by the National Association of Pension Funds. The maximum on the list is£750, though this is not binding.

Sallie Quin of Fairshares says: 'Large and medium-sized schemes won't have a problem, but sharing arrangements could be disproportionately expensive for small employers.'

Sharing could apply to several different pension scheme funds if your spouse has more than one fund from previous jobs. The rules can also be applied to personal pensions.

Mistakes by professionals can haunt you long after they are made. Divorce solicitors have, in the past, helped women into a poverty- stricken old age by ignoring husbands' pensions.

A big effort is being made to educate lawyers about the reform, but most will not be capable of dealing with this issue particularly well. Ensure that your solicitor understands the issue, perhaps by using one recommended by the Solicitors' Family Law Association. It has an accreditation system for divorce solicitors, who understand pensions - but only about 35 out of its 5,000 members are yet accredited.

You could benefit from asking an actuary to look at the pension valuation, or get advice on setting up a personal pension.

'Don't accept what you are first offered,' says Donna Bradshaw of independent financial adviser Fiona Price & Partners. 'It is a highly emotional time, and you want people with you who understand the issues.'

Further information

'Pensions and Marriage Breakdown', aimed at professionals and 'informed laymen', £19.99, is published by Bene Factum (020 7630 8616).

The Divorce Corporation: 0114 262 0616.

The Solicitors' Family Law Association: 01689 850227.

webTitle: Supermarkets: A mortgage and a pinta

fields.headline: A mortgage and a pinta
fields.standfirst: Are supermarket financial products as half-baked as their ciabattas?  Virginia Wallis reports
fields.trailText: Are supermarket financial products as half-baked as their ciabattas? Virginia Wallis reports
fields.body:
It's official: we are not being ripped off by supermarkets. The Competition Commission report on supermarkets published last month concluded: 'The industry is broadly competitive and, overall, excessive prices are not being charged nor excessive profits earned.'

That may be true of bacon and baked beans, but can the same be said of the supermarkets' financial products? There was certainly no hint of profiteering when Sainsbury and Tesco launched their savings accounts back in 1997. And the attractive rates paid on balances of £1 and upwards put them well ahead of the high street and ensured regular appearances in best-buy tables. But then the new supermarket banks realised that giving consumers such a good deal wasn't making them enough money.

Less than a year later they were still offering better deals than the average high-street savings account, but with the introduction of interest-rate tiers and new banks set up by insurers Legal & General, Scottish Widows and Standard Life - and the Safeway-branded accounts operated by Abbey National - they were by no means market leaders any longer.

You could earn over £300 more a year (before tax) with the CLIC Direct Easy Access account from Bristol & West (0845 111 0114) and the SimplySave account offered by Birmingham Midshires (0845 602 2828), both of which pay 6.85 per cent.

Although they haven't gone down the cash Isa route, both Sainsbury's and Tesco do offer low-charging equity-based Isas. Managed by its banking partner Bank of Scotland, Sainsbury's Direct Isa, which tracks the FTSE top 100 companies, has no initial charge, an annual management fee of 0.75 per cent and no minimum investment. The Tesco Growth Isa tracks the FTSE All-Share Index, while its Income Isa invests in quality corporate bonds and gilts. Both Tesco Isas - which are managed by Norwich Union - require a minimum investment of £500, incur no charges in the first tax year and an annual management fee of 1 per cent after that.

fields.headline: Building societies to link up
fields.trailText: Building societies intend to form a branch-sharing network that will allow customers to use the facilities of any building society branch in the country free of charge
fields.body:
Building societies intend to form a branch-sharing network that will allow customers to use the facilities of any building society branch in the country free of charge. This would rival the Link system, which connects all bank cash machines.

Yorkshire Building Society is behind the plan, which came out of its recent strategic review.

It says a network will give building societies strength in numbers and set them 'further apart from banks'. It also believes the network will improve service and benefits to members by giving them easier access to their accounts.

Yorkshire has written to all of the UK's 67 building societies asking them to join the scheme and says it has received 'positive responses' from more than half.

The building societies have agreed to join in principle but will not sign on the dotted line until they see the details of how the scheme will work.

Yorkshire says the network will allow customers to perform basic transactions such as deposits and withdrawals at no extra charge. But building societies will not be promoting and selling each other's products under the scheme.

Yorkshire agreed an initial link-up with fellow society Britannia in August. From early next year, customers of the Britannia and Yorkshire will be able to use branches of either society across the country. The two societies, the second and third largest in the country after Nationwide, have 322 branches and 4 million members.

Britannia spokesman David Ginnivan says: 'We are happy to see as many building societies as possible show as much interest as possible so that we can be united behind mutuality.'

The proposals come at a time when banks have been under fire over sweeping branch closures, and smaller building societies have come under pressure to merge in order to survive.

A total of 10 building societies have converted into mortgage banks in the past 10 years, according to the Building Societies' Association.

webTitle: Bosses need to regain control from assessors

fields.headline: The 'quality' you can't feel
fields.standfirst: The universally used ISO 9000 standard is failing to improve business.  John Seddon  on why bosses need to regain control from assessors
fields.trailText: The universally used ISO 9000 standard is failing to improve business. John Seddon on why bosses need to regain control from assessors
fields.body:
ISO 9000 is everywhere. Drive on any motorway and you notice the 'quality assured to ISO 9000' logos on commercial vehicles. Managers in both private and public sectors know that achieving this standard it is a requirement for doing business with many customers.

But is ISO 9000 improving the way organisations serve their customers - or is it a disease in the fabric of our industrial society? It was 1979 when Margaret Thatcher pushed the button that began the spread of the ISO 9000 phenomenon. In the interests of 'improving' British management she was persuaded that an approach used by the military and power generators would have value.

For the previous 20 years the UK had experienced problems with munitions production, power generation and, in fact, all its new technologies. These were tackled by the introduction of the British Standard BSD 5750, which required organisations to specify how they worked, write that down and prove it to an inspector. For the first time we had a standard that was concerned not with what was made but how it was made - that is, a management, not a product standard.

As a method of management, BS 5750 appeared to solve the problems of the time - bombs stopped going off in factories - but did the organisations improve? Did they make better bombs? Had they solved the problems or merely controlled them?

US Navy chief Admiral Hyman Rickover had similar concerns about the management of the navy's error-strewn nuclear programme. His diagnosis was that decision-making had become separated from work. Managers were removed physically and mentally from it, relying on paper reports for information about what was going on.

He could see that the 'inspection and control' movement was a central part of the problem. But by then the 'quality' institutions were established. 1979 was their watershed for worldwide promulgation. Market-place coercion - 'you comply or we won't buy' - led to the rapid adoption of this 'quality manage ment' standard. In 1987, the British Government persuaded the International Standards Organisation to adopt it as an international standard. The infrastructure of consultants, assessors and quality managers now pervades organisational life on an international scale.

The tragedy is that far from being a force for improvement, this British invention is bad for business. It makes people do things that make them worse and stops them doing things that would make them better.

Rickover was right. ISO 9000 is not improving organisations because it is based on bad theory. Underlying it are concepts of specification and control, rather than those of understanding and improvement, which are the heart of real quality. Customers will recognise that ISO 9000 has led our organisations to focus on procedures rather than service; managers point to the excessive bureaucracy and work whose only purpose is to satisfy the ISO 9000 assessor.

What had happened was that Government Ministers and managers had persuaded themselves that this standard for 'quality assurance' was akin to the 'Japanese miracle'. After eager visits to Japan, they copied the things they saw - quality circles and suggestion schemes. But it was what they didn't see that mattered, a different way of thinking about the design and management of work. These and principles and methods behind the 'miracle' were based on managing the organisation as a system, and the cornerstone was the integration of decision-making with work - something anathema to ISO 9000's traditions.

The Japanese, coerced into registering to ISO 9000, complain that it has been undermining world-class thinking. This year Toyota Japan has declared it will not use ISO 9000. Now the standard is being revised. After a five-year review, December this year will see the publication of ISO 9000: 2000, claimed as 'an improvement'. Already, the growth of registrations to ISO 9000 is diminishing in those countries where ISO 9000 has been well-established. In countries that follow rather than lead, the rate of new registrations continues apace.

The 2000 review was heralded with an admission that people had problems interpreting it and with value for money. But while the new standard has some new language, its underlying philosophy remains unchanged. The requirements for documentation remain; management is conceptualised as an arm's-length activity.

The new ISO 9000 maintains a philosophy of planning and control, whereas we should be encouraging managers to learn about the 'what and why' of current performance as the basis for learning rather than control. When managers do learn how to understand the 'what and why' of current performance they discover for themselves just how much their registration to ISO 9000 is hindering rather than improving performance.

If I were Stephen Byers I would tell managers to desist. If managers are to learn and improve, the focus of control of their learning should be with them, the learners, not assessors and standard-setters. I would tell managers to do just one thing - the thing that Taiichi Ohno did in the Toyota Production System all those years ago: get an understanding of the 'what and why' of the organisation's performance as a system, for this will teach them how to improve it. If and when managers do, they will wrest control of their organisations from the 'quality' movement. This would achieve more for British management than anything government has done in the last 25 years.

 John Seddon is the author of 'The Case Against ISO 9000', Oak Tree Press.

webTitle: Supermarkets: Loyalty, but only up to a point for borrowers

fields.headline: Loyalty, but only up to a point for borrowers
fields.standfirst: Sainsbury's and Tesco stack up fairly well in the credit stakes
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's and Tesco stack up fairly well in the credit stakes.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's and Tesco may no longer offer savers market-leading rates, but do they - and some of the other supermarkets - give a good deal to borrowers?

The main attraction for customers of Budgens, Morrisons, Sainsbury and Tesco is that taking out your favourite supermarket's credit card increases the number of loyalty points you earn if you use the card to pay for your shopping.

This is also true of the Advantage Visa card recently issued by their high-street rival in toiletries and drugs, Boots.

But for people running a debt, there is no attraction in a Budgens card, since it offers no introductory incentives and standard rates (see table on page 4) that are higher than those charged by some high street banks.

The Morrisons credit card does at least offer better rates to new customers, but they could hardly be described as competitive.

Only Boots can match the zero per cent that is charged on new purchases by Capital One Bank (0800 952 5252) and Egg (www.egg.com). But for debt transfers, the cards from Boots, Sainsbury and Tesco offer better rates than the 7.9 per cent charged by Capital One.

The Boots Advantage Visa, even beats the 2.5 per cent charged by Egg (which 'powers' the Boots card) for balances transferred within six months of the card being issued. Sainsbury's introductory rate of 7.5 per cent for cash withdrawals looks good compared with other supermarket cards - and it's likely to be cheaper than withdrawing cash on a bank overdraft.

But even lower teaser rates for cash are available from the Halifax (0800 389 6000), Lombard Direct (0800 215 000) and Nationwide (0500 302 011).

Tesco may have lost ground to more competitive credit card rivals, but where personal loans are concerned it is up there with the market leaders.

According to Moneyfacts, on a £5,000 loan repaid over three years, its monthly repayment of £161.13 without creditor insurance is second only to the £159.05 a month that the same loan would cost with Northern Rock (0845 605 0808). For more details of Tesco loans, call 0845 600 6016 or go to www.tesco.com/finance.

With a monthly figure of £162.25, the total cost of a loan from Sainsbury is 40 more than the one from Tesco, enough to keep it out of the Moneyfacts best buys. Sainsbury is more competitive than the first retailer-led financial institution, Marks & Spencer Financial Services, where a similar loan costs £166.53 a month.

However, once you include the cost of insurance in the loan repayments, neither Sainsbury's nor Tesco offers particularly good deals.

And in charging £182.11 and £181.21 a month respectively, they are more expensive than the £169.95 from Intelligent Finance (0845 609 4343) which over the life of the loan makes a difference of at least £400.

In comparison with the 7.74 per cent standard variable rate (SVR) that a lot of high-street lenders charge mortgage customers, Sainsbury's SVR of 6.95 per cent on its flexible Options Mortgage (0500 700 600) is a good deal.

But even with the discounted rate of 5.95 per cent for the first six months of a new loan, the Sainsbury's deal is not as good as the flexible mortgages with rates of: 6.35 per cent from Scarborough Direct (01723 355 111); 6.39 per cent from Hinckley & Rugby Building Society (0800 774 499); and 6.6 per cent from Coventry (0845 766 5522).

These lenders' deals are also better than Sainsbury's two fixed-rate mortgages, and the 'extra special offers' that are now available through Tesco.

Tesco does not sell own-brand mortgages. Instead, it provides a mortgage finder service on its website (www.tesco.com/finance).

This aims to find the best deal from 400 products, including deals exclusively available to Tesco.

But with the exception of the mortgage from the Yorkshire, which fixes the interest rate at 5.79 per cent for two years followed by a variable rate of 6.74 per cent, none of Tesco's other special offers provided better value than standard deals from Sainsbury's.

webTitle: Supermarkets: Checking out cover at the check out

fields.headline: Checking out cover at the check out
fields.standfirst: Shop around to make sure you don't pay over the odds
fields.trailText: Shop around to make sure you don't pay over the odds.
fields.body:
While the supermarkets can be consistently good value for savings, particularly large sums, in insurance their performance is more hit and miss.

An example is mortgage payment protection insurance, which is designed to cover mortgage payments if your earnings dry up as a result of illness or unemployment. Sainsbury's Mortgage Payment Sure policy costs£6.01 a month for every £100 of cover, so insuring a regular mortgage payment of £500 would add £30.05 to your monthly outgoings. This compares with a market average of £5.50 per £100 of cover, and is one-and-a- half times as much as the same cover from the new entrant, Marks & Spencer (0800 363 448), which charges £4. An even cheaper alternative is to buy over the internet from www.securityfirst.co.uk, where this sort of insurance costs only £3.75 per £100.

Life cover

Marks & Spencer also undercuts mortgage lenders in the field of life insurance. But although the company still offers cheaper policies than most high-street lenders, it can't quite keep up with the highly competitive premiums from Tesco. According to Moneyfacts Life and Pensions, for a 35-year-old non-smoking man wanting £100,000 of cover over 20 years the £9.74 a month he would pay Tesco (0845 845 1477) is the lowest premium on the market. A non-smoking woman of the same age would pay Tesco £8.82, which is less than the £9.55 Marks & Spencer (0800 363 422) charges but not quite as good as the £8.40 premium on offer from Scottish Widows (0345 678 910). However, in charging a man £18.56 and a woman £14.45, Tesco is not as good value for 35-year-old smokers, who would do better turning to Equitable Life (0870 900 8020), where he and she pay £13.55 and £10.17 respectively.

Home and contents

Sainsbury's doesn't stock life insurance, but in common with Marks & Spencer and Tesco, it does sell both buildings and house contents insurance. It is impossible to say whether they will definitely give a good deal because so much depends on personal circumstances. But the quotes these retailers supplied to Cash - which were compared with figures from independent broker Charcol (0800 939 393) - suggest that it would be worth adding them to your list of companies to contact next time your house insur ance comes up for renewal.

Quotes were based on a policy without accidental damage or all-risks cover for a couple of 40-year-old teachers living in a three-bedroom turn-of-the-century terraced house with a rebuilding cost of £100,000 and contents worth £30,000. Figures were given for three different postcodes and assume the house is fitted with British Standard door and window locks but no burglar alarm.

In all postcodes, Tesco (0845 300 6600) gave the lowest quote for buildings insurance. Sainsbury's (0500 301 030) was cheapest for contents at the medium-risk address but Charcol gave the most competitive contents quotes for the low- and high-risk postcodes.

Marks & Spencer didn't do that well on price but is worth investigating for what it describes as its market-beating unlimited cover. Of most interest is the company's claim that, with the exception of personal money, the policy does not place a maximum on what it will pay out in the event of a claim - on condition that you tell M&S about any single item worth £4,000 or more when you apply for the insurance (0800 389 9988 or go to www.marksandspencer.com).

Car

It's also worth getting a quote from Tesco if it's time to renew your car insurance (0845 300 4400 or go to www.tesco.com/finance). Although it is not always competitive, it did provide some of the lowest premiums for a notional 1998 Ford Mondeo driven by a 40-year-old couple with six claim-free years.

Travel

Asda, Boots, Sainsbury's and Tesco are right to claim that their travel insurance is cheaper than travel agents and tour operators. But they charge maybe twice as much as specialist travel insurers such as Direct Travel (01903 812345 or go to www.direct-travel.co.uk), Options (0870 848 00870), TravelPlan Direct (0800 018 8747) and Worldwide Travel (01892 833 338), all of which featured as best buys in a recent survey by Which? magazine.

The exception to this is the Asda for Travel annual worldwide policy from Asda (08000 646688 or go to www.asdafortravel.com). The prices of £57.95 for a single adult, £74.95 for a single parent, £78.95 for a couple and £91.95 for a family compare favourably with policies from independent insurers. Asda's price is particularly good value if you are over 65. Boots doubles the premium for this age group, while Sainsbury's and Tesco add an age-related loading that depends on individual circumstances. Asda does not charge extra until age 70.

Pets

You buy pet food from supermarkets, so why not pet insurance? If you want this kind of cover (which helps only with unexpected vet's bills, not routine treatment), Tesco's rates, which start at £4 a month for cats and £7 for dogs, cost less than the £6.99 and £8.99 charged by Sainsbury's.

Tesco (0845 300 2200) also gives slightly better cover. An alternative, which costs slightly more than Tesco for cats but less for dogs, is to take out an RSPCA Pet Insurance policy (0870 444 3127 or www.rspca.org.uk). In the first year 5 per cent of the monthly premium is donated to the RSPCA.

webTitle: Online banks pray for rising interest

fields.headline: Online banks pray for rising interest
fields.standfirst: Web companies believe more customers will turn to them, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Web companies believe more customers will turn to them, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
From the amount of money spent on advertising financial websites, you could be forgiven for thinking it was the most popular way of conducting your financial transactions.

But new research has produced mixed messages about the state of internet banking. While online bank account holders have doubled in the past year, only a quarter of customers are happy with the service.

Cahoot, Abbey National's standalone internet operation, has attracted just 70,000 customers so far, and rival Egg recently saw a large chunk of money disappear from its savings account when it cut interest rates.

Online share dealing also appears not to be living up to its early promise. Despite an initial explosion in online share dealing and lots of hype, online execution-only trades now account for just a quarter of such deals.

So are we still in love with the net? Or is the affair over already? Chris Rawlins, director of the British Bankers' Association (BBA), believes internet banking has not peaked yet.

By the end of 2000, a third of EU households will have access to the internet, rising to 55 per cent in three years, according to figures from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney - and that's just on PCs. With more platforms coming on the scene, such as Wap phones and interactive TV, even more people will have access to the web.

BBA believes the range of services offered by internet banks, and the low cost of using those services, will also boost the popularity of these banks. A Mori poll predicts that 30 per cent of bank customers will be using the internet by 2003.

But in the meantime BBA's Rawlins says some operations are suffering from the race to get something - anything - on the net as soon as possible. And dealing with new technology causes teething problems. The internet has been dubbed the 'world wide wait', because of protracted download times.

However, the industry is confident it can overcome these problems. Rawlins says the next challenge is to exploit the net to its full extent. 'Banks have to offer something different, as the Woolwich has, if they want "stickability", or the reten tion of customers.' He singles out the Woolwich for its open plan account, which allows customers to put money in virtual 'jam jars' so that they can move it around as they please.

Cahoot marketing director Tim Sawyer agrees that the internet is ultimately about service: 'The price is just an incentive to join.'

He stresses that the internet is a much more convenient way of banking than writing letters or making phone calls. Sawyer points to Cahoot's credit card facility as an example of where the internet comes into its own. Customers can 'design' a card by deciding whether they want to pay a monthly fee or an interest rate. Next on the horizon is a 'highly flexible' unsecured loan.

But Sawyer agrees with Rawlins that the internet has come out of its honeymoon period. He says: 'A lot of the froth has been blown away. But the fact remains that the internet is a cost-effective way of banking, therefore it will see steady growth. It is a question of how quickly it will grow rather than if.'

A new system being piloted by the Association for Payment Clearing Services should encourage growth. Widely available at the end of next year, it will make it easier to transfer your bank details from one account to another using electronic rather than paper means.

As for other future trends, Egg marketing director Andrew Firth says he will be interested to see whether customers stick with their original banks, who tend to offer traditional products online, or transfer to a brand such as Egg, which 'tries to offer something different'. He puts Egg's loss of funds from its savings account - £443m since flotation - down to the the antics of so-called silver surfers, senior citizens who have become adept at seeking out the best online deals. Egg is keen to point out that it only lost 20,000 out of 2 million customers. They just happened to take some bumper balances with them.

Firth sees the growth of internet banking continuing unabated as people become accustomed to internet culture and further distribution channels open up.

However, the experts agree that people will not forsake their phones entirely. They rely on call centres to deal with problems and give out more detailed information. The online share dealing industry has also not managed to extricate people from their phones.

Stocktrade spokesman Carolyn Abbott says the majority of its clients are still happier dealing over the phone. Many online dealers tend to run a telephone service in tandem to their internet offering.

The Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers says a quarter of execution-only trades are now done online. This may not sound much, but it is up from one in a thousand in 1998.

Analyst Compeer says: 'It has been a relatively flat quarter, but the market has been static generally. We believe that growth will continue - but steadily. We won't experience the explosion that was felt at the beginning of the year.'

It says online share dealing will continue to grow despite limiting factors such as stamp duty, because it is cheaper than using the phone, and there are easy links to research and other information. The market will also benefit from the increase in prosperity and growing awareness of the need for self-provision.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ...avoid suffering from stress
fields.trailText: ...avoid suffering from stress
fields.body:
1 Accept that many people deliberately stay in stressful situations because they are too scared to act on their own initiative and get out. If you feel a victim to your circumstances but you also know that you could get another job, then you should accept that you are currently prolonging your own discomfort. In Victorian days there was little escape for exhausted housemaids but you can now carve out your own destiny if you hate your job and your boss.

2 Think about what you really want from life, says Dr Malcolm VanDenBurg who runs stress workshops under the banner Positive Under Pressure: 'Once someone knows what they want from life then difficult decisions become easier to make.' Many people thrive on a high level of achievement in life but even they will benefit from quieter periods.

3 Take some form of relaxation each day, advises VanDenBurg, even if this is just two 10-minute slots of yoga or self-hypnosis (activities that are easy to learn and perform). Not only do these pursuits help lower the blood pressure and create other healthy effects, but they also give you a sense of perspective. Tax assistant Shareen Brooksbank has massage sessions three lunchtimes a week: 'You put things in perspective, it's a way of escaping from work.'

4 Ensure that you have regular breaks if you work in a stressful job. Under the law of diminishing returns, you will get angrier and less productive if you are a taxi driver forced to work in traffic jams for seven hours without respite. But if you take a cup of tea with other drivers, you will find that their bad stories or jokes will ease your tension. Stress is caused by tension: it is very difficult to experience stress if you are relaxed.

5 Increase your resources if you are under pressure. Karen Roughly, a PA for Prime Time Recruitment in Northampton, creates more time for herself by using 'to do' lists and always planning ahead: 'If I didn't plan ahead I would feel stressed and not in control.'

Lack of short-term control, be it caused by inefficient bosses, difficult deadlines or anything else, is a common factor in stress. If a lazy or difficult colleague is causing you grief, recognise that they are limiting your effectiveness, creativity and other resources. Try to find a way to deal with the situation rather than letting it drain your vitality.
